3pineapple-weed-flowers

These small, rounded, stalked, cone-shaped, yellow-green flower heads, set in a greenish cup composed of interlocking bracts, consist of many tiny but distinct disk flowers bunched together. Along with the pineapple scent (not shown), and the finely divided leaves, and the lack of ray flowers, they make this small plant easy to recognize.
Pokeweed
pokeweed
Family: Phytolaccaceae, the pokeweed family
The shoots are in season in mid-spring, and the berries, for medicinal purposes only, ripen in the fall.
Partially shaded habitats or full sun, disturbed habitats, roadsides, meadows, fields, pastures, open woods, edge habitats.
Eastern US, the West Coast and all the southern states.
Eastern North America

Look for a plant with medium-sized, toothless, oval, alternate leaves, a purple-tinged, stout, upright, branched stem, and drooping racemes with either medium-sized, white, five-parted flowers, or dark purple, slightly indented berries.

This large, stout, smooth, widely branching, purple-tinged, native perennial grows from four to nine feet tall, and dies to the ground in the winter, leaving a whitish skeleton that overwinters.

In mid-early spring, the young, reddish-tinged, stout, unbranched shoot grows to about one inch thick. The oval, toothless, alternate leaves wrap around the stem and point upward at first.

Later in the spring, the elliptical, entire, stalked, alternate, emerald-green leaves grow form eight to 12 inches long, and 2.5 to five inches wide. They're sometimes mottled by a plant mosaic virus.

Growing on drooping, six to eight inch long, terminal racemes, the stalked, radially-symmetrical flowers grow to about 0.5 inch across, each with a green central ovary, ten stamens, and five petal-like white sepals, but no true petals. They bloom from summer to fall.

After the sepals fall off in late summer or fall, the ovary enlarges and becomes a shiny, dark, purple, juicy, stalked, spherical berry 0.33 inch across, composed of five to 12 segments fused into a ring. Each berry, filled with tiny, hard seeds, is indented on both ends, as though poked. The magenta raceme droops with the weight of the berries.

The fleshy, light tan, perennial taproot can become enormous over the years.

•Stout, reddish, upright shoot with medium-sized, alternate, entire, elliptical leaves, in mid-spring
•Large, broadly branching herbaceous plant with curved racemes of small flowers
•Flower with a green, central, button-like ovary surrounded by five white, petal-like sepals
•Drooping, magenta raceme of purple, stalked berries
•Spherical berry slightly indented at the tip, containing several small, hard seeds
•Very large, light tan taproot

Break or cut off the shoots no taller than ten inches with your hands, in mid-spring only. Be absolutely certain that you haven't accidentally harvested any pieces of the poisonous taproots! Collect only in the spring. Avoid any plants beginning to flower, which will be much larger than ten inches anyway.

Collect the berries for medicinal purposes when they're dark purple and juicy, from mid-summer through fall.

The puffer fish (Tetraodontidae spp.) of the vegetable kingdom, this plant has an indescribably delicious flavor if prepared properly, deadly if not. But it's easy to prepare pokeweed properly: Set up two pots of rapidly boiling water, a medium-sized cooking pot and a larger reserve pot. Never use cold water.

Rinse the pokeweed shoots and chop into bite-sized pieces. Boil 1 minute in the medium-sized pot, drain in a colander, return to the cooking pot, cover with more boiling water from the reserve pot, boil another minute, drain again, return to the cooking pot, pour in more boiling water, and boil until the pokeweed's been boiled for a total of 15 to 20 minutes. This is necessary to be sure you've removed all the poisons, which are water-soluble. Drain thoroughly in a colander, pressing the pokeweed against the colander's sides with a large wooden- or slotted spoon, so it isn't soggy.

Although you could certainly serve this boiled pokeweed with a dash of olive oil plus salt and pepper to taste, it's especially delicious with more seasonings. For example, you could lightly sauté some chopped garlic in olive oil until lightly browned (be carefully not to overcook the garlic, or it will become very bitter) and stir that into the drained, hot pokeweed, along with some tamari soy sauce (the high-quality soy sauce sold in health food stores). Or choose a different oil and matching seasonings from any of the world's many great cuisines.

You can also add the boiled pokeweed, seasoned or unseasoned, to any variety of vegetable recipes or entrées—soups, stews, grain dishes, ethnic dishes, or others.

Pokeweed is a great source of vitamin A, a fat-soluble vitamin that's not destroyed by boiling. It also contains vitamins B1, B2, B3, and C, plus the minerals calcium, phosphorus, and iron, but these are probably dissipated by the necessary boiling.

Although none of the hundreds of people attending my tours every year since 1982 has ever gotten sick from eating this plant prepared according to my directions, this is still not a plant for unsupervised beginners. Pokeweed contains phytolaccatoxin and related triterpene saponins, an alkaloid called phytolaccin, plus histamines. Even if you don't know what these substances are, they can kill you: Poisoning causes burning of mouth and throat, salivation, severe stomach irritation, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, spasms, and convulsions. Without prompt medical attention, the accompanying severe dehydration can lead to death.

Never eat pokeweed raw, never eat the roots, flowers, or seeds; use only shoots no more than eight inches tall, during springtime only. Never eat pokeweed when it's in flower, or getting close to flowering, when the concentration of poisons skyrockets. Cook only as directed above. Make sure you don't accidentally include any pieces of the highly toxic root when you collect the shoots.

Although I know people from the Deep South, where people have been eating this wild food for centuries, who eat the new, young growth in the summer with no harm, there are reports to the contrary in the literature, so I've never taken this unnecessary risk myself, and strongly advise against it.

Although some people have reportedly gotten away with eating the berries (which aren't even supposed to be tasty), they're dangerous too, and should be avoided. Also, the seeds inside the berries are highly toxic.
Anyone who confuses the term poke sallet (an old English word for cooked vegetable) with poke salad is in for a surprise tour of the emergency room. This is not a food for people on a raw food diet!
Poke Sallet, Poke Root, American Nightshade, Cancer Jalap, Coakum, Garget, iInkberry, Pigeon Berry, Pocan Bush, Redweed, Scoke, Red Ink Plant, Chui Xu Shang Lu
The pufferfish and this plant can be either exceptionally delicious and healthful or a deadly poison, depending on when you harvest it, which parts you use, and how you prepare it.
Creamed Pokeweed
creamed-pokeweed

Smothered in a special vegan cream sauce, pokeweed simply can’t be beat.

9 cups young pokeweed shoots, chopped
1 14-oz. can of coconut milk
1/4 cup sesame oil
1/2 tsp. cloves, ground
1/4 cup arrowroot or kudzu
1/4 cup mellow miso (available in health food stores)
1-1/2 tbs. fresh basil
2 tsp. turmeric
1 tsp. powdered commercial or ground wild ginger, or 1 tbs. fresh commercial or wild ginger
4 common spicebush berries, or 1 tsp. allspice, ground
1 tsp. coriander, ground
1/8 tsp. Cayenne hot pepper, or to taste

1. Boil the pokeweed in 2 changes of rapidly boiling water, 1 minute, 1 minute, and 15 minutes, as directed under "food uses."

2. Meanwhile, purée; the remaining ingredients in a blender.

3. Bring this sauce to a boil in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring constantly.

4. Reduce the heat to low and simmer the sauce, covered, 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

5. Drain the properly cooked pokeweed thoroughly, stir it into to the sauce, and simmer 3 minutes over low heat, stirring occasionally.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 40 minutes

The small, stalked, white, five-sepaled flower, with a green, button-like, central ovary, grows on a drooping raceme from summer to fall, accompanied by the same leaves as the shoot.

The indented, shiny, dark purple berries grow on drooping, magenta racemes in the summer and fall.

The large, light tan taproot is perennial.

Entire, alternate, elliptical, stalked leaves on a stout, purple-tinged stem six t0 eight inches tall characterize pokeweed shoots when they're suitable for cooking.

Poor Man's Pepper
poor-mans-pepper
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family
Early spring to late fall.
Sunny habitats, lawns, gardens, parks, disturbed habitats, fields, meadows, roadsides.
Throughout the US plus eastern and western Canada.
Europe

In early spring and fall, look for basal rosettes of deeply lobed or toothed leaves with no colored sap and sharp teeth mostly pointing toward the leaf tip. From mid-spring to fall, look for a medium-sized plant with flower and seed stalks resembling bottle brushes, tiny, white, four-petaled flowers, and small, flat, nearly circular, very slightly notched seedpods.

This small to medium-sized, spicy-flavored, exotic annual grows six inches to three feet tall, beginning with a basal rosette in early spring. The narrow, stalked, lobed basal leaves grow two to five inches long. The basal leaves soon exchange their lobes for deep, sharp teeth that usually point toward the leaf tips. The rosette disappears when the plant flowers, so people who recognize it at one stage often have to re-learn what it looks in its other form.

Resembling a bottle brush, a long, wiry, branching flower stalk grows from the rosette's center from mid-spring to fall, with similar but smaller alternate, linear to lance-shaped, toothed leaves, tapering toward the base. There's usually no leaf stalk.

From spring to fall, many tiny, short-stalked flowers 0.125 inch across, each with four white petals configured like a cross (typical of the mustard family), bloom at the tips of the branches, on racemes. In the summer and fall, they’re replaced from the bottom up by many small, flat, circular-to-ovate, short-stalked seed pods, very slightly notched at the tips, growing 0.125 inch across. Tiny yellow-brown seeds fall out as the plant dies and the seed pods turn white. This white skeleton often persists into the winter.

There's no colored sap when you break open the plant, which has a short, slender, white taproot.

•Basal rosette of lobed or toothed leaves, no colored sap
•Teeth on all leaves pointing mostly toward the leaves' tips
•Bottle brush-like branched flower stalk up to three feet high
•Tiny, white, four-petaled flowers on racemes
•Small, flat, nearly circular to ovate seed pods, slightly notched at the tips

Although you can certainly tear off the basal leaves with your fingers, it's much more effective to sweep a pocket knife under the rosette to sever the root and gain the entire rosette. Then you can shake off the debris and bag the plant.

Strip off the leaves, seed pods, and flowers (the wiry stem is too tough to eat) with any tender parts of the stem's top. This is easier if you proceed from the top to the bottom of the stem.

Poor man's pepper is one of the best-tasting mustards around, with a peppery flavor (what else would you expect?) a little like radish, horseradish, and wasabe. The chopped leaves, as well as the seeds and flowers, are great added raw to salads and sandwiches, or cooked for 10 minutes like any other greens, in soups, stews, casseroles, sauces, or virtually any savory dish, although they lose some of their pungency when you cook them.

You can even roll the chopped plant into a sheet of toasted nori (a seaweed available in health food or Asian grocery stores and health food stores) with cooked rice and vegetables, to make vegetarian sushi (don't forget to include a few pieces of a chopped vegetarian!)

The seeds are too small to use, but you can make prepared mustard with the seed pods. Cover them with a mild vinegar in a blender, and purée; with turmeric (for color) and garlic, plus mellow miso (available in health food stores) for texture. Other spices, such as those on label of your favorite prepared mustard, i.e., tarragon or lemon rind, are optional.

You could even eat the taproot, but it's too small to be worth it.
The leaves provide vitamin C, calcium, iron, and potassium.
This plant is usually too spicy for young children. (Older children, on the other hand, love tricking their friends into eating a large mouthful at once!)

This plant is in the mustard family, not related to pepper. It's sometimes called peppergrass, but this is its subgroup. Other similar edible peppergrasses include field pennycress (Thlaspi arvense) and field peppergrass or cow cress (L. campestre). They [both] have larger seed pods, and leaves that clasp the flower stalk.

Shepherd’s purse (Capsella bursa-pastoris), another edible relative, has leaves that clasp the stem, with lobes pointing outward no sharp teeth, plus heart-shaped rather than circular seedpods.

Unrelated dandelions (Taraxacum officinale), chicory (Cichorium intybus), and wild lettuce (Lactuca spp.), all edible, have white, milky sap, which poor man's pepper lacks, and their leaves' teeth never point toward the leaf tips.
Virginia Pepperweed, Peppergrass

In Columbus' day, long before refrigeration, food would often spoil. Rich people would use expensive black pepper, imported to Europe from India, to cover up the off flavor, and poor people would use locally available poor man's pepper.
Greater Ragweed, Field Pennycress, Field Peppergrass, Shepherd's Purse, Common Dandelion, Chicory, Wild lettuce
Poor Man's Pepper Sauté
poor-mans-pepper-sauté

Poor man’s pepper and spices make plain ol’ tofu anything but bland. Serve with whole grains or bread.

3 tbs. olive oil
2 14-oz. packages of soft tofu, drained and diced
1/3 cup poor man’s pepper leaves, chopped
2 tbs. Old Bay Seasoning
2 tbs. lemon juice
1/2 tsp. Vege-sal (available in health food stores) or seasoned salt

Sauté all ingredients in the olive oil for 10 minutes.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation/Cooking time: 15 minutes

The linear to lance-shaped leaves, with teeth pointing toward the leaf tips, and the tiny, white flowers on terminal racemes, above nearly circular, flat seeds, make this branching plant easy to recognize.

The lobes on this very young, early spring rosette point toward the leaf tips. Along with a lack of hairs or milky sap, they make it easier to distinguish poor man's pepper from similar plants.

As the basal rosette begins to produce a flower stalk, the lobes on these linear, pointed leaves transform into sharp teeth which point toward the leaf's tip.

The branching, wiry plant, with stalkless, linear, alternate leaves and a raceme of flat, nearly circular seed pods with small, white flowers on top, creates the impression of a bottle brush. The characteristic teeth on the leaves pointing toward the leaf tip, and the slight notch at the tip of each seed pods, clinches the plant's identity.
Purslane
purslane
Family: Portulacaceae, the purslane family
Late spring to early fall.
Sunny habitats, very poor soil, lawns, gardens, fields, meadows, and cracks in the sidewalk.
Throughout most North America.
Eurasia
Look for a prostrate plant with a thick, smooth, succulent, purple-red stem, and stalkless, paddle-shaped leaves, growing in sunny places with very poor soil.

This sprawling, smooth, thick succulent's purple-red stem grows four to ten inches long and up to six inches tall. With its fleshy, alternate or opposite, stalkless, toothless, paddle-shaped leaves, 0.5 to two inches long, it provides foragers everywhere with an abundant supply of tasty, nutritious food every summer.

Blooming from mid-summer to late summer, inconspicuous, tiny, yellow flowers only 0.2 inch wide, with five petals and two sepals, hide in the leaf axils or the tips of the branches, opening only on sunny mornings.

Ovoid fruit capsules replace the flowers in late summer. Up to 0.25 inch long, they split in half when they're ready to spill their tiny, hard, roundish, black seeds, each the size of poppy seeds,

Purslane's small taproot gives rise to many fibrous secondary roots.

•Sprawling succulent with thick, smooth, purple-red stems
•Small, fleshy, stalkless, paddle-shaped leaves
•Tiny, hidden, yellow flowers, opening only on sunny summer mornings
•Tiny ovoid fruit capsules splitting in half to release black seeds the size of poppy seeds.
Simply break off the stems and bag them with the leaves, discarding any especially thick stems if they appear somewhat woody. The seeds, although edible, are far too few and too small bothering with.

Chop the leaves and stems and add them, raw, to salads and sandwiches. The mild sweet-sour flavor and crunchy texture make purslane idea for virtually any cooking method, and great in any kind of vegetable dish or entrée;. It cooks in about 10 to 15 minutes.

Because it's mucilaginous, it will thicken soups, stews, and sauces the way okra does. You may even set aside the leaves, which would fall off, and pickle the stems.

One of the most nutritious foods on the planet, purslane provides vitamins A and C, some vitamin-complex B and carotenoids, plus the minerals magnesium, calcium, potassium, and iron. It also contains more omega-3 fatty acids, especially alpha-linolenic acid, than any other plant, and it's an excellent source of icosapentaenoic acid (EPA). Furthermore, it provides reddish betacyanins and the yellow betaxanthins, both of which have anti-mutagenic effects, and may lower the risk of cancer.

Purslane is used to treat infections or uro-genital bleeding, as well as dysentery, in traditional Chinese medicine. The fresh herb has also been applied topically for skin sores, and insect and snake bites. Eating it also greatly reduces the symptoms of oral lichen planus, an autoimmune disease of unknown causes that effects the mouth's mucus membranes.

Spurge (Euphorbia spp.) doesn't look very much like purslane. It does sprawl along the ground, but it has elliptical, not paddle-shaped leaves, the stem is wiry, not succulent, the flowers are white, and it exudes a sickly looking white sap when cut. But because it often grows side-by-side with purslane, this acrid poison could accidentally wind up in your bag if you're not wary.
Pussley, Verdolaga, Pigweed, and Little Hogweed

This common garden weed contains substances that could lower the risk of heart disease and cancer, it's loaded with vitamins, and it's very tasty. Widespread and easy to recognize, it grows in sandy, sunny habitats, and it's around from late spring to early fall.
Chollas
Spotted Spurge
Purslane with Beets
purslane-with-beets

Purslane with Beets

Here’s a match made in heaven. As you can tell after your first bite, this Turkish-style purslane casserole can't be beet!

2-1/2 cups purslane, chopped
2 cups water
6 beets, sliced
1 small red onions, chopped
3 small tomatoes, chopped
3 cup beet greens, chopped
1/2 cup basmati brown rice
1/2 cup fresh parsley, chopped
2 tbs. fresh dill weed, chopped, or 2 tsp. dried dill weed, ground
3 tbs. olive oil
1 tbs. lemon juice
2 tsp. Vege-sal (available in health food stores) or seasoned salt, or to taste

1. Place the rice in an oiled casserole dish.

2. Mix together all the other ingredients and place on top of the rice.

3. Bake in a preheated 350 degree oven, covered, 75 to 90 minutes, or until the rice is tender.

Serves 6 to 8

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 75 to 90 minutes
1)Young Purslane
1young-purslane
The thick, smooth, succulent, sprawling, purple-red stem, and the stalkless, toothless, fleshy, paddle-shaped leaves, are all you need to see to recognize this distinctive plant.
2)Purslane Flower
2purslane-flower

You hardly ever see purslane's tiny, five-petaled, yellow flower, which only opens during sunny summer mornings. It grows in the axils of the small, smooth, stalkless, paddle-shaped, alternate leaves.
3)Purslane Fruit and Seeds
3purslane-fruit-and-seeds
The light green, ovoid fruit capsules split along the middle to release the many tiny, rounded, black seeds.
Red Clover
red-clover
Family: Fabaceae, the pea or legume family
The leaves are barely edible in early spring, while the flowers are at their peak in late spring, although you can still find a few good ones in the summer and fall.
Sunny places, meadows, pastures, open fields, roadsides, lawns, parks, disturbed habitats
Throughout most of North America
Eurasia

Look on lawns and in meadows for the familiar, medium-sized, rounded flower heads composed of many tiny, narrow, two-sided magenta flowers, growing above a slender, branching flower stalk with alternate, three-parted, palmate compound leaves.

Usually upright, parts of this well-known plant, which grows from six to 24 inches tall, may also creep along the ground, producing stems and fibrous roots at nodes.

The alternate, palmate-compound leaves arise from a long, slender, branching downy stem. The three oval to elliptical leaflets, 0.5 to 0.25 inches long and half as wide, each marked with a V-shaped chevron, and as though folded in half with a central seam.

Up to 60 tiny, bilateral-symmetrical, magenta, pea-like flowers, which grow up to 0.5 inch long, are crowded onto rounded flower head one inch across, at the tops of the stems.

The seeds in the dry flower heads are very tiny and brown.

•Medium-sized herbaceous plant with alternate, three-parted, palmate-compound leaves growing on a slender stem
•Roundish, magenta flower head packed with many long, narrow flowers
•Oval to elliptical leaflets with a midrib running down the their length, creating a seam
•A V-shaped chevron on each leaflet
•Many tiny brown seeds

Pick the young leaves and the flower heads by hand. If you're using the flowers for tea, including a few mature leaves won't do any harm

The best time to collect the flowers is when the greatest number of plants have come into full flower at the same time, and most of the flowers are brightly colored, usually in late spring. Collect only the most attractive-looking flower heads. These are the best. Avoid those that still include some immature, green flowers, and those with brown, withered flowers. They're terrible. Leave those for the health food stores, which sell brown dried herbs that must have been picked as they were going bad, since freshly dried herbs retain their color.

You can also pull the flowers off the flower heads with your fingers and add them (the flowers, not your finger!) raw, to salads. Or cook the flowers in virtually any dish that calls for vegetables. They cook in about 10 to 15 minutes. Although somewhat fibrous, they taste like sweet snap peas. I also like showering them, raw, onto ice cream, where they make colorful, sweet sprinkles.

You can also dehydrate them, grind them into powder in a blender in a blender, and use them to supplement the protein of whole grains in breads and muffins. This works for the completely brown, dry flower heads, which contain the seeds, too, although they're not as tasty as the flowers. Add the meal of either to whole-grain flour to use in breads, pancakes, and muffins.

Red clover infusion, made with the freshest flower heads along with a few of the leaves, has been popular since prehistoric times. You can add a few of the youngest leaves raw, to salads, although they're hard to digest. It's much better to cook them like other greens, for about 15 minutes. They're not one of my favorite vegetables, with a raw string bean/turnip flavor, but some people like them.
Red clover flower tea provides vitamins C, B1, B3, and E, plus the minerals calcium, chromium, magnesium, phosphorus, and potassium.
Eating too many mature leaves may cause a fatal disease called *the bloat,* but only if you're a cow!

White clover (T. repens), also edible, resembles red clover, but it's smaller, the flowers and leaves arise from separate stems, and the flowers are white, not magenta.

People confuse wood sorrel (Oxalis spp.) with clover, but this edible plant has heart-shaped, not oval leaves, and completely different flowers from any clover's.
Beebread, Cow Clover, Cow Grass, Meadow Clover, Purple Clover, Wild Clover, Meadow Honeysuckle, Meadow Trefoil, Trefoil, Broad Red, Cleaver Grass, Marl Grass

This familiar, common, widespread plant makes a superb, healthful tea, so long as you get very fresh, brightly colored flowers. You can also add the flowers to recipes, or dry and grind them, to make flower flour!
Red Clover in Flower
red-clover-in-flower

The magenta flower head of red clover, composed of many tiny, tubular flowers bunched together, grows atop a long, slender, downy, branching flower stalk. The palmate-compound leaves consist of three oval to elliptical leaflets divided in half by a midrib that runs down their lengths. Each leaflet is marked by a V-shaped chevron.
Red Clover Flower
red-clover-flower

The rounded flower head is composed of many tiny, narrow, two-sided magenta flowers. It grows above a slender, downy flower stalk that bears alternate, compound leaves consisting of three oval to elliptical leaflets, each marked with a V-shaped chevron.
Peachy Keen Ice Cream with Red Clover Sprinkles
peachy-keen-ice-cream-with-red-clover-sprinkles

Here’s a flavorful, creamy ice cream you can make with wild or commercial peaches, where my method of making vegan ice creams reaches perfection. And the red clover sprinkles give it a special touch.

3 wild or commercial peaches, chopped
3-1/2 cups soy-rice milk, oat milk, or nut milk
1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
1 tbs. agar
1/2 raw cup pignola or cashew nuts
1/4 cup lecithin granules (available in health food stores)
1/4 cup grape seed oil or canola oil
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin (available in health food stores)
1/4 cup flowers pulled off the flower heads of fresh red clovers

1. Simmer the peaches in the soy-rice milk with the arrowroot and agar 5 minutes or until the peaches are tender, stirring often.

2. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

3. Serve sprinkled with the red clover flowers

Makes 5-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 20

Freezing time: 120 minutes
White Clover
white-clover
Family: Fabaceae, the pea or legume family
The leaves are barely early in spring, while the flowers are at their peak in late spring, although you can still find a few good ones in the summer and fall.
Sunny places, meadows, pastures, open fields, roadsides, lawns, parks, disturbed habitats
Throughout most of North America
Europe
Look for a small plant with three leaflets and a small, spherical white flower head consisting of many tiny, tubular, two-sided flowers growing on a separate stem from the leaflets.

This low, Eurasian, spreading, herbaceous plant, four to 16 inches tall, creeps along the ground and roots at nodes. The root system is fibrous.

It bears a rounded, white flower head and three-parted palmate-compound leaves that are familiar to anyone who's ever ventured outdoors. The leaves come up on a separate stalk from the flower head. Oval to elliptical, the leaflets grow from about 0.5 to 1.25 inches in length, with a seam down their length. A V-shaped chevron marks each leaflet, and there's a tiny notch at the leaflet's tip.

20 to 40 tiny, long, narrow, bilaterally symmetrical flowers crowd onto the flower head, which grows above a long, slender, unbranched, leafless stem.

•Small herbaceous plant with alternate, three-parted, palmate-compound leaves
•Leaf growing on a slender stem separate from the flower's stem
•Oval to elliptical leaflets with a midrib running down the their length, creating a seam
•A V-shaped chevron on each leaflet
•A tiny notch at the tip of each leaflet
•Roundish, white flower head packed with many long, narrow flowers

Pick the young leaves and the flower heads by hand. If you're using the flowers for tea, including a few mature leaves won't do any harm.

The best time to collect the flowers is when the greatest number of plants are blooming at the same time and most of the flowers are brightly colored, usually in late spring. Collect only the most attractive-looking flower heads. These are the best. Avoid those that still include some immature, green florets, and those with brown, withered flowers, which taste terrible.

You can add a few of the youngest leaves, raw, to salads, but they're hard to digest. It's much better to cook them like other greens, for about 15 minutes. They're not one of my favorite vegetables, with a raw string bean/turnip flavor, but some people like them.

People have used an infusion of the flower heads since prehistoric times. Use only the whitest flower heads, which are the best quality. You can include a few leaves too.

You can also pull the flowers off the flower heads with your fingers and add them raw, to salads (the flowers, not your fingers!) Or cook the flowers in virtually any dish that calls for vegetables. They cook in about 10 to 15 minutes. Although somewhat fibrous, they taste like sweet snap peas. I also like showering them, raw, onto ice cream, where they make attractive, sweet, white sprinkles.

You can also dehydrate them, grind them into a powder in a blender, and use them to supplement the protein of whole grains in breads and muffins. This works for the completely brown, dry flower heads, which contain the seeds, too, although they're not as tasty as the flowers. Add the meal of the flowers, or the dried flower heads and seeds, to whole-grain flour to use in breads, pancakes, and muffins.
Various Native American tribes used an infusion of the flowers for fevers, coughs, and colds, although I'm skeptical about it's efficacy. An infusion of the flowers has even been used as an eyewash.

Red clover, also edible, resembles white clover, but this close relative is larger, the flowers and leaves arise from the same stems, and the flowers are magenta, not white.

People confuse wood sorrel (Oxalis spp.) with clover, but these edible plant has heart-shaped leaves and completely different flowers.
Creeping White Clover, Dutch Clover, Ladino Clover
Yellow Wood Sorrel, Red Clover
White Clover Flower
white-clover-flower
Tiny, long, two-sided flowers crowd together to make this rounded flower head growing on top of a slender, leafless stalk.
White Clover Leaf
white-clover-leaf
The three-parted palmate-compound leaf consists of three oval to elliptical leaflets, each with a seam running its length, a V-shaped chevron, and a tiny notch at the tip.
Miso Soup with White Clover
miso-soup-with-white-clover

Nori is a seaweed that’s formed into a papery sheet, familiar to anyone who’s eaten sushi. Here it replaces the traditional wakame seaweed in Japanese miso soup, and does a great job. My Vegan Fish Stock (yes, some fish really are vegans, especially the ones that read my Wild Vegan Cookbook) works perfectly here too. Finally, white clover flowers add a perfectly wild touch!

8 cups Vegan Fish Stock
1-1/3 cup soft tofu, finely chopped
1-1/3 cup Nori Krinkles (instant nori, available in health food stores)
1/4 cup white clover flowers, pulled from fresh flower heads
2/3 cup mellow miso

1. Simmer the tofu, nori flakes, and white clover flowers in the fish stock 10 minutes.

2. Lower a strainer into the soup and incorporate the miso by stirring it into the soup with a wooden spoon, or purée; it with some of the stock in a blender.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 10 minutes

Sheep Sorrel
sheep-sorrel
Family: Polygonaceae, the knotweed or smartweed family
Sheep sorrel is available from early spring to late fall, but it's at its best in the basal rosette stage, in early spring and fall.
Sunny lawns, fields, openings in the woods, trail sides, open fields, parks, roadsides, disturbed habitats, and acidic soil.
Throughout most of the US and Canada.
Europe

Look for a plant with basal rosettes of arrow-shaped, long-stalked leaves in early spring and fall, and racemes of the reddish-tinged, branching, flowering stems with small, alternate, arrow-shaped leaves in the summer.

This unique plant has mature leaves that resemble a sheep’s face—there’s a pointed nose at the tip, and two spreading ears (lobes) perpendicular to the arrow-shaped leaf’s broad base, although the very youngest leaves are oval. A papery sheath wraps around the stem adjacent to the leaf axils, typical of the knotweed family.

Spreading by rhizomes, this hairless European perennial, which also has a taproot, begins in early spring with a basal rosette with long-stalked leaves 1.5 to three inches long. New rosettes develop in the fall.

A slender, branched, deeply ridged, jointed stem 1.5 to nine (sometimes up to 18) inches tall, with much smaller, alternate, stalkless leaves that may be arrow-shaped or linear, grows in mid-spring.

Long, lacy, loosely branched racemes of tiny, yellow-green male flowers, plus tiny reddish female flowers, bloom on the upper stalks in late spring and early summer. Tiny, inconspicuous, reddish to yellow-brown fruits in papery wrappers also ripen in the summer.

•Long-stalked arrow-shaped basal leaves in early spring and fall
•Very young basal leaves oval to linear
•Branching stem in mid-spring and summer, with racemes of tiny, reddish flowers
•Leaves strongly lemon-flavored

The basal leaves are the best ones, although the stem leaves are edible too. Grab a bunch with one hand, hold down the leaf stalks with the other, and break off the leaves. You can also strip the leaves off the flower stalks with your fingers.

Sheep sorrel basal leaves have an intensely lemony flavor, much better than commercial garden sorrel (R. acetosa). People who try it say: "Not b...a...a..a...d!" It's so tasty, I eat it at every opportunity. The leaves on the stem aren't as good, and the flowers are unpleasantly bitter and astringent.

Use the leaves raw in salads and sandwiches. They're excellent in soups and stews, cooked about 10 minutes, but you can use them in any dish that calls for leafy vegetables. As with most strongly flavored ingredients, they complement mild, creamy ones, such as potatoes or squash. You can even bake them into bread, where their strong flavor won't get lost.
Sheep sorrel provides vitamins C, A, B-complex, D, E, K, P and U, plus the minerals calcium, phosphorus, magnesium, potassium, silicon, iron, sulfur, copper, iodine, manganese, and zinc.

Don't believe the inaccurate scare-literature that says sheep sorrel is dangerous because it contains oxalic acid. Unless you have kidney stones, it's no more hazardous than spinach, and people have been enjoying it in good health for thousands of years.

Bindweed (Convolvulus spp.) also has arrow-shaped leaves, but it's a vine, not an upright plant, and its large, funnel-shaped flowers look like its relative, morning glory (Ipomoea purpurea.)

Wood sorrel (Rumex spp.) also protects itself from non-human herbivores with a lemony flavor, but this unrelated edible has nothing else in common with sheep sorrel other than its flavor and name.
Red Sorrel, Sour Weed, and Field Sorrel
This common plant, with it's highly nutritious and very tasty arrow-shaped leaves that resemble a sheep's face, is not ba-a-a-d!
Field Bindweed, Yellow Wood Sorrel
1)Sheep Sorrel Basal Leaves and Stem
1sheep-sorrel-basal-leaves-and-stem

The arrow-shaped, long-stalked basal leaf resembles a sheep's face, with a nose-like tip and to ear-like lobes. The leaves on the stem are similar but smaller, with papery sheathes adjacent to the leaf axils. The raceme includes long clusters of tiny flowers.
2)Sheep Sorrel Young Basal Leaves
2sheep-sorrel-young-basal-leaves

The youngest of these long-stalked basal leaves are oval, whereas the older ones are arrow-shaped. This is what sheep sorrel looks like very early in the spring, before most other edibles have made their appearances.
3)Sheep Sorrel Flowers
3sheep-sorrel-flowers
Tiny yellow-green male flowers and equally small reddish male flowers grow on long, branching racemes.
Schav
schav

Since the leaf resembles a calf's face as much as a sheep's, this traditional Jewish soup, usually made with dairy products, is called shav, which means calf in Yiddish. Here's a vegan version without all the animal fat that tastes better than ever. It's great served hot on a cold day or cold on a hot day, so go ahead and try it—don't be sheepish!

8 cups vegetable stock
6 cups sheep sorrel or garden sorrel
2 medium red onions, finely-chopped
1 tbs. flax seeds, ground
1/2 tbs. Vege-sal (available in health food stores) or 3/4 tsp. salt, or to taste
1/4 tsp. black pepper, or to taste, ground
1 tbs. lemon juice
1 tbs. corn oil
1/2 tbs. lecithin granules
1 cup silken tofu, diced

1. Bring 3/4 of the stock, plus the sheep sorrel, onion, flax seeds, Vege-sal, and black pepper to a boil in a saucepan over medium heat, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, covered, 5 minutes.

2. Meanwhile, purée; the lemon juice, corn oil, and lecithin granules in a blender with the remaining stock.

3. Stir this the into the soup with the tofu, adjust the seasonings to taste, and add additional lemon juice if desired.

Serves 6

Cooking/preparation time: 30 minutes
Shepherd's Purse
shepherds-purse
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

The basal leaves are edible in early spring, and mid- to late fall, when new ones often come up.

The flower buds and flowers are available in mid-spring.
One of the first plants to colonize newly disturbed habitats, it grows in full sunlight or partial shade, along roadsides, and in fields, pastures, lawns, and parks.
Throughout most of North America.
Europe

Look for basal rosettes of blunt-lobed or toothed, lance-shaped leaves, with lobes facing outward, in early spring. In mid-spring, look for the addition of long, slender, branching stems with loosely configured, heart-shaped or triangular seed pods, plus tiny, four-petaled, white flowers on top.

Shepherd’s purse begins with a basal rosette of stalked, lobed to deeply toothed, lance-shaped leaves up to nine inches long, broader toward the tip, arising from a slender, white taproot. Unlike similar-looking rosettes, the leaves' lobes point outward, and there's no white, milky sap.

In mid-spring, long, wiry, erect flower stalks, branching from the base, grow from eight inches to 2.5 feet tall. Smaller, alternate, stalkless, lance-shaped or linear leaves, sometimes with tiny teeth, clasp the stems with two small, pointed lobes at their bases.

Growing on loose terminal racemes, tiny, stalked flowers, growing inside four green, oval sepals, have four white petals that form a cross, typical of the mustard family. Maturing from the bottom up, the flowers metamorphosize into long-stalked, flattened, heart-shaped to triangular, two-parted seed pods 0.25 inch long, with very tiny seeds inside.

•Basal rosette of lance-shaped, blunt-lobed or deeply toothed leaves
•Lobes pointing laterally
•Lobes larger toward the leaf's tip
•Slender, wiry stems up to 2.5 feet high, branching at the base
•Racemes of tiny, four-petaled, white flowers at the tops of the stems
•Loose racemes of small, heart-shaped to triangular seed pods
•Small, white, hairy taproot

While you can certainly grab handfuls of leaves, cutting the root just under the center of the rosette with a pocketknife gets you the entire rosette in a second, and while it's still intact, you can shake off most of the debris before bagging the plant. The basal leaves become tough after the stem appears, so get them very early in the spring, or in the fall when they often reappear.

I find this the most mild-tasting of all the mustards, good in salads, sandwiches, or cooked dishes that call for vegetables. They cook in 10 to 15 minutes. Include stronger-tasting vegetables, herbs, or spices, or your dish will taste too bland.

In season in mid-spring, the flowers, flower buds, and the top parts of the stems that are tender enough to pinch off, taste like broccoli, excellent in salads (cooking would probably drown out the flavor), but small enough that it's hardly worth my while to harvest, although it would make an excellent garnish. Kids invariably love collecting and eating these parts, and rarely leave any unpicked, even if they hate broccoli!

The seedpods are, in reality, as tasteless as my jokes- definitely not worth collecting!

The small, hairy root, albeit edible, also isn't worth the trouble to harvest and clean, much less chew!

Shepherd's purse leaves provide vitamins A, C, K, B1, B2, B3, choline, and inositol, plus the minerals include calcium, potassium, and phosphorus. They also contain fumaric acid, which may inhibit cancer, especially if you're a lab mouse (it hasn't been tested in humans yet!)

An infusion of the above-ground parts contains saponins, choline, acetylcholine, and tyramine. It's supposed to be astringent, anti-inflammatory, and diuretic, as well as hemostatic, but when I tried it on a paper cut, it had no effect on the bleeding, and didn't make me run behind a bush either!

Used during or after childbirth and to ease difficult menstruation, it's also supposed to constrict the blood vessels, lower blood pressure, and contract the uterus, but I haven't seen any science either verifying or disproving these claims.

Because of its possible effects on the blood, this plant is contraindicated for pregnant women.

Avoid all contact with the tiny, sticky seeds if you're a microscopic invertebrate. You'll get stuck to them, and be absorbed by the carnivorous plant embryo!

The common dandelion, wild lettuce, and chicory, all edible, have similar basal leaves, but the first 2 don't have lobes that point outward consistently, all 3 have white, milky sap, which shepherd's purse lacks, and the flowers and seeds are all very different from shepherd's purse's. Furthermore, chicory leaves usually have some red discoloration, plus some hairs on the underside of the leaf's midrib.

Poor man's pepper and its relatives the peppergrasses (Lepidium spp.), all edible, have basal leaves with no colored sap too, but their leaves are aren't lobed and blunt. The seeds are never heart-shaped or triangular. The teeth of poor man's pepper, for example, point toward the leaf's base, and it seeds are circular. The seeds of field pennycress are circular and notched, and the seedpods of field pepper grass (Lepidium campestre) are circular but not notched.
Mother's Heart, Pickpurse, Pickpocket, Lady's Purse, and Rattle Pouches
This common edible plant is unusual among the members of the mustard family because it's so mild-tasting. Nevertheless, it's common, widespread, and easy to ID.
Poor man's pepper, Field Pennycress, Field Peppergrass, Common Dandelion, Wild Lettuce, Chicory
1)Mature Shepherd's Purse
1mature-shepherds-purse

The blunt-lobed basal leaves, and the long, slender, branching stems with small, alternate, stalkless leaves, tiny clusters of white flowers, and triangular to heart-shaped seed pods, make this common, edible "weed" easy to recognize.
2)Shepherd's Purse Basal Rosette
2shepherds-purse-basal-rosette

4shepherds-purse-flowers-and-seeds
Due to the long leaf stalk, shepherd's purse's four-petaled, white flowers, and heart-shaped to triangular seed pods form much looser clusters than their short-stalked relatives.

Curried Bok Choy with Shepherd's Purse
curried-bok-choy-with-shepherds-purse

Chinese bok choy does great in an Indian context, with shepherd's purse leaves adding a wild touch.

1/4 cup peanut oil
2 tbs. dark sesame oil
3 cups bok choy leaves or other greens, chopped
1 cup shepherd's purse leaves, chopped
1 14-oz package of soft tofu, drained and diced

Sauce:

1-1/2 cups water
2 tbs. peanut butter
2 tbs. Steve's Curry Powder or commercial curry powder, or to taste
2 tbs. soy mayonnaise
2 tsp. arrowroot or kudzu (available in health food stores)
1 tbs. lemon juice

1. Purée; all sauce ingredients in a blender, or mix with a whisk.

2. Mix the oils together.

3. Successively stir-fry the bok choy with the shepherd's purse, then the tofu, in a wok or large frying pan, using half the oils at a time.

4. Add the sauce, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.

Serves 6

Prep/cooking time: 30 minutes

Common Blue Violet
common-blue-violet
Violaceae, the violet family

The leaves are edible from early- to mid-spring, before they get tough and coarse in late spring, although sometimes new tender leaves come up where the older ones were mowed, and occasionally, you can find a few new, young leaves coming up in late fall.

The edible flowers bloom in mid-spring.
Gardens, lawns, meadows, fields, parks, damp woodland openings, trail edges, near riverbanks, and along roadsides.
Eastern and much of central North America.

Look for dense stands of odorless, heart-shaped, shallow-toothed leaves, each arising from the ground on its own slender, hairless leaf stalk. In mid-spring, look for the addition of bilaterally symmetrical, medium-sized violet flowers with five petals—the lower three deeply veined, the side two bearded deep inside the flower.

This common, widespread, colonial plant’s only leaves are basal. Odorless, heart-shaped, hairless, shallow-toothed, they grow three to five inches long and as wide as they're long. Tightly curled at first, each leaf grows on top of a single, slender, hairless leafstalk three to eight inches high.

Barely taller than the leaves, each bilaterally symmetrical, scentless, violet-colored flower also arises from the ground on its own slender, hairless flower stalk. Of the five rounded petals, the two side ones are bearded with bushy stamens near the flower's throat, the three lower ones are deeply veined, and the lowest is slightly spurred. Hundreds of these colorful flowers, 0.75 to one inch across, fill meadows in mid-spring, arising from the branched rhizomes about 0.5 inches thick.

These showy springtime flowers are sterile, but in the fall, the fertile flowers—inconspicuous oblong, beige capsules about 0.5 inch long, hide at ground level. They self-fertilize, mature, and split lengthwise into three long, narrow troughs, to release a few dozen tiny, spherical seeds that look like ant eggs, translucent white at first, then dark brown when mature.

• Heart-shaped, shallow-toothed leaves three to five inches long and wide
• Each leaf arising from the ground on its own leaf stalk
•Bilaterally symmetrical, medium-sized five-petaled, violet flowers
•Each flower arising from the ground on its own flower stalk
•Prominent veins on the three lower petals
•Side petals bearded, deep inside the flower
•Small spur at the base of the lower petal
•Inconspicuous light brown flowers and fruits 0.5 inch long capsules, hidden at ground level
•Fruit capsule splitting into three long, narrow troughs containing tiny, spherical, dark brown seeds
•Entire plant odorless

In early- and mid-spring, hold down handfuls of plants with one hand, and pull off as many leaves and violet flowers as possible, with as little of the tougher flower and leaf stalks as possible. Other parts of the plant are not edible.

Violets have a mild, subtle, but quite enjoyable flavor—somewhat bland at first, but with a surprise bite as part of the aftertaste. They're excellent raw, in salads and sandwiches, and they're great as cooked greens, steamed and served with olive oil, salt, and pepper, or in any vegetable dish that calls for cooked greens. They make an excellent replacement for spinach, for example, and cook in about 10 minutes.
The leaves provide vitamin A and C, the flowers vitamin C.

Not much used by herbalists nowadays, a poultice of the leaves has been applied externally to relieve headaches and for boils, and an infusion of the leaves and flowers has been used for dysentery, constipation, coughs and colds, although I'm very skeptical about any of these uses actually working.

On the other hand, violets leaves contain genistein (also present in red clover), and isoflavone (a plant estrogen and anti-oxidant) that may lower the risk of cancer. Laboratory research shows that genistein alters the action of the genes that prostate cancer cells use to spread throughout the body, and research is underway to determine whether taking genistein benefits prostate cancer patients.

Eat only the young leaves in the spring or fall, and the violet flowers that bloom in the spring. Don't eat the rhizomes, which may cause nausea and vomiting, or the inconspicuous ground level fall flower, fruit, or seeds.

There are close to 80 similar edible violet-colored violet species in the US, and even the common blue violet is now considered a subspecies of a highly variable species that includes, among others, a subspecies with a white flower (V. sororia albiflora), and a very common hybrid of that subspecies with the blue form that results in a blue-and-white flower.

If that's not enough of a confusing factor for you, I don't know what is. My preference is to enjoy these violets and let the botanists who are paid to do so work out the differences.

Young garlic mustard's (Alliaria petiolata) edible leaves resemble violets', but they're rounded, not pointed. Unlike violets, they grow in a basal rosette before a tall stem with white, four-petaled flowers appear; their leaf margins are wavy, they're very deeply veined, and they smell like garlic when crushed.

Avoid violet species with yellow flowers, which may cause nausea and vomiting.

Don’t confuse the common blue violet with the poisonous larkspur (Delphinium tricorne), with a large, erect spur behind its violet colored, five-petaled flower, and leaves different from the violet's.

The poisonous monk’s hood (Aconitum uncinatum) also has a violet flower, different leaves, and an upper sepal covers two of its petals like a helmet.

Don’t eat the African violet (Saintpaulia spp.), a poisonous house plant that’s not a violet at all.
Common Meadow Violet, Purple Violet, Woolly Blue Violet, Hooded Violet and Wood Violet
Garlic Mustard
Round Leaf Yellow Violet
2)Common Blue Violet in Flower
2common-blue-violet-in-flower

The heart-shaped, shallow-toothed, basal leaves, along with the violet, five-petaled flower growing on a long, leafless, slender flower stalk, plus the flower's deep veins and white beard, make this common species unmistakable. The heart-shaped, toothed leaves, all basal, arise from the rhizome separately.
Scalloped Cauliflower with Violets
scalloped-cauliflower-with-violets

Here’s a simple, wonderful vegetable dish you can get into the oven in 10 minutes. Rich, tasty, nutritious, and filling, it’s ideal when you have a bagful of violets, and not much time to cook.

1 cauliflower, broken into florets
2 cups vegan cheddar cheese, grated
2 cups violet leaves, chopped
1.5 cups dried whole-grain bread crumbs
2 tbs. olive oil
1 tsp. rosemary, ground
1 tsp. tarragon, ground
1 tsp. thyme, ground
2 cloves of garlic, crushed
1 tsp. Vege-sal (available in health food stores), or seasoned salt

Stir all ingredients together, transfer to an oiled casserole dish and bake, uncovered, in a preheated 425 degree oven, 45 minutes, or until the cauliflower is tender and the cheese has melted.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 10

Baking time: 45 minutes
3)Violet Seeds and Fruit Capsule
3violet-seeds-and-fruit-capsule
Packed in rows inside the ovate fruit, these white, spherical seeds taste delicious, but only if you're an ant!
1)Violet Flower, Leaf, and Opened Fruit
1violet-flower,-leaf,-and-opened-fruit

The five-parted, bilaterally symmetrical flower, with deeply veins on the lower petal and a small spur behind, plus the long-stemmed, heart-shaped, shallow-toothed leaf, are easy to spot and recognize. However, you have to search along the ground for the three-parted fruit which appears in late summer and autumn.
4)Violet Fruit Skeleton
4violet-fruit-skeleton

The opened, three-parted fruit skeleton persists after the seeds have fallen out. If you look closely along the ground, you may even find it in the winter and locate your spring supply of violets in advance.
5)White Violet
5white-violet
Now considered the same species as the common blue violet, this subspecies (V. sororia albiflora), also edible, has white flowers substantially taller than the heart-shaped leaves.
6)Blue-and-White Violet
6blue-and-white-violet

This common hybrid of the common blue violet (V. sororia sororia) and the white violet (V. sororia albiflora) is just as tasty as its parent subspecies. Except for the color, the bilaterally symmetrical flower with a longer lower petal, and the beard inside the flower, are just like the parent subspecies'.
Wild Carrot
wild-carrot
Apiaceae or Umbelliferae, the umbellifers, or the parsley family

Taproot: Fall, winter (in very warm regions), and early spring

Seeds: Mid-summer through fall
Sunny, dry, sandy soil, open fields, meadows, roadsides, disturbed habitats, and pastures
Throughout most of North America
Europe

Wild carrots are good to eat in early spring, before the stored food gets dispersed into the above-ground parts, and then again in the fall, when food is again stored underground. You can also locate and dig up the roots during the winter in warm regions where the rosettes hang on and the ground doesn't freeze.

When I first began to forage, it seemed that the taproots were way to small to be worth harvesting. Then, after a few years, I discovered that they're quite large in sunny, sandy fields without grass competing for nutrients i.e., near the seashore. Not living in farm country, it only took me only another 28 years to learn that the roots also get very large in pastures, due to the fertilizing effect of the manure, and that's no BS (or maybe it is!)

Wild carrots are very easy to dig up with a shovel, especially where the soil is sandy or moist and there aren't many rocks. A trowel also also works. And in particularly sandy fields, like those near the seashore, you can sometimes harvest wild carrots in quantity by gripping the top of the taproot under the rosette firmly with two hands and pulling.

Break off the seed heads while the seeds are still somewhat green and use them fresh or dried.

Wild carrots are stronger-tasting than commercial carrots, though not as sweet. There's more carrot and less water, so they don't make much juice when put through a juicer, and they're somewhat tough in salads, but they're superb grated or sliced thinly and cooked, where they retain their texture and don't get mushy the way commercial carrots do. Use them in soups, stews, casseroles, carrot cakes, carrot puddings, and carrot cookies. They cook in 15 to 20 minutes, and they're way better than their wimpy domesticated descendants in such recipes.

Although the flowers and very young leaves are edible, they're somewhat bitter and not worth using, although some people do. The green or slightly brown seeds, on the other hand, make an excellent seasoning, similar to caraway and celery seeds. Use them fresh or dried, finely chopped or ground, in soups, stews, casseroles, or breads. They're exceptionally strong-flavored, so I usually use only one part wild carrot seeds in place of eight parts caraway or celery seeds!

Except for beta-carotene, present in commercial carrots but absent in wild carrots, which aren't orange, the nutrients in the two related subspecies include vitamins C, D, E, K, B1 and B6, as well as biotin, potassium, calcium, magnesium, phosphorus, organic sodium and some trace minerals.

According to research by Dr. Jim Duke (he's great—Google him and attend his tours if you ever get the opportunity), wild carrots provide acetone, acetyl-choline, alpha-linolenic-acid, alpha-pinene, alpha-tocopherol, apigenin, arachidonic-acid, arginine, asarone, ascorbic-acid, bergapten, beta-sitosterol, caffeic-acid, camphor, chlorogenic-acid, chlorophyll, chrysin, citral, citric-acid, coumarin, elemicin, esculetin, ethanol, eugenol, falcarinol, ferulic-acid, folacin, formic-acid, fructose, gamma-linolenic-acid, geraniol, glutamine, glycine, hcn, histidine, kaempferol, lecithin, limonene, linoleic-acid, lithium, lupeol, lutein, luteolin, lycopene, magnesium, manganese, methionine, mufa, myrcene, myricetin, myristicin, niacin, oleic-acid, pantothenic-acid, pectin, phenylalanine, potassium, psoralen, quercetin, scopoletin, stigmasterol, sucrose, terpinen-4-ol, thiamin, tryptophan, tyrosine, umbelliferone, xanthotoxin, and a slew of other vitamins and minerals. [-Also, they're good for you!]

Handling the leaves with sweaty skin, followed by exposure to sunlight, may cause contact phytophotodermatitis, resulting in a poison ivy-like rash. I've never seen this happen, so this well-documented problem must be uncommon.

The herb tea and root could cause uterine contractions, so pregnant women should avoid this plant.

And if you're digging up wild carrots in pastures, one of its best habitats, beware of bulls!

Yarrow (Achillea millefolium), a medicinal plant used for tea, has a narrow, once-divided compound leaf, and a composite flower head consisting of tightly clustered tiny individual flowers, each with a disk and rays. And its roots don't smell like carrots.

People are surprised to learn that Queen Anne's Lace and wild carrot are the same thing.

The very deadly relative, poison hemlock , with leaves and flowers similar to wild carrots, has purple-blotched, hollow stems without hairs (carrot stems are hairy and not spotted), and the taproot smells musty, like a dead mouse, not like a carrot.

Fool's parsley (Aethusa cynapium), a little less deadly than poison hemlock, also resembles the wild carrot, but this relative has a blue-flecked, hairless stem and a foul odor.

Other poisonous relatives of the wild carrots may pop up anywhere in the country, but none has a root that smells like carrots. Make certain all the characteristics of your plant matches the ones listed here, and be absolutely sure to scratch and sniff the root, the easiest verify the wild carrot's identity.
Queen Anne's Lace

The root of Queen Anne's Lace, when it's in the basal rosette stage, provides a fantastic, strong-flavored cooked vegetable, way better than commercial carrots. Just make sure the stems are hairy and the root smells like carrots or you could die!
Yarrow
Poison Hemlock
2)Wild Carrot Basal Rosette and Taproot
2wild-carrot-basal-rosette-and-taproot
The young wild carrot has feathery, twice or three times divided feather-compound leaves with hairy leaf stalks, plus a white taproot with some side branches.
5)Wild Carrot Flower (Queen Anne's Lace)
5wild-carrot-flower-queen-annes-lace

The wild carrot's flattened, lacy flower head consists of lots tiny, white flowers configured like an umbrella—an umbel. There's often a purple flower in the center, representing a drop of blood shed by Queen Anne after she pricked her finger while making the lace.
3)Wild Carrot Basal Leaves
3wild-carrot-basal-leaves

This basal rosette, with its long-stalked, oblong, twice or thrice-divided compound leaves and its hairy leafstalks, is what you look for in early spring or fall (also in the winter in warm regions) if you want to dig up wild carrots.
4)Wild Carrot in Flower
4wild-carrot-in-flower

The mature wild carrot has branching stems with alternate, two or three times compound leaves with hairy leaf stalks, plus flat-topped, terminal, white flower heads called Queen Anne's Lace, growing above three-parted bracts. The tiny individual flowers grow on flower stalks configured like umbrellas.
6)Wild Carrot Seed Head
6wild-carrot-seed-head

The wild carrot's terminal flower head curls up, like a bird's nest, as the tiny, bristly, ovate seeds mature, creating the impression of a bird's nest or hollow cup. The three-pronged bracts, characteristic of this species, persist beneath.
Creamy Wild Carrot Soup
creamy-wild-carrot-soup

Creamy Wild Carrot Soup

Here’s a very simple, flavorful soup based on wild carrots that you can whip up in minutes.

4-1/2 cups soy-rice milk, oat milk, or nut milk
3/4 cup vegan cheddar cheese, coarsely diced
3 cloves of garlic
3 tbs. mellow miso (available in health food stores)
3 tbs. lecithin granules (available in health food stores)
3 tbs. olive oil
1/2 tbs. sweet paprika
3/4 tsp. lemon thyme or thyme
1/2 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1/2 tsp. black pepper, ground
1/2 tsp. dill seeds
3 cups wild or commercial carrots, coarsely chopped

1. Purée; 3 cups of the soy-rice milk and all other ingredients except the carrots in a blender.

2. Pour half the purée; into a saucepan, add the carrots and remaining soy-rice milk to the blender, and chop briefly on low speed, until the carrots are finely chopped.

3. Add this to the saucepan, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring often, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 15 minutes, or until the carrots are tender.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Cooking time: 15 minutes
1)Wild Carrot Flower, Taproot, and Seed Head
1wild-carrot-flower,-taproot,-and-seed-head

The wild carrot's whitish taproot, which sometimes branches, is smaller than the commercial carrot's root. It gives rise to a basal rosette of long-stalked, lacy, two and three times divided, feather-compound leaves.

The flat-topped, terminal, umbrella-like flower head, and cup-shaped seed head, grow above long, narrow bracts, on a slender, erect, stem which is as distinctly hairy as leafstalks. The many tiny, five-petaled white flowers produce tiny, oblong, bristly seeds as the flower head contracts into what looks like a bird's nest.
Wild Lettuce
wild-lettuce
Family Asteraceae (Compositae), the astor or composite family
The basal leaves are only good very early in springtime, while the upper leaves and top of the stem are good in mid-spring.
Sunny or partially shaded moist habitats, sandy soil, thickets, disturbed soil, open woods, overgrown fields, lake borders, riverbanks, edges, roadsides, pastures, and fields
Most of the US except for Nevada and Utah, and most of southern Canada

In early spring, look for basal rosettes with shallow-toothed leaves that become deeply lobed, with a few hairs on the leaves' midribs' undersides, no prickles, and no woody remnants of a previous year's flower stalks connected to the rosettes.

In mid-spring, look for an unbranched stem with deeply lobed, alternate, stalkless leaves except for near the top, where the leaves are barely toothed and clasp the stem.

In the summer and fall, look for small, yellow, dandelion-like flowers on long, slender branches, as well as small, white, dandelion-like seed heads with small achenes sticking together.

This native annual or biennial looks completely different from commercial lettuce, but it's a close relative, and quite good if you get it when it's very young.

The basal leaves, five to ten inches long, usually wider at the base than at the tip, are bluntly lobed at first, then become deeply toothed. The leaf midrib is triangular in cross-section, and its underside has at least some fine hairs.

By mid-spring of its second year, or later in the first year if conditions are optimal, a stout, smooth, blue-green tinged, unbranched stem grows from four to ten feet tall. The stalkless, toothed, alternate leaves get ten inches long and three inches wide, sometimes with small, widely spaced teeth. The larger ones are deeply lobed, while the smaller upper ones have no lobes or shallow ones. Those near the top clasp the stem.

Pale yellow, sometimes orange-tinged, odorless, dandelion-like flower heads, 0.25 to 0.33 inch across, arise from slender, branching stalks toward the plant's top. Blooming from early summer to fall, they produce puffy, white, dandelion-like seed heads, again smaller than the dandelion's, often while some of the branches are still have buds or flowers. Attached to each other by slender beaks, the tiny, hard, dark brown achenes use tufts of white hairs for dispersion by the wind.

The root is a thick taproot. When cut, the whole plant exudes a white, milky, bitter sap that turns brown when it dries.

•A basal rosette of lobed or toothed leaves
•Some fine hairs on the underside of the leaf's midrib
•Leaf midrib triangular in cross section
•Deep, thick taproot
•White, milky sap throughout the plant, drying brown
•Stout, unbranched stem four to ten feet tall, beginning in mid-spring
•Stalkless, toothed, alternate leaves on the stem up to ten inches long and three inches wide, sometimes with small, widely spaced teeth
•Upper leaves clasping the stem
•Larger stem leaves deeply lobed, smaller ones with shallow lobes or none

The very young basal leaves are good in very early spring, before they develop lobes and become very bitter. While you can certainly grab handfuls of these leaves, cutting the root just under the center of the rosette with a pocket knife gets you the entire rosette in a second, and while it's still intact, you can shake off most of the debris before bagging the plant.

The tender upper part of the flower stalk and accompanying small, young leaves you find in mid-spring, before the flowers appear, are also quite good. Cut them with a pocket knife, clippers or scissors, or just break them off with your hands.

Wild lettuce's basal leaves taste like commercial lettuce, only stronger, with only a slightly bitter aftertaste if you harvest it early enough. The immature tops of the flower stalks and the youngest top leaves are just as good before the plant begins to flower.

Use wild lettuce sparingly in salads or sandwiches, or sauté it with herbs or spices before simmering it another 10 t0 15 minutes in a liquid, i.e., a sauce, soup, or stew, to counteract the concentration of bitterness that would otherwise occur as the leaves shrink.
Wild lettuce provides vitamins A, B1, B2, and C, plus potassium, phosphorus, calcium, iron, manganese, copper, zinc, and sodium.
People have reportedly poisoned themselves by overdosing on the dried sap, which they used as an opium substitute for medicinal purposes, or, more likely, to (unsuccessfully) get high.

Wild lettuce has lots of edible relatives: Other wild lettuce species (Lactuca spp.), all edible but not as tasty, may be difficult to tell apart, but they all have distinguishing features. Blue lettuce (L. biennis) has blue flowers. Prickly lettuce (L. scariola) has bluish-tinged leaves with stout spines on the underside of the leaf's midrib, which you have to cut off with scissors before eating (the leaves, not the spines!) And, to no one’s surprise, hairy lettuce (L. hirsuta) is unpleasantly hairy (as well as very bitter.)

The common dandelion's edible leaves' deep teeth point toward the leaves bases, it's hairless, and always remains a basal rosette. Chicory, also edible, has deeply lobed leaves, often reddish-tinged, without a midrib that's triangular in cross section. Its basal rosettes grow among the remains of this perennial's previous year's woody flower stalks. And sow thistle (Sonchus spp.), edible as well, is prickly.
Canada Lettuce
This plant is quite tasty, like commercial lettuce on steroids, if you get it at just the right time. It has lots of look-alikes, some good, some pretty bitter, but none poisonous.
Prickly Lettuce, Hairy Lettuce, Sow Thistle, Common Dandelion, Chicory
Barbecued Tofu with Wild Lettuce
barbecued-tofu-with-wild-lettuce

Tofu never tasted so good as when it’s grilled, smothered in this rich, savory sauce, and served over savory wild lettuce.

3 14-oz. packages of soft tofu, drained and sliced into 1/2 inch slabs
1 cup soy mayonnaise
1 cup fruit-sweetened ketchup
9 tbs. prepared mustard
6 tbs. tamari soy sauce (available in health food stores)
2 cups wild or commercial lettuce, coarsely chopped

1. Mix the mayo, ketchup, mustard, and tamari, and pour over the tofu.

2. Grill the 1/3 of the tofu, covered with 1/3 of the sauce, in a covered grill pan over medium heat for 5 minutes, or until lightly browned underneath, transfer to an oiled casserole dish, cover, and keep warm in a preheated 250 degree oven.

3. Repeat the process 2 more times, or until all the ingredients are used.

4. Serve over a bed of wild lettuce

Serves 6

Prep/cooking time: 35 minutes
2)Wild Lettuce Young Basal Rosette
2wild-lettuce-young-basal-rosette
The young basal rosette's toothed leaves are just beginning to form lobes. At this stage, they're still good to eat. Later on, they'll get very bitter.
3)Wild Lettuce Before Flowering
3wild-lettuce-before-flowering

Wild lettuce's tall, unbranched flower stalk hasn't formed flowers yet. Avoid the larger, alternate,deeply lobed leaves and go for the younger upper ones which are slightly toothed if at all, and without lobes. Along with the tender tops of the stems, these are great to eat now.
4)Wild Lettuce Immature Top
4wild-lettuce-immature-top

The narrow, alternate leaves on the top of immature wild lettuce, along with the tender top of the straight flower stalk, are a real delicacy, sautéed with spices and simmered in a sauce. The further down the stalk you go, the more bitter the deeply lobed leaves become.
5)Wild Lettuce with Flowers and Seeds
5wild-lettuce-with-flowers-and-seeds
Mature wild lettuce is a tall plant with alternate, deeply lobed leaves and branches of small, dandelion-like flowers, along with fluffy, white seed heads. It's way too bitter to eat at this time.
1)Mature Wild Lettuce Top
1mature-wild-lettuce-top
Way too late to eat, deeply lobed, toothed, alternate leaves clasp the unbranched stalk while seeds begin to mature on branching flower stalks.
6)Wild Lettuce Seed Heads
6wild-lettuce-seed-heads
Dandelion-like clusters of fluffy, white seed heads grow at the ends of the long, slender, branching seed stalks, along with unopened seed heads.
Spearmint
spearmint
Lamiaceae, Mint Family
Early spring to late fall
Sunny or partially shaded wet habitats, meadows, fields, disturbed habitats, and near lakes and river
Most of the US and southern Canada
Europe

Look for dense stands of medium-sized plants with opposite leaves and square stems. Check for a minty fragrance to confirm you have a mint species, and notice whether it smells like spearmint. Then see if the leaves are toothed, oval to lance-shaped and hairless, and short-stalked or stalkless. See if the flowers grow in tufts from the leaf axils on terminal clusters, if they have protruding stamens, and whether they're white, pale violet, or pink-purple.

Mints are among the easiest plants to recognize. They all have opposite leaves, plus a square stem you can feel when you twirl it in your fingers. And edible mints smell like mint.

Growing 10 to 20 inches tall with a branched, purple-tinged stem, this spearmint spreads with branching rhizomes. It’s pointed (hence the spear in spearmint), toothed, oval to lance-shaped, nearly hairless, stalkless or short-stalked, deeply-veined leaves grow up to three inches or more long, and up to one inch wide.

Growing in tufts from the leaf axils, along the top of the stem in terminal spikes, many white, pale violet, or purple-pink, bilaterally symmetrical, five-lobed flowers, with protruding stamens (spicata means furnish with spikes) bloom from late spring through mid-fall.

The fruit is a small, inconspicuous, dry capsule containing one to four seeds.

•Square stems
•Opposite, oval to lance-shaped, toothed, short-stalked or stalkless, pointed leaves, up to three inches long and 1 inch wide
•Odor of spearmint when crushed
•Many flowers growing in tufts from terminal spikes arising from the leaf axils
•Flowers bilaterally symmetrical, pale violet, or purple-pink, five-lobed, with protruding stamens
Cut or break off all above-ground parts for tea, or strip the leaves and tops with your fingers for food use, leaving as much of the hard stems as possible behind.

Use any or all of the above-ground parts for making tea. For cooking, use the leaves, which don't have hard parts, finely chopped (or whole, as a garnish). They're great in virtually any dessert or sweet recipe, i.e., pies, cakes, sauces, puddings, ice cream, jello, breakfast cereals, and many more.

Spearmint provides vitamins A, B1, B2. B3. beta-carotene, and other related antioxidant carotenoids (vitamin A precursors), the flavonoid hesperidin, and tryptophan, along with calcium, phosphorus, and iron.

Spearmint contains the essential oil menthol, and other biologically active compounds and antioxidants such as 1,8-cineole, acetic-acid, acetophenone, alpha-pinene, alpha-terpineol, apigenin, arginine, benzaldehyde, benzyl-alcohol, beta-sitosterol, borneol, carvacrol, carvone, caryophyllene, diosmin, ethanol, eugenol, farnesol, geraniol, limonene, luteolin, methionine, oleanolic-acid, perillyl-alcohol, pulegone, rosmarinic-acid, terpinen-4-ol, thymol, ursolic-acid,

An infusion of the above-ground parts of the plant does a great job settling upset stomachs and improving digestion. It's also used for morning sickness and motion sickness. It's been used for children’s digestive disorders, including colic, for centuries, whereas stronger peppermint has been preferred for adult indigestion.

Containing antimicrobial compounds, it's also used for colds, influenza, and fever, as well as for nervous headaches. Research even shows that it's good for mild hirsutism (excessive hairiness) in women because it reduces androgen levels.

Spearmint is a mild diuretic. This is one I definitely avoid before leading foraging tours. If I have to duck behind the bushes, 20 people run after me, to see what I'm going to find! Nevertheless, a strong cup of hot tea will promote the flow of urine and relieve swelling due to water retention (of course, if the water retention is due to heart or kidney failure, you better get a correct diagnosis and appropriate treatment before you cure the the symptoms, and drop dead.)

Macerated spearmint stems are also good as a poultice on bruises. Mixing them with burdock leaves, water, and clay may be even more effective.
An overdose of the concentrated essential oil, menthol, which you'd have to buy, is toxic, especially for pregnant women and infants.
This familiar plant is easy to recognize, common, and widespread. It enhances the flavor of countless dishes, and makes an excellent tea with medicinal properties.
1)Spearmint in Flower
1spearmint-in-flower

The square stem and opposite leaves indicate that you should check for a minty fragrance. Spearmint's virtually stalkless, oval to lance-shaped, medium-sized, toothed leaves, and the terminal spikes with tufts of many flowers with long stamens, distinguish it from the other mints.
2)Mature Spearmint
2mature-spearmint

The usually stalkless, oval to spear-shaped, deeply veined, toothed leaves, plus the terminal spikes with tufts of many pink-tinted or purple-tinted white flowers, with their protruding stamens, make spearmint easy to recognize. If you're still not sure, just smell it!
3)Spearmint Flowers
3spearmint-flowers
Spearmint Ice Cream
spearmint-ice-cream

Spearmint fits into my vegan ice cream protocol perfectly, especially when you add sweet carob chips at the end.

3-4 cups almond milk or other non-dairy milk
6 tbs. fresh spearmint or other mint leaves, loosely packed
2 tsp. powdered agar or 1 tbs. agar flakes (available in health food stores)
1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
1/2 cup raw pignoli nuts or cashews
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin
1/4 cup grape seed oil or canola oil
2 tsp. liquid stevia
1/2 tsp. salt
1/4 tsp. lemon extract
1 cup vegan carob- or chocolate chips

1. Stir 4 tbs. of the spearmint, the agar, and arrowroot into the almond milk, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, and simmer 5 minutes, or until the agar is dissolved, stirring often.

2. Combine with all the remaining ingredients except the carob chips in a blender and purée;.

3. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

4. Stir in the carob chips.

5. Garnish with the remaining spearmint leaves.

Makes 5-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Freezing time: 2-1/2 hours
Water Mint
water-mint
Lamiaceae, Mint Family
Mid-spring to mid-fall
Wet, sunny or partially shaded places, in shallow water, lake edges, streams, ponds, ditches, wet meadows, wet woods, springs, swamps, marshes, bogs, and fens
Much Eastern North America, much of Western North America, and southern Canada, but not in the Deep South
Europe

Look for stands of minty-smelling, hairy, small plants with square stems growing in water, with opposite, oval to round leaves, and spikes of densely packed spherical clusters of tiny, pinkish to lilac, two-lipped flowers.

Edible mints are among the easiest plants to recognize. They all have opposite leaves, a square stem that becomes obvious when you twirl it in your fingers, and a minty fragrance. This wonderful-flavored, small, flavorful example, which reaches six inches to 1.5 feet in height, grows shallow water, is always a pleasure to find and use.

The oval to round, stalked, coarsely toothed, opposite leaves, covered with distinctly curved hairs, are heart-shaped at their bases. They may be short-stalked or stalkless.

The tiny, densely crowded, purple to lilac, tubular, two-lipped, pinkish to lilac flowers, which bloom in late summer and fall, crowd into spherical clusters on terminal spikes arising from the square stem, which, like the leaves, is often tinged with purple.

Like other mints, it spreads through rhizomes, and the fruit is a small, inconspicuous, dry capsule.

•Square, purple-tinged stems
•Oval to round, short-stalked or stalkless, coarsely toothed, hairy, purple-tinged, opposite leaves, heart-shaped at the base
•Flowers growing in spherical clusters along terminal spikes
•Flowers tiny, densely packed, purple to lilac, tubular, two-lipped, blooming in late summer and fall
•Strong odor of mint when crushed
Break off the whole plant for tea, or strip off the leaves and any tender parts of the stems for other recipes.

This is an especially strong-flavored mint that will really empower your recipes. Like other mints, you can use the leaves, stems, and flowers for making tea. For cooking, use the leaves, finely chopped (or whole, as a garnish). They're great in virtually any dessert or sweet recipe, such as pies, cakes, sauces, puddings, ice cream, jello, breakfast cereals, and they're an especially good seasoning for chocolate.
Like other mints, an infusion is used for fevers, headaches, and indigestion. The tea is also used as a mouthwash and a gargle for sore throats, ulcers, and bad breath.
An overdose of the concentrated essential oil, menthol, which you'd have to buy, can be toxic, especially for pregnant women and infants.
This strong-tasting mint is wonderful in dessert dishes with other flavorful ingredients, it makes an outstanding tea, and it's good for indigestion and fever.

water-mint-smoothie

You can vary the fruits in this basic smoothie, and even switch the extracts if you’d like, but as long as you're using water mint as a basic flavoring, it’s hard to go wrong.

3 cups almond milk, oat milk, or soy milk
1 sweet navel orange, sectioned
11 small strawberries
1 tbs. liquid stevia (available in health food stores)
1/2 tbs. fresh or 1/2 tsp. dried water mint or other mint species
1/2 tsp. orange extract
1 tsp. vanilla extract
1/2 tsp. strawberry extract (optional)

Purée; all ingredients in a blender.

Serves 4

Preparation time: 5 minutes
