Peppermint
peppermint
Lamiaceae, Mint Family
Mid-spring to mid-fall
Sunny and partially shaded wet places, such as ditches, along streams, in gardens, edge habitats, and in wet meadows.
The Eastern US and southeastern Canada, and much of the Western US and southwest Canada
Europe

Look for a stand of plants with purple-blotched square stems partially reclining, elliptical, opposite leaves, and short, interrupted clusters of tiny, pink to violet flowers growing on terminal spikes, all with the obvious fragrance of peppermint.

Well-known as a flavoring, this plant is actually a sterile hybrid of spearmint and water mint. Unable to disperse by seeds, it uses rhizomes to spread.

The dark green, purplish-tinged, hairless to slightly hairy, short-stalked, pointed, coarsely toothed, elliptical leaves grow one to 2.5 inches long.

Blooming in summer or fall, the tiny, four-lobed, pink to violet, tubular, weakly lipped, bilaterally symmetrical flowers grow 0.2 inch wide, whorled in terminal clusters on short or interrupted, thick, blunt, upright spikes.

The purplish-tinged, smooth, square, branching stems can grow from 1.5 to three feet long, but they mostly recline and often stick up less than one foot.

•Branching, partially reclining, purple-blotched square stems
•Dark green, purple-tinged, coarsely toothed, short-stalked, elliptical, opposite leaves one to 2.5 inches long
•Thick, blunt, upright spikes with terminal clusters of short or interrupted whorls of flowers
•Pink to violet, tubular, weakly lipped, bilaterally symmetrical, four-lobed flowers, 0.2 inch wide
•Peppermint fragrance

Cut or break off all above-ground parts for tea, or strip the leaves and tops with your fingers for food use, leaving as much of the hard stems as possible behind. Use all above-ground parts for making tea.

Use any or all of the above-ground parts for making tea. For cooking, use the leaves, which don't have hard parts, finely chopped (or whole, as a garnish). They're great in virtually any dessert or sweet recipe, such as pies, cakes, sauces, puddings, ice cream, jello, breakfast cereals, and many more. This is also one of the best flavorings to use with chocolate.
Peppermint provides carotinoids that the body uses to make vitamin A, and it provides the minerals calcium, iron, phosphorus, silicon, and chromium.

A stimulant with carminative, anti-spasmodic, and anti-microbial properties, the infusion is used for indigestion, flatulence, colic, sore throats, diarrhea, dysentery, colds, the flu, rheumatism, and toothache, as well as for hookworm, fungus infections, and nervous headaches. And its essential oil, menthol, (which is dangerous taken internally in overdose,) has been used externally for pain. Under controlled doses and medical supervision, it has been shown to improve irritable bowel syndrome, and eating the leaves for this condition is safe.

I usually complain that there hasn't been enough research done on herbs. But when I see how many additional compounds were discovered in peppermint, I wish I'd kept my mouth shut:

Field Garlic
field-garlic
Family: Amaryllidaceae, The amaryllis family (previously, Family: Alliaceae)
The leaves are in season from fall through early spring, the flowers from late spring to early summer, the bulblets in early summer, and the bulbs from early fall to mid-summer.
Partially shaded and sunny habitats, edges, lawns, meadows, pastures, fields, roadsides, river and stream sides, backyards, disturbed soil, parks, and open woods.
Throughout most of the eastern half of North America and eastern Canada, and the Pacific states and western North America.
Europe, West Asia, and Northern Africa

Look for bunches of narrow, cylindrical, erect basal leaves, sometimes floppy on top, in early spring and fall (and through mild spells during the winter). A spherical seed cluster sits on top of a tall, leafless stem in early summer. Check for onion/garlic like bulbs underground, and crush any part of the plant to detect the garlicky odor.

This is a delicious, common, widespread member of the onion/garlic family that smells like what you'd expect from such foods.

By mid-spring, field garlic produces long, slender, unbranched, hollow, round, grooved basal leaves 0.5 to two feet tall. They emerge from layered, underground bulbs resembling tiny onions. It's easy to distinguish field garlic from the surrounding grass once you start looking for bunches of cylindrical leaves growing among grass's flat blades.

The layered underground bulbs, growing to nearly one inch wide, look like small onions in the fall, winter, and early spring, but by mid-spring, smaller bulbs, resembling garlic cloves, partially split off to become new plants.

In late spring, a spherical cluster 0.75 to two inches wide, consisting of stalkless, whitish, green-tinged to reddish bulblets grows on the top of a single, long, slender, erect, smooth, leafless stem one to 3.5 feet tall. Each ovoid bulblet, with a flat side and a curved side, projects a tiny, slender, green shoot upward. Sometimes additional stalks about 0.75 inch long, with tiny, lilac-colored, six-petaled, short-stalked flowers, arise from the bulblets. Later on, a membrane surrounding the bulblets ruptures, and they fall to the ground to become new plants.

•Bunches of tightly packed, long, narrow, cylindrical basal leaves
•A long, slender, leafless stem
•Spherical cluster of green, white, or pink bulblets on top of the stem
•Ovoid bulblets flat on one surface, curved on the other
•Tiny, slender green shoots often emerging from the tops of the young bulblets
•Tiny, lilac-colored, six-parted flowers sometimes growing from the tops of the young bulblets
•Small, onion- or garlic-like bulbs underground
•Distinct garlicky odor when any part of the plant is torn or crushed

Simply break or tear off the tender, young basal leaves in early spring and fall, and in the winter when the weather is mild, if the leaves aren't so badly damaged by the cold that there are too many yellow parts.

Remove the young, spherical clusters of terminal bulblets along with any accompanying tiny shoots or flowers.

You can dig up the bulbs with a shovel or trowel, although they sometimes come up when you pull out all the basal leaves at once. Swing them against a tree to separate some of the soil. Divide the bunch of leaves in half, then swing them against a tree again. Repeat until you're rid of most of the soil.

It's amazing how much you can find on and offline about how tough, stringy, and awful this plant is. Apparently none of these writers goes out to forage in very early spring, or even autumn (they certainly don't know there's a second season), when the leaves are young, tender, and delicious. Use these tender, young leaves raw or cooked like scallions or chives when they first come up in early spring or fall, not when they really are tough and coarse, in mid-spring. They cook in about 15 minutes, and taste like an exotic combination of onions, garlic, and chives. For onion/garlic aficionados on my early spring or autumn tours who never heard of this plant before, it's always love at first bite!

The small underground bulbs taste like onions in seasons when the weather is cold, then become spicier, like garlic, when the weather gets warmer. Use them accordingly, raw or cooked. They cook in about 10 minutes.

The terminal bulblets are quite spicy, like garlic. Use them while they're still young, before the skin gets tough, like you use garlic.

Little information is available about the nutrient content of this plant, but field garlic contains strong anti-oxidative properties due to its high concentration of flavonoids, carotenoids and chlorophyll, and members of this genus are generally healthful to eat. They contain sulfur compounds that help reduce bad cholesterol levels and promote good digestion, and they may act as tonics for the circulatory system.

Field garlic is considered a blood purifier, carminative, diuretic, expectorant, stimulant, and vasodilator. The raw bulbs can lower blood pressure, which makes this a good candidate for treating high blood pressure, as long as the condition is medically monitored in case of fluctuations either way. And a tincture has been used to prevent children from getting colic and croup. The whole plant has been shown to have anti-asthmatic properties, a good food for people with this condition.

Field garlic is also supposed to prevent kids from getting worms, but this definitely doesn't work. Whenever my 6-year-old daughter, Violet, who loves field garlic, finds a worm while she's digging up the bulbs on one of my tours, the plant never prevents her from getting the worm, and keeps it to play with until she lets it go at the end of the tour!

1. Avoid this plant if you suffer from low blood pressure.

2. Don't let your cow eat the plant, lest it flavor her milk!

3. Never eat this plant before going on a date, unless your date has eaten it too!

4. Never go on a date with someone who's eaten this plant, unless you've eat it as well!

Field garlic has poisonous look-alikes, but no poisonous smell-alikes. The plants below have no odor, as well as completely different flowers:

Star of Bethlehem (Ornithogalum umbellatum) grows in bunches like field garlic, with underground bulbs, and often right next to field garlic, but it has flat, not cylindrical leaves, with a faint, white stripe running the length of each leaf.

Various poisonous lily species (Lilium spp.) have long, narrow leaves like field garlic, sometimes with bulbs underground, but they're not cylindrical, and everything else about them is different too.
Onion Grass, Meadow garlic, Wild Onion, Canada garlic, Wild garlic, Rose Leek, Meadow Leek, Tree Onion
This delicious, onion/garlic scented and -flavored plant is great used like onions, scallions, or garlic, and it always gets you a seat on the subway.
Star of Bethlehem, various lilies
2)Field Garlic Sourdough Bread
2field-garlic-sourdough-bread
http://dev.winterroot.net/deepwinter/foraging/cms#pageId-351
1)Sourdough Starter for Dummies
1sourdough-starter-for-dummies

Sourdough Starter for Dummies from The Wild Vegan Cookbook, by "Wildman" Steve Brill

In the early 1980s I was introduced to a naturally fermented health drink called rejuvelac in a course taught by Steve Meyerowitz, the Sproutman. Simple to make, this fermented health drink also provides a foolproof starting point for inaugurating a sourdough starter that yields wonderfully tangy sourdough breads, pancakes, and muffins.

After you experience genuine wild sourdough baked goods, you'll never even think of using commercial starter again. You'll want to maintain your starter forever, and you may even give some away as a gift to grateful culinary friends. Here's everything you need to know about creating, using, and maintaining a wild yeast starter. The steps are many, but each one is very simple.

Never use up all of your starter. Use some for your recipes, and add more rye or some other whole-grain flour and water to the remainder to replenish it. If you use the starter daily, store it at room temperature, beat it twice a day (I know this sounds cruel), and replenish it as necessary. If you use your starter less frequently, store it in the refrigerator, beat it every few days to keep the flour and water from separating, and feed it with additional flour and water once a week to keep it from starving to death (now that would really be cruel). 6 to 12 hours before you plan on using your starter again, feed it, add enough water to restore it to a thick batter, beat it, and let it stand at room temperature. You can use it again as soon as it bubbles actively.

To turn a normal yeast bread recipe into a sourdough recipe, replace the dry yeast required for 2 medium-size loaves with 1 cup starter and omit 1/2 cup of the flour and 1/2 cup of the water from the recipe.

1/4 cup wheat berries (available in health food stores)
1/2 cup water, plus more as needed
1 cup rye flour (or half as much rye flour as the amount of starter you want to make)

1. In a small bowl, soak the wheat berries in the 1/2 cup water overnight.

2. Drain the wheat berries and then tie them in a mesh bag, cheesecloth, nylon stocking (a clean one!), or any other porous cloth container and hang the sprout sack where it can drain at room temperature. Rinse the bag with water twice a day for about 3 days, until the sprouts on the wheat berries are as long as the wheat berry itself.

3. Put the sprouts in a blender with twice their volume of water and blend on the lowest speed for a few seconds, just to break up the sprouts. Don't overblend.

4. Put the sprout-water combination in a non-metal (glass, plastic, or ceramic--metal kills wild yeast) jar or food container and cover the container with cheesecloth or a towel (it should not be airtight). Let the mixture sit at room temperature for about 3 days, stirring it twice a day with a non-metal implement, until the liquid bubbles and tastes sour.

5. Strain out and discard the sprouts. The liquid is now called rejuvelac.

6. Using a non-metal implement, stir in the rye flour and enough additional water to make a thick batter. Something close to an equal volume of liquid to flour usually does the trick. Cover the starter loosely, let it sit at room temperature, and stir it twice a day. When it bubbles actively, it's ready to use.

Notes: Don't fill your starter container to the top when storing it. The starter may expand, pop the lid, and make a mess.

Wild Garlic
wild-garlic
Family: Amaryllidaceae, The amaryllis family (previously, Family: Alliaceae)

Leaves: Early- to late spring

Bulblets: Early spring to winter

Bulbs: Early spring to winter
Partial shaded or sunny habitats, open woodlands, edges, fields, prairies, moist meadows near rivers, thickets, lakes edges, and disturbed habitats
Most of Eastern and Central North America

Chefs and foragers praise the ramp as the acme of wild onions, but this lesser-known plant is just as good. Way tastier than any commercial onion, the flavor is part-way between that of onions and garlic. Use the leaves, bulbs, flowers, and bulblets the way you'd use onions, garlic scapes, scallions, or chives, in any type of savory recipe, using any cooking method. They cook in about 10 minutes.

There's no nutritional analysis available, although it's likely that this plant is packed with nutrients, like the other Alliums in this app. And since Lewis and Clark staved off both starvation and scurvy in the winter by eating this plant's bulblets, it must be a good source of vitamin C.

Like its wild and commercial relatives, this plant is considered anti-asthmatic, carminative, diuretic, expectorant, and a stimulant. A tincture has been used for worms, colic, and croup in children, while its sulfur-containing amino acids may reduce bad cholesterol levels, tonify the cariovascular system, and aid digestion.

Native Americans and pioneers applied the juice of the plant to burns, and various Native American tribes used crushed bulbs to treat boils, bee stings, and snakebites. They also used this plant for fevers, skin problems, hemorrhoids, earaches, rheumatism and arthritis, tapeworms and other internal parasites, blood disorders, and lung problems. These uses should be tested, although I'm not going to volunteer to be bitten by a snake!

Avoid this plant if you suffer from low blood pressure. It could aggravate the condition.

Considered a noxious weed in some Deep South states, where it gives milk a garlicky flavor if cows eat it, it's a threatened or endangered species in some of the northernmost states in the East. Please don't collect it in Maine, New Hampshire, or Vermont. There are plenty of other edibles that are very common.

Other edible Alliums look and smell similar to wild garlic, but none has fibers surrounding the bulb. Field garlic, for example, has flat, hollow basal leaves and a leafless flower stalk, while nodding onion has a floppy flower- and seed head.

Daylily shoots, also edible, have flat, narrow leaves branching from near the base, but the young leaves aren't floppy, the plant has rhizomes and tubers underground instead of bulbs, and there's no odor.

People sometimes confuse this plant with grass, but grass has thin blades, no bulbs, and it smells like grass!

Nodding Onion
nodding-onion
Family: Amaryllidaceae, The amaryllis family (previously, Family: Alliaceae)

Leaves: Mid-spring to late summer

Flowers: Mid-summer

Bulbs: Mid-spring through fall
Full or partial sunlight, dry woodlands, prairies, and rocky slopes
Much of Eastern North America and southeastern Canada, the Rocky Mountain region, the Pacific NW, and and much of southwestern Canada

Look for a vase-like configuration of long, narrow, outward-drooping leaves that smell like onions, and a drooping flower cluster configured like an umbrella, with long-stemmed, small, six-pepaled, white, lavender, or pink flowers, and no bulblets. Scratch and sniff for the odor of garlic.

This spicy-tasting plant grows a basal rosette configured like a cone, with long, narrow, smooth, linear, outward-drooping basal leaves one foot long and 0.25 inch across. A shallow groove runs down each leaf's length.

A slender, leafless stem up to 1.5 feet tall (sometimes taller) bends over on top, like a shepherd's crook, and produces a flower head at its tip with six-tepaled white, lavender, or pink, bell-like flowers, 0.25 inch long, all spread out into a loose circle, hanging umbrella-fashion (so only bees, which don't mind being upside-down, can pollinate them), by slender, smooth, spoke-like flower stalks 0.75 inch long.

Unlike its relatives, no bulblets grow on top. Blooming in mid-summer, the flowers are soon replaced by seed capsules containing small, flat black seeds light enough to be spread by the wind.

The underground bulb, longer than it's wide, subdivides into new bulbs, creating bunches of plants. The whole plant smells like onions or garlic when crushed.

•Onion odor
•Long, narrow smooth basal leaves flopping outward, creating a cone configuration
•Shallow groove running down leaf's length
•A long, smooth, slender, leafless stem drooping over toward the top
•Small, six-tepaled white, pink, or lavender flowers hanging from long flower stalks, configured like an umbrella hanging from the end of the stem
•Oblong bulb underground

Use the leaves, bulbs, and flowers the way you'd use onions, garlic scapes, scallions, or chives, in any type of savory recipe, using any cooking method. The flavor is similar to all those relatives, but with its own twist. The plant cooks in about 10 to 15 minutes.

This plant probably has properties similar to garlic, but should be tested. The Native Americans used the juice of the plant for hives, croup, colds and sore throat. The applied a poultice of the whole plant externally for pleurisy, croup, infections, sores, and swellings, and used a warm poultice of the bulbs for sore throat.

Avoid this plant and its relatives if you suffer from low blood pressure. Alliums could aggravate the condition.

This plant is threatened in some areas. Please don't collect it in those places. Collect only where abundant, and even then, don't collect more than a small fraction of the bulbs.

Other edible Alliums look and smell similar to nodding onions, but none has a bent-over flower cluster. Field garlic, for example, has flat, hollow basal leaves and an upright leafless flower stalk with bulblets, while wild garlic has an upright flower- and seed head plus a net of fibers around its ovoid bulb.

Daylily shoots, also edible, have flat, narrow leaves branching near the base, but the young leaves aren't floppy, the plant has rhizomes and tubers underground instead of bulbs, and there's no odor.

People sometimes confuse this plant with grass, but grass has thin blades, no bulbs, and it smells like grass!

Chipolte Rice with Nodding Onions
chipolte-rice-with-nodding-onions

Chipolte chillies and nodding onions are among my favorite ingredients, so centering a rice dish around their flavors is very appealing. The Tex-Mex seasonings and garlic, logical complements to the other flavorful spices, blend in so perfectly, as soon as you taste the recipe, you'll give it the nod!

1-1/2 cups basmati brown rice
3-1/4 cups vegetable stock or water
1 cup nodding onion leaves, flowers, or bulbs, chopped, or 1 large red onion, chopped
1-1/2 tbs. olive oil
2 cloves of garlic, chopped

1 tbs. Barbecue Seasoning, or to taste

Bring all ingredients to a boil over medium heat in a saucepan, stirring often, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 45 minutes, or until all the liquid is absorbed and the rice is tender.

Preparation time: 10 minutes
