Most of the continental US, southern Canada and Mexico, but not Nevada, Arizona, and New Mexico
Europe

Look for a low, trailing plant with long-stalked, opposite, scallop-edged, kidney-shaped leaves, and small funnel-shaped, purple-blue or bluish-violet to lavender flowers growing in the leaf axils. Sniff for a musty mint odor.

This common mint's round to kidney-shaped, scallop-edged, opposite, stalked leaves, often tinged with purple, and with hairs on the upper surface, grow 0.5 to 2.5 inches across. The hairy leafstalks are longer than the leaves.

Opposite clusters of small, two-lipped, funnel shaped, bilaterally symmetrical, purple-blue or bluish-violet to lavender flowers bloom in the leaf axils, usually in groups of two or three, from early spring through early summer. The five-lobed, purple-spotted flowers have fine, whitish hairs inside. Each flower may produce up to four tiny, oval, brown nutlets.

Ground ivy spreads using runners, resulting in dense mats all of one inch high, although the plant sometimes grows upright and reaches a height of about eight inches.

When crushed, the whole plant smells musty, like mint with a hint of motor oil.

•Opposite, kidney-shaped, scallop-edged leaves
•Square stems creeping along ground and rooting at nodes
•Odor of mint tinged with motor oil
•Leaves' upper surfaces hairy
•Long, square leafstalks
•Trumpet-shaped, five-lobed, bilaterally symmetrical, purple-blue or bluish-violet to lavender flowers in the leaf axils, usually in groups of two or three
Simply strip off leaves and flowers with your fingers if you're going to eat the plant, and include the stems if you're going to make tea.

Although the young leaves are edible, they're not very tasty, somewhat bitter and with overtones of mint and balsam. While people sometimes include them in salads or add them to soups, they're best used in tea, especially with other herbs. Lemon verbena (Aloysia triphylla), which doesn't grow wild in the US, is the traditional companion herb.
Ground ivy is a good source of vitamin C, iron, and antioxidants.

An infusion has been used as a general tonic, for colds and coughs, and to relieve congested mucous membranes, for centuries. This has been upheld by science, which has demonstrated it to have antibiotic and anti-inflammatory effects in lab animals. And it's definitely a diuretic. I once embarked on a five mile bicycle ride after sharing a cup of ground ivy tea with a friend. I had to make five pit stops, and there were no pits!

A poultice of bruised fresh leaves was applied to wounds and sores, and an infusion of the leaves, flowers, and stems has been used for jaundice, poisoning, sciatica, gout, tinnitus, catarrh, diarrhea, bile disorders, hemorrhoids, lead poisoning, and tuberculosis, and even the plague. Its efficacy here is uncertain, but a if it doesn't work and you die of all these maladies, don't worry—the plant can still help you—the English make a wreath from the stems and leaves for the dead!

1. This plant can poison you, but only if you're a horse!

2. It does contain terpenoids and terpene-rich volatile oils that could irritate the gastrointestinal tract and kidneys of humans, so start with small quantities of this plant to be sure you don't get any adverse reactions.

Here's another example of a common name causing confusion. This plant is a mint, unrelated to ivies (Hedera spp.). Other mints (Mentha spp.) may superficially resemble ground ivy, but most don't have creeping stems that root at the nodes. Henbit (Lamium amplexicaule) does, but it has no leaf stalks rather than long ones, and the flower are bright pink.

Ground ivy leaves look like those of common mallow, also edible, but mallow leaves are hairless and odorless, and the stem is round, not square.

People sometimes confuse ground ivy leaves with those of garlic mustard. However, garlic mustard's hairless leaves are much larger, they grow in basal rosettes, not trailing the ground, and they smell like garlic, not mint.
Gill-Over-the-Ground, Creeping Charlie
This is a tasty, healthful, common, widespread plant that makes a good cup of herb tea.
Garlic Mustard, Stinging Nettles, Common Mallow
2)Ground Ivy in Flower
2ground-ivy-in-flower

This trailing plant sometimes grows upright. But with the paired, kidney-shaped, long-stalked, scallop-edged leaves with short hairs on top, the cluster of small, blue and white, two-lipped, stalked, funnel-shaped flowers, and the square stem, you just need to smell it to verify its identity.
1)Ground Ivy Flowers
1ground-ivy-flowers
Ground ivy's long, tubular, two-lipped, lavender to white flowers grow from the leaf axils, next to the long-stalked, kidney-shaped, scallop-edged leaves that are hairy on top.
Winter Cress
winter-cress
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

Leaves: Available when few wild foods are around, they're at their best during warm spells in the winter, in the earliest spring, and late in the fall, when they first come up.

Flower buds and flowers: Early to mid-spring
Sunny or lightly shaded, moist fields, disturbed sites, marshes, vacant lots, roadsides, and ditches
Throughout most of the US and southern Canada, except for Mississippi Louisiana, Texas, Utah, and Nevada
Europe

Look for plants with shiny, dark green basal leaves with several smaller lobes and one large terminal lobe growing in a basal rosette in cold weather seasons. In the spring, look for shiny, alternate, hairless leaves, lobed toward the bottom of a top-branching flower stalk, and smaller with fewer or no lobes on top. Look for terminal culsters of bright yellow four-petaled flowers, 0.33 inches across, followed by long, slender seed pods.

This common mustard's glossy, dark green, toothless, hairless, deeply lobed basal leaves first appear in late winter. Two to eight inches long, they have one to four paired lobes and a larger, heart-shaped terminal lobe.

By mid-spring (during the second year for those plants that are biennial instead of annual), a hairless, ridged, purple-tinged stem, branching toward the top, reaches one to three feet in height. Its long, broad, wavy edged or toothed, stalkless lower alternate leaves have four to eight paired lobes, while the progressively smaller upper leaves have fewer lobes, until the ones near the top, which clasp the stem, are shaped like duck's feet.

The small, stalked flower buds, which grow on terminal clusters toward the top of the plant, resemble tiny heads of broccoli. They open into long clusters of small, four-petaled, bright yellow, stalked flowers, which in turn mature into tough, narrow, slender, unlobed seed pods, called silques, up to one inch long. These grow below the flowers.

The roots are fibrous.

•A basal rosette of glossy, hairless, leaves with opposite lobes and a larger, heart-shaped terminal lobe
•A ridged, purple-tinged stem, branching near the top
•Hairless, alternate stem leaves, lobed near the bottom, and smaller leaves with fewer or no lobes, clasping the stem, toward the top
•Small, broccoli-like flower buds, followed by terminal clusters of bright yellow four-petaled flowers 0.33 inches across toward the top of the plant
•Slender seed pods 0.33 inch long on terminal clusters, growing below the flowers

Although you may certainly tear off the basal leaves with your fingers, it's much more effective to sweep a pocket knife under the rosette to sever the root and gain the entire rosette. Then you can shake off the debris and bag it.

Pluck off the flower buds or flowers with your fingers.

This is nearly everyone's least favorite wild food, with leaves and the tender tops of the stems tasting like bitter cabbage, although about one of out 10 people say they like this plant (I don't know whether to believe them.) Only once, during a tour of Central Park, did we find the leaves when they must have just come up a few days earlier, and everyone was surprised by how good they tasted, very much like arugula. It took only 27 years of foraging tours to find them in this state, and it might take another 27 years before this ever happens again!

You can use the flower buds like broccoli, but they're so small, it may not be worth the effort. You can also add the flowers to salads or cooked vegetable dishes. They're spicy but also bitter, so use them sparingly.

People have boiled the leaves in repeated changes of water to get rid of the bitterness, but this also destroys the nutrients. I've had success pickling them with Korean spices and making kimchi. I've also dehydrated them, ground it into powder in a blender, mixed this with buckwheat flour, olive oil, salt, and water, and rolled this out into very tasty pasta with a pasta machine.

Adding small amounts of very young leaves to a salad that contains sweet ingredients, i.e., grapes or raisins, also works, and you could try sautée;ing the leaves in oil with lots of spices, then simmering them in a sauce, which works for some bitter greens.

Winter cress leaves provide generous amounts of vitamins A, B1, B2, C, and E, as well as iron, manganese, and calcium. The flower buds are rich in protein.

The leaves are also a good source of phenethyl isothiocyanate (PEITC). In combination with curcumin, which is found in the herb turmeric (Curcuma longa), it’s been demonstrated to prevent prostate cancer and slow its progression in mice .This may or may not prove effective in humans.

The leaves are considered a vulnerary, and have been used in poultices on open wounds, bee stings and other skin ailments. An infusion of the tea is supposed to be a diuretic, and the Mohegan Indians used this infusion for coughs. I don't know how well it works.

A better-tasting close relative with deeper, more even lobes, creasy greens (B. verna), also called land cress, American cress, bank cress, Belle Isle cress, Bermuda cress, early yellow rocket, early wintercress, scurvy cress, and upland cress, grows in the southeastern US, where it’s even sometimes sold in markets. I only got to try it once, and it's very good.

Wild mustard (Brassica kaber) and wild radish, both edible, look like winter cress. The former has hairy leaves, and the latter's leaves lack the large terminal lobe.

People confuse winter cress with watercress, also edible, but the latter is a smaller plant with white, not yellow flowers, that grows in the water.
Yellow Rocket

One of the least tasty wild plants, you have to get this one when it's very very young, pickle it, or turn it into flour to make it worthwhile, but it does grow in the winter, when there's not much else around.
Wild Watercress, Wild Radish, Wild Mustard, Creasy Greens
1)Winter Cress Flower, Seed Pod, and Basal Leaf
1winter-cress-flower,-seed-pod,-and-basal-leaf

The smooth, shiny basal leaf has paired, toothless lobes along its length, and a larger terminal lobe. The alternate, stalkless upper leaves are toothed and clasp the stem. They resemble duck's feet. The small flowers at the top of terminal clusters have four petals configured like a cross, typical of the mustard family, and the seed pods are long, narrow, curved, and cylindrical.
2)Winter Cress Basal Rosette
2winter-cress-basal-rosette
The shiny, hairless, untoothed basal leaves, which appear in late winter, have one large terminal lobe, and smaller paired lobes.
3)Winter Cress Flower Bud and Upper Leaves
3winter-cress-flower-bud-and-upper-leaves

The glossy, hairless, alternate, stalkless, toothed upper leaves are too bitter to eat. If the broccoli-like flower bud isn't to your taste either, get someone else to eat it. Just tell them: "This bud's for you!"
4)Winter Cress Flowers
4winter-cress-flowers

These bright yellow flowers, with the broccoli-like flower buds, and the hairless, duck foot-like, alternate, upper leaves, which clasp the stem, make this plant easy to spot any time you're near a wet, sunny spot in early- or mid-spring. But is you taste the bitter leaves now, you'll wish it had been harder to find!
Yellow Wood Sorrel
yellow-wood-sorrel
Family: Oxalidaceae, the wood sorrel family
Not cold tolerant, you can find this plant from mid-spring to mid-fall.
Sunny or partially shaded lawns, gardens, edges, trail sides, roadsides, fields, meadows, thickets, disturbed soil, and partially-sunny spots in the woods.
Most of the US and southern Canada except the west coast and Rocky Mountain states
Wood sorrel is also native to Europe. A muddy-footed migrating bird, blow off course by a storm, probably transferred the tiny seeds across the Atlantic in prehistoric times.

Look for a medium-sized plant with three-parted palmate-compound leaves. It has small, radially symmetrical five-parted yellow flowers, and small, cylindrical, flat-sided, pointed fruits that look like tiny pickles or bananas.

This common, widespread, delicious, medium-sized plant is one of the easiest to recognize—one of the best for beginners and kids. A weak, green to pink stem, branched at base, grows from six to around 18 inches tall, or creeps along the ground, supported by rhizomes and fibrous roots.

The alternate,palmate-compound leaves, each about 0.75 inch across, consist of three distinctive, heart-shaped leaflets, each with a seam running along its length.

Growing on a long, slender stem that branches with age, groups of two to seven radially-symmetrical, yellow, five-petaled flowers, 0.33 to 0.75 inch across, bloom from late spring to fall.

Shaped like a banana or pickle, the fruit is an upright, narrow, pointed, ridged seedpod under 0.75 inch long, sparsely hairy, with flat sides, and five sepals at the base. The tiny, round, reddish-brown seeds inside disperse explosively when the ripe fruit splits after being disturbed.

•Three-parted, heart-shaped, palmate-compound leaves
•Small, yellow, radially symmetrical flowers
•Upright, pickle- or banana-shaped seedpod one inch long
•Tiny, reddish seeds that discharge explosively from the ripe seed pod
Strip off the leaves, flowers, seeds, and tender parts of the stem with your fingers.

This plant is excellent raw in salads and sandwiches, and you can cook it in any vegetable or dessert dish that would benefit from its sour flavor. Use any cooking method. It cooks in 5 to 10 minutes.
Yellow wood sorrel and its relatives are excellent sources of vitamin C.

The oxalic acid content of wood sorrel is very dangerous, blocking calcium uptake and causing rapid, agonizing death through calcium deficiency, but only in books and ill-informed websites! Unless you have such severe kidney problems or gout that you can't eat spinach, which as comparable levels of this substance, this plant is completely safe, and there are no recorded cases of anyone ever haven gotten sick from eating this healthful plant.
Sourgrass, Shamrock, Pickleplant
With three heart-shaped leaves and yellow five-petaled flowers, this is one of the most common, easy to recognize, widespread, and delicious plants in the world.
Red Clover, White Clover
1)Yellow Wood Sorrel Seed Pods, Leaf, and Flower
1yellow-wood-sorrel-seed-pods,-leaf,-and-flower

The upright seed pods set this species apart from its edible relatives (stricta means upright). Growing on short branches, pickle-shaped, and seamed, five tiny sepals surround its base. It's three-parted leaf composed of heart-shaped leaflets, each with a seam running down its length, makes the plant easy to recognize. The yellow, radially symmetrical, five-parted flower, as well as any parts that are soft enough to chew, are always good to eat.
2)Mature Yellow Wood Sorrel
2mature-yellow-wood-sorrel

You can see the ripe seeds inside the upright, pickle- or banana-shaped seedpod. The three seamed leaflets of the palmate-compound leaves, and the stalked, radially symmetrical, five-parted, yellow flower make this one of the easiest to recognize and safest (not to mention most delicious) plants for beginning foragers.
Wood Sorrel Ice Cream
wood-sorrel-ice-cream

Lemony flavored wood sorrel makes for a wonderful, exotic-tasting ice cream, and my vegan ice cream making concepts work perfectly here.

1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
2 tsp. agar powder
4 cups soy-rice milk, nut milk, or oat milk
1/2 cup raw pignola nuts or cashews
1/4 c vegetable glycerin
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/4 cup grape seed oil or canola oil
1 tbs. liquid stevia
1/2 tsp. salt
1 tsp. lime extract or lemon extract
2 cups wood sorrel leaves, seeds, and flowers

1. Stir the agar and arrowroot into the soy-rice milk, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, and simmer 5 minutes, or until the agar is dissolved, stirring often.

2. Combine with the remaining ingredients except for the wood sorrel in a blender and purée.

3. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

4. Stir in the wood sorrel.

Makes 5-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Freezing time: 2-1/2 hours
Beach Pea
beach-pea
Family : Fabaceae, the legume family
Sandy coasts and sandy soil, shores, beaches, dunes, and inland sands
Atlantic, Pacific, and Great Lakes coasts
Because the seeds remain viable floating in salt water for five years, this plant is native to coastal areas around much of the world.

Look for a stout, somewhat angled, green, trailing or clambering herbaceous vine with compound leaves and oval to elliptical, toothless leaflets. Curling tendrils extend from the ends of the leaves, and racemes of white to purple-blue pea-like flowers are followed by tiny, green, hairless pea pods.

This trailing or clambering plant of sandy shores grows up to two feet long, with short, rounded, angles stems.

Branching tendrils grow at the tips of the feather-compound leaves, which consist of three to 12 pairs of long, oval to elliptical, toothless leaflets that grow one to two inches long. Broad, paired, arrowhead-shaped stipules clasp the base of each leafstalk.

In the summer, racemes grow on the upper stalks with three to eight bilaterally symmetrical, showy, pea-like flowers 0.75 inch across. The upper petals are reddish to purple-blue, while the wing petals are white.

From mid- to late summer, smooth, stalkless, hairless, veined seedpods grow on the same racemes, with a row of tiny, smooth, green, spherical peas inside.

•Trailing or clambering herbaceous plant with stout, round, angled stems growing one to two feet long, on sandy shores
•Alternate or opposite feather-compound leaves consisting of three to 12 pairs of leaflets
•Branching tendrils at the tips of the leaves
•Broad, paired, arrowhead-shaped stipules clasping the base of each leafstalk.
•Leaflets one to two inches long, oval to elliptical, and toothless
•Racemes on upper stalks with three to eight bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like flowers 0.75 inch across
•Upper petals reddish to purple-blue, wing petals white
•Smooth, stalkless, hairless, veined seedpods
•A row of tiny green, spherical peas inside each pod
Strip off the tender, immature pods. Split mature pods open with your fingers and remove the peas, in the field or at home. Because they're so small, collecting is labor-intensive, but well worth it.

The immature pods taste like snow peas. If they're tender enough for your taste, add them to salads. Otherwise, they're excellent stir-fried in east Asian dishes, simmered in soups, or included in virtually any recipe that calls for cooked veggies.

The green peas taste like commercial peas, only better (but by the time they turn brown, they become about as edible as the pebbles they resemble). The big problem is their small size. Unless you have unlimited time and patience for collecting and shelling, you're best mixing some into a salad, using them as a garnish, or including them in virtually any vegetable dish as a minor ingredient (or try sprouting them). They cook in five to ten minutes.
Beach peas contain high concentrations of B-complex vitamins, beta-carotene, and protein, similar to commercial peas, but probably more concentrated.
Not used in traditional Western herbal medicine. I've heard mention of the leaves being used in traditional Chinese medicine, but haven't been able to learn any of the details.

1. Warnings have been posted about beach peas containing the same toxic amino acid found in high concentrations in related species, where it causes lanthyrism, an irreversible paralysis similar to what I experienced every time I entered my lethally boring middle school French class. But beach peas would have to constitute 30% if your diet to cause this, and they're so small, you'd probably die of old age before you could collect enough do harm!

2. Sometimes when you open a pod, you'll find a grub inside instead of peas.

Other members of the genus Lanthyrus that don't have all the characteristics described above can cause paralysis or death. Make sure all the characteristics of your plant match those listed here before you eat this plant.

Sounds scary, but this plant is so easy to recognize once she learned it, my five-year-old daughter was collecting it on a seashore vacation without any problems or confusion.
Sea Pea, Circumpolar Pea, Sea Vetchling
These very small, very tasty peas, make a superb trail nibble or garnish when you're in a seashore habitat.
2)Beach Pea in Flower
2beach-pea-in-flower
1)Beach Pea Pods
1beach-pea-pods

The smooth, light green pea-like pods, growing with feather-compound leaves composed of opposite, elliptical leaflets, plus the branched, curly tendrils at the leaf tips, make it clear that you have the right plant.
3)Beach Pea Flower Cluster
3beach-pea-flower-cluster
4)Beach Peas in a Pod
4beach-peas-in-a-pod
Tiny, green, smooth, spherical beach [peas] grow in a single row inside the smooth, green pod, very much like commercial peas, only smaller.
Wild Mint
wild-mint
Lamiaceae, the mint family
Mid-spring through mid-fall
Sunny and partially shaded wet places, ditches, stream banks, gardens, edge habitats, marshes, swamps, and wet meadows
Most of the US and southern Canada, except some of the states in the Deep South

Look for interrupted whorls of tiny, tubular, pale violet to white flowers around the upper leaf axils of a square stem of a medium-sized plant. It has opposite, oval to lance-shaped toothed leaves where each pair grows perpendicular to the pair above and below it. And notice the fragrance of mint.

This colonial mint, which produces stems from nodes along its creeping rhizomes, grows from four to 30 inches tall, although it sometimes sprawls. The stems often branch a few times, and downward-pointing, flattened hairs often grow near the stem's top.

The opposite, short-stalked, deeply veined, oval to lance-shaped, pointed, sharp-toothed leaves, which grow from one to 2.5 inches long and 0.5 to one inch wide (smaller toward the top), are often slightly hairy underneath. Pairs of leaves grow at right angles to those above and below them.

For most of the summer, clusters of tiny, stalkless, tubular, bilaterally symmetrical, pale violet to white flowers 0.125 inch long, with slightly protruding stamens, grow above the upper leaf axils in dense, interrupted whorls 0.5 to 0.75 inch wide. The seed is a tiny nutlet.

•Opposite leaves
•Square stem
•Minty fragrance
•Oval to lance-shaped, toothed leaves, one to 2.5 inches long and 0.5 to one inch wide
•Pairs of leaves growing at right angles to those above and below them
•Clusters of tiny, pale stalkless, tubular, bilaterally symmetrical, violet to white flowers with slightly protruding stamens, growing above the upper leaf axils in dense, interrupted whorls
Break off whole plants for tea, or strip off the leaves for food use.

This is such a tasty mint that the menthol used to flavor food comes from a cultivated variety of this species. Use it like other mint species, for tea, for flavoring fruit dishes, drinks, and desserts, or to complement the flavor of savory dishes. Use any cooking method. It cooks in about 10 minutes.

The above-ground parts are considered an anesthetic, anti-spasmodic, antiseptic, aromatic, anti-inflammatory, carminative, diaphoretic, emmenagogue, galactagogue, febrifuge, stomachic, and stimulant. An infusion is especially good for aiding digestion.

Taken internally, the essential oil, which you'd have to buy, is toxic, and can cause abortion, so pregnant women are advised to avoid mints, just in case, even though normal use of these plants for food is probably safe.
Field Mint, Marsh Mint, American Wild Mint
This is one of the tastiest of the mints. Each set of opposite leaves is perpendicular to the sets above and below it. This helps you tell this aromatic plant apart from its edible relatives.
1)Wild Mint in Flower
1wild-mint-in-flower

Many mints have short-stalked, oval toothed leaves, and they all have square stalks, but the whorled clusters of tiny, white to lilac, stalkless flowers with protruding stamens makes wild mint distinct. Furthermore, each set of opposite leaves grows at right angles to those above and below it on the stalk.
2)Wild Mint Flowers
2wild-mint-flowers

One of the tastiest of mints, the clusters of tiny, tubular white to lilac flowers with protruding stamens, whorled around the stem above the leaf axils, and the way each set of opposite leaves is perpendicular to the those above and below it on the square stem, makes this fragrant species easy to distinguish from the others.
Pure Wild Mint Ice Cream
pure-wild-mint-ice-cream

The only seasoning in this ice cream is wild mint, and lots of it. And that’s all it needs to show off how well my vegan ice cream formulation works, and how good wild mint tastes! Serve as is, or sprinkle with chocolate chips or carob chips.

3-1/2 cups soy-rice milk, almond milk, oat milk, or other non-dairy milk
1 tsp. agar powder or 1 tbs. agar flakes (available in health food stores)
1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
1/2 cup silken tofu, drained
1/2 cup raw pignola nuts or cashews
1/4 lecithin granules
1/4 cup grape seed oil
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin (available in health food stores)
1/3 cup wild mint leaves, or to taste
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia (available in health food stores)
1/2 tsp. salt

1. Bring 2 cups of the soy-rice milk to a boil with the agar, arrowroot, and half the wild mint, in a small saucepan, over medium heat, stirring constantly.

2. Reduce the heat to low and simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes, or until the agar is dissolved, stirring often.

3. Transfer to a blender and purée; with all the remaining ingredients except the remaining mint.

4. Add the remaining mint leaves and blend briefly on low speed until finely chopped.

5. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

Makes 5-1/2 cup

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Freezing time: 120 minutes
Black Birch
black-birch
Betulaceae, the Birch Family
This tree is in season all year. At other times, you can't use it!
Open woodlands, edges of forests, parks.
Eastern North America

Look for a medium-sized tree with smooth, silver-gray bark sometimes cracked, that doesn't peel, streaked with horizontal, whitish lines. Black Birch has alternate, double toothed, medium-sized, oval to elliptical leaves, pendant catkins, and short, stubby upright cones in early spring. Scratch and sniff for the fragrance of wintergreen.

This very tasty, medium-sized tree grows 50 to 80 feet tall, with a trunk up to 2.5 feet across, a rounded crown, and spreading branches. The shiny, smooth, non-peeling bark is marked with distinct, whitish horizontal lenticels. The bark, reddish-brown when young, silver-gray when mature, and dark gray when old. It doesn’t peel in younger trees, but develops irregular cracks as it ages, becoming furrowed and broken into shallow scales.

In the spring, long, yellowish male catkins, two to three inches long, hang from the tips of the slender, reddish-brown, white-dotted twigs. Smaller, stubby, erect, greenish, female flowers, 0.5 to one inch long, grow behind them on same twig tips. Small upright cones, one inch to 1.5 inches long, persist from late summer to winter, with many tiny, hard, winged seeds inside.

Simple, alternate, oval, double-toothed, pointy tipped leaves grow 2.5 to six inches long, with heart-shaped bases, a darker, shiny upper surface, and a paler underside. The leaves turn bright yellow in autumn.In the winter, slender, pointed, reddish-brown and greenish, alternate buds grow on the twigs.

The whole tree smells like wintergreen when injured.

•A medium-sized tree with smooth, non-peeling, silver-gray bark, sometimes cracked, marked by horizontal lines
•Oil of wintergreen fragrance where injured
•Alternate, double-toothed, oval to lance-shaped leaves 2.5 to 6 inches long
•Long, yellowish male catkins, two to three inches, hanging from the tips of the twigs in early spring
•Stubby, erect, greenish, female flowers, 0.5 to one inch long, growing behind the catkins
•Small upright cones, one inch to 1.5 inches long, from summer into winter

Break off the twigs any time of the year and use them fresh or dehydrated. If a tree has recently been felled by a storm, use a knife to collect the green cambium, the green layer of tissue between the bark and wood. But please don't go injuring healthy trees by stripping off the bark to collect the cambium, when the twigs are just as good!

Chew on the twigs in the field. They're delicious and refreshing. Steep them to make a tasty tea. Simmer agar (available in health food stores) in the water beforehand until dissolved, add a sweetener, plus additional sweet seasonings if desired, strain out the twigs, and chill. You'll have a unique black birch jello!

If you've harvested the cambium, you can eat it as is, or use it as a sweet seasoning, fresh or dried, chopped or ground.

An infusion of black birch twigs or cambium contains oil of wintergreen, a.k.a. methyl salicylate, the chemical forerunner of aspirin and a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory, used by the Indians for pain and inflammation. You must drink many cups of a strong tea over a period of hours to achieve an effective dosage, but if you had had pain and inflammation before Bayer synthesized aspirin from the same chemical (originally extracted from white willow tree (Salix alba)), this was the remedy of choice.

Low dose aspirin is prescribed for people with heart disease, to thin the blood and prevent clots in the coronary arteries causing heart attacks, but aspirin increases the risk of internal bleeds that could lead to gastrointestinal ulcers and strokes. It lowers your risk of death if you have heart disease, but give it to millions of healthy people, and the risk outweighs the benefit. A couple of cups of strong black birch tea a day could have the same protective effect, there's no documented evidence of side effects, and it tastes good.

This low dose painkiller worked whenever my daughter, Violet, was teething, stopping the pain every time when she was too young for more concentrated pharmaceutical painkillers. I simply gave her the twigs to chew, and they're too large to swallow. I probably just rediscovered what the Native Americans must have been doing hundreds of years ago, and while I've found no documentation of this practice, they knew about this painkiller, and would have liked to quiet a crying baby as much as anyone else would!

Chewing on the twigs also covers up the bad breath you get from eating wild or cultivated members of the onion family (Allium spp.).

Oil of wintergreen, a concentrate you'd have to buy, is a traditional counter-irritant for arthritis and neuralgia, applied externally as a balm, liniment, or ointment. It's supposed to be an alternative, pain-killer, antiseptic, deobstruent, purgative, diaphoretic, diuretic, parasiticide, pectoral, stomachic, and vulnerary, also used for burns, chafing, cholera, colds, cough, dandruff, diarrhea, dysentery, painful menstruation, gout, gravel, lumbago, rheumatism, scalds, sciatica, sores, and more, but without supporting evidence. However, it's toxic when taken internally, or used excessively externally.

Black birch also contains betulin, which will lower your cholesterol levels, prevent obesity, improve your insulin sensitivity, and increase your resistance to developing atherosclerotic plaques in the arteries, but only if you're a lab mouse, so far.

Taken internally or applied excessively externally, oil of wintergreen (methyl salicylate), a concentrate you'd have to buy, is toxic, and has caused deaths, especially among children and especially sensitive individuals. In 1997, for example, a teenage track star died from using too much liniment containing this substance. If you have problems with aspirin, avoid this plant.

The black cherry tree (Prunus serotina) has similar bark, but way more cracks in larger trees, a bitter almond odor when injured (like that of the inside of an apricot or peach kernels), and different leaves, flowers, and fruit. Although the cambium contains a chemical precursor of cyanide, the poison, if formed, is destroyed by heat.

Other birches (Betula spp.) have lighter-colored barks that peel. Non-poisonous, they don't contain enough oil of wintergreen to make a tasty tea.
Sweet Birch, Cherry Birch
Black birch twigs are great to chew on. They make an excellent, healthful tea, and they're good for bad breath.
2)Black Birch Catkins
2black-birch-catkins
The hanging catkins release pollen into the air in the spring just as the leaves are just beginning to develop from the leaf buds.
4)Black Birch Leaves and Female Flowers
4black-birch-leaves-and-female-flowers
The oval to lance-shaped, alternate, double-toothed leaves, and the upright female catkins, all growing on slender twigs, make this delicious wild food easy to recognize.
5)Black Birch Fruits
5black-birch-fruits
These hard, brown, cone-like fruits will produce hard, winged seeds.
6)Black Birch Bark
6black-birch-bark
The smooth, dark gray bark, dashed with horizontal lenticels and marked with a couple of cracks, is typical for the mature black birch tree.
7)Feeling No Pain
7feeling-no-pain
11-month-old Violet Brill chews on a black birch twig to effectively relieve the pain of teething.
3)This Bud's for You!
3this-buds-for-you!

The slender, reddish-brown, white-dotted twig has alternate buds, corresponding to the alternate leaves they'll become. The bud is narrow and pointed, mostly reddish-brown, with hits of greenish scales showing through. Below the bud are the bundle scars, broken ends of circulatory tubes that connected leaves of previous years to the twig.
Black Birch Jello, from Foraging with Kids By "Wildman" Steve Brill
black-birch-jello,-from-<i>foraging-with-kids<i>-b
1)Black Birch Twig, Leaves, and Buds
1black-birch-twig,-leaves,-and-buds
The shiny, oval, alternate leaves, with their very fine teeth, grow on slender twigs, which already formed buds here, in preparation for the following spring.
Black Locust Tree
black-locust-tree
Fabaceae or Leguminosae, the legume family
The edible flowers bloom from toward the end of mid-spring.
Dry woods, old fields, prairies, savannas, burned areas, and near the seashore.
All of the US, plus SE and SW Canada.
Native to the southeast US, it's been planted throughout the country and in various temperate regions throughout the world.

Look for a tall tree with deeply grooved bark, alternate, feather-compound leaves, paired oval to elliptical leaflets, a lone leading leaflet, pairs of angled spines sometimes growing at the leaf bases, and pendant clusters of showy, fragrant, white, bilaterally symmetrical flowers blooming in mid-spring.

This native Eastern tree provides sweet, vanilla-flavored blossoms in great quantity for a few weeks every spring. Growing from 40 to 100 feet tall and 12 to 30 inches in diameter, the deeply grooved, dark reddish-brown to brown or dark gray bark is composed of deeply furrowed flat ridges. Very young trees have smooth, brown bark, and lots of prickly spines.

Turning yellow-brown in autumn, the alternate, feather-compound leaves grow from six to 14 inches long, with seven to 21 oval to elliptical, toothless leaflets, each one to two inches long. Pairs of small, angled spines, much more common on younger trees than older ones, protect the leaf axils.

In mid-spring, fragrant, white, bilateral-symmetrical flowers 0.75 to one inch across, grow in dense, showy, drooping terminal racemes four to eight inches long. Each flower hangs from a slender, reddish-brown or reddish green flower stalk half an inch long.

Ripening in autumn and persisting through the winter, short, flat, hairless, two-sided, black pods, growing from two to six inches long and 0.75 inch across, contain four to seven flat, hard, black, bean-like seeds under 0.25 inch across. They hang from the tree in such numbers that with very good imagination and very poor vision, they could resemble a swarm of roosting locusts.

•Tall tree with feather-compound leaves
•Paired oval to elliptical, smooth-edged, short-stalked leaflets, plus one lone leading leaflet
•Paired prickles at the base of the leaves
•Pendulous clusters of fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, white, pea-like flowers
•Thick, dark gray or dark brown, ropey bark
•Persistent, small, short, flat, brown seedpods
•Small, hard, flattened, black seeds
Strip off and bag the flowers, which freeze well. You can also collect the mature seeds from the pods.

The flowers, with their strong, sweet, vanilla-like fragrance and flavor, are ideal for salads, ice cream, pies, fruit soups, fritters, pancakes, smoothies, and all variety of desserts. I've even made a delicious wine with them (that one's in my cookbook—plug, plug!). They're can be quite strong-flavored, so use them sparingly, and don't use them with vanilla, or the combined flavors become too intense.

You could also try cooking the seeds like beans, but they're too small to be worthwhile and I never got around to trying them.

The flowers are considered antispasmodic, aromatic, diuretic, and emollient, as well as laxative, but my tour participants and I have been enjoying them in quantity for years, and no one's ever starting running around the parks looking for mullein (Verbascum thapsus) leaves to use as toilet paper, so all the medicinal claims could be wishful thinking. Nevertheless, the flowers contain do benzaldehyde, which may lower the risk of cancer in the low concentrations present.

A decoction made from the cambium was used as an emetic and purgative in the days of heroic herbalism, such harmful treatments aren't used anymore today.

Don't stand under this tall tree during a thunderstorm, when torrents of electrically-conductive rainwater flow down the trunk's deep grooves.

Many books claim the seeds are poisonous, but 1960s foraging guru Ewell Gibbons fed them to his family, so, while I haven't had the patience to collect enough of the tiny seeds to cook myself, I relegate the claims of toxicity to the spurious foraging phobias.

A nearly identical relative with similar edible flowers, the New Mexican locust (R. meomexicana), grows in the Southwest.

The honey locust tree (Gleditsia triacanthos), which has pods with edible seeds and edible pulp, looks a little like the black locust, but it has a densely thorny trunk, and its pods are very long and twisted, not small and short.

The pagoda tree (Styphnolobium japonicum), an Asian ornamental and medicinal plant with poisonous seeds, has feather-compound leaves and drooping racemes with white flowers, like the black locust, but the flowers lack a sweet vanilla fragrance, and they bloom from mid- to late summer, not in the spring.

The ailanthus tree (Ailanthus altissima) has feather-compound leaves, but the leaflets are pointed, they smell like rotten peanut butter when crushed, there are no fragrant, white flowers, and all other features are different too.
False Acacia, Post Locust
This native tree has fabulous, sweet, vanilla-scented and -flavored blossoms that bloom in great profusion for a couple of weeks every year in mid-spring.
Pagoda Tree, Honey Locust,
1)Black Locust Leaf, Flower, and Seed Pod
1black-locust-leaf,-flower,-and-seed-pod

The black locust tree's compound leaf is divided into opposite, oval to elliptical, short-stalked, untoothed leaflets, with a single leaflet at the tip. A pendant raceme produces showy, fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, stalked, white, pea-like flowers. The pod is short and flat, not long and twisted, or thick, like some of the tree's relatives.
2)Black Locust Leaves and Flowers
2black-locust-leaves-and-flowers

The black locust tree's showy raceme of white, bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like flowers hang among the alternate, feather-compound leaves. These consist of paired, short-stalked, oval to elliptical leaflets, and a single leading leaflet at the tip.
4)Black Locust Seed Pods
4black-locust-seed-pods
These short, flat, blackish seed pods hang from the tree like a bunch of locusts, which is how the tree got its name. Inside are flat, hard, unappetizing seeds that people have cooked and eaten.
3)Black Locust Tree, Bark, and Flowers
3black-locust-tree,-bark,-and-flowers

This straight, tall tree has dark gray, reddish-brown, or dark brown bark so deeply furrowed that the bark looks like it's been embossed with rope. It's showy, white, bilaterally symmetrical, short-stalked, pea-like flowers, hanging on racemes, produce such a strong, sweet, vanilla-like fragrance, you can smell the tree a block away. The short, flat, black, slightly curved seedpods contain around nine small, hard, flat, ovate seeds, each in its own compartment.
Sweet Locust Pudding
sweet-locust-pudding

Here’s a great way to enjoy the wonderful flavor of black locust blossoms, similar to a vanilla tapioca pudding, but with vanilla-flavored flowers instead of vanilla. I love locust pudding, even though I'm a vegan who never eats bugs!

4 cups almond milk
1/2 cup pignoli nuts or cashews
1/4 cup lecithin granules
2 tsp. clear liquid stevia (available in health food stores)
2 cups black locust flowers
6 tbs. tapioca pearls

1. Purée the nuts, lecithin, and stevia in the almond milk in a blender.

2. Simmer 10 minutes with the remaining ingredients.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 20 minutes
Bracken
bracken
Family: Dennstaedtiaceae
This plant is in season mainly in mid-spring, although a few individuals remain in season into late spring.
Sunny or lightly shaded habitats, pastures, cultivated fields, disturbed habitats, rocky woods, upland forests, trail- and roadsides, clearcuts, and burnt habitats.
Throughout the US except for S. Dakota, most of southern Canada, and throughout much of the temperate world
This ancient species grows throughout most of the temperate and subtropical world.

Look for a large fern with triangular, three-parted leaves and a smooth, shiny, rigid stem which grows as tall as the leaf and is grooved in front. It has a silvery, hairy base, and fiddleheads with three prongs that look like talons.

This cosmopolitan non-flowering fern, with large, triangular fronds, is as delicious as it's sought after, but it's not without its dangers.

This colonial plant propagates underground by long, branched, woody, hairy, spreading rhizomes. The young shoot or fiddlehead resembles a raptors claws, with three curled-up talon-like prongs. It often grows alongside mature ferns, as well as the skeletons of the previous year's fronds.

The smooth, shiny, rigid stem, which grows as tall as the leaf and is grooved in front, arises from a silvery, hairy base. Green at first, it turns dark brown as it grows.

The mature fern grows from one to ten feet tall, as each branch divides into rows of feathery, blunt-tipped leaflets. Silvery at first due to wooly, silver-gray hairs, the triangular fronds, which grow from one to three feet tall and wide and turn grass-green when mature, bend until they're nearly horizontal. Divided into 3 parts, a longer terminal branch is completely separated from the midrib, while and two opposite branches are not.

Purplish or brownish black spots called nectaries grow where the leaflets join the stalk, providing food for ants. As a fern, the plant lacks flowers, but mature fronds are dotted underneath with the sori—reproductive structures that make spores.

•Fiddlehead with with three curled-up talon-like prongs in mid-spring
•Smooth, shiny, rigid stem as tall as the leaf
•Stem grooved in front, green at first, then dark brown
•Fern base silvery-hairy.
•Triangular frond growing from one to three feet tall and wide, bending until nearly horizontal
•Frond's longer terminal branch completely separated from the midrib, 2 opposite branches not separate from the midrib.
Break off the unopened fiddleheads. Avoid unfurled ones, which are poisonous, and take no more than half of each bunch, so you don't deplete the rhizomes' reserve food supply.

Sautée, steam, or simmer the fiddleheads in soups or stews. They cook in 10 minutes, and taste like a combination of asparagus and green beans. Season them lightly, and avoid using lots of strong-flavored ingredients, or you'll drown out the fiddleheads' delicate flavor.

People from around the world also cook the rhizomes 10 to 15 minutes and separate the starch from the fiber. They also dry them, pound them with mallets, and sift out the starch to use as flour, or as a thickener. I never found bracken in enough quantity to dig them up without causing ecological harm, so I don't know how easy this is to do, but it looks like this kind of processing usually tends to be labor-intensive.
Bracken fiddleheads provide vitamins A and E, plus calcium, phosphorus, potassium, and iron.

Use only the unrolled fiddleheads, not the mature ferns, which are poisonous.

The raw fiddleheads may cause gastric distress, and they contain thiamase, an enzyme that breaks down thiamine and can lead to beriberi if eaten in quantity.

Bracken has at least thee known carcinogens, and has been associated with stomach cancer in Japan, where it's canned and eaten year-around, so it's safer not to eat this seasonal plant regularly throughout the year if you chose to consume it at all.

This plant is common in some places are rare in others. Please leave it alone where it's rare, and collect no more than half the fiddleheads from any one bunch, so the rhizome, which can't put up any new growth until the following spring, isn't starved to death. And certainly don't dig up the rhizomes unless the plant's very common, and then take only a small fraction of them.

Bracken fiddleheads are easy to distinguish from other unopened ferns because of the woolly, grayish-white color, and the lack of a scaly coverings or long hairs, and their three-parted talon-like configuration.
Brake, Brake Fern, Pasture Brake, Eagle Fern
Prized for its fiddleheads in Japan, this contemporary of the dinosaurs spread around the world before the continents split apart.
1)Bracken Fiddlehead
1bracken-fiddlehead
The three-pronged fiddlehead, like a bird's talons, makes this species distinct.
2)Mature Bracken
2mature-bracken

The large, triangular, three-parted frond, spreading horizontally, plus the accompanying botanical garden's sign, make the identity of this fern certain! Still, you can't eat it now. The mature fern is poisonous, only the immature form is safe.
Bracken Minestroni
bracken-minestroni
Bull Thistle
bull-thistle
Asteraceae or Compositae, the aster, daisy, or sunflower family
The taproot's edible in the fall, in the winter where there are mild winters, and in early spring, and the fiddlehead's in season in mid-spring.
Sunny or partially shaded disturbed habitats, untended gardens, pastures, fields, thickets, trail- and roadsides, edges, forest clearcuts, wetlands, and riverbanks.
Throughout the US and most of Canada
Eurasia, Northern Africa

Look for a seriously spiny plant that begins as a basal rosette with very hairy, deeply lobed, lance-shaped basal leaves. Similarly stalkless, bull thistle has alternate stem leaves with leaf bases descending the stem pink to magenta flower heads that look like shaving brushes on ovate bases, and tiny seeds with tufts of white hairs.

This forbiddingly spiny, coarse, erect invasive Eurasian plant has both tasty roots and a delicious stem.

The plant begins with a basal rosette of very hairy, lance-shaped, feather-compound leaves up to 1.5 feet long, with spines at the midribs and tips of the lobes. Coarse hairs grow on the leaves' upper surfaces, while the undersides are wooly.

A stout, hairy, spiny stem that usually branches in the middle and grows from three to 12 feet tall arises in mid-spring of the second year, with similar alternate leaves. Lacking leaf stalks, the leaves' thorny bases descend the stem on prominent ridges, arming it with spiny "wings."

From late spring to early fall, terminal, pink to magenta, shaving brush-shaped flower heads both one to two inches long and wide, usually grow individually (sometimes in groups) above green, ovoid bases—each composed of fused, spine-tipped bracts. Many tiny, slender, tubular disk flowers, without ray flowers, comprise the composite flower head. The wind blows off the tiny straw-colored seeds, along with tufts of white hair, known as thistledown.

Several light brown, fleshy, branching taproots three to 12 inches long, grow underground.

•Basal rosette consisting of long, lance-shaped, very hairy, spiny, feather-compound leaves
•Long, sharp spines at the leaves' midribs and the tips of the leaves' lobes (and just about everywhere else!)
•Leaves' upper surfaces coarsely hairy
•Leaves' undersides wooly
•Stout, prickly stems three to 12 feet tall, often branching
•Long, alternate, lance-shaped, very hairy, spiny, feather-compound stem leaves
•Stalkless leaves' thorny bases descending the stem on prominent ridges
•Pink to magenta shaving brush-shaped flower heads, both one to two inches long and wide
•Flower heads growing above ovoid, prickly, green bases
•Flower heads composed of many tiny, slender, pink, tubular disk flowers
•Seeds, tiny and straw-colored, attached to tufts of white hair
•Light brown fleshy, branching taproots three to 12 inches long

Always wear heavy duty work gloves when handling this plant.

1. Dig up the taproots of the basal rosette with a shovel or trowel. Choose a location where the plant is common, but rocks are not, and dig after it's rained when the soil is yielding, not during a drought. Use a knife to trim off the foliage.

2. Before the stem is fully grown and while it still feels soft and flexible, long before the flowers develop, cut it off with a pocket knife, cut off and discard the leaves, and peel the stem to get rid of the prickles. This is easier to do in the field than bringing home bags full of large, bulky, prickly plants.

Use the peeled, immature stems like celery. It has a similar texture but tastes better than celery. It's excellent raw in salads and sandwiches, and you'll love it cooked 10 to 15 minutes in virtually any savory dish, using any cooking method.

The taproots taste like a combination of Jerusalem artichokes and parsnips. Slice them and cook 15 to 20 minutes in soups, stews, or casseroles.

Although the young leaves are edible, you'd have to spend the rest of your life cutting off the prickles before you get to try them.

While detailed information is lacking, the roots contain inulin, a sweet-tasting polysaccharide that doesn't cause a blood sugar spike, good for diabetes and hypogycemia, although it gives some people gas.

Not a major medicinal plant, people used both a poultice and decoction of the roots for sore jaws, and made an herbal steam of the whole plant for treating rheumatic joints. A decoction of the whole plant has also been used both internally and externally for bleeding piles. But since there's been no research on unfortunate rheumatic people with bleeding piles who were socked in the jaw, there's no telling whether or not it's effective.
Don't handle this plant without heavy duty work gloves. The spines are long and very sharp, and can even pierce such gloves, so handle with care.

Other non-poisonous thistles may resemble bull thistle:

Canada Thistle (C. arvense) has similar flower head, but rhizomes rather than a taproots, and no basal rosettes. Since this invasive species provides no food, the only good thing to do with Canada thistle is send it back to Canada! And musk thistle (Carduus nutans) looks similar, but its leaves usually lack hairs.

Sow thistles, which include the common sow thistle (Sonchus oleraceus) are edible, but they aren't true thistles. However, they have bristles that don't hurt you, and white, milky sap, which true thistles lack.
Canada Thistle, Californian Thistle, Canadian Thistle, Creeping Thistle, Field Thistle, Corn Thistle, Perennial Thistle
This prickly, invasive nuisance plant hides a tasty stem under a coating of very nasty thorns, and it's taproots are good to eat too.
Common Sow Thistle
1)Bull Thistle Basal Rosette
1bull-thistle-basal-rosette
Delicious taproots, available to anyone with a shovel and heavy-duty work gloves, underlie this intimidating mass of prickly leaves.
2)Bull Thistle Basal Rosette and Taproot
2bull-thistle-basal-rosette-and-taproot
These light brown, branching taproots are great cooked in soups or stews—just leave out the lance-shaped, hairy, prickly, basal leaves!
3)Bull Thistle's Immature Stem
3bull-thistles-immature-stem

All the prickles on these immature stems are protecting something good! Wearing heavy-duty work gloves, cut off the alternate, lance-shaped, armored leaves and peel the stems. The insides taste like super-delicious celery!
5)Bull Thistle Flower Head
5bull-thistle-flower-head

Shaped like a shaving brush, the flattened flower head is composed of many tiny, pink, slender tubular flowers. The unsual-looking, prickly green base is composed of fused sepals. Underneath grow long, alternate, lance-shaped, feather-compound leaves. Each lobe ends with a long, sharp prickle.
6)Bull Thistle Seed Head
6bull-thistle-seed-head
The seed head is composed of many tiny, light brown seeds connected to tufts of white hairs ready to fly with the wind.
7)Bull Thistle Hair Tuft
7bull-thistle-hair-tuft
Tufts of hair will carry the underlying seed off to create more torment and misery for the unwary (or more food for the prepared forager)!
4)Bull Thistle in Flower
4bull-thistle-in-flower

Mature bull thistle can reach 12 feet in height. The prickly stem supports long, lance-shaped, prickly, feather-compound leaves, plus the pink to magenta flower heads shaped like shaving brushes that on top of prickly, ovoid bases. The plant is easiest to recognize at this stage, but no longer edible.
Split Pea Soup with Bull Thistle Roots
split-pea-soup-with-bull-thistle-roots

Here’s a better-than-ever vegan version of a traditional favorite, with tasty bull thistle roots for additional flavor.

2 cups split peas, rinsed
5 cups vegetable stock or water
1/4 cup corn oil
2 onions, chopped
2 cloves of garlic, chopped
1 cup bull thistle roots, chopped
1 tbs. fresh basil, chopped
1 tsp. black pepper, ground
1 tsp. thyme, ground
1 tsp. hot or sweet paprika
4 northern bayberry leaves or 2 bay leaves
2 tbs. Bragg’s liquid aminos (available in health food stores)
1 tsp. Vege-sal (available in health food stores) or seasoned salt, or to taste
6 tofu pups or other vegan hot dogs, sliced
2 cups poor man’s pepper leaves or arugula, chopped
1/4 cup vegan bacon bits (available in health food stores)

1. Simmer the peas, basil, pepper, thyme, bayberry leaves, and paprika in the stock 1 to 2 hours, or until the peas are tender.

2. Meanwhile, sautée the onions, garlic, tofu pups, and carrots in the corn oil 15 minutes.

3. Add to the soup along with the all remaining ingredients except for the vegan bacon bits, bring to a boil, and simmer 5 minutes.

4. Serve garnished with the vegan bacon bits.

Serves 6 to 8

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 2 hours
Carrion Flower
carrion-flower
Family: Smilacaceae, the catbrier family
The plant is best in mid-spring, when there are lots of tender shoots, although you can still find some of these into early summer.
Partially shaded moist habitats with rich soil, i.e, thickets, edge habitats, trail sides, fence rows, open woods, swampy forests, and wooded coves
The eastern half the the US and most of eastern Canada

Look for a smooth, non-woody, thornless vine with oval to heart- or lance-shaped leaves, paired tendrils, and a ball of small, stinky, six-petaled flowers, or a ball or bluish-green spherical berries.

Growing 6 to 10 feet long and up to one inch thick, this light green to purplish, smooth, cylindrical, climbing, non-woody, branching vine's shoots taste a lot better than its flowers smell. Their odor of decomposing flesh attract flies and repels people.

The oval to heart-shaped or lance-shaped, smooth, alternate leaves, growing up to three to five inches long and 2.5 inches wide, have parallel veins. With paired tendrils at their bases, bright green, hairless leafstalks grow up to 1.75 inches long.

Umbels of flowers grow from the upper and middle leaves' axils, each connected to the stem by a long thick stalk that grows from four to ten inches long. Growing on separate vines in spherical clusters one to two inches across, 20 to 120 foul-smelling, six-parted, green to yellow-green, male or female flowers 0.25 inch across set individually on stalks that range from 1.5 to three inches across, bloom in early summer.

Dull bluish-green, rubbery, spherical berries grow in the same balls. Each berry grows to about 0.25 inch across, and contains about three to five seeds.

•Light green to purplish, smooth, cylindrical, climbing, non-woody, branching vine six to ten feet long and up to one inch thick
•Oval to heart-shaped or lance-shaped, smooth, alternate, stalked leaves, growing up to three to five inches long and 2.5 inches wide, with parallel veins
•Umbels of green-yellow flowers one to two inches across
•Spherical flower clusters 1.5 to three inches across, growing from the upper and middle leaves' axils, connected to the stem by a long, thick stalk four to ten inches long
•20 to 120 foul-smelling, six-parted, green to yellow-green flowers 0.25 inch across, set individually on stalks ranging from 1.5 to three inches across
•Balls of dull bluish-green spherical berries, each about 0.25 inch across
Break off the shoots where they're tender and break easily, along with any immature leaves that are tender enough to chew.

Enjoy the tender shoots and tender, young leaves raw, or cooked for 5 to 10 minutes. They taste like asparagus, a distant relative, and you can use them the same way as asparagus in virtually any dish that calls for vegetables, using any cooking method.

Botanists have recently divided carrion flower into a number of closely related species, but even if this takes hold, they all have the very similar general features (although some lack tendrils or don't smell as bad as others), and you use them all the same way.

Closely related greenbriers (Smilax spp.), also edible, differ because they have woody vines, plus thorns.
Carrion Vine
This non-woody vine, with stinky flowers, has shoots and leaves flavored like asparagus.
greenbrier
2)Carrion Flower Shoot and Immature Flower Cluster
2carrion-flower-shoot-and-immature-flower-cluster
1)Carrion Flower Shoot
1carrion-flower-shoot

Carrion flower is a smooth, thornless vine with paired tendrils arising from the leaf axils, and lance-shaped, oval, or heart-shaped, stalked leaves. The vine looks flexible and tender here, the perfect stage to break off the shoots and young leaves and enjoy them!
Wild Brown Rice with Carrion Flower
wild-brown-rice-with-carrion-flower

Here’s a simple brown rice recipe where carrion flower, wild rice, and suitable flavorings make it perfect, and it’s simple to prepare.

4 cups boiling water
1-3/4 cup basmati brown rice (available in health food stores)
1/4 cup wild rice
1/2 red onion, chopped
1 cup carrion flower, greenbrier, or asparagus, chopped
2 large cloves of garlic, chopped
2 tsp. sesame oil
1 tsp. dark sesame oil
1 tbs. tamari soy sauce
1 tsp. Vege-sal (available in health food stores) or 1/2 tsp. salt, or to taste
1 tsp. chili paste or hot sauce

Simmer all ingredients together, covered, in a saucepan, over low heat, 40 to 60 minutes, or until all the liquid has been absorbed.

Makes 6 cup

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 40 to 60 minutes
Common Cattail
common-cattail
Family: Typhaceae, the cattail family

Shoots: early spring to early summer—best from mid- to late spring

Immature male flower heads: late spring

Mature male flower heads' pollen: late spring

Rhizomes: fall, winter, and early spring
Sunny, fresh to slightly brackish, shallow water, wetlands, marshes, ditches, wet meadows
Throughout most of north America and most of the Northern Hemisphere

Look for dense stands of tall freshwater wetland plants with narrow basal leaves only. The tight, cylindrical flower heads are first green, then covered with golden pollen, and finally with fluffy, white seeds that overwinter and persist into spring.

One of the best plants for foragers of any level of knowledge, this tasty, abundant, widespread, easy-to-recognize wetland plant has several edible parts. Cattails grow in dense colonies, spreading from stout rhizomes usually 0.25 to 1.25 inches across, and up to 27 inches long, growing three to four inches beneath the mud or sand.

The 12 to 16 erect, flat, linear, basal leaves grow from three to ten feet tall and 0.33 to 0.75 inches wide. With parallel veins and a spongy cross section, a clear, mucilaginous substance oozes from between the leaves.

The erect, leafless stem grows from six to ten feet tall, 0.375 to 0.75 inches across, tapering toward the top. Male and female flowers grow on separate parts of an unjointed, terminal, cylindrical spike six inches long and one inch across, with the male always on top, befitting a very ancient plant that evolved before the sexual revolution! Green at first, the flower head’s mature male section becomes covered with golden pollen in late spring.

After the male flower withers, the green female section turns brown in the summer, then becomes covered with fluffy, white seeds in late fall. The seed head persists into early spring, making it easy to differentiate a stand of cattails from other wetland plants.

•12 to 16 erect, flat, linear, exclusively basal leaves, growing from three to ten feet tall and 0.33 to 0.75 inches wide
•Erect, leafless stem growing from six to ten feet tall and 0.375 to 0.75 inches across
•Separate male and female flowers growing on an unjointed, terminal, cylindrical spike six inches long and one inch across
•Flower spike first green, then covered with golden pollen, next brown, and finally coated with fluffy, white seeds
•Colonial plant growing in wetland habitats

It's much easier to harvest any part of the cattail in periods of dry weather, when you can walk right up to the plants, rather than after lots of rain, when you have to walk through water or slog through mud, so try to plan your activities accordingly (or buy wading boots!)

Shoot: Before an individual stalk flowers, pull apart some of the outer leaves, grab the core, and pull.

Male (upper) immature green flower head: Clip with shears or heavy-duty scissors, or cut off with a knife.

Pollen: After days without wind (which blows away the pollen), repeatedly bend mature flower heads over a paper bag and shake. Sift out the debris later. Or collect the immature male spikes and let them mature at home.

Rhizomes: Wrench the rhizomes, along with any small lateral shoots, out of the mud, and hose them down thoroughly to remove the mud.

Shoots: The peeled shoots are delicious, substantial, and easy to collect, especially as they get quite large before they flower (once they flower the shoots become incredibly tough), with a flavor of cucumber and zucchini. Use this very versatile food raw, or cook using virtually any cooking method, in any recipe that calls for vegetables. They cook in about 10 to 15 minutes.

Immature green male flower heads: Steam, bake with seasoned oil, or boil 15 to 20 minutes—they're a little like corn-on-the-cob, but drier, so they're at their best served with a sauce.

Pollen: Sweet and tasty, use it to supplement whole-grain flour in breads, muffins, pancakes, waffles, or any baked goods. Lacking gluten, it won't help bread rise, so you can use it in recipes that call for flour that don't need to rise, or supplement non-gluten flours with ground flax seeds or chia seeds, plus guar or xanthan gum.

Rhizomes: This is an impractical wild food. Wrenching the interconnected rhizomes out of the mud is back-breaking, time-consuming work. Even with a garden hose, cleaning off all the embedded mud is also very labor-intensive, even more difficult for apartment dwellers doing this in a kitchen sink.

Once cleaned, you can separate the starch from the inedible fibers by rubbing the fibers with your fingers in a bowl of water, and waiting an hour for the starch to settle to the bottom before pouring off the water. Every time I tried this, a got a few tablespoons of tasty starch—enough to thicken a pot of soup—after hours of work. Or you can also tear apart the rhizomes, dehydrate them in a food dehydrator, pound with a mallet, and sift. If you're into wilderness survival, you can chew on the washed rhizomes and spit out the fibers—definitely not fine gourmet dining!

Only a few foragers report better success with cattail rhizomes than I've experienced. One said that they found large, easy to harvest rhizomes along the Banana River in Florida, but that's a subtropical habitat substantially different from the rest of the US. Harvesting cattails in sandy wetlands, rather than the muddy ones, might also make a difference, but don't expect this to be quick or easy if you decide to attempt it.

The lateral shoots on the rhizomes taste like the shoots, but they're small and buried in mud, so it's easier to wait until they become substantial above-water shoots, in mid-spring, before harvesting them.

The shoots provide vitamins K and B6, plus iron, phosphorus, calcium, sodium, magnesium, potassium and manganese.

The immature, green flower heads and the pollen provide essential fatty acids, calories, and protein.

The mucilaginous substance from between the leaves makes an excellent hand lotion. It's been used as an antiseptic for cuts and as a dental anesthetic, although I'm skeptical as to its efficacy.

The rhizomes have been pounded into a poultice and applied to skin sores cuts, wounds, burns, stings, and bruises.

The pollen has been used externally and internally for bleeding, but I'd also have to see convincing evidence that it works before I'd use it.
Never yank out a cattail if there's an animal rights activist watching!

Young cattail shoots resemble the poisonous daffodil (Amaryllidaceae) and iris (Iris spp.) shoots, which have similar leaves. But remnants of the previous year’s cottony seed heads make the cattail unmistakable, the cattail shoot has a tender, white, inner core, neither of these poisonous plants grows more than a few feet tall, and by mid-spring, the much larger cattail shoot becomes obvious, even for beginners.
Broad-leaf Cattail, Cat-o'-nine-tails, Bullrush
This is one of the best-tasting, most versatile, widespread, and easy-to-recognize plants, with several edible parts.
Common Reed
Daffodil, Iris
Baked Cattail Flower Heads
baked-cattail-flower-heads

You can’t get much simpler than this one--only 2 ingredients, but a perfect combination. Cattail flower heads are flavorful but dry, so Spiceberry Butter Sauce is just right for them.

24 green (immature) cattail flower heads
2 tbs. Spiceberry Butter Sauce

Toss the cattail flower in the Spiceberry Butter Sauce and bake on a rack over a cookie sheet covered with a non-stick baking sheet, or over an oiled cookie sheet 10 to 15 minutes or until lightly browned. Be careful not to let the cattails burn.

Preparation time: 5 minutes

Cooking time: 15 minutes
1)Cattail Shoot and Mature and Immature Flower Heads
1cattail-shoot-and-mature-and-immature-flower-head

The tender, white core inside the long, narrow basal leaves that comprise the shoot are delicious in any variety of recipes. The immature green, cylindrical flower head is great cooked like corn-on-the-cob and served with a sauce, while golden pollen of the mature flower head provides a delicious, healthful, attractive-looking flour.
2)Cattail Shoot
2cattail-shoot
The best time to collect these shoots is when they're tall, but before they've flowered. The very long, narrow, exclusively basal leaves make these cylindrical shoots easy to recognize.
3)Cattail Mature Flower Head
3cattail-mature-flower-head

Covered with golden pollen and partially capped by a tapering papery sheath, the golden, cylindrical male flower spike grows above the female spike. Long, tall, narrow, flat, parallel-veined basal leaves extend above the flowers.
4)Cattail Flower Heads and Peeled Shoot
4cattail-flower-heads-and-peeled-shoot

The most familiar part of the cattail, the bare, brown seed head, persists into the spring, a good indicator of this plant. Before that, it's covered with fluffy seeds, which blow away in the wind. It's not edible in either of these stages. But the crunchy core of the peeled shoot, which tastes cucumbers and zucchini, are superb, cooked or raw.
Common Milkweed
common-milkweed
Family: Apocynaceae, the dogbane family

Shoots: mid-spring

Top of the stems with young, upper leaves: mid- to late spring

Flower buds: late spring to mid-summer

Flowers: late spring to mid-summer

Immature seed pods: early to mid-summer
Sunny habitats, old fields, pastures, roadsides, disturbed habitats, poor, sandy soil, fields and dunes near shores, thickets, woodland borders, vacant lots, and fence rows
Most of North America east of the Rocky Mountains, plus Oregon

Look for a medium-sized, upright plant with a stout, unbranched, finely downy stem. It has large, smooth-edged, oval to lance-shaped leaves, spherical clusters of broccoli-like flower buds which yield fragrant, pink, five-petaled flowers. The seed pods are pickle-shaped.

This upright, unbranched plant has a stout stalk that's finely hairy under magnification. Growing from two to six feet tall, it contains a bitter, sticky, white, milky latex—protection against most insects, except for the monarch butterfly, which is adapted to the plant. Spreading, white rhizomes give rise to true roots and small or large stands of plants.

Downy underneath, smooth above, and tapering to a rounded point at each end, the thick, velvety, toothless, broadly oval to lance-shaped, opposite leaves grow from four to nine inches long and two to 4.5 inches wide. The main vein is reddish, and the leaf stalk is short.

Resembling loose heads of broccoli, the long-stemmed, spherical flower buds, 1.5 to five inches across, emerge from the upper leaf axils. The subsequent long-stemmed, fragrant, purple-pink, hooded, attractive flowers grow in umbrella-like spherical clusters that often droop. Each of the 30 to 120 flowers in each cluster grows up to 0.5 inch tall and nearly 0.25 inch across, divided into five radially-symmetrical parts. The five reflexed sepals grow longer than the flowers.

The teardrop-shaped, grayish-green, hairy, mature seed pods look like warty cucumbers. Growing up to four inches long, they become filled with tufts of silky hairs attached to tiny, flattened, brown seeds that disperse into the wind. Skeletons of the dead stalks and split seed pods often persist through the winter.

•Upright, unbranched, stout-stemmed plant usually three to five feet tall
•Stem with some very small, fine hairs
•Opposite, smooth-edged, short-stalked, oval to lance-shaped leaves four to nine inches long and two to 4.5 inches wide
•Flower buds in spherical clusters 1.5 to five inches across, emerging from the upper leaf axils
•Long-stemmed, fragrant, purple-pink, hooded, radially symmetrical five-petaled flowers 0.5 inch tall and up to 0.25 inch across
•Sepals longer than the flowers
•Teardrop-shaped, grayish-green, hairy seedpods growing up to four inches long
•Tiny, flattened, brown seeds attached to tufts of silky hairs
•White, milky sap throughout

Snap off the tender, young stems along with their leaves when the shoots first appear in mid-spring. Later in the spring, snap off the tender, breakable tops of the stems with their accompanying leaves and flower buds, or break off the flower buds separately. In late spring, break off the open flowers. In early- to mid-summer, snap off the small, immature, firm seedpods. Avoid any rubbery, maturing seed pods.

Milkweed tastes like a combination of asparagus and broccoli, and the immature seed pods have the texture of okra. Cook all edible parts 15 to 20 minutes in rapidly boiling water (don't start cooking with cold water), except for the open flowers, which only require 1 minute of boiling. This gets rid of the bitter, toxic, white sap.

Since many milkweed species contain cardiac glycocides, I used to follow the long-accepted recommendations of boiling most parts in 2 changes of water, but after other foragers never got ill after boiling once, I now boil once, and write to tell: Yes, 1 boiling turns out to be safe.

After boiling, drain in a colander and press the milkweed against its sides with a large serving spoon, to extract as much water as possible and reduce sogginess.

While the milkweed's boiling, preparing savory seasonings is optional. You can sautée garlic in olive oil and stir that into the drained milkweed, along with some tamari soy sauce or Bragg's liquid aminos (both of which contain salt and emani or meaty flavors). Or sautée Thai seasonings, i.e., basil, ginger, cilantro, and hot peppers (optional), in coconut oil, and add that to the cooked milkweed along with some salt. Any source of salt, oil, and herbs or spices, all from 1 culinary tradition, should work.

And to transform it from a side dish into an entrée, include a culinarily compatible source of protein, i.e., whole grain noodles, glass noodles, tofu, texturized vegetable protein, cooked beans, or tempeh. You can get even more elaborate with the addition of other vegetables, nuts, diced pineapple, or mushrooms, again choosing a set traditionally used in one of the world's great culinary traditions.

Various Native American tribes used milkweed sap to remove warts, and to treat ringworm and bee stings, and they used an infusion of the whole plant as a laxative, for gravel and edema, mastitis, and a variety of disparate ailments. It's a folk remedy for asthma, bronchitis, cancer, catarrh, cough, edema, dysentery, dyspepsia, fever, gallstones, gonorrhea, moles, pleurisy, pneumonia, rheumatism, ringworm, scrofula, sores, ulcers, warts, and wounds, but there's no independent evidence that any of the aforementioned uses works.

Milkweed rhizomes contain cardiac glycosides with potential for treating heart disease, but without adequate research to characterize the properties of the individual chemicals, their specific effects on the different parts of the heart and circulatory system, correct dosages, or unusual individual reactions, so they could easily do more harm than good, and should be avoided until after such research gets the funding it deserves.

Common milkweed is poisonous raw, and it gives some individuals vomiting and diarrhea even after it's cooked, so eat very small amounts of this plant at first, and gradually increase your portions until you're sure you don't get such reactions.

Due to habitat destruction, common milkweed is rare in some regions. Please collect only where it's very common, and do not disturb any monarch butterfly caterpillars you may find on milkweed plants—they're in trouble due to habitat destruction too.

Eat only common milkweed. Other milkweed species (Asclepias spp.), which are poisonous, have smooth seed pods, and some have clear sap. Many grow in Western North America.

Young poisonous dogbane (Apocynum spp.) shoots closely resemble those of common milkweed before dogbane begins to branch and develop different flowers, and the two plants often grow side-by-side. Dogbane has smooth stems, whereas a few small hairs grow on milkweed's stems, clearly apparent under magnification.

Milkweed shoots are fair game for experienced foragers armed with magnifying loops, but beginners who value their lives should stick to the distinctive flower buds, flowers, and young seed pods.
Butterfly Flower, Common Silkweed, Silky Swallowwort, Silkweed, Silky Swallow-wort, Virginia Silkweed, Cottonweed, Milkweed, Wild cotton, Virginia-silk
This is a delicious plant you can eat in different stages of its development, but don't forage for the youngest plants if you're an unsupervised beginner. It has a very similar deadly look-alike.
Dogbane
Savory Milkweed
savory-milkweed

The combination of spices plus common milkweed here is way greater than the sum of its parts. Serve it over noodles or brown rice, and you'll be collecting milkweed every year.

8 cups common milkweed shoots, flower buds, tops, sliced young pods, all sliced.
3 tbs. peanut oil
3 tbs. corn oil or flax seed oil
2 tsp. whole cumin seeds
1/4 tsp. crushed red pepper
1/4 cup fresh basil, chopped
1 tbs. garlic, chopped
1/2 tsp. coriander seeds, ground
6 tbs. brewer’s or nutritional yeast
1/4 tsp. cloves
1 tsp. tamari soy sauce

1. Boil the milkweed in rapidly boiling, salted water 20 minutes, drain in a colander, and press against the sides of the colander with a serving spoon to drain thoroughly.

2. Meanwhile, cook the cumin seeds and crushed red pepper in the peanut oil and corn oil over low heat 2 to 3 minutes, stirring constantly.

2. Add the basil and garlic and cook another minute, stirring often.

3. Add the remaining ingredients except for the milkweed, remove it from the heat, and allow it to cook in the hot pan another 2 minutes, stirring often.

3. Add the milkweed and heat through if necessary.

Serves 6

Cooking time: 30 minutes
