Common milkweed arises from a branching rhizome that gives rise to erect, unbranched shoots with opposite leaves. Thick, opposite, toothless, elliptical leaves also grow from the mature plant's stem, and whole plant exudes a white, milk sap where cut.

The long-stalked, spherical, green flower buds resemble broccoli. When the five-petaled flowers open, the sphere turns pink.
Common Spicebush
common-spicebush
Family: Lauraceae, the laurel family

You can make tea with the twigs all year, and with the leaves from mid-spring to mid-fall.

The berries are in season from early- to mid-fall.
Damp, partially shaded, rich woodlands, on mountains’ lower slopes, in moist thickets and swamps, and along trail sides, streams, and riverbanks
Throughout most of the eastern United States, except the northernmost regions.

Look for a medium-sized shrub with oval to oblong, alternate leaves of varying sizes and clusters of tiny, yellow flowers growing in the leaf axils before the leaves appear. In the fall look for ovate to oblong, small, red berries.

This medium-sized, spreading, deciduous, colonial shrub, with olive-brown to gray-brown bark speckled with light-colored lenticels, grows from five to 20 feet tall.

The bright green, alternate, toothless, pointy-tipped, oval to oblong, short-stalked leaves, which turn yellow to golden in autumn, grow from two to six inches long and up to 2.5 inches wide. Small, stunted leaves appear along with full-grown ones. The crushed leaves smell lemony, like Fruit Loops†.

Dense clusters of tiny, short-stalked, fragrant yellow flowers with 6 sepals and no petals bloom in the leaf axils in early spring, before the leaves appear, male and female flowers growing on separate shrubs. Also growing in the same clusters from the leaf axils, short-stalked, scarlet, ovate to oblong berries about 0.375 inch long, each containing one large, brown, ovate seed, replace the flowers on the female shrubs in autumn. The injured berries smell like allspice, as do the twigs.

•Medium-sized, spreading shrub with olive-brown to gray-brown bark spotted with whitish lenticels.
•Oval to oblong entire leaves two to four inches long and up to 2.5 inches wide
•Fully grown and stunted leaves on the same shrub
•Dense clusters of tiny, fragrant, yellow flowers, growing in the leaf axils in early spring
•Oblong to ovate, small, red berries, each containing one large, oblong to ovate, brown seed
•All parts fragrant, like lemon, allspice, or Fruit Loops†, when crushed
Break off the twigs any time. Strip off the leaves or flowers when present, and pick clusters of berries with your fingers.

Make an infusion of the fresh (drying them drives away the flavor) twigs, leaves, or berries. Some people also like to chew on the twigs. Hunters use them as skewers to season venison, so they should work the same way for veggies or tofu. Don't eat the leaves. They have an unpleasantly bitter flavor that doesn't pass into the tea.

Use the finely chopped berries to season main courses, side dishes, and desserts. They're similar to allspice, and impart an exotic flavor to any recipe.

The berries are too oily to dry, since oil becomes rancid upon exposure to oxygen whether or not there's water present. Freeze them separately on a plate, tray, or cookie sheet, then transfer them into a freezer container, where they won't stick together. Then you can remove and use them as needed.

The Native Americans used a spiceberry cambium infusion as a diaphoretic for coughs, colds, and measles. They also used it for cramps, anemia, delayed menstruation, croup, and worms.

They used the oil from the berries externally for chronic arthritis and bruises, and internally for flatulence and colic. Spicebush leaf, bark, or berry tea compresses were also used for mild skin irritations, i.e., rashes, itching, and bruises. These traditional uses have not been verified or disproven.
Be careful when harvesting spiceberries not to bump into one of the Spice Girls!

The common winterberry's (Ilex verticillata) red berries cause vomiting and diarrhea, but the leaves are toothed, and the bush is odorless, so you'd have to make a concerted effort to disregard these differences if you wanted to poison yourself.
Spicebush, Northern Spicebush, Wild Allspice, Benjamin Bush
This is one of the best wild herbal seasonings, transforming entrées and desserts into exotic treats.
Carnelian Cherry
Common Winterberry
2)Spicebush Chocolate Chip Cookies
2spicebush-chocolate-chip-cookies

Here’s my healthful, vegan version of one of the most common cookie recipes. As I've come to learn, refined white flour is totally unnecessary. The whole-grain flours make the cookies chewy and tasty. Likewise, a few dates and some liquid stevia do away with the need for white sugar, even with unsweetened chocolate’s intrinsic bitterness. Corn oil imparts the flavor of butter, lecithin granules and flax seeds replace the egg yolks and -whites respectively, and the seasonings, especially the common spicebush berries, enhance the other flavors. You’ll love these cookies, even if you're skeptical of vegan cuisine.

1-1/2 cup sugar-free vegan chocolate chips or carob chips

Dry Ingredients

11 oz. buckwheat flour (2-1/3 cup) + 8 oz. (1 cup) sweet brown rice flour, or 17 of oz. any whole-grain flour
2 tbs. flaxseeds ground into 1/4 cup meal
1/2 cup unsweetened Dutch cocoa powder
1 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1 tsp. star anise, ground
1 tsp. cream of tartar, ground
1/2 tsp. baking soda, ground
1/2 tsp. salt

Ingredients to Blend

1-1/2 cups soy-rice milk, nut milk, or oat milk
1/4 cup corn oil
1/4 cup Medjool (soft) dates, pitted
1 tbs. liquid stevia
2-1/2 tbs. lecithin granules
2 tsp. vanilla
1 tsp. common spicebush berries or ground allspice

1. Mix together the dry ingredients.

2. Purée the ingredients to blend in a blender.

3. Mix the wet ingredients with the dry ingredients. Don’t over-mix.

4. Stir in the chocolate chips.

5. Spoon about 1-1/2 tbs. at a time onto 2 nonstick baking pads on 2 cookie sheets, or use 2 oiled cookie sheets.

6. Bake 15 to 20 minutes in a preheated 350 degree oven, or until an inserted cake tester or toothpick emerges clean.

7. Cool on racks.

Makes 32 cookies

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Baking time 15 minutes

Here’s an authentic-tasting non-dairy mock butter sauce flavored with common spicebush berries. It’s great for vegans who miss the flavor of butter. Use as a spread or for sauteing.

1 cup grape seed oil

6 tbs. lecithin granules
3 tbs. mellow (light-colored) miso
2 tbs. parsley
1 tbs. common spicebush (Lindera benzoin) berries (36 berries) or 1/2 tbs. ground allspice
1 clove of garlic
1/4 tsp. white pepper

Puree all ingredients in a blender.

Makes 2 cup

Cow Parsnip
cow-parsnip
Family: Apiaceae or Umbelliferae, the carrot family
The stems are good to eat from mid- to late spring, the taproots in early spring, and in the fall if basal rosettes are present.
Partially shaded wet areas, old meadows, grasslands, open woods, trail sides, roadsides, ditches, and edges habitats
Throughout most of North America except for parts of the Deep South.

Look for a very large, woolly, fragrant, branching plant with very large, alternate, there-parted, palmate-compound leaves. The toothed leaflets are lobed, and five-petaled flowers grow in large, flat, and twice-branched, umbrella-like clusters of tiny white.

Hairy throughout and growing from three to ten feet tall with a stout, slightly ridged, branched, hollow stem, this coarse-looking herbaceous perennial stands out whenever it grows.

With three deeply lobed and toothed leaflets, the huge, woolly, toothed, palmate-compound leaves often grow up to 16 inches long and a foot wide. Beginning as basal leaves, they become alternate on the stem. The stout leaf stalks, each with a swollen base that has a broad wing, clasp the stem.

In mid-summer, the umbrella-like flower heads emerge on the upper branches from buds on the stem that consist of swellings several inches across. Slender, long bracts widened near their bases extend from the base of the flower head. The flattened flower heads, which can grow up to eight inches across and are twice-divided, with spoke-like flower stalks, consist of numerous tiny, fragrant flowers up to 0.33 inch long, with notched, often purple-tinged, five-petaled white petals. The outer flowers are larger than the more central ones.

The flowers give way to green, ovate, fragrant fruits, 0.375 to 0.5 inch long and 0.25 to 0.375 inch wide, with four conspicuous, vertical purple lines. Inside, ridged seeds, flattened on one side and rounded on the other, grow in tight pairs.

The taproots or fibrous roots smell spicy, as does the rest of the plant.

•Entire plant wholly and fragrant
•Stout, slightly ridged, hollow stout stem three to ten feet tall
•No purple blotches on the stem
•Huge, three-parted, palmate-compound leaves up to 16 inches long and one foot wide
•Leaflets deeply lobed and toothed
•Doubly branched, flat-topped, umbrella-like flower heads up to eight inches wide, growing from upper branches
•Tiny, white, five-petaled, fragrant flowers up to 0.33 inch long, with notched, often purple-tinged petals
•Green, ovate, fragrant fruits, 0.375 to 0.5 inch long, 0.25 to 0.375 inch wide, with four conspicuous vertical purple lines
•Tightly paired ridged seeds, flattened on one side and rounded on the other
•Taproot or fibrous roots
Cut off the young leaves and stems with a pocket knife or shears. Dig up the taproots with a shovel or trowel.

The best parts of this plant are the young leaf stalks and flower stalks, which taste like celery on steroids. Edible raw after peeling, they're too spicy for most people, but they're excellent simmered in soups or stews, or baked into casseroles. Some people boil them in a couple of changes of water to make the more mild tasting, but I don't find that necessary. Although people allegedly eat the young leaves raw, they're too hairy and strong-flavored to enjoy, inferior to the stalks, which you can peel.

The taproots, which taste like parsnips and rutabagas, are edible in early spring and fall, but unfortunately, they're usually small and puny, often intergrading into fibrous roots, so that I've never had a satisfactory harvest.

You can also use the green seeds as seasoning in the summer, although I don’t find them very tasty. People add them to soups, stews, and breads, the way you’d use celery seeds or caraway seeds.

Various Indian tribes used a decoction of the roots for colds, coughs, sore throats, flu, headaches, indigestion, asthma, and cramps. They applied the chopped roots as a poultice for sores, bruises, swellings, boils, and arthritis. This plant isn't commonly used in herbal medicine today, and there's no convincing evidence of its effectiveness.
The cow parsnip contains furanocoumarins, which, in conjunction with sunlight and wet, sweaty skin, gives sensitive people rashes. You can avoid this by handling the plant with work gloves.
The wild parsnip, also edible, is a smaller relative with different features.

Don’t confuse the cow-parsnip with water hemlock, an especially deadly plant with smooth, not hairy, stems, and two- or 3 times compound leave. Its veins end in the notches between the teeth, not inside the teeth, a very important distinction. I bite of that plant can kill.

Giant hogweed (Heracleum mantegazzianum), an invasive which is spreading throughout eastern North America, looks like a larger version of cow parsnip, but it's stem is also purple-blotched. Touching it can cause a severe rash.
Indian Celery, Pushki

This large, coarse plant has especially delicious stems, which you peel and cook. Although the root is edible, I usually don't find it where it's substantial enough to be worth digging and cleaning it.
wild parsnip
Water hemlock
Unmeat Loaf
unmeat-loaf

Meat loaf normally consists of sautéed veggies and tomato sauce, which I also use here, plus ground meat, for which I substitute Chinese fake meat, and eggs to bind everything together. Flax seeds, lecithin granules, and arrowroot, plus xanthan and guar gum do everything eggs do for flavor and binding, and cow parsnip stalks provide additional flavor. The result: a superb meat loaf even Archie Bunker would be proud of!

6 tbs. olive oil
3 medium onions, chopped
5 cloves of garlic, chopped
3 9-inch stalks of peeled cow parsnip, or celery, chopped
1 green pepper, chopped
1-3/4 cup Chinese fake ham (available in Chinese specialty stores, and online), grated, or other vegan meat substitute
2 cups dry bread crumbs
2 cups tomato sauce
5 tbs. lecithin granules
2 tbs. fresh basil, chopped
2 tbs. fresh parsley, chopped
2 tbs. flax seeds (available in health food stores)
1-1/2 tsp. sage, ground
2 tsp. Bragg’s liquid aminos or tamari soy sauce (available in health food stores)
1 tsp. thyme, ground
1 tsp. oregano, ground
1 tsp. marjoram, ground
1/2 tsp. black pepper, ground
1/4 tsp. rosemary, ground
1 tbs. arrowroot
1 tsp. xanthan gum (available in health food stores)
1/2 tsp. guar gum (available in health food stores)
1 cup fruit juice-sweetened ketchup

1. Sautée the onions in the olive oil 10 minutes or until translucent.

2. Add the cow parsnips and green pepper and sautée another 5 minutes.

3. Add the Chinese fake ham and garlic and sauée another 5 minutes.

4. Stir in all remaining ingredients except the ketchup and transfer into an oiled loaf pan.

5. Top with the ketchup

6. Bake 45 minutes in a preheated 350 degree oven.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Baking time: 45 minutes
2)Immature Cow Parsnip
2immature-cow-parsnip
These huge, woolly, three-parted leaves growing on a stout, woolly, hollow, slightly grooved stalk, indicate that the cow parsnip is at the right stage for harvesting.
4)Cow Parnip in Flower
4cow-parnip-in-flower

This tall, wholly, branching plant's flat-topped, umbrella-like flower clusters consist of tiny, white, five-petaled flowers growing in secondary clusters. The large, wholly, three-parted, palmate-compound leaves are composed of lobed, toothed leaflets.
3)Cow Parsnip Basal Leaves
3cow-parsnip-basal-leaves

The three coarse, wholly, lobed, toothed leaflets of this palmate-compound leaf arise from a stout, slightly ridged, green, unblotched woolly stalk that sets this plant apart from poison hemlock, which has purple blotches on the stem.
1)Cow Parsnip Leaves and Flowers
1cow-parsnip-leaves-and-flowers

Long, slender bracts extend from the base of the large flower head, which split into umbrella-like clusters. The flower heads grow on the top of a stout, fuzzy, grooved stem that also has large, toothed, three-parted, alternate, palmate-compound leaves. Stout leaf stalks, each with a swollen base that has a broad wing, clasp the stem.
Cutleaved Toothwort
cutleaved-toothwort
Family: Brassicaceaeor Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family
The leaves are around from early- through mid-spring, when you can also dig up the tubers.
Partially shaded moist woodlands and floodplains
Throughout most of Eastern North America

Look for an early spring plant with deeply divided palmate-compound leaves and deeply divided toothed leaflets. Cutleaved toothwort has a stem four to 16 inches tall with a terminal spike of nodding, fragrant, long-stalked, pinkish-white, four-petaled flower and long, narrow, pointed seed pods.

The hairless, deeply divided leaves of this spring ephemeral encircle the stem, forming a whorl. Each of the palmate-compound basal leaves and the three whorled stem leaves grow to about three inches long and three inches wide, with three to five narrow, toothed lobes.

A stem four to 16 inches tall ends with a slender, nodding spike of alternating, fragrant, long-stalked, white to pinkish four-petaled flowers, each about 0.75 inch across, blooming in mid-spring. The flowers give way to long, narrow, pointed seed pods about 1.5 inches long.

Ivory-white, tooth-like tubers adorn a shallow, white, jointed, knobby, rhizome.

•A spring ephemeral with deeply divided, smooth, palmate-compound basal leaves at first
•Deeply lobed, toothed leaflets
•Three to five palmate-compound leaves forming a whorl around the stalk
•Flower spike four to 16 inches tall, growing above the leaves
•Fragrant, long-stalked, white to pinkish, four-petaled flowers, each about 0.75 inch across, blooming in mid-spring
•Long, narrow, pointed seedpods around 1.5 inches long
•A shallow, jointed, white, knobby rhizome with white, tooth-like tubers
•Whole plant flavored like wasabe

Break off the leaves, flowers, and tender, breakable portions of the flower stalk with your fingers.

Please collect only where very abundant, and don't dig up the rhizomes unless the plants are so crowded that thinning them out will be helpful.

The fiery-tasting leaves, flowers, and rhizomes taste like wasabe. Harvest just the above-ground parts where they’re very abundant, to avoid harming the environment (for this reason, I’ve tasted the roots only once). Add the leaves and flowers sparingly to salads, or include them in soups, stews, sauces, and casseroles. Cut down or eliminate other hot spices—you won’t need them!

There's no concrete information available, but it's possible that it contains vitamins A, C, and B complex, and minerals such as calcium, iron, potassium, and phosphorus, like other members of the mustard family.

Most wild foods are very common and renewable, but this one is endangered in Maine and New Hampshire. Please don't pick it in those states, or anywhere it's not very common. And use sparingly if you don't care for spicy foods!
Crow's Toes, Pepper Root, Purple-flowered Toothwort
This hot mustard, with tooth-shaped roots, has leaves you can use in any dish that needs some zing.
Wild Springtime Soup
wild-springtime-soup

Wild spring ingredients that taste delicious on their own are also great combined in a simple gourmet soup.

4 cups oat milk or nut milk
1-1/2 cup burdock root or parsnips, thinly sliced
2 tbs. olive oil
2 cloves garlic, crushed
1 tsp. Vege-sal or seasoned salt
1/4 tsp. black pepper, ground
2/3 cups ostrich fern fiddleheads or asparagus, chopped
1 cup ramp leaves or shallots, chopped
1/2 cup cutleaved toothwort or garlic mustard leaves, chopped
2 cups curly dock or spinach leaves, chopped

1. Simmer the burdock in the oat milk with the garlic, olive oil, Vege-sal, and pepper 15 minutes.

2. Add the ostrich fern, ramps, toothwort, and simmer another 5 minutes.

3. Add the curly dock leaves and simmer another minute.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 30 minutes

The whorl of three palmate-compound leaves consisting of deeply lobed, toothed leaflets, below a slender raceme of long-stalked, pink-white, four-petaled flowers, makes this spring ephemeral easy to recognize.
2)Cutleaved Toothwort Basal Leaves

These palmate-compound basal leaves with deeply toothed leaflets are among the first delicious edibles you'll find in partially shaded, damp woods in early spring.

Common Evening Primrose
common-evening-primrose
Family: Onagraceae, the willowherb family or evening primrose family

The taproot's in season in autumn and early spring, also in the winter where winters are mild, the ground isn't frozen, and there are rosettes around to indicate where to dig.

The flowers are in season in the summer and fall.
Sunny places with poor soil, empty lots, disturbed sites, fields, prairies, seashore areas, dunes, glades, thickets, and roadsides
Most of North America except for some of the Rocky Mountain states

Look for a basal rosette of lance-shaped, hairy leaves, each with a prominent whitish midrib. Its hairy stem is a tall, light green to reddish, with similar but smaller alternate leaves. Four-parted yellow flowers are at the ends of its branches with flat-topped, woody, cylindrical fruit capsules that split into four parts.

This native biennial arises from a white, fleshy, taproot, pink toward the top, that grows from two inches to over one foot long. A tight basal rosette of light or olive green, hairy, elliptical to lance-shaped leaves, sometimes slightly toothed, appears in early spring of the first year. Characterized by a prominent whitish midrib, the raggedy-edged, hairy leaves, which can survive mild winters but become tinged with red in cold weather, can reach nearly one foot in length.

The rosette returns early in the spring of the second year, but in mid-spring, an erect, stout, hairy, light green to reddish stem, unbranched or branched at the base, with similar but smaller alternate leaves forming a spiral pattern, reaches four to seven feet in height.

Long-stemmed, sweetly lemon-scented, four-parted yellow flowers, one to two inches across, bloom in terminal panicles from the tops of the branches in summer and fall, opening in the evening (to attract moths), and closing by noon. The bases of the broad petals unite to form a long, narrow tube. A distinctive four-parted stigma in the flower’s center forms an “X” shape. Drooping sepals grow beneath the flowers.

After each flower withers, the ovary matures into a flat-topped, cylindrical, woody seed capsule up to 1.5 inches long, full of tiny, hard, long, reddish-black seeds. The dead stem with the seed capsules, which split into four sections, persists through the winter.

•Basal rosette of lance-shaped, hairy leaves, each with a conspicuous, white midrib
•White, fleshy, spicy-scented taproot, pink on top
•Stout, hairy, light green to reddish stem, usually branched at the base, with spiraling, lance-shaped leaves
•Long-stemmed, sweetly lemon-scented, four-parted yellow flowers one to two inches across, in panicles at the tops of the branches, in summer and fall
•Four-parted stigma in the flower’s center forming an “X”
•Persistent woody, flat-topped, cylindrical seed capsules up to 1.5 inches long, containing many tiny, hard, long, reddish-black seeds

Dig up the taproot with a shovel or trowel in early spring or in the fall (or in the winter where winters are mild.) If it's growing in the sand, the best place for collection, you may even be able to pull out the taproot by hand.

Pick the flowers with your fingers in the summer.

The pungent pepper-and-radish flavor of the basal rosette's taproot is especially good in spicy dishes, such as chilly or curry. Simmer it 15 to 20 minutes. It thickens soups the way okra does, and you can even pickle it. Add it sparingly in dishes with mild-flavored ingredients, so it doesn't overpower them.

The tender, young leaves toward the rosette's center are too hairy to enjoy raw, but they’re alright simmered ten minutes in soups, though nowhere near as good as the roots. The peeled young stem is too fibrous to be worthwhile, but the mild-flavored flowers can add color to salads, and make an attractive garnish.

The seeds’ oil contains gamma-linolenic acid, gamma-linoleic acid (an anti-clotting agent), and vitamin F (essential fatty acids.) Gamma-linoleic acid is the precursor of PGEI. This is a prostaglandin, one of many short-lived fatty hormones—named because they were first isolated from the prostate gland. It regulates a variety of metabolic functions. However, you need industrial equipment to extract the oil, which is available in health food- and drug stores.
Beware of anyone who ever tries to walk you down the primrose path!

Common evening primrose is not related to the cultivated European garden primrose (Primula vulgaris), which doesn't grow wild in North America.

Other very similar edible relatives (Oenothera spp.) in this very variable genus, and their hybrids grow across the country. Hooker's evening primrose's (O. Hookeri) yellow flowers, for example, turn red with age.
Weedy Evening Primrose, German Rampion, Hog Weed, King's Cure-all, Fever-plant, Evening Star
This is a great native root vegetable commonly known for the medicinal oil extracted from the seeds.
Coconut Primrose
coconut-primrose

Common evening primrose adds the perfect amount of bite to this coconut-flavored Thai-style tofu dish.

1/4 cup corn oil
3 packages soft tofu, drained and diced
4-1/2 cups coconut milk
3/4 cups common evening primrose root
1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
1 tbs. lemon grass
1 tbs. dried pennyroyal or mint
1/2 tbs. powdered ginger
1/2 tbs. salt

1. Sautée the tofu in the corn oil 5 minutes

2. Meanwhile, purée the remaining ingredients in a blender.

3. Pour the sauce over the tofu, bring to a boil over medium heat, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 20 minutes

This fleshy, white taproot gives rise to a tight rosette of lance-shaped, raggedy looking basal leaves, each with a prominent midrib. Find this form in early spring or fall, and you have a delicious, spicy flavored root vegetable.

2young-common-evening-primrose

Each of these sweet-scented, long-stalked, four-parted, yellow flowers contains an "X"-shaped stigma. With their long, droopy green sepals, they grow at the ends of stalks with spirals of lance-shaped, raggedy looking leaves, each with a conspicuous, white midrib. The flowers taste good, and make an excellent garnish.
4)Common Evening Primrose Seedpods
4common-evening-primrose-seedpods

These cylindrical, flat-topped, four-parted seedpods, spiraling down the stem along with the lance-shaped leaves, help you recognize second-year common evening primrose in late summer and fall, and show you where to search for first-year rosettes, with their edible taproots.
5)Common Evening Immature Primrose Seeds
5common-evening-immature-primrose-seeds

The long, upright, woody, cylindrical seed capsules, which crowd the top of the stem, peel open from the tips to release many tiny, elongated, dark brown seeds. And the dead plant's skeleton persists through the winter.
False Solomon's Seal
false-solomons-seal
Family: Ruscaceae or Liliaceae
The shoot is edible when it first appears in early spring for a period of about two weeks before the leaves unfurl and the stem gets tough.
Rich, partially shaded woodlands, moist areas, stream banks, clearings, and meadows
This subspecies grows throughout most of Eastern North America, although other very similar edible subspecies grow throughout the rest of most of North America

As the seasons progress, look for stands of green pencil-like shoots with leaves wrapped around their top sections, followed by arching zigzag stems with alternate, elliptical, entire, very short-stalked leaves, then a pyramidal terminal panicle of cream-white, six-petaled star-like flowers, and finally a terminal panicle of berries; green with copper spots which become cream white, and then purple-striped and red.
Cut or break off the tender parts of the stems when they first come up before the leaves unroll. Discard any hard parts of the stems, and all of the acrid leaves.

Enjoy the tender stems raw, chopped into salads, or steam or simmer them for 10 to 15 minutes, like asparagus. They taste like asparagus, only better.

You might be able to remove the rhizomes' bitterness and neutralize their strong laxative qualities if you cook them in lye water overnight, but there are so many better wild roots to cook, there's no reason to fiddle with caustic chemicals that may not even work.

A poultice made from the roots of this plant was used to treat sunburns by American Indians, who also dried and smoked them to treat hyperactivity and depression. They also used the smoke as a cough suppressant, but the plant isn't currently used in herbal medicine, and its efficacy and safety are doubtful.

The rhizomes are normally poisonous, although it's possible that with extraordinary treatment, they might be rendered safe.

This plant acts as a laxative in sensitive individuals, so begin with very small quantities and gradually increase your portions, and the bitter berries might cause diarrhea if anyone could [-somehow] manage to eat them in quantity.

This plant is very abundant in some regions, and rare in others. Please collect sparingly unless this plant is very abundant, and go after other edibles where this plant is rare.

Other very similar edible subspecies, all of which can interbreed (which is why they're considered one species) grow across the US. The stem of feathery false lily of the valley (M. racemosum ssp. amplexicaule), the most common subspecies of the West Coast, for example, grows erect instead of arching over. The leaves of starry false Solomon's seal are more narrow than those of false Solomon's seal, and its mature berries are black instead of whitish or pink-red.

Solomon’s seal (Polygonatum biflorum), also edible, has tubular, six-parted flowers and dark blue, spherical berries that hang from the leaf axils, not in a terminal panicle, and the rhizome is whitish, not yellow-brown.

False hellebore (Veratrum viride) is a swamp plant with an upright green shoot, but it's shaped more like the wide crayons toddlers use than a slender pencil, and the shoot and mature leaves are deeply pleated, like an accordion. Although its resemblance to false Solomon's seal is slight, the effects of eating it are not: it causes severe poisoning terminating in cardiac arrest, so be aware of it!
Solomon's Treacle, Solomon's Plume, False Spikenard, Feathery False Lily of the Valley
This common woodland plant produces a short-lived asparagus flavored shoot toward the end of early spring.
Starry False Solomon's Seal, Solomon's Seal, False Lily of the Valley
False Hellebore
Saffron Rice with False Solomon's Seal
saffron-rice-with-false-solomons-seal

The asparagus-like flavor of false Solomon’s seal perfectly compliments that of saffron, as do the other herbs.

4-1/4 cups water
1 tsp. saffron
2 cups basmati brown rice
6 tbs. corn oil
1 large red onion, finely-chopped
1 cup false Solomon’s seal shoots or asparagus, chopped
1 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1/4 cloves, ground
1/4 tsp. cardamon, ground
1-1/2 tsp. salt

1. Bring the 1/4 cup of water to a boil, add the saffron, turn off the heat, and allow to dissolve for 10 minutes.

2. Meanwhile, sauté the onion and false Solomon’s seal shoots in the corn oil with the cinnamon, cloves, and cardamon 5 minutes.

3. Add the rice and cook another 5 minutes.

4. Place all ingredients in an oiled casserole dish, cover, and bake 75 minutes, or until all the water is absorbed, in a preheated 375°F oven.

Makes 6 cups

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Cooking time: 75 minutes
1)Mature False Solomon's Seal and Shoot
1mature-false-solomons-seal-and-shoot

False Solomon's seal's shoot (below) looks like an upright green pencil wrapped with leaves toward the top, and a sheath toward the bottom. The regularly spaced bumps on the rhizomes display the locations of previous year's above-ground growth. Later, the mature slender stem (above) bends over. Alternate, elliptical, entire, pointed leaves with parallel veins grow along its length, and a terminal panicle of spherical berries hang from the tip.
2)False Solomon's Seal Shoots
2false-solomons-seal-shoots

False Solomon's Seal's leaves wrap tightly around the top of the green shoot's upright stem at first, while a grayish sheath covers its bottom portion. This is the time to eat the shoot. Once the leaves start to unfurl, the shoot gets too tough to eat.
4)False Solomon's Seal Berries
4false-solomons-seal-berries

These spherical, greenish, red-speckled berries grow on the same terminal panicle as the flowers. They might cause diarrhea if eaten in quantity, but they're too bitter for anyone to have tested this! The less mature berries in the background are amber-gray.
3)False Solomon's Seal Flowers
3false-solomons-seal-flowers
These tiny, star-shaped, white flowers, with long, protuding stamens, grow on a loose, branching, pyramidal, terminal panicle.
5)False Solomon's Seal Rhizome
5false-solomons-seal-rhizome
Scars of previous years' growth resembling signet rings punctuate the yellow-brown rhizome, which gives rise to the white true roots.
Solomon's Seal
solomons-seal
Family: Ruscaceae or Liliacae
The shoot is in season in early spring. The rhizome is in season in fall and early spring, but usually should not be harvested because it's usually uncommon.
Rich soil, partially shaded woodlands, moist areas, stream- and pond banks, roadside ditches, clearings, meadows, and gardens
Most of North America east of the Rockies

Look for an unbranched, arching plant one to six feet long with smooth, alternate, entire, elliptical leaves clasping the stem. Six-parted bell-shaped, greenish- to yellowish-white, stalked flowers in twos or threes hang from the leaf axils in late spring and early summer and are replaced by spherical, blue berries in late summer.

This colonial perennial's unbranched, gracefully arching, zig-zag stem grows from one to six feet long. Undeveloped young leaves wrap tightly around the top of the pencil-shaped shoot in early spring.

The long, pointed, stalkless, elliptical, alternate, entire, hairless leaves, which turn yellow in autumn, grow up to six inches long and four inches wide. The leaf base clasps the stem.

In late spring or early summer, 12 to 20 tubular, six-parted, bell-shaped, whitish green to pale yellow-green flowers, 0.5 to 0.75 inch long, hang in twos or threes from long, slender, branched stalks arising from the leaf axils under the upper portion of the stem, to be followed later in the summer by groups of two or three dark blue, spherical berries up to 0.5 inch across.

The stout, whitish, knobby, segmented rhizome bears scars from previous years' growth at regular intervals, like impressions of a signet ring.

•Unbranched, arching, zig-zag stem growing from one to six feet tall
•Undeveloped young leaves wrapped tightly around the top of a pencil-shaped shoot in early spring
•Long, pointed, stalkless, elliptical, alternate, entire, hairless leaves up to six inches long four inches wide
•Leaf bases clasping the stem
•12 to 20 tubular, six-parted, bell-shaped, whitish green to pale yellow-green flowers, 0.5 to 0.75 inch long
•Flowers hanging in twos or threes from long, slender, branched stalks arising from the leaf axils under the upper portion of the stem, in late spring and summer
•Dark blue, spherical berries, green at first, up to 0.5 inch across, hanging from slender, branched stalks under the leaf axils in groups of two or three in summer.
•Stout, whitish, knobby, segmented rhizome stamped with scars from previous years' growth

Harvest only where abundant, and please don't harvest where the plant is protected or endangered. Break off tender parts of the stems before the leaves unroll. Discard any hard parts of the stems and all the acrid immature leaves.

Dig up the rhizomes with a shovel or a trowel only where the plant is so crowded that thinning it out will be helpful.

Discard the acrid leaves and use the tender stems raw, or steam or simmer them for 10 to 15 minutes. They taste like asparagus, only better. Use them when they first come up, before the leaves begin to unfurl and the stems become tough.

Because there are few places where they're abundant enough to harvest the rhizomes in my area, I only tasted one once. However, people grow them in their gardens, so if you garden, get them from a reputable supplier, grow them, and dig them up to your heart's content.

They're crisp, like water chestnuts, and somewhat sweet. You can eat them raw, slice and roast them in a light vegetable oil with sweet spices, or dry and grind them into flour. They're also suitable for soups, stews, and casseroles. They cook in 10 to 15 minutes.

The berries are not edible.

A decoction of the root has been used for a wide variety of ailments ranging from indigestion to coughing. It's been used to treat menstrual cramps, PMS, and bleeding, as well as for lowering blood pressure and increasing concentration and mental clarity.

A poultice of the roots has been applied topically on cuts and bruises, acute injuries related to tendons, joints, ligaments, muscles, bones, bruises, connecting tissues, and cartilage, as well as for osteoarthritis. Although there's no science upholding any of these claims, some of which derive from a European relative that's been used since ancient times, this plant definitely deserves to be tested.

This plant can be rare, and it's protected or endangered in some locations. Please go after more common plants where this is so, and be especially cautious about uprooting it, as this kills the plant.

Great Solomon's Seal (P. biflorum spp. commutatum) is an edible subspecies which grows as tall as seven feet, and has two to ten larger flowers per cluster.

Star-flowered Solomon's seal, another edible relative, has unbranched flower clusters and more narrow leaves than Solomon's seal. It grows in the sandy habitat of the seashore, as well as moist meadows.

Hairy Solomon's seal, (P. pubescens) also edible, has hair under the leaves, but it's rare.

False Solomon's seal (Maianthemum racemosum), with a similar, edible shoot and a poisonous, yellow-brown rhizome, has short leaf stalks, and flowers and berries on terminal clusters, not under the leaf axils.

False hellebore (Veratrum viride) is a swamp plant an upright green shoot, but it's shaped more like a wide crayon that toddlers use rather than a slender pencil, and the shoot and mature leaves are deeply pleated, like an accordion. Although its resemblance to Solomon's seal is slight, the effects of eating it are not: It causes severe poisoning terminating in cardiac arrest and death.
Smooth Solomon's Seal, Small Solomon's Seal
This very tasty wild plant, in season briefly in early spring, has a stem that tastes like asparagus, but it should only be picked where very common.
Star-flowered Solomon's Seal, Hairy Solomon's Seal, False Solomon's Seal, False Hellebore, Great Solomon's Seal
Solomon's Dip
solomons-dip

1-1/4 cups silken tofu, drained

2. Add the Solomon's Seal and process until well-integrated but not puréed.

Makes 2 cups

Preparation time: 10 minutes

The pencil-shaped shoot, with leaves tightly wrapped around the top of the green stem, resembles that of false Solomon's seal. You need to look at the root system or wait for the plants to mature to be sure which is which. Fortunately, the shoots of both plants are good to eat.
5)Solomon's Seals Rhizome
5solomons-seals-rhizome

4solomons-seal-berries

The small groups of spherical, stalked berries, which change from green to blue and hang from the leaf axils, make this woodland plant easy to distinguish. And the elliptical, entire leaves with parallel veins clasp the stem, rather than attaching with short leafstalks. This provides another important distinction.
Goutweed
goutweed
Apiaceae or Umbelliferae, the umbellifers, or the parsley family
Although you can find some new young, edible leaves in the summer and fall, all the leaves are young and tender in early spring, and there are still very many young leaves in mid-spring.
Partially shaded, fully shaded, or sunny areas, moist soil, old gardens, forests where trees have been cut, old fields and pastures, and disturbed habitats
Much of Northeastern North America and the Pacific Northwest, but not in parts of the Deep South
Eurasia

Look for a medium-sized colonial plant with hairless, long-stalked, palmate-compound, three-parted basal leaves which are often twice-divided. Goutweed has oval, pointed, sharp-toothed, irregularly lobed leaflets one to four inches long and similar alternate leaves on the stem. Umbrella-like flower clusters stand with tiny, white, five-petaled flowers and small, elongated, flattened, green seeds. Sniff for the odor of parsley or celery.

This invasive, colonial, parsley and celery-scented plant, which spreads with long, white, branching rhizomes, begins its growth with hairless, long-stalked, three-parted palmate-compound basal leaves. Each oval, pointed, sharp-toothed, irregularly lobed leaflet grows from one to four inches long. The larger ones subsequently divide into another two or three lobes, the smaller ones don't.

Similar alternate leaves grow on the hollow, furrowed stem, which appears in mid- to late spring or early summer, and grows from 1.5 to over three feet tall. Flat-topped, umbrella-like flower clusters two to four inches across, consisting of tiny, five-petaled, white flowers, bloom at the tops of the branching stems in the summer. Soon after, small, elongated, flattened, green seeds replace them.

•Three-parted, palmate-compound basal leaves secondarily divided into two or three irregularly lobed, oval, sharp-toothed leaflets one to four inches long
•Round, hollow, furrowed stem 1.5 to over 3 feet tall, branching at the base
•Flat-topped, twice-branched umbels two to four inches across at the tops of the stems
•Tiny, five-petaled, white flowers at the ends of the umbels
•Small, elongated, flattened, green seeds at the ends of the umbels
•Plant growing in dense stands
•Fragrance of parsley and celery throughout when crushed
Strip off bunches of the small, younger leaves with your fingers in early spring. Later on, search for these under the larger leaves, close to ground level.

Some people cook the young leaves like spinach. I find them a little too strong-flavored for this.

Although you could attenuate the flavor by boiling, this leaches out the water-soluble vitamins, so I use goutweed as a seasoning, raw or cooked, fresh or dried, the way you'd use parsley. With its flavor of celery, carrots, and parsley, it's a great addition to salads, sandwiches, soups, stews, and sauces.

Korean people also pickle the stems.

An edible variety with leaves with white borders is planted in gardens as an ornamental.

Although it's called sometimes called ground-elder, goutweed isn't related to elderberries and, although it's used for gout (and might treat gout if it contains vitamin C, which has been shown to help gout), its name is a corruption of its old name, "goatweed" (goats love it)!

Honewort, also edible, looks and tastes similar, but it has a much smaller flower head, and leaves that divide but once.

Wild carrot or Queen Anne's lace has umbrella-like white flowers, but the leaves are lacy and finely cut, not broad, and the plant has a carrot-scented taproot, not rhizomes.

Water hemlock (Cicuta maculata) is a deadly relative with umbrella-like flowers and compound leaves, but the leaves are feather-compound, not palmate compound, and the flowers are yellow, not white. If you confuse these plants, you'd have to be quite careless (and quite dead).

Other plants in this family also have similar flowers, but the rest of the features are different as well.
Bishopsweed, Ground-Elder, Herb Gerard, Snow-in-the-mountain
Once established, this excellent parsley-like seasoning grows in dense stands.
Honewort, Wild Carrot, Common Elderberry
2)Creamy Wild Mushroom Soup with Goutweed
2creamy-wild-mushroom-soup-with-goutweed

You’ll never buy the canned version again after trying the real thing, especially if you use wild mushrooms and goutweed.

1/4 cup corn oil
3-1/2 cups meadow mushrooms (Agaricus campestris) or commercial mushrooms, sliced
1 red onion, chopped
6 cloves of garlic, chopped
1/2 cup silken tofu
1/4 cup mellow miso (available in health food stores)
1/4 cup lecithin granules (available in health food stores)
1/4 cup raw cashews or pignoli nuts
3 tbs. arrowroot
1 tbs. fresh goutweed or parsley, chopped
1 tsp. sweet paprika
1 tsp. tarragon, ground
1 tsp.turmeric
1 tsp. marjoram, ground
1 tsp. black pepper, ground

1. Sauté the mushrooms, onion, and garlic in the corn oil for 10 minutes.

2. Meanwhile, purée; the remaining ingredients in a blender.

3. Combine the purée; with the sautéed; ingredients in a saucepan, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation/Cooking time: 30 minutes

Goutweed's branched stems are topped with umbrella-like clusters of branching spokes that end in tiny, white flowers. The long-stalked, alternate, palmate-compound leaves on the stem consist of three irregularly lobed, sharply toothed, oval leaflets.
Glasswort
glasswort
Family: Amaranthaceae, the amaranth family

Although this plant is around from mid-spring through early fall, it's at its best when it first comes up, in late spring and early summer, while it's still tender. Later on, it becomes unpleasantly woody, with a hard, inedible core.
Salt marshes and mud flats near shores
East Coast, Gulf Coast except for Utah, and the California coast
It's also native to Europe, South Africa and South Asia.
Look for an upright, green, branching, jointed succulent in mud flats, without leaves, with very inconspicuous flowers, and that turns pink in the fall.

All you usually see of this seashore plant is its upright, leafless, green, branching, jointed, succulent stem, but that's enough to recognize these unique species. Growing to about six inches tall, it turns a translucent pink in autumn.

Reduced to inconspicuous, opposite scales to conserve water in its hostile, salty environment, the leaves are barely visible. Minute, green flowers, in groups of three to seven, hide in the joints of the upper branches, on stalks only 0.125 inch long. The seeds are tiny enough to escape notice too. These reduced features make it very difficult to distinguish between the various species of Glasswort, but there are several, most annual, and one perennial. However, no other plants with such an unusual appearance, and all species are equally edible.

•Upright green, leafless, branching, jointed succulent
•Growing only in salt marshes and mud flats near shores
•Translucent pink color in autumn
Plan your trip at low tide if you want a better chance of keeping your feet dry! Simply break off the stems with your fingers.

Use this flavorful, crunchy vegetable, which tastes like spinach and asparagus, cooked 10 to 15 minutes, in soups, stews, or rice dishes. It also makes great pickles.

Don't add salt to dishes that include glasswort. The plant provides plenty of sodium.

This plant contains so much linoleic acid, an essential fatty acid, that people are trying to cultivate it in deserts, where they water it with seawater, to produce biofuel! Besides more than enough sodium, it also provides the minerals sodium, potassium and calcium, iron, iodine, and copper.

Glasswort juice is a traditional diuretic, but the plant is high in sodium, which makes you thirsty, after which you excrete the extra water in the urine. I think using glasswort as a diuretic is outdated.
Avoid using glasswort raw, since it may create an unpleasant burning sensation in your throat. It's high in sodium, so use it very sparingly if you're on a low-sodium diet.
Samphire, Pickleweed, Sea Bean, Sea Asparagus
This plant is an excellent, flavorful salt substitute.
Boston Baked Beans with Glasswort
boston-baked-beans-with-glasswort

Boston Baked Beans with Glasswort

There are so many great recipes with which to experiment with, it took me 33 years to get to this one, and only happened because my wife had a craving for this dish. An uncharacteristically sweet bean recipe, burnt sugar extract and caramel extract (available at http://www.bickfordflavors.com/index.html), plus my standard liquid stevia sweetener, replace the sweet flavor of the traditional molasses (a refined, concentrated carbohydrate I avoid). Barbecue seasoning replaces the traditional sugary barbecue sauce, and glasswort takes care of the salt. And my wife had no time (or cause) to complain about these changes as she devoured the tasty result.

2 cups red kidney beans, soaked in water to cover overnight, or steeped in water off the boil 1 hour, drained, rinsed, and pressure cooked 15 minutes (or boiled 2-1/2 hours or until tender), drained
2 cups vegetable stock or water
1/4 cup fruit-sweetened ketchup
2 tbs. tomato paste
2 red onions, chopped
1 large red bell pepper, chopped
5 Tofu Pups (vegan hot dogs, available in health food stores), sliced
1 tbs. olive oil or corn oil
1/4 cup glasswort, chopped, or 2 tsp. Vege-sal (a seasoned salt available in health food stores), or 1 tsp. salt
2 tsp. black peppercorns, ground into 4 tsp. (or to taste)
2 tsp. barbecue seasoning
1 tsp. cumin, ground
1/2 tsp. liquid stevia (available in health food stores)
1/4 tsp. caramel extract
1/4 tsp. burnt sugar extract (optional)

Bake covered in an oiled casserole dish in a preheated 350 degree oven for 2-1/2 hours.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 10 min.

Baking time: 2-1/2 hours

This branching, jointed, leafless succulent plant of mudflats is one of the easiest wild foods to recognize.

Greenbrier
greenbrier
Family: Ruscaceae or Liliaceae

All the leaves, the tendrils, and the shoots are edible when the vine first begin growing in mid-spring. Later on, all but the tips of the shoots and their associated immature leaves and tendrils become leathery. My mid-summer, there's barely anything tender enough left to nibble.
Partially shaded habitats, thickets, old fields, fencerows, open, deciduous woodlands, edges of trails and meadows, clearings, roadsides, and stable dunes
Most of the eastern US and Ontario

Strip off all the tender, young leaves, shoots, and tendrils when they first appear, in mid-spring. From late spring to early summer, break off the tender tips of the shoots along with any accompanying tender, young leaves. The flowers are edible, but too small to be substantial. And the berries are about as good as a rubber pencil eraser!

Greenbrier has a piercing, sweet-sour flavor, it’s one of my favorite salad greens. The young leaves, shoots, and tendrils are more delicate than any other wild vegetable. They're also great in sandwiches, soups, and casseroles, or steamed or sautéed. Cook no more than 5 minutes.
There's no information available, but the sour flavor indicates vitamin C.
Ants love greenbriar, so shake them off before you eat this plant, especially if you’re a vegetarian.

Roundleaf greenbrier is just one representative species of a large number of quite similar greenbriers (Smilax spp.), all edible, that grow throughout the US.

Carrion flower (Smilax renifolia, S. herbacea) is a similar-looking related edible with a non-woody vine that lacks thorns.
Roundleaf Greenbriar, Catbriar, Bullbrier, Horsebrier, Blasphemy Vine, Stretchberry
This common woodland plant has deliciously sour-flavored young leaves, tendrils, and shoots.
Carrion flower
4)Mature Roundleaf Greenbrier
4mature-roundleaf-greenbrier
White Beans Supreme
white-beans-supreme

Beans, although very nutritious, are intrinsically dull-flavored, but this shortcoming is cured by using piquant greenbrier leaves and plenty of savory seasonings, as you’ll find out when you can’t stop eating something that’s not at all boring!

1-1/2 cup white beans, soaked overnight or steeped 1 hour in water just off the boil, drained, and rinsed
5 tbs. olive oil
1 onion, chopped
3 cups greenbrier leaves, shoots, and tendrils, chopped; or 2 carrots, sliced
3 cloves of garlic, chopped
2 tbs. wakame seaweed (available in health food stores), soaked to reconstitute, drained, rinsed, and chopped
1/4 cup fresh basil, chopped
1 tbs. savory, ground
2 tsp. tarragon, ground
2 tsp. lemon thyme or thyme, ground
1 tsp. black pepper, ground into 2 tsp.
3 cup vegetable stock or water
1/3 cup mellow miso (available in health food stores)

1. Simmer the beans in the stock with the basil, savory, tarragon, thyme, pepper, and 1 tbs. of the olive oil, covered, 3 hours or until tender, or pressure cook for 15 minutes.

2. Meanwhile, sauté the onion in the remaining olive oil 20 minutes, add the greenbrier and garlic, and sauté another 5 minutes.

3. Add the sautéed; veggies to the beans about 10 minutes before the end of cooking.

4. When the beans are tender, add 1/4 cup of them to a blender with 1/2 a cup of the liquid and the miso. Purée;, then stir this back into the pot.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Cooking time: 3 hours

3)Greenbrier Flowers
3greenbrier-flowers
These small, six-petaled, yellow-green to green, long-stalked, flowers hang in flat-topped bunches soon after the plant begins its spring growth.
2)Greenbrier Shoot and Berry
2greenbrier-shoot-and-berry

The young greenbrier vine, with oval, translucent-green, entire, parallel-veined, pointed leaves, plus paired tendrils arising from the leaf stalks, is at its best now. The leaves, tendrils, and tender ends of the shoots, along with the soft, young thorns, are all delicious. The spherical blue berry is nothing of not consistent—it's always at its worst, about as delicious as a rubber eraser!
Groundnut
groundnut
Family: Fabaceae, the pea or legume family
Although the tubers are edible all year, but they’re best in late summer and fall.
Sunny, wet, overgrown areas: fences and bushes in moist woodlands, bottom lands, moist thickets, fields, and meadows, and near streams and shores
Eastern North America and eastern Canada

Look for a twining vine, white in winter, with feather-compound leaves consisting of five to nine lance-shaped, toothless, short-stalked leaflets—only the leading one unpaired. Short, tight racemes are composed of pale-pink to maroon, fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like, short-stalked flowers. Also look for short seedpods.

This inconspicuous, hairless, twining vine, which can grow up to 12 feet long, hides delicious tubers underground.

Each feather-compound, alternate leaf consist of five to nine lance-shaped, toothless, short-stalked leaflets from one to 2.25 inches long, all paired except the broader, long-stalked leading one.

Showy, fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like, pale-pink, red-brown or maroon, short-stalked flowers bloom from late spring through the summer, configured in small, short, tight racemes from two to six inches long, quite different from other, more loosely configured legumes' racemes.

The seedpods grow from two to 4.25 inches long and about 0.25 inch broad. They contain small, edible, lentil-like seeds.

The vine becomes more noticeable in the winter, when its skeleton turns white. Follow it underground when the ground isn't frozen to locate a slender, necklace-like rhizome punctuated with ovate, brown tubers, white and firm inside, that grow from the size of a marble to that of a grapefruit, and contain a white, milky latex.

•Hairless, twining vine up to 12 feet long
•Feather-compound leaf with five to nine lance-shaped, toothless, short-stalked leaflets from one to 2.25 inches long
•All leaflets except the leading one paired
•Leading leaflet with longer leaf stalk
•Small, short, tight racemes from two to six inches long
•Showy, pale-pink, red-brown, or maroon, fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like, short-stalked flowers
•Seed pods from two to 4.25 inches long, 0.25 inch broad, containing small, lentil-like seeds
•Necklace-like rhizome punctuated with ovate, brown tubers from the size of a marble to that of a grapefruit
•Tubers white and firm inside, containing a white, milky latex
•Skeleton of vine turning white in the winter

Trace the vine to the ground, even possible in the winter, and dig up the tubers with a shovel and trowel. Look for chicken egg-sized tubers, which are the best.

You can collect the seed pods by hand.

Peel, then simmer or roast the light, nutty-tasting tubers, like potatoes, or slice and sauté them. Eat them hot. They're not tasty when cold.

You can eat the ripe seeds in the mature pods from mid-summer to fall (although they're so small, that's how long it will take you to fill your stomach), cooked like lentils or peas. However, their small size makes this way too labor-intensive.
The tuber is an excellent source of starch and protein, and the seeds contain vitamins A, C, and E.
The Indians applied a plaster of the tubers to proud flesh, an excessive growth of granulation tissue that sometimes develops over an open wound.

Groundnuts often grow along with poison ivy (Toxicodendron radicans). Take appropriate precautions: wear long pants, long sleeves, and work gloves, and actively look for this toxic plant.

Don't eat groundnuts raw. They taste terrible, and contain a protease inhibitor, destroyed by cooking—the same kind of chemical that's used to fight AIDS.

Other legumes may have poisonous seeds, but they aren't twining vines with tight racemes of flowers, five to nine parted, feather-compound leaves, or rhizomes strung with tubers. Just don't start randomly eating seeds of any leguminous plant without checking for these obvious features.
Hopniss, Potato Bean, Indian Potato
This modest vine conceals substantial, tasty underground tubers, a major food source for Lewis and Clark.
Poison Ivy
Scalloped Ground Nuts
scalloped-ground-nuts

Here’s a simple, familiar, traditional dish with a touch of wildness in the form of ground nuts, great for introducing the uninitiated to wild foods.

1/4 cup olive oil
2 onions, sliced
1 green bell pepper, sliced
2 cloves of garlic, chopped
1/2 tsp. thyme, ground
1/2 tsp. black pepper, ground
1/4 tsp. nutmeg, ground
2 cups of any wild or commercial mushrooms
6 cups groundnuts or 4 baked potatoes, sliced
2 cups soy-rice milk, nut milk, or oat milk
2 tsp. arrowroot or kudzu
2 tsp. Vege-sal (available in health food stores)
1 10-oz. package of vegan cheddar cheese (available in health food stores), sliced

1. Sauté the onions, mushrooms, bell pepper, and garlic in the olive oil for 15 minutes, or until the onions are lightly browned.

2. Meanwhile, combine the soy-rice milk, Vege-sal, and arrowroot with a whisk. Bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

3. Layer an oiled baking dish with sauce, groundnuts, sautéed; ingredients, sauce, and cheese.

4. Bake 30 minutes or until bubbly, uncovered, in a preheated 350 degree oven.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 30 minutes

This twining vine has completely covered a chain-link fence with feather-compound leaves comprised of lance-shaped, smooth-edged leaflets. The tight raceme of pinkish, bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like flowers makes this legume easily recognizable.

The slender, rounded rhizome leads to ovate, brown tubers, firm and white inside.
Hairy Bittercress
hairy-bittercress
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

This winter annual's rosettes come up in late fall, sometimes flowering then, and either overwinter or disappear, depending on how cold it gets. They reappear very early in the spring, flower, go to seed, and die by mid-spring.
Sunny, damp, disturbed soil, wet lawns and meadows, old fields, along paths and roadsides, near woods, and wherever rainwater tends to pool
Most of Eastern North America except northernmost New England, all the southern states, the West Coast, and southwestern Canada
Eurasia

Look for one or more mound-shaped basal rosettes of short, feather-compound leaves composed of five to nine rounded, opposite leaflets and a larger, kidney-shaped leading leaflet. Similar, more narrow, alternate leaves adorn central stems up to one foot tall. Very small, four-petaled, white flowers are arranged in terminal racemes with long, slender, curved, long-stalked, olive-brown or grayish, upright seed capsules.

In late fall or very early spring, this plant starts of with a basal rosette that grows in small, dense, mounded clump usually four to eight inches in diameter, sometimes next to so many other rosettes that they form a mat. A small, white taproot grows under each rosette.

Short, feather-compound basal leaves up to four inches long and 0.75 inch across grow at the ends of long, slender, leafstalks that are sparsely hairy and usually dull purple. The basal rosette soon becomes dense, with five to nine opposite, roundish leaflets on each leaf. The largest leaflet is kidney-shaped and grows, unpaired, at the leaf tip.

Three to five similar, but shorter and more narrow, alternate leaves grow along the stems, which can reach ten or 12 inches tall, and arise from the center of the rosette. Racemes of white, four-petaled flowers, each less than 0.25 inch wide and cupped in light green to dull purple, and oblong sepals grow on the tops of the many stems.

The flowers grow above the alternate, light grayish- to olive brown, very slender, long-stalked, upright, flat-topped, curved seed capsules, which reach from 0.75 t0 1.25 inches in length. The tiny, brown, ovoid, flattened seeds they contain spread explosively, flying up to ten feet from the plant.

•Dense, dome-shaped basal rosette four to eight inches across, sometimes forming a mat with neighboring rosettes
•Feather-compound basal leaves up to four inches long and 0.75 inch across, growing on slender, long, sparsely hairy, usually dull purple leaf stalks
•Five to nine opposite, roundish leaflets on each leaf
•Solitary, terminal, kidney-shaped leaflet the largest
•Many stems up to 12 inches long arising from the rosette's center
•Three to five similar, but shorter and more narrow, alternate feather-compound leaves growing on each stem
•Terminal racemes of white, four-petaled flowers, each less than 0.25 inch wide
•Light green to dull purple oblong sepals, growing around the flowers' bases
•Alternate, light grayish- to olive brown, very slender, long-stalked, upright, curved seed capsules, from 0.75 t0 1.25 inches long, growing beneath the flowers
•Tiny, brown, ovoid, flattened seeds spreading explosively from the seed pods
•Small, white taproot

Easy to collect in quantity when there aren't many other edible wild plants around, cut the top of the root under the rosette with a pocket knife, and you’ll get the entire basal rosette. Or, pinch off the flowers, upper pods, and tender tops by the handful.

Among the best-flavored of the wild mustards, the spicy leaves and tender flower spikes make a great garnish and a superb addition, raw, to salads or sandwiches. Or cook 10 to 15 minutes in soups, stews, and casseroles.
Pepperweed, Shotweed, Snapweed, Bittercress, Land Cress, Lamb's Cress
One of the first edibles to appear in late winter, this is also one of the best, neither very hairy nor bitter, and it can appear in surprising quantities.
Curried Cress
curried-cress

This European vegetable does great in an Indian context. Its flavor is too strong for the curry spices to drown out, and it adds just the right amount of spiciness to enhance the other spices

1/4 cup peanut oil
2 tbs. dark sesame oil
4 cups hairy bittercress or bok choy
1 14-oz. package of soft tofu, drained and diced

Sauce

1-1/2 cups water
2 tbs. peanut butter
1 tbs. curry paste or powder, or to taste
2 tbs. soy mayonnaise (available in health food stores)
2 tsp. arrowroot or kudzu
1 tbs. lemon juice

1. Mix all sauce ingredients together.

2. Stir-fry the bittercress with half the peanut oil in a wok or large frying pan for 2 minutes, and set aside.

3 Stir-fry the tofu in the remaining peanut oil for 4 minutes.

4. Add the sauce, bring to a boil, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 30 minutes

The youngest hairy bittercress rosette's few leaves have few leaflets (left) , while older rosettes (right) develop more leaves, and the leaves develop more leaflets. In both stages, the leaf stalks are characteristically long, and, except for the largest, solitary, terminal leaflet, the rounded leaflets grow in pairs.
2)Hairy Bittercress Basal Rosette
2hairy-bittercress-basal-rosette

3hairy-bittercress-in-flower

Hairy bittercress' basal leaves begin to wilt and disappear after its multiple stems appear. Terminal racemes of tiny, white, four-petaled flowers grow above the slender, erect, long-stalked, curved, light olive-brown seed pods. Long-stalked alternate, feather-compound leaves, with irregularly elliptical, lobed leaflets—largest leaflet at the tip—grow on the stems.
4)Hairy Bittercress Flowers and Seed Pods
4hairy-bittercress-flowers-and-seed-pods
The tiny flowers' four petals grow cupped in purplish-green, ovate sepals. Long, purplish to olive green, alternate, long-stalked, flat-topped seed pods grow beneath the flowers.
Hedge Mustard
hedge-mustard
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

Young basal leaves: when they first appear, just before mid-spring, through mid-spring, and mid- to late fall.

The smaller, upper leaves: mid-spring to early summer

Flowers, immature seedpods, and tender tops of the stems: early summer
Full sunlight or partial shade, moist, disturbed soil, park lands, meadows, overgrown fields, and along roadsides and the edges of trails and woods
Throughout most of the continental US and southeastern and southwestern Canada, but not in Utah
This native of Europe and North Africa now grows around the world.

You can pull off bunches of basal leaves with your fingers, or cut them off just below ground with a pocket knife to get the entire rosette at once. Because this invasive plant is large, you can get lots of greens with no environmental impact very quickly.

As the plant gets larger, strip the leaves off the stem and break off the tender tops of the stems. Do the same with the smaller, immature leaves, stem tops, and their accompanying leaves or flowers as the plant matures. Or strip off the flowers and any young seed pods (which quickly get tough) with your fingers.

The seeds themselves are too small to be worth harvesting.

Hedge mustard leaves, flowers (which are especially spicy), tender, young stem tips, and tender, young seed pods, all taste like the hot mustard you get in Chinese restaurants. Use them raw in soups or salad, or cook them, which reduces their pungency, for 10 to 15 minutes, in soups, stews, sauces, or casseroles. You can also chop and stir-fry them.

Kids: This is one of the best plants for you if you don't like spicy food. Offer a whole bunch to your friend. Say: "Here, eat all these flowers. They're so-o-o sweet—you'll love them!" After a few seconds of chewing, your friend will start jumping up and down and searching desperately for water. You may lose a friend, but the laugh you'll get will make it well worth it!

Hedge mustard contains high concentrations of iso­thiocyanates, plant estrogens tailored to interfere with insect reproduction that block human estrogen and estrogen-like environmental contaminants from activating cell reproduction and causing the abnormal cell proliferation that may lead to cancer. Thus, including this plant and its relatives in your diet lowers your chances of getting cancer.

Over 40 hydrodistillates have been extracted from hedge mustard, and some of these show strong antibacterial activity against five gram-positive bacteria and other pathogens.

Like most leafy green vegetables and other members of the mustard family, hedge mustard is probably loaded with vitamins and minerals, though no specific information is available.
Eat this plant sparingly at first if you're not accustomed to spicy food.
Other similar-looking relatives, also edible, don't become as large or coarse-looking as hedge mustard.
Singer's Plant, Wireweed, Tumble Weed, Wild Rocket
This common, widespread, prolific wild mustard is as spicy as it is large, although the tiny flowers are the hottest parts!
Fennel-Seasoned Mung Beans with Hedge Mustard Leaves
fennel-seasoned-mung-beans-with-hedge-mustard-leav

This traditional seasoning combination works great with mung beans, and hedge mustard adds more flavor, plus spiciness.

1 cup mung beans, steeped (brought to a boil, covered, and removed from the heat) 1 hour, or soaked overnight, drained and rinsed
2 cups hedge mustard leaves, flowers, or tender stems, chopped
2 cups vegetable stock
2 cloves of garlic, finely chopped
2 tbs. olive oil
2 tsp. fennel seeds ground
1 tsp. black peppercorns, ground into 1/2 tsp., or to taste
1/2 tsp. coriander seed, ground
1/2 tsp. freshly grated lemon rind
1 tsp. thyme, ground
1 tbs. tamari soy sauce

1. Simmer all ingredients except the tamari (which will keep the beans from getting tender) covered, 50 minutes, or until the mung beans are tender, stirring occasionally,

2. Stir in the tamari soy sauce.

Makes 3 cups

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Steeping and cooking time: 100 minutes
1)Immature Hedge Mustard
1immature-hedge-mustard
When the coarse, hairy, deeply lobed, shallow-toothed, alternate leaves on the stem have reached full size like this, you can collect them in quantity in no time.
2)Hedge Mustard Young Leaves
2hedge-mustard-young-leaves
The coarse tangle of basal leaves, with their deep lobes, irregular teeth, and hairiness, can be picked in their entirety, as long as you leave enough behind to regenerate.

The tops of the stem, the tiny, yellow, four-parted, cross-configured flowers, and the alternate, three-parted, arrow-shaped upper leaves are all delicious at this stage.
4)Hedge Mustard Flowers and Young Seed Pods
4hedge-mustard-flowers-and-young-seed-pods

These tightly clustered, yellow, four-petaled, cross-shaped flowers, and the accompanying tender stem tops, are particularly pungent, like Chinese mustard. The cylindrical, flat-topped, immature seed pods are delicious too—so long as you like spicy food!
Devil's Walkingstick
devils-walkingstick
Family: Araliaceae, the ginseng family

The shoots, the only edible parts, are at their best just before and during mid-spring, when they're abundant, although you can still find a few shoots that haven't leafed out well into early summer. The tree flowers in late summer and the poisonous berries ripen in the fall.
Partially sunny areas, open spots in moist woods, trail edges, park lands, thickets, and stream banks
Much of Eastern North America, and locally where it's been planted on the West Coast
It's also native to Asia, perhaps because a migrating bird, blown off course by a storm, spread the seeds from one continent to the other in its droppings.

•Small tree heavily armed throughout with large, sharp thorns
•Large, stout, burgundy-colored, thorny shoots in early- and mid-spring
•Twice-divided, feather-compound, alternate leaves three to six feet long,
•Small halos of tiny, five-petaled, cream-white flowers growing in white, terminal panicles three to four feet across, from late summer to fall
•Circular clusters of long-stalked, 0.25 inch wide, juicy, spherical, black-blue, berries growing in white terminal panicles three to four feet across, in autumn

Wearing heavy duty work gloves and using a pruning shears or a knife, carefully cut off the stout shoots after the leaf buds begin to open, but before the prickles harden and the individual leaflets separate. Trim off any hard leaflets and thorns in the field if you prefer.

Pare the prickles off the shoots with a sharp knife or potato peeler, slice thinly, and steam, simmer in a soup or stew, bake, sauté, or dip in batter and deep fry. They cook in 10 to 15 minutes and taste like asparagus, only more meaty and even better-flavored.

Very popular in early America when the human body was thought of as a foul, sinful object that must be violently "cleansed" like a dirty bathroom floor, doctors administered a poisonous decoction of the fresh cambium of the roots as an emetic and purgative. This counterproductive form of "heroic" herbalism, long rejected by science, is best relegated to the past.

At the same time, the decoction of the dried cambium, which doesn't have such harsh effects, was considered a stimulant and tonic. It was also used as eye drops for sore eyes, and to increase the flow of saliva.

A poultice of the root has been used externally for skin eruptions, boils, varicose veins, sores that don’t heal, and swellings, and a tincture of the berries was widely used in various pain remedies, and for rheumatism and toothache, in colonial times.

Because parts of this plant are potentially toxic, it's not suitable to use for making home remedies.

1. Handling this tree gives some people rashes. Use work gloves. [-But] The thorns are sharp enough to penetrate work gloves if you're not careful.

2. Don’t eat the shoots raw—they're probably poisonous uncooked. Eat only the cooked shoots. The berries and other parts of the tree are definitely poisonous.

3. Also—don't sign a contract with someone who's using the trunk of this tree as a walking stick—especially in blood!
Hercules' Club, Angelica Tree, Prickly Ash, Prickly Elder
Trim away the prickly thorns growing on this tree's shoots, and you'll have a wild vegetable that's a favorite among many of the foragers who know about it.
szechuan pepper, common elderberry
Onions and Apples with Devil's Walkingstick
onions-and-apples-with-devils-walkingstick

Everyone knows you can't mix apples and oranges, but how about apples and onions? With a few seasonings plus Devil's walkingstick as a catalyst, the combination works remarkably well, creating a superb side dish.

3 tbs. corn oil
3 tbs. sesame oil

6 yellow onions, sliced
2 cups Devil's walkingstick, sliced
1 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1 tsp. anise seed, ground
3/4 tsp. nutmeg

Gently sauté all ingredients in the oils for 25 minutes, or until the onions are lightly browned.

Serves 6 to 8

Cooking time: 30 minutes
