Honewort
honewort
Family: Apiaceae or Umbelliferae, the umbellifers

Young basal leaves: best from early- through mid-spring and in autumn, with some tender, young leaves at the base of the plant in the summer

Tender, young, green seeds: early summer

Roots: fall and early spring (they're insubstantial)
Partially shaded areas of moist woods, in thickets, and along edges of forest and park paths, near streams, and along river and stream banks
Throughout the eastern half of North America
Honewort's also native to Japan.

Look for a medium-sized, light green, hairless plant branching on top. The leaf structure includes of long-stalked, three-parted, palmate-compound basal leaves, plus alternate, medium-sized, irregularly lobed, sharply double-toothed, shiny, hairless, oval to lance-shaped leaflets lower-stalk leaves, as well smaller as undivided upper leaves.

Honewort has irregular, twice-compound, diffuse clusters of tiny, white, five-petaled flowers and small, elongated, green seeds that turn black.

Scratch and sniff for parsley and celery.

Branching toward the top, this slender, hairless perennial's light green stem grows from one to over three feet tall. Despite spreading via its taproot it also spreads by seeds.

Long-stalked palmate-compound basal leaves, and the stem's similar alternate lower leaves, consist of three irregularly lobed, sharply double-toothed, shiny, hairless, lance-shaped, oval leaflets, up to four inches long and two inches across, with leaf stalks sheathed near the leaf axil. Smaller, undivided, upper leaves pretty much lack leaf stalks.

Blooming on the upper stems and from the leaf axils from early- through mid-summer, small, diffuse, irregularly compound, umbrella-like flower clusters two to three inches across split into three to eight groups, which again split into groups of three to ten flowers. Growing on stalks of different lengths, the white, five-petaled, odorless flowers reach less that 0.125 inch across. Unlike similar-looking relatives, they lack bracts and sepals.

Small, elongated, two-parted ribbed seeds, 0.25 inch long, replace the flowers in late summer and autumn. Green at first, they darken to blackish.

The whole plant smells like parsley and celery when cut or bruised.

•Slender, hairless, light green-stemmed plant, branching toward the top
•Long-stalked, three-parted palmate-compound basal leaves
•Leaves composed of three irregularly lobed, shiny, sharply double-toothed, hairless, lance-shaped oval leaflets up to four inches long and two inches across
•Lower leaves on stem alternate, similar to basal leaves
•Upper stem leaves alternate, smaller than lower leaves, undivided, nearly stalkless
•Leaf stalks sheathed near the leaf axil
•Small, diffuse, irregularly compound, umbrella-like flower clusters two to three inches across, terminal and from the leaf axils
•Flower clusters split into three to eight groups, then subdivided again into groups of three to ten flowers
•White, five-petaled, odorless flowers less that 0.125 inch across, growing on stalks of different lengths
•Flowers lacking bracts and sepals
•Small, elongated, two-parted, ribbed seeds, 0.25 inch long, first green, then blackish
•Celery-parsley fragrance when injured
Pinch off the basal leaves and tender, young upper leaves along with accompanying tender stem tops, or strip off the immature seeds with your fingers.

Honewort has a fresh green flavor, similar to commercial chervil and its relative goutweed—a combination of parsley, celery, and carrots. Collect it in the spring and use the leaves as a parsley-like seasoning raw, or cooked for five to ten minutes. It's an excellent seasoning for salads and savory dishes, like parsley or commercial chervil, and it's cultivated in Japan for use in sushi and miso soup. It's also good dried, like parsley. Especially useful in bean soups, you can crumble dried honewort into almost any savory recipe. It's possible to use it as a green, leafy vegetable too, although it's quite strong-flavored.

You can also use the mild-flavored, crunchy very young stem, or the stem tops, like celery, although the leaves are much more abundant. Use the tender, young, green seeds in place of celery seed in breads, muffins, soups, or stews.

The roots of the young plant are reputedly like parsnips or carrots in early spring and autumn, but I always find them small and tough. The tiny flowers are reputedly edible, but I always find them too bitter.
Honewort is a good source of vitamins A, C, and B complex, as well as the minerals calcium, potassium, phosphorus, and iron.
Because this hard-to-recognize plant has poisonous relatives, it's not suitable for unsupervised beginners.

Similar-looking and edible, goutweed’s three leaves subdivide a second time, and it grows a much larger, denser, more bushy flower head. Sweet cicely, also edible, has denser, more regular flower clusters, hairy leaves, bracts, and the odor of black licorice. Other similar relatives simply don't share all of honewort's characteristics.

An unrelated, different-looking European honewort (Trinia glauca) doesn’t grow wild in North America.
Canadian Honewort, Wild Chervil
This is an excellent seasoning similar to parsley, but it has similar-looking poisonous relatives.
Goutweed, Sweet Cicely
Black Snakeroot
2)Luscious Latkes
2luscious-latkes

Combining principles of traditional latke-making with my original vegan concepts, you can make the best-tasting Jewish potato pancakes you’ve ever eaten [-(even if you've never tried Jewish potato pancakes)!]

Grating russet potatoes and immediately submerging them in water, then squeezing out the water, is the tried and true way of getting the starch content right. Lecithin granules and flaxseeds replace the flavor of egg yolks and whites respectively, something I’ve doing successfully for years now. Oatmeal is gooey, so using oat flour instead of the traditional, unhealthful, refined white flour helps the flax seeds to replace the binding power of the traditional eggs. Honewort adds a wild touch.

Serve with applesauce and Tofu Sour Cream

2 lbs. Russet potatoes (4 medium potatoes)
1 medium onion or 1 cup ramp bulbs, finely chopped
7 oz. (1 cup + 3 tbs.) oat flour
3 tbs. lecithin granules (available in health food stores)
1-1/2 tbs. flax seeds, ground into 3 tbs. meal
1/4 cup fresh honewort or parsley, finely chopped
1 tbs. Vege-sal (available in health food stores)
1/2 tsp. black pepper, ground
10 tbs. olive oil

1. Grate the potatoes and immediately submerge them in a bowl of water for at least 2 minutes.

2. Drain the potatoes and squeeze out the excess water in a cheesecloth or towel.

3. Mix with all remaining ingredients except the oil.

4. Heat the oil to 375 degrees in a frying pan.

5. Shape half the potato mixture into sloppy patties about 4 inches across and fry 4 minutes until browned underneath, then flip and brown the other side.

6. Remove with a spatula, place on layers of paper towels, and press out the excess oil with more paper towels.

7. Repeat steps 5 and 6 with the remaining potato mixture.

Makes 16 latkes

Cooking/preparation time: 30 minutes

This simple mixture serves as an excellent non-dairy alternative to sour cream. If you're suspicious of vegan cuisine or tofu and open-minded enough to experiment, this one will change your mind. Use it just as you would dairy sour cream.

Horse Balm
horse-balm
Lamiaceae, Mint Family
Late summer to fall
Partially shaded, rich, moist woodlands, especially along the edges of trails.
Much of Eastern North America

Look for a large-leafed branching mint in moist woodlands, with square stems and large, oval, pointed, stalked, coarsely toothed, opposite leaves. The large, loose, leafless terminal panicles branch vertically. They bear lemon-scented yellow flower with especially long lower lips have protruding stamens. The fruits are fan-shaped, three-pronged, and lemon-scented.

This large-leafed, branching mint, growing from two to five feet tall, has flowers and fruits with the lemony smell of citronella. It's called stoneroot for its large, hard, dense, knobby, slow-growing, woody rhizomes, which grow wrapped in dense, fibrous roots.

The oval, pointed, stalked, coarsely toothed, opposite leaves grow six to eight inches long and three to four inches wide.

Spreading in large, loose, leafless, vertically branching, terminal panicles atypical of the mint family, the yellow flowers grow from 0.33 to 0.05 inch long, with especially long lower lips, fringed tips, and two long, protruding stamens. The seeds consist of four flattened nutlets inside a green, curved, fan-shaped, three-pointed fruit.

•Square stem two to five feet tall growing in moist forests
•Oval, pointed, stalked, coarsely toothed, opposite leaves six to eight inches long and three to four inches wide
•Flowers in large, loose, leafless, vertically branching terminal panicles
*Yellow flowers growing from 0.33 to 0.05 inch long, with especially long lower lips, fringed tips, and two long, protruding stamens
•Fan-shaped, green, curved, flattened, three-pointed fruit
•Seeds consisting of four flattened nutlets
•Large, hard, dense, knobby, woody rhizomes wrapped in dense, fibrous roots
•Flowers and fruit strongly lemon-scented
Strip off the flowers and seeds with your fingers.

The strong, lemony flavor of the flowers and fruits makes them an outstanding culinary seasoning. Use in any dessert or sweet dish. Other ingredients will never drown out the flavor. A tea of the flowers or fruits is also delicious.

Freeze the flowers and fruits to preserve them. Drying dissipates the flavor.

Please collect this plant only where it's very common and abundant, not in places where it's uncommon, rare, legally protected, or endangered, and don't uproot and kill this slow-growing plant, which is already in decline due to overharvesting. If you must have the roots, please buy them from a reputable dealer who gets it from a supplier who cultivates it.

And don't eat the leaves, which induce vomiting.

Other mints (Mentha spp.), many of which are edible, don't grow in shady forests. They have much smaller leaves, and they smell minty, not lemony.

Horse balm isn't related to or similar to the citronella tree (Citronella spp.), which doesn't grow wild in North America, although it contains the same essential oil and has the same fragrance.
Stoneroot, Citronella, Richweed, Hardhack, Heal-All, Horseweed, Ox-Balm, Hardhack, Knob Grass, Knob Root, Richweed
This unusual, large-leafed forest mint has seeds that make an outstanding tea and seasoning.
2)Horse Balm with Flowers and Fruit
2horse-balm-with-flowers-and-fruit
This mint has huge, oval, pointed, toothed, opposite leaves; long, branching panicles of paired yellow flowers, and paired green fruits.
3)Horse Balm Flowers and Fruit
3horse-balm-flowers-and-fruit
The flattened, yellow, opposite flowers have two very long, protruding stamens, while the green, curved, flattened fruit has three prongs, and the stem is four-sided.

mango-lassie

Horse balm's large, opposite leaves have very little fragrance, and besides, they're poisonous, but the three-pronged, flattened seeds, which grow on loose, terminal panicles, have the wonderful lemony fragrance and flavor of citronella.
Irish Moss
irish-moss1
Family: Gigartinaceae, the red seaweed family
Irish moss is in season all year.
On rocks, in tidal pools, lower intertidal and shallow subtidal zones, and washed up onto beaches.
The Northeast Coast from New Jersey northward, the European Atlantic Ocean, reportedly off California and Japan too, and, if you live inland, in health food stores!
It's native to both sides of the Atlantic ocean.

Look for a short, frilly, fan-shaped, cartilaginous seaweed up to six inches across, that may be dark purplish-brown to black, greenish-yellow, red, or even white. It's short stalks branch four or five times.

This short, frilly, fan-shaped perennial seaweed, up to six inches long, feels soft and cartilaginous (gristly). It's tough and elastic when wet, brittle when dry.

Usually dark purplish-brown to black, it may also be greenish-yellow, or red. Underwater, it’s sometimes iridescent-blue (water blocks red light and lets blue through, so colors always get distorted underwater), and after enough bleaching in the sun, it turns white.

Growing from a disk-shaped holdfast, the short stalk branches four or five times, creating a variable, fan-like shape with subsections up to 0.75 inches across, ending in crowded, frilled-looking tips.

•Fan-shaped, cartilaginous-textured seaweed up to six inches across
•Park purplish-brown to black, greenish-yellow, red, colored, or bleached white by the sun
•Frilled margins
•Short, flat stalks 0.75 inch across, branching four or five times
•Disk-shaped holdfast

Your best chance of harvesting Irish Moss along beaches is at low tide, especially after storms have ripped it from its underwater habitat, but the currents must be favorable too. However, if you visit the seashore often, pretty soon you'll be able to harvest a supply that will last for years, especially if you have a food dehydrator to preserve your harvest.

Unlike other edible seaweeds, this one is too tough to eat directly. But it contains a substance called carrageenan that makes a great thickener for puddings, soups, sauces, and gravies. Put a handful of fresh or dried Irish Moss in a cheesecloth or fine-mesh bag and cook it for up to an hour a sweetened liquid. Most of the Irish moss will dissolve, and you’ll get a tasty, creamy pudding.

The Irish simmer sun-blanched Irish moss (colored Irish moss discolors food) in milk (I use non-dairy milk) for 20 minutes, then discard it, to make blancmange, their traditional pudding. Use 1.5 cups of fresh seaweed or 0.5 cup reconstituted dried seaweed to thicken three to four cups of liquid. Cinnamon, sassafras, lemon, sumac, and licorice are good complementary seasonings. (Lemon juice and sumac concentrate cause soy milk to curdle, but they're fine with nut- or oat milk.)

To thicken soups, stews, or sauces, simmer it in some of the broth for 20 minutes, strain it out, and return the broth to the recipe.

Irish moss is highly nutritious, and the dishes you make from it are easy for convalescents to digest. It provides vitamin B1, beta-carotene, iodine, sulfur, potassium, calcium, phosphorus, iron, sodium, manganese, bromine, mucins, protein, and a little fat.

Carrageenan is considered an anti-coagulant, anti-inflammatory, demulcent, emollient, expectorant, and tonic, with the ability to coat the digestive tract and sooth peptic and duodenal ulcers. It’s used for thyroid problems such as goiter (for which it will be effective if the cause iis an iodine deficiency), and for gastritis, colon disorders and obesity. It also relieves diarrhea and helps form bulky stools, and there's evidence that it can lower high blood pressure. It's an especially valuable food for convalescents, especially after a bout of tuberculosis and pneumonia. Laboratory experiments have demonstrated anti-viral properties, supporting its traditional use for irritating coughs, bronchitis and many other lung problems, some of which are viral in origin.

A syrup of Irish moss with rose hips, honey, and lemon has been used for sore throat, and a decoction helps heal chapped hands. Irish moss is also supposed to be helpful for treating radiation contamination, although I'd like to see convincing evidence that this is so.

Some sources have suggested that Irish moss is dangerous because processed extracts are toxic. But since the digestive system can’t release the carrageenan into the bloodstream, there's no evidence of any toxins absorbed, or of people getting sick after using this seaweed, these fears seem unfounded.

Avoid collecting in polluted areas.

Because Irish Moss also has anticoagulant properties, avoid it if you take prescription blood thinners such as Coumadin, and don't use it if you're suffering from Crohn's disease.
Don’t confuse Irish moss with Iceland moss (Cetraria islandica), a lichen that doesn’t grow in the sea.
Sea Moss, Blancmange, Jelly Moss, Pearl Moss, Carrageen moss, Seamuisin, Curly Moss, Curly Gristle Moss, Dorset weed, Sea Moss, White Wrack
A healthful thickener, traditionally used in Irish cuisine, you can sometimes find unlimited quantities of this seaweed washed up on beaches.
Irish Moss
irish-moss
This fan-shaped, reddish seaweed's flattened blades subdivide repeatedly, creating a frilly look.
Lemon Seaweed Pudding
lemon-seaweed-pudding

Irish moss is one of the best thickeners for cold dishes, such as puddings. Here, kudzu helps counteract the dampening effect of the lemon juice, which is essential in a lemon pudding. You may garnish this pudding with fresh mint leaves at the table.

3 cups boiling water
1/2 cup Irish moss
1/2 cup raw cashews
1/2 cup silken tofu
1/4 cup lecithin granules (available in health food stores)
2 tbs. glycerin
2 tbs. olive oil
1 tsp. clear liquid stevia (available in health food stores)
2 tsp. lemon juice
2 tsp. dried peppermint leaves, ground
1/2 tsp. lemon extract
The zest of 1 lemon
1/2 tbs. fresh orange rind
1/4 tsp. wild ginger

1. Simmer the Irish moss in the water 10 minutes very carefully, covered. Take care that it doesn't boil over.

2. Meanwhile, place the remaining ingredients in a blender.

3. Strain out and discard the seaweed, pour the liquid into the blender, and pur334e completely.

4. Bring to a boil over medium heat stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer, stirring occasionally, for another 10 minutes.

5. Chill

Makes 4 cups

Preparation/cooking time: 30 minutes
Jerusalem Artichoke
jerusalem-artichoke
Family Asteraceae (Compositae), the astor or composite family
The tubers are available in early spring and fall.
Fields and thickets, along roadsides, and near streams and ponds
Most of North America except the Southwest and Western Canada
Probably originally from The Great Plains, the Native Americans traded this plant around much of Eastern North America in prehistoric times.

Look for a tall, coarsely hairy sunflower, branching mostly toward the top, with large, coarsely hairy, oval to lance-shaped, slender, three-ribbed, pointed, toothed leaves and partially winged leaf stalks. It has several composite flower heads consisting of 12 to 20 yellow ray flowers encircling a central, yellow-brown disk. Pointed, hairy, lance-shaped to ovate green bracts overlap at the base of each flower head.

Growing six to 12 feet tall, this coarse-haired native sunflower branches toward the top.

Oval to lance-shaped, slender, three-ribbed, pointed, toothed leaves six to ten inches long, grow opposite toward the plant’s base, and alternate toward the top. Growing six to ten inches long and two to inches wide, they're broadest near the base. The long leaf stalks are partially winged.

Several odorless composite flower heads 2 to 3.5 inches across bloom in late summer and fall, with 12 to 20 yellow ray flowers and a central, yellow-brown disk. Several series of pointed, hairy, lance-shaped to ovate, green bracts overlap at the base of each flower head.

Tubers clustered at the base of each plant allow this species to spread and form colonies. The lumpy, whitish, light brown, reddish, or purple tubers, shaped like commercial ginger and crisp and white inside, grow from one to 2.5 inches long—smaller than commercial varieties.

•Tall, coarsely hairy sunflower six to 12 feet tall, branching mostly near the top
•Alternate leaves toward the top, opposite leaves toward the bottom
•Toothed leaves large, lance-shaped to oval, coarsely hairy, three-ribbed, pointed, six to ten inches long, broadest toward the base
•Long leaf stalk partially winged
•Several terminal, odorless composite flower heads two to 3.5 inches across
•Flower head with 12 to 20 yellow ray flowers encircling a yellow-brown disk
•Hairy, pointed, lance-shaped to ovate, green bracts overlapping at each flower head's base
•Lumpy tubers from one to 2.5 inches long whitish, light brown, reddish, or purple
•Tubers crisp and white inside, growing under the plant's base
Dig up the tubers with a shovel, easiest after rain has softened the soil and in locations with the fewest rocks. You can store them, refrigerated, for several weeks.

If your digestive system can handle them, the crisp, sliced tubers are excellent, raw, in salads, with a flavor like sunflower seeds, not like artichokes—a widely reported error. Although they've been cooked like potatoes, boiling them for long periods of time makes them mushy. However, they're great steamed, or simmered in soups. You can also sauté them 5 to 10 minutes, or stir-fry them for 2 minutes. I've also dehydrated them, ground them into powder, and used them along with whole-grain flour for baking.

They're excellent tossed in olive oil with herbs or spices and salt, and baked in a covered casserole dish about for 20 minutes or until just cooked through like a quick version of baked potatoes. People have also pickled them.

Jerusalem artichokes provide vitamins A, B1, and B3, as well as the minerals potassium, phosphorous, calcium, iron, and copper, plus fructose. They're also rich in inulin, a polysaccharide that doesn't get absorbed or elicit an insulin response, and is beneficial to people with blood sugar problems.

Considered an aperient, aphrodisiac, cholagogue, diuretic, spermatogenic, stomachic, and tonic in herbal medicine, it's been used as a folk remedy for diabetes and rheumatism, but needs testing for efficacy.
These tubers, which you should eat in moderation at first, cause great flatulence in some people, especially if eaten raw. Avoid standing downwind from such individuals!

This native sunflower isn't from Jerusalem, so its first name is probably a corruption of the Spanish word for sunflower, girosol. Someone must have thought it tastes like an artichoke (it doesn't) and gave it its surname accordingly.

There are other members of the sunflower family (Helianthus spp.), cultivated and wild, all non-poisonous, that look similar. However, only the Jerusalem artichoke's leaves have partially winged leaf stalks. None of the other species have tubers, and their other features also don't all match. Nevertheless, when someone on a Central Park tour refused to believe me, I lent her my shovel and let her dig for the tubers of one of the cultivated look-alike. Maybe she'll give up her fruitless (or tuber-less) search as we pass her by on my next tour, and I'll be able to recover my shovel!
Sunchoke, Sunroot, Earth Apple
Sometimes sold commercially, this native sunflower produces delicious tubers that are easy to dig up.
Sunchoke Soup
sunchoke-soup

This soup includes some of the elements of miso soup (namely the miso!), but it contains lots of vegetables, including Jerusalem artichokes, so it's significantly more filling.

3 tbs. olive oil
1-1/4 cups Jerusalem artichokes, sliced
1 onion, chopped
2 cloves of garlic, chopped
3 celery stalks, sliced
5 cups vegetable stock
1 14-oz.package silken tofu, diced
1/4 cup mellow miso

1. Sauté the Jerusalem artichokes, onion, garlic, and celery in the olive oil 10 to 15 minutes, or until the onions are translucent.

2. Add the vegetable stock and tofu and simmer another 10 minutes.

3. Turn off the heat, lower a strainer part way into the soup, place the miso inside the strainer, and stir with a wooden spoon to incorporate the miso into the soup.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Jewelweed
jewelweed
Family Balsaminaceae, the balsam family

The shoots are available in early spring, the seeds occur from summer to early fall, but you can harvest the stems for skin irritations from when the plant first appears, in early spring, until it dies back in mid-fall.
Partially shaded, wet habitats, i.e., wetlands, near streams, ponds, and lakes, and along the edges of trails in moist woods—often growing in dense stands
All of the US east of the Rocky Mountains, the Pacific Northwest, and southern Canada

Look for succulent sprouts, each with one pair of toothless, kidney shaped to circular leaves, in early spring. Later on, look for a medium-sized plant with succulent, translucent, smooth, pale green, hairless, branching, blue-green powdered, succulent stems that support blue-green, oval, wavy-edged, alternate and opposite, long-stalked leaves. Yellow or red-spotted, pendant, trumpet- or slipper-shaped, spurred medium-sized flowers hang with small, cucumber-shaped seedpods.

Springing from shallow, fibrous roots, this branching, hairless annual grows from two to four feet tall, usually in dense stands. Segmented by thickened nodes, powdered with a waxy, blue-green bloom, and filled with a clear liquid, the succulent, translucent, smooth, pale green stems grows three to five feet tall and 0.75 inches wide.

In early spring, jewelweed begins as a smooth, slender, succulent sprout with one pair of toothless, circular to kidney shaped, blue-green leaves.

The subsequent wavy-toothed, oval, opposite (bottom) or alternate (upper), blue-green mature leaves grow from two to 4.5 inches long and 1.25 to 3 inches wide, with leaf stalks up to 2.5 inches long. The leaves repel water, either due to a wax on the surface, or because both the surfaces of the leaves and the water drops bear the same electrical charges, and therefore repel each other. This makes the leaves’ undersides shine silvery when submerged in water, and causes glistening, spherical drops to form on the leaves when it rains.

Attractive, trumpet- or slipper-shaped flowers each hang suspended from a slender flower stalk. Blooming from late spring to mid fall, they grow to about 0.75 inch long, each with three petals, one which curls, forming a long tube with a flared opening, and ending in a narrow, curled base that looks like a spur. Spotted jewelweed’s orange flower is spotted with dark red, while pale jewelweed’s flower is yellow, with less conspicuous spots.

0.5 to one inch long, the green, cucumber-shaped seedpods consist of layers of tissue that dry and shrink at different rates, creating tension that’s released along the seams when touched. One to several tiny, ovoid, green-and-brown, turquoise, or blackish seeds disperse explosively.

•Succulent sprout with one pair of toothless, kidney shaped to circular leaves in early spring
•Pale green, smooth, succulent, pale green stem three to five feet tall and 0.75 inches wide
•Stem segmented by thickened nodes, powdered with a waxy, blue-green bloom, and filled with a clear liquid
•Shallow, fibrous roots
•Oval, shallow-toothed, opposite or alternate stem leaves, two to 4.5 inches long and 1.25 to three inches wide
•Water drops form spheres on the leaves
•Leaf undersides shine silvery when submerged in water
•Yellow flowers, or red-spotted orange flowers, trumpet- or slipper-shaped, each with a curled base, hanging from slender flower stalks
•Cucumber-shaped green seedpods 0.5 to three inch long
•One to several tiny, ovoid, green-and-brown, turquoise, or blackish seeds in each pod
•Mature seeds ejected explosively
•Moist, partially shaded habitat

Chop shoots no more than eight inches tall, boil for 20 minutes, discard the water, and use as a cooked vegetable. Mild flavored and delicate, it’s best as a side dish, with spices, salt, and a few drops of a light oil, or (after parboiling) added to soups, stews, casseroles, or rice. The sprouts shrink when you cook them, and while some people like them, I find them too unexciting and labor-intensive to prepare them very often.

The tiny seeds taste like walnuts, fun for kids of all ages to gather, but too small for more than a trail nibble or garnish.

Containing the anti-inflammatory and fungicide 2-methoxy-1-(4-naphtho)quinine, both species contain a superb topical anti-inflammatory: Crush the stem and apply the juice directly to a wide range of skin conditions, from acne to fungus infections, and you won't be making a rash decision. It cures mosquito bites if you keep the bite wet with the fresh juice for 15 minutes, beginning right after you've been bitten. I've used it thousands of times, on myself and others. It's also good for bee and other insect stings, significantly lessening their severity. It's excellent for nettle stings, minor cooking burns, sunburn, scrapes, rashes, and a wide range of other skin irritations, as well as for fungus infections such as athlete's foot and ringworm.

Rub it where you’ve touched poison ivy before you develop the rash, and unless you're hypersensitive to poison ivy, you won't get the rash. Jewelweed also seems to be effective against poison ivy rash once it’s developed in about half the people who try it.

Chemists have synthesized anti-inflammatory chemical found in jewelweed, mixed it into an ointment, and apply it where the sun don't shine. What did they create?

Preparation H!
Don't eat any parts of the plant except for the seeds and the boiled sprouts, or you'll be ingesting bitter, acrid glycosides or alkaloids that can cause vomiting and diarrhea.
Touch-Me-Not
A minor edible plant, this is a major medicinal one, curing mosquito bites in the fiel and preventing poison ivy rash.
2)Jewelweed-Witch Hazel Extract
2jewelweed-witch-hazel-extract

Although you can boil jewelweed and freeze the water, which will contain the medicine, in ice cube trays, this recipe is much more practical, and completely effective. The solvent is Witch hazel (Hamamelis virginiana), a purely medicinal woodland shrub not covered in this app, but carried by drugstores as a pure, inexpensive extract.

Pack a jar with jewelweed stems only. Pour witch hazel over it to the very top of the jar. Cover the jar tightly, and shake. If air bubbles appear, pour in more witch hazel or mold will develop. Shake twice a day for 2 weeks, then strain out and discard the jewelweed. Transfer the extract to a squirt bottle. This medicine, which is great for all sorts of skin irritations, lasts for years at room temperature.
1)Jewelweed—Very Young Plant, and Flowering Jewelweed
1jewelweed—very-young-plant,-and-flowering-jewelwe

The youngest, lower leaves of the sprout (left) are rounded to kidney shaped. All the other leaves are oval and wavy-toothed. On the mature plant, the lower leaves are opposite, the upper leaves alternate. Trumpet- or slipper-shaped, spurred flowers, and cucumber-shaped seedpods, hang from slender flower stalks. The stem is always smooth and succulent.
2)Jewelweed Sprout
2jewelweed-sprout
At its youngest stage, jewelweed's pale, succulent stem bears a pair of long-stalked, round to kidney-shaped, smooth, toothless leaves at its top. You can parboil and eat these sprouts.
6)Jewelweed Leaf with Water Drops
6jewelweed-leaf-with-water-drops
Jewelweed's oval leaves repel water, which forms spherical drops.
3)Spotted Jewelweed in Flower
3spotted-jewelweed-in-flower

Spotted jewelweed is a succulent, branching herbaceous plant with long-stalked, opposite and alternate, oval, wavy toothed leaves, and pendant, orange, trumpet- or slipper-shaped flowers. It always grows in moist soil.
4)Spotted Jewelweed Flowers and Seedpod
4spotted-jewelweed-flowers-and-seedpod

The orange, two-sided, red-spotted flower has an open end with three petals, and a curved spur on the other end. The green, cucumber-shaped seedpod's seams will split open when touched, to eject the seeds. Each flower and seedpod hangs suspended from a long, slender stalk.
5)Pale Jewelweed Flower
5pale-jewelweed-flower
Pale jewelweed's flower is very similar to spotted jewelweed, only it's yellow. The immature seedpod, not ready to pop, is still very slender.
1)Pineapple Fool
1pineapple-fool

You won’t make a fool out of yourself when you serve this winner—great with wild jewelweed seeds or nuts!

2-1/4 cups fresh, ripe pineapple, diced
1 cup Tofu-whipped Creme
1/2 cup raisins
1/4 cup jewelweed seeds, black walnuts or chopped commercial walnuts
1 tsp. cinnamon

Mix all ingredients together.

Serves 4

Preparation time: 5 minutes

Kelp
kelp
Family: Phaeophyceae, the brown algae
Spring and summer
Clear, shallow oceans—anchored to rocks beyond the low tide zone
From the Long Island Sound north on the east coast, and from northern California to Alaska on the west coast.
Various kelp species grow in cold ocean waters worldwide.
Look for dark brown seaweeds up to ten feet long with a flattened midrib and thin, ruffled edges, plus [a] butterfly shaped reproductive sporophylls above the anchoring holdfast.

This group of long-bladed, dark brown seaweeds normally grow up to ten feet long, with a flattened midrib, and thin, ruffled edges. When the seaweed reproduces, butterfly-shaped reproductive structures called sporophylls grow above the holdfast. Many kelp species have pneumatocysts—gas-filled bladders, usually around the base of the blade near the midrib.

Different kelp species supposedly grow in the deep, cold, northern waters of the east and west coasts (an Alaskan variety grows 70 feet long), and if you’re not a scuba diver, you’re supposed to wait to gather it after a storm washes it ashore. Nevertheless, I found a ten-year supply of sugar kelp (Laminaria sacchaina) while I was swimming in the Long Island Sound on vacation in Montauk, NY. The water was so shallow that I could hold my breath, swim down eight feet to the bottom, stuff a handful of kelp into my wet suit (you can also use a mesh bag), and come up for air to dive again.

•Brown seaweed up to ten feet or more long
•Flattened midrib
•Thin, ruffled edges
•Holdfast attached to hard object on seabed
•Butterfly shaped sporophylls above the holdfast sometimes present

Use goggles, flippers (if you have them), and a mesh bag. Take a deep breath, and dive (it also helps to know how to swim). Otherwise, wait for storms and the right currents to wash it onto beaches. If you have a food dehydrator, you can gather enough to last for years under the right circumstances.

Cook kelp in soups or stews, or with grains until tender. Some species are good to eat after simmering 10 minutes, others require over an hour of simmering.

Kelp is also great cooked with beans. It helps soften them, and reduces the amount of gas they cause.

In Wales, they sell kelp's midrib, which tastes like a salty carrot, as a fresh vegetable.

Kelp provides mucopolysaccharides and the sugar mannitol, plus algin, phenolic compounds, polar lipids, and glycosyl ester diglycerides, as well as protein, carbohydrates, and essential fatty acids. It provides beta-carotene, vitamins B1, B3, B5, B6, B9, B12, C, E, biotin, choline, inositol, and PABA. It's a source of around 30 minerals and trace minerals, including iodine, potassium, calcium, iron, zinc, copper, magnesium, selenium, sulfur, phosphorus, silicon, sodium, bromine, nickel, strontium, and vanadium.

All seaweeds are high in sodium, so use them sparingly, and avoid them if you're on a low-sodium diet. Eating too much kelp can also give you too much iodine, so enjoy it in moderation. And, of course, avoid collecting kelp in polluted waters.
There are many species of kelp, all edible.
This well-known edible seaweed is even better when you collect it yourself; you can find many species they don't sell in health food stores.
Sugar Kelp
sugar-kelp
The brown blade, central midrib, frilly edges, and holdfast are typical features of all the kelps.
Vegetable-Seaweed Soup
vegetable-seaweed-soup

This easy-to-make soup gets its outstanding qualities with the addition of wild kelp, and one of my favorite flavoring: chonce.

14 cups vegetable stock
1-1/2 cups barley
1-1/2 cups dried kelp, soaked to reconstitute and chopped
1 large red onion, sliced
4 carrots, sliced
3 celery stalks, sliced
1/2 cup Chonce
1/2 cup red miso

1. Simmer the barley and kelp in the stock for 1 hour.

2. Add the celery, carrots, and chonce and simmer another 15 minutes.

3. Turn off the heat, lower a strainer part way into the soup, place the miso in the strainer, and mash it into the soup with a wooden spoon.

Serves 8 to 12

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 1 hour

Kentucky Coffee-tree
kentucky-coffee-tree
Family: Fabaceae, the pea or legume family

The pods ripen in the fall, but, unless assailed by severe storms, don't fall to the ground until mid-spring. However, bare seeds from pods that have decomposed lie on the ground, apparently immune to decay, all year.

This tree grows naturally in rich soil in the woods, but landscapers plant it in urban and suburban parks, as well as on city streets, i.e., along the sidewalks in the Inwood neighborhood of Manhattan.
It grows throughout much of the US east of the Rocky Mountains, and in Ontario, but not in New Hampshire, Vermont, Louisiana, or Florida. It has also been planted, locally, in other states.

Look for a large tree with thick twigs and dark gray, scaly, deeply grooved bark; very large, twice-divided feather-compound leaves, many oval, toothless, paired leaflets; and flattened, somewhat curved, brown, chunky, leathery seedpods with thickened rims, each on a slender fruit stalks.

[Look for a large tree with thick twigs and dark gray, scaly, deeply grooved bark. This tree has very large, twice-divided feather-compound leaves and many oval, toothless, paired leaflets. Flattened, somewhat curved, brown, chunky, leathery seedpods have thickened rims. Each pod grows on a slender fruit stalk.

This tree, with thick twigs and dark gray, scaly, deeply grooved bark, grows from 40 to 100 feet tall and up to 50 feet across. It bears gigantic, feather-compound, twice-divided, alternate leaves one to three feet long, with seven to 13 oval, toothless, paired leaflets. The leaves, which turn yellow in autumn, develop later and drop earlier than those of other trees. Also, the tiny leaf buds remain hidden under a woolly covering in the leaf axils, so the tree looks dead for half the year.

In the spring, green-white flowers hang from the leaf axils on loosely branching pyramidal panicles, three to four inches long on male trees, ten to 12 inches long on female trees.

Hanging from slender stalks one to two inches long, flattened, somewhat curved, brown, chunky, leathery, thick-rimmed seedpods, five to ten inches long, two to trhee inches wide, and one to two inches thick, ripen on the female trees in autumn. Inside, six to ten flattened, dark brown seeds, each under one inch in diameter and 0.25 inch thick, lie embedded in a sticky, green pulp.

•Tree from 40 to 100 feet tall and up to 50 feet across, with thick twigs and dark gray, scaly, deeply grooved bark
•Feather-compound, twice-divided, alternate leaves one to three feet long
•Leaf composed of seven to 13 oval, toothless, paired leaflets, turning yellow in autumn
•Green-white flowers hanging from the leaf axils on loose, pyramidal panicles, three to four inches long on male trees, and ten to 12 inches long on female trees
•Flattened, somewhat curved, thick-rimmed, brown, chunky, leathery seedpods, five to ten inches long, two to three inches wide, and one to two inches thick
•Slender fruit stalks one to two inches long
•Six to ten flattened, dark brown seeds, each under one inch in diameter and 0.25 inch thick, inside the pods
•Sticky greenish pulp inside the pods

Collect the seedpods when you they're available, and look for bare seeds on the ground under the tree, sometimes partially embedded in the soil. It may take your eyes a while to learn to spot them, and some places under the tree will have more seeds than others, so be patient and persistent.

Or show a seed to a kid. They have sharp eyes, love searching for things, and get good at this very quickly.

This seeds provide an excellent caffeine-free coffee substitute. Even though the tree's unrelated to coffee, beverage's resemblance is so strong, I can't drink it (I dislike coffee).

Wash off all the pulp and roast the seeds for 3 hours in a 300 degree F oven in a covered casserole dish or baking pan. The seeds sometimes pop like popcorn, and you don't want them all over your oven. Thorough cooking is required to destroy all toxins in the seeds.

Grind the seeds to the consistency of coffee in a blender, 0.5 cup at a time (they're too heavy to grind en masse in a coffee- or spice grinder), and brew in a coffee maker, like regular coffee.

The seeds also make a first-rate culinary seasoning, used like coffee, to flavor chocolate or mocha dishes, or Mexican moles. Crack the toasted seeds with a mallet or hammer, discard the shells, and grind a few seeds into a powder in a spice- or coffee grinder. Since you're using them as a spice, and not to make coffee, you won't be using so many seeds that you'll destroy your spice grinder.

The Kentucky coffee-tree's green pulp and raw seeds are poisonous. They contain the cytisine, which suppresses respiration, plus hydrocyanic acid and saponins. These toxins are destroyed by thorough roasting, and none of the hundreds of people who collected them on my many tours every year going back to 1982 ever reported having been made sick from them. Also, the pioneers used these seeds as a coffee substitute in the past, with good results, although they missed the caffeine. Just rinse off the seeds and roast them as directed.

The much longer, flat, twisted brown pods of the honey locust tree, which also has large, twice-divided, feather-compound leaves and has edible parts, is thorny, as is Devil's walkingstick, which has similar leaves but develops berries rather than seedpods. The Kentucky Coffee-tree bears no thorns, and you should have no trouble telling these species apart using if you look for these obvious differences.

The pods superficially resemble those of poisonous relatives in the legume family, although other features won't match. Eating the seeds the knobby green pods of wisteria (Wisteria spp.) can be deadly. However, wisteria's a vine, not a tree, the Kentucky coffee-tree's pods are dark brown, not green, and you don't use it by eating the seeds!
Nicker Tree, Stately Manor Coffeetree
This tree provides the world's best caffeine-free coffee substitute, and a very useful coffee-flavored seasoning for chocolate- and other appropriate recipes.
Wisteria
1)Wild Hot Chocolate
1wild-hot-chocolate

Here’s my vegan version of this well-loved beverage, better than ever with a balance of natural flavorings, especially the Kentucky coffee-tree seeds, which enhance the complimentary flavors of chocolate and carob perfectly.

3-1/2 cups soy-rice milk, oat milk, almond milk, or other nut milk
3/4 cup dairy-free sugar-free carob chips (available in health food stores) or chocolate chips
3 tbs. lecithin granules (available in health food stores)
1/4 cup unsweetened Dutch cocoa
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia (available in health food stores)
The scrapings of 1 inch of vanilla bean or 2 tsp. vanilla extract
The of insides of 3 roasted Kentucky coffee-tree seeds, ground, or 1/2 tsp. coffee extract
1 tsp. orange extract
1/2 tsp. salt

1. Heat almond milk until very hot, but not boiling, around 160 degrees F (a liquid thermometer makes this easier).

2. Meanwhile, place the remaining ingredients in a blender.

3. Pour in the almond milk and blend 15 seconds or until just smooth, beginning on low speed and shifting to high, while holding down the cover with a dishtowel to prevent an eruption. The longer you blend, the more frothy the drink will become.

Makes 6 cups

Preparation time: 15 minutes
1)Kentucky Coffee-tree Leaf and Seedpod
1kentucky-coffee-tree-leaf-and-seedpod

This huge leaf is divided into large segments, which are again divided into oval, pointed, toothed opposite leaflets. [-So this is a twice-divided feather-compound leaf.] The chunky, flattened, stalked seedpod, thickened at the rim, contains several dark, flattened, circular seeds. You can see one where the pod is cracked open.
6)Kentucky Coffee-tree Bark
6kentucky-coffee-tree-bark
This tree has dark gray, scaly, deeply furrowed bark.
2)Kentucky Coffee-tree Leaves, Pods, and Seeds
2kentucky-coffee-tree-leaves,-pods,-and-seeds

As the chunky, slightly curved, stalked seedpods ripen, the seeds within, round, hard, and flattened, become dark brown. They make an excellent, caffeine-free coffee substitute and coffee-flavored seasoning after thorough roasting and grinding, but they're poisonous raw. The sticky yellow-green pulp that surrounds them is toxic too.
4)Kentucky Coffee-tree in Winter
4kentucky-coffee-tree-in-winter

This inconspicuous, long panicle of tiny, green-white flowers releases pollen into the wind, to fertilize the female flowers on other trees. They develop among the opposite, oval, pointed, toothed leaflets in late spring.
5)Kentucky Coffee-tree Leaves and Pods

This tree's huge, twice-divided, feather-compound leaves turn yellow in autumn, as the dark brown seedpods, which usually remain on the tree until spring, ripen.
2)Chocolate-Coffee Ice Cream
2chocolate-coffee-ice-cream

Kentucky coffee-tree seeds add just the right contrast to the chocolate and carob in this unusual variant of a favorite dessert.

3-1/2 cups almond milk, soy milk, oat milk, or other nut milk
3/4 cup dairy-free sugar-free carob chips (available in health food stores)
1/2 cup silken tofu, drained
1/2 cup pignola nuts
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin
1/4 cup unsweetened Dutch cocoa
1/4 cup grape seed oil
3 tbs. lecithin granules (available in health food stores)
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia
The scrapings of 1 inch of vanilla bean or 2 tsp. vanilla extract
The of insides of 3 roasted Kentucky coffee-tree seeds, ground; or 1/2 tsp. coffee extract
1 tsp. orange extract
1/2 tsp. salt
1/2 cup unsweetened chocolate chips

1. Heat almond milk until very hot, but not boiling, around 160 degrees F (a liquid thermometer makes this easier).

2. Purée in a blender with all the remaining ingredients except the chocolate chips and the remaining almond milk

3. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions with the remaining almond milk

3. Stir in the chocolate chips

Makes 6 cups

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Freezing time: 2-1/2 hours
Linden Tree
linden-tree
Family: Malvaceae, the mallow family
The leaves start to develop in mid-spring, and the flowers bloom in late spring.
In full sunlight in parks, and along urban and suburban streets
Throughout the US, where it's commonly planted
Europe

Look for a medium-sized street or park tree with simple, alternate, long-stalked, heart-shaped, pointy tipped leaves with unequal bases. Several small, light yellow, strongly fragrant, long-stemmed flowers with five petals and five sepals, grow on a raceme hanging from a papery, pale yellow-green bract in late spring. Small, hard, greenish-white, long-stalked, paired, spherical fruits hang from the same bracts in the summer.

A naturally occurring hybrid between two European trees that don't grow in America, the small-leaved lime (T. cordata), and the large-leafed lime (T. platyphyllos), this common, cultivated, medium-sized tree, which takes on a pyramidal shape if unimpeded, grows up to 60 feet tall.

Two to ten inches across, the simple, alternate, heart-shaped, toothed leaves, thinly hairy below, have pointed tips, unequal bases, and long leafstalks.

In late spring, four to ten light yellow, strongly fragrant, long-stemmed flowers, each about 0.5 inch across, with five petals and five sepals, grow on a raceme hanging from a papery, pale yellow-green, strip-shaped bract about five inches long, and from 0.5 to one inch wide.

Small, hard, greenish-white, long-stalked, paired, spherical fruits, about 0.25 inches, grow from the same bracts in the summer. For some strange reason, these tiny balls are sometimes call monkey’s nuts! After they ripen in the summer, the bract breaks and whirls off into the wind with the fruit, like a helicopter.

•Medium-sized street- or park tree with simple, alternate, long-stalked, heart-shaped leaves with pointed tips, unequal bases, and sparse hairs underneath
•Four to ten light yellow, strongly fragrant, long-stemmed flowers, about 0.5 inch across, with five petals and five sepals
•Flowers growing on a raceme hanging from a papery, pale yellow-green, strip-shaped bract
•Small, hard, greenish-white, long-stalked, paired, spherical fruits, about 0.25 inches, hanging from the bracts in the summer

And collect the young leaves in mid-spring, while they're young and tender, before they reach full size.

Collect the flowers while they’re fresh, fragrant and colorful, before they begin to brown.

A strong infusion of the flowers makes a tasty, relaxing tea. The young leaves that develop in mid-spring are also good in salads, or as a cooked green. During World War II, the French dried the mature leaves, powdered them, passed them through a sieve, and used them as a thickener and in place of flour.

Many sources suggest using the immature seeds as a chocolate substitute, but whenever I or anyone on my tours tastes them, they turn out to have all the culinary properties of pebbles. The best thing to do with these "monkey's nuts" is to return them to the emasculated monkey!
Avoid using the flowers if you're allergic to perfumes. And avoid getting stung by the bees when you collect—they're also attracted to the flowers [-too]!
Lime Tree, Monkey Nut Tree
This European tree, planted extensively in America, produces one of the best-tasting herb teas. It is also very good for stress.
Pineapple Weed, Linden Viburnum
Chick Peas with Linden Leaves
chick-peas-with-linden-leaves

Here’s a simple way to prepare this tasty, nutritious staple, with linden leaves adding a wild touch.

1-1/2 cups chick peas, soaked overnight or steeped 1 hour, rinsed, and drained
4-1/4 cups of vegetable stock or water
2 cups young linden leaves, chopped
2 tsp. fennel seeds, ground
1 tsp. black peppercorns, ground into 2 tsp.
2 tsp. lemon thyme or thyme, ground
2 tsp. tarragon, ground
1 tsp. dried lemon rind
3 cloves of garlic, crushed
2 tbs. olive oil
2 tbs. dark miso

1. Simmer all ingredients except the miso covered, over low heat, 2 to 3 hours, or until the chickpeas are tender.

2. Drain, stir the miso into the liquid in a strainer lowered into the put, using a whisk.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 2 to 3 hours
4)Linden Tree in Flower
4linden-tree-in-flower

This medium-sized tree has a pyramidal shape when growing in the open. In late spring, its branches are covered with long, thin, papery bracts, from which loose racemes of the fragrant, pale yellow flowers hang. A park like this is a common place to find this tree, which is also planted along neighborhood streets.
1)Linden Flowers and Leaves
1linden-flowers-and-leaves

Hanging from racemes attached to pale green, papery bracts, these fragrant, pale yellow flowers make this common street tree especially attractive in late spring. Each flower [-[see inset]] has five petals, lots of red-brown-tipped stamens, and an ovoid conglomeration of pistils.
3)Linden Seeds
3linden-seeds
The paired, long-stalked, hard, whitish, spherical, inedible seeds ("monkey's nuts") will get carried off into the wind by the light green, strip-shaped, papery bract.
2)Linden Leaves and Bracts
2linden-leaves-and-bracts

Good to eat while still young and tender, these heart-shaped, toothed, long-stalked, alternate leaves always have long, pointed tips and uneven bases. The light green, strip-shaped, papery bracts will eventually fly off into the wind with the seeds, but at this stage, the leaves are too old to eat, and flower buds haven't opened yet.
Marsh Marigold
marsh-marigold
Ranunculaceae, the buttercup or crowfoot family
The immature leaves and flower buds are in season in early spring, before the flowers open.
The marsh marigold grows anchored to the soil in sunny, freshwater wetlands, such as marshes and fens. People also plant it in water gardens.
Northeastern North America, the West Coast, and Canada

Look for a medium-sized wetland plant with many medium-sized, shiny, round to kidney shaped, shallow-toothed basal leaves supported by long, thick, hollow, branching stems. Shiny, showy, clusters of waxy, yellow, five-parted buttercup-like flowers grow on short, thick, hollow, branched, succulent, stems with small, dry, reflexed seed capsules.

In the early spring, this wetland plant, which grows from one to two feet tall, forms basal rosettes of shiny, round to kidney-shaped, shallow-toothed leaves three to seven inches wide, supported by long, thick, hollow, branching stems.

Shiny, waxy, yellow, showy flowers, which look like oversized buttercups, bloom from early spring through late spring—sometimes well into the summer. One to 1.5 inches across, they grow on short, thick, hollow, branched, succulent, stems in clusters of one to 7. Each flower has five sepals in place of petals.

The fruit is a small, dry, recurved capsule called a follicle. It ripens in late spring and summer, when it splits lengthwise to release its red seeds.

•Wetland plant one to two feet tall
•Basal rosette consisting of many shiny, round to kidney shaped, shallow-toothed leaves three to seven inches across
•Leaves supported by long, thick, hollow, branching stems
•Flowers growing on short, thick, hollow, branched, stems in clusters of one to seven, from early spring sometimes into summer
•Shiny, waxy, yellow, buttercup-like flowers one to 1.5 inches across, with five showy sepals
•Small, dry, recurved follicles that split lengthwise
•Tiny, red seeds

Cut off the young leaves and flower buds with a knife, or break them of with your hands. Waterproof footwear or wading boots will make them much more accessible. And use rubber gloves, since handling the plant can cause problems.

This is not a plant for unsupervised beginners—buttercups are poisonous, as is this one, if not properly prepared. Boil the young leaves or unopened flower buds without their stems or the roots in two changes of rapidly boiling water, one minute in the first water, then five to six minutes in the second batch of boiling water. Don't use cold water.

You may subsequently pickle the boiled flower buds in hot vinegar with pickling spices, but you must discard the vinegar. Though not spectacular, if properly prepared, adequately seasoned (use any savory herbs or vinegar, some vegetable oil, and salt) marsh marigold leaves’ soft texture and mild flavor go well with other ingredients in soups, casseroles, or other vegetable dishes.
Marsh marigold leaves are a good source of iron, although this may be lost through the necessary boiling.

People made an antispasmodic decoction for children’s fits by boiling the roots. The decoction was also used to help cough up mucus from the lungs, to induce sweating, stimulate the immune system to combat infections, and as a laxative. People have also chewed the roots and applied them to inflamed wounds as a poultice, and to remove warts. Nevertheless, the plant contains potentially deadly toxins, so this plant is not a suitable for home remedies.

This is not a plant for unsupervised beginners. Prepare only as directed. The plant contains the acrid, if aptly named, glucoside, called helleborin, plus another toxin called protoanemonin. Symptoms of poisoning include a burning sensation in the throat, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, dizziness, fainting, and convulsions. Even too much handling can cause a severe rash, so wear gloves when you handle it.

Let's dispel some of the great confusion that plant causes:

1. The marsh marigold is not a marigold (Tagetes patula) at all, but a member of the buttercup family.

2. A completely different edible plant is also called cowslip (Primula veris). Although it grows in England, not in America, American herb books sometimes refer to it without differentiating between the 2 species, leading to accidental misuse of the American plant.

3. A similar-looking member of the buttercup family that grows in partially sunny habitats in wet woodlands, lesser celandine, also has young leaves which are edible boiled, but it's smaller, the leaves lack teeth, and each leaf has a black stripe running along its length.

4. A smaller relative, floating marsh marigold (C. natans), also edible, has small white or pinkish flowers, kidney-shaped leaves, and stems that may float. It grows from Alaska southeastward to northern Minnesota.
Cowslip, Kingcup
This marsh plant is edible if properly prepared, but too dangerous for unsupervised beginner.
2)Curried Red Beans
2curried-red-beans

My original curry powder recipe works perfectly with red beans, especially after you add mild-flavored marsh marigold leaves to contrast the spiciness.

2 cups red beans, steeped 1 hour (or soaked overnight), drained, and rinsed
5 cups water
7 oz. fake meat (available in Chinese fake meat supply stores), diced, or soaked, drained texturized vegetable protein
1 red onion, chopped
3/4 cup Steve's Curry Powder or commercial curry powder, or to taste
1 tbs. coconut oil or sesame oil
4 cloves of garlic, chopped
The juice of 1 lemon
2 cups twice boiled marsh marigold leaves (caution—this plant must be precooked as directed above.)
2 tsp. Vege-sal (available in health food stores)

1. Pressure cook all ingredients except the marsh marigolds and Vege-sal, or simmer in a saucepan 3 hours or until the beans are tender.

2. Stir in the remaining ingredients.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Cooking time: 40 minutes or 3 hours

Steve’s Curry Powder

Simple, effective, and great in all appropriate recipes, I was very happy to formulate this recipe until it disappeared. Try as I might, I could never duplicate it. Finally, years later, my refrigerator died, and when the workmen removed it to put in the replacement, there was the battered, yellowed index card with the priceless recipe. Here it is, resurrected. Compare it with commercial curry powder any recipe, and you'll taste what I'm talking about!

6 tbs. coriander seeds
3 tbs. cumin seeds
3 tbs. cardamom seeds
2 tbs. cinnamon sticks, broken into pieces
6 tbs. turmeric
2 tbs. powdered ginger
1 tbs. Cayenne hot pepper

1. Grind the coriander, cumin, cardamom, and cinnamon in a spice grinder

2. Mix them with the powdered herbs.

Makes 1-1/2 cup

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Northern Bayberry
northern-bayberry
Family: Myricaceae

You can collect the leaves from mid-spring, when they first appear, to late fall, when most of them fall off. A few partially brown leaves hang on through the winter, and you can still use these, alth0ugh they're not as good as the fresh, green leaves.
Sunny or partially shaded sandy habitats and fields, especially coastal seashore habitats
Most of Northeastern North America, the North Atlantic Coast, the Great Lakes Region, and eastern Canada

Look for a stout, upright, spreading shrub with light gray bark and many branches, growing near the seashore or in fields, with oval, leathery, shiny, dark green leaves, with a few shallow teeth at their apex. BB sized, chalky, gray-white, stalkless berries cluster on the short branches beneath the female shrubs' leafy tips.

This stout, upright, spreading, fragrant, semi-evergreen shrub, with light gray bark and many branches, grows three to 12 feet tall and equally wide.

Starting off red-tinged, the dark green, shiny, oval, leathery, strongly aromatic, elliptical leaves grow 1.5 to four inches long and 0.5 to 1.5 inches wide. Shallow teeth grow at the leaf apex, and if you have very good vision (or a magnifier) you'll see tiny, yellowish resin dots on their undersides. Some leaves overwinter, become increasingly brown, and remaining fragrant.

Inconspicuously flowering in late spring and early summer, the male flowers are yellow green catkins, while the tiny, green female flowers, growing individually and blooming on separate bushes, lack sepals and petals. They cluster on the branches beneath the shrubs’ leafy tips, to be replaced by stalkless, chalky, gray-white, waxy, BB sized berries that ripen in late summer and fall.

•Stout, upright, spreading shrub with light gray bark and many branches, growing near the seashore or in fields
•Leathery, shiny, dark green, strongly aromatic leaves 1.5 to four inches long and 0.5 to 1.5 inches wide
•Shallow teeth at the leaf apex
•Tiny, yellowish resin dots on leaf undersides
•Male flowers yellow-green catkins
•Tiny individual, greenish female flowers lacking petals and sepals, blooming on separate bushes from the male flowers
•Waxy, BB sized, chalky, gray-white, stalkless berries clustering on the branches beneath the shrubs’ leafy tips
Simply strip off the leaves with your fingers.

Use bayberry leaves the same way as you use commercial bay leaves (Laurus nobilus), but use twice the volume of bayberry leaves. Their flavor is vastly superior to commercial bay leaves. Add them to soups, stews, gravy, tomato sauce, salsa and beans, and remove them after the recipe is done. Putting them in a tea bag, tea ball, or tying them into a piece of cheesecloth makes them easier to remove.

The leaves are easy to dehydrate for long-term storage.

Thanks to the resins that permeate the northern bayberry and its relatives, all parts of these bushes have important medicinal uses. The leaves are carminative. Add them to bean dishes, and they'll reduce the amount of gas the beans cause.

The cambium, leaves, and roots are used as a tonics, stimulants, and astringents. A decoction of the cambium or roots supposedly improves circulation and tones tissues, particularly in the stomach and intestines. It's used to clear up mucus congestion of the head and stomach, and a hot tea, which contains the anti-microbial compound myrictrin, is used for colds, fevers, and to promote the flow of bile.

As an astringent, the decoction was used for hemorrhages, as a gargle for sore throats, and as a wash for gum disease. Externally, a compress of strong tea was used for varicose veins, swelling from insect bites, and as a douche. The leaves are the weakest part, best for less severe conditions. Although all these various uses haven't been tested, and you shouldn't experiment on yourself with them for serious conditions, they certainly should be researched.

Be sure to remove bayberry after cooking. Commercial bay leaves are tough and sharp enough to cut people’s stomachs, sometimes necessitating surgery. This is less likely with the wild species, but you have nothing to lose by enclosing the leaves in a tea bag, tea ball, or a piece of cheesecloth, and removing them when the recipe is done.

Mricadiol, which this herb contains, reportedly makes you retain sodium and excrete potassium, just the opposite of what you need for cardiac health. This is not a problem for normal culinary use, but for this reason, extended use of high concentrations for medicinal purposes is inadvisable.
This is one of the best ingredients to cook with, even though you never eat it!
Classic Tomato Sauce
classic-tomato-sauce

If you use the highest-quality ingredients in the right proportions and cook them to perfection, and you’ll create a tomato sauce so good, you’ll never be satisfied with any brand of canned tomato sauce. And using wild bayberry leaves instead of commercial bay leaves adds a noticeable extra touch. I use this with pasta, in soup, and with vegetables, and freeze some for future use.

6 tbs. olive oil
4 large red onions, sliced
8 cloves of garlic, chopped
10 cups dead-ripe tomatoes, coarsely chopped
2 small cans of tomato paste
1/2 cup white wine
1/2 cup fresh basil, chopped
2 tbs. Vege-sal (available in health food stores) or seasoned salt, or to taste
1 tbs. bayberry leaves packed into a tea ball or tied into a piece of cheescloth, or 1/2 tbs. bay leaves.
2 tsp. dried oregano, ground
1/2 tbs. dried tarragon, ground
1 tsp. dried lemon thyme or thyme, ground
1 tsp. black peppercorns, ground
1 tsp. dried marjoram, ground

1. Slowly sauté the onions in the olive oil 25 minutes, or until translucent.

2. Add the garlic and continue to sauté another 10 minutes, or until the onions are lightly browned.

3. Combine with the remaining ingredients in a large saucepan, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring often, reduce the heat to low and simmer, uncovered, 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.

4. Remove the bayberry leaves.

Makes 12 cups

Preparation time: 35 minutes

Cooking time: 65 minutes

orpine
Family: Crassulaceae, the orpine family
The leaves are in season from mid-spring to early summer, the tubers are edible in the fall, and before the flowers appear in the spring.

Look for a thick-stemmed succulent one to 1.5 feet tall with light green, oval, blunt-toothed, succulent, whorled or alternate leaves under 2.5 inches long and a rounded terminal cluster of small, pink-lavender, star-shaped flowers.

This thick-stemmed perennial grows from one to 1.5 feet tall, with light green, oval, blunt-toothed, succulent leaves one to 2.33 inches long. They either grow in whorls of three, or they're alternate. With very short leaf or no stalks, the leaves are so fleshy,[- live-forever] can survive for weeks without water, and even a piece of leaf can regenerate a new plant.

Growing on a showy, dense, rounded terminal cluster, the small, pink-lavender five-petaled, star-shaped flowers bloom from summer to early fall. Each flower is up to 0.5 inches long, twice as long as the sepals.

The distinctive rhizomes form horizontal masses of finger-like tubers, the main form of propagation. Orpine rarely sets seed.

•Thick-stemmed, succulent perennial one to 1.5 feet tall
•Light green, oval, blunt-toothed, succulent leaves one to 2.33 inches long
•Leaves alternate or growing in whorls of three
•Leaf stalks short or absent
•Small, pink-lavender five-petaled, star-shaped flowers in a showy, rounded, terminal cluster
•Each flower up to 0.5 inches long,
•Sepals half as long as the petals
Break off the young leaves with your fingers, or dig up the roots with a shovel or trowel.

A mild-flavored vegetable excellent in salads, young orpine leaves are crunchy and tender, good used with other more spicy greens. They're also fine sautéed;, or added to soups or other vegetable dishes, cooking in about 10 to 15 minutes. You can also boil older leaves 15 to 20 minutes or until tender.

The boiled, young tubers are reputedly edible, but this garden plant doesn't grow wild in my area, and while I've nibbled a few leaves from neighborhood gardens, I never had the nerve to dig up the roots!

Pliny the Elder recommended this plant for wounds and fistulas in the first century AD, while in more recent times, it's been used externally as a compress for slow-healing external ulcers, and internally as an infusion of the whole plant, for ulcers, lung problems, and diarrhea, but with no research one way or the other concerning its effectiveness.

While this plant has been eaten by foragers for years, it contains the slightly toxic alkaloids sedine and sedamine, apparently not in enough concentration to cause any harm, but this is a plant to eat in small amounts at first, to make sure it doesn't give you nausea.

Roseroot (Sedum rosea), also edible, resembles orpine, but it’s smaller, with untoothed, spirally arranged, overlapping leaves. A circle of leaves surrounds its yellowish or purple four-petaled flowers, and the large, inedible roots smell like roses. Also, the plants' ranges differ—roseroot grows in colder places such as Canada, or on mountain tops in New England.
Stonecrop, Live Forever, Live-long, Aaron's Rod, Purse Plant, Witch's Purse, Frog's Belly, Pudding-bags
This common garden succulent, which also grows wild, provides foragers with pleasantly chewy, mild-flavored leaves, as well as edible tubers.

cream-of-orpine-soup

How do you make cream soups without dairy products? Simple—use flavorful vegetable stock thickened with silken tofu and raw cashews, plus some butter-flavored corn oil and the egg yolk properties of lecithin granules—you’ll never miss the milk and cream. Add with the right seasonings and fresh vegetables, and you’ll come up with a winner every time. Here’s how to use orpine for this:

3 cups orpine leaves or broccoli, steamed 15 minutes
1/2 cup silken tofu
1/2 cup raw cashews or pignoli nuts
2 tbs. mellow miso
2 tbs. corn oil
2 tbs. lecithin granules

1 tsp. caraway seeds, ground
1 tsp. paprika
1/4 tsp. yellow mustard seeds, ground
1/2 tsp. turmeric
2-1/2 cups boiling vegetable stock

1. Purée; all ingredients in a blender.

2. Transfer to a saucepan, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly.

3. Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Ostrich Fern
ostrich-fern
Family: Dryopteridaceae, the wood ferns

Depending on the climate and latitude, the fiddleheads are in season for only about ten days toward the end of early spring. And the timing varies from year to year, depending on whether there's an early or late spring.
Partially shaded or sunny, rich, damp ground, moist woods, riverbanks, alluvial plains, and swamps
Easterm North America and southeastern Canada
A circumpolar plant, it's also native to northern Europe and parts of Scandinavia

Look for a large, colonial vase-shaped fern arising from a black, knobby base, with tall, unbranching, twice-divided fronds tapering rapidly upward and slowly downward, surrounding more dense fertile fronds. Or, a hairless fiddlehead with a groove running along its back, a stout base tapering upward, and large, brown, papery scales.

•Large, colonial fern with unbranching sterile fronds configured like a vase
•Sterile fronds twice-divided, narrowing abruptly toward tip, tapering gradually toward the base
•Distinctive, shorter, dense, persistent, central fertile fronds, blackening in the winter
•Fern's base a black, rough, knobby tangle of dead material just above ground level
•Hairless fiddlehead with a stout base, tapering upward
•Large, brown, papery scales surrounding the fiddlehead
•A groove running along the back of each fiddlehead
•Fronds growing from a black, knobby base
•Thick, braided-looking rhizomes and black roots

Snap off half the fiddleheads of each bunch with your hands, along with the accompanying stems. Don't collect unrolled ferns, which are poisonous, and please don't deplete the rhizome by collecting more than half the fiddleheads of each bunch.

This is one of the few wild foods sought-after by restaurant chefs and touted in food columns and blogs, and it deserves the attention it's getting. Its delicate flavor lies somewhere between that of asparagus and snap peas.

Rub off the scaly membrane under running water in a tall colander set into a shorter bowl. Drain, chop, then steam, simmer, or saut334 the fiddleheads for 5 to 10 minutes. They're somewhat dry, so if you're serving them as a stand-alone vegetable, add a light sauce (i.e., a lemon sauce). The contrast will turns the fiddlehead's dryness into an asset. Avoid overseasoning or overcooking fiddleheads, or you'll drown out their wonderful flavor.
Ostrich fern fiddleheads provide lots of vitamin A and niacin, some vitamin C, the minerals potassium, phosphorus, magnesium, and iron, and the trace minerals manganese, zinc, and copper.

Mature ostrich ferns are poisonous. Eat only the fiddleheads before they've unfurled, and cook them. Raw fiddleheads eaten in quantity may cause severe diarrhea, and they can destroy the body's reserves of thiamine.

Unlike most other wild vegetables, fiddleheads don’t grow back after you pick them. Be sure to collect only where very abundant, and take no more than half the fiddleheads from any bunch, to avoid depleting the rhizome of nutrients and killing it.

Bracken, with an edible three-parted fiddlehead that appears from mid- to late spring is branched, whereas the ostrich fern isn't.

Fiddleheads of other ferns won’t kill you, but they’re usually too bitter and/or hairy to eat. The cinnamon fern’s (Osmunda cinnamomea) fiddlehead looks like the ostrich fern's, but it's one of the hairy, bitter species. It doesn't arise from a single base, and its fertile frond is reddish and knobby, not feathery like the ostrich fern’s. Nevertheless, people who want this to be the ostrich fern (which they only know under the name of "fiddlehead") pick and eat it, and try to ignore its hairs and awful flavor.
Some deadly plants such as poison hemlock have finely divided, fern-like leaves when mature, but they never form fiddleheads, and exhibit only the most superficial resemblance to the ostrich fern.
Fiddlehead Fern, Garden Fern, Hardy Fern
This delicious wild fern is one of the few edible wild plants that non-foraging foodies know about. It has a short season, but it can be very abundant, and is well-worth locating.
2)Ostrich-stuffed Eggplant From The Wild Vegan Cookbook, by "Wildman" Steve Brill
2ostrich-stuffed-eggplant-from-<i>the-wild-vegan-c

Ostrich fern fiddleheads with seasonings and tofu-cheese make a wonderful stuffing for this Middle Eastern appetizer. Serve it hot or cold.

2 large eggplants
4 cups ostrich fern fiddleheads, coarsely chopped
1 cup Tofu Cream Cheese
6 cloves of garlic, crushed
2 tbs. fresh basil, chopped
2 tsp. oregano, ground
2 tsp. Vege-sal (available in health food stores)
1 tsp. fennel seeds, ground
2 tbs. sesame seeds

1. Prick the eggplants with a fork to prevent them from exploding, place them on a rack over a cookie sheet and bake 50 minutes in a preheated 350°F oven.

2. Cut the eggplants in half lengthwise when cooled, and use a spoon to remove most of the pulp from the skins.

3. Mix the pulp with all the remaining ingredients except for the sesame seeds.

4. Sprinkle with the sesame seeds.

5. Transfer the stuffing back into the skins

6. Bake 30 minutes on an oiled cookie sheet in a preheated 350°F oven

Serves 8

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Cooking time: 90 minutes

Look for mats of mossy, green, succulent plants up to 1.5 inches tall with oval, entire, stalkless, crowded, very thick, succulent, erect, alternate leaves less than 0.25 inch long and terminal clusters of long-stalked, yellow, five-petaled flowers, 0.25 inch across, blooming from mid- to late spring.

This mossy, succulent evergreen either grows up to 1.5 inches tall, or trails three to four inches along the ground, spreading with runners, to form mats.

Its oval, toothless, stalkless, crowded, very thick, erect, alternate leaves grow less than 0.25 inch long.

Break off the leaves and stems with your fingers, taking care not to uproot and destroy the plant.
Pepper sedum has a biting, peppery aftertaste that isn't apparent at first. Use it in small quantities, raw or cooked, as you would black pepper, to flavor food.
Pepper sedum is a good source of vitamin C.

An infusion of this plant, which contains calcium malate, has been used as a diuretic for edema, but edema is a symptom, so a diagnosis of the cause is essential. People have also used the tea to expel worms.

The juice or the crushed leaves have been applied externally to skin ulcers, corns, boils, warts, wounds, ringworm, and minor burns. However, the plant can be a skin irritant, so it should be used with caution.
The sap can give susceptible people rashes. Don’t eat it in large quantities (as though anyone could!), or it may make you vomit and cause diarrhea. Use it as a seasoning only.
