Shallow, slow-moving, fresh water, ponds, ditches, lakes, margins and streams
Eastern North America and Oregon
Look for a colonial water plant with large, relatively narrow, lance-shaped, ovate, or triangular leaves, and attractive blue and purple flowers on the ends of round, erect, unbranched stems.

This is a hard one to harvest, since you have to wade in the water. Wear wading boots, or shorts and sandals. Gather the leaves and tender, young stems in early summer, and gather the seeds in the fall, using your hands.

In early summer, you can add the young, unfurling leaves and tender tops of the stem raw in salads, steam or sauté them lightly, or cook them 10 to 15 minutes in soups.

The crunchy, nutty-flavored seeds are great raw or lightly toasted. You can snack on them, or add them to cereals, like nuts. You can also cook them like a grain, boiled 20 to 30 minutes or until tender in twice their volume of water, with a dash of vegetable oil and seasonings. You can also grind them into flour and use with whole-grain flours.

Eating the leaves growing in water entails the same risk of chemicals or pathogens as drinking the water, so use the leaves only where the water's been tested. And don't harvest bare-footed—slobs tend to throw glass bottles into shallow water, and your feet can get badly cut! Also, don't wade without wading boots unless you're sure the water's free of parasites.

One person reported to me that he experienced a delayed reaction to eating the seeds—numbness in his throat and mouth, with a very unpleasant burning, prickly sensation—every time he tried them. This may be a rare individual reaction, but you should try very little of this plant the first time, and gradually increase you portions.

A similar southern relative, P. lanceolata, which you use the same as the northern species, has lance-shaped leaves.

Unlike pickerelweed, the leaves of the similar-looking arrowhead (Sagittaria australis), which has difficult-to-harvest but edible tubers, have a main midrib, as well as pointed lobes at its base.
Arrow arum (Peltandra virginica), which contains poisonous calcium oxalate crystals, is an aquatic plant with pointed lobes at its leaves' bases, and completely different flowers and seeds.
Pickerel Rush, Tuckahoe, Black Potato, Wampee, Wampi
Difficult to harvest, this water plant has edible young leaves and seeds.
Chewy Granola
chewy-granola

Roasting oats in a date mixture makes them chewy and sweet. Adding mixed wild pickerelweed seeds and sweet spices creates a superb breakfast cereal.

5 cups quick rolled oats
4-1/2 cups toasted wild or commercial nuts and seeds, chopped
1/2 cup pickerelweed seeds
1 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1 tsp. powdered ginger
1 tsp. cloves, ground

To Blend

1/4 cup apple juice
1/4 cup water
1/4 cup Medjool (soft) dates, pitted
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/4 cup sesame oil
1 tsp. vanilla
1/2 tsp. clear liquid stevia
1/2 tsp. salt
1/2 tsp. cinnamon extract
1/2 tsp. peppermint extract

1. Puré the ingredients to blend in a blender.

2. Mix with the oats and roast in a baking dish in a preheated 300 degree oven 1 hour, or until lightly browned and fragrant.

3. Mix with the remaining ingredients.

4. Serve with soy-, oat-, or nut milk, plus fresh or dried fruit

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Cooking time: 60 minutes
3)A Stand of Pickerelweed
3a-stand-of-pickerelweed

Pickerelweed grows in dense stands. The large, long, smooth, basal leaves have distinctive rounded lobes at their bases, and no main midrib. The small, blue flowers crowd onto the tops of unbranched stems, each with one stalkless leaf below the spike.
1)Pickerelweed Flower Spike
1pickerelweed-flower-spike
Pickerelweed's small, blue and purple, two-lipped flowers grow crowded at the top of an unbranched terminal spike, above a single, stalkless, long, smooth leaf that has two rounded lobes at its base.
2)Pickerelweed Flowers
2pickerelweed-flowers
These small, hairy, blue-and-purple, bilaterally symmetrical flowers each have two yellow spots. They grow crowded on an unbranched spike at the top of the stem.
Ramp
ramp
Family: Amaryllidaceae, The amaryllis family (previously, Family: Alliaceae)

People think ramps are in season only in early spring, but that only applies to the leaves, which wilt and die when the trees shade them out. You can dig up the bulbs, which are at their best after the leaves are gone, in the summer, fall, and winter (if the ground isn't frozen), as long as you can recognize the plant when it's in flower or seed, or you can spot the plant's skeleton from late fall to early spring.
Partially shaded, moist, deciduous woodlands, slopes, swamps, and near rivers
Northeastern North America plus Georgia, Alabama, and Oklahoma

Look for dense stands of medium-sized onion/garlic scented plants with two to three smooth, pointed, elliptical, parallel-veined, light green basal leaves. Ramps have short, hairless, purple, scallion-like leaf stalks, each wrapped in a sheath. There's a smooth, slender, round, erect, unbranched, leafless, reddish stem. A small, dome-shaped flower cluster grows above a pair of short-lived bracts on top with close to 35 white-stalked, small, creamy white, six-petaled flowers. The flowers become tiny, hard, shiny, spherical black seeds, grouped in threes.

Growing in dense stands, this onion/garlic-scented plant has but two or three smooth, pointed, elliptical, parallel-veined, light green leaves—basal only—four to 12 inches long and one to three inches across, with arising from, hairless, purple, scallion-like leaf stalks wrapped in a sheath. Growing in bunches up to ten inches across, they come up in early spring, then yellow and die in mid-spring when the trees shade them out.

In early- to mid-summer, a smooth, slender, round, erect, unbranched, leafless, reddish stem grows from six to 18 inches tall, with a sheath at the bottom. At the apex, close to 35 creamy white, six-tepaled flowers, each around 0.125 inch across and 0.25 inch long, bloom in a dome-shaped cluster 1.25 to 2 inches across, above a pair of short-lived bracts. Each flower has its own slender, whitish flower stalk.

From late summer through fall, tiny, hard, shiny, spherical black seeds, grouped in threes, supplant the flowers. Some of the leafless stems persist over the winter, indicating the locations of the two to six layered, pear-shaped, onion-like, white bulbs, each about 0.75 to two inches long and covered in a light brown papery wrapping.

•Dense stand of onion/garlic-scented plants with only two or three smooth, pointed, elliptical, parallel-veined, light green basal leaves
•Leaves four to 12 inches long and one to there inches across, with parallel veins, growing in bunches up to ten inches across
•Leaves yellowing and dying from mid- to late spring
•Short, hairless, purple, scallion-like leaf stalks wrapped in a sheath
•Smooth, slender, round, erect, unbranched, leafless, reddish stem growing from six to 18 inches tall, with a sheath at the bottom, in the summer
•Terminal flower cluster dome-shaped, 1.25 to two inches across, above a pair of short-lived bracts
•Close to 35 six-tepaled creamy white flowers, each around 0.125 inch across and 0.25 inch long
•Each flower with a slender, white flower stalk
•Tiny, hard, shiny, spherical black seeds grouped in threes
•Two to six layered, pear-shaped, white, onion-like bulbs, each about 0.75 to two inches long
•Entire plant strongly scented of onions and garlic when injured

In early spring, hold down the stems with one hand, and pull off bunches of the leaves with the other hand, or cut them with a knife or shears. The bulbs are puny while the leaves, which have taken up all their nutrients, are in season, but the leaves are excellent.

The bulbs are much larger after the leaves wilt, so dig them up with a shovel or trowel from mid-spring through fall, or even in the winter, if the ground isn't frozen and you can recognize the skeleton of the seed stalk.

Ramps have been over-harvested in some locations, but they're very common in other places. Please don't collect them where they're rare, and collect only a small proportion, especially when harvesting the bulbs, where the plant isn't very common.

Use the rightfully prized, strong-flavored leaves and bulbs like scallions or shallots—raw in salads, or cooked, using nearly any method in virtually any savory recipe.
Ramps are the best tasting member of the Alliums (the onion/garlic group). They make fantastic soups (try using them in your favorite traditional leek and potato soup), stews, sauces, and casseroles. You could also simply steam the leaves for 5 to 10 minutes and serve, seasoned with salt and pepper, as a superb vegetable side dish. A ramp dip is exquisite too. The bulbs make excellent pickles, and you may also dry ramps, or freeze them after cooking. Dried, powdered ramps make a terrific seasoning.

After the plant flowers in the summer, the flower stalk extends into the bulb and forms a hard core, which needs to be cut out with a paring knife. This usually isn't the case in autumn.
Ramps provide vitamins A and C and some vitamin B1, plus potassium, phosphorus, calcium, and iron.

Not much used medicinally, ramps probably have medicinal uses similar to wild and commercial garlic species. Native Americans used the leaves as a spring tonic, and to treat colds and croup. They also treated earaches by applying the warm juice of the bulbs and leaves externally.

This plant can lead to the loss of your romantic partner and all your friends—saying that it causes bad breath is a colossal understatement!

Collect small proportions of ramps where they are common, avoid collecting where rare, and please don't over-harvest.

The ramp isn't similar to the commercial leek *(A. porrum)* or most other Alliums, all of which are edible. Although these relatives all smell like onions or garlic, the ramp is almost the only species with broad leaves. Only 1 rare edible relative, also called the wild leek (A. burdickii), has broad leaves, but they're much smaller, only 1 to 2 inches across, and only 10 to 20 flowers grow in each cluster.

Ramp flowers resemble those of sarsaparilla, (Aralia nudicaulis), but this odorless medicinal plant has large, feather-compound leaves when it flowers, and all its other features are completely different from the ramp's too.

The ramp is misleadingly named after an edible European plant, the rampion (Campanula rapunculus), which looks different and doesn't grow wild in America—quite fortunate, since it's very dangerous—just look what befell Rapunzel after her dad filched one from a witch's garden to satisfy the craving of his pregnant wife!

The poisonous lily of the valley's (Convallaria magalis) leaves resemble ramps, but this garden plant, which also grows wild, has no odor, and the flowers, seeds, and roots are completely different from the ramps'.
Wild Leek, Wood Leek

The world's best-tasting member of the onion/garlic family, you can find it in large quantities in moist woodlands and swamps every spring. It's so good, they have ramp festivals in the Deep South every spring, but they have to close all the schools the next day—they can't pay the teachers enough to endure being in the same classroom with a bunch of kids with ramp breath!
Lily of the Valley
Ramp Casserole
ramp-casserole

Here’s a very simple way for onion lovers to enjoy ramps with pasta.

1/4 cup olive oil
11 ramp bulbs, sliced
5 large red onions, sliced
2/3 cup Classic Tomato Sauce or commercial tomato sauce
2/3 cup soy mayonnaise
4 cups whole-grain macaroni
1 10-oz. package of any non-dairy cheese (available in health food stores), grated
2 tsp. Vege-sal
1 tbs. arrowroot

1. Gently sauté the onions and ramps in the olive oil 30 minutes, or until lightly browned.

2. Meanwhile, boil the macaroni in salted water with a dash of olive oil according to the manufacturer’s directions, and drain in a colander.

3. Stir the tomato sauce, mayo, and Vege-sal into the pasta and transfer into a large, oiled roasting pan.

4. Top with the grated cheese.

5. Bake 30 minutes, or until the cheese has at least partially melted, in a preheated 350 degree oven.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 30 minutes

The tiny, cream-white flowers grow above two short-lived, papery bracts atop a smooth, slender, leafless stem. They're replaced by tiny, hard, black, spherical seeds, grouped in threes.

Redbud Tree
redbud-tree
Family: Fabaceae, the pea or legume family
The flowers bloom at the end of early spring and beginning of mid-spring, while immature pods appear in mid-spring.
Sunny to lightly shaded places, cultivated parks, thickets, ravines, and borders of streams, edges of woods, and lightly shaded moist woodlands
Redbuds grow wild in much of Eastern North America, but not in Northern New England. They also grow in the easternmost Southwest, and in Ontario, but landscapers may plant them anywhere.

Look for a small to medium-sized, often shrubby tree, with a short main trunk, rounded crown, zig-zag stems, and dark brown bark. This tree has medium-sized, smooth, toothless, pointy tipped, heart-shaped, alternate leaves. Reddish-purple buds cover the branches and trunk in early spring, followed by dense, showy clusters of four to eight small, long-stalked, fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, rosy-pink flowers. Small, persistent, flattened, seedpods change from green to brown.

This small to medium-sized often shrubby tree, with a short main trunk, rounded crown, and zig-zag stems, usually grows from 20 to 30 feet tall and 25 to 30 feet wide. Vase-shaped when young, it leans toward the sunlight or becomes irregularly shaped when older, with an umbrella-shaped crown. The dark brown bark starts off smooth, then becomes scaly and ridged, sometimes with maroon or orange-brown patches exposed as the bark peels somewhat on older trees.

The smooth, toothless, alternate, pointy-tipped, heart-shaped leaves grow from 2 to 6 inches across and long. Bright green tinged with red at first, the leaves mature to a dark green color, then turn bright yellow in autumn.

Dense, showy clusters of four to eight small, long-stalked, fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, rosy-pink, pea-like flowers arising from reddish-purple buds cover the branches and trunk in early spring, while the leaves are just beginning to form.

The fruit is a persistent, flattened pod two to four inches long, changing from green to brown, and containing several flat, elliptical, brown seeds 0.25 inches across.

•Small to medium-sized, often shrubby tree, with a short main trunk, rounded crown, and zig-zag stems, usually growing from 20 to 30 feet tall and 25 to 30 feet wide
•Dark brown bark starting smooth, then becoming scaly and ridged, sometimes with maroon or orange-brown regions
•Smooth, toothless, pointy-tipped, heart-shaped, alternate leaves grow from two to six inches across and long, tinged with red at first
•Dense clusters of reddish-purple buds covering the branches and trunk in early spring
•Dense, showy clusters of four to eight small, long-stalked, fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, rosy-pink, pea-like flowers, covering the branches and trunk in early spring
•Persistent, flattened seedpods two to four inches long, changing from green to brown
•Several flat, elliptical, brown seeds 0.25 inches across, inside the pods
Strip off the flowers or immature seed pods with your fingers.

The flowers impart a delicious, sweet-sour flavor with an overtone of fresh snap peas, plus a gorgeous color, to salads and a large variety of cooked dishes. You can toss them into oatmeal when it’s finished cooking, add them to pancake batter to make fritters, put them to bread dough, or use even use them ice cream, where they make terrific sprinkles. Freeze them with water in ice cubes and serve them in drinks, or use them in wine-making. You can pickle the unopened flower buds too.

For a week or so, when they've first appeared but before they get tough, you can use the tender, young pods, raw or lightly cooked, like snow peas. Their season is shorter than any other edible plant I know, so unless they grow near where you live, they're very easy to miss. The Native Americans reputedly roasted the seeds, but I haven't had a chance to verify whether this works, and I'm afraid they may be as hard a pebbles.
They flowers are a good source of vitamin C and anthocyanins. The young pods and seeds provide proanthocyanides, linolenic, alpha-linolenic, oleic, and palmitic acids.

Not currently used medicinally, a decoction of the cambium, which is astringent, has been used to treat dysentery and diarrhea. It has also been used for leukemia, though there's no evidence that it works. A cold decoction was used for chest complaints such as whooping cough and congestion as well.

Though the flowers wilt and fall off within a couple of weeks after they bloom, there are thousands of them on every tree. Removing some does no harm to the tree, so don't let anyone who doesn't understand the difference between renewable and nonrenewable resources tell you otherwise!

Various subspecies occur throughout this tree's range, and the nearly identical western redbud (C. orbiculata) grows in the foothills, dry slopes, and canyons of California, Nevada, Utah, and Arizona. You can use them all the same way.
American Redbud, Eastern Redbud, Judas Tree

This small native tree produces an abundance of sweet, delicious flowers for a couple of weeks every year in early spring. You can use them raw or cooked in any recipe that will benefit from color, sweetness, and the flavor of snap peas.
Redbud Blossom Cookies
redbud-blossom-cookies

Here’s a successful example of my radical approach to cooking, successfully replacing the conventional white flower, sugar and eggs that make cookies such nutritional national disaster areas with whole-foods vegan ingredients that work. The wild redbud flowers, complemented with just the right seasonings, add the final touch to make these cookies perfect. I originally designed these cookies without any crunchy ingredients so my then-11-month-old daughter could safely eat them, and she loved them as much as I do.

Dry Ingredients

12 oz. (2 cups) sweet brown rice flour + 6 oz. (1 cup) buckwheat flour, or 18 oz. of other whole-grain flours
1/4 cup flax seeds ground into 1/2 cup meal
3 tbs. arrowroot
1 tbs. xanthan gum
1 tsp. salt
1 tsp. cream of tartar
1/2 tsp. baking soda
1 tsp. cinnamon, ground

To Blend

1-1/2 cups pear juice
1/2 cup corn oil
1/4 cup lecithin
2 tsp. liquid stevia
1/2 cup commercial currants
1 tbs. fresh lemon rind
1 tsp. orange rind
1 tsp. vanilla

Other Ingredients

1 cup redbud flowers

1. Mix together the dry ingredients

2. Purée; the ingredients to blend in a blender

3. Mix the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Don’t overmix.

4. Stir in the redbuds. Don’t overmix.

5. Shape into about 36 cookies and place on 3 nonstick cookie mats on 3 cookie sheets, or on 3 oiled cookie sheets

6. Bake 10 minutes or until lightly browned underneath, in a preheated 400 degree oven, turn over with a spatula, and bake another 5 to 10 minutes on the other side. Be careful to avoid scorching.

7. Cool on wire racks.

Makes 36 cookies

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 20 minutes

Rockweed
rockweed
Family: Fucaceae, the brown algae
In season all year, it's easiest to collect when the weather isn't icy.
On rocks along the seashore, exposed at low tide
This seaweed grows in the North Atlantic, but similar close relatives you can use the same way grow in the North Pacific.
It's also native to the Eastern North Atlantic, and if human activities hasn't spread it around the world yet, that probably not far off.

Look on rocks exposed at low tide for a ribbony, fan-shaped, olive-brown seaweed consisting of many flat, leathery, wavy strips divided by a midrib straddled by Y-shaped forked branches and paired, oval, air vessels. Ovoid, heart-shaped, or irregularly shaped yellow-green or olive reproductive organs reside at the seaweed's tips with a branched, discoid holdfast.

Growing up to three feet long and 0.5 inch wide, this ribbony, fan-shaped, olive-brown seaweed, yellowish when young, consists of many flat, leathery, wavy strips that divide in two repeatedly, like the letter "Y." Each blade is divided by a midrib and puntuated by paired, oval, air vessels 0.5 to 0.75 inch long (one subspecies lacks these bladders).

Covered with white-tipped bumps, yellow-green, jelly-filled, conspicuous, ovoid, heart-shaped, or irregularly shaped reproductive organs up to one inch in long grow at the seaweed's tips. A woody, branched, discoid holdfast anchors rockweed to rocks.

•Ribbony, fan-shaped, olive-brown seaweed, yellowish when young, up to three feet long and 0.5 inch wide
•Many flat, leathery, wavy strips each divided by a midrib
•Y-shaped forked branches
•Paired, oval, air vessels 0.5 to 0.75 inch long
•Ovoid, heart-shaped, or irregularly shaped yellow-green or olive reproductive organs up to one inch long, growing at the seaweed's tips
•Reproductive organs jelly-filled, covered with white-tipped bumps
•A woody, branched, discoid holdfast
Gather the best-looking plants at low tide, when they're the most accessible. Sometimes large quantities get washed up by storms.

The best parts of this plant are the reproductive organs. They taste like pickles—great sliced and added raw to salads and sandwiches, in place of pickles, or cooked in virtually any savory recipe, using any variety of cooking methods. They cook in 10 to 15 minutes.

You can also dehydrate rockweed, then add a tiny amount of oil and a good amount of spices, and roast it in the oven at 300 degrees F, 30 to 60 minutes, or until crisp, for a unique snack food. I've tried this with curry powder as well as with chili powder, but any spice combination should work.

The blades, which cook in about 15 minutes, taste like fish—great for vegan mock fish recipes, fish sauces, or Worchestershire Sauce. They're excellent simmered in soups, stews and grain dishes. And I always use rockweed, which you can add dried, when I make vegetable stock.

Use rockweed sparingly. It's very strong-flavored, and can overpower other ingredients. And don't add salt—rockweed provides plenty of sodium, and you can always salt to taste at the end of the recipe if necessary.
Rockweed is a great source of iodine, bromine, sodium, potassium, and chlorine, as well as alginic acid and many trace minerals.

Modern science upholds the traditional medicinal uses of this plants for a variety of ailments. Herbalists used to recommend rockweed for thyroid problems such as goiter. If the cause was an iodine deficiency, it was beneficial. However, rockweed's iodine content varies, and nowadays the precise dosages of iodine available through modern medicine are much safer and more effective. Rockweed has been used traditionally for weight loss, and although it's only effective when excessive weight is caused by thyroid problems created by iodine deficiency, you still find it in many of the ineffective herbal weight loss products being pandered today.

Rockweed lowers blood cholesterol levels, accounting for its traditional use for heart disease (it's also a weak blood thinner, reducing the chance of the coronary artery blood clots that produce heart attacks). Since estrogen is made from cholesterol, it also lowers estrogen levels, accounting for its traditional use for menstrual problems. Furthermore, Japanese women, who traditionally eat lots of seaweeds, have low rates of breast cancer (until they adapt a Western diet), another apparent benefit of this plant and other seaweeds, which have been used traditionally to fight cancer (some breast tumors need estrogen to grow).

Research also upholds rockweed's traditional use for kidney and bladder inflammations. It probably works because it contains mannite, an osmotic diuretic agent and a weak renal vasodilator.

A poultice of rockweed has been used applied externally for arthritis, rheumatism, enlarged or hardened glands, burns, and scalds, and people chewed it for bleeding gums. These uses have not been researched.

Enjoy this plant in moderation. Rockweed contains alginic acid, a laxative, so eating too much could can cause diarrhea. And it contains sodium—not good for people on a low-salt diet. Eaten in excess over long periods of time, it can give you too much iodine, resulting in an overactive thyroid gland. And people who are allergic to iodine or are taking iodine for medical reasons should also avoid this plant, as should those with acne, which, according to the latest research, iodine can worsen.

Because it's a blood thinner, avoid it if you're already taking medicines with the same effect, i.e., aspirin. And, since it effects estrogen levels, don't use it if you're being treated medically with drugs that effect such hormones.

Rockweed can pick up heavy metals from the water, so don't collect it in polluted waters.
Similar edible relatives, with and without air bubbles, also grow along the Atlantic and Pacific coasts.
Bladderwrack, Bladder Fucus, Sea Wrack, Kelp Ware, Black-Tang, Cutweed, Sea Oak, Dyers Fucus, Red Fucus, Rock Wrack

Sassafras
sassafras
Family: Lauraceae, the laurel family

You can collect sassafras saplings' roots any time the ground isn't frozen. The twigs are in season all year. Collect them young leaves for making gumbo filé from mid-spring, when they're at their best, into mid-summer, after which their quality diminishes.

Sassafras grows on dry, acidic soil, in old fields, on the borders of woods, in open woodlands, on bottomlands, in thickets, along fencerows and roadsides, on lower slopes, in urban parks, and on neighborhood streets.
Throughout most of the eastern US and Ontario

Look for a medium-sized, fragrant tree with irregular, reddish-brown vertical ridges split by horizontal slits,; 3 kinds of smooth, toothless medium-sized leaves—oval, 2-lobed, and 3-lobed; small, yellow, 5-petaled, radially-symmetrical, long-stalked flowers; blue-black, ovate fruits set in long-stalked, red cups; and saplings shaped like green, candelabras.

[Look for a medium-sized, fragrant tree with irregular, reddish-brown vertical ridges split by horizontal slits,; three kinds of smooth, toothless medium-sized leaves—oval, two-lobed, and three-lobed; small, yellow, five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, long-stalked flowers; blue-black, ovate fruits set in long-stalked, red cups; and saplings shaped like green, candelabras.]

Scratch and sniff for lemon-scented leaves and saplings.

This medium-sized tree, which grows up to 80 feet tall (but usually ranges between 30 and 40 feet), smells like lemon or root beer anywhere it's injured. The irregularly-furrowed, red-brown bark, which reveals a red-orange color underneath when scratched, looks as though someone slit its vertical ridges horizontally with a knife.

The three different kinds of smooth, stalked, toothless, alternate leaves, three to six inches long, which turn brilliant shades of yellow, orange and red in autumn, may be oval, two-lobed like a mitten, or three-lobed like a T. rex footprint .
The tiny, five-petaled, long-stalked, radially-symmetrical yellow flowers bloom on small racemes in the spring, as the leaves begin to form, male and female flowers on separate trees. The blue-black ovate fruits, about 0.5 inch long, ripen in the summer in long-stalked, red cups, on the female trees.

Many green, candelabra-shaped, minutely hairy, lemon-scented saplings usually grow near the mature trees.

•Medium-sized tree, fragrant throughout, usually 30 to 40 (sometimes up to 80) feet tall with irregular vertical ridges slit by horizontal knife-like cuts
•Bark reddish-brown, but red-orange underneath when scratched or cut
•Three kinds of smooth, oval, toothless leaves three to six inches long: entire, one-lobed, and two-lobed
•Short racemes of small, yellow, five-petaled, radially-symmetrical flowers blooming in the spring before the leaves have matured
•Blue-black, ovate fruits about 0.5 inch long, ripening in the summer, in long-stalked red cups, on the female trees
•Saplings green, candelabra-shaped, minutely hairy, lemon-scented
•Root root beer-scented

Pull up small saplings to harvest the cambium—easiest to do with other people, after rain has softened the ground, and on slopes. You'll have no environmental impact if the saplings aren't growing in full sunlight, since even partial shade eventually kills them.

You could also cut through the bark of a recently storm-felled tree to get at the cambium, but this isn't easy.

You can collect twigs or leaves for making tea, but this will be much weaker than tea made from the cambium. However, you can strip off the young leaves for making gumbo filé.

Scrub the root (which has no bark) and scrape off the cambium, which you can use fresh or dried, whole, chopped, or ground, in place of cinnamon, in a variety of sweet dishes. Discard the underlying wood.

Or simmer the whole root (or just the cambium) 20 minutes in a covered pot, strain, and serve a reddish-brown, flavorful decoction. The longer you simmer it, the stronger it gets. A small piece goes a surprisingly long way, and you can use the root over and over. Stir chilled (heat makes carbonated beverages go flat) sparkling water into a chilled decoction (an excellent ice tea in its own right) with a sweetener, and you'll have root beer.

You can also make a delicious jello by simmering ground sassafras cambium in fruit juice with agar. Use less agar and you'll get sassafras jelly.

Dry young sassafras leaves and grind them into a powder in a spice grinder or blender to make gumbo filé—an expensive gourmet product used to thicken soups. Stir a few tablespoons into a soup after it's finished cooking, turn off the heat to prevent it from becoming to gummy, and you'll have a delicious Louisiana gumbo.
Mulberry trees also have various kinds of leaves, but unlike sassafras, they’re rough, toothed and odorless.
White Sassafras, Gumbo Filé, Cinnamon Wood, Mitten Tree, Ague Tree, Saxifras, Tea Tree
This traditional beverage, the original source of root beer, also provides the Gulf Coast thickener called gumbo filé. And it also makes an excellent seasoning, a little like cinnamon.
Sassafras Jello
sassafras-jello

Other foraging authors never suggest using sassafras as a culinary seasoning, but it's excellent in this respect.[- There's only 1 catch: you have to cook, something most of these academic botanists apparently don't know how to do.]
Here’s a simple, sweet dessert with flavors that work perfectly together. Only problem with it happened when I brought it on a foraging tour and gave out samples during the lunch break. Everyone liked it so much, soon there was none left for me!

3/4 tsp. shavings of the outer layer of sassafras root, the cambium, finely chopped
1 quart water or apple juice
2 tbs. agar flakes
1 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tsp. vanilla
1 tsp. freshly grated orange rind

1. Simmer all ingredients 20 minutes, covered, over low heat.

2. Pour into a mold or bowl and chill until jelled.

Makes 4 cups

Cooking time: 20 minutes

Chill time: 2 hours
1)Sassafras Flowers and Twig
1sassafras-flowers-and-twig

Sassafras' long-stemmed, five-petaled, radially symmetrical flowers grow in small groups on short racemes, just as the leaves are beginning to develop. Earlier on, the undeveloped alternate leaf buds on the twig contrast with the larger flower buds, which are preparing to open and release the raceme of flowers. And the way the branches angle upward will make the sapling take the shape of a candelabra.
2)Sassafras Sapling
2sassafras-sapling

This is the best target for sassafras foragers: a sapling small enough to pull up, so you can get to the root of the matter. [-And] It's easy to recognize this fragrant plant, even with both nostrils closed. The leaves are toothless and smooth, one is oval, one has two lobes, and one has three lobes. [-And the leaves are toothless and smooth.]
3)Sassafras Flowers
3sassafras-flowers
As the unlobed, two-lobed, and three-lobed leaves are just getting going, the small, five-petaled, radially symmetrical, long-stalked, yellow flowers bloom, a few each on small racemes.
4)Sassafras Immature Berries
4sassafras-immature-berries
The small, ovate, green berries, which will turn blue when ripe, each grows in a cup attached to a long stem.
7)Sassafras Trunk
7sassafras-trunk
Sassafras' trunk's irregular, vertical, reddish-brown ridges are punctuated by horizontal slits, easy to notice only if you're looking for them.
5)Sassafras Tree in Autumn
5sassafras-tree-in-autumn
This medium-sized trees' three different-looking leaves turn various colors in autumn.
6)Bare Sassafras Sapling
6bare-sassafras-sapling
The slender branches of these dull green saplings arch upward, helping you recognize them in the winter. If you find these, scratch and sniff to confirm your find.
8)Sassafras Root
8sassafras-root

You can easily unearth such a large root if you do so after lots of heavy rain. The reddish substance just to the right of the knot is the cambium. Its color contrasts with that of the reddish-brown cambium, to the right of the knot.
Sea Lettuce
sea-lettuce
Family: Ulvaecea, the sea lettuce family
This annual seaweed grows in the spring, summer, and fall.
Along the seashore on submerged rocks and shells, or in the intertidal zone, often washed up on beaches. It does especially well in polluted waters!
East and West Coasts, and worldwide
Look for a seaweed that looks like a wrinkled sheet of torn, green plastic wrap

This soft, translucent, bright or dark green, flat, broad, thin, sometimes rounded, wrinkled, filmy seaweed often perforated with holes, grows in undivided or lobed sheets from six inches to three feet across. Often torn before being washed up onto shore, it reminds me of green plastic wrap.

It may discolor black when it dries out or decomposes, or it could become bleached white by the sun. A discoid holdfast anchors it to rocks, but this rarely gets washed ashore.

•Seaweed forming a thin, transparent, green sheet
•Ruffled edge
•Often torn
Collect it, bag it, and use it within a couple of days—it's perishable

Refrigerate it as soon as possible, and use it within a day or two, because it spoils very quickly. Wash it thoroughly under running water, in a colander set into a low bowl, to get rid of all the sand. Change the water in the bowl several times, and make sure all the tenacious sand is gone.

Although you can eat some raw, finely chopped, it’s a little tough. It's much in soups or stews, stir-fried, or sautéed; 10 to 15 minutes. You can also freeze it after cooking.
Sea lettuce provides iron, protein, iodine, aluminum, manganese, and nickel, as well a beta-carotene, B-complex vitamins, vitamin C, starch, fat, and sugar.

Pollution may make this seaweed grow in huge amounts. If this all washes up on a shore and decomposes, it may produce deadly hydrogen sulfide gas, which smells like rotten eggs. This has killed people in France in 2009. If you smell rotten eggs as you approach the seashore, head inland immediately.

Eat this seaweed in moderation. It can give you too much iodine, resulting in an overactive thyroid gland. And people who are allergic to iodine or are taking iodine for medical reasons should also avoid sea lettuce, as should those with acne, which iodine can worsen.
Other very similar closely related species of Ulva are also edible.
This [-is a] seaweed [-that] looks like sheets of green plastic wrap that you can sauté or add to soups.
1)Sea Lettuce
1sea-lettuce
One of the easiest edibles to recognize, this seaweed looks like sheets of semi-transparent, green plastic wrap.
Sautéed Sea Lettuce
sautéed-sea-lettuce

Sautéed Sea Lettuce

Sautéeing sea lettuce like a land vegetable, with garlic and other seasonings, is simple, but effective.

3 tbs. olive oil
4 cups sea lettuce, thoroughly rinsed, chopped
2 cloves of garlic, finely chopped
1 tbs. fresh dill weed, chopped, or 1 tsp. dried dill weed, ground
1/4 tsp. oregano, ground
1/4 tsp. savory, ground
1/4 tsp. black pepper, ground
1 tsp. tamari soy sauce, or to taste

1. Sauté all ingredients except the tamari soy sauce in the olive oil 10 minutes.

2. Stir in the tamari soy sauce

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 15 minutes
Sea Lettuce in the Sand
sea-lettuce-in-the-sand
Sea lettuce often gets wash up on beaches like this. It will take repeated rinses in a colander set in a bowl to wash out all the sand, but you'll end up with a magnificent vegetable.
Stinging Nettle
stinging-nettle
Family: Urticaceae, the nettle family

Collect nettles when they first appear in early spring until they flower and become unsafe to eat, close to late spring. People think nettles are only good in the spring, but autumn's new growth is just as good as the spring form, if not quite as abundant. Collect these until they're destroyed by frost.
Partially shaded, moist, rich, soil, disturbed habitats, fields, open woodlands, edges of trails, thickets, and riverbanks
Most of the continental US, Canada, and Mexico, as well as most of the temperate world
European and American varieties grow in the US, but because this plant is covered with thousands of tiny hypodermic needles, evolutionary biologists think it originated in the South Bronx!

Look for a hairy, erect, unbranched, herbaceous plant with a stout, ribbed, hollow stem, and creeping, spreading rhizomes. Stinging nettle has oval, long-stalked, dark green, opposite, rough-textured, coarse-toothed leaves with pointed tips and heart-shaped bases and long. Slender paired panicles of tiny, green, inconspicuous flowers and fruits hang from the upper leaf axils.

Feel for a painful sting when you touch the plant (but only if you're really dumb!)

Densely covered with hollow, stinging hairs (as well as non-stinging hairs) that can contain acetylcholine, histamine, serotonin, and formic acid, this unbranched colonial plant develops a rather stout, ribbed, erect, four-sided, hollow stem growing from three to seven feet tall, plus creeping, branching rhizomes it uses to spread.

The somewhat oval, long-stalked, dark green, opposite leaves, with a rough, papery texture, grow two to six inches long and one to two inches wide. The leaf tip is pointed, the base is heart-shaped, and the teeth get larger toward the long leaf tip. A pair of stipules grows at the base of each leaf stalk.

Blooming from late spring to early fall, long, slender, paired panicles of tiny, green, inconspicuous flowers droop from the upper leaf axils—male and female flowers growing on separate plants. The fruits, which contain tiny seeds, resemble the flowers.

•Densely hairy, erect, unbranched herbaceous colonial plant with stout, ribbed, four-sided, hollow stem, growing from three to seven feet tall
•Creeping, spreading rhizomes
•Oval, long-stalked, dark green, opposite, rough-textured leaves, two to six inches long and one to two inches wide
•Leaf tip pointed, leaf base heart-shaped, teeth increasingly large toward the tip
•A pair of stipules at the base of each leaf stalk
•Long, slender paired panicles of tiny, green, inconspicuous flowers and similar fruits hanging from the upper leaf axils
•Many stinging hairs throughout the plant

Collect nettles wearing gloves, or put your hand inside a bag. Long sleeves and long pants also make harvesting easier. Use entire young shoots a few inches tall, and strip off the smaller leaves near the tops of larger plants. They come off most easily if you strip them from the top down. Keep the tough stems for making tea.

Stinging nettles impart a strong, rich, satisfying flavor and chewy texture to any cooked vegetable dish, and even light cooking (or drying) destroys the stinging effect. Delicious when properly prepared, nettles get a very bad rap in countless literary works, usually by culinarily clueless authors from England, a country world-famous for its exceptional cuisine (but not because it's exceptionally good!)

Don't boil stinging nettles in water. This removes their flavor and nutrients, and makes them taste awful. Rinse, chop, then steam the young leaves for 5 to 10 minutes or until just wilted, in a heavy pot, covered, with no additional water (which would dilute their flavor). Then season them with olive or other oil, savory herbs, and salt and pepper to taste. Cook nettles in soups, stews, or rice, adding them during the last 5 minutes of the cooking time. Include cooked nettles when making stuffing and pesto too.

One of the most healthful foods on Earth, nettles provide more protein than any other green, and they’re very high in readily absorbable iron, plus calcium, chromium, magnesium, potassium, phosphorous, manganese, silica, iodine, sodium, sulfur, and zinc. They’re also high in carotenoids, vitamins C, K, and B-complex, as well chlorophyll, lecithin, flavonoids, sterols, and tannins.

Stinging nettles sting. This causes minor skin irritation that disappears within an hour for me, whereas for some people, it's equivalent to a bee sting! Wear work- or rubber gloves when handling raw nettles, and don't run through a field of nettles wearing shorts! If stung, apply the juice of crushed jewelweed stems, common- or long-leaf plantain leaves, or curly dock leaves—all quite effective.

Don’t use nettles after they begin flowering around mid-spring, when they get tough and stringy. Much has been made about the dangers the gritty cystoliths that form at that time, and how these can irritate the urinary tract, but the cystoliths are just baking soda!

And don't collect in soil contaminated with nitrates, which nettles readily absorb.

Slender nettle (U. gracilis), with sparse stingers, has lance-shaped leaves, fewer stinging hairs, and none on its leaves' upper surfaces. Wood nettles (Laportea canadense) have larger, rounded leaves—opposite when the plant’s very young, alternate when mature. Both of these relatives are delicious in their own right, and you can harvested and prepared any true nettles the same way as stinging nettles.

Clearweed (Pilea pumila), is a similar-looking, nonpoisonous but relatively tasteless relative, without stinging hairs. Henbit deadnette (Lamium amplexicaule) is a musty-smelling, non-poisonous hairy mint with similar opposite leaves that droop, and a square stem, but the showy, two-sided pink flowers of this non-edible softly hairy plant are also different, and it doesn't sting.

Stinging nettles have a square like a mint, and look a little like catnip, but nettles no fragrance and they don't attract cats. Also, no one has ever been stung by catnip!
Burn Nettle, Burn Weed, Burn Hazel, Mountain Nettle, Nettle, Giant Creek Nettle, Hoary Nettle

Cooking takes the sting out of this common plant, and if you cook it properly, it's incredibly delicious and healthful. Nevertheless, some people insist on boiling it in water, after which the flavor is even worse than the sting!
Clearweed, Henbit Deadnettle, Slender Nettle, Wood Nettle
Stinging Nettle Risotto
stinging-nettle-risotto

Here’s a creamy, vegan rice-and-cheese casserole punctuated by the intense flavor of stinging nettles.

5 cups cooked brown rice
4 cups stinging nettles or other nettle species
10 oz. soy mozzarella, grated
1/2 cup hazelnut milk or other non-dairy milk
1/4 cup any mushrooms, sliced
1/4 cup roasted, unsalted pistachio nuts
2 tbs. Spice Oil
1 tbs. Vege-sal

Bake all ingredients in a covered, oiled casserole dish 45 minutes in a preheated 350 degree oven.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 5 minutes

Cooking time: 45 minutes

1)Mature and Immature Stinging Nettles
1mature-and-immature-stinging-nettles

Stinging nettles have erect stems and opposite, long-stalked, coarsely toothed, oval leaves, with pointed tips and heart-shaped bases. Mature plants, which you don't want to eat, have paired panicles of tiny flowers hanging from the upper leaf axils. The whole plant is covered with stinging hairs.
2)Young Stinging Nettle
2young-stinging-nettle

This young stinging nettle has an unbranched square stem, pointed, heart-shaped, coarsely toothed opposite leaves, and plenty of stinging hairs. A pair of stipules grows on the base of the leaf axils, and the reddish runner allows nettles to form dense colonies.
4)Stinging Nettle in Flower
4stinging-nettle-in-flower
When long panicles of tiny, inconspicuous green flowers dangle from the leaf axils, it's way to late to harvest this plant.
3)Stinging Nettle Stand
3stinging-nettle-stand
Because nettles grow in such dense stands, you'll get quite a meal if you're prepared for them, and quite an unpleasant surprise if you blunder into them unprepared!
5)Stinging Nettle Stingers
5stinging-nettle-stingers
You never want to be this close to stinging nettle stingers in real life!
Slender Nettle
slender-nettle1
Family: Urticaceae, the nettle family

Collect slender nettles when they first appear in early spring, until they flower and become unsafe to eat, close to late spring. I haven't seen new growth in the fall, but if they do reappear then, the young plants would be edible again.
Partially shaded, moist, rich, soil, disturbed habitats, edges of trails, thickets, and riverbanks
Most or the US and Canada, but not in Alabama, Georgia, South Carolina, Florida, and Nevada

Look for a stout, erect, light green, ridged, mostly unbranched plant growing from three to seven feet tall, sparsely covered with stinging hairs; with slightly drooping, rough-textured, lance-shaped, coarsely toothed, long-stalked, opposite leaves without stinging hairs on the upper surfaces; a pair of stipules at the base of each leaf stalk; and long, slender, branching panicles of tiny, green, inconspicuous flowers without petals, and similar fruits, extending outward from the middle and upper leaf axils.

Sparsely covered with hollow, stinging hairs (as well as non-stinging hairs) that can contain acetylcholine, histamine, serotonin, and formic acid, this unbranched herbaceous perennial develops a rather stout, erect, light green, ridged, mostly unbranched stem growing from three to seven feet tall, plus creeping, branching rhizomes it uses to spread.

The slightly drooping, rough-textured, lance-shaped, coarsely toothed, opposite leaves grow from 2.5 to eight inches long and 1.5 to 2.5 inches wide. The leaf tip is pointed and the base rounded. The leaf's upper surface is hairless, the underside sparsely covered with stinging hairs and the the slender leafstalks can reach one inch in length. A pair of stipules 0.5 inches long grows at the base of each leaf stalk.

Blooming throughout most of the summer, long, slender, branching panicles of tiny, green, inconspicuous flowers without petals extend outward from the middle and upper leaf axils. Male or female flowers predominate on separate plants. The fruits, which contain tiny seeds, resemble the flowers.

•Stout, erect, light green, ridged, mostly unbranched stem growing from three to seven feet tall
•Slightly drooping, rough-textured, lance-shaped, coarsely toothed opposite leaves, 2.5 to eight inches long and 1.5 to 2.5 inches wide
•Leaves' upper surfaces hairless
•Slender leafstalks up to one inch long
•A pair of stipules at the base of each leaf stalk
•Sparse stinging hairs on the stems and undersides of the leaves
•Long, slender, branching panicles of tiny, green, inconspicuous flowers without petals extending outward from the middle and upper leaf axils in the summer
•Fruits similar to the flowers, in autumn

Collect slender nettles wearing gloves, or put your hand inside a bag. Long sleeves and long pants also make harvesting easier. Use entire young shoots a few inches tall, and strip off the smaller leaves near the tops of larger plants. They come off most easily if you strip them from the top down. Keep the tough stems for making tea.

Nettles impart a strong, rich, satisfying flavor and chewy texture to any cooked vegetable dish, and even light cooking (or drying) destroys the stinging effect. Rinse, chop, then steam the young leaves for five to ten minutes or until just wilted, in a heavy pot, covered, with no additional water (which would dilute the flavor), and season with olive or other oils, savory herbs, and salt and pepper to taste. Cook nettles in soups, stews, or rice, adding them during the last five minutes of the cooking time. Include cooked nettles when making stuffing and pesto too.

Don't boil nettles in water. This removes their flavor and nutrients, and makes them taste awful.

Although there's no direct research on this plant available, they're probably very similar in nutrient content to stinging nettles , providing more protein than other greens, plus iron, plus calcium, chromium, magnesium, potassium, phosphorous, manganese, silica, iodine, sodium, sulfur, and zinc, as well as carotenoids, vitamins C, K, and B-complex, plus chlorophyll, lecithin, flavonoids, sterols, and tannins.

Not widely used like stinging nettles, slender nettles probably have very similar medicinal properties. The freshly-squeezed nettle juice, loaded with nutrients, might help rebuild the strength of the chronically ill, and could be a good topical treatment for nettle sting. It may also help with digestive problems, prostatitis, hepatitis, gall bladder inflammation, hay fever and osteoarthritis.

An infusion of the leaves is probably a safe, gentle diuretic, good for the kidneys and bladder, and it may be helpful for cystitis and nephritis. If it's also high in vitamin K content, it should help blood clot, and be useful for excessive menstruation, bloody coughs, and nose bleeds.

A tincture of the whole plant might be good for flu, colds, bronchitis, pneumonia, and eczema, or to promote lactation.

Slender nettles sting. This causes minor skin irritation that disappears within an hour for me, whereas for some people, it's equivalent to a bee sting. Wear work- or rubber gloves when handling raw nettles, and don't run through a field of nettles wearing shorts! If stung, apply the juice of crushed jewelweed stems, common- or long-leaf plantain leaves, or curly dock leaves—all quite effective.

Don’t use nettles after they begin flowering around mid-spring, when they get tough and stringy. Much has been made about the dangers the gritty cystoliths that form at that time, and how these can irritate the urinary tract, but the cystoliths are just baking soda!

Don't collect in soil contaminated with nitrates, which nettles readily absorb.

Stinging nettles have oval leaves, stinging hairs on both surfaces of the leaf, more stingers throughout, and drooping flower panicles. Wood nettles have larger, rounded leaves—opposite when the plant’s very young, alternate when mature. All true nettle species are delicious, and you can harvested and prepare them same way.

Clearweed (Pilea pumila), is a similar-looking, nonpoisonous but relatively tasteless relative, without stinging hairs.
California Nettle
Like its better-known relative, stinging nettle, this is a delicious, healthful vegetable that loses its stinging properties when you cook it.
Stinging Nettles, Wood Nettles, Clearweed
Slender Nettle
slender-nettle

The slender nettle has lance-shaped, long-pointed, coarsely toothed, opposite leaves growing on an erect, unbranched, ridged stem, plus panicles of tiny, inconspicuous flowers extending from the leaf axils. Unlike stinging nettles, there's only a sparsely coating of stinging hairs.
Nettlesome Rice
nettlesome-rice

Here’s a filling dish featuring the wonderful flavor of wood nettles that also lets you use up leftover brown rice. I first made it after a vegetarian Chinese restaurant included a packet of brown rice with every dish I took out for my family—a nettlesome problem that this recipe solves!

5 cups cooked short-grain brown rice or any left-over rice
4 cups nettles, chopped
1/4 cup any mushrooms, chopped
10 oz. soy mozzarella, grated
2 tbs. Spice Oil
1 tbs. Vege-sal
1/3 cup roasted, unsalted pistachio nuts or other nuts
1/2 cup hazelnut milk or other non-dairy milk

Mix all ingredients together, transfer to an oiled casserole dish, and bake, covered, 45 minutes.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 5 minutes

Cooking time: 45 minutes

Wood Nettle
wood-nettle
Family: Urticaceae, the nettle family
Collect wood nettles when they first appear in mid-spring, and until they flower and become unpleasant to eat by summer.
Wood nettles grow in partially shaded, moist, rich soil, disturbed habitats, edges of trails, thickets, and riverbanks.
Eastern US and Eastern Canada

Look for an erect colonial plant with a ridged, usually unbranched stem up to two to four feet tall, covered with white, fuzzy-looking stinging hairs. Wood nettles have oval, toothed, opposite leaves up to six inches long and four inches across, each rounded at the base and pointed at the tip, with some stinging hairs. Large, feathery, branched terminal cymes about four inches long, with tiny, crowded, greenish-white female flowers without petals, bloom in early summer. Crowded cymes of petal-less male flowers about the same length as the leaves spreading outward from the leaf axils, and clusters of small, dry, curved, ovoid fruit replace the female flowers in late summer and fall.

This nettle has an erect, ridged stem up to two to four feet tall, usually unbranched, covered with white, fuzzy-looking stinging hairs. It spreads by rhizomes, forming large or small colonies.

The large, oval, toothed, opposite leaves, up to six inches long and four inches across, each rounded at the base and pointed at the tip, have fewer stinging hairs than the stem, although the slender leaf stalks, up to four inches long, are very well-armed.

Blooming in the summer, large, feathery, branched cymes about four inches long, with tiny, crowded, greenish-white female flowers without petals, each about 0.125 inch across, grow in terminal clusters. At the same time, branching, crowded male cymes, about the same length as the leaves, spread outward from the leaf axils. Clusters of small, dry, curved, ovoid fruits replace the female flowers in late summer and fall.

•Erect, ridged, usually unbranched stem up to two to four feet tall
•Stem covered with white, fuzzy-looking stinging hairs
•Colonial plant spreading by rhizomes
•Oval, toothed, opposite leaves up to six inches long and four inches across, each rounded at the base and pointed at the tip, with some stinging hairs
•Long, slender leaf stalks armed with fine, stinging hairs
•Large, feathery, branched terminal cymes about four inches long, with tiny, crowded, greenish-white female flowers without petals
•Crowded cymes of male flowers about the same length as the leaves, spreading outward from the leaf axils
•Clusters of small, dry, curved, ovoid fruit replacing the female flowers in late summer and fall

Collect nettles wearing gloves, or put your hand inside a bag. Long sleeves and long pants also make harvesting easier. Break or cut off entire young shoots a few inches tall, and strip off the smaller leaves near the tops of larger plants. They come off most easily if you strip them from the top downward. You can keep the tough stems for making tea.

Overshadowed by its much better-known relative, the stinging nettles, the wood nettle is just as good, with a similar, rich, earthy flavor all its own. And in many areas, it's more abundant than its more notorious relative. And even light cooking (or drying) destroys the stinging effect. The leaves cook in 5 to 10 minutes.

Rinse, chop, and steam the young leaves for 5 to 10 minutes or until just wilted in a heavy pot, covered, with no additional water (which would dilute the flavor), and season with olive or other oil, savory herbs, and salt and pepper to taste. Or add the leaves to any dish that calls for cooked vegetables. They're great in soups, stews, or rice, added during the last 5 minutes of the cooking time. Include nettles in recipes such as stuffing or pesto too.

Don't just boil nettles in water. This removes their flavor and nutrients, and makes them taste awful.

Wood nettles sting as effectively as stinging nettles, injecting you with acetylcholine, histamine, serotonin, and formic acid—more painful and long-lasting for some people than others. However, these stinging hairs are completely harmless if you simply avoid touching them! Wear work- or rubber gloves when handling raw nettles, as well as long pants and long sleeves. If stung, apply the juice of crushed jewelweed (Impatiens spp.) stems, crushed plantain (Plantago spp.) leaves, or crushed dock (Rumex spp.) leaves—all quite effective.

Don’t use nettles after they begin flowering around mid-spring, when they get tough and stringy. Much has been made about the dangers the gritty cystoliths that form at that time, and how these can irritate the urinary tract, but the cystoliths are just baking soda!

Don't collect in soil contaminated with nitrates, which nettles readily absorb.

All other nettles (Urtica spp.) are delicious. You can harvest, prepare them, or get stung by them the same way. Stinging nettles have more narrow, oval leaves and drooping flower panicles. Slender nettles, with sparse stingers, have lance-shaped leaves, fewer stinging hairs, and no stingers on the leaves' upper surfaces.

Clearweed (Pilea pumila), is a similar-looking, nonpoisonous but relatively tasteless relative, with different flowers, and without stinging hairs.

White snakeroot has long-stalked, opposite, coarsely toothed leaves and a terminal cluster of flowers, like wood nettles, but it lacks stinging hairs, the flowers are white, not green-white, and they're configured like an umbrella

Preventing the brain from signaling the lungs to breath and the heart to beat, eating this native woodland plant leads to respiratory failure and cardiac arrest.
As good (or as bad, if you let it sting you) as stinging nettles, this common woodland plant's leaves provide very enjoyable, strong-flavored greens.
Stinging Nettles, Slender Nettles, Clearweed, Jewelweed, Clearweed, Common Plantain, Curly Dock
White Snakeroot
Tempeh with Wood Nettles
tempeh-with-wood-nettles

Here’s a hearty entrée; based on chewy tempeh, flavored with the intensity of wood nettles, sweetened with pineapple, and tempered with savory seasonings.

3 cups diced tempeh, parboiled 10 minutes and drained
2 tbs. olive oil
1 tbs. Citrus Chili Dry Rub
1 tsp. All-purpose Seasoning
4 cups wood nettle leaves or other nettle leaves, chopped
3 cups pineapple, diced
2 tbs. tamari soy sauce
1/4 cup Soy Mayonnaise


1. Sautée; the tempeh in the olive oil with the Citrus Rub and All-purpose seasoning 10 minutes, or until lightly browned.

2. Add the nettles, pineapple, and tamari, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 10 minutes.

3. Stir in the mayo.

Serves 6 Excellent

Cooking/preparation time: 30 minutes

Very young wood nettles already have fine stinging hairs on the ridged stem, and the same long-stalked, oval, pointed, toothed opposite leaves of more mature plants. At this stage, you can cook and eat the whole above-ground plant.
Common Sunflower
common-sunflower
Family Asteraceae (Compositae), the astor or composite family
The seeds ripen from early- to mid-fall.
Sunny habitat, old fields, disturbed soil, praries, and dry, open ground

This plant is distributed sporadically throughout all the states of the continental US and most of Canada, although it's absent in some regions altogether. It's most common in the Midwest and the Great Plains.

Look for a large herbaceous plant with a single, ridged, erect stem and large, coarse, heart-shaped to triangular, hairy, toothed, slender-stalked, alternate leaves. A large, composite flower with a brown or purple central disk and many golden rays will look familiar, as will small, thin-shelled, woody, gray and black seeds.

This large herbaceous plant grows from three to eight feet tall (up to 16 feet if cultivated) with one single, erect stalk. The coarse, heart-shaped to triangular, hairy, toothed, slender-stalked, alternate leaves, which grow from 2.5 inches to 12 inches long, feel like sandpaper.

Blooming mainly in the summer, the large, familiar, composite flower, which rotates to face the sun, grows from three to six inches across, with a brown or purple central disk and many golden rays. The seed head's disk is composed of many, tiny, five-petaled, yellow flowers.

The thin-shelled, woody, gray and black seeds, with whitish kernels inside, are smaller than commercial sunflower seeds.

•Large herbaceous plant usually three to eight feet tall, with a single, ridged, erect stem
•Coarse, alternate, heart-shaped to triangular, hairy, toothed, slender-stalked leaves 2.5 inches to 12 inches long
•Leaves with the texture of sandpaper
•Large, familiar, composite flower three to six inches across, with a brown or purple central disk, and many golden rays
•Disk composed of many, tiny, five-petaled, yellow flowers
•Thin-shelled, woody, gray and black seeds, smaller than commercial sunflower varieties', with whitish kernels

Cut off the seed head before the seeds ripen completely or the birds will get them all. They'll ripen in a supermarket shopping bag, although a mesh bag, that allows more air circulation, is even better. Take care that moisture doesn't cause any of your seed heads to get moldy, especially if they were collected after the rain.

Enclose the seed head in a paper or mesh bag for a few of weeks until the seeds dry and mature. Don't crowd to many seed heads together, especially if you collected them after it's rained, or they'll get moldy. Remove the seeds from the seed head, and eat them raw or lightly roasted: You can roast them in a 300 degree F oven for 40 minutes or until crisp, stirring often. Crack them with your teeth and eat them like commercial sunflower seeds. You can also pre-boil the seeds in water with spices, olive oil, and salt for 15 minutes. You can try curry powder, black pepper, chili powder, lemon juice, fresh garlic, a Thai spice mix, Italian herbs, or any combination of these and other flavorings that you can imagine. Drain the seeds, add a dash of olive oil and salt to taste, and roast them.

Wild sunflower seeds are smaller than commercial ones, so shelling them by hand is too tedious to be worth it. You could coarsely grind the seeds with water in a blender, transfer to a bowl of water, and separate the floating shells from the nutmeat, which sinks, but this is also very labor-intensive.

You could also boil the ground seeds and skim off the sunflower seed oil that rises to the surface, to use in salad dressings or for cooking. Or roast the shells and use them as a caffeine-free coffee substitute, the way you’d use coffee beans, Kentucky coffee-tree seeds, or chicory root.

You can also sprout the seeds: Soak them in their shells overnight to begin germination, then tie them in a mesh bag or stocking and hang them over the sink to drain. Rinse a twice day. When the new root is as large as the seeds, plant them in a shallow tray of rich soil, water occasionally, and give them plenty of sunlight. In about a week, after the first leaves have opened, cut off the sprouts to use as snacks, or include them in salads, soups, or cooked vegetable dishes. Their peppery taste and chewy texture make them a favorite of adults and kids. And the clipped seeds may provide a second harvest in another week.

Finally, some people eat the flower buds of wild sunflowers, but the plant is so rare in my area that I've only found it once (and it was absent from where I'd found it the following year), and haven't been able to verify how well this works.

One of the few wild plants high in calories, sunflower seeds also provide protein, vitamins B2 and C, plus linoleic acid, calcium, phosphorus, iron, sodium, and iron. The sprouts are even more nutritious than the seeds.

Not commonly used medicinally nowadays, a tea made from the leaves is considered astringent, diuretic and expectorant, and it's been used for high fever, probably not with much effect. People also crushed leaves and applied them to sores, swellings, snakebites and spider bites as a poultice.

The flower head and seeds are considered a febrifuge, nutritive and stomachic, while the seed is supposed to be diuretic and expectorant, and it's been used for lung problems, but convincing evidence of its efficacy is lacking.

Various non-poisonous relatives in the sunflower family (Helianthus spp.) don't produce seeds, and they have different-colored flowers or different leaves. The Jerusalem artichoke, for example, is a perennial that never sets seed, but has edible tubers the common sunflower lacks. It's coarsely hairy, branches mostly toward the top, and has large, coarsely hairy, oval to lance-shaped, slender, three-ribbed, pointed, toothed leaves and partially winged leaf stalks, rather than the sunflower's heart-shaped to triangular leaves. The several composite flower heads consist of 12 to 20 yellow ray flowers encircling a central, yellow-brown disk, rather than the brown-purple disk of the common sunflower.
Wild sunflowers have seeds that are smaller than commercial seeds, but they're quite tasty, and make an excellent snack food.
jerusalem artichoke, chicory, kentucky coffee-tree
Roasted Wild Sunflower Seeds
roasted-wild-sunflower-seeds

When I finally first found sunflowers growing wild in my region, this recipe made the 25 year search worth it!

3 cups raw sunflower seeds
2 cups water
The juice of 2 limes
4 cloves of garlic, crushed
2 tsp. olive oil
4 tsp. Vege-sal

1. Boil the sunflower seeds in the water 15 minutes with the lime juice, garlic, and half the olive oil and Vege-sal.

2. Drain, mix with the remaining ingredients, and roast in a roasting pan in a preheated 275 degree oven for 2 hours or until the seeds are dry and crisp, stirring occasionally.

Makes 3 cups

Preparation time: 25 minutes

Roasting time: 120 minutes

Sweet Cicely
sweet-cicely
Apiaceae or Umbelliferae, the umbellifers, or the parsley family

The newly growing leaves of early- to mid-spring and autumn are the best to eat, although they're also good if you can find them during warm spells in the winter, or where winters are mild.

The taproots are good all year, though you're not going to find it when the ground is frozen and covered with snow, and it's difficult, but not impossible, to find fleshy, usable taproots in the summer. They're at their best from early- to mid-spring, before the plant flowers, and from mid-fall, when new basal rosettes appear, through late fall.

The immature seedpods are edible in late spring, before they get tough.
Sweet cicely grows in light shade, in woodlands with rich soil, along the edges of paths, and in thickets.

This species grows throughout much of the US and eastern Canada except for Florida, Louisiana, and the West Coast, although other closely related edible species cover most of the rest of North America and Canada

Look for a plant with a light green, reddish-tinged, hairy, somewhat branched stem one to three feet tall, with alternate leaves similar to basal leaves—long, deeply toothed, twice-compound, and divided into threes, with long, purple leaf stalks. The long-oval, pointed leaflets also divide into threes.

Fve small, sparse, flat-topped, umbrella-like terminal clusters of tiny, white, five-petaled flowers grow above recurved, linear to lance-shaped bracts. The flowers become sharp, slender, black, ribbed, crescent-shaped, persistent, tapered, barbed seedpods, maturing from green to black.

Scratch and sniff for the odor or black licorice or anise.

This attractive herb, which smell like licorice or anise when injured, begins in early spring with a basal rosette of deeply toothed, twice-compound, often slightly hairy leaves with long, purple leaf stalks. The leaves can grow up to one foot long. They're divided into groups of three. The long-oval, pointed leaflets, also in threes, grow up to one inch long. The terminal leaflet is always the largest.

In late spring, a smooth, light green, reddish-tinged, hairy, somewhat branched stem, with alternate leaves similar to but smaller than the basal ones, grows from one to three feet tall. For about two to three weeks in late spring to early summer, it produces five small, sparse, flat-topped, umbrella-like terminal clusters of eight to 16 tiny, white, five-petaled flowers 0.125 inch across. Recurved linear to lance-shaped bracts grow beneath the flowers.

Replacing the flowers, painfully sharp, slender, black, ribbed, crescent-shaped, tapered, barbed seedpods mature from green to black in mid-summer and fall.

A short, stout, gnarled, light brown underground base gives rise to many tightly packed, small, light brown, fleshy taproots, white inside. They grow four to six inches long.

•Basal leaves up to one foot long, deeply toothed, twice-compound, divided into groups of three
•Pointed, long-oval leaflets up to one inch long
•Terminal leaflet always the largest
•Long, purple leaf stalks
•Short, stout, gnarled, light brown underground base giving rise to many small, tightly packed, fleshy, light brown taproots
•Light green, reddish-tinged, hairy, somewhat branched stem one to three feet tall, with alternate leaves similar to the basal leaves
•Five small, sparse, flat-topped, umbrella-like terminal clusters of eight to 16 tiny, white, five-petaled flowers
•Recurved, linear to lance-shaped bracts, growing beneath the flowers
•Slender, black, ribbed, crescent-shaped, persistent, tapered, sharply barbed seedpods maturing from green to black

Pinch off the leaves or flowers with your fingers. Dig up the roots with a shovel or trowel, taking only a fraction of the plants where they're very abundant, and remove the taproots, which are the best parts to eat, from the tough base.

Add the leaves, flowers, or tender young stems raw to salads, or add them to soups, stews, or desserts, at the end of the cooking time, to preserve the delicate flavor. They cook in about five minutes. Their delicate licorice flavor also makes them an especially good garnish.

Discard the hard, gnarled, underground base above the taproots (or steep it to make tea, which you can do with any part of the plant) and use the fleshy, strongly licorice-flavored taproots, the best part of the plant, grated or sliced, like you'd use carrots. Use them sparingly, or they'll overpower the other ingredients in your recipe. Edible raw, they're also great in soups and stews, as well as dessert dishes. I add them, grated, to ice cream, include them in smoothies, and always put some into oatmeal and cooked cereals. I also keep some grated roots in the freezer, to use as a seasoning.

You may also nibble on the immature green seedpods before they get tough, or use them in salads and cakes in place of anise seeds.

Don’t dehydrate this plant or it will lose all its flavor and become as tasteless as my jokes. But you can freeze the taproots raw or cooked. They're already adapted to freezing in the winter.
Avoid walking thorough the sharp, pointed seeds in autumn, or they'll poke you through your socks and needle you!

Although sweet cicely smells like it relative, anise (Pimpinella anisum), which doesn't grow in America either, they're completely different plants.

Other closely related licorice-scented sweet cicely species (Osmorhiza spp.) are all very hard to tell apart from O. longistylis, but they're all edible.

There’s also a totally different, unrelated European sweet cicely (Myrrhis odorata) that doesn't grow wild in America.
Anise Root, Sweetroot, Longstyle Sweetroot, Licorice Root, Wild Anise
This black licorice-flavored plant is one of my favorites to use in dessert dishes, and if anyone in my household gets a tummy ache, I always have some of this herb ready to turn into tea.
Poison Hemlock, Fool's Parsley
Banana Chocolate Chip Pancakes with Sweet Cicely
banana-chocolate-chip-pancakes-with-sweet-cicely

This is what my wife and my five-year-old daughter, Violet, asked for, and with the right combination of herbs, especially the sweet cicely, it came out like a perfect combination of pancakes and confection.

1 cup sugar-free vegan chocolate chips

Dry Ingredients

1-1/2 cups (7 oz.) buckwheat flour or other whole-grain flour
1 tbs. flaxseeds, ground
1 tsp. cream of tartar
1/2 tsp. baking soda
1 tsp. cream of tartar
1 tsp. xanthan gum
1/2 tsp. guar gum
1/2 tsp. salt
1/2 tsp. powdered stevia
1/4 tsp. cloves, ground

Ingredients to Blend

3 cups soy-rice milk or other non-dairy milk
2 ripe bananas
1/4 cup corn oil
1/4 cup sweet cicely root (or add 1/2 tsp. star anise, ground, to the dry ingredients)
2 tbs. lecithin granules
2 tsp. vanilla

1. Mix together the dry ingredients.

2. Purée; the ingredients to blend in a blender.

3. Stir the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Don’t overmix.

4. Stir in the chips. Don’t overmix.

5. Pour a ladle-full of batter onto an oiled hot griddle, cook until lightly browned underneath, flip with a spatula, and repeat the process to use up all the batter.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 45 minutes

Trout Lily
trout-lily
Family: Liliaceae, the lily family
The young leaves and corms are in season in early spring only, before the flowers appear.
Partially shaded habitats, often near bodies of water, rich moist woods, wooded slopes,
Most of Northeastern North America except for Florida

Look for sets of one or two smooth-edged, shiny, fleshy, hairless, lance-shaped, ovate to elliptical, pointed, medium-sized leaves, forming extensive colonies on the forest floor in early spring. There's a smooth, slender, leafless flower stalk four to ten inches tall with a solitary, nodding, yellow, six-tepaled flower one to two inches wide, streaked with reddish lines, tepals bent backwards. And Look for an ovate fruit in late spring.

This spring ephemeral's smooth-edged, shiny, lance-shaped, ovate, to elliptical, pointed, fleshy, basal leaves grow three to six inches long and about one inch wide, with nearly no leaf stalks. Sterile plants have but one leaf, fertile plants have two. Purple-brown mottling makes the leaves resemble the skin of a speckled trout.

A solitary, nodding, yellow, six-tepaled flower one to two inches wide, streaked with reddish lines, emerges from the ground atop a long, smooth, slender, leafless stalk four to ten inches tall, blooming from early- to mid-spring. The tepals are bent backwards, revealing six brown stamens and one thick pistil. It's followed by an ovate fruit in late spring, before the plant dies to the ground.

A solid, light brown, tooth-shaped corm 0.33 to one inch long, white inside, grows deep underground. Stolons help the plant, which also spreads by seeds, grow into dense colonies.

•One or two smooth-edged, shiny, fleshy, hairless, lance-shaped, ovate, or elliptical pointed, leaves three to six inches long and about one inch wide
•Leaves mottled with irregular, purple-brown spots
•Long, smooth, slender, leafless flower stalk four to ten inches tall
•Solitary, nodding, yellow, six-tepaled flower one to two inches wide, streaked with reddish lines
•Tepals bent backwards, revealing six brown stamens and one thick pistil
•Ovate fruit replacing flower in late spring
•Solid, light brown, tooth-shaped corm, 0.33 to one inch long, white inside, growing deep underground

Grasping a few at a time, break off the young leaves before the flowers appear. You may also dig up the corms with a shovel or trowel while the leaves are very small and the corms' food reserves haven't been tapped yet, but this is quite labor-intensive and barely worth the effort. If you're going to undertake this, do so where the plant is at its most dense.

The leaves have a pleasant flavor similar to that of cucumbers, so they're excellent chopped and added raw to salads or sandwiches. They're also fine cooked 5 to 10 minute in any dish that calls for vegetables, using any cooking method.

If you have the time and patience to collect enough of them, you can prepare the corms like potatoes.
Trout lilies provide vitamin C, as well as alph-methylene-butyrolactone, which has anti-mutagenic activity and may help prevent cells from becoming cancerous.

Cherokees and other Native American tribes used the crushed plant as a soothing emollient on inflamed surfaces, such as rashes, bruises, and sores that won’t heal. They’d also drink an infusion of the corms for fever. It would be nice to see these uses tested experimentally.

Eat this plant in very small quantities at first, and increase your portions slowly—it makes some people throw up. And don't eat the leaves after the flowers appears, when they becomes slightly toxic.

Although the corm’s shape may resemble a dog’s tooth, the ineptly named dog tooth violet is no more a violet (Viola spp.) than it is a dog (Canus domesticus), or even a trout (Salvelinus fontinalis). It is a lily.

Many other similar edible close relatives, (Erythronium spp.) grow throughout the US. The white dog tooth violet's (Erythronium albidum) leaves, for example, resembles those of the trout lily, but its flower is white.
Yellow trout-lily, American Trout-lily, Adder's Tongue, Fawn Lily
This common spring ephemeral can be very abundant for a couple of weeks in early spring, and its leaves have the surprising flavor of cucumbers.
Common Blue Violet
Tofu in Peanut Sauce
tofu-in-peanut-sauce

Here’s a great way to season tofu to create an entrée. With trout-lilies providing the a surprising cucumber flavor, that will taste good even to tofu-haters. Serve alongside brown rice.

2 cup apple juice
1/4 cup peanut butter
1/4 cup mellow miso

2. Place the tofu in an oiled casserole dish, pour the sauce over it, and bake, covered, 45 minutes, or until bubbly.

Preparation time: 15 minutes
