Virginia Waterleaf
virginia-waterleaf
Family: Hydrophylloideae, the waterleaf family
Eat the leaves soon after they come up in early spring, before they flower and become tough and unpalatable in mid-spring.
Partially shaded, moist, rich, or low woods, thickets, ravine bottoms, bases of bluffs, flood plains, and stream valleys
Throughout most of Eastern North America, but not in most of the southernmost states

Look for a medium-sized colonial plant with distinctly white-spotted, feather-compound, broadly triangular, deeply lobed leaves. It has three- to seven-parted, with large, regular teeth and pointed leaflets. The green to reddish-green, leafless flower stalks grow one to three feet tall and end in one or two loose, terminal, flower clusters with eight to 20 showy, white to pale violet, bell-shaped, five-lobed, hairy flowers, followed by capsule-like fruits.

Appearing in early spring, and spreading via rhizomes, this colonial plant’s broadly triangular, three- to seven-parted feather-compound leaves, distinctly white-spotted and deeply lobed, grow four to six inches long and three to four inches across. With large, regular teeth, the leaflets are pointy tipped.

In mid-spring, a green to reddish-green, leafless stem grows one to three feet tall, with one or two loose, terminal flower clusters two inches across. These consist of eight to 20 white to pale violet, bell-shaped, five-lobed, hairy flowers, each 0.33 to 0.5 inch across. Straight, protruding stamens grow longer than the flowers.

A capsule-like fruit splits open in the summer to release its seeds.

•Three- to seven-parted feather-compound, broadly triangular, deeply lobed leaves, 4 to 6 inches long and 3 to 4 inches across
•Distinct white-spots on the leaves, especially when young
•Leaflets with large, regular teeth and pointed tips
•Green to reddish-green, leafless stem one to three feet tall
•One or two loose terminal flower clusters two inches across
•Eight to 20 white to pale violet, bell-shaped, five-lobed, hairy flowers, each 0.33 to 0.5 inch across
•Straight, protruding stamens longer than the flowers
•Capsule-like fruit that splits open in the summer to release its seeds
•Plant usually colonial with rhizomes
Hold down the leaf stalks and break off bunches of leaves before the flowers appear.

This plant tastes like parsley, with the delicate feel of cilantro. Some people cook it as a green, whereas I tend to use it fresh or dried in place of parsley, in a large range of savory dishes. It's especially good in soups or stews.
Native Americans used a decoction of the root internally as an astringent, for diarrhea and dysentery and externally for poison ivy rash. And they also chewed the raw roots for mouth sores.

There are no poisonous look-alikes. Nonpoisonous cutleaf coneflower (Rudbeckia laciniata) leaves resemble Virginia waterleaf, but without the watermarks.

The 12 or so other similar waterleaf species (Hydrophyllum spp.), which grow throughout North America, are also edible. The color of their flowers varies, as do their leaves, which are mainly feather-compound, basal or alternate, usually with light green splotches. Large-leaf waterleaf (H. macrophylum), for example looks like Virginia waterleaf, but the leaves are divided into at least seven lobes, and it’s rough-hairy. Broad-leaved waterleaf (H. canadense) has maple-like leaves, with the flower stalks beneath the leaves.
This plant, which can carpet floodplains, looks like it's been watermarked with white spots. The texture is delicate, and it tastes like parsley.
Cutleaf Coneflower
Burdock and Waterleaf Stew
burdock-and-waterleaf-stew

Cooking lots of delicious vegetables together, with burdock and Virginia waterleaf as the leaders, plus appropriate Greek-inspired seasonings along with a touch of long-grain rice, how can you go wrong?

4 cups burdock root or potatoes, sliced

Pressure cook all ingredients 15 minutes; or simmer, covered, 45 minutes, or until the burdock is tender and the rice is done.

Cooking time 15 or 45 minutes
1)Virginia Waterleaf in Flower
1virginia-waterleaf-in-flower

An easy plant to recognize, this showy resident of moist woods has deeply divided, large-toothed, feather-compound leaves, and clusters of a few white, bell-shaped flowers, with long, protruding stamens, blooming atop one or two long, slender, leafless stems. And even more distinctive are the white spots on the leaves.
2)Young Virginia Waterleaf
2young-virginia-waterleaf
These deeply divided, long-toothed, feather-compound leaves are at the perfect stage for harvesting, and the white spots on the leaves makes it easy to confirm their identity.

3virginia-waterleaf-flowers

This terminal cluster of white, five-parted, bell-shaped flowers' long, straight, protruding brown-tipped stamens are longer than the flowers themselves—quite distinctive, especially in combination with the leaves.
Wild Watercress
wild-watercress
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

New leaves come up toward the end of early spring, and are at their best until the plant flowers, in mid- to late spring. Although the plant remains edible through the summer, it plant becomes excessively spicy and somewhat bitter.

New young leaves return in the fall, but become harder to pick as the weather gets cold. Frosts cut the plant down to the level of the water, where it picks up too much annoying-to-clean autumn detritus.

You can also sometimes find watercress during warm spells in the winter, especially in regions where the winters aren't cold.
Sunny, shallow fresh, moving water, ditches, wet ground, springs, and the edges of lakes and streams
Throughout most of North America
Eurasia

Look for dense mats of wild watercress in shallow, cold, flowing, fresh water. It has fleshy, wavy edged, feather-compound, smooth basal leaves divided into three to 11 smooth-edged, oblong to oval, opposite leaflets. The alternate leaves on the hollow, grooved, trailing stem are similar, but they partially clasp the stem, which is upright at the its end. White, fibrous roots emanate from the stem.

Terminal and axillary racemes from the upper leaves bear tiny, white, four-petaled flowers, followed by short, slender, slightly curved, long-stalked, cylindrical seed capsules.

Usually floating in dense mats in shallow, cold, flowing, fresh water, this hairless, toothless European mustard first appears toward the end of early spring. Its fleshy, trailing, hollow stems, attached at nodes to fibrous, white roots, grow upright at their ends.

Sometimes turning purple in cold weather, the delicate, glossy, basal leaves grow 1.5 to to six inches long. Fleshy and wavy edged, these feather-compound leaves divide completely into segments of three to 11 smooth-edged, oblong to oval, opposite leaflets—the end leaflet always being the largest. The youngest leaflets aren't divided.

In early summer, terminal racemes of tiny, white, four-petaled flowers 0.2 inch across grow atop the grooved, hollow stem, which reaches up to 6 inches tall. Some racemes also arise from the upper leaf axils. Below, alternate leaves similar to but smaller than the basal leaves, grow from leaf stalks that partially clasp the stem.

In mid-summer, the flowers give way to short, slender, slightly curved, cylindrical seed capsules one inch long, growing at the ends of long seed stalks, with four rows of tiny, spherical seeds inside. Watercress spreads vegetatively as pieces break off, as well as through its seeds.

•Dense mats in shallow, cold, flowing, fresh water, with fleshy, trailing, hollow stems
•Stems growing upright up to 6 inches tall at their ends
•Fleshy, wavy edged, feather-compound, smooth leaves divided into 3 to 11 smooth-edged, oblong to oval, opposite leaflets.
•End leaflet always the largest
•Youngest leaflets not divided
•Alternate leaves on stem resembling the larger basal leaves
•Leaves and stems attached at nodes to fibrous, white roots
•Terminal racemes, and racemes growing from the upper leaf axils, consisting of tiny, white, 4-petaled flowers 0.2 inch across
•Leaf stalks partially clasping the stem
•Short, slender, slightly curved, cylindrical seedpods 1 inch long, growing at the ends of long seed stalks,
•Seedpods containing four rows of tiny, spherical seeds
Remove your shoes, roll up your pants, take a plastic bag, and wade in after this superb vegetable. Pinch off bunches with your fingers. Bring a towel to dry your feet afterward.

A superb-tasting, spicy, nutritious wild vegetable, add it to raw to salads and sandwiches, or cook 5 to 10 minutes in soups, sauces, casseroles, or other vegetable dishes and entrée;s. Because of its strong flavor, it's especially good combined with bland foods such as potatoes, tofu, or pasta, but it also does well in spicy dishes, as it never gets drowned out.

The seeds are tiny and hard to collect in quantity, but you can grind them and mix them with cold water and vinegar to make a prepared mustard, or sprout them.

Although most adults enjoy it's hot flavor and don't mind its tantalizing touch of bitterness, many kids don't like it—certainly the greatest contrast I've ever noticed between the taste of adults and kids for any wild plant.

Watercress is more nutritious than anything you can buy. Only dandelions and lamb's-quarters rival it.

It's loaded with more vitamin A and C, carotenoids, folic acid, iron, and potassium than any vegetable you can buy. It’s also an excellent source of flavonoids, vitamins E, B1, and B2, as well as the minerals and trace minerals phosphorus, sodium, iodine, manganese, sulfur, zinc, copper, cobalt, and vanadium. It also provides arginine, aspartic acid, beta carotene, biotin, glutamic acid, glycine, histidine, isoleucine, lysine, methionine, pantothenic acid, phenylalanine, serine, threonine, tryptophan, tyrosine, and valine.

Always have the water tested for pathogens before eating this plant raw, especially near where sheep, which carry liver fluke, graze. Fortunately, cooking destroys parasites. [-(no wonder you never see politicians or lawyers cooking!)]

Other mustards, all edible, resemble watercress somewhat, but they're also all terrestial, not aquatic. Winter cress, for example, has thicker, glossy leaves and yellow flowers. It grows in moist areas. So does yellow watercress, another mustard with yellow, 4-petaled flowers, as well as long, narrow, regularly lobed leaves.

Duckweed (Lemna species) often grows along with watercress. With smaller flowers than any other North American plant, its tiny, opposite, unlobed leaves are so tiny, people confuse it with pond algae. People around the world have eaten various duckweed species, so while it's unlikely that any of them are poisonous, the plant is too puny to be worth picking, and you should avoid accidentally collecting it when gathering watercress.
Brooklime, Brown Cress, Cress, Cresson, Nasturtium, Water Cresses, True Watercress
This is the same vegetable you get in stores or restaurants, but with a big difference in flavor. As usual, the wild vegetable wins big, hands down!
common dandelion, lamb's-quarters, winter cress, yellow watercress
Wild Winter Soup
wild-winter-soup

Here’s a tasty, filling, nutritious simple soup you can make with cold-weather plants as winter approaches.

6-1/2 cups vegetable stock
1 cooked medium potato
2 cloves of garlic
1/4 cup mellow miso
1 tsp. spearmint
1 tsp. coriander, ground
1 tsp. yellow mustard seeds, ground
1 tbs. lemon juice
2 cups silken tofu, diced
2 cups wild or commercial watercress, or garlic mustard leaves, chopped
1 cup sheep sorrel leaves or other greens, chopped

1. Purée; the potato, garlic, miso, spearmint, coriander, mustard seeds, and lemon juice in a blender.

2. Combine with the remaining ingredients in a large saucepan, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 10 minutes.

Serves 8 to 10

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Cooking time: 10 minutes

The shiny, fleshy, feather-compound, smooth, wavy-edged leaves' largest leaflet is at the tip. Tiny, four-petaled flowers grow in terminal racemes above the fleshy stem. They turn into long-stalked, narrow, seedpods, which grow below the flowers.

These fleshy, smooth, shiny, feather-compound basal leaves float on the water, usually along with the smaller duckweed. The terminal leaflet is always the largest.

Wild Asparagus
wild-asparagus
Family: Liliaceae, the lily family
Collect the shoots at the end of early spring and the beginning of mid-spring, and break off any remaining tender young tops throughout mid-spring.

Asparagus grows in partially sunny habitats, pastures, fence rows, old, sandy uncultivated or old cultivated or fields, disturbed sites, open woods, and roadsides, although I find it most often in fields that associated with salt marshes.

Although wild asparagus grows throughout the US and southern Canada, especially in farming areas, it's not common everywhere. After stalking the wild asparagus in the Greater NY area since 1980, to my great frustration, I've only found it in a handful of places, and never in any abundance.
Europe, Western Asia, and Northern Africa

Look for thin, crooked, hairless, unbranched green shoots that resemble commercial asparagus, with scales becoming crowded toward the tip, at the start and just before mid-spring. In the late spring and summer, look for a plant shaped like a Christmas tree, with hairless, upward- facing branches. They have feathery, needle-like leaves, six-tepaled, yellow-green, narrowly bell-shaped flowers, or tiny, short-stalked, spherical, bright red berries in twos or threes.

Wild asparagus begins like a familiar, if thinner and more crooked, version of commercial asparagus. Alternate, triangular scales become crowded toward the tip the hairless, unbranched, green shoot.

Later on, a hairless branched stalk, which reaches two to seven feet in height, grows feathery, needle-like leaves (actually modified stems) 0.75 inch long, on very slender, upward-curving branches. At this stage, it resembles a Christmas tree.

Arising from the junctions of the branches and grouped in sets of two or three, tiny, yellow, short-stalked, six-tepaled, yellow-green, narrowly bell-shaped flowers just over 0.125 inches long, bloom in late spring.

There are separate male and female plants, so only the females have the thin-stalked, spherical, poisonous, bright red berries, 0.375 inch across, which ripen in the summer. Inside are three to six tiny seeds.

Asparagus’ much-branching rhizomes give rise to colonies. As with many other wild edibles, dead overwintered stalks, here shaped like small, wilted Christmas trees, provide a marker for the following spring's new growth.

•Unbranched, hairless, scaly, green shoot, resembling commercial asparagus, but thinner and more crooked
•Alternate, triangular scales becoming crowded toward the shoot's tip
•Hairless mature stalk two to seven feet high with very slender, upward-curving branches
•Mature leaves feathery, needle-like, 0.75 inch long
•Flowers and berries in sets of two or three, arising from the junctions of the branches
•Tiny, yellow-green, thin-stalked, six-tepaled, narrowly bell-shaped flowers, just over 0.125 inch across
•Thin-stalked, spherical, bright red berries, 0.375 inch across, containing three to six tiny seeds
•Persistent winter skeleton resembling a small, dead Christmas tree

You can cut off the young stalks from just below ground level, and clip the tips of somewhat larger stalks, but don’t harvest mature plants—they’re mildly toxic. Also, be sure to let some stalks mature fully, supplying the rhizomes with nutrients for next year’s growth.

Although you can nibble on the smallest and most tender shoots raw, asparagus is best cooked. Although you can sometimes find raw asparagus in restaurant salads, if you eat too much raw, it may act as a laxative.

Tie the tender parts of the stalks together with a string and place this in a tall pot of boiling water with just the tougher bottoms are submerged. Simmer, covered, five to ten minutes, or until just tender. You may add seasonings such as olive oil, wild or commercial bay leaves, thyme, oregano, or marjoram to the water if desired.

Season cooked wild asparagus with salt, pepper, and a dash of olive oil, or stir in some hollandaise sauce, and serve piping hot. You can also add wild asparagus to almost any soup or stew five to ten minutes before it’s finished cooking, or include it in casseroles.

Asparagus is especially rich in beta-carotene and vitamin C. It's also an excellent source of vitamin E, B1, B2, B6, and folic acid, as well as the minerals potassium, calcium, magnesium, manganese, phosphorus, iron, and zinc, plus the trace minerals chromium and selenium. It also contains asparagine, saponins, flavonoids, a volatile oil, a glucoside, gum, resin, and tannic acid.

Asparagus is a traditional diuretic. It's supposed to cleanse and tone the urinary tract and help clear urinary obstructions. Herbalists recommend the juice for edema and kidney stones. In addition, the grated shoots have been used to make a stimulating facial wash, applied externally for 10 minutes. It's been recommended for oily and acne-blemished skin.
Don't eat too much raw asparagus, lest it give you diarrhea, and avoid the mildly toxic mature plant and berries.
Japanese knotweed shoots, also edible, look slightly similar to asparagus, although, unlike asparagus, they have reddish-green stems encircled at intervals by papery wrappings.
Wild asparagus looks like commercial asparagus, just thinner and more crooked, and it's flavor is first-rate.
Japanese Knotweed
Wild (or Unwild) Spring Soup
wild-or-unwild-spring-soup

Wild spring ingredients that taste delicious on their own are also great combined in a simple soup, which you can also make with store-bought ingredients.

4 cups oat milk or nut milk
1-1/2 cup burdock root or wild or commercial parsnips, thinly sliced
2 tbs. olive oil
2 cloves garlic, crushed
1 tsp. Vege-sal or 1/2 tps. salt
1/4 tsp. black pepper, ground
2/3 cups wild or commercial asparagus, or ostrich fern fiddleheads, chopped
1 cup ramp leaves or shallots, chopped
1/2 cup wild or commercial watercress, garlic mustard leaves, or cutleaved toothwort leaves, chopped
2 cups curly dock leaves or spinach, chopped

1. Simmer the burdock in the oat milk with the garlic, olive oil, Vege-sal, and pepper 15 minutes.

2. Add the remaining ingredients and simmer another 5 minutes.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 30 minutes

Wild Ginger
wild-ginger
Family: Aristolochiaceae, the birthwort family

The rhizomes are in season all year, and the semi-evergreen leaves sometimes persist for much of the winter, to help you locate the rhizomes, so you can dig them up most of the time the ground isn't frozen.
Shaded or partially shaded rich, undisturbed woods

Three very similar wild ginger species (A. canadense, A. acuminatum, and A. reflexum) grow throughout most of the eastern half of North America except for Florida, and another species (A. caudatum) grows in California and the Pacific Northwest.

European wild ginger (A. Europaeum) grows in sandy woodlands and where it's been planted, in cultivated parks, throughout North America.
European wild ginger is obviously European. The other species are native.

Look for a stemless, velvety, ginger-scented plant with two large, long-stalked, toothless, heart-shaped basal leaves. In the spring you'll find solitary, slender-stemmed, dark brown-purple flower with three reddish sepals united around a cream-colored ovary. Later there will be a small, leathery, six-parted fruit capsule visible at ground level.

This stemless perennial, which grows from four to 12 inches tall, has 2 large, long-stalked, toothless, heart-shaped, velvety, ginger-scented basal leaves that grow from three to six inches across.

Arising from the crotch of the two hairy leafstalks and hidden beneath the leaves (it's pollinated by ground-dwelling bugs), a solitary, slender-stemmed, dark brown-purple, flower without petals blooms from early- to mid- spring. Three reddish petal-like sepals unite to form a protective layer around a cream colored ovary. A small, leathery, six-parted fruit capsule ripens in the summer.

The shallow, fleshy, branched, ginger-scented rhizomes, less than 0.5 inch thick, interconnect the plants to form a dense colony.

•Stemless, velvety, colonial, ginger-scented plant four to 12 inches tall
•Two large, long-stalked, toothless, heart-shaped, basal leaves three to six inches across
•Leaf stalks fuzzy
•A solitary, slender-stemmed, dark brown-purple flower, with three reddish sepals joining around a cream-colored ovary
•A small, leathery, six-parted fruit capsule
•Shallow network of fleshy, branched, ginger-scented rhizomes about 0.5 inches thick
Please harvest the rhizomes sparingly, using a shovel or trowel, only where they're very abundant, and only thin out very dense patches.

Although this plant isn't related to commercial ginger, you use it the same way, as a seasoning or tea, in about twice the volume as the less delicate-flavored commercial plant. Add the ground rhizome, fresh or dried, to fruit dishes, baked goods, curries, ice creams, pies, puddings, or any other dessert or appropriate main course or side dish.

Ongoing research has uncovered antibacterial and anti-fungal properties of wild ginger, which contains aristolochic acid, a substance that kills bacteria and inhibits tumor growth. And a related Asian species have also been used with success in traditional Chinese medicine for centuries.

Native Americans used a decoction of the rhizomes for gastric upset, indigestion, nausea, coughs, menstrual cramps, and fevers, and there's extensive anecdotal evidence that it works. They also used it to prevent food spoilage, consistent with its antibacterial properties.

Native Americans and colonists inhaled the dried, powdered rhizome like snuff, for sinus congestion and headaches, and applied the crushed rhizome to inflamed and infected cuts and wounds. A decoction was sometimes even cooled and poured directly into infected ears.

This plant is included in many current herbal formulas as a circulatory stimulant, to increase the other ingredients’ effectiveness.

Collect only a limited quantity from large, dense stands, so you don’t damage the plant.

Some recent research indicates that the aristolochic acid this plant contains could be toxic to the kidneys, but since this plant, which has been so useful for hundreds of years, hasn't been getting people sick, its moderate use as a seasoning and tea doesn't seem unduly risky, although it's your choice whether or not to use it.

Other edible forest plants, such as garlic mustard and violets have heart-shaped leaves, but they're all toothed rather than smooth-edged, the leaves don't grow in pairs, and they don't smell like ginger.

Sometimes called "coltsfoot," wild ginger is a completely different plant from an unrelated medicinal plant with the same name, Tussilago farfara, a relative of dandelions.
Indian Ginger, Canada Snakeroot, Coltsfoot
Unrelated to commercial ginger, this plant has a similar flavor. You use it in the same kind of recipes, and it even has similar medicinal properties to its Asian namesake.
Garlic Mustard, Common Blue Violet
Wild Ginger-Chocolate Pudding
wild-ginger-chocolate-pudding

Wild ginger complements the other flavorings, while silken tofu, lecithin, dates, and almond oil produce just the right texture, and liquid stevia adds the sweetness. Cocoa and carob give the chocolate flavor added dimension, and everything works together perfectly in this simple but very tasty pudding.

6 cups silken tofu, drained
3/4 cup Dutch unsweetened cocoa
3/4 cup lecithin granules
3/4 cup of pitted Medjool (soft) dates
2 tbs. almond oil
1 tbs. vanilla
3/4 tsp. salt
1/2 tsp. wild ginger, ground, or commercial powdered ginger
1/2 tsp. almond extract
1/2 tsp. amaretto extract (optional)
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia
1 cup carob chips
1/4 cup pecans, finely chopped

1. Purée; all ingredients except the carob chips and pecans in a food processor.

2. Add the carob chips and process just enough to mix.

3. Serve sprinkled with the pecans.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 5 minutes

Wild Parsnip
wild-parsnip
Apiaceae or Umbelliferae, the umbellifers, or the parsley family

The taproot of the wild parsnip's basal rosette stage stores food underground in autumn, when it becomes edible, and remains so until mid-spring, when stored food moves to the growing above-ground parts and the root becomes tough and woody. With the absence of leaves in the winter, plus frozen soil, the root's generally unavailable then, so unless you live where winters are very mild and the basal leaves persist, harvest it in the fall and early spring.
This fragrant garden escape grows in sunny spots on damp, disturbed soil, in empty lots, wetlands, and fields, as well as along edge habitats and roadsides, both inland and near the seashore.
Throughout most of North America except the Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida
Europe

Look for a rosette of large, stalked, unbranched, feather-compound, hairless, basal leaves divided into five to 15 coarse, ovate to oblong, deeply lobed, variably saw-toothed leaflets on both sides of a midrib. There's a stout, deeply grooved, hollow, branching, hairless stem three to five feet tall; upper stems ending in long-stalked, flat-topped umbrella-like flower clusters three to eight inches across, without bracts. Terminal flower clusters divide into 15 to 25 umbrella-like clusters ending in many tiny, long-stalked, yellow, five-petaled flowers, followed by many small, long-stalked, fragrant, flat, ribbed, oval seeds.

In early spring of both its teo years of life, this biennial produces a basal rosette six inches high. The large, stalked, unbranched, feather-compound, hairless basal leaves grow close to one foot long and four inches wide, with five to 15 coarse, ovate to oblong, deeply lobed, variably saw-toothed leaflets on both sides of a midrib.

In mid-spring of its second year, a stout, deeply grooved, hollow, branching, hairless stem grows from three to five feet tall. Resembling the basal leaves, stalked alternate leaves grow near the bottom. They become progressively smaller and nearly stalkless higher up.

The upper stems end in long-stalked, flat-topped, terminal, umbrella-like flower clusters three to eight inches across, without bracts. These divide twice, ending with 15 to 25 umbrella-like clusters of 12 to 35 long-stalked, yellow, five-petaled flowers, 0.125 inch across—hundreds altogether. Each flower becomes a long-stalked, fragrant, flat, ribbed, oval seed 0.25 inch long, ripening in late summer and fall.

The single, thick, whitish, fleshy taproot, which smells like commercial parsnips, can grow over one foot long.

•Basal rosette six inches high consisting of large, stalked, unbranched, feather-compound, hairless leaves
•Stalked basal leaves divided into five to 15 coarse, ovate to oblong, deeply lobed, variably saw-toothed leaflets, on both sides of a midrib
•Stout, unbranched, deeply grooved, hollow, branching, hairless stem three to five feet tall
•Branched alternate leaves similar to basal leaves on stem, long-stalked below, nearly stalkless above
•Upper stems ending in long-stalked, flat-topped umbrella-like flower clusters three to eight inches across
•Flower clusters divided into 15 to 25 umbrella-like clusters ending in groups of 12 to 35 tiny, long-stalked, yellow, five-petaled flowers 0.125 inch across
•No bracts
•Many long-stalked, fragrant, flat, ribbed, oval seeds 0.25 inch long
•Single, large, thick, whitish, fleshy taproot smelling like commercial parsnips

Dig up the taproots of the basal rosettes with a shovel or trowel in early spring or fall. In sandy soil, you might be able to pull out the taproot if you grip its top firmly with your hands. Don't collect any other parts of this plant, and avoid skin contact with the leaves.

More coarse-looking that its commercial forerunner, the wild parsnip is more flavorful and sweeter. Although it’s edible raw, large quantities may be laxative, and it has a tough, stringy texture. Cooking tenderizes it and brings out its remarkable sweetness. It’s a good steamed vegetable, but it’s exceptionally tasty in soups or stews, or cooked with whole grains—way better than commercial parsnips, cooking in about 20 minutes. You can also use it for making stock.
Wild parsnips provide calcium, potassium, phosphorus, vitamin C, and fiber, as well as more calories than most wild foods—especially important for survivalists.

Some sources recommend a tea of parsnip leaves for diabetes, as well as for kidney and urinary problems, with warnings that too much may lower the blood sugar excessively. The only problem is that the leaves are poisonous! Use only the root of the basal rosette, and avoid other parts of the plant. There are plenty of safe medicinal plants around.

Wild parsnip leaves contain furanocoumarin, highly concentrated when the plant is flowering (when it's not edible anyway). It can cause a severe rash if you're exposed to the sun after contacting the leaves with sweaty skin.

Medieval European monks, forced to be self-sufficient, poisoned themselves by eating the leaves, so eat only the taproots of this plant!
The wild parsnip resembles the rare prairie parsley (Polytaenia nuttallii), a non-poisonous Midwest endangered plant with much more sparse, light-yellow flowers, and leaflets with way fewer teeth.
This feral offspring of garden parsnips, subject to a very brief stint with natural selection, has already developed a less elegant appearance and way more flavor.
2)Wild Parsnips in Happy Hoison Sauce
2wild-parsnips-in-happy-hoison-sauce

Savoy Chinese Happy Hoisin Sauce balances the strong flavor of wild parsnips in this hearty, Chinese-style stir-fried entrée. Serve with brown rice or noodles.

3 tbs. sesame oil
1 tbs. dark sesame oil
2 cups wild or commercial parsnips, thinly sliced
2 medium red onions, sliced
1-1/2 cups vegetarian beef chunks (available in Asian frozen fake meat stores and website), diced, parboiled tempeh, or drained extra-firm tofu
1 tbs. Oriental Seasoning blend
1 tsp. Chinese 5-Spice Seasoning
1 cup Happy Hoisin Sauce

1. Measure and prepare the ingredients beforehand

2. Mix the oils together, heat 1/3 of the oil in a wok, stir-fry the parsnips 4 minutes, and set aside.

3. Add half the remaining oil to the wok and stir-fry the onions 4 minutes or until translucent, then set aside.

4. Add the remaining oil to the wok and stir-fry the vegetarian beef chunks or the equivalent 4 minutes.

4. Stir in the remaining ingredients and the set-aside ingredients, bring to a boil, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 10 minutes.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 40 minutes

1)Wild Parsnip Leaves, Taproot, Flowers and Seeds

The wild parsnip's single, white, fleshy taproot underlies a basal rosette of irregularly divided, feather-compound basal leaves. The sharp-toothed, hairless, irregular leaflets have both deep and shallow lobes, making them look raggedy.

Configured like an umbrella, the tiny, five-petaled flowers grow at the ends of long flower stalks. The small, flattened, ovate seeds that follow take on a similar configuration.

This tall, stout, deeply grooved, branching, hairless stem, with the smallest leaves toward the top, ends in long-stalked, flat-topped, terminal, umbrella-like flower clusters without bracts. These divide twice, ending with 15 to 25 umbrella-like clusters of many tiny, long-stalked, yellow, five-petaled flowers.
Wisteria
wisteria
Family: Fabaceae, the pea or legume family
The edible flowers bloom toward the end of early spring or the beginning of mid-spring. The poisonous seeds ripen in late summer and fall.
Sunny, cultivated areas, openings in forests, edge habitats, thickets, along streams, floodplains, roadsides, and trail sides
Throughout North America
This Asian species has similar Asian and native relatives growing wild and under cultivation in America.

Look for a smooth, woody, twining vine, sometimes massive, with alternate, feather-compound leaves up to 2 feet long. Wisteria has nine to 19 long-oval, toothless, paired leaflets three inches long. Drooping racemes six to 18 inches long become densely covered with showy, fragrant bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like, purple to lilac (sometimes white) flowers, each about 1 inch across in the spring, followed by green, velvety, knobby seedpods four to eight inches long.

This showy, smooth-barked, counterclockwise-twining, woody vine, which can climb up to 70 feet high and live for hundreds of years, getting as thick as a tree. The feather-compound alternate leaves grow up to two feet long, with nine to 19 long-oval, toothless, paired, pointed leaflets around three inches long.

Long, dense, drooping racemes six to 18 inches long become densely covered with showy, fragrant, bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like purple to lilac (sometimes white) flowers, about one inch across. This common, cultivated Asian species, which readily escapes into the wild, blooms in mid-spring, just before the leaves finish developing.

In the summer, wisteria produces green, velvety knobby seedpods four to eight inches long, containing one to three flattened, long-oval, black-streaked, reddish-brown to yellowish-brown seeds, so poisonous that no animal eats them. They disperse explosively when the pod dries out and suddenly contracts.

•Smooth, woody, twining vine, sometimes massive
•Alternate, feather-compound leaves up to two feet long, with nine to 19 long-oval, toothless, paired leaflets, three inches long
•Long, dense, drooping racemes six to 18 inches long, densely covered with showy, fragrant bilaterally symmetrical, pea-like purple to lilac flowers about one inch across
•Green, velvety, knobby seedpods four to eight inches long
•One to three flattened, long-oval, black-streaked, reddish-brown to yellowish-brown seeds inside each pod
Strip the flowers off the racemes with your fingers, taking care not to include any unopened flowers.

Wisteria flowers have an unusual, sweet, perfumed flavor. You can add them raw to salads, or include them in ice cream, pies, fruit soups, smoothies, and all variety of desserts. They're especially good in pancakes and fritters,[-. They're] a wonderful, exotic garnish, and [-they] make a great wine [-too].

Wisteria flowers are quite strong-flavored, so use them sparingly or they'll overpower the other ingredients.

Wisteria flowers cause nausea and vomiting in sensitive individuals, so taste very small quantities at first, then gradually increase your portions. If your stomach begins to feel queasy, avoid this food. Use only opened flowers, not the unopened flower buds, which are much more likely to cause problems. Raw flowers are more likely to cause bad reactions than cooked ones.

The seeds that the pods cast off contain a toxic glycoside called wisterin, as well as toxic lectins. Don't subscribe to such pod-casts! Just two seeds can cause mild to severe nausea, repeated vomiting (sometimes bloody), abdominal pain, and diarrhea. In severe cases, dehydration, collapse, and death may occur. Otherwise, recovery usually occurs within 24 hours.

Japanese wisteria (W. floribunda), also edible, is similar to Wisteria sinensis, but it twines clockwise. The two species readily hybridize, and there's no need to try to tell them apart.

A similar but smaller American species (W. frutescens) is also edible, but with shorter racemes and smooth seedpods. It blooms in the summer. There are other edible wisteria species, also hard to distinguish, and they may also hybridize.
Chinese Wisteria
The exotic-flavored flowers of this "ornamental" vine make for great pancakes and desserts, but you have to collect it during the short period it's in season every year.
Wisteria Tapioca Pudding
wisteria-tapioca-pudding

Wisteria blossoms transform this pudding into something special.

1 container (1.06 Qt.) almond- or other nut milk, oat milk, or soy-rice milk
3/4 cup raisins
1/2 cup wisteria or black locust blossoms
1/2 cup cashews
1/2 tsp. salt
1 tsp. liquid stevia
1/4 cup pitted soft dates
1/4 cup lecithin granules
3 tbs. tapioca
2 tbs. corn oil
2 tsp. vanilla
1 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1/2 tsp. lemon extract

1. Simmer all ingredients except the wisteria blossoms 10 minutes.

2. Stir in the blossoms and remove from the heat.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 30 minutes

1wisteria-blossoms
Wisteria's fragrant, showy, pendant racemes become covered with bilaterally symmetrical, blue to violet, pea-like flowers, making them as decorative as they are delicious!
3)Wisteria Leaves and Pods
3wisteria-leaves-and-pods
The long, thick, velvety, green seedpods, hanging from a vine with alternate, feather-compound leaves, makes wisteria quite distinct.

This clambering vine, with alternate, feather-compound leaves, and thick, green, velvety pods, will grow over anything relatively quickly.

4wisteria-seedpods-and-seeds

Honey Locust
honey-locust
Family: Fabaceae, the pea or legume family

The young seedpod is edible in early summer, the seeds are good to eat in mid-summer, and the pulp inside the pods is ready to eat from mid- to late fall through winter, the same time some people roast the hard seeds and use them like coffee.

This tree thrives in full sunlight, although it tolerates partial shade. It grows in rich woods, in cultivated parks, along urban and suburban streets, along the edges of woods, on the borders of streams, and sometimes even on dry, sterile, gravelly hills.
The honey locust tree grows wild in sunny and partially shaded places throughout the Central and Atlantic states, and it's been planted extensively in parks and along streets throughout the country.

Look for a tall street or woodland tree with gray to blackish bark consisting of long, smooth, flat plates separated by furrows, sometimes with clusters large, sharp, branched thorns. Alternate, feather-compound leaves are often subdivided into three to six side branches then eight to 14 small, oblong, toothless, usually opposite, leaflets. Racemes of small, inconspicuous, fragrant, yellow-green flowers hang from the leaf axils with long, flat, bumpy, green seedpods that twist and blacken in the fall.

This common street tree grows from 60 to 100 feet tall (75 feet is common), with a crown 50 feet across. The gray to blackish bark consists of long, smooth, flat plates separated by furrows. It's sometimes armed with clusters large, sharp, branched thorns, often grouped in threes, although some varieties, especially those planted as street trees, are thornless.

Alternate, feather-compound leaves four to eight inches long often subdivide into three to six side branches. They don't appear until late spring, and fall off in early autumn. The eight to 14 oblong, toothless, usually opposite leaflets grow 0.75 to 1.25 inches long. Dark green and shiny above, they turn yellow in autumn.

Racemes of small, inconspicuous, fragrant, yellow-green flowers, four to eight inches long, hang from the leaf axils in early summer.

In mid- and late summer, the flowers give way to long, flat, green seedpods, six to 16 inches long and one to 1.5 inches wide, with up to 20 flattened, ovate, green, bean-like seeds under 0.5 inches long. The bumpy, leathery, strap-like pods curve, twist partially, and turn dark reddish-brown in autumn, when a sweet, sticky, green-yellow, banana-scented pulp forms inside, and the seeds darken and harden.

•Tall street- and woodland tree with gray to blackish bark consisting of long, smooth, flat plates separated by furrows
•Clusters large, sharp, branched thorns, often grouped in threes, in some wild varieties
•Alternate, feather-compound leaves often subdivided into three to six side branches
•Small, oblong, toothless, opposite leaflets, dark green and shiny above
•Short racemes of small, inconspicuous, fragrant, yellow-green flowers hanging from the leaf axils in early summer
•Long, narrow, flat, green seedpods in mid- to late summer
•Up to 20 flattened, ovate, green, bean-like seeds inside the seedpods in mid- and late summer
•Long, bumpy, leathery, strap-like, curved, twisted, dark reddish-brown seedpods in autumn
•Sweet, sticky, banana-scented pulp inside the seedpods in autumn
•Up to 20 hard, blackish, ovate seeds inside seedpods in autumn

Pick the very young, immature, green seedpods from the branches within reach in early summer, or open them to remove the edible seeds in mid-summer.

Gather the brown, mature pods from the branches or from the ground in autumn. Harvest the hard, dark brown seeds for making coffee then too, if desired.

You can use the tender, very young seedpods like snow peas, cooked in stir-fry recipes, soups, or stews, early in the summer. After they've developed in mid-summer, the immature, green seeds taste like a combination of green peas and beans. You can eat them raw or cook them like green peas in any recipe where peas are suitable.

The sweet pulp inside the mature, reddish-brown seedpods smells and tastes like bananas. Although people used it in beer-making and to sweeten beverages, the pods are hard to split in half, especially in the northern states, and there's usually not enough hard-to-extract pulp to do much more than use it as a tasty trail nibble.

People have also roasted and ground the mature seeds, and used them as a caffeine-free coffee substitute.

Very few edible wild plants have enough calories or protein to make survivalists happy, but this tree is an exception. The seeds contain sugar, protein, and fat, as well as calcium, and phosphorus. The yellow-green pulp obviously contains sugar, but other nutrients in this and the remaining edible parts of the tree not been analyzed.

An infusion of the immature pods has been used of indigestion, measles, and nasal congestion, and its juice has some antiseptic activity. Since the immature pods are edible, this should be safe, even if it doesn't work.

An extract of the mature pods also showed activity against cancer cells, but with severe side effects. A decoction of the cambium has been used for whooping cough, measles, and smallpox, but it contains the toxic alkaloids gleditschine and stenocarpine, so these parts are off-limits as home remedies.

The black locust tree has similar leaves, but they're once-compound. Its edible flowers are fragrant, showy, and white, and its much smaller seedpods that aren't twisted.

The inedible ailanthus tree or tree-of-heaven has longer, pointed leaflets that smell like rancid peanut butter, and no seedpods.

The Kentucky coffee-tree has feather-compound leaves and reddish-brown seedpods containing a sticky, greenish pulp, but the tree's always thornless, the pods are short and thick, not long, flat, or twisted, and the dark brown seeds, which make an excellent coffee substitute, are much larger than the honey locust's. Although the pulp and raw seeds are poisonous, the two species are also easy to tell apart.

Wisteria has feather-compound leaves and seedpods, but it's a vine, not a tree, and has showy, edible, blue to violet flowers. Its short, bumpy seedpods are always green and never twisted. They contain no sticky pulp, and just one to three large, flattened seeds, which are highly poisonous. But with such great differences, you'd have to be more than careless to confuse these very different species.
Sweet Bean, Sweet Locust, Honeyshuck
This common native street tree has edible immature pods and seeds, plus sweet pulp in the mature pods that's good to eat right through winter.
Black Locust Tree, Ailanthus Tree, Kentucky Coffee-tree
Wisteria
Boiled Locusts
boiled-locusts

Serve this as a side dish, as you would cooked peas. These locusts are so good, I eat then any time I can, even though I’m a vegan!

2 cups vegetable stock, or as needed
2 cups green honey locust seeds or fresh green peas
1/2 cup dried kelp, soaked, rinsed, drained, and chopped finely
1 tbs. sesame oil
4 cloves of garlic, finely chopped
6 northern bayberry leaves or 3 bay leaves
1 tsp. oregano, ground
1 tsp. sage, ground
1 tsp. oregano, ground
1 tsp. dried epazote or tarragon, ground
1 tsp. Vege-sal or 1/2 tsp. salt, or to taste
1/4 tsp. black pepper, ground

1. Simmer all ingredients except the Vege-sal together 45 minutes or until the seeds are tender, adding more stock if necessary.

2. Remove the bayberry leaves and stir in the Vege-sal.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation/cooking time: 1 hour

The sweet, yellow-green pulp inside the long, flat, twisted, reddish-brown seedpod, smells and tastes like bananas. The oval, brown, inedible seeds are hard as a pebbles, but you can roast and grind them, and use them as a coffee substitute.
Szechuan Pepper
szechuan-pepper
Rutaceae, the rue or citrus family
The young leaves are in season in the spring, the berries in the fall.
In sun or shade, on fertile, well-drained soil, in woodlands, and along riverbanks
North Central States, plus parts of NY, PA, and extreme southern Quebec

Look for a shrub or small tree with gray to brown, smooth bark punctuated with mounds usually armed with paired spines, often forming thickets. The red-brown to gray branches are usually armed with opposite thorns and alternate, feather-compound, lemon-scented leaves consist of five to 11 small, elliptic, ovate to oblong, nearly stalkless, wavy edged or toothless leaflets. Loose clusters of small, inconspicuous, long-stalked, five-petaled, green flowers growing from the leaf axils, to be replaced by lemon-scented, spherical to ellipsoid, bumpy, long-stalked, red fruit capsules containing shiny, hard, aromatic black seeds.

The gray to brown, smooth bark of this shrub or small tree, which grows from nine to 18 feet tall, is covered with mounds usually armed with paired spines 0.2 to 0.6 inch long, as are the red-brown to gray branches. It sometimes forms impenetrable thickets.

The alternate, feather-compound, lemon-scented leaves grow up to one foot long, with five to 11 elliptic, ovate, or oblong, nearly stalkless, wavy edged or toothless leaflets 0.8 to three inches long and 0.4 to 1.5 inches wide. With an asymmetrical base, each leaflet is dull green above, paler beneath. They turn yellow in autumn. The side leaflets are stalkless. The terminal leaflet has a short leafstalk, and the older leaflets are peppered with resin dots.

A loose cluster of small, inconspicuous, five-petaled, long-stalked green flowers grows from the leaf axils in the spring. Highly aromatic, spherical to ellipsoid, bumpy, long-stalked fruit capsules 0.25 inch form from summer to fall. Green ripening to red, each fruit capsule contains one or two small, shiny, hard, black seeds.

•Shrub or small tree nine to 18 feet tall often forming thickets
•Gray to brown, smooth bark usually punctuated with mounds usually armed with paired spines
•Red-brown to gray branches usually armed with paired spines
•Alternate, feather-compound, lemon-scented leaves
•Five to 11 small, elliptic, ovate, or oblong, nearly stalkless, wavy edged or toothless leaflets
•Loose clusters of small, inconspicuous, long-stalked, five-petaled, green flowers, growing from the leaf axils, in the spring
•Highly aromatic, spherical to ellipsoid, long-stalked, bumpy fruit capsules 0.25 inch, first green, then red
•One or two small, shiny, hard, black seeds inside fruit
Strip off the young leaflets, or pick the ripe fruits with your fingers.

A signature herb of Szechuan cuisine, the toasted ground fruit capsules (without the gritty seeds) create a tingly, numbing sensation on the tip of the tongue, along with an overtone of citrus. They're best pan-roasted, ground, and added to soups, stews, tofu dishes, or mock fish dishes, at the end of cooking. Traditional companion seasonings include ginger, anise seed, chili peppers, black pepper, and garlic.

This spice is also big in Japan, where its called sansho. The Japanese also use the young leaves as a garnish, and sell a mixture of roasted, ground fruit capsules mixed with ground black pepper.

This herb is contraindicated for anyone with ulcerative colitis, peptic ulcers, ulcers of the digestive tract, and gastro-esophageal reflux. Since it's used to bring on menstruation, pregnant women should avoid it, even in Chinese restaurants. And don't touch your eyes after handling the shrub—it can be quite painful if you don't wash your hands beforehand.

This species certainly confused me—I knew it as a medicinal shrub called prickly ash for decades, and it too 28 years of foraging tours before someone finally revealed that it was identical to Szechuan pepper!

The shrub is not related to black pepper or hot peppers. And the related toothache tree (Z. clava-herculis), also sometimes called prickly ash, has larger leaves and similar medicinal uses to Szechuan pepper.

Devil's walkingstick (Aralia spinosa) is a small, spiny tree with feather-compound leaves and edible shoots, but the leaves are much larger, and the flowers and fruits are completely different.

If you eat in a Szechuan Chinese restaurant or purchase prickly ash in an herb store or online, you'll probably get the Chinese species (Z. bungeanum), but these two related shrubs have the same culinary and medicinal uses.

American Prickly Ash, Northern Prickly Ash, Prickly Ash Berry, Toothache Tree, Sansho, Chinese Pepper, Japanese Pepper, Aniseed Pepper, Sprice Pepper, Fagara, Nepal pepper, Indonesian Lemon Pepper, Tickle Tongue Tree, Angelica Tree
This major traditional medicinal tree provides a unique hot seasoning familiar to anyone who has tried Szechuan cuisine.

This shrub's smooth, gray bark, covered with pointed mounds ending in paired prickles, and the alternate, feather-compound leaves consisting of five to 11 elliptic, ovate, or oblong, nearly stalkless, wavy edged or toothless leaflets, make prickly ash distinct, even without the small, long-stalked, spherical fruits.
3)Szechuan Pepper Unripe and Ripe Fruit
3szechuan-pepper-unripe-and-ripe-fruit

These long-stalked, spherical, bumpy fruits—green at first, then red—grow in small, loose clusters. It's the ripe, red fruits you use as a spice, something the ant with a taste for Szechuan food clearly knows!

This prickly, many-branched, funnel-shaped, gray shrub, with feather compound leaves, provides small clusters of small, red, spicy fruits in autumn.

Szechuan pepper's gray trunk is punctuated with mounds tipped with paired spines, making this shrub or small tree unlike any other species. It makes me think of the hide of a stegosaurus!

5szechuan-pepper-seeds
These shiny, hard, black seeds are gritty, even when ground. It's the fruit capsule you use for food.
Szechuan Dressing
szechuan-dressing

This tangy dressing will zap your tongue with every bite of salad you eat!

2/3 cup olive oil
1/3 cup red wine vinegar
2 tbs. lecithin granules
2 tbs. mellow miso
1 clove of garlic
1 tsp. Szechuan pepper, ground, or to taste
1/2 tsp. marjoram, ground
1/2 tsp. rosemary, ground
1/2 tsp. tarragon, ground

Purée all ingredients in a blender.

Makes 1/2 cup

Preparation time: 5 minutes
Cuckoo Flower
cuckoo-flower
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

The basal leaves appear in early spring, and the flowers bloom from early spring through late spring. The seedpods ripen in early summer, after which the plant disappears until new basal leaves re-emerge in autumn.
Moist, sunny or partially shaded places such as in swamps, near springs, in wet meadows, and in openings in wet woods
Throughout the Northeastern US and all of Canada
Europe and West Asia

Look for an herbaceous, unbranched plant eight to 20 inches tall. It has upward-tilted, alternate, fern-like, toothless, feather compound leaves with two to six small, paired leaflets plus one larger terminal leaflet. A terminal raceme of relatively large, white, lavender or pink, four-petaled flowers forms around long, slender seedpods.

This mustard grows from eight to 20 inches tall, with a slender, erect, unbranched stem.

Distinctive, fern-like, upward-tilted, feather-compound, alternate leaves two to three inches long. Each leaf consists of two to six toothless, paired leaflets 0.4 inch long, plus one terminal leaflet. The similar basal leaflets are rounder, with a larger terminal leaflet, while the upper leaflets become increasingly narrow.

Blooming throughout the spring, lavender, white, or pink, four-petaled flowers grow 0.5 to 0.75 inch across, in a terminal raceme on top of the stem. After tiny seeds disperse from the long, slender seedpods in the summer, the plant disappears, although new basal leaves re-appear in autumn.

•Herbaceous, unbranched plant with smooth, erect stem eight to 20 inches tall
•Upward-tilted, alternate, fern-like, hairless, toothless, feather compound leaves two to three inches long
•Two to six paired leaflets 0.4 inch long per leaf, plus one larger terminal leaflet
•Basal leaflets rounded, upper leaflets increasingly narrow
•Terminal raceme of white, lavender, or pink, four-petaled flowers up to 0.75 inch across
•Long, slender seed pods containing tiny seeds

Sever the basal rosette from the roots by sweeping a pocket knife under the leaves. Collect the mature plant's flowers, leaves, and tender, upper parts of the stems that you can pinch off, using your fingers.
The whole plant is full of vitamin C, and it certainly provides other vitamins and minerals, although they haven't been analyzed yet.
Even though this isn't a native species, please don't pick it where it's rare, and collect just a small fraction of any stand.
Bittercresses (Cardamine spp.) such as hairy bittercress, also edible, have feather-compound leaves, but the leaves and flowers are much smaller than cuckoo flower's.

hairy bittercress

This delicate perennial has relatively large, long-stalked, four-petaled flowers growing on a terminal raceme. The long, smooth, slender stem supports upward-tilted, alternate, feather-compound leaves consisting of narrow, stalkless, smooth leaflets. The basal leaves are similar, but with rounded leaflets.
