Black Walnut
black-walnut
Juglandaceae, the walnut family or the hickory family
Ripe nuts fall to the ground mainly in mid-fall, although you may still sometimes find some that aren't rotten in late fall.
Rich, well-drained soil, deciduous woods, bottom lands, floodplains, residential streets, and urban and suburban parks.
Most of the eastern half of North America plus Utah, with similar edible relatives in the Southwest and West Coast.

Look for a large tree with dark brown, ropey bark, long, finely toothed, feather-compound leaves usually lacking terminal leaflets and inconspicuous, drooping, green catkins. The hard-shelled walnuts are inside a spherical, green husk in the tree or on the ground. Keep an eye out for old walnut shells on the ground.

This majestic tree, with a crown spread of 70 feet, grows 50 to 130 feet tall, with a trunk one to four feet in diameter, and no branches near the bottom. The dark brown, deeply furrowed, ropey looking, ridged bark creates diamond patterns. Wooly, whitish buds, rounded at the tips, grow from 0.33 to 0.5 inch long, at the tips of the stout, smooth, greenish brown to gray twigs.

The alternate, feather-compound leaves, one to two feet long, include ten to 24 lance-shaped, narrow, finely toothed, lemon-scented, unevenly-paired leaflets, each three to five inches long and about one inch broad, with pointed tips and uneven bases. Pale green above and downy below, but turning yellow in autumn, the largest leaflets grow toward the leaf's center, usually without a terminal leaflet.

In the spring, tiny, green, inconspicuous male flowers grow on long, slender, green catkins three to four inches long, hanging from the branches and releasing pollen into the wind just before the young leaves become large enough block it. The small, inconspicuous, green, pear-shaped, Y-tipped female flowers grow in terminal clusters of two to five at the tips of the branches then too.

Ripening in mid-autumn, the spherical, lemony-scented, semi-fleshy fruits two to 2.5 inches across, growing singly or in tight groups of up to four, look like crinkly, green tennis balls. As autumn progresses, the thick husk turns yellow, then blackens as it's consumed by insects. Inside the husk, a hard, furrowed black nutshell 1.5 inches across encloses the bilaterally symmetrical nutmeat, which looks like that of the commercial or English walnut (J. regia). Nutshell fragments persist on the ground under the tree all year.

•Tree 50 to 130 feet tall, trunk one to four feet across, and crown spread of 70 feet
•Dark brown, deeply furrowed, ropey looking, ridged bark with diamond patterns
•Lemon-scented, alternate, feather-compound leaves, one to two feet long
•Ten to 24 unevenly-paired, finely toothed, lance-shaped leaflets three to five inches long and about one inch broad
•Leaflets pale green above and downy below, with pointed tips and uneven bases
•Largest leaflets toward leaf center
•Terminal leaflet usually absent
•Tiny, green, inconspicuous male flowers on slender, drooping, terminal green catkins 3 to 4 inches long
•Two to five small, inconspicuous, pear-shaped, Y-tipped female flowers in terminal clusters
•Spherical, corrugated, lemony-scented, semi-fleshy fruits two to 2.5 inches across, solitary or in tight groups of up to four
•Fruit color changing from green to yellow to black
•Hard, furrowed, black nutshell 1.5 inches across, enclosing bilaterally symmetrical nutmeat

The husks can dye your hands brown for a few days unless you may wear rubber gloves, but if you don't remove the husks soon, the maggots that live in them will bore through the nutshells and ruin the nuts. Roll off the black walnut’s green husk underfoot on a hard surface such as a pavement, wearing old shoes. Some people strike the husk the butt of a baseball bat, and some cut a walnut-sized hole in a plywood board and whack the nut through with a hammer, so the husk remains behind. Others run over the nuts with a car, but this cracks the nutshells and reduces the nut's shelf life.

After the husk is removed, you can smash open the shell with a heavy rock on a level pavement, (so they don't roll away) or on a flat rock, pick out the moist nutmeat (bring a nutpick), and enjoy the nuts in the field. But if you take the nuts home and spread them on newspapers to dry out, their flavor and texture improves, and they'll no longer stain your hands. The dry nuts will keep indefinitely in their shells, but once you've shelled them, freeze any you don't use within a few days, so the perishable oils don't begin to become rancid.

A hard nut to crack, you can open the nuts at home with a heavy hammer, a vice or a heavy duty nutcracker (a regular nutcracker is too weak). I got mine from C.E. Potter, Sapula, Oklahoma 74066, (918) 224-0567. (A technophobe, Mr. Potter has no website or even voice mail!) Other black walnut crackers are available online too, but I haven't tried them.

Cover the nut with a clean rag before you crack it, or the pieces will fly across the room. Use a nutpick (also called a lobster pick), available in hardware stores, to remove the nutmeat.

Black walnuts taste stronger and richer than the commercial walnuts, a little like very savory commercial walnuts plus wine and mushrooms. Use the nuts raw, or roast them 30 minutes in a 300°F oven, shelled or unshelled, stirring occasionally. Add small amounts in cereals, granola, cakes, pies, pasta, pesto, stuffing, casseroles, or mixed into peanut butter. Too many may overpower the other ingredients, although mixing 1 part black walnuts with 3 parts commercial walnuts alleviates this problem. You can also grind raw black walnuts into a meal and add this to flour for any kind of baking.

Black walnut oil, which you can get by boiling the shelled nuts and skimming the oil from the surface of the water, is great mixed with milder oils in salad dressing, or for cooking, but it's labor-intensive to make, and I'd rather eat my hard-earned walnuts.

People have allegedly pickled the excess immature walnuts that the tree drops in the summer, to lighten its load (trees often begin with an excess of fruit, then drop some undeveloped ones to give the rest a better chance of developing fully), by boiling them in vinegar with salt and pickling spices, until a pin can pass through them. I've never gotten this to work, though. Perhaps it only works with commercial walnuts, which have thinner shells.

People have also tapped black walnut trees in early spring, like maple trees. You have to boil the sap to 1/4th of its volume to make the syrup—enough processing to destroy any nutrients—and you can't do this indoors without all the steam making the paint peeling off your walls!

Black walnuts are packed with important nutrients, including protein and carbohydrates; vitamin B1, B2, B3, and E; the minerals iron, magnesium, and potassium; and the fatty acids linolenic, linoleic, palmytic, stearic, and oleic acid.

Black walnuts contain alkaloids with demonstrated anti-cancer properties, although the research that led to this discovery were discontinued prematurely years ago when funding ran out.

A decoction of boiled husks, which contain tannin, juglandin, juglone, and juglandic acid, has been used internally to kill parasites. Someone should try it on a lawyer or politician to see if it works!

A compress of the decoction successfully treats athlete’s foot, ringworm and other fungal infections of the skin. It's also been used for herpes and eczema, although there's no convincing evidence that it's effective.

A decoction of the cambium has been used for diarrhea and to stop milk production, but it can cause vomiting, so it should be avoided. And an infusion of the leaves has been used to lower high blood pressure, something that could easily be tested with a blood pressure monitoring device.
The fresh husk of the black walnut will stain your hands brown for a few days, especially if you have light-colored skin, although swimming in a chlorinated pool speeds recovery.

The black walnut has similar-looking, edible close relatives that cover much of the US: The California walnut (J. californica) grows in southern California, while the northern California walnut (J. hindsii) grows in the northern part of the state. The Texas walnut (J. microcarpa), interbreeds with the black walnut in TX where their ranges overlap, and the Arizona walnut (J. major) grows along streams and washes in the Southwest.

Other related and unrelated trees with feather-compound leaves are easier to distinguish:

The closely related butternut tree (J. cinerea) resembles the black walnut tree, but this Eastern relative has light gray bark with flat ridges. There's usually a terminal leaflet, and the edible, green-husked nut is lemon-shaped, not spherical.

Hickory trees (Carya spp.), more distant relatives, have shorter feather-compound leaves with fewer leaflets, bark without large ridges and furrows, and smaller nuts with husks that partially split into four sections. Some, but not all species, have delicious nuts, although the nuts of one common variety taste worse than [-my] the school lunch I remember!

The unrelated Kentucky coffee-tree's (Gymnnocladis dioca) feather-compound leaves are twice-divided. This source of caffeine-free coffee has dark, grayish brown, scaly bark that develops deep furrows with scaly ridges, and its fruit is a thick, black, bean-like seedpod containing seeds.

The feather-compound leaves of the non-edible unrelated ailanthus tree or tree-of-heaven (Ailanthus altissimus) smell of rotten peanut butter, not lemons. They have terminal leaflets, rough, gray bark without ridges or furrows, and key-like samaras, similar to those of maple trees, instead of nuts.
Eastern Black Walnut
This tree produces a hard nut to crack, but the tasty nutmeat inside makes it more than worth the effort.
Butternut, Hickory Trees, Kentucky Coffee-tree, Ailanthus tree
Sweet Baked Bananas
sweet-baked-bananas

When I bought bananas after forgetting that I already had more than enough in the refrigerator, I had to do something to all this fruit. This tasty black walnut-flavored pudding-like recipe, which came to me while I was meditating, handily solved the problem!

8 bananas, sliced
1 cup apple juice
3/4 cup bread crumbs
1/4 cup black walnuts or commercial walnuts
1/4 cup raisins
1 tbs. red wine
1 tsp. lemon juice
1 tsp. clear liquid stevia
1/2 tbs. cinnamon, ground
1/2 tsp. nutmeg, ground

1. Mix together all ingredients.

2. Transfer to an oiled casserole dish and bake, uncovered, 1 hour, or until thickened and bubbly.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Baking time: 60 minutes
5)Black Walnut Tree
5black-walnut-tree
This large tree, with alternate, feather-compound leaves and dark bark, characteristically has no branches near the bottom.
1)Black Walnut Leaves and Fruit
1black-walnut-leaves-and-fruit

The black walnut tree's long, alternate, feather-compound leaves consist of many unevenly paired, lance-shaped leaflets with pointed tips and uneven, rounded bases. Tight clusters of a few spherical green nuts grow at the ends of the branches.
3)Black Walnut Flowers
3black-walnut-flowers

The black walnut's small, inconspicuous, green male flowers grow on long, hanging catkins, while the green, Y-tipped, pear-shaped female flowers grow in small clusters. Flowering occurs before the leaves are fully developed.
4)Black Walnut Husks and Shells
4black-walnut-husks-and-shells
You can roll the green, corrugated husk off the nutshell underfoot on a hard surface, and stain the sidewalk with the dye the husks contain.
7)Black Walnut in Nut Cracker
7black-walnut-in-nut-cracker

This heavy duty nutcracker, which looks like a relic from a medieval torture chamber, is great for cracking the hard, rough, brown, ellipsoid nutshell and get at the tasty, nutritous, irregularly shaped nutmeat inside.

There are other black walnut crackers on the market that may be just as good, but as a freelance environmental educator without extra funds to throw about, and not a consumer product tester, I've stuck with this one, which works quite well. I bought it from C.E. Potter, Sapula, Oklahoma 74066, (918) 224-0567. A technophobe, Mr. Potter has no website or even voice mail, but he does have an excellent device!
6)Black Walnut Tree Bare, and Bark
6black-walnut-tree-bare,-and-bark
This large tree, with dark, ropey bark, typically has no branches near the ground.
2)Black Walnuts in the Tree
2black-walnuts-in-the-tree

Black walnuts grow in yellow-green, spherical husks, in small clusters at the ends of the tree's branches. The long, feather-compound leaves, with pointed, finely toothed, elliptical leaflets usually have no terminal leaflet.
Butternut
butternut
Juglandaceae, the walnut family or the hickory family
Butternuts fall to the ground in late summer and early fall.

This tree grows in full sunlight in fertile, moist, well-drained soil, with little tolerance of shade. Look for it in forests of mixed hardwoods, along stream banks, near coves, on slopes and terraces, in open parklands, and around the talus (broken rock) of ledges.
Most of Eastern North America, excluding Florida and Louisiana

Just pick up the butternuts from the ground under the tree. If grass is hiding them, walk in a grid pattern to cover the entire area under the tree, shuffling your feet, to detect by touch those nuts you don't see. If the tree is healthy and weather conditions are decent, you can get a good crop every two or three years, with a light crop (sometimes none) other years.

The butternut has a light, sweet, smoky flavor. After you collect butternuts, don’t remove the husks, as some foraging authors suggest—it's a huge amount of unnecessary work. Dry the nuts in a food dehydrator—very inexpensive on eBay nowadays. The husks turn brown shrink to nothing, and the nuts ripen and improve in flavor and texture. The dried nuts will last indefinitely instead of perishing in two weeks, and, unlike with the fresh fruits, the husks won't stain your hands.

Although you can crack the shells with a large rock on a hard surface, or with a vice or hammer, a heavy-duty nutcracker works best (a regular nutcracker is too weak). If the butternut is too long to fit into the nutcracker, clip off the tip with kitchen shears, a wire cutter, or pruning shears.

I use a nutcracker form C.E. Potter, Sapula, Oklahoma 74066, (918) 224-0567. A low-tech person, Mr. Potter has no website or even voice mail, but his nut cracker is excellent, although I've heard that others are just as good.

Cover the nut with a clean rag before you crack it, or the pieces will fly across the room. Use a nutpick (also called a lobster pick), available in hardware stores, to remove the nutmeat. Freeze any nuts you're not going to use within a few days—their oil goes rancid quite quickly.

Native Americans roasted the nuts, boiled the crushed nutmeat, and skimmed off the oil that rose to the surface, which they used like butter, but this is labor-intensive, health food stores sell high-quality vegan butter substitutes, and I'd rather eat or cook with the hard-earned nuts.
Butternuts provide protein, iron, magnesium, and linolenic and linoleic acids. They have the lowest carbohydrate content of all the nuts, only 3%, ideal for people on a low-carb diet.

Native Americans used a decoction of the cambium as a laxative. Low doses are a safe and effective way to treat constipation, although it doesn't address any underlying causes. It was very popular in the 18th and 19th centuries, when constipation was a little-remembered major health obsession in the Western world. It's also been used for as a cathartic—part of a dated, heroic approach to herbalism, as well as for liver congestion, rheumatic and arthritic joints, headaches, and dysentery, but without supporting evidence.

A warm compress of the decoction was used to stop wounds from bleeding, and butternut oil has been used to treat ringworm and fungal infections. One of its constituents, juglone, is an antiseptic and fungicidal that also shows some anti-tumor activity.

Black walnut (J. nigra) leaflets are wider towards the base, whereas butternut leaflets are wider toward the center, and this close relative's leaves usually lack the butternut's terminal leaflet. The black walnut has a dark brown, ropey bark, and the edible nut is spherical, not oblong.

Hickory trees (Carya spp.), distantly related, have shorter feather-compound leaves with fewer leaflets and smaller nuts. The husks split partially into four sections. Many species have delicious nuts.

The unrelated Kentucky coffee-tree's (Gymnnocladis dioca) feather-compound leaves are twice-divided. This source of caffeine-free coffee has dark, grayish brown, scaly bark that develops deep furrows with scaly ridges, and its fruit is a thick, black, bean-like seedpod contains flattened, disk-shaped seeds, not nuts.

The feather-compound leaves of the non-edible unrelated ailanthus tree or tree-of-heaven (Ailanthus altissimus) smell of rotten peanut butter when crushed, not lemons. They have gray bark without ridges or furrows, and key-like samaras, similar to those of maple trees, instead of nuts.
White Walnut, White Walnut, Oilnut
This very tasty nut tree is in decline, but if you find one, you're in for a treat every few years.
Hickory Trees, Black Walnut, Kentucky Coffee-tree, Ailanthus
Date-Nut Ice Cream
date-nut-ice-cream

The subtle flavor of butternuts combined with sweet creaminess of dates creates a wonderful, healthful ice cream they don’t serve at Baskin-Robbins.

3-1/2 cups almond milk, oat milk, or soy milk
1 tbs. agar flakes
1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
1/4 cup canola oil
1/2 cup raw pignoli nuts or cashews
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin
1 tsp. liquid stevia
1/2 tsp. salt
1/4 tsp. ginger
1 tsp. vanilla
1/4 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1 tsp. freshly-grated lemon rind
1 cup butternuts or other nuts
3/4 cup dates

1. Mix the arrowroot and kudzu with the almond milk, bring to a boil over low heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes, or until the agar is dissolved, stirring often.

2. Purée half the butternuts and 1/4 cup of the dates in a blender with the almond milk and the other remaining ingredients.

3. Add the remaining butternuts and dates and blend on low speed until just chopped.

3. Pour into an ice cream machine and prepare according to the manufacturer’s directions.

Makes 5-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Freezing time: 3 hours
1)Butternut Tree, Nut, and Leaf
1butternut-tree,-nut,-and-leaf

The butternut tree's light gray bark, with flat ridges and shallow grooves, in combination with its wide, spreading crown, and the upright branches toward the top, helps you recognize this uncommon tree in the winter. The corrugated fruit is lemon-shaped. The feather-compound leaf includes opposite leaflets, the largest ones toward the center, and a leading leaflet.
3)Butternut Trunk
3butternut-trunk
The butternut tree's light gray, shallow-furrowed bark, with shiny, flattened ridges, forms irregular, diamond-shaped patterns.
2)Butternut Leaves and Fruit
2butternut-leaves-and-fruit

The butternut's finely toothed, alternate, feather-compound leaves have a large, distinct leading leaflet, plus paired leaflets largest toward the leaf's center. The green, lemon-shaped fruits grow in clusters. Dehydrated, they turn brown and reveal the wrinkles of the underlying nut shell.
4)Shelled Butternuts
4shelled-butternuts
The butternut's light brown nutmeat is shaped like a keeled shovel, complete with a handle!
American Beech Tree and Copper Beech Trees
american-beech-tree-and-copper-beech-trees
Fagaceae, the beech family
Most of the nuts ripen in mid-fall, although a few can be ripe in early fall, and you can still find some that haven't decomposed in late fall.
Sunny or shady habitats, deep, rich, moist, well-drained soils, forests, bottom land, upland soil, and park lands.

The American Beech grows throughout most of Eastern North America plus Utah, but not in Florida or southern Georgia.

The Copper Beach has been planted in parks throughout most of the US and southern Canada.
The American Beech is native, while the Copper Beach comes from Europe.

Look for a large, wide tree with a rounded crown, and stout, horizontal or ascending branches that often touch the ground. The American Beeches have smooth, light gray bark usually covered with graffiti and have small, short-stalked, soft-spined, four-parted burs. The medium-sized leaves are alternate, elliptical, short-stalked, waxy, sparsely toothed, shiny green above and light green below (or copper-colored).

This large, very wide tree, with smooth, light bark usually defaced with graffiti, grows 60 to 115 feet tall, with a spread of 50 to 70 feet, a dense, rounded crown, stout horizontal or ascending branches, and a trunk two to three feet in diameter. Some of the branches often touch the ground. Long, scaly, cigar-shaped buds, 0.5 inch long, stick out like thorns from the slender, zig-zag twigs from late summer to early spring.

Alternate, elliptical, short-stalked, waxy leaves, shiny green above and light green below (sometimes dark green or copper-colored in some cultivated European varieties), grow from two to five inches long and one to three inches wide, with 11 to 14 prominent veins, each ending in a sharp tooth. The leaf base is broad and it's tip pointed. The leaves, which turn yellow or brown on the American species, and copper on the Copper Beech, often persist through the winter.

Just after the leaves form in the spring, the yellowish male flowers grow packed into spheres up to one inch across, drooping from a hairy, slender stalk. The female flowers, 0.25 inches across, grow paired or in fours. Surrounded by reddish, hairy scales, you'll find them at the tips of short, hairy stems.

In autumn, a short-stalked, soft-spined, four-parted bur, 0.5 to 0.75 inch across, encloses two or three small, three-sided, shiny, brown, sharply angled shells, each containing a small, light brown, oily nut.

The tree produces deep shade, and has dense, shallow roots that absorb all the water under the tree, so no plants can grow under it.

•Large, wide tree with rounded crown, and stout, horizontal or ascending branches that often touch the ground
•Smooth, light gray bark irresistible to graffiti artists
•Long, scaly, alternate, cigar-shaped buds, 0.5 inch long, arranged in zig-zag fashion
•Alternate, elliptical, short-stalked, waxy, sparsely toothed leaves, shiny green above and light green below, two to five inches long and one to three inches wide
•11 to 14 prominent veins per leaf, each ending in a sharp tooth
•Leaf tips pointed, bases broad
•Leaves turning yellow (American beech) or copper (copper beech) in autumn, some persisting into winter
•Yellowish male flowers grow packed into spheres up to one inch across, drooping from a hairy, slender stalk
•Groups of two or four female flowers 0.25 inch long surrounded by reddish, hairy scales, growing at the tips of short, hairy stems
•Short-stalked, soft-spined, four-parted burs, 0.5 to 0.75 inch across
•Bur enclosing two or three sharply angled, three-sided, shiny brown nutshells
•One small oily, light brown, irregularly shaped nut inside each shell

Collect the nuts from the ground after they've fallen out of the husks, or remove the nutshells from the low-hanging husks by hand.

The flowers are usually damaged by early frosts, resulting in empty nutshells in the fall, so I've only been able to harvest beechnuts twice from 1982 to 2010, but the two good years provided very large crops.

Beechnuts are among the most delicious of nuts, tasting like a combination of hazelnuts and sunflower seeds. After you remove them from the husks, you can crack the thin shells open with your teeth, like sunflower seeds, or peel them with your fingernails. The nuts are great raw or roasted, shelled or unshelled. Add the shelled nuts to cereals, stuffing, pies, cakes, or other desserts, as you would other nuts. You can roast them before or after shelling in a preheated 300° F oven for 20 to 25 minutes, stirring occasionally.

You can store beechnuts unroasted and unshelled in a paper bag at room temperature for months. Once you crack the shells, oxygen in the air will make the oil in the nuts rancid. You can store the shelled nuts in a refrigerator for a couple of weeks, or freeze them for long-term storage.
Beech nuts provide protein, vitamins B1 and B2, calcium, magnesium, and iron, plus high-quality monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats.

Some beech trees may contain nuts with some tannin content, making them slightly toxic if eaten in large quantity. I've never come across this, as tannin is bitter, and all the beechnuts I've tried were sweet, but if you notice bitterness, soak the nuts in multiple changes of water to leach out the tannin until the bitterness is gone, or boil the nuts.

Be careful not to stumble over a young tree while collecting nuts from the vicinity of its parent tree. It might be a son-of-a-beech!

The American and European copper beech are very similar, and foragers can use them identically. The copper beech's leaves turn copper- or reddish-brown in fall. It's the species most commonly planted in parks, whereas the American species is more common in wilder forested areas.

American Beech: Carolina Beech, Gray Beech, Red Beech , Ridge Beech, White Beech

Copper Beech: German Beech, English Beech, Danish Beech, and French Beech
This tree has delicious nuts, but you only seem to get a good crop at most a decade.
Tex-Mex Beechnuts
tex-mex-beechnuts

I’ve been making lots of snack foods infusing seeds with spices before roasting them with more spices. This variant uses beechnuts with Tex-Mex seasonings, and it works quite well.

5 cups water
4 cups shelled beechnuts, sunflower seeds, or other nuts
The juice of 1/2 a lime
The grated rind of 1/2 lime
1/4 cup Tex-Mex Rub
2 tbs. Adobo Sauce, puréed
3 cloves of garlic, chopped
1/2 tbs. olive oil
1 tbs. Vege-sal

1. Simmer the seeds 15 minutes in the water with the lime juice, lime rind, garlic, and half of the remaining ingredients.

2. Drain

3. Mix in the remaining ingredients.

4. Roast in a roasting pan in a preheated 300 degree oven 2 hours or until dry and crisp, stirring occasionally.

Makes 8 cups

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 2 hours

Adobo Sauce
adobo-sauce

A little of this smoky flavored Mexican hot sauce, enhanced with wild herbs if possible, will spice up any recipe. And it lasts for weeks, refrigerated.

17 chipolte chilis, seeds removed
10 tbs. apple cider vinegar
1/3 cup ramp bulbs or shallots, chopped
1/2 cup fruit-sweetened catsup
1/4 cup mellow miso
4 cloves garlic, chopped
1 tsp. dried (or 1 tbs. fresh) epazote or tarragon
2 common spicebush berries or 1/4 tsp. ground allspice

2. Purée in a food processor.

American Chestnut Tree
american-chestnut-tree
Fagaceae, the beech family
Chestnuts ripen mainly in mid-fall.
Sunny or or shaded forests and thickets.

Stunted, diseased American chestnuts barely survive throughout Eastern America, whereas Chinese chestnut trees grow in cultivated areas. However, some American chestnut trees grow under cultivation on the West Coast, where the blight that affects the Eastern trees is absent. And some healthy trees grow in areas of the Midwest, outside the tree's historic range, where they've also been planted, and where the disease is less virulent.
American chestnuts are native. I'll let you guess the place of origin of the other species.

Use all chestnuts and their edible relatives the way you would use commercial, Asian chestnuts: Remove them from their husks and cut an “X” in the shells with a paring knife, so they won’t explode in the oven. Roast them at 425 degrees F for 15 to 25 minutes, or boil them about 25 minutes. Peel them and eat them as is, or include them in stuffing, cakes, puddings, ice creams, other desserts, or vegetable dishes.

Use all chestnuts way you use commercial, Asian chestnuts: Remove them from their husks and cut an “X” in the shells with a paring knife, so they don’t explode in the oven, and bake in a preheated 425 degrees F oven for 15 to 25 minutes or until fragrant and lightly browned. You may also boil them about 25 minutes.

Peel and eat them as is, or include them in stuffing, cakes, or vegetable dishes.

Chestnuts contain lots of calories in the form of carbohydrates, plenty of potassium, moderate amounts of phosphorus and calcium, and some protein and iron. They contain less oil than any other nut, and they’re easy to digest.

Native Americans used a decoction of the cambium as a cough syrup, and for whooping cough and heart disease. They also dried the cambium and used it as a powder for chafed skin. An infusion of the leaves was used both to calm the respiratory nerves and as an expectorant. However, there are indications that the herb is simply a mild astringent, and it's not used medicinally today.

Cultivated and abandoned Chinese chestnut trees (C. mollissima) and other close relatives grow in residential areas and woodlands throughout the United States. They're hard to tell apart from the native species, although they become full-grown trees, not sickly looking branches arising from stumps. Otherwise, the clearest difference is that American chestnut tree's twigs are hairless, and the other species' are hairy.

The Eastern chinquapin (C. pumila) is a shrub or small tree similar to the American chestnut tree, but no more than 10 to 25 feet tall. The bark is light reddish-brown, and the young twigs are densely hairy. Whitish and hairy beneath, the coarsely-toothed, alternate, lance-shaped, simple leaves grow up to 5 inches long and 2 inches wide. Tiny, inconspicuous, beige flowers grow on long, narrow spikes in the spring, and burr-like husks grow just under 0.5 inches across, smaller than chestnuts', with just 1 edible nut that's not flattened per husk. Growing in dry woods and thickets in the Southeast and north to NJ, they’re occasionally cultivated throughout the country.

The bush chinquapin (C. sempervirens) is a similar evergreen shrub of the Pacific Northwest, with one to three nuts encased in each spiny bur. All these species have edible nuts.

The chestnut oak (Quercus prinus) has leaves that look like the chestnut's, but with rounded lobes on their margins, not pointed teeth like the chestnut's leaves. And it produces edible acorns, but no chestnuts.

This rare plant, devastated by an early 20th century blight, bears fruit so rarely that it took me 28 years to find. The cultivated Chinese species that brought the disease, and the poisonous horse chestnut, are much easier to locate.
Chinese Chestnut
Horse Chestnut, Chinese Chestnut
Vanilla Cake with Chestnut Filling
vanilla-cake-with-chestnut-filling

Plenty of wonderful flavors, a rich texture, and healthful ingredients—what more could you ask for in a cake? This recipe has many ingredients, but preparing them is easy. If you want to impress guests who are used to eating conventional foods with how good natural eating can be, this one, filled with puréed chestnuts, takes the cake!

Cake Dry Ingredients

8 oz. buckwheat flour
8 oz. barley flour
2 tsp. xanthan gum
2 tbs. flaxseeds ground into 1/4 cup meal
2 tsp. baking soda
1/4 tsp. salt

Cake Wet Ingredients

2 cups almond milk or soy milk
3 tbs. lemon juice
The grated rind of 1 orange
3/4 cup lecithin granules
6 tbs. corn oil
2 tbs. vanilla extract
1 tbs. liquid stevia
The scrapings of 1 vanilla bean
1/2 tsp. common spicebush berries

Chestnut Filling Ingredients

2-2/3 cups cooked chestnuts
3/4 cups apple juice
1 tbs. tapioca flour
1 tsp. liquid stevia
2 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1 tsp. star anise, ground
1/4 tsp. powdered ginger
1/2 tsp. burn sugar extract (optional)

Lemon Frosting Ingredients

2-1/2 cups silken tofu, drained
1 cup pitted dates2 tbs. lemon juice
1/2 tsp. liquid stevia
12 tsp. lemon extract
2 tbs. lecithin granules
1/4 tsp. salt

1. Mix together the cake dry ingredients.

2. Purée the cake wet ingredients in a blender.

3. Stir the cake wet ingredients into the cake dry ingredients. Don’t overmix.

4. Transfer to 2 oiled cake pans and bake in a preheated 350 degree oven 20 minutes, or until an inserted toothpick emerges clean.

5. Transfer to racks to cool.

6. Meanwhile, simmer the apple juice with the tapioca flour 5 minutes, stirring often, then purée with the remaining chestnut filling ingredients in a food processor.

7. Remove the chestnut filling and purée all the lemon frosting ingredients in the food processor.

8. Spread the chestnut filling on one of the cakes, place the other cake on top, and spread the lemon frosting on top and around the sides.

Serves 8 to 12

Preparation time: 1 hour

Baking time: 20 minutes
3)American Chestnut Tree
3american-chestnut-tree
This small tree, albeit bearing fruit, is the best example of what used to be a magnificent, dominant forest tree I could find in 28 years of foraging tours!
1)American Chestnut with Nuts

The American chestnut tree's lance-shaped leaf is tipped with curved teeth. The bristly four-parted husk holds up to three small, but very sweet-tasting, nuts. Its round, flattened nutshell lacks the large, prominent white ellipse of the poisonous horse chestnut.
2)American Chestnut Trunk
2american-chestnut-trunk
The mature American chestnut tree has dark brown bark with widely-separated, shallow grooves, but this young one has bands of light and dark gray, plus large, white spots.
Gingko Tree
gingko-tree
Family: Ginkgoaceae—the gingko tree is the only living member of this otherwise-extinct family
Ginkgo nuts fall to the ground mostly in mid- and late fall, and sometimes some persist through the winter.

A relic from 200 million years ago and thought to be extinct since the Ice Ages, Western botanists were amazed to discover a few cultivated trees in temple gardens in China in 1690. Although they don’t grow in the wild any more, ginkgoes have been planted extensively in parks and along streets, where they need nearly full sunlight. Because their population was so low, and all other members of their genus and order are long gone, their parasites and diseases are extinct too. Only a relic fungus that decomposes the fallen leaves remains. So these trees always remain healthy under the most unfavorable urban conditions.
This living fossil grows under cultivation throughout North America and the much of the temperate world.

Ginkgoes are native to Laurasia, a supercontinent that no longer exists. Some ginkgoes grow wild in Southern China, but they're so genetically similar to cultivated trees that most botanists think these holdovers of the Triassic Period were introduced into the wild by the Chinese in ancient times.

Look for a slender, sparsely branched, columnar tree with gray, furrowed bark and alternate, fan-shaped, medium-sized leaves growing in clusters on short, thick, bullet-shaped twigs. Orange, spherical, fleshy, long-stalked, fruit under than one inch across hangs from the branches.

Or, even better, sniff for the fruit's smell of vomit and rotting flesh—detectable (but certainly not delectable) from a block away!

Growing from 65 to 115 feet tall with gray, furrowed bark, this tall, slender, straight, columnar, and sparingly branched tree's unique, short, thick, bullet-shaped twigs or spur shoots make it as distinct in the winter as the leaves do at other times.

The alternate, fan-shaped leaves grow in clusters on short branches or twigs, called spur shoots, along the longer branches, with leaf stalks about three inches long. These mostly notched or lobed leaves, which usually grow from two to four inches across, turn bright yellow in autumn.

Unlike any other living tree, the leaves' raised veins fan out into the leaf blade from its base, repeatedly splitting into two. These spreading, bifurcating veins look like the needles of an ancestral leaf that knit together, like a duck's webbed feet.

Tiny, inconspicuous, wind-pollinated flowers hang from the spur branches in short, narrow clusters early spring.

Ripening in autumn, the orange, spherical, fleshy, long-stalked, malodorous fruit grows to less than 1 inch across. Butyric acid (first discovered in rancid butter and present in decaying flesh and other disgusting objects) makes the fruit smell like vomit, and most certainly functioned as a very effective dinosaur repellent. The single, light brown, woody, thin-shelled, seamed, almond-sized nutshell inside each fruit encloses a soft, greenish, almond-sized, ovate kernel that’s wrapped in a brown, papery membrane.

•Slender, sparsely branched, columnar tree with gray, furrowed bark
•Alternate, fan-shaped leaves two to four inches across, growing in clusters on short, thick, bullet-shaped twigs
•Leaves turning yellow in autumn
•Raised leaf veins fanning out from the leaf base, repeatedly splitting into 2
•Tiny, inconspicuous, yellow, wind-pollinated flowers hanging in short, narrow clusters in the spring
•Spherical, orange, fleshy, long-stalked, foul-smelling fruit, growing less than 1 inch across, ripening on female trees in autumn
•Whitish, woody, thin-shelled, seamed, almond-sized nutshell inside the fruit
•One soft, greenish, almond-sized, ovate kernel wrapped in a brown, papery membrane, inside the nutshell

Collect gingko nuts wearing rubber gloves. Some people get a rash from touching the poisonous fruit, which also makes bare hands smell bad. Squeeze the fruit so the nut pops out. Leave the fruit next to the tree trunk, so other foragers won’t confuse it with unopened fruit.

Wearing rubber gloves, rinse the de-fruited nuts thoroughly in a colander, then roast them (the nuts, not the gloves) in an oiled baking dish in a preheated 300° F oven for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. The nuts are only edible cooked. Properly cooked gingkos are soft and rich. Undercooked nuts are hard and slightly unpleasant-tasting.

Because all its close and distant relatives are long extinct, gingko nuts taste different from anything you've ever eaten—like a combination of green peas and Limburger cheese—weird at first, then delicious, and perfectly suited to East Asian cuisine, where cheesy-tasting fermented foods are common.

Too delicate for a nutcracker, crack open the thin-shelled nuts with your teeth, like sunflower seeds, or tap them with an empty water glass. Eat them then and there, or add them to soups, stews, pilafs, stuffings, rice, stir-fry dishes, congee, and other Chinese or East Asian recipes. Combined with fermented-flavored brewer’s yeast or nutritional yeast, they’ll make any vegan dish taste like it contains cheese.

To store ginkgoes, freeze them before or after you’ve toasted them, but don’t store refrigerated for more than two days, or they may get as hard as rocks as they dry out. Briefly re-roast them to defrost, and they’ll be perfect.
Ginkgo seeds provide calories, protein, flavonoids, vitamins C, b1, B3, B6, and folate, plus the minerals copper, iron, magnesium, phosphorus, potassium, sodium, and zinc.

Gingko leaf extract contains many biologically active substances, such as antioxidant and anti-inflammatory ginkgolides, heterosides, and vasodilators. Extracts are prescribed by doctors in Germany for memory problems. Although recent studies on its effects on memory show mixed results, I know it how to make it improve memory without fail: Smell the stinky fruit just once, you'll never forget it!

Research shows that the extract is good for headache, tinnitus, intermittent claudication, and even depression, possibly because it improves blood flow in the arteries and capillaries. It’s also used for circulatory disorders, headaches, asthma, toxic shock syndrome, bleeding, bruising, asthma, heart and kidney disorders, glucose intolerance, and edema. It contains an analog of platelet activating factor, intervening in the formation of arterial plaques. And it destroys free radicals, which might make it lower the risk of cancer.

In Chinese folklore, the fruit is applied as a dressing for wounds. An infusion of the fruit is used for indigestion, and as an expectorant for asthma, bronchitis and tuberculosis. But the fruit is poisonous, both internally and externally, and it’s quite repulsive, so I don't think my advice to avoid it is even necessary.

Eating ginkgo nuts is considered very healthful in Chinese traditional medicine (and in Japan), where they're supposed to promote digestion and diminish the effects of excessive alcohol. The nuts may produce similar health benefits to the leaf extract, although this still awaits testing.

Gather the nuts before Asian families, who also appreciate this traditional delicacy and often sell the nuts, get to the trees first!

Collect ginkgo nuts wearing rubber gloves. Some people get a rash from touching the poisonous fruit, which also makes your hands stink. And don't eat ginkgoes raw—they're poisonous before cooking.

Japanese folklore advises eating no more than seven nuts at a time (stuffing eight into your mouth at once would also be bad manners!) I eat dozens with no ill effects, but I do know people who get headaches from eating lots of ginkgoes, and other ginkgo over-eaters experience shortness of breath, either due to an allergy, or from wolfing down too many nuts and neglecting to breathe. Eat very small servings the first time and gradually increase the amount.

Don't take ginkgo extracts if you're pregnant, nursing, or taking MAO inhibitors or blood-thinning medication.

Some ginkgo trees never produce fruit. Here's why—most modern plants have both male and female flowers on the same individual, but the ginkgo, which goes very far back in time, has separate male and female trees. And unlike human beings, it's the female of the species that has the nuts!
Maidenhair Tree
These tasty nuts, which taste like a combination of green peas and Limburger cheese, were rescued from extinction by ancient Chinese gardeners, and go back to the days of the dinosaurs.
Ginkgo-Stuffed Dosas
ginkgo-stuffed-dosas

You'll love these traditional Indian pancakes piled with a filling using ginkgoes instead of the traditional green peas, in a happy union of East-meets-East.

Dosa

4-1/2 cups (21.2 0z.) sweet brown rice flour
1 cup urad dal meal (available in Indian grocery stores or websites)
1/4 tsp. fenugreek, ground
1/2 tsp. salt
3 cups water, or as needed
1 tsp. sourdough starter

Filling

1/4 cup peanut oil or as needed
4 large potatoes, chopped
2 tomatoes, chopped
2 large red onions, chopped
2 inches of fresh ginger, chopped
2 green chilies, or to taste
4 cloves of garlic
2 sprigs curry leaves
1 tsp. fennel seeds
1 tsp. cumin
1 tsp. black mustard seeds
1 tsp. salt
2 cups cooked, shelled ginkgoes, or cooked green peas
1 cup fresh cilantro, chopped

1. Mix the rice flour, urad dal meal, fenugreek, salt, and sourdough starter with enough water to make a thick batter.

2. Cover and allow to ferment overnight.

3. Heat the peanut oil in a pan, add the fennel seeds, mustard seeds, and cumin, and cook, stirring constantly, until the mustard seeds pop.

4. Add the remaining filling ingredients except the cilantro and cook over low heat for 30 minutes, or until the potatoes are tender, stirring occasionally.

5. Meanwhile, cook the dosas on a hot, oiled griddle until lightly browned underneath, turn over, and repeat with the other side.

6. Pile the hot filling on the dosas and serve garnished with the cilantro.

Makes 20 dosas

Preparation/cooking time: 1 hour

Fermentation time: overnight
1)Ginkgo Tree, Leaf, and Bark
1ginkgo-tree,-leaf,-and-bark

The ginkgo is a tall, slender, columnar tree with gray, furrowed bark and fan-shaped, notched leaves that turn yellow in autumn. The leaf's raised veins, spreading from the leaf's base, repeatedly divide in twos.
2)Male Ginkgo Flowers
2male-ginkgo-flowers
The tiny, yellow, male ginkgo flowers grow on long, dense clusters in early spring.
3)Ginkgo Fruit and Nut
3ginkgo-fruit-and-nut
The foul-smelling, stalked orange fruit contains the white, almond-shaped nutshell.
Hazelnuts
hazelnuts
Family: Betulaceae, the birch family
Hazelnuts ripen in late summer and early fall.
Thickets, dry to moist woodlands, forest margins, roadsides, fence rows, and other disturbed areas
The American hazelnut grows throughout Eastern North America, but not in Florida, while the beaked hazelnut grows across the Northern US and Southern Canada, extending south only in mountains.
The American hazelnut is native, the beaked hazelnut is Eurasian.

Look for a smooth-barked, gray shrub, often in dense stands, with alternate, simple, toothed or double-toothed, rounded to nearly heart-shaped, medium-sized leaves. Straight, slender, drooping, regularly spaced, yellow-brown male catkins hang with bristly, paired, papery, coarsely toothed husks. These husks can be rounded or pointed, each surrounding a spherical, white, thin-shelled nut.

These spreading, smooth-barked, gray shrubs usually grow in dense stands reaching a height of ten to 20, with a spread of eight to 13 feet. Rough hairs cover the American hazelnut's (C. americana) twigs and leaf stalks, unlike the beaked hazelnut's (C. cornuta) smooth twigs.

Both similar species' alternate, simple, toothed or double-toothed, rounded to nearly heart-shaped leaves grow from two to six inches long.

In late winter or early spring before the leaves unfurl, straight, slender, drooping, yellow-brown male catkins, one to four inches long, regularly spaced along the branches in clusters of twos or threes, wind-pollinate the petal-less female flowers. Less than 0.25 inch across, the tiny female flowers' clusters of bright red pistils project in all directions from the tips of their ovate ovaries.

In late summer, bristly, paired, papery, coarsely toothed husks surround the spherical, thin-shelled, white nuts, 0.5 inch across. The American hazelnut's blunt, open-ended husk contrasts with the long, pointed beaked hazelnut's husk, which grows one to two inches long. A brown, papery wrapping encloses the white nutmeat.

•Smooth-barked, gray shrub ten to 20 feet tall, with a spread of eight to 13 feet, usually growing in dense stands
•Twigs and leaf stalks roughly hairy in the American hazelnut, smooth in the beaked hazelnut
•Alternate, simple, toothed or double-toothed, rounded to nearly heart-shaped leaves, two to six inches long
•Straight, slender, drooping, yellow-brown male catkins, one to four inches long, regularly spaced along the branches in clusters of twos or threes
•Crimson pistils projecting in all directions from the tips of the female flowers' ovate ovaries, which grow under 0.25 inch across
•Bristly, paired, papery, coarsely toothed husk surrounding a spherical, white, thin-shelled nut 0.5 inch long
•Brown, papery wrapping enclosing the white nutmeat
•American hazelnut husk blunt and open-ended
•Beaked hazelnut's husk pointed

Hazelnut bushes can produce good crops every two to three years, but I hardly find more than one or two nuts in the bushes or on the ground in my area (Greater NY), possibly because squirrels get them first.

Collect hazelnuts (wearing gloves for the bristly American species) a little under-ripe, before critters get them, and let them brown, dry, and ripen in storage.

These nuts taste even better than commercial hazelnuts. Crack them with a nutcracker and use them as you would any nuts, raw or cooked. You can also grind them in a food processor or blender and use the meal along with whole-grain flours in baking—especially good in pie crusts, pastries, and biscuits. Or grind them with some nut oil and salt in a food processor to make nut butter.

Hazelnuts provide vitamin A, B1, B2, B3, B6, C, E, and K, alpha carotene, beta carotene, folate, pantothenic acid, and choline. Minerals include calcium, copper, iron, manganese, phosphorus, potassium, selenium, and zinc.
Handle bristly American hazelnuts with gloves so they don't irritate your hands.
Witch hazel (Hamamelis viginiana) is an unrelated medicinal shrub with leaves similar to hazelnuts', but all its other features are different.
Filbert
These nuts are better-tasting than commercial hazelnuts, they're not sprayed, and they're free, something the squirrels in my area know only too well!
Witch Hazel
Czeck Rice Pudding
czeck-rice-pudding

Here’s a classic dessert that Czecks top with fresh fruit. Use fresh wild berries if they’re in season.

As usual with my vegan cooking discoveries, liquid stevia handily replaces sugar, and lecithin granules take over from egg yolks. Sweet brown rice, much more healthful than refined white rice, has just the flavor and texture qualities you want for desserts, and the flavoring extracts complement the traditional hazelnuts perfectly. Czech it out!

2 cups sweet brown rice
4 cups almond milk or other non-dairy milk
1/4 cup elderberries or other seasonal berries
1/4 cup raisins or currants
1/2 cup hazelnuts or almonds, chopped
1/4 cup lecithin granules
2 tbs. hazelnut oil or almond oil
1/2 tsp. almond extract
1/2 tsp. amaretto extract (optional)
1/2 tsp. orange extract
2 drops bitter almond extract or 1 tsp. almond extract
1/2 tsp. salt
2 cups of any fresh berries, or 2 cups of other chopped fruit

1. Mix all ingredients except the fresh berries and bake in an oiled casserole dish, uncovered, 2 hours or until all the liquid is absorbed and the pudding is lightly browned, in a preheated 400 degree F oven.

2. Top with the fresh berries or chopped fruit.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 2 hours

In late winter or early spring, this spreading bush looks yellow due to all the long, narrow, hanging, pollen-filled male catkins, while the crimson-tipped female flowers are only visible close-up.

The roundish American hazelnut shell, with its flattened, whitish circle, looks very much like commercial hazelnuts.
3)American Hazelnut Flowers
3american-hazelnut-flowers

The American hazelnut's male flowers (left) consist of long, brown catkins that release pollen into the air in late winter. The tiny, radiating, crimson stigma at the tip of the bulbous female flower (right) catches the pollen. It's so tiny, you need magnification to appreciate its beauty.
Hickory Trees
hickory-trees
Juglandaceae, the walnut family or the hickory family

Hickory nuts ripen from early- to mid-fall, although you can sometimes still find some intact nuts on the ground in late fall. A good crop occurs only once every two or three years for most species, which is why only the more reliable pecan is grown commercially.

You can find hickories in full sun or partial shade, in a wide variety of woodland habitats such as rich, open woodlands, bottomlands, dry, upland slopes, and on well-drained soil in lowlands and valleys.
Most hickory trees species grow throughout most of Eastern North America, but the pecan grows only in the Southern Mississippi Basin and the Southeast.

Look for tall, narrow trees with fragrant, alternate, feather-compound leaves consisting of five to seven opposite, lance-shaped to elliptical, toothed leaflets that turn yellow in autumn. Tiny, green male flowers hang from long catkins. Spikes of small female flowers grow from the branches' tips and spherical, green, four-parted husks contain ovate or rounded nuts.

These common woodland trees grow from 60 to 180 feet tall. Fragrant, alternate, feather-compound leaves with five to seven opposite, lance-shaped to elliptical, toothed leaflets that turn yellow in autumn, grow from eight to 30 inches long. In springtime, tiny, green male flowers hang from long catkins, while small spikes of female flowers hide at the branches' tips. Hickory trees drop nuts inside distinctive, spherical, four-parted green husks, 0.5 to 1.5 inches in diameter, in autumn.

We have about 24 species native to Eastern North America (one more grows in China!), too many to cover them all individually, especially since they can hybridize, but they're all similar enough for you to recognize them all as hickories. Many species have delicious nuts, and although a few have nuts too bitter to eat, none is poisonous. Here are a few of the most common ones:

Growing from 60 to 120 feet tall (sometimes up to 180 feet) with a straight trunk and cylindrical shape, the shagbark hickory's (C. ovata) light gray bark looks shaggy when mature, with long, flat, vertical slabs curling away from the trunk in long. This makes it one of the easiest trees to recognize, even in the winter. Eight to 14 inches long, the leaves usually have five to seven apple-scented leaflets four to six inches long and about 2 inches wide. The leaflets near the leaf base are the smallest. The male catkins hang from four to six inches long, while the female flowers grow on short spikes 0.3 inches long. The nuts grow singly or in twos or threes. As it matures, the spherical, thick husk, two inches across, changes from green to yellow-green, then to black. The thin-shelled, light tan, ovate nutshell, one to 1.5 inches across, encloses a sweet nut, which I think is the best of the hickories.

The less common shellbark hickory (C. laciniosa) is similar to the shagbark, but with less curly bark and nine to 17 leaflets per leaf, while the water hickory (C. aquatica), also similar, has seven to nine leaflets. Foragers can treat all three of these species identically.

The mockernut hickory (C. tomentosa), which usually grows 50 to 60 (sometimes 100) feet tall with a straight stem and a rounded crown, has dark-gray, tight, furrowed bark, creating a diamond pattern, and dense hair under the twigs. The leaves grow six to 12 inches long, with five to nine leaflets up to eight inches long. Their undersides and the central axis are densely woolly. The ovoid to ellipsoid nut, 1.5 to two inches long, has a thinner husk than the shagbark hickory, and a thick, hard (mockernut means heavy-hammer nut in Dutch), light tan, four-ribbed shell. The tasty nut is harder to remove from its convoluted shell than the shagbark, but quite tasty.

The aptly named pignut hickory (C. glabra) usually grows from 60 to 80 (sometimes 100) feet tall and ten to 40 inches wide, with a crown 25 to 35 feet wide, a cylindrical shape, gray-brown, shallow-ridged, furrowed bark creating a diamond pattern, and stout stems. The leaves grow eight to 12 inches long, with five to seven finely toothed, hairless, lance-shaped leaflets 2.5 to five inches long and one to two inches wide. The terminal leaflet is the largest. The male catkins grow in clusters of three from short spurs near the young twigs' tips. The thin, dark brown, pear-shaped husk grows one to two inches long and about 0.75 inch across, with a thick-shelled, somewhat flattened nut about one inch across inside. You’ll love the nutmeat inside, but only if you’re a pig! It's usually fiercely bitter, full of tannin. I’ve heard of a few individual pignut trees with tasty nuts, but I’ve never found one after 29 years of foraging in the Greater NY region, though you might fare better elsewhere.

The bitternut or yellowbud hickory (C. cordiformis) grows from 60 to 100 feet tall, with a cylindrical, irregular crown up to 25 feet wide, and a trunk 1.5 to three feet across, with shallowly ridged, gray bark, and distinctive, powdery, sulfur-yellow buds. The three to five inch long male catkins grow in threes. The leaf grows seven to 14 inches long, with five to nine sharply toothed, stalkless leaflets. Because the four narrow ridges of the husk's ridges extend from the outer tip inward to between 0.5 and 0.33 of the fruit's length, only the bottom half of the thin husk, which grows from one to 1.5 inches across, splits open, revealing a rounded, beaked, cream-colored, smooth, thin-shelled nut shell one inch in diameter, with a reddish-coated kernel, again way to bitter to eat.

The pecan (C. illinoensis) has dark, reddish-brown bark broken into vertical ridges. The leaves, 12 to 30 inches long, include nine to 17 lance-shaped, glossy, unsymmetrical leaflets with recurved tips. The oblong, smooth, thin-shelled nuts, over one inch long, have distinct ridges. The tree and tasty nuts quite similar to commercial pecans.

•Narrow trees 60 to 180 feet tall
•Fragrant, alternate, feather-compound leaves from eight to 30 inches long
•Five to seven opposite, lance-shaped to elliptical, toothed leaflets
•Leaves turning yellow in autumn
•Tiny, green male flowers hanging from long catkins
•Small female flowers on spikes, growing from the branches' tips
•Spherical, green nuts in distinctive, four-parted husks

Simply pick the nuts up off the ground while the husks are still green, and before insects or other critters get to them. You can pry the husks in the field or at home with your fingers or with a screwdriver.

If you want to eat the nuts in the field, place them on a hard, flat surface and crack them with a large rock. Be careful not to smash them to bits. If you bring a nutpick (also called a lobster pick), removing the nutmeat will be easier.

Store hickory nuts in paper bags until the husks dry and open, releasing the mature nuts. Unshelled nuts keep indefinitely.

You’ll need a large rock, hammer, vice, or special nutcracker to open the hard shell, and a nutpick to remove the nutmeat. I use a nutcracker from C.E. Potter, Sapula, Oklahoma 74066, (918) 224-0567. A low-tech person, Mr. Potter has no website or even voice mail, but his nut cracker is excellent, although I've heard that others are just as good.

Store shelled nuts, refrigerated, in closed containers and use them within a few weeks, or freeze them. Use them like any other nuts, raw or roasted. Add them to pies, cakes, pudding, granola, ice cream, salads, or stuffing, for example.

I've read that mashing and boiling nuts that are too bitter to eat releases high-quality oil you can skim off the water's surface. Since the bitter tannin is water-soluble and not fat-soluble, it can’t affect the oil. Great in theory, but after three hours collecting, de-husking, and smashing large quantities of bitternuts to bits with a mallet, and more hours of boiling and stirring, just a few specks of oil dotted the water's surface! I haven't tried this with the edible species—the temptation to eat or cook the nuts, rather than risk wasting them, is simply too great!

You can also tap shagbark hickory trees in late winter, like maple trees, boil down the sap to 1/40th its volume, and make a syrup that's like maple syrup, but with a smoked hickory flavor.

0.66 of the shelled nut’s dry weight is a high-quality, easily digestible oil, including the high-quality essential fatty acids shown to prevent heart disease. High in calories, hickory nuts also provide protein, carbohydrates, vitamins A and C, iron phosphorus, potassium, and trace minerals.

Although new growth of young leaves have been steamed to make an inhalant for headaches, and the cambium has been used for arthritis, internally as decoction and externally as a poultice, there's no evidence that it works, and it's not currently used in herbal medicine.

Of the many species of hickories, it's those with long, flat, curled strips of bark that provide the best nuts for foragers.

Hickory trees somewhat resemble their edible relatives, the black walnut tree and the butternut tree, but those have longer leaves with more leaflets, and their husks don't split into four (or any) parts.
Many hickory species provide the best-tasting nuts in the world in years when they're producing well.
Black Walnut, Butternut
Chocolate Hickory Pudding
chocolate-hickory-pudding

This pudding will show you how good desserts can taste without unhealthful conventional ingredients, and hickory nuts add just the right finishing touch.

3-1/2 cups almond milk or other non-dairy milk
6 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
3 tbs. lecithin granules
5 Medjool (soft) dates, pitted
2 tbs. vegetable glycerin
2 tbs. cherry juice concentrate
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia
1 tsp. vanilla
1/2 tsp. orange extract
1/4 tsp. salt
1/4 tsp. amaretto extract or almond extract
3 tbs. Dutch unsweetened cocoa
1 oz. dark unsweetened non-dairy chocolate
1/2 cup hickory nuts

1. Stir the arrowroot into the almond milk, bring to a boil in a heavy saucepan over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes, stirring often.

2. Meanwhile, place the remaining ingredients except the nuts in a blender.

3. Add the almond milk mixture and purée;, beginning on low speed and holding down the cover with a towel before increasing the setting to high, to avoid an eruption.

4. Serve hot or chilled, sprinkled with the hickory nuts.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 15 minutes
2)Shagbark Hickory Tree and Leaf Bud
2shagbark-hickory-tree-and-leaf-bud

The shagbark hickory is a tall, cylindrical tree with shaggy-looking, gray bark curling off the trunk in vertical strips, and no branches toward the bottom. The fuzzy terminal bud is much larger than the alternate side buds.
1)Shagbark Hickory Leaves and Nuts
1shagbark-hickory-leaves-and-nuts

The shagbark hickory's alternate, feather-compound leaves usually consists of five finely toothed, elliptical leaflets. An ovate, ribbed, light tan, hard-shelled nut, inside a thick, spherical, four-parted green husk, encloses a delicious kernel with whitish nutmeat in a reddish-brown coat.
4)Bitternut Hickory Tree with Nuts
4bitternut-hickory-tree-with-nuts

This too common tree has a trunk with shallowly ridged, gray bark, and distinctive, powdery, sulfur-yellow buds. Four narrow ridges of the husk's ridges extend from the outer tip, revealing a rounded, beaked, cream-colored, smooth, thin-shelled nut shell one inch in diameter, with an awful-tasting reddish-coated kernel.
3)Mockernut Hickory Leaf with Nut
3mockernut-hickory-leaf-with-nut

The mockernut hickory has leaves grow six to 12 inches long, with five to nine leaflets up to eight inches long, with a wooly central axis and undersides. The ovoid to ellipsoid nut, 1.5 to two inches long, has a thinner husk than the shagbark hickory, and a thick, hard, light tan, four-ribbed internally convoluted shell that makes the tasty nut is harder to remove.
Oak Trees
oak-trees
Fagaceae, the beech family

Acorns ripen from early- to mid-fall, but they're sometimes preserved through the winter, and you can also use the young, partially developed leaves of white oak trees for winemaking from early- to mid-spring.
Most oak trees grow in forests, thickets, cultivated parks, and along neighborhood streets. Gambel's oak grows in canyons, on dry foothills and and on lower mountain slopes.
Many species of oaks grow throughout North America, and much of the temperate world. The white oak and chestnut oaks grow throughout most of the Eastern US, while Gambel's oak grows in the Southwest.
Many native oak species grow across North America, but some European and Asian species are sometimes planted too.

Look for what are usually tall trees with simple, alternate, long-oval, blunt-edged or pointy tipped, usually lobed leaves and tiny yellow male flowers growing on long, narrow drooping catkins that hang from the twigs. Small, inconspicuous spikes of female flowers give way to ovate, thin-shelled, cupped nuts in autumn.

Long, lobed leaves and cupped acorns make these large, familiar trees, which grow from 12 to 120 feet tall, quite distinct. The simple, alternate, long-oval, blunt-edged or pointy tipped leaves are usually partially divided lengthwise into lobes.

Tiny yellow male flowers grow on long, narrow drooping catkins that hang from the twigs in early- or mid-spring. They release large amounts of highly allergenic pollen into the wind while the immature leaves are still too small to block it. The inconspicuous female flowers grow on much smaller spikes.

Ovate, thin-shelled nuts surrounded by cups ripen in autumn.

Oak trees generally fall into two groups:

1. The white oaks have blunt-tipped leaves. Their acorns take one year to mature, and the nutshells are hairless inside. Their acorns are usually the best to eat.

2. The red oaks have pointy tips on their leaves’ lobes. Their acorns take two years to mature, and the nutshells are hairy inside. Their acorns are usually much more difficult to process.

The acorns from trees within the white oak group are usually the best for foragers, although there can always be exceptions. This group comprises many species, often hard to distinguish from each other, and they can sometime hybridize. Here are a few of the best: [Again here I've grouped the information by tree]

The best-known member of the white oak group is the white oak tree (Q. alba) itself. It grows from 60 to 120 feet tall with light gray, somewhat furrowed, slightly scaly, flat-ridged bark, a rounded crown, and branches that extend horizontally. Dark glossy-green above, sometimes slightly downy underneath, the blunt-edged leaves grow from five to nine inches long and two to four inches wide, with seven to ten shallow or deep, even, rounded lobes. The male flower catkins grow two to four inches long, while the female flowers are short, single, reddish-green spikes. Long-ovate, light brown when mature, and with a bowl-shaped cup covering up to 0.33 of the nut, the usually stemless acorns grow less than two inches. It's nuts are wonderful when processed.

The chestnut oak or rock oak (Q. prinus or Q. montana) is a medium-size tree, usually 60 to 70 feet tall with a 60 to 70 foot spread. The thick, deeply furrowed reddish-brown to dark brown bark features long, tight ridges that make it look like alligator hide. With wavy margins, the coarsely toothed, elliptical to oblong leaves, dark green above and light green with fine fuzz below, resemble chestnut leaves. They grow five to ten inches long and 3 to 4.5 inches wide. The acorns, which grow singly or paired and reach one to 1.5 inches long, are enclosed by the cup that covers 0.33 of their length. These large, mild-tasting nuts are among the best for eating, and require little if any leaching.

The Gambel’s oak (Q. gambelii) is a shrub or small tree ten to 60 feet tall, with grayish-brown, scaly bark. Dark green and glossy above, lighter and softly fuzzy beneath, the leaves, which have seven to 11 moderate to deep lobes, grow from three to six inches long and two to three inches wide. The spherical acorns grow 0.5 to 0.75 inch long. Their cups enclose 0.25 to 0.75% of them, and they grow singly or paired. They contain so little tannin, some people eat the nuts unprocessed.

•Usually tall trees with long leaves
•Leaves simple, alternate, long-oval, blunt-edged or pointy tipped
•Leaves usually partially divided lengthwise into lobes
•Tiny yellow male flowers growing on long, narrow catkins hanging from the twigs
•Small, inconspicuous spikes of female flowers
•Ovate, thin-shelled, cupped nuts

Collect acorns from the ground as soon as possible after they fall, before they become infested with insects or begin to sprout. Discard any acorns with tiny holes, which will be infested. Insect infestation is greater in some regions, and during some years, than others.

To shell acorns, boil them 1 minute to loosen their shells, split them with a paring knife, and either peel off the shell with your fingers, or scoop out the nutmeat with a nutpick or a grapefruit spoon. Discard any that have rotten sections inside. There's also an acorn sheller you can buy.

Acorns usually contain too much tannin to eat as is, especially the red oak species, but this bitter substance, which becomes toxic if ingested repeatedly, is water-soluble. You can either leach out the tannin or boil it away.

To leach the tannin out, 1 way is to chop the shelled acorns to the size of rice grains in a blender with enough water to grind evenly first. This increases the acorns' surface area and speeds up the process.

Native Americans tied acorns into a weighted sack and submerged this in a river or stream—one way to do cold-water leaching. This clears the tannin in 2 weeks, even with high-tannin red oak acorns. They'd also bury red oak acorns and leave them for months, which reportedly worked.

Don't have an unpolluted river handy? Some toilets have a tank of clean water well above the toilet bowl—ideal for leaching acorns. Unfortunately, the tannin will blacken the toiled bowl. For some reason, my wife, who's as much into home remodeling as foraging, isn't thrilled with this method, but if The Home Decorating Channel ever comes up with an Elegant Primitive Living series, I may yet get my chance. (I could try it anyway, and if she complains, just explain that I forgot to flush!)]

Another method consists of submerging the chopped acorns in a large bowl of cold water for a few hours, than rinsing and replacing the water until the acorns no longer taste bitter, and there isn't enough tannin being produced to turn the water brown anymore. This can take many days or even weeks with low-tannin white oak acorns, and months or more with high-tannin red oaks.

Hot water leaching if faster: Boil the chopped acorns for 20 to 60 minutes, rinse, and re-boil repeatedly until the acorns no longer taste bitter and there isn't enough tannin left to turn the water brown. The last time I did this with white oak acorns, it took the better part of a day, but it was well worth it.

Although hot-water leaching is faster for low-tannin acorns (it didn't work for me with red oak acorns, even after days of boiling), it removes the acorns' starch, and hence their ability to gel, a property used to make a Korean pudding called dotorimuk.

After 29 years of leading foraging tours, I found a 3rd way to leach much of the tannin out of high tannin red oak acorns: just let winter do most of the work for you! White oak acorns are very perishable, even in the refrigerator, but red oak acorns seem to last much longer. Thus, when my tour participants and I tasted some red oak acorns recently released from the ice and snow of an exceptionally cold and snowy winter (early March in southern Connecticut in 2011), we could barely detect the tannin, and a little boiling should have leached out the remainder. This probably doesn't always work, but if you find acorns that haven't gone bad at the end of winter, give them a try.

With the nutty flavor and texture of chestnuts but less sweet, leeched acorns make a versatile culinary ingredient. Native Americans discovered that they're an excellent addition to soups and stews. You can use them in mock meat loaves and stuffing too.

I've boiled them in water with curry powder, lemon juice, garlic, seasoned salt, chili paste or hot sauce, and a little olive oil; drained them, added more curry powder, seasoned salt, lemon juice, olive and chili paste, then baked them in a roasting pan until chewy. I call these curried acorns Park Nuts.

You can dry leached acorns in a food dehydrator, then grind them into a powder in a blender or spice grinder. They make an excellent flour—nutty flavored and hearty. The flour doesn't rise, but you can mix it with flours that do, or use it in recipes that don't need leavening, like crepes, sauces, or flatbreads.

In addition to the nuts, young, partially developed white oak leaves make an outstanding wild wine, and you can roast the leached acorns until black, grind them, and use them to make a coffee substitute.
Acorns provide protein, fat, vitamind B3 and B6, folate, and pantothenic acid, plus the minerals calcium, magnesium, potassium, zinc, copper, and manganese.

Native Americans and Europeans made a bitter decoction from the white oak’s cambium and use it for diarrhea, as a gargle for sore throat, and as a douche for yeast infections. It’s a good wash for skin ulcers, ringworm, and other fungal skin infections, and a cold compress is good for cuts and burns. People have also inhaled the dried, powered cambium like snuff for nosebleeds.

Most acorns contain the bitter polyphenolic compound tannin, as well as gallic acid and ellagitannin. Tannin is astringent, antiseptic and anti-viral, with both anti-tumor and carcinogenic activity. Although present in commercial Chinese tea, long-term intake is unhealthful—contributing to constipation and interfering with calcium absorption. Prolonged high doses can cause kidney damage. Make sure you've prepared acorns as directed, and that you've removed this easily detectable, bitter-tasting substance when present.

The group of oak species with blunt-tipped leaves is called the white oak, and within that group there's also a species called the white oak. It's helpful to differentiate between the group and the species that share the same name.
1)"Wildman's" Acorn Bread
1wildmans-acorn-bread

Acorns give this bread a wonderfully soft texture, dark color, and an overtone of nuttiness that fit perfectly with the blend of herbs, whole grains, and my radical innovations for making vegan breads. The result is one of the tastiest breads I’ve ever come up with.

To Blend

3-1/4 cups lukewarm almond milk or other non-dairy milk
2 tbs. yeast
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/4 cup olive oil
2 cloves of garlic

Dry Ingredients

1/2 lb. each acorn, barley, oat, and sweet brown rice flour
2 tbs. flax seeds, ground into 1/4 cup meal
2 tsp. guar gum
2 tsp. rosemary, ground
1 tsp. marjoram, ground
2 tbs. caraway seeds
2 tbs. Vege-sal or 1 tsp. salt

Other Ingredients

2 tbs. olive oil
1 tsp. paprika

1. Mix the yeast into the almond milk and allow to dissolve 5 minutes.

2. Meanwhile, mix the dry ingredients together

3. Purée; the ingredients to blend in a blender along with the almond milk mixture.

4. Mix 1/3 of the dry ingredient mixture with the wet ingredients and allow to sit, loosely covered, in a warm place for 1 hour.

5. Mix in the remaining dry ingredients, transfer to 2 oiled bread pans, shape into loaves, smooth the top surface with a spatula, brush on the remaining olive oil, sprinkle with the paprika, cover loosely, and keep in a warm place for 2 hours.

6. Bake in a preheated 350 degree oven, along with a pan of water to keep the bread from getting too crusty, 55 minutes, or until an inserted cake tester or toothpick emerges clean.

7. Cool on racks

Makes 2 loaves

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Rising and baking time: 4 hours
2)White Oak Wine From The Wild Vegan Cookbook by "Wildman" Steve Brill
2white-oak-wine-from-<i>the-wild-vegan-cookbook<i>

Here’s one of the weirdest wild food experiments I’ve ever conducted, making wine from oak leaves. I was completely astonished when it resulted in a superb wine that you can use as a table wine, in place of white wine, or for virtually any savory recipe that calls for wine. The flavor is robust but not overpowering, and it's very satisfying. The secret is using very young white oak leaves, before they develop a high tannin content.

1 gallon boiling water
1 gallon immature white oak tree leaves or leaves of other members of the white oak group, gathered just before the leaves have reach full size.
7 cups sugar
The juice of 1 lemon
1/4 cup juniper berries
1/4 cup fennel seed
1/4 cup celery seed
1/2 tsp. champagne yeast or other wine yeast

1. Dissolve the sugar in the water in a non-metal (plastic or ceramic) food container and add the oak leaves and spices.

2. When cooled to lukewarm, stir in yeast and cover with a non-airtight cover, cheesecloth, or towel.

3. Allow to ferment a week at room temperature, stirring twice a day.

4. Strain through a cheesecloth, transfer the liquid to a jug, and seal with an airlock stopper (which lets carbon dioxide bubbles escape but keeps oxygen out.)

5. When fermentation ends a few weeks later, seal the jar with stopper and age 2 to 6 months (taste it to determine if it’s ready) before using.

6. Siphon the wine to get rid of the sediment if desired.

Makes 1 gallon

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Fermentation time: 2 months to 6 months

The white oak tree is a large, spreading tree with horizontal branches and light gray bark. The olive-brown ovate acorn, here without its cup, has a flat top and pointed base.

Like other oaks, the red oak's (Q. rubra) tiny, male flowers (left) grow without petals on long, pendant catkins, where they release large volumes of pollen into the wind. This northeastern species, with pointy tipped leaves, has acorns with a very high tannin content that require weeks of leaching.

The white oak tree (Q. alba), on the other hand, has blunt-tipped leaves (right), although the flowers are similar. This species requires much less processing, and at this stage, the immature leaves are perfect for wine-making!
