These long leaves, with rounded lobes, are a sure feature of the white oak tree, the most common of the white oak group in the East. This one will have relatively easy acorns to process.
Hog Peanut
hog-peanut
Family: Fabaceae, the pea or legume family

The tubers are edible from fall through early spring, although when there's no foliage in the winter and the ground is frozen, you're not going to be able to find them or get at them. The pods are in season in the summer.
Partially sunny, rich soil, open woods, thickets, trailsides, floodplains, and along streams, and in soggy thickets, damp sandy meadows, and seeps
Eastern North America

Look for a slender, sparsely branched, hairy, twining vine with alternate, palmate-compound leaves arising from a long, slender leaf stalk. The leaves are comprised of three oval, short-pointed, toothless leaflets. Racemes hang from the leaf axils with small, pale purple or white, bilaterally symmetrical, tubular, five-petaled, pea-like flowers. Small, flattened, green seedpods arise from the leaf axils among tangled masses of threadlike, creeping runners.

This a slender, sparsely branched, hairy, twining vine grows two to eight feet long.

Its alternate, palmate-compound leaves arise from a slender leafstalk two to six inches long, with a pair of stipules less than 0.25 inch long at the leaf stalk base. The leaves include three oval, short-pointed, toothless leaflets. The center leaflet, which grows from 2.25 to four inches long, has a 0.75 in inch long stalk, while those of the two slightly smaller side leaflets are 0.125 inch long.

The plant produces two kinds of flowers and two kinds of seeds.

1. Above ground, racemes hanging from the leaf axils bear two to 15 small, pale purple or white, bilaterally symmetrical, tubular, five-petaled, pea-like flowers up to two inch across, that bloom from summer to early fall. They develop into small, flattened, green seedpods one to 1.5 inches long, each containing one to four tiny seeds.

2. Additional tiny petal-less blossoms arise from the roots on threadlike, creeping runners. These hidden, self-fertilizing, petal-less flowers become single-seeded pods that soon disappear, releasing light brown, discoid, peanut-flavored seeds up to 0.5 in diameter, each with a tough outer coating. They grow among masses of white stringy vines entangled along the ground, just under the leaf litter.

•Slender, sparsely branched, hairy, twining vine
•Alternate, palmate-compound leaves arising from a slender leaf stalk two to six inches long
•Leaves comprised of three oval, short-pointed, toothless leaflets
•Central leaflet the largest, with the longest leafstalk
•Above ground racemes hanging from the leaf axils
•Racemes with two to 15 small, pale purple or white, bilaterally symmetrical, tubular, five-petaled, pea-like flowers up to two inch across
•Small, flattened, green seedpods one to 1.5 inches long, arising from leaf axils
•Each seedpod containing one to four tiny seeds,
•Tangled masses of threadlike, creeping runners at ground level
•Light brown, discoid seeds up to 0.5 in diameter. growing from runners
•Seed with a tough outer coating

Look for this plant where the tangle of vines is most dense, pull up the vines, and pick off the tubers with your fingers. It will take quite a bit of time to collect enough tubers for a recipe, but with some patience and persistence, and a spot where the vine is doing especially well, it can be done.

Soak the underground seeds, which taste like a combination of green peas and peanuts, to loosen the tough outer coating (or just rub of the coating), and use them like peas or beans. Sweeter than commercial beans, you can eat them raw, add them to salads, or cook them about 10 minutes, like fresh commercial peas.

You can also eat the young pods while they’re still tender enough to pinch through, although they’re so small, it's hard to collect more than what you could use as a trail nibble. You could also cook their seeds like peas and bequeath them to your grandchildren, since you'll probably die of old age before you can collect enough to use them yourself!
The underground seeds are high in protein, 25%. There's no analysis of other nutrients.

The groundnut's (Apios americana) vine's compound leaves consist of 5 leaflets. It's reddish-brown flowers are less cylindrical, and it has large, edible, underground tubers. Other leguminous vines have differently shaped flowers and leaflets.
Poison ivy often grows as a vine and also has a three-parted compound leaf, but it's much larger, robust and hairy, not slender and delicate. You'd have to be especially careless to confuse the two.
This legume has edible tubers, although they're so small, they're only worth collecting under exceptionally favorable conditions.
Groundnut
1)Hog Peanut Vine with Seed

The hog peanut is a slender, twining vine with a long-stalked, three-parted, palmate-compound leaf. The leading leaflet is the largest, with the longest leafstalk. The flattened, ovate seed tastes like a combination of a green pea and a peanut.

This tiny seedpod, which contains one to four small seeds, is edible when very young, and the tiny seeds inside are edible too, while they're tender.
Hog Peanut Stew
hog-peanut-stew

This recipe has neither hogs or peanuts, but its hog peanut seeds optimize this synthesis of Eastern and Western ingredients. Serve it with brown rice or noodles.

2 cups hog peanuts, or mung beans that have soaked overnight or steeped 1 hour and drained
2 red onions, chopped
4 cloves of garlic, chopped
2 cups kombu, soaked 15 minutes, drained, and rinsed (a seaweed available in Chinese grocery stores and websites, and in health food stores)
2 cups zucchini, chopped
1/2 cup pickled bamboo shoots
2 tsp. sage, ground
1 tsp. black mustard, ground
1 tsp. cumin, ground
3 tbs. sesame oil
2 tbs. tamari soy sauce

1. Simmer all ingredients 20 minutes (or 45 minutes if you're using mung beans instead of hog peanuts), or until the seeds and onions are tender.

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Yellow Watercress
yellow-watercress
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family
You can collect this plant from mid-spring through late fall, but it's at its best when you can collect young leaves, in the spring, and from mid- to late fall.

Sunny, flood-prone disturbed areas, wet lawns, and meadows, muddy borders of ponds and small rivers, marshes, openings in floodplain woodlands, sloughs in prairies or meadows, poorly drained fallow fields, and ditches
Throughout North America
One of our most cosmopolitan species, this native of both North America and Eurasia also grows in Australia and South America, where it's been introduced.

Look for dense stands of this small to medium-sized hairless plant in sunny, wet places, with its strongly furrowed or ribbed stems. It has long, narrow, feather-compound leaves progressively smaller going up the stem, and terminal racemes of tiny flowers with four yellow, spoon-shaped petals and four yellow-green sepals. Hairless, green, cylindrical, sausage-shaped seedpods flattened on both ends, growing farther down the raceme, on long seed stalks.

With light green to reddish green, smooth, strongly furrowed or ribbed, branched or unbranched stems, and forming dense stands, this variable plant, which may be an annual or biennial, grows from one to three feet tall (or as short as eight inches on wet lawns that get mowed), arising from a shallow, branching taproot.

The long, narrow, feather-compound leaves grow up to 7 inches long and 2 inches wide, becoming progressively smaller going up the stem. They're variably lobed: oblong, oval, or lance-shaped. The lower leaves have stout leafstalks, the upper leaves have close to none. The variable leaf tips may be pointed or blunt.

The upper stems end with racemes four to ten inches long. Flowers not much more than 0.125 inch across, with four yellow, spoon-shaped petals surrounded by four green-yellow sepals, grow at each raceme's tips. Hairless, green, cylindrical, sausage-shaped seedpods 0.33 inch long, flattened on both ends, grow farther down, each on a seed stalk 0.5 inch long. Two rows of tiny seeds grow inside the pod.

•Herbaceous plant of wet, sunny places, eight inches to three feet tall
• Light green to reddish green, smooth, strongly furrowed or ribbed stems,
•Plant forming dense stands
•Long, narrow, feather-compound leaves grow up to seven inches long and two inches wide, becoming progressively smaller going up the stem
•Leaves variably lobed: oblong, oval, or lance-shaped
•Lower leaves with stout leafstalks, upper leaves nearly stalkless
•Terminal racemes four to ten inches long
•Flowers growing at each raceme's tips
•Flowers not much more than 0.125 inch across, with yellow, spoon-shaped petals surrounded by four yellow-green sepals
•Hairless, green, cylindrical, long-stalked, sausage-shaped seedpods 0.33 inch long, flattened on both ends, growing below the flowers
•Two rows of minute seeds inside each pod
•Shallow, branching taproot
Pinch or strip off young leaves, or pinch off the stems or tops of stems where they're tender enough to do so, with your fingers.

This flavorful, spicy wild vegetable tastes a lot like watercress. The younger leaves and flowering tops are the best. Older leaves are somewhat bitter, but still good.

Add any tender parts raw to salads and sandwiches, or cook 5 to 10 minutes in soups, sauces, casseroles, or other vegetable dishes and entrées. Because of the strong flavor, it's especially good combined with bland foods such as potatoes, tofu, or pasta, but it will hold its own in spicy dishes too.
Avoid collecting where the water's polluted. If there's any possibility of parasites, cook the plant.

Other common yellow cresses (Rorippa spp.), which grow in the same kinds of habitats as yellow watercress, are quite similar to this plant, but their flowers are either larger or smaller. Fortunately, they're all edible and tasty, and you use them the same way.
Marshcress, Bog Marshcress, Bog Yellowcress, Common Yellowcress, Marsh Yellowcress
This mustard of wet, sunny places makes up in flavor what it lacks in size. You often find it in dense stands, so collection can be quick.
2)Yellow Watercress Stand

This hairless, herbaceous plant, which grows in dense stands in wet, sunny places, has shallow-toothed, alternate, feather-compound leaves, and terminal racemes of four-petaled, yellow flowers. Beneath the flowers grow long, slender seed pods with long seed stalks.

Young yellow watercress' delicate-looking feather-compound basal leaves' leaflets are variably toothed or lobed.
Curried Yellow Watercress
curried-yellow-watercress

This wild vegetable has such as strong flavor that it hold its own in an intense curry dish, with wonderful results. Serve with clear noodles or brown rice.

1/4 cup peanut oil
2 tbs. dark sesame oil
2 cups yellow watercress, chopped
2 cups bok choy (Chinese cabbage) or red cabbage, chopped
1 package soft tofu, drained and diced

Sauce

1-1/2 cups water
2 tbs. peanut butter
1 tbs. Panang curry paste or curry powder, or to taste
2 tbs. soy mayonnaise
2 tsp. arrowroot
1 tbs. lemon juice

1. Mix all sauce ingredients together.

2. Successively stir-fry (cook over high heat, stirring constantly) the bok choy with the yellow watercress, then the tofu, in a wok or large frying pan, using half the oils at a time.

3. Add the sauce, bring to a boil, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 30 minutes
3)Yellow Watercress Flowers
3yellow-watercress-flowers

Yellow watercress flowers, with four yellow, spoon-shaped petals and four green-yellow sepals, grow at the ends of terminal racemes. Below them grow the long, narrow, long-stalked seed pods, flattened on both ends.
Wild Radish
wild-radish
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

The best time for the young greens is in mid-spring, and fall if new greens are coming up. Older leaves are coarse and bitter.

The flowers and the tender, young seedpods are in season from mid- to late summer, and the taproot's good to eat in the spring and fall.
Sunny, dry, and sandy soil, disturbed habitats, neglected gardens, roadsides, and fields—both inland and near the seashore, and in orchards
Most of the US and most of southern Canada
Eurasia

Look for a medium-sized, erect, coarsely hairy plant, usually branching toward the top, with elliptical, lobed or feather-compound basal leaves and similar, alternate stem leaves; stalked, four-petaled, white, yellow, or pale purplish pink flowers, sometimes darkly veined, at the tips of terminal racemes; and long, nearly straight, beaked, segmented seedpods containing for to ten minutes, round to ovate seeds. Feel for the texture of sandpaper.
Strip off the young leaves, flowers, and seedpods with your hands or fingers, and dig up the taproot with a shovel if you can't pull it up.

This spicy plant tastes like commercial radishes. Too hairy to enjoy raw, you can cook the pungent young leaves in soups and stews. Parboil them for a minute if they're too strong-tasting for you. The old leaves are too bitter and coarse to eat.

The flowers and the tender, young seedpods make great garnishes, and you can also cook them in any savory recipe. It takes 5 to 10 minutes.

The roots have a hard rind that you must peel off. The tender core tastes like turnips, edible sliced raw into salads or cooked 10 to 15 minutes in a wide variety of appropriate dishes that include vegetables. The seeds, while edible, are too small for practical use.

Commercial radishes, especially the leaves, are a good source of vitamin A, B1, B2, B3, B5, B, C, K, and folate, and as well as the minerals calcium, iron magnesium, manganese, phosphorus, potassium, and sodium, plus the trace minerals copper, fluoride, selenium, and zinc. They're a good source of protein, carbohydrate, and omega-3 and -6 fatty acids. It stands to reason that wild radishes provide the similar nutrients, possibly in higher concentrations. As a member of the mustard family, the wild radish probably contains beneficial antioxidants too.
Wild radish was supposed to be good for arthritis—taken internally and applied externally in ancient Egypt, when it was very popular, but not currently used medicinally.
Eating the leaves of this plant can make you very sick, but only if you're a horse!
Other similar edible mustards don't have veins on the flower petals. They're not as hairy, the seedpods don't end in beaks, and the pods split lengthwise, rather than fragmenting, like wild radish's.

This leafy plant, without the familiar rounded root, tastes just like commercial radishes, to which it's ancestral. You can eat the inner portion of the taproot, and the young leaves, flowers, and seedpods.
Wild Radish Salad with Lemony Dressing
wild-radish-salad-with-lemony-dressing

Wild radish flowers decorate and flavor this tasty, colorful spring salad, and the lemon dressing gives it even more zest.

1 head of romaine lettuce, torn into bite-sized pieces
1 red bell pepper, sliced
2 celery stalks, peeled and sliced
1 large carrot, grated
1/2 cup wild radish flowers or tender, young seedpods
1/2 cup vidalia onion, chopped
1/4 cup walnuts, chopped
1/4 cup raisins

Lemony Dressing

1 cup olive oil
The juice of 1 lemon
2 tbs. rice vinegar
1 shallot, diced
1-1/2 tbs. lecithin granules
3 tbs. mellow miso

1. Toss all salad ingredients together.

2. Purée; all salad dressing ingredients in a blender.

3. Stir enough of the dressing into the salad to moisten the salad ingredients.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Spring Beauty
spring-beauty
Portulacaceae, the purslane family

The leaves of this spring ephemeral are good to eat in early spring before the flowers appear, and tuber is in season from when the leaves first appear into mid-spring, before the above-ground parts disappear and you don't know where to dig.
Moist to dry deciduous woodlands, savannas, park lands, thickets, clearings, wetlands, seeps, riparian hardwood forests, copses, bluffs, ravines, and prairies
Most of Eastern North America, but not VT, NH, or FL
Look for a low plant with loose, terminal clusters of pink or whitish flowers with pink-striped petals, and a pair of smooth, grass-like leaves half-way up the slender stem.

Growing from three to six inches tall, this delicate colonial plant's smooth, light green, succulent, unbranched stem bears one set of a pair of long, narrow, opposite, recurved, stalkless leaves. Light- or reddish-green, lance-shaped, somewhat succulent, three to six inches long and about 0.25 inch wide, they look like blades of grass. A central vein runs along each leaf's length.

A floppy, loose raceme of fragrant flowers, each 0.5 inch across, with two sepals, five stamens with pink anthers, and a three-parted pistil, grows at the top of the stem from early- to mid-spring. Three pointed sepals grow under the flower. The flower buds droop, but the flowers are erect. Distinctive, branching pink stripes run the length of the five white petals.

The flower's ovary develops into an ovoid capsule containing several seeds, surrounded by the two sepals. A light brown, ovoid corm grows underground.

•Colonial plant with smooth, unbranched stem three to six inches tall
•One set of long, narrow, recurved, opposite, stalkless leaves
•Grasslike, lance-shaped, somewhat succulent leaves three to six inches long and 0.25 inch wide
•Each leaf with long, central vein
•Loose, floppy racemes with five-petaled flowers
•Drooping flower buds
•Upright open flowers
•Flower's five-petals with distinct pink stripes
•Ovoid seed capsules containing several seeds
•Two sepals underlying each flower and seed capsule
•Each plant with a single, ovoid corm

Pinch off the leaves by hand, and dig up the corms with a shovel or trowel. The corms are only worth collecting where the plant is thriving and very abundant. That's where the corms will be relatively large. Otherwise, it's a lot of work for very little food.

Please collect only where very abundant (where the tubers are the best anyway), and thin out the stand by collecting a little from various spots throughout the stand, to avoid any adverse environmental impact.

The leaves taste like string beans but more mild, and the corms have a peanut flavor and the texture of water chestnuts. Enjoy both raw or cooked, chopped in salads and sandwiches, and in a variety of savory dishes. The corms are especially good stir-fried.
Please don't dig up the tubers where the plant is rare.
Other similar edible relatives grow throughout the country. Carolina beauty (C. carolina), which grows in the Eastern US, for example, has broader leaves that aren't grass-like.
Eastern Spring Beauty, Virginia Spring Beauty, Fairy Spuds
This aptly named plant often festoons the floor of forests with spectacular color and form, and where it's in such abundance, you can enjoy the peanut-flavored corms.
1)Spring Beauty in Flower
1spring-beauty-in-flower

This smooth-stemmed, unbranched plant, with opposite, grass-like leaves, has a corm at the bottom, and terminal raceme of flowers at the other end. The open, five-petaled flowers stand erect, while the unopened flower buds droop.
2)Spring Beauty with Corm and Flowers
2spring-beauty-with-corm-and-flowers

Spring beauty's reddish-brown, ovate corm gives rise to an unbranched, slender, hairless stem with a pair of opposite, grass-like leaves and a terminal raceme of five-petaled, flowers. Pink veins stripe the white petals.
3)Spring Beauty Flower
3spring-beauty-flower
The showy, five-petaled, white flowers striped with pink veins, set among grass-like leaves, makes this plant's identity unmistakable.
Sea Rocket
sea-rocket
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

The leaves are in season from mid-spring to early fall, most tender when they first appear, and most spicy toward the end of their season. The tender young pods are in season from mid- to late summer.
Full sunlight, close to open water, on sandy or gravelly beaches, and on dunes
Ocean shores of Eastern and Western US and Canada, and the Great Lakes' shores
Sea rocket is native to the East Coast.

Look for a succulent beach plant with oval to spoon-shaped, wavy-edged, alternate leaves; terminal clusters of small, pink-purple, lavender, or white, four-petaled flowers; and two-parted, green seedpods shaped like rocket ship nosecones, growing below the flowers.

This pioneer plant of seashore habitats has erect to prostrate, zig-zag, branching, succulent stems 0.5 to 20 inches tall. It's sometimes as wide as it's tall, like a tumbleweed.

The fleshy, wedge-shaped, hairless, wavy-toothed, oval to spoon-shaped alternate leaves, which grow one to three inches long and 0.25 to one inch across, are widest along the upper third. The upper leaves are smaller than the lower ones.

The small, short, pink-purple, lavender, or white, four-petaled flowers, which bloom throughout the summer and into the fall, grow 0.25 inch across, at the ends of irregular terminal racemes two to ten inches long.

The two-parted seedpods, 0.5 to 0.75 inch long and narrowed in the middle, grow below the flowers. The beaked upper portion is bulbous, and the more narrow and cone-shaped base is smaller. The pods resemble the nose-cone of rocket ship, even though, the word rocket means mustard. The pod's upper portion, which detaches and disperses via the ocean, contains a one seed, while the lower segment, which stays near the parent plant, contains either one seed or none.

•Erect to prostrate, zig-zag, succulent beach plant 0.5 to 20 inches tall
•Fleshy, wedge-shaped, hairless, wavy-toothed, oval to spoon-shaped alternate leaves one to three inches long and 0.25 to one inch across
•Flowers in irregular terminal racemes two to ten inches long
•Small, short, pink-purple, lavender, or white four-petaled flowers 0.25 inch across
•Green, beaked, cone-shaped, two-parted seedpods, constricted in the middle, 0.5 to 0.75 inch long, bulbous at the base and narrowed and pointed at the tip
Strip off the leaves, tender, immature seedpods, and young, tender tops of the stems, with your fingers.

The tangy leaves, flowers, and tender, young seedpods (the seedpods get tough as they mature) become wonderfully spicy as the season progresses, with a flavor very much like wasabe and horseradish. Mix them with milder greens in salads and sandwiches, or include them in cooked vegetable dishes that call for fire. Use sparingly or it may overpower the other ingredients, and your mouth. It cooks in about 10 minutes.

You may also pickle the young seedpods, or use them to create prepared mustard.
This plant isn't used medicinally, though, like horseradish or wasabe, I wouldn't be surprised if eating it were to temporarily clear nasal and sinus congestion.

Similar-looking close edible relatives also grow on beaches. Here are a few examples:

Harper's sea rocket (C. harperi), with more angular pods, grows from North Carolina to Florida. European Sea rocket (C. maritima), which grows along mid-Atlantic, Alabama, Texas, and West Coast beaches, has very deeply lobed leaves. And coastal sea rocket (C. lanceolata), which grows along the Gulf Coast, has more narrow leaves than sea rocket.

Wall rocket (Diplotaxis tenuifolia), also called sand rocket and Lincoln weed, grows in fields near the seashore, as well as along roadsides and in disturbed habitats in Northeast North America, parts of the Gulf Coast, and the Pacific Northwest except for Washington State. This tasty, erect, branching European mustard grows up to 1.5 feet tall, with fleshy, alternate, lobed or unlobed leaves, somewhat like sea rocket. But its small, four-petaled yellow flowers and long, straight, narrow seeds capsules, up to two inches long, sets it apart from sea rocket.
American Searocket
This fiery tasting mustard ignites like a rocket in your mouth. Fortunately, it grows near the ocean, so there's enough water to quell the flames!
Wall Rocket, Harper's sea rocket, European Sea Rocket, Coastal Sea Rocket, Horseradish
2)Young Sea Rocket
2young-sea-rocket
The succulent, oval- to spoon-shaped, wavy-toothed, alternate leaves of this seashore plant makes it easy to recognize, even when it's very young.
3)Sea Rocket Flower
3sea-rocket-flower

The short-stalked, four-petaled, white to lavender flowers, along with the short-stalked, ovate seedpods and the smooth, succulent, ovate to spoon-shaped leaves, make this delicious edible stand out when you see it in the sand near the ocean.
Sea Mustard
sea-mustard

Here’s a hot prepared mustard similar to commercial mustard, but better, thanks to sea rocket seedpods.

1/3 cup young sea rocket pods
1/4 cup white wine vinegar
2 tbs. water, or as needed
1 large clove of garlic
1/2 tsp. turmeric
1/2 tsp. sea salt (the recipe is called Sea Mustard, after all!), or to taste

1. Purée all ingredients in a food processor.

2. Bring to a boil over medium heat in a heavy saucepan, stirring constantly.

3. Reduce the heat to low and simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes, stirring often.

4. Stir in more water if necessary to achieve the consistency you prefer.

Makes 1 cup

Preparation/cooking time: 10 minutes
1)Sea Rocket in Flower
1sea-rocket-in-flower

This smooth, succulent plant has oval to spoon-shaped, wavy-edged, alternate leaves, plus terminal racemes of small, four-petaled flowers growing above green seedpods that are shaped like rocket ship nosecones.
4)Sea Rocket Seeds
4sea-rocket-seeds

Sea rocket's two-parted seedpods, clustered beneath the flowers on terminal racemes, resemble the nosecones of rocket ships. Beneath a pointed tip is a bulbous segment, growing above a conical segment. Green at first, the pods turn yellow with age. The fleshy, oval- to spoon-shaped, alternate leaves usually have wavy margins.
Wild Thyme
wild-thyme
Lamiaceae, the mint family

The best time to collect wild thyme is from mid-spring to mid-fall. Because it's evergreen, you could also collect it from late fall through early spring. Although it's in a pretty sorry state then, it's still usable, at least for making tea.
Full sunlight, in fields, along roadsides, on poor or rocky soil, on hillsides and mountains, in dry places, and in disturbed habitats
Scattered among some of the states of Eastern North America and the Pacific Northwest, and in parts of Eastern Canada
Europe and North Africa

Look for a dense mat of sprawling, downy, fragrant plants with tiny, elliptical, opposite leaves. The bilaterally symmetrical, two-lipped, tubular flowers flowers grow in dense whorls of lilac, pink-purple, magenta, or rarely white. Wild thyme enjoys growing in full sunlight on generally poor, rocky soil.

Sniff for the fragrance of thyme as you walk. You might smell the plants if you step on them before you see them.

Woody at the base and forming dense mats, this sprawling, highly branched, downy, evergreen garden escape, which spreads through runners, grows one to three inches tall, and from four inches to one foot long.

The tiny, fragrant, slightly hairy, opposite, dull gray-green, short-stalked, elliptical, toothless, evergreen leaves grow from 0.25 to 0.5 inch long and 0.12 to 0.25 inch wide.

Dense whorls of very small, fragrant, lilac, pink-purple, magenta, or rarely white, bilaterally symmetrical, two-lipped, tubular flowers 0.15 to 0.25 inches across, bloom in the summer. They grow on racemes that arise from the tips of the branches and the leaf axils.

The nearly smooth nutlets contain four small, brown seeds.

•Highly branched, downy, sprawling evergreen plant one to three inches tall, forming dense mats, woody at the base
• Tiny, fragrant, slightly hairy, opposite, dull gray-green, short-stalked, elliptical, toothless leaves, 0.25 to 0.5 inch long and 0.12 to 0.25 inch wide
•Dense terminal racemes and racemes arising from leaf axils with short, whorled flower clusters
•Whorls of tiny, fragrant,bilaterally symmetrical, two-lipped, tubular, lilac, pink-purple, magenta, or rarely white flowers, blooming in the summer
•Nearly smooth nutlets containing four small, brown seeds
•Entire plant with strong thyme fragrance
Strip off the leaves, flowers, and tender portions of the stems with your fingers. If you do this where the plant is growing in its greatest density, you'll be more effective.

With a strong, savory flavor, thyme is a standard culinary seasoning for salads, stews, stuffing, rice, eggs, fish, and pickles, as well as vegetables such as cabbage, eggplant and zucchini. If you're making vegan versions of egg and fish dishes, thyme will make them taste more authentic. Use it fresh or dried, finely chopped or ground.

To make thyme vinegar, simply cover a jar of thyme with vinegar, leave it in the refrigerator for a few days or weeks, then strain it out. It’s great for any recipe that needs some acidity and lots of flavor.
Thyme contains vitamins A, B1, C, and E, as well as the minerals calcium, iron, potassium, and phosphorus, although using it as a seasoning couldn't contribute significantly to your nutrient levels.

Everyone's familiar thyme as a culinary herb, but it's also an important medicinal plant, with a long history of safe use. Considered a tonic, carminative, emmenagogue, and antispasmodic, wild and cultivated thyme contain borneol, fluorine, triterpenic acids, and gum, plus thyme oil, which consists of thymol and cavacrol. Thymol has demonstrated antibiotic, antiseptic, anti-fungal, and anthelmintic properties.

Gargling with a strong, warm infusion of the whole plant will lessen the severity of sore throat. People have also used thyme honey (honey from bees that foraged on thyme flowers) for coughs, sore throats, and even headaches and upset stomachs.

A strong infusion of thyme is also used for colds, flu, coughs, bronchitis, laryngitis, colic, hangovers, oral infections, asthma, chronic respiratory problems, sinusitis, mucus congestion, headaches, indigestion, and gas. It's supposed to relax the nervous system—useful for insomnia, nervous disorders, headaches, and depression. As an antispasmodic, it's been used for cramps, spasms, and painful menstruation, as well as for treating uterine muscles following childbirth. And it may even lower HDL (bad cholesterol) levels. It certainly deserves thorough testing, and I wouldn't be surprised if many of the claims prove to be valid.

An infusion has been used as a mouthwash, an after-shave lotion, and even an underarm deodorant, probably the best people could come up with before more effective modern alternatives.

Don't use thyme medicinally if you're pregnant. Otherwise, using the infusion for home remedies is safe. However, the concentrated oil, a product created by distillation, can be toxic, and should be administered only competent practitioners.

Common thyme (T. vulgaris), a larger edible relative, grows in Europe, not North America. Lemon thyme (T. pulegioides), also edible, is another similar but larger European species, recorded as growing in the Northeast, but rare enough that I've never seen it outside of gardens.
Creeping Thyme, Breckland Thyme, Mother of Thyme
This familiar culinary herb takes on a whole new dimension when you find it growing in the wild. Bring it into your kitchen an you'll have a wild thyme!
Wild Thyme in Flower
wild-thyme-in-flower

This highly branched, prostrate, slightly downy plant, with tiny, elliptical, opposite leaves, has lilac flowers in dense whorls, growing on racemes originating in terminal clusters, or coming from the leaf axils.
Pistachio-Thyme Stuffing
pistachio-thyme-stuffing

Here’s a rice stuffing based on pistachio nuts and wild thyme you can use to stuff squash, bell peppers, mushrooms, or anything else.

6 tbs. olive oil
2 large red onions, chopped
6 cloves of garlic, chopped
4 cups cooked brown rice
1 tbs. sage, ground
2 tbs. fresh or 2 tsp. dried wild or commercial thyme, chopped or ground
1 tsp. nutmeg, ground
3/4 cup commercial currants
1/2 raw, unsalted cup pistachios, chopped
1 tbs. Braggs Liquid Aminos or tamari soy sauce
1 tbs. white wine

1. Gently sauté the onions in the olive oil 20 minutes or until lightly browned.

2. Add the garlic and sauté another 5 minutes

3. Stir in the brown rice, sage, thyme, and nutmeg, and sauté another 5 minutes.

4. Stir in the remaining ingredients.

5. Bake stuffed inside suitable vegetables (i.e., bell peppers or zucchini) or loaves until the vegetables or loaves are done, or bake 40 minutes in an oiled casserole dish, covered, in a preheated 350 degree oven.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 40 minutes
Tulip Tree
tulip-tree
Magnoliaceae, the magnolia family
The flowers bloom in mid-spring
Deep, rich, and moist soil, such as bottomlands, and cultivated habitats
Much of Eastern North America and southeastern Canada, but not in the northernmost Northeast or Midwest states

Look for a tall, straight tree with dark gray bark with diamond-patterned interlocking ridges and white furrows. Check for simple, alternate, broad, toothless, saddle-shaped leaves. The large, solitary, six-tepaled, greenish-yellow flowers have orange markings inside, and cone-shaped, woody fruits are composed of spirally arranged samaras resembling woody maple keys.

This very straight, tall tree grows from 60 to 165 (rarely 180) feet tall and 24 to 30 feet wide. Its pyramidal crown tapers sharply at the summit. As the tallest tree in the Eastern forest, it often protrudes through the canopy.

Young trees have dark green, smooth bark with whitish, vertical streaks, while older trees' bark turns dark gray, with flat-topped, interlocking ridges and conspicuous whitish furrows, forming diamond-shaped patterns. The large, reddish, flattened winter buds resemble the bills of ducks.

Tulip-shaped in outline, the distinctive, broad, flat, bright green, alternate, toothless, simple, saddle-shaped, flat-based, long-stalked leaves, which turn bright yellow in autumn, grow from four to eight inches long and four to six inches across, with four large lobes and a notched to flat top.

Large, erect, greenish-yellow, solitary, fragrant flowers grow 1.5 to four inches across, with three petals and three similar-looking sepals that have orange markings inside. Stamens and pistils are arranged spirally around a central spike.

Ripening in autumn, the narrow, pointed, scaly, woody, oblong, cone-like fruits, 2.5 to three inches long, consist of close-packed, spirally arranged, four-angled samaras, each to two inches long. These winged seeds look like woody versions of maple keys. They're released after the green fruit becomes light brown in autumn and shatters.

•Very straight, tall tree usually 60 to 165 feet tall and 24 to 30 feet wide, with a pyramidal crown
•Dark gray, flat-topped mature bark, with interlocking ridges, conspicuous whitish furrows, and diamond-patterns
•Large, reddish, flattened winter buds resembling a duck's bill
•Broad, medium-sized, flat, bright green, simple, toothless, saddle-shaped, flat-based, long-stalked, alternate leaves
•Large, erect, greenish-yellow, solitary, fragrant, six-tepaled flowers, superficially resembling tulips
•Orange markings inside the flowers
•Narrow, pointed, scaly, oblong, cone-like fruits, 2.5 to three inches long, consisting of close-packed, spirally arranged, four-angled samaras
•Winged seeds resembling woody versions of maple keys

Pick the flowers off the ground as soon as possible after they fall, before the ants get into them, or pick them from a young tree with low branches (mature trees don't have branches near the ground). Some years are better than others. If a high winds blow away all the flowers, or rainstorms wash away the nectar, there'll be no harvest.

The clear, shiny, sticky, sweet-tasting sap inside the flower is an excellent trail nibble, especially for kids, who all love sweets. The freshest looking, most vividly colored flowers with the most visibly shiny sap on the insides of the tepals are the best. Simply remove the petals and lick the sap.

Although you could use the sap as a sweetener, it would be very labor-intensive to collect enough.
Watch out for ants that may have gotten to the sweet, sticky sap before you, especially if you're a vegetarian!

The tulip poplar is unrelated to the tulip (Tulpa spp.) or to poplar (Populus) trees. The tree is named after the tulip because its leaves are shaped like the flower's petals, and the leaf is shaped like the outline of a tulip.
Tulip Poplar, White Poplar, Tulipwood, Saddle Leaf Tree, White Wood, Canoewood
This is a fun tree. For about a week in mid-spring, you can collect the flowers off the ground and lick the very sweet nectar from the insides of the petals.
Tulip, Poplar Tree
Tulip Tree in Winter and Summer
tulip-tree-in-winter-and-summer
This tall, straight tree has a pointed crown, and dark gray bark with furrows and interlocking ridges that create diamond patterns.
Tulip Tree Flower and Leaves
tulip-tree-flower-and-leaves
Japanese Barberry
japanese-barberry
Berberidaceae, the barberry family
The leaves are best when they first appear, mostly in the spring, although you can still find some young leaves in the summer.

This invasive shrub grows in full sunlight or partial shade, from damp lowlands to dry roadsides, in closed canopy forests and open woodlands, old fields, wetlands, pastures, meadows, gardens and park lands, along fence rows and trailsides, and in thickets and disturbed sites
Most of the eastern half of North America, but not the southernmost states
Japan (Duhh!)

Look for a dense, compact, small to medium-sized spiny bush with dense clusters of small, oval to spatula-shaped, smooth-edged leaves that turn red or purple in autumn; tiny, pale, yellow 6-sepaled flowers blooming in mid-spring; and small, dry, mealy, oblong, bright red berries in autumn and winter.

[Look for a dense, compact, small to medium-sized spiny bush with dense clusters of small, oval to spatula-shaped, smooth-edged leaves that turn red or purple in autumn. Tiny, pale, yellow six-sepaled flowers bloom in mid-spring and small, dry, mealy, oblong, bright red berries are present in autumn and winter.]
Strip off the young, light green leaves with your fingers, avoiding the sharp spines.

The young leaves have a pleasant, sour flavor. They make a great trail nibble, and you can add them raw to salads and sandwiches. They're good in soups and stews, cooking in about 15 minutes, and you can use them in any dish that calls for leafy vegetables.

The berries have an unpleasant, bitter flavor. Although they're non-poisonous, and some do people eat them, I find them to be quite awful-tasting. Use them raw or cooked in any recipe that you want to ruin!
The spines are especially good at what they do!
American barberry (B. canadensis) is similar, but the leaves are larger, and the prickles grow in small groups.
Crimson Pygmy, Dwarf Redleaf Barberry, Redleaf Japanese Bush
This shrub's sour-flavored leaves provide an excellent trail nibble, and you can add them to salads and cooked vegetable dishes too.
American Barberry
1)Japanese Barberry Flowers
1japanese-barberry-flowers
4)Japanese Barberry Bush in Autumn
4japanese-barberry-bush-in-autumn
3)Japanese Barberry Fruit
3japanese-barberry-fruit
These dry, ovate, long-stalked, red berries grow on slender, thorny twigs.
2)Japanese Barberry Bush with Fruit
2japanese-barberry-bush-with-fruit
Only a bird would find it worthwhile to brave the thorns in this densely branched bush to get at the unpleasant-flavored, ovate, red berries.
Japanese Honeysuckle
japanese-honeysuckle
Caprifoliaceae, the honeysuckle family
The flowers contain nectar from mid-spring to early summer.
Forest floors and canopies, roadsides, wetlands, and disturbed areas
Most of the US and Ontario, but not in the northern states west of the Great Lakes
East Asia

Look for a long trailing, climbing, or twining vine with medium-sized, stalkless, oval, finely fuzzy, opposite leaves; pairs of tubular, 5-parted white or yellow flowers; and pairs of shiny, spherical, dark blue to black berries. Sniff for the sweet, perfumed fragrance of the flowers, which can carry long distances.

[Look for a long trailing, climbing, or twining vine with medium-sized, stalkless, oval, finely fuzzy, opposite leaves and pairs of tubular, five-parted white or yellow flowers. Pairs of shiny, spherical, dark blue to black berries ripen in autumn. Sniff for the sweet, perfumed fragrance of the flowers, which can carry long distances.]

This invasive evergreen to semi-evergreen trailing, climbing, or twining, tan vine grows to over 80 feet long and up to two inches thick. It can climb over 30 feet high on trees, and it becomes woody when it gets large.

The stalkless, finely fuzzy, oval, opposite leaves grow from one to three inches long and 0.75 to one inch wide.

Showy, fragrant, tubular, five-parted, white or yellow, very fragrant flowers bloom in the leaf axils, from mid-spring to mid-summer.

Ripening in autumn, pairs of shiny, dark blue to black, spherical berries about 0.25 inch across contain two to three seeds 0.2 to 0.3 inches in diameter.

•Long, tan, trailing or climbing evergreen vine, sometimes woody
•Stalkless, finely fuzzy, oval, opposite leaves one to three inches long and 0.75 to 1 inch wide
•Showy, fragrant, tubular, five-parted, white or yellow, very fragrant flowers, growing in the leaf axils
•Pairs of shiny, dark blue to black spherical berries about 0.25 inch in diameter
•two to three tiny seeds 0.2 to 0.3 inches in diameter, inside berries
Collect the yellow flowers, the white ones usually contain no nectar.

Although you can't use this common vine in recipes, it's been a favorite trail nibble for generations, especially among kids. Pinch off the base of the yellow flowers (the white ones usually have no nectar), taking care not to sever the pistil. Pull the pistil out through the base, and there'll often be a drop of nectar at the pistil's tip that you can lick off. Suck on the base of the empty floral tube and you'll get still more nectar.
The nectar certainly contains sugar and calories, but only enough to be significant if you're an insect!

Japanese honeysuckle has antibacterial and anti-inflammatory properties. It's used in combination with forsythia (Forsythia suspensa) in traditional Chinese medicine to "dispel heat," remove toxins, and treat carbuncles, fevers, influenza and ulcers.

Only the nectar from the flowers is safe. The berries are terrible tasting, but weather they're poisonous is still being debated. Some authorities consider them non-poisonous, others claim that they cause vomiting, diarrhea, pupil dilation, cold sweat, rapid heartbeat, respiratory failure, convulsions, coma, and death!

Other vine honeysuckles' (Lonicera spp.) leaves are fused at the base, forming a perforated leaf. The flowers are non-poisonous, and some of them may have enough nectar for a trail nibble, but they're much less common than Japanese honeysuckle.

There are also bush honeysuckles with similar flowers and berries that are sometimes red. I never find enough nectar to taste in their flowers, and most species have very bitter berries, probably nonpoisonous, although once in a while, you may find an early-fruiting variety with red berries that taste sweet.
Kids have been pinching off the stamens of these flowers and sucking out the nectar for generations.
1)Japanese Honeysuckle in Flower
1japanese-honeysuckle-in-flower
This invasive, clambering vine can take over from everything else. Its five-parted, tubular flowers, which turn from white to yellow, are especially fragrant.
2)Japanese Honeysuckle Yellow Flowers
2japanese-honeysuckle-yellow-flowers
These mature, bilaterally symmetrical, tubular, 5-parted yellow flowers have very long stamens. These are much likely to contain a drop of nectar than the immature white flowers.
3)Japanese Honeysuckle Berries
3japanese-honeysuckle-berries

Japanese honeysuckle is a vine with short-pointed, smooth-edges, simple, oval, opposite leaves of varying sizes, and pairs of small, spherical black berries. Accounts conflict as to whether or not the bitter-tasting berries are poisonous to humans, but birds like them enough to keep spreading this invasive species.
Mile-a-Minute
mile-a-minute1
Polygonaceae, the buckwheat family
The leaves are best when the plant's young, in the spring and summer, but since this plant grows so rapidly, you can find tender young leaves into autumn.

Sunny, open, warm areas, along the edges of woods, wetlands, stream banks, and roadsides, in uncultivated open fields, openings in the woods, parks, forest edges, fence rows, and wetlands with poor soil

Recently introduced into PA, it's spreading into the Northeast states, and recently introduced into OR, it's spreading into the Pacific NW too. New to me, I first saw it in one of the NYC parks in 2010. Because it can grow 6 inches per day, and birds, mammals, insects, and water all spread it, this very invasive plant may become very widespread quite soon.
East Asia and the Phillipines

Look for a highly branched, delicate-looking, thin, jointed, reddish, climbing or trailing vine covered with highly effective, small, curved spines. Medium-sized, light green, entire, triangular, alternate leaves and circular, leafy structures surround the stems near the leaf base, with small, white flowers, and shiny, metallic-blue, pea-sized fruits.

This highly branched, delicate-looking, thin, jointed, reddish, climbing or trailing vine is covered with highly effective, small, curved spines.

Barbed underneath the veins, the light green, entire, triangular, alternate leaves grow from one to three inches long. Small, inconspicuous, white flowers arise from circular, leafy structures that surround the base of the leaf's barbed stalks.

Shiny, metallic-blue, pea-sized fruits arise from these structures from mid-summer to fall. The fruits are divided into segments, each of which contains a single black or reddish-black seed.

•Highly branched, delicate-looking, thin, jointed, reddish, climbing or trailing vine
• Light green, entire, alternate leaves from one to three inches long, shaped like an equilateral triangle
•White flowers arising from the circular, leafy structures that surround the stem near the leaf stalk's base
•Shiny, segmented, metallic-blue, pea-sized fruits
•A single black or reddish black seed inside each fruit segment
•Curved barbs on stems, leaf stalks, and the veins on the leaves' undersides
Strip off the leaves wearing work gloves.

Mile-a-minute has a delicious, sour flavor similar to sheep sorrel, a relative, and the unrelated wood sorrel. Trim away sections of the leaves and stems that have barbs, and enjoy the plant raw, in salads or in sandwiches. Cook it in any dish that will benefit from some sourness. It cooks in about 10 to 15 minutes.
The sour flavor indicates vitamin C, but no nutritional analysis is available.

Watch out for the very nasty barbs when handling the plant!

The leaves contain the dreaded compound, oxalic acid, making eating this plant about as dangerous to eat for most people as eating spinach, although people with kidney disease should avoid both vegetables.
Any similar-looking vines lack barbs.
Devil's Tail, Tearthumb, Asiatic Tearthumb, Gangbangui, Devil Shield
This is America's newest invasive wild food, most likely coming to your area soon.
Mile-a-Minute
mile-a-minute
This delicate-looking, branching vine, with triangular, toothless leaves, is anything but...it's heavily armed with nasty barbs!
Red Lentils with Mile-a-Minute
red-lentils-with-mile-a-minute

Small red lentils, dal, are a staple in India, and I’ve made many delicious dishes cooking them with Indian ingredients. Turns out they’re just as good with Western ingredients, and the mile-a-minute, which usually tastes sour, gives them a slightly sweet flavor here. Don’t add the tamari until the end, because cooking beans with salt makes them tough.

1/4 cup olive oil
2 large red onions, sliced
4 cloves of garlic, finely chopped
2 yellow bell peppers, sliced
2 medium carrots, sliced
2 cups mile-a-minute, sheep sorrel, wood sorrel, or other wild or commercial greens
2 cups vegetable stock
2 tsp. thyme, ground
2 tsp. sage, ground
2 tsp. oregano, ground
1/2 tsp. black pepper
2 tsp. tamari soy sauce
2 cups small red lentils (dal)

1. Sauté the onions, garlic, bell peppers, and carrots in the olive oil 15 minutes, or until the onion is translucent.

2. Stir in the remaining ingredients except the tamari soy sauce, bring to a boil over high heat, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 1 hour until the lentils are tender.

3. Stir in the tamari soy sauce.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 25 minutes

Cooking time: 1 hour
Quickweed
quickweed
Family Asteraceae (Compositae), the astor or composite family
Quickweed is in season from mid-spring through late fall.
Sunny and partially shaded areas with moist soil, gardens and cultivated areas, parks, lowland fields, disturbed soil, and cracks in pavements.
This plant grows throughout most of the US, Quebec, and British Columbia, but not in the Rocky Mountain states, LA, FL, and AL, although it's spread to much of the rest of the world.
Central and South America

Look for colonies of medium-sized soft, slender, branching plants, hairy throughout, with medium-sized, lance-shaped, oval, or triangular, coarse-toothed, stalked leaves. Tiny composite flowers have four to five white, three-toothed ray flowers and many tiny, yellow disk flowers and tiny, dandelions-like seeds.

Growing from six inches to two feet tall from fibrous roots, this group of very similar, invasive, colonial plants has soft, slender, erect, ridged, branching stems covered with hair.

The lance-shaped, oval or triangular, coarsely-toothed, medium- to dark green opposite leaves, about three inches long and two inches across (smaller, more narrow, and stalkless toward the top of the stem), are densely hairy above, with additional hairs on the veins of the leaf's underside. The hairy leafstalks grow to about 1.5 inches long.

Blooming from summer through late fall, many composite flowers grow in sparse terminal clusters, or in clusters arising from the leaf axils. About 0.25 to 0.4 inch wide, they consist of four to five white, three-toothed, outer ray flowers, and many tiny, yellow, inner disk flowers. Each flower head is surrounded by about two outer and several inner green, oval, scale-like bracts.

The seeds are achenes that look like tiny dandelion seeds, that blow away in the wind.

•Colonial plants with soft, slender, erect, ridged, branching stems, covered with hair
•Opposite, lance-shaped, oval or triangular, coarsely-toothed, medium- to dark green leaves, about three inches long and two inches across, densely hairy above, with more hairs on the veins of the leaf's underside
•Similar smaller, more narrow leaves toward the plant's top
•Hairy leaf stalks about 1.5 inches long
•Many sparse flower clusters at the tips of the branches, and arising from the leaf axils
•Tiny composite flower heads with four to five white, three-toothed, outer ray flowers, and many tiny, inner yellow disk flowers
•Flower heads surrounded by about two outer and several inner green, oval, scale-like bracts
•Seeds similar to dandelion achenes but smaller
Strip off the leaves, flowers, and any tender parts of the stems with your fingers, grabbing as many bunches at a time as possible.

This plant is unpleasantly hairy raw. You can add it raw to salads and sandwiches, AS LONG AS YOU DON'T EAT THEM!

Cooked, it's less unpleasantly hairy to me, and people in Columbia add it to a chicken soup called ajiaco bogotano, but I still don't like eating hairy food. In fact, I avoided eating quickweed for 28 years. It wasn't quick, but I finally figured out what to do with this plant (besides throwing it out).

1. You can cook it in recipes that are going to be puréed, i.e., cream soups and sauces. Then it's quite good, with a flavor remarkably like artichokes, and puréeing it in these recipes solves the problem of the hairs.

2. You can also dehydrate it, grind it into a powder in a spice grinder, and use it to impart an artichoke flavor to any appropriate recipe, certainly the most unusual of any wild seasoning I've ever made. This is especially good in dips that contain olives, and it's not bad added to soups or sauces either.
Quickweed provides some protein and calories, plus vitamin A, B1, B2, B3, and C, plus the minerals phosphorus and iron.

The juice of this plant is one of the best herbal medicines for wounds, and it relieves the sting of stinging nettles. It helps blood to coagulate more quickly, and has antibiotic activity. It may even speed the healing of wounds, but this needs to be tested.
Never serve quickweed to member of the Slow Food Movement!
Chickweed comprises a completely different group of edible plants that only sounds similar to quickweed.
Galinsoga, Four-pointed Galinsoga, Peruvian Daisy, Shaggy Soldier, Potato Weed, Gallant Soldiers, Soldiers of the Queen

This common, widespread, easy-to-recognize plant is so hairy that if you take a bite of it, you'll want to spit it out very quickly. Nevertheless, it has a wonderful flavor of artichokes, and you can purée it, or dry and grind it to sidestep the otherwise unpleasant texture.

2quickweed-in-flower

This medium-sized, very hairy plant has soft, slender branching stems, and medium-sized, oval to triangular, coarse-toothed, stalked leaves. The many tiny composite flowers consist of four to five white, three-toothed ray flowers, plus many tiny, yellow, central, disk flowers.

American Pennyroyal
american-pennyroyal
Lamiaceae, Mint Family
Spring through fall.
Dry upland woods, rocky woods, rocky glades, pastures, fields, edges of trails, and slopes, mountains, roadsides, and pastures.
Eastern and Central North America, but not Florida, Louisiana, or Texas.

Look for a relatively small, slender, hairy, square-stemmed plant with small, thin, oblong to lance-shaped, toothed or toothless, short-stalked, opposite leaves. Small clusters of one to four pale bluish-violet, two-lipped, tubular flowers arise from the leaf axis. A pair of leafy bracts, at least as long the flower, sit at each flower's base.

This low-growing, highly aromatic mint's slender, branched, hairy, square stem grows from four to 12 inches tall, arising from fibrous, yellowish roots.

Its small, thin, oblong to lance-shaped, toothed or toothless, short-stalked, opposite leaves grow from 0.5 to 1.5 inches long and about 0.25 inches wide, sometimes with a few blunt teeth toward the tips.

Small clusters of one to four pale bluish-violet to white, two-lipped, tubular flowers, 0.25 inch across, bloom in the leaf axils throughout the summer. A pair of leafy bracts at least as long the flower grows at each flower's base. The flowers give way to four tiny nutlets.

•Slender, hairy, square-stemmed, branched plant four to 12 inches tall
•Small, thin, oblong to lance-shaped, toothed or toothless, short-stalked, opposite leaves, 0.5 to 1.5 inches long and about 0.25 inches wide
•Leaves toothless or sometimes with sparse, coarse teeth at the tips
•Small clusters of one to four pale bluish-violet to white, two-lipped, tubular flowers, 0.25 inch across, blooming in the leaf axils throughout the summer
•A pair of leafy bracts at least as long the flower at each flower's base
•Four tiny nutlets replacing the flowers in autumn
For food use, strip off the leaves and flowers, and pinch off any tender parts of the stems. You can use the whole above-ground plant for tea.

One of the strongest-tasting and best mints, you can use the leaves, flowers, and tender parts of the stems, fresh and finely chopped, or dried and ground, raw or cooked, in virtually any dessert or sweet recipe, pies, cakes, sauces, puddings, ice cream, jello, breakfast cereals, smoothies, and more. The leaves or flowers make a great garnish too, and you can use any or all of the above-ground parts for making tea.

The essential oil of pennyroyal, which you'd have to buy, is toxic when taken internally, damaging the liver and kidneys. It's even killed women trying to use it to induce abortions.

Avoid using this herb altogether if you're pregnant, and don't give it to young children.

Clammy Hedge hyssop (Gratiola neglecta) looks a little like American pennyroyal, but this non-poisonous relative has no odor, and it grows in wet areas, where you won't find American pennyroyal.

European pennyroyal (Mentha pulegioides) is a different member of the mint family that doesn't grow wild in North America.
American False Pennyroyal, Mock Pennyroyal, Squaw Mint, Stinking Balm, Thickweed, Tickweed, Stinking Balm, Mosquito Plant
This mint makes up in flavor what it lacks in size. It's quite small, and especially delicious.
American Pennyroyal in Flower
american-pennyroyal-in-flower

This small, slender, hairy, square-stemmed plant, with small, thin, oblong to lance-shaped, short-stalked, opposite leaves, has pale bluish-violet, two-lipped, tubular flowers growing in the leaf axils and a pair of long, leafy bracts at each flower's base.

baked-bananas

American Hackberry Tree
american-hackberry-tree
Ulmaceae, the elm family

The berries are at their best in early fall, before they shrivel and perish in mid-fall, although in some parts of the country they reportedly hang on (literally and figuratively), fresh and edible, into the winter.
Full sun or partial shade, rich, most soil, gravelly or rocky hillsides, woodlands, parks, backyards, empty lots, river banks, rocky barrens, and floodplains.

The American hackberry grows throughout most of Eastern and Central North America and most of southeastern Canada, but not in VT or LA. Its close relatives, also edible, have overlapping ranges, and they sometime hybridize with each other. The sugarberry, for example, sticks to the Deep South, the dwarf hackberry grows in Eastern North America, and the desert hackberry grows where there's underground water in the deserts of the SW.

Look for a variably sized tree with a rounded crown, spreading or slightly drooping branches, corky gray bark, and disease-deformed twigs pointing in all directions. The simple, rough, alternate, oval, stalked, dull green, medium-sized, finely toothed, leaves are insect-defaced with asymmetrical bases. Thin-fleshed, solitary, long-stalked, spherical, orange-brown to dark purple berries hang.

•Variably sized tree with a rounded crown, spreading or slightly drooping branches, and corky, gray bark
•Disease-deformed twigs pointing in all directions
•Simple, rough, alternate, oval, stalked, dull green, finely toothed leaves two to five inches long and one to two inches wide, with three long veins, long pointed tips, and asymmetrical bases
•Knobby insect galls usually marring the leaves' undersides
•Thin-fleshed, solitary, long-stalked, spherical, orange-brown to dark purple berries
•A single, hard, cream-colored pit inside each berry
Pick the tasty berries with your fingers—labor-intensive but definitely worth the effort. However, the berries are small, so bringing more than one container is definitely not worth the effort.

The thin pulp has sweet flavor similar to the candy coating of M&Ms, but with too little substance for more than a trail nibble. The seeds are good to eat too, if you like the hardness of pebbles (although this may not be true for all the subspecies).

A decoction of the cambium and an infusion was used as a gargle for sore throats and pain reliever, and the berries were also used for dysentery, but there's no evidence backing up any of these claims, and this tree isn't currently used in herbal medicine.

You can also eat the berries of a number of the American Hackberry's very similar relatives, which hybridize where their ranges overlap: The related Sugarberry (C. laevigata), which grows in the South, has toothless, more narrow leaves, and the much smaller dwarf hackberry's (C. tenuifolia) large, broad leaves lack tooth as well. The desert hackberry’s (C. pallida) evergreen leaves are only toothed from the middle to the tip, the fruit is yellow to orange, and the twigs are spiny.

Anything else you might confuse with hackberry has clustered fruit, whereas hackberries' long-stalked fruits are solitary.
Common Hackberry, Nettletree, Beaverwood, Northern Hackberry
This common, messy-looking tree with gray, corky bark and insect-damaged leaves provides a surprisingly tasty, if small berry, often in great abundance.
1)American Hackberry Leaves and Berries
1american-hackberry-leaves-and-berries

The American hackberry has simple, alternate, oval, long-stalked, dull green, medium-sized, finely toothed leaves with asymmetrical bases. Thin-fleshed, solitary, long-stalked, spherical, orange-brown to dark purple berries hang from the twigs on long fruit stalks.
2)American Hackberry Flowers
2american-hackberry-flowers

Its easy to miss these tiny, light green or white, two-sided, inconspicuous, four- or five-lobed flowers, which don't even have petals. Wind-pollinated, they appear in mid-spring, soon after the leaves begin their development.
3)American Hackberry Fruit
3american-hackberry-fruit

These small, spherical, solitary, orange berries, hanging from the twigs on long, slender stalks, are quite tasty, although the large pit inside the thin, dry pulp makes them insubstantial. The simple, alternate, oval, stalked, dull green, finely toothed leaves, with, long pointed tips and asymmetrical bases, make the tree easy to recognize.

American Persimmon
american-persimmon
Ebenaceae, the ebony family
Late fall is the best time for this fruit, although some trees keep dropping their fruit into the winter. The fruit of a few rare individual trees ripen significantly earlier.
Forests, rocky hillsides, bottomland swamps, stream banks, upland forests, piney woods, fields, dry scrub lands along the edges of fields, and parks.
Southeastern North America up to Long Island, and in parks and botanical gardens further north.

Look for a small to large tree with thick, gray-black, blocky bark divided into distinctive, mosaic-like squares. Its medium-sized leaves are elliptical and toothless, the flowers small, fragrant, four-petaled, and bell-shaped. The orange, spherical, pulpy fruits are one to two inches across with four leathery, brown sepals encircling the fruit's base.

This small or tall tree, which grows from 15 to 100 feet tall, depending on the soil and habitat, has thick, gray-black, blocky bark divided into distinctive, mosaic-like squares 1.5 inches across. The short, slender trunk often produces pendulous, spreading branches, and sometimes forms a narrow, rounded crown.

With pointed tips and bases, shiny upper surfaces and light green undersides, the toothless, elliptical, alternate leaves grow up to six inches long and three inches wide.

Growing on female trees only, the fragrant, pale yellow, bell-shaped, short-stalked, solitary fertile flowers grow 0.75 inch long, producing both male and female parts with four petals and eight stamens. The male trees grow similarly sterile flowers up to 0.375 inch long, in clusters of two or three, with male parts (16 long stamens) only.

The spherical fruit is orange throughout but discoloring to yellowish-brown, one to two inches across. It which contains one to eight large, flattened, brown seeds and grows from one to two inches across on female trees only. Four leathery, brown sepals encircle the fruit’s base.

•Small to large tree with thick, gray-black, blocky bark divided into distinctive, mosaic-like squares
•Elliptical, toothless leaves six inches long and three inches wide, shiny above and light green below
•Small, fragrant, four-petaled, bell-shaped flowers, all either clustered or solitary
•Orange, spherical, pulpy fruit one to two inches across, discoloring yellowish-brown
•One or more flattened, brown seeds in the fruit
•Four leathery, brown sepals encircling the fruit's base

Collect the persimmons from the ground, or shake the tree if it's small enough. Gently pack the delicate fruit into shallow food containers. Separate the ripe ones from the unripe ones, which will ripen off the tree at room temperature, especially if you store them with apples, which give of ethylene gas that hastens ripening. Although persimmons usually ripen when the weather is frosty, contrary to a widespread belief, they doesn't require frost to ripen. Just ask anyone who picks them in Florida!

Smaller and tastier than commercial Asian persimmons, this fruit is only good when it's completely ripe—discolored, blotchy, and spoiled-looking. Use the sweet, pulpy fruit, raw or cooked, in any dessert, from smoothies to ice creams and in cakes, pies, breads, puddings, or pancakes. Avoid attractive-looking, unripe, or even partially ripe fruits, which are unpleasantly astringent.

Oranges make a perfect complement to persimmons, so I often include orange juice, rind, or extract in persimmon recipes. Lemon is another good complementary flavor, and there's nothing like eating raw persimmons sprinkled with freshly squeezed lemon juice. Remove the seeds with a food mill or your fingers, and the purée is outstanding in any dessert recipe. I use them in pies, cakes, smoothies, ice cream, cookies, cereal, and many other kinds of desserts.

You can freeze American persimmons raw or cooked, and you can steep the leaves to make a tasty herb tea.

Persimmons are one of the most caloric, filling fruits, and an excellent source of vitamin C and D, plus calcium, phosphorous, and potassium.

Persimmon leaf infusion is very high in vitamin C, and tasty too.

Native Americans applied cut, unripe persimmons, which may be slightly antiseptic, to burns, where the astringency counteracts the burn's tendency to ooze. They also used this astringency to stop wounds from bleeding.

Like the papaya and pineapple, persimmons contain the digestive enzymes papain and bromelaine—included in digestive enzyme preparations, so eating these fruits should help digestion.

But the American persimmon's most important medicinal use is to cure the talcum-powder-in-the-mouth feeling you get from eating a partially ripe persimmon!
Don't eat think of eating partially unripe persimmons—they're horribly astringent!

A closely related edible species of the Southwest, the Texas persimmon (D. texana) is similar to the American persimmon, but with smooth, gray bark and black fruit.

The nonpoisonous blackgum (Nyssa sylvatica) has glossy leaves with a few teeth, but no persimmon-like fruit, and the leaves turn red in autumn.
Date Plum, Simmon
This is an incredibly delicious fruit if eatten when it's dead ripe and rotten-looking, but absolutely awful if even partially unripe.
Creamy Persimmon Ice Cream
creamy-persimmon-ice-cream

The combination of my radical vegan ice cream protocol plus wild persimmons makes a dessert you won’t be able to resist.

3-1/2 cups soy-rice milk or other non-dairy milk
1 tbs. agar flakes
1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
1/2 cup American persimmon pulp
1/3 cup grape seed oil
1/2 cup raw pignoli nuts or cashews
1 tbs. liquid stevia
The scrapings of 1/2 inch of a vanilla bean or 2 tsp. vanilla extract
1/2 tsp. freshly grated lemon or orange rind
1/4 tsp. nutmeg, ground

1. Stir the agar, arrowroot, and persimmons into the soy-rice milk, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce, the heat to low, and simmer, uncovered, for 5 minutes, or until all the agar is dissolved, stirring often.

2. Combine with the remaining ingredients in a blender and purée.

3. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

Makes 5-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Freezing time: 2 hours

As the alternate, elliptical, simple leaves turn brown and begin to die in autumn, the American persimmon's stalkless, spherical fruit begins to ripen. The dark blotches on the orange skin indicate ripeness, not rot, and it's these discolored fruits that are so good to eat.
Wild Raspberry
wild-raspberry
Rosaceae, the rose family
The fruit is available from mid-summer to late summer, and there's sometimes a second season from mid- to late fall. You can use the leaves for tea from spring, when they're at their best, to fall.
Moist, sunny or partially shady habitats, thickets, hedges, overgrown fields, edges of woods, openings in woods, trail sides, and roadsides
Throughout most of North America except parts of the Southeast

Look for arching or erect, colonial, multi-stemmed, shrubs up to six feet tall, with round, purplish-red stems armed with curved prickles. The bright green, palmate-compound, alternate leaves with have three to five (rarely seven) toothed, pointed, oval leaflets that are whitish underneath. Short, loose terminal racemes of white, five-petaled flowers give way to round, downy, red raspberries in the summer and fall.

Growing from three to six feet tall and from six to 12 feet wide, this bramble has many arching or erect, woody, thorny, rounded stems called canes, growing from perennial roots. The first-year stems are called primocanes, which produce only leaves. From the primocanes come lateral branches called floricanes the second year. These bear flowers and fruit. The canes all die back to the roots at the end of the second season, and the cycle repeats.

The bright green, palmate-compound, alternate leaves consist of three to five (rarely seven) toothed, pointed, oval leaflets, whitish underneath, 1.5 to 2.5 inches long and about half as wide, turning red and purple in fall.

Short, loose terminal racemes grow on side shoots during the second year. They consist of five-petaled, white to greenish-white flowers, which give way to round, downy, red raspberries, an aggregate fruit with five triangular sepals at the fruit's base.

•Arching or erect, colonial, multi-stemmed, thorny shrub up to six feet tall, with round stems armed with curved prickles
•Bright green, palmate-compound, alternate leaves with three to five (rarely seven) toothed, pointed, oval leaflets, whitish underneath, 1.5 to 2.5 inches long and about half as wide
•Short, loose terminal racemes of white, five-petaled flowers, growing on side shoots
•Round, downy, red raspberries

Here's a good way to collect lots of bramble berries with most effectively: Plan your harvest in advance, choosing a relatively cool day, and forage early in the morning, so you can wear long pants and sleeves to protect yourself from thorns and mosquitoes without getting too hot.

Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. Wear heavy-duty work gloves with the fingertips of your picking hand's glove cut off (kitchen shears will do this) to protect your hands as much as possible. When your container and stomach are full, transfer your harvest into one of your empty containers and resume picking.

Use these berries like commercial raspberries, raw or cooked, in virtually any dessert recipe. They're more flavorful that commercial raspberries, but more seedy. I add them to cereals, pancakes, muffins, sauces, pies, fruit salads, compotes, puddings, ice creams, jams, jellies, and drinks. If you purée them, strain out any hard seeds, which would otherwise be annoying.

To say that raspberries are good for you in a gross understatement. They provide vitamins A, B1, B2, B6, C, E, K, pantothenic acid, and folate, as well as the minerals and trace minerals calcium, iron, magnesium, phosporus, potassium, sodium, zinc, copper, manganese, and selenium.

Raspberries are loaded with health-promoting antioxidants including ellagic acid, the flavonoids quercetin and kaempferol, and cyanidin-based molecules called cyanidin-3-glucosylrutinoside and cyanidin-3-rutinoside. These phytochemicals are antimicrobial too, inhibiting pathogens such as Candida albicans, which causes yeast infections and may aggravate irritable bowel syndrome. Research even indicates that eating raspberries reduces your chances of getting cancer.

Unfortunately, buying enough raspberries to eat them regularly is quite expensive. Fortunately, wild raspberries are widespread and free, and they're easy to freeze.

An infusion of the leaves and roots is used as an astringent for diarrhea, especially for children, since it's more gentle than other herbal astringents, but it's main use is as a tonic to the strengthen the female reproductive system. As such, it's been used for centuries by Native American, European, and Asian herbalists, and it contains constituents that both stimulate and relax the uterus.

It's used during the last three months of gestation, during childbirth, and to lessen the symptoms of menopause, as well as for menstrual cramps. It's also used for nausea and to suppress vomiting, as a gargle for tonsillitis and mouth inflammations, and as a poultice or wash for sores, conjunctivitis, minor wounds, burns, and varicose ulcers.

Botanists disagree over whether this American species is a subspecies of the Eurasian raspberry (R. idaeus), which doesn't grow wild in North America, or whether they're separate species. I'd rather eat the berries than participate in the debate!

Poison ivy and poison oak have palmate-compound leaves and often grow near or with raspberries, but the leaves aren't sharply toothed, there's no thorny cane, and the flowers and fruits are completely different. As long as you're on the lookout for these plants when you pick raspberries, you'll be able to avoid them.
American Red Raspberry
Wild raspberries look just like commercial raspberries until you put them in your mouth and discover that they're way more flavorful. They're also common and widespread.
1)Wild Raspberry Jam
1wild-raspberry-jam

Here’s a simple, delicious jam you can make with any species of raspberries (you could make it with blackberries too, but then it would have to be called Blackberry Jam).

4 cups wild raspberries, wineberries, or other raspberry species
6 tbs. pear juice
1-1/2 cups agar flakes
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia
1 tbs. red wine or red wine (optional)
1 tsp. raspberry extract (optional)
1/4 tsp. orange extract

1. Simmer all ingredients together for 5 minutes, or until the agar is dissolved.

2. Purée in a blender, holding down the cover with a dish towel and beginning at low speed at first, to prevent an eruption

3. Strain out the seeds using a fine-mesh strainer if desired.

5. Test a spoonful in a freezer for 2 minutes. Add water if too thick, or simmer with more agar if too thin.

6. Chill until set.

Makes 4 cups

Preparation/Cooking time: 15 minutes

Setting time: 90 minutes
2)Frosted Wild Raspberry Cookies
2frosted-wild-raspberry-cookies

These frosted cookies combine the texture and flavor of wild raspberries with that of flour cookies and frosting—a great reminder of summer past, future, or present.

Dry Ingredients

1-1/4 cup (6 oz.) sweet brown rice flour + 1/2 cup (3 oz.) buckwheat flour, or 9 oz. of any whole-grain flour
2 tbs. flaxseeds or chia seeds, ground into 1/4 cup meal
1/2 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1/2 tsp. xanthan gum
1/2 tsp. salt
1/4 tsp. baking soda

To Blend

1/4 cup pomegranate juice
1/2 cup Wild Raspberry Jam or other jam
1/4 cup corn oil
2 tbs. lecithin granules
1 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tsp. vanilla
1 tsp. raspberry extract (optional)

Frosting

3/4 cup silken tofu, drained
2 tbs. pitted Medjool (soft) dates
1/4 cup Wild Raspberry Jam or other jam
1/4 tsp. liquid stevia
1/4 tsp. raspberry extract (optional)
1/8 tsp. vanilla extract
1/4 tsp. salt
1/8 tsp. orange extract

1. Mix together dry ingredients

2. Blend the ingredients to blend except the jam in a blender until smooth.

3. Stir in the jam.

4. Mix the blended ingredients into the dry ingredients. Don’t overmix.

5. Shape into a dozen cookies

6. Bake 10 minutes or until lightly browned underneath in a preheated 375 degree F. oven.

7. Turn over with a spatula and bake another 10 minutes, or until lightly browned underneath.

8. Meanwhile, purée the frosting ingredients in a food processor

9. Cool the cookies on racks.

10. Spread the frosting on the cookies

Makes 12 cookies

Preparation Time: 30 minutes

Baking Time: 20 minutes
