1)Wild Raspberry Flowers
1wild-raspberry-flowers

The wild raspberry has light green, feather-compound leaves with three to five fine-toothed, oval, pointed leaflets, and loose, terminal racemes of white, five-petaled flowers, growing on thorny stems. The five-petaled, white to greenish-white flowers have five triangular sepals at their base.
2)Red Raspberry Fruit
2red-raspberry-fruit

The red raspberry has easily recognizable terminal racemes of hollow, downy, spherical, red, aggregate fruits, with five long, triangular sepals at the fruit's base. Unlike blackberries, after you pick a berry, the cone-shaped receptacle is left behind.
Wild Apples
wild-apples
Rosaceae, the rose family
Apples ripen from late summer through mid-fall, while various crab apples ripen from early fall through late fall. The flowers bloom briefly in early spring.
Gardens, parks, and other cultivated areas; fields, edges of forests, clearings in forests, and thickets
Throughout North America
Although we have some native crabapples, but most of the apple trees you find originate in Asia.

Look for small to medium-sized, gnarled trees with cracked (or smooth, if they're young), scaly, gray, brown or reddish-brown bark, and a dense, twiggy crown. The medium-sized, alternate leaves are coarse, elliptical, pointed, stalked, finely toothed, and medium- to dark green. The five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, fragrant, pink, red, or white flowers bloom in early spring. The spherical, green, yellow or red fruits vary in size.

These small to medium-sized, gnarled trees, growing from 12 to 36 feet high, have cracked (smooth when young), scaly, gray, brown or reddish-brown bark, and a dense, twiggy crown. Some may have thorns, although I've never seen these. Botanists group apples into 30 to 55 species (it's hard to draw the line between species and subspecies, especially with the trees that hybridize readily).

Slightly fuzzy underneath, the coarse, elliptical, pointed, stalked, slightly toothed, medium- to dark green, alternate leaves grow from one to four inches long.

White, pink, or red, the five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, fragrant, flowers, which grow up to 0.75 inches across, bloom in early spring and drop to the ground soon thereafter.

Ripening in late summer or autumn, the red, yellow, or green fruit may look like an imperfect commercial apple or a smaller crab apple, but unlike other similar-looking fruit, the brown, teardrop-shaped apple grow in sets of 5 around core’s circumference. Split an apple in half along its “equator,” and they will always form a 5-parted star.

Crab apples are defined as having fruit less than two inches across, apples as more than 2 inches across. Don't ask me what a tree is called if some of its fruit is less than two inches across, and some is larger!

•Small to medium-sized, gnarled tree with cracked (or smooth, if it's young), scaly, gray, brown, or reddish-brown bark, rarely thorny
•Dense, twiggy crown
•Coarse, elliptical, pointed, stalked, slightly toothed, medium- to dark green, alternate leaves, one to four inches long
•Leaves slightly fuzzy underneath
•Fragrant, pink, red, or white, five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, short-lived flowers, up to 0.75 inches across, blooming in early spring
•Fruit spherical, green, yellow to red, 0.5 to five inches in diameter, ripening in late summer or fall
•Brown, teardrop-shaped seeds in five compartments, forming a pentagon when the apple is split horizontally

Bring strong bags and pick the windfall apples, those that have fallen by themselves, first. If they haven't been lying around long enough to rot, they're are the best ones. You can also shake the branches to increase your harvest.

Some trees bear bumpier and less perfect-looking than commercial apples, with bumps indicating healed injuries. Some apples contain insect larvae, mistakenly called “worms,” that leave brown, rotten trails inside the apple—quite distasteful, but not toxic. You can use slightly infested apples after you out cut out the bad parts. Some years are better for gathering an excellent wild apple crop, others are better for the "worms!"

Many, but not all, crab apple varieties are only good to eat when they get soft and orange-brown, in late fall. If they're hard and bitter and aren't falling to the ground yet, you're too early. The crab apples that taste good before they turn brown, on the other hand, usually ripen and start falling off the trees by mid-fall.

Wild apples often differ from cultivated ones, more flavorful and tart, with rough or papery unwaxed skins. They’re compact rather than overly light and watery, and their flavors vary wonderfully from tree to tree. Commercial apples, which are bred for uniformity, durability, and appearance, not flavor. Wild apples are great raw, and far superior to commercial apples in pies, tarts, compotes, apple crisp, cobblers, applesauce, pancakes, stuffing, or any of the hundreds of dishes containing apples.

It’s difficult to core the early-season crab apples that taste good before they turn brown and get soft. So long as they're ripe and not astringent, I cook them with fruit juice, spices, and a sweetener, then pass them through a food mill (you can also use a strainer) to remove the seeds, creating a very flavorful applesauce. You can also puree the cooked fruit, seeds and all, in a blender, if the seeds don't bother you. Crushed raw apple seeds are poisonous if eaten in quantity, but cooking destroys the toxin.

The soft, orange-brown, ripe fruit of late-season crab apples tastes like a sour tamarind, with the texture of applesauce. If you enjoy sour flavors, you’ll love eating them right off the tree. And if you cook them in apple juice, sweeten them, and remove the seeds with a food mill or strainer, you'll get an exotic apple-tamarind butter.

Apple blossoms are considered edible, although if you eat them in large quantities, you might have problems with the same poison that's in the seeds. However, though some disagree with me, I don't think they taste very good.
Apples provide vitamin A, C, beta-carotene, and folate, plus the minerals calcium, phosphorus potassium, magnesium, and iron.

The malic and tartaric acids that produce the fruit’s tartness supposedly assists digestion of rich foods, and the pectin apples contain helps to remove toxic heavy metals such as lead, mercury, arsenic, and copper from the body, although if you're suffering from acute heavy metal poisoning, you may need more fast-acting medical treatment.

Pectin is also a non-soluable fiber that prevents the intestinal damage and constipation associated with a low-fiber diet. It's also been shown to reduce blood cholesterol by binding with bile acids, thereby decreasing absorption of cholesterol and fat in the small intestine. If you're on cholesterol-lowering medication, eating lots of pectin-rich food may allow you to reduce your dosage of the drug, which does have its dangers. Of course, you'll have to have your cholesterol levels monitored to see how much of an effect you're getting.

Furthermore, pectin slows absorption of sugars and carbohydrates in the intestine, increasing energy efficiency and slowing the rise of blood sugar. This benefits hypoglycemics and diabetics. Researchers at Yale’s Psychophysiology Center even found that the smell of spiced apples lowers blood pressure in people under stress.

That being said, there are also myths about apples that are simply untrue. I'm sure you've heard the old saw that an apple a day keeps the doctor away. I once led a tour for medical doctors focusing on medicinal plants, but when we came upon a wild apple tree loaded with fruit, instead of turning away, the doctors all loaded their bags with the wild apples!

Apple seeds contain amygdalin, which breaks down into cyanide. If you swallow a few seeds, the chemical won't be released in enough quantity to do any harm, and some people even think it's good for you, but if you crush the seeds and eat a bowlful, you could die.

Although cooking destroys this toxic compound, if it suddenly occurs to you that that you just happened to eat a whole bowlful of crushed, raw apple seeds, don't rush into the kitchen in a frenzy and start creating recipes—call 911, and Poison Control!

Hawthorn trees have edible fruit that looks like crab apples, but the branches have large thorns that look like knitting needles, and the seeds inside aren't arranged in five compartments, like the apple's.

Cherry blossoms resemble white apple blossoms, and the trees bloom at the same time, but you can tell the difference right away by looking at the bark. Cherry bark is smooth, reddish-brown, and horizontally streaked with white, whereas apple bark is gray and scaly.
Crab Apple
Wild apples are less perfect-looking than commercial apples, but way more tasty, especially cooked. Cut away any bad parts and head into the kitchen!
Hawthorn, Sweet Cherry
Wild Apple Cobbler
wild-apple-cobbler

This basic recipe turns tastes exotic because of the combination of wild apples and pineapples.

Crumble Layer

4 cups dry, whole-grain bread crumbs
1 cup walnuts or other nuts, chopped
1/4 tsp. salt
1-1/4 cups soy milk, nut milk, or oat milk
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/4 cup corn oil
2 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tsp. vanilla extract

Fruit Layer

7 medium-sized wild apples or commercial green apples, sliced
1-1/4 cup pineapple, diced
3/4 cup raisins
1/2 cup grape juice
1 tbs. lemon juice
1 tbs. kudzu or arrowroot
1 tbs. freshly grated orange rind
1 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1 tsp. liquid stevia

1. Purée the soy milk, lecithin, corn oil 1 tsp. of the liquid stevia, and vanilla in a blender.

2. Mix the bread crumbs, walnuts, and salt, and stir in the purée.

3. Mix together the fruit layer ingredients and transfer this to an oiled baking dish.

4. Spread the crumble layer on top.

5. Bake 50 minutes or until lightly browned and fragrant in a preheated 350 degree oven.

Serves 6 to 8

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 30 minutes

2wild-apple-tree-in-flower
White, red, or pink, apple blossoms put on quite a show every year in early spring, as the twiggy tree is loaded with color.

The apple tree's white, five-petaled flowers bloom in clusters on the many slender twigs, as the leaves are developing in early spring. And the elliptical, toothed, stalked, pointy-tipped, alternate, coarse leaves of this tree will reach the end of their existence when the yellow-green tinged, long-stalked, spherical red fruits ripen, in late fall.

Each apple blossom has five radially symmetrical petals and lots of long stamens, similar to the related rose.
Autumn Olive
autumn-olive
Elaeagnaceae, the oleaster family

Autumn olives ripen mainly in mid-fall, although some bushes ripen earlier or later than average, in early or late fall. When I first started foraging in the early 1980s, the season was from early November to New Years in the Northeast. But due to climate change, the flowers begin blooming a month earlier, causing the fruit to ripen much earlier too.

[-CORRECTION: As anyone who listens to talk radio knows, climate change is a myth perpetuated by all the climate scientists who get published in disreputable, peer-reviewed, international science journals, conspirators who know we're really heading into another ice age, but want to deceive everyone so they can get more funding (fortunately, they were smart enough to go into science to get rich, rather than such unlucrative professions as finance or corporate law). So the real explanation must be that Al Gore is sneaking out in the middle of the night to fool the autumn olive bushes (and all the other species that have so drastically shifted their life cycles—he's keeping himself quite busy) into flowering and fruiting early, so he can make more money selling his books!]

Sunny and partially shaded places with poor soil (like legumes, it can get nitrogen from the atmosphere), disturbed habitats, fields, thickets, parks, pastures, hay fields, roadsides, rights-of-way, and overgrown areas near the seashore

Autumn olives grow throughout most of Eastern North America and Ontario, plus Kansas, Nebraska, Washington, Oregon, and Montana, and there's no reason to doubt that this foreign invasive species won't keep spreading to other regions.
East Asia

You can spot autumn olive bushes from quite a distance, even while driving because of the distinctive silvery cast of the bush's leaves' undersides. Then look for a large shrub with gray bark, growing in dense stands, with lance-shaped to oval, dull green, dotted leaves that are silvery underneath. There are crowded clusters of small, fragrant, scaly, tubular, four-parted yellowish flowers, hanging from the leaf axils in early spring, and dense clusters of spherical, stalked, silver-dotted red berries in autumn.

This large, twiggy, speckled, sometimes thorny shrub, with smooth, gray bark, grows from 12 to 20 feet tall, often in orchard-like stands.

The lance-shaped to oval, speckled leaves are dull green above and covered with lustrous, silvery-white scales beneath. With wavy, toothless leaf margins, they grow from two to four inches long and from 0.75 to 1.5 inches wide.

Growing from the leaf axis, crowded clusters of five to two fragrant, tubular, scaly, four-parted, pale yellow, radially-symmetrical flowers, about 0.5 inch long, bloom in early spring, after the leaves have appeared.

Dense clusters of spherical, stalked, silver-dotted red berries, 0.25 to 0.75 inch across, ripen in the same leaf axils in autumn. Inside are several small, soft, yellowish, oblong, ribbed seeds.

•Large, twiggy, speckled, sometimes thorny shrub, with smooth, gray bark, usually in dense stands
•Lance-shaped to oval, speckled leaves, two to four inches long and from 0.75 to 1.5 inches wide
•Leaves dull green above, covered with lustrous, silvery-white scales below
•Crowded clusters of five to ten fragrant, tubular, scaly, four-parted, pale yellow, radially-symmetrical flowers, 0.5 inch long, hanging growing from the leaf axils in early spring
•Dense clusters of spherical, stalked, silver-dotted, red berries, 0.25 to 0.75 inch across, growing from the leaf axils in autumn
•Small, soft, yellowish, oblong, ribbed seeds inside the berries

Sample all the bushes you can before collecting. The largest, softest, juiciest berries are usually the best, while the small, hard, dry ones are the worst. Some people prefer more tart berries, others, especially kids, prefer the sweeter ones.

Use a key ring and clip to attach a food container with a hole punched near the top to your belt, to free both hands, and bring additional containers to transfer your harvest after you fill your collecting container. You can harvest very large quantities of this top-rate fruit under favorable circumstances.

The soft, ripe, juicy berries taste like a wonderful combination of pomegranates, plums, currants, cranberries, and raspberries, but better. Enjoy autumn olives raw, and spit out the seeds if desired (or eat the seeds too, if you want), or cook the fruit. I simmer it about ten minutes with a sweetener and a thickener to make jam, pie filling, or sauce, then strain out the seeds with a food mill. You can also make the purée without sweeteners or thickeners, and add those later, depending on what you're going to make. I use the it in cookies, cakes, ice cream, sherbet, and other desserts.

The berries freeze well both before and after cooking, and you can dehydrate the thickened, sweetened, strained pulp to make a fantastic fruit leather. I've [-also] made a delicious white wine out of autumn olive, and the Japanese also make a liqueur by soaking the berries in wine for six months.

Autumn olives are high in vitamin A, C, E, and beta-carotene, plus essential fatty acids (very unusual for a fruit) and the antioxidants phytoene and cryptoxanthins. They have up to 17 times more of the anti-oxidant lycopene than tomatoes, making them useful in preventing or fighting prostate cancer, and possibly other malignancies.
An infusion of the seeds is used as an expectorant for cough and pulmonary problems in traditional Chinese medicine.

Friendships and relationships have been destroyed by people arguing over which autumn olive bush has the best-tasting berries—stick to discussing less controversial subjects, such as politics, religion, and global warming! And while you're at it, watch out for the occasional thorns.
Autumn Berry, Japanese Silverberry, Umbellate Oleaster
This common, invasive shrub produces a little-known but fantastic-flavored, super-healthful berry in huge quantites.

2. Stir in the raisins and walnuts

Wild Blackberries
wild-blackberries
Rosaceae the rose family
Blackberries are in season in the second half of the summer in the Northeast, but as early as June in the Deep South.

Full sun, partial shade, poor soil, thickets, clearings in the woods, along roadsides and paths, on hillsides and mountain slopes, in overgrown fields, disturbed habitats, ditches, hedgerows, empty lots, and bushy areas near the seashore. Along fencerows, in pine barrens, on mountain slopes, in young woodlands, along woodland margins, and in wetlands.

Various species grow throughout North America and much of the temperate world.

The common blackberry grows throughout the most of the Eastern US, and in in CA, Southern Canada, and British Columbia, but not in the southernmost Eastern states.

The cutleaf blackberry grows in the Northeast, the Pacific Northwest, plus California, Colorado, Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming, but not in Northern New England.

The dewberry grows throughout most of the eastern half of North America.

The California blackberry grows in all the West Coast states plus Idaho, Montana, and British Columbia.

The cloudberry is a circumpolar species that grows in New York, Minnesota, Maine, and all of Canada.
Blackberries are also native to Eurasia and South America, so we have both native and foreign species growing throughout North America.

Here's a good way to collect lots of bramble berries with most effectively:

1. Plan your harvest in advance, choosing a relatively cool day, and forage early in the morning, so you can wear long pants and sleeves to protect yourself from thorns and mosquitoes without getting too hot.

2. Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking.

3. Wear heavy-duty work gloves with the fingertips of your picking hand's glove cut off (kitchen shears will do this) to protect your hands as much as possible. (Be sure to remove the glove from your hand before cutting off the fingertips!)

4. When your container and stomach are full, transfer your harvest into one of your empty containers, and resume picking.

Blackberries keep ripening for nearly a month, so you can return for the unripe ones later. Some years are better for blackberries than others. If there's too much rain when the flowers are blooming, for example, pollinators can't do their job and the berries fail to form. Or if there are too many cloudy or rainy days when the berries are developing, they become stunted from lack of sunlight and don't get sweet. But in other years conditions are perfect, and there are more berries than even the very large groups that attend my tours can come close to picking!

Delicious raw or cooked, wild blackberries, which are much tastier than commercial blackberries, impart a powerful, earthy tang to complement their fruitiness. They're excellent in pies, puddings, cobblers, ice cream, cakes, cereals, smoothies, fruit sauces, jams, jellies, and virtually any dessert. And they're especially good in desserts that also include apples—a great companion fruit.

Unlike commercial blackberries, wild blackberries have hard seeds, which are very annoying in recipes that involve puréeing the fruit, but you can easily eliminate the seeds by passing the purée through a strainer or food mill.

Blackberries are rich in potassium, magnesium, calcium, iron, phosphorous, beta-carotene, and vitamin C. They're also very high in healthful polyphenol antioxidants, i.e., ellagic acid, tannins, ellagitannins, quercetin, gallic acid, anthocyanins and cyanidins. These substances have been shown reduce the risk of contracting many common chronic diseases such as cancer, heart disease, and diabetes.

DANGER! In Shakespeare's day, people called lawyers bramble bushes because they have sharp thorns, grab on to you, and they don't let go until they've drawn blood! And that's still true today. So when you pick blackberries, be sure to protect yourself from the thorns, and from any lurking lawyers!

And don't eat blackberries after old Michaelmas Day, Oct. 11. According to English folklore, that's the day God ejected Satan from Heaven. He fell, kicking and screaming, and landed on a blackberry bush, which scratched him badly. In revenge, he peed on the blackberries, making them unfit for human consumption for the rest of the year!

People confuse raspberries (Rubus spp.), especially black raspberries, with blackberries, but raspberries have round stems, without blackberries' flat surfaces, and the fruit is hollow—the receptacle (the fruit's base) remains behind when you pick the fruit, unlike the blackberry, where the receptacle comes along for the ride, so blackberries are never hollow.

Mulberries (Morus spp.) look a little like blackberries too, but these edible berries hang from the branches of trees on slender fruit stalks, unlike blackberries, which grow on a base on thorny canes.

Poison ivy and poison oak have palmate-compound leaves and often grow near, or right with blackberries, but their leaves aren't sharply toothed, there's no thorny cane, and the flowers and fruits are completely different. As long as you're on the lookout for these plants when you pick blackberries, you'll easily be able to avoid brushing against them.
Caneberry, Bramble

Wild blackberries look like commercial blackberries, but, as often happens when comparing wild and commercial foods of the same species, smaller and less perfect-looking. But, as also commonly happens, the flavor of the wild fruit is way superior.
Black Raspberry, Mulberries
Poison Ivy, Poison Oak

blackberry-kasha-breakfast-cereal

1)Common Blackberry with Flowers, and with Ripe Fruit
1common-blackberry-with-flowers,-and-with-ripe-fru

The common blackberry has thorny, woody, thorny, angled stems and three- to five-parted toothed, palmate compound leaves. Short, loose, terminal racemes of five-petaled, radially-symmetrical white flowers, with many bushy stamens surrounding the closely packed central pistils, grow in loose terminal racemes. The elliptical, black, aggregate fruits grow in the same racemes, above five sepals.
2)Common Blackberry Flower

This radially-symmetrical, flower has five ovate to oblong white petals, and many bushy stamens that surround the tightly packed central pistils.

Each shiny, rounded, blackberry consists of many tiny berries, all produced from one flower, and each has its own seed. The berries are bound together, which is why it's called an aggregate fruit. Five sepals grow at the base of each berry.

5raspberry-and-blackberry-stems
The black raspberry stem (left) is round, whereas the common blackberry stem (right) is angled, with flat planes, making it easy to tell these relatives apart any time of the year.
4)Cutleaf Blackberry in Flower
4cutleaf-blackberry-in-flower

The palmate-compound leaves of this invasive European species has more deeply cut leaflets than the common blackberry, but the five-parted white flower, with closely packed pistils surrounded by many bushy stamens, is quite similar to other blackberry flowers. [-And] It will produce a superb fruit.
Black Raspberry
black-raspberry
Rosaceae the rose family
The berries ripen in early summer.
Full sunlight or partially sunny thickets, trailsides, overgrown vacant lots and fields, open deciduous woodlands, woodland borders, savannas, fence rows, and disturbed habitats.
Most of Eastern North America, but not Florida, Louisiana, or Texas

Look for an erect or arching bramble with many woody, rounded, thorny, blue-green stems coated with a white, waxy powder. It's three- to five-parted palmate compound leaves are whitish underneath and pair with short, flattened terminal racemes of three to seven small, white, five-petaled flowers. Flat-topped clusters of hollow, ovoid to hemispheric, aggregate fruits can be red-purple to black.

Growing six to 12 feet wide, this erect or arching bramble has many woody, rounded stems called canes, growing three to six feet tall and arising from perennial, woody, branching taproots. Sparse, short, curved prickles arm the canes, which root where they touch the ground. A white, waxy powder called a bloom, which looks like a chemical spray, coats the blue-green stems.

First-year stems called primocanes bear only leaves. The second year, the primocanes produce lateral branches called floricanes, which grow flowers and fruit. The canes then die back to the roots at the end of the growing season, and the cycle repeats.

The palmate-compound leaves are sharply double-toothed, and white-hairy beneath. Leaves of the primocanes have three leaflets, while those of the floricanes have five. The oval to heart-shaped leaflets grow about three inches long and two inches across. The leading leaflet has a short leaf stalk, while the side leaflets have next to none.

Short, flattened terminal racemes of three to seven white to pink flowers 0.5 inch across, with five elliptical to oblong petals, bloom in mid- to late spring. Five distinct, slender, spreading, triangular sepals, longer than the petals, extend beyond the edge of the flowers, and beyond the edge of subsequent berries.

The hollow, ovoid to hemispheric aggregate fruit, 0.33 to 0.5 inch across, grows in the same clusters, ripening in early summer, and changing from green to red-purple to black. Each subsection of the fruit, called a druplet, contains one small, hard seed.

•Erect or arching bramble with many woody, rounded, thorny stems, three to six feet tall
•Blue-green stems coated with a white, waxy powder
•Palmate compound leaves divided into three to five leaflets
•Leaflets whitish underneath
•Short, flattened terminal racemes of three to seven white, five-petaled flowers 0.5 inch across
•Five slender, spreading, triangular sepals, longer than the petals and the fruit
•Hollow, ovoid to hemispheric, aggregate fruit, 0.33 to 0.5 inch across, growing in flat-topped clusters, ripening from green to red-purple to black

Here's a good way to collect lots of bramble berries with most effectively[Here's the most effective way to collect lots of bramble berries]: Plan your harvest in advance, choosing a relatively cool day and forage early in the morning, so you can wear long pants and sleeves to protect yourself from thorns and mosquitoes without getting too hot. Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. Wear heavy-duty work gloves with the fingertips of your picking hand's glove cut off (kitchen shears will do this) to protect your hands as much as possible. When your container and stomach are full, transfer your harvest into one of your empty containers, and resume picking.

Collect only berries that are black throughout and come off the bush easily. These are the ripest and tastiest. Unripe ones, which you have to yank off, and usually still have traces of red, are bitter.

This fruit is much better-tasting than commercial black raspberries. Enjoy it raw or cooked, and use it in virtually any dessert recipe, such as cereals, pancakes, muffins, sauces, pies, fruit salads, compotes, puddings, ice creams, jams, jellies, and drinks. In dishes that will be puréed, strain out the hard seeds after puréeing. Otherwise they get to be quite annoying.

Black raspberries provide vitamins A, E, K, C, thiamin, ribovlavin, niacin, B6, pantothenic acid, and folate, as well as the minerals calcium, iron, manganese, magnesium, phosphorus, potassium, sodium, zinc, copper, manganese, and selenium. They're also loaded with health-promoting antioxidants such as ellagic acid, the flavonoids quercetin and kaempferol, and the cyanidin-based molecules cyanidin-3-glucosylrutinoside and cyanidin-3-rutinoside.

Research has linked the anthocyanins, which give black raspberries their color, with improved vision, cardiovascular health, memory retention in old age, and reduced risk of hypertension. Foods containing these substances have been demonstrated to lower the risk of contracting a wide variety of diseases, including cancer (eating a very large serving of black raspberries every day has already been proven to prevent esophageal cancer, but only if you're a rat), and they're antimicrobial too, inhibiting pathogens such as Candida albicans, which causes yeast infections and may aggravate irritable bowel syndrome.

As with wild red raspberries (R. strigosus), an infusion of the leaves and roots is used as an astringent for diarrhea, especially for children, since it's more gentle than other herbal astringents, but it's main use is as a tonic to the strengthen the female reproductive system. As such, it's been used for centuries by Native American, European, and Asian herbalists, and it contains constituents that both stimulate and relax the uterus. It's used during the last 3 months of gestation, during childbirth, and to lessen the symptoms of menopause, as well as for menstrual cramps. It's also used for nausea and to suppress vomiting, as a gargle for tonsillitis and mouth inflammations, as a poultice for sores, and as a wash for conjunctivitis, minor wounds, burns, and varicose ulcers.

Black raspberries are finally being tested in humans to see if compounds they contain are effective in shrinking malignant esophageal and colon tumors.

A similar, closely related Western American species, R. leucodermis, is also called black raspberry, and it's just as good.

People confuse black raspberries with the related, edible blackberries (Rubus spp), but blackberries aren't hollow, and their stems are angled, not ridged.

Poison ivy (Toxicodendron radicans) and poison oak (T. diversilobum and T. pubescens) have palmate-compound leaves and often grows near, or along with black raspberries, but the leaves aren't sharply toothed, there's no thorny cane, and the flowers and fruits are completely different. As long as you're on the lookout for these plants when you pick black raspberries, you'll be able to avoid them.
Wild Black Raspberry, Black Caps, Black Cap Raspberry, Thimbleberry, Scotch Cap
Similar to commercial black raspberries, this wild version has far more flavor.
Black Raspberry Pops
black-raspberry-pops
1)Black Raspberry Fruit
1black-raspberry-fruit

Black raspberry canes have sparse, curved prickles, toothed, three- to five-parted, palmate-compound leaves, and flat-topped clusters of shiny, black, hollow, round to hemispheric, aggregate fruits. Long, triangular sepals extend beyond the fruit's circumference.
2)Black Raspberry Flower
2black-raspberry-flower

The black raspberry's flower consists of five white, oval to elliptical petals, so small that they don't overlap. Many bushy stamens surround the packed, central pistils. And triangular sepals, longer than the petals, extend beyond the rest of the flower's periphery. Alternate, palmate-compound leaves, with three to five pointed, double-toothed leaflets, grow on prickly stems.
3)Black Raspberry Cane with Fruit
3black-raspberry-cane-with-fruit

These spherical to hemispheric aggregate fruits turn black after being green, red and purple. Five long, triangular sepals extend beyond their edges. The fruits grow on thorny, round canes with three- to five-parted, double-toothed, palmate-compound leaves.
Blueberries and Huckleberries
blueberries-and-huckleberries
Ericaceae, the heath family
The berries of the various species come into season throughout the summer, although once I found huckleberries in early fall.
Moist, acidic, partly shaded or shaded habitats, mountainous regions, thickets, along roadsides and lakesides, and in swamps and bogs.
Eastern, Northwestern, and Southeastern North America, but not Florida

Look for small or tall shrubs with slender, thornless twigs, growing in acidic soil and smooth-edged or finely-toothed, short-stalked, elliptical, sometimes leathery, alternate leaves that turn reddish-purple in autumn. Terminal clusters of white (sometimes tinged with pink, red, or green), bell-shaped five-parted flowers bloom in the spring, and spherical, blue or dark blue berries form with a five-parted flared crown at the end.

•Small or tall shrubs with slender, thornless twigs, growing in acidic soil
•Smooth-edged or finely-toothed, short-stalked, elliptical, sometimes leathery, alternate leaves from 0.5 to 3 inches long and 0.2 to 1.5 inches long
•Leaves turning reddish-purple in autumn
•Terminal clusters of white, bell-shaped five-parted flowers (sometimes tinged with pink, red, or green) about 0.75 inch long, blooming in the spring
•Spherical berries 0.2 to 0.6 inch across, first green, then red-purple, ripening to blue or dark blue
•Berry with a 5-parted flared crown at the tip

Pick by hand, and attach a container with a perforation to your belt, using a key ring and key clip, or use a blueberry scoop, which looks like a saw-edged box with a handle.

The quality of fruit varies from year to year. A light frost when the bushes are flowering, for example, will prevent the berries from forming altogether.

Use wild blueberries and huckleberries the same way you use blueberries you buy in the store, just be prepared for a more intense, rich flavor. Add them to cereal, put them in shakes, make jam or ice cream with them, mix them with other fruits to make a fruit salad, or bake them into muffins, pies, cobblers, or cakes. You need very little thickener when you cook with them because they contain their pectin, the same substance that thickens applesauce.
Blueberries provide manganese, vitamins B6, C, and K, plus healthful anthocyanins, proanthocyanidins, resveratrol, flavonols, and tannins.

Europeans call a circumpolar relative, the bilberry (V. myrtillus), a blueberry. This edible relative has berries that grow singly or in pairs, not in clusters, but like blueberries or huckleberries, and doesn't grow in the contiguous 48 states. Some other close relatives of blueberries and huckleberries (Vaccinium spp.) with different features aren't palatable, but they won't poison you.

The blue, edible berry of the juneberry (Amelanchier spp.) also has a flared crown, but this unrelated shrub's bark is smooth and gray, the flower isn’t bell-shaped, it usually ripens toward the start of summer, and it contains relatively large, soft, almond-flavored seeds.

The black chokeberry (Aronia melancarpa) bush, on the other hand, has berries you also might confuse with blueberries, but there's a five-parted star pattern that's impressed into the tip of the non-poisonous berry, not a flared crown, and the five-parted, radially symmetrical flowers are different from the blueberries' bell-like ones. Too astringent and awful-tasting to eat, there's nothing you can do with this aptly named fruit (often confused with the edible chokecherry, Prunus virginiana, due to the similarity of their names) but to put it through a juicer and drink the juice, sweetened.

The garden supply industry, trying to hawk black nightshade (Solanum melanocerasum), a common weed with poisonous leaves, to gardeners, under a less sinister name, call it "garden huckleberry," sowing more confusion than sales. This non-woody relative of tomatoes has edible, spherical, black berries which, unlike blueberries lack a crown.

There are many spherical, blue berries, but no poisonous ones have a flared crown, so you'd have to be careless to the point of negligence to poison yourself with something like European buckthorn (Rhamnus cathartica), which has no crown, and is different-looking from blueberries in all other respects too.
Compared to its cultivated counterpart, this well-known wild fruit more than makes up in flavor what it lacks in size.
Chokeberries, Black Nightshade
European Buckthorn
Wild Blueberry Jello
wild-blueberry-jello

Wild blueberries or huckleberries will add an exotic touch to this familiar fruit dessert, which jells due to a seaweed traditional to Japanese cuisine, rather than the more usual animal hoof gelatin.

4 cups apple juice
1 cup wild or commercial blueberries, or huckleberries
1 cup strawberries, sliced
1/2 cup raspberries or other berries
1/2 cup raisins
1 green apple, chopped
2 tbs. agar flakes
1 tbs. liquid stevia
1 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1/2 tsp. dried wild or commercial mint, ground
1/4 tsp. powdered ginger
1/4 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1/4 tsp. orange extract

Bring all ingredients to a boil over medium heat in a saucepan, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, uncovered, 10 minutes, or until the apples are soft and the agar has dissolved.

2. Transfer into an oiled mold or bowl, chill until jelled, place the moldin hot water to loosen, and invert onto a platter to serve.

Serves 6

Preparation/Cooking Time: 15 minutes

Jelling Time: 3 hours
1)Highbush Blueberry
1highbush-blueberry

This tall bush has elliptical, short-stalked, toothed, alternate leaves, slender, green twigs, white to greenish, bell-shaped, five-parted flowers, and spherical, blue berries with a flaring, five-parted crown. Smaller than commercial blueberries, it's way tastier, and arguably the best wild blueberry to eat.
2)Huckleberry
2huckleberry
Similar to the related blueberry, this delicious fruit has alternate, toothless, elliptical leaves, and a smaller berry that's almost black. When you eat it, you'll notice tiny, crunchy seeds.
Carnelian Cherry
carnelian-cherry
Cornaceae, the dogwood family
The berries usually ripen in late summer, although I've eaten fruit from bushes on the grounds of in the Canterbury School in New Milford, CT, that ripens every October.
These bushes grow in sunny or partially shaded cultivated areas, in parks, and around buildings. I've only once seen them spread into the wild.
These popular ornamental bushes are planted throughout the US, especially in the northern half of the country.
Southern Europe and Southwest Asia

Look for a large, rounded shrub or small tree with dense branches beginning near the ground. Carnelian cherry grows mainly in cultivated areas, with scaly, gray-brown and yellow-tan, patchy bark. It has opposite, elliptical, untoothed, medium-sized leaves with pointed tips, wavy margins, and parallel veins on each side of the midrib. Clusters of tiny, bright yellow, four-sepaled flowers form in late winter or very early spring, and give way to juicy, olive-sized and -shaped, short-stalked, red or dark purple berries.

•Large, rounded shrub or small tree with dense branches beginning near the ground, growing mainly in cultivated areas
•Scaly, patchy, gray-brown and yellow-tan bark
•Opposite, elliptical, short-stalked, untoothed, medium-sized leaves with pointed tips
•Parallel veins curving to follow the leaf's wavy margin on both sides of the midrib
•Tiny, bright yellow, odorless, four-sepaled flowers blooming in tight, rounded clusters of ten to 25, at the ends of the smooth, slender, green twigs, in late winter or very early spring
•Juicy, olive-sized and -shaped, short-stalked berries, ripening from bright red to dark purple, mainly in late summer
•One large, hard, light tan, oblong, football-shaped, ribbed seed inside each berry

Collect the delicate ripe and nearly ripe fruit from the ground or from the branches (which you can shake over a dropcloth if the density of nearly ripe fruit is great enough), and place them in separate containers. You may store ripe fruit under refrigeration for a few days before using or freezing. [-And] [T]ransfer the unripe fruit to a shallow bowl, unrefrigerated until they ripen, which can take from a few days to nearly a week. You can hasten ripening by storing them with apples, which release ethylene gas to accomplish this.

During periods of drought, you may [-also] find dehydrated ripe fruit on the branches which you can also collect and eat like raisins with pits, or soak in fruit juice (pear juice, which isn't acidic, works best for this sour fruit) to rehydrate, if desired.

Unlike most other fruits, this one can ripen off the bush. Don't eat bright red berries. They're under-ripe, astringent, and way too sour. Wait until they turn dark purple and become very soft. They develop a delicious sour flavor, with overtones of cherries, lemons, cranberries, and plums.

Enjoy ripe carnelian cherries raw, or cook them with a thickener and sweetener, strain out the seeds with a food mill, and use the tart, flavorful pulp to make jam, cake or cake topping, cookies, pies, ice cream, puddings, or any other kind of dessert. Only about 0.33 of your carnelian cherries will become pulp, but the sour flavor is so intense, you can mix the pulp with other ingredients and stretch your hard-earned wild harvest without dissipating the berries' taste.

Apparently, you can roast and grind the seeds and use them as a coffee substitute, but I've never tried this.

Carnelian cherries are an excellent source of vitamin C, potassium, calcium, iron, zinc, manganese, copper, and sodium. They also contain healthful antioxidant phenolic compounds, typical of brightly colored berries.

The carnelian cherry is a dogwood, not a cherry (Prunus spp.). Although the fruit superficially resembles a cherry, cherries are spherical, not oblong, the leaves are alternate, not opposite, and the flowers are completely different too. The carnelian cherry’s fruit also superficially resembles a plum (Prunus spp.), but plum trees, again, have alternate leaves and different flowers.

The common spicebush's small, fragrant flowers look a little like the carnelian cherry's scentless ones, and they bloom at the same time, sometimes side-by-side but the spicebush, which has fragrant twigs, develops alternate, not opposite leaves. You can observe this in the leaf buds before the leaves develop. Before the leaves develop, the leaf buds are alternate, while all features on the carnelian cherry's twigs are opposite. The spicebush's allspice-scented, edible berries, which ripen in autumn, are much smaller than the carnelian cherry's as well.
Carnelian Cherry Dogwood, European Cornel
These berries are delicious when dark purple and completely ripe, and will ripen off the bush—very unusual for wild fruit.
Sweet Cherry, Common Spicebush
Carnelian Pecan Cookies
carnelian-pecan-cookies

The sourness of carnelian cherries adds just the right bite to these sweet, chewy, spiced cookies. There are lots of ingredients, but putting them together is quite simple.

Dry Ingredients

2-1/2 cups (12 oz.) sweet brown rice flour + 1-1/2 cup (6 oz.) barley flour or 18 oz. any whole grain flour
1/4 cup arrowroot or kudzu
1/4 cup flax seeds, ground into 1/2 cup meal
1 cup pecans, ground
1 tsp. cream of tartar
1/2 tsp. baking soda
1 tbs. cinnamon, ground
1 tsp. cloves, ground
1 tsp. coriander, ground

To Blend

1 cup apple juice
1/2 cup corn oil
6 tbs. carnelian cherry purée, made from 1-1/4 cups fruit, cooked and passed through a food mill
1/4 tsp. lecithin granules
2 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tsp. vanilla
1/2 tsp. cranberry extract (optional)
1 tsp. butter pecan extract (optional)
1 tsp. Grand Marnier extract (optional)

Other Ingredients

1 cup raisins
1 cup pecans, chopped

1. Mix together the dry ingredients.

2. Purée the ingredients to blend in a blender.

3. Mix the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Don’t overmix.

4. Stir in the other ingredients. Don’t over mix.

5. Shape into 2 dozen round cookies and place on 2 non-stick baking mats on 2 cookie sheets, or on 2 oiled cookie sheets.

6. Bake 20 minutes in a preheated 400 degree oven, or until an inserted cake tester or toothpick emerges clean.

7. Cool on racks.

Makes 2 dozen cookies

Preparation Time: 30 minutes

Cooking Time: 20 minutes
1)Carnelian Cherry with Fruit—Two Views
1carnelian-cherry-with-fruit—two-views

The opposite, elliptical, short-stalked leaves have parallel veins and no teeth. The fruit clusters have short-stalked, red, olive-sized and -shaped fruit hanging from the long slender, light twigs [-(which boys stripped of their leaves in the Bronze Age and used to safely learn swordsmanship). These features make this cultivated, under appreciated fruit easy to recognize.]
2)Carnelian Cherry in Flower
2carnelian-cherry-in-flower

The carnelian cherry's yellow flowers grow in dense clusters, making up for their small size. They're commonly planted to add color to parks (this one's growing in Central Park) very early in the season, when there's hardly any botanical activity. This bush begins branching close to ground level, and, as with all dogwoods, the flowers, tiny and clustered in this species, have four sepals.
3)Carnelian Cherry Branches with Berries
3carnelian-cherry-branches-with-berries

The carnelian cherry's patchy, dark gray bark flakes off, revealing the yellow-brown cambium beneath. The short-stalked, opposite, elliptical leaves have wavy margins, but no teeth, and the curved veins on each side of the midrib run parallel to each other. The olive sized and shaped fruit is bright red at first, then dark purple. Sometimes, as here, it becomes almost black, like a cured black olive. Inside each berry is a hard, football-shaped, light tan, ribbed seed.
Black Nightshade
black-nightshade
Solanaceae, the potato or nightshade family
Berries continue to ripen from mid-summer through late fall.
Sunny or shady habitats, wooded areas, edge habitats, roadsides, agricultural and wild fields, gardens, and disturbed habitats.
Many of the Eastern states, all of the West Coast, plus eastern and western Canada.
South America

Look for a slender, much-branched, medium-sized herbaceous plant with downy or smooth, oval to heart-shaped, deep green, medium-sized leaves that have wavy or coarsely toothed edges and pointed tips. The drooping clusters of small, five-petaled, white flowers have a central cluster of bright yellow anthers and drooping clusters of spherical, pea-sized, stalked, black berries with five green sepals.

This much-branched, herbaceous, weedy looking plant grows from 1 to 3.5 feet tall, with a slender stem, sometimes ridged or fuzzy, and fibrous root plus a shallow taproot, growing most often in disturbed habitats.

The downy or smooth, oval to heart-shaped, deep green leaves grow from one to 1.66 inches long and one to 2.5 inches across, with wavy or coarsely toothed edges, a pointed tip, and a leafstalk 0.5 to one inch long that's winged on its upper portion.

Four to nine star-shaped, stalked flowers grow in drooping, umbrella-like clusters in the leaf axils or tops of the stems. Each flower, between 0.3 and 0.5 across, has a central cluster of bright yellow anthers and five white to greenish or light violet petals that bend backwards with age.

Seedy, spherical, pea-sized, tomato-like berries 0.25 to 0.75 inch in diameter, with five green sepals, begin green and become dull black.

•Much-branched herbaceous plant one to 3.5 feet tall, with slender, sometimes fuzzy, green or dull purplish stem
•Downy or smooth, oval to heart-shaped, deep green leaves one to 1.66 inches long and one to 2.5 inches across, with wavy or coarsely toothed edges, and pointed tips
•Drooping clusters of four to nine small flowers, at stem tips and leaf axils
•Small, star-shaped flowers with a central cluster of bright yellow anthers, and five white, greenish, or light violet petals that bend backwards with age
•Seedy, spherical, pea-sized berries 0.25 to 0.75 inch in diameter, beginning green and turning dull black
•Berries with five green sepals

Pick the completely ripe, black berries with your fingers, and transfer any you don't eat into a food container. The berries are small, but if you can get the help of kids, who love collecting berries, you'll greatly speed up the process (unless they eat all the berries!)

This plant has a reputation of being poisonous and the leaves are dangerous, but over the years people around the world have been eating the completely ripe berries without being harmed. My family and I (and hundreds of my tour participants) have been eating them too, and I consider them to be safe.

The berries taste like sweet tomatoes—quite delicious. However, they're quite small, so even when you find them in quantity, it takes a long time to collect enough for a recipe, so I use them mainly as a trail nibble or garnish, for which they're outstanding.

The unripe green berries are very poisonous, with high concentrations of the neurotoxin solanine. Eating them can cause nausea, vomiting and diarrhea, followed by cardiovascular and central nervous system symptoms, dehydration, electrolyte imbalance (from the diarrhea), and cardiac arrhythmia. Circulatory and respiratory failure, possibly followed by death, although this is rare. There's no antidote, but with ER symptomatic supportive therapy, if you survive 24 hours, you should recover. Better yet, don't eat the green berries in the first place!

The leaves contain the same poison, and even small amounts of an infusion of the leaves causes perspiration and purging of the bowels. Nevertheless, people in India, Africa, and East Asia eat the boiled leaves and discard the toxic water. Still, the boiled leaves contain enough poison that some individuals get very sick from eating the same meal that leaves others unaffected.

I knew one such individual, who got her misadventure published in Science News Magazine. She ate some cooked black nightshade greens with Thai friends who were unharmed, but she got very, very sick for days. After she recovered, her friends told her that such severe reactions are not unfamiliar in their culture, and such individuals simply avoid this traditional vegetable (for some reason, a close brush with death tends to have that affect!)

And even if you don't develop symptoms, who knows what other harm this nerve toxin might be doing? So, this is one traditionally eaten wild green I strongly urge everyone to avoid. There are too many other tasty, healthful, safe wild greens to warrant the known and unknown risks of eating these leaves.
Garden Huckleberry, Duscle, Garden Nightshade, Hound's Berry, Petty Morel, Wonder Berry, Small-fruited Black Nightshade, Popolo, Sunberry
These small, shiny, black berries taste like sweet tomatoes. The green, unripe ones, on the other hand, are highly toxic.
Black Nightshade with Flower and Berries
black-nightshade-with-flower-and-berries

This herbaceous plant has alternate, heart-shaped to oval, sometimes fuzzy leaves. It has drooping, five-petaled, white flowers with clustered yellow anthers in the center, plus drooping clusters of small, spherical, stalked, dull-black berries. Beware, the unripe green berries are highly poisonous.
Polenta with Black Nightshade
polenta-with-black-nightshade

Here’s a classic recipe made even more healthful and tasty: Vege-sal adds some oomph and lowers the sodium content compared to table salt, soy cheese replaces dairy cheese, corn oil supersedes butter, the optional use of wild mushrooms improves the flavor further, and garnishing it with black nightshade berries makes it even more special.

6 cups rapidly boiling water
2 cups yellow corn grits or polenta (they're the same thing)
1 tsp. Vege-sal or 1/2 tsp. salt
1/4 tsp. black pepper, ground
3 tbs. corn oil
1 10-oz. package of vegan Jack or vegan cheddar cheese, grated
1 cup cooked wild or commercial mushrooms, chopped (optional)
1/2 cup ripe black nightshade berries, or chopped, ripe cherry tomatoes

1. Stir the corn grits and Vege-sal into the water and bring to a boil over high heat, stirring constantly.

2. Reduce the heat to low and simmer about 6 minutes or until thickened, stirring constantly.

3. Stir in the mushrooms, corn oil, and pepper, and pour onto a non-stick baking mat on a cookie sheet, or onto an oiled cookie sheet, and allow to cool.

4. Spread the cheese over the solidified polenta and bake in a preheated 350 degree oven 30 minutes, or until the cheese has melted.

5. Serve garnished with the nightshade berries

Serves 6

Preparation Time: 20 minutes

Resting Time: 20 minutes

Cooking Time: 30 minutes
Beach Plum
beach-plum
Rosaceae, the rose family
Beach plums are in season from late summer through early fall.
This salt-tolerant shrub grows on sunny, sand dunes near the seashore.
Sadly for people who live elsewhere, this prized fruit grows only along the northeast coast of the US, from Maine to Maryland.

Look for a much-branched, thornless shrub growing in dense stands on seashore dunes with finely-toothed, oval, alternate, stalked, medium-sized leaves. It's showy clusters of small, five-petaled white flowers, are long-stalked, fragrant, and radially symmetrical. The long-stalked, grape-sized, thin-skinned spherical fruits can be green, red-purple, or blue-black.

Usually forming dense stands, this much-branched, thornless shrub, with rough, reddish-brown bark streaked with horizontal, white lines, usually grows from three to eight (sometimes 12) feet tall, with a spread equal to its height.

The finely-toothed, oval, alternate, stalked, dark green leaves grow from one to two inches long and from 0.5 to one inch broad.

Clustered from two to four, the showy, long-stalked, fragrant, white flowers, with five radially-symmetrical petals and many long, red, pink, and white filaments tipped with yellow anthers, barely grow over 0.5 inch across.

Powdered with a faint, whitish, powdery bloom, the spherical, grape-sized fruit grows up to one inch in diameter, with a thin skin covering the flesh, and a single large, flattened stone inside. Green at first, the plum becomes red, then purple, and finally blue-black.

•Much-branched, densely branched, thornless shrub, usually three to eight feet tall and equally wide, usually in dense stands
•Rough, reddish-brown bark streaked with horizontal, white lines
•Sand dune habitat
•Finely-toothed, oval, alternate, stalked, dark green leaves, one to two inches long and 0.5 to one inch broad
• Clusters of two to four showy, long-stalked, fragrant, radially symmetrical, five-petaled white flowers, 0.5 inch across
•Flowers with many long, red, pink, and white filaments tipped with yellow anthers
•Clusters of long-stalked, grape-sized, thin-skinned, spherical fruit one inch across
•Fruit covered with a white, waxy powder
•Fruit first green, then red-purple, finally blue-black
•Single flattened stone inside the fruit

Plan your harvest in advance, choosing a relatively cool, windy day, and forage early in the morning, so you can wear long pants and sleeves to protect yourself from poison ivy (Toxidodendron radicans), mosquitoes and sand flies without getting too hot, especially if you're collecting in marshy areas (avoid these if you can find the fruit elsewhere), where dense swarms of biting insects sometimes abound. Strong winds are great for blowing away these pests.

Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. When your container and stomach are full, transfer your harvest into one of your empty containers and resume picking.

Beach plums are the best plums you’ll ever taste. The intense, sweet and tart flavor is outstanding.

Eat them raw, or remove the stones with a food mill or by hand. Cook with a thickener and sweetener either before or after pitting the fruit, and use the pulp in jams, jellies, drinks, pies, cakes, ice cream, sauces, cold cereal, oatmeal, puddings, smoothies, or any sweet recipes your imagination can conjure up.

Beach plums are a good source of vitamins A, C, and potassium, and they provide even more antioxidants than blueberries and cranberries, so eating them probably reduces your chances of getting heart disease, cancer, and other diseases.

Beware of sand flies, which have a painful bite, and dense swarms of mosquitoes, if you collect in marshy habitats without a strong wind. Poison ivy also grows near or among beach plums, so learn this plant and carefully avoid it.

This shrub is endangered in Maine, Maryland, and Pennsylvania, not because of foragers, but due to coastal development (habitat loss is a big danger to wild plants in general in the US, not foragers. If you live in those states, spit out plenty of pits when you eat the fruit, and fight the developers who like to build in ecologically sensitive sites where, due to the possibilities of hurricanes and flooding, aren't appropriate for human habitation in the first place!

Elsewhere, the American plum or wild plum (P. americana) is the most common species, although there are other similar edible plums growing in various parts of the country too. The small, tart fruit is red or yellow, with only a little flesh—not quite as good as the beach plum, but still enjoyable. It grows in dense stands, like the beach plum, on moist soils in valleys, roadsides, low slopes and moist edges of forests and thickets of the Eastern part of the United States, ripening from late summer through fall.

The Canada plum (P. nigra) is a light reddish-orange, larger, tastier version of the American plum that also grows in the eastern states and Canada.
This is one of the best-tasting fruits you'll ever eat. It grows in the sand near beaches in the Northeast.

You can recognize beach plums from their small clusters of small, five-petaled, white flowers with lots of long stamens. It has finely-toothed, oval, alternate, stalked, leaves, and clusters of spherical, thin-skinned, grape-sized fruits.

2beach-plum-bush,-flowers,-and-plums

This dense bush, with alternate, oval, finely toothed leaves, has small, showy clusters of small, five-petaled flowers with long filaments and yellow anthers. The very tasty, long-stalked, spherical fruits, hang in clusters from the thick twigs and are blue or blue-black when mature.
Black Cherry Tree
black-cherry-tree
Rosaceae, the rose family

Black cherries are at their peak in the second half of the summer, with some trees starting or ending their seasons a little earlier or later.

The best time for harvesting the cambium for medicinal use is in autumn.

Black cherry trees are very common, growing in sunny and partially shaded habitats, cultivated parks, backyards, thickets, fields, and mixed hardwood forests, and along forest edges, residential streets, trail and field edges, and roadsides. I've found the best fruit growing in fields and thickets near the seashore.
Most of North America east of the Rocky Mountain states, and on mountains in the SW and Mexico

Look for a medium-sized tree with silver-gray, blocky bark punctuated with dark brown fissures and glossy, elliptical, finely toothed, sharp-pointed, thick, leathery, medium-sized, stalked, alternate, leaves. Black cherry trees have showy terminal masses of oblong, cylindrical, drooping racemes with many small, rank-smelling, radially-symmetrical, white, five-petaled flowers and many spherical, short-stalked, shiny, black cherries which are reddish at first.

This medium-size tree can grow up to 125 feet tall, but 40 to 60 feet is usual, with a trunk up to 2.33 feet in diameter. Straight and narrow in forests, it develops a broad, irregular crown in open places. Whitish lenticels streaks its bark, which is shiny and silvery when young. When mature, it becomes blocky, cracking into upturned parts punctuated with dark brown, almost black fissures.

Scratch and sniff the reddish brown, white-dotted twigs, or crush the leaves, and you’ll detect the fragrance of bitter almond, the same as inside the stones of related apricots or peaches.

The glossy, elliptical, finely toothed, sharp-pointed, thick, leathery, stalked, alternate leaves, are lighter underneath, grow two to five inches long and one to 1.5 inches wide. They turn yellow, orange or red in the fall. Distinct, tiny, orange-brown hairs grow along the midrib of the leaf's underside.

In early spring, after the leaves have developed, masses of oblong-cylindrical, green, drooping racemes four to six inches long and 0.75 to one inch in diameter grow at the ends of the current year's new growth. About 40 small, rank-smelling, radially-symmetrical, white, five-petaled flowers, less that 0.25 inch across, grow on each raceme, attracting pollinating flies.

Ripening on the same now-red racemes, many spherical, short-stalked, shiny black fruits, reddish at first, grow up to 0.5 inch in diameter. Each contains one hard stone 0.33 in diameter.

•Medium-sized tree with silvery, white-streaked, blocky bark, cracking into upturned plates when mature, with dark cracks
•Glossy, elliptical, finely toothed, sharp-pointed, thick, leathery, stalked, alternate leaves, lighter underneath, two to five inches long and one to 1.5 inches wide
•Rows of tiny, orange-brown hairs along both sides of the leaf midrib's underside
•Broken twigs and crushed leaves smelling of bitter almond
•Terminal masses of oblong-cylindrical, green, drooping racemes four to six inches long and 0.75 to one inch, in early spring
•Close to 40 small, rank-smelling, radially-symmetrical, white, five-petaled flowers, less that 0.25 inch across, growing on each raceme
•Many spherical, short-stalked, shiny, black cherries, reddish at first, up to 0.5 inch in diameter, on racemes from late summer to early fall
•One small, hard seed inside each cherry

Black cherries vary greatly in quantity and quality from tree to tree and from year to year, with a really good crop every three or four years. Some trees usually produce sweet and juicy fruit, others small, hard, bitter cherries. Sample different trees and collect from one with the largest, softest, sweetest cherries, growing from trees with branches within reach, usually on larger trees growing in full sunlight. This tree is so common, you can afford to be choosy.

If it's a bad year, few trees will have fruit, and those that do usually have small, unpalatable cherries. If this is the case, try again the following year.

Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. When your container and stomach are full, transfer your harvest into one of your empty containers and resume picking.

Black cherries are among the most unusual-tasting of wild fruits—with an intense bittersweet combination of commercial cherries, grapefruit, and wine— weird at first, then addictive, even though they're not very sweet. Enjoy them raw, as a snack, or cook them with a sweetener and thickener, strain out the seeds using a food mill, and turn them into jams, pie fillings, vegan cheesecake topping, sauces, puddings, and fruit leather. Fresh ginger, nutmeg, mint, and cloves are excellent companion seasonings, and the fruit's strong flavor holds its own with other strong flavors, so the purée is especially good in chocolate recipes.
Black cherries provide vitamin A, B1, C, folate, and pantothenic acid, plus calcium, magnesium, iron, sodium, phosphorus, potassium, copper, selenium, and zinc.

Eat just the cherries—the leaves contain high concentrations prunasin, harmless until you eat them. Then it turns to deadly cyanide, but not to worry— the decaying leaves are much more poisonous than the fresh ones!

The seeds have the cyanide precursor too, but they're too hard too eat, and if you cook the cherries with the seeds, the heat destroys the toxin.

There are other delicious wild cherry species that grow throughout the US:

People often confuse the black cherry tree with the similar chokecherry (P. virginiana). However, chokecherry leaves’ midribs aren’t hairy beneath, and the smaller mature fruit's red, not black. And they're are so astringent, they’ll make your mouth pucker, unless you cook and sweeten them. This fruit grows in the same kind of habitats as the black cherry, but further north, especially in mountainous areas—throughout much of the northern half of the United States, much of California, and southern Canada.

The pin cherry (P. pensylvanica), which grow high on the mountains, has shorter racemes, more narrow leaves, and long-stemmed red cherries.

Sometimes black-colored commercial cherries are marketed under the name black cherry, but they're really a dark cultivated version of the sweet cherry (P. Avium). Both black and red varieties grow wild in Eastern and Western North America, but clusters of larger cherries hand from the twigs on long fruit stalks, not on the racemes of the native black cherry.
Rum Cherry, Wild Black Cherry, Mountain Black Cherry
With an unusual bittersweet flavor of cherries and grapefruit, this is one of the best, most common wild fruits you'll find.
Choke Cherry, Sweet Cherry
Black Cherry Tapioca Pudding
black-cherry-tapioca-pudding

This exotic-flavored pudding makes it worthwhile to spend time collecting all the black cherries you can get your hands on! Serve it hot or cold.

1-1/2 cups black cherry purée, made by simmering 3-1/2 cups black cherries 5 to 10 minutes or until soft, and straining out the seeds with a food mill
3 cup soy-rice milk or other non-dairy milk
1/4 cup walnut oil
l1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/2 cup raw pignoli nuts or cashews
1/2 cup silken tofu
1/3 cup tapioca pearls
2 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tsp. vanilla
1/2 tsp almond extract
1/4 tsp. amaretto extract or almond extract (optional)
1/4 tsp. orange extract
1/4 tsp. salt

1. Purée all ingredients in a blender or food processor.

2. Bring to a boil over medium heat in a saucepan, stirring constantly. Reduce the heat to low and simmer, uncovered, 10 minutes.

Serves 6

Preparation Time: 20 minutes
1)Black Cherry Flowers and Fruit
1black-cherry-flowers-and-fruit

Finely toothed, alternate, long-pointed, elliptical leaves grow on the black cherry tree's slender twigs. In the spring, drooping terminal racemes bear dense, cylindrical clusters of tiny, five-petaled, radially symmetrical, white flowers, then from late summer to early fall they're replaced by many small, spherical, black, stalked fruits.
2)Black Cherry Racemes with Flowers
2black-cherry-racemes-with-flowers
The black cherry's dense, drooping racemes bear five-petaled, radially symmetrical, white flowers after the finely toothed, alternate, pointed elliptical leaves have already developed.
4)Black Cherry Tree, Fruit, Trunk, and Leaf
4black-cherry-tree,-fruit,-trunk,-and-leaf

The mature black cherry has a straight, narrow trunk, and bark is broken into shiny, uplifted, gray blocks, between dark, brown mostly vertical cracks. In the open, the crown is irregular. The rusty hairs along the underside of the leaf's midrib distinguishes this tree from other cherry species, especially the similar choke cherry.
3)Black Cherry Fruit
3black-cherry-fruit

Black cherry trees have stalked, spherical fruit, first red, then black, growing on long racemes. When the raceme is full of relatively large, dark black fruit, you've found a great tree for foraging.
Sweet Cherry
sweet-cherry
Rosaceae, the rose family
These cherries ripen as spring gives way to summer.
Forests, edges of forests, edges of paths, park lands, cultivated areas
Eastern and Western North America, but not in Utah
Eurasia and Northern Africa

Look for a small tree with purplish-brown bark, or a medium-sized tree with silvery gray cracked bark, both shiny streaked with horizontal white lines. The shiny, fine-toothed, medium-sized, oval, pointed, alternate leaves have distinct red glands on the leafstalks. Clusters of two to six radially-symmetrical, five-petaled, showy, long-stalked, white flowers grow on the twig tips. Small, smooth, spherical, red, yellow, or black umbrella-like clusters of long-stalked cherries replace the flowers when the weather begins to get hot.

Growing up from 50 to 70 feet tall, with the trunk dominant over the branches, the sweet cherry tree is a feral form of the commercial cherry, created from seed, not from cuttings, so that it's more like ancestral wild cherries than the uniform cultivated clones of orchard and backyards. The symmetrical, conical crown becomes rounded to irregular with age. White, horizontal lines streak the shiny, smooth, purplish-brown bark, which becomes dark silvery gray and fissured with age.

Shiny, fine-toothed, oval, pointed, alternate leaves, which turn orange, pink, or red in the fall, grow from 2.75 to over 5.5 inches long and 1.5 to 2.75 inches wide. The reddish leafstalk, which has two to five small, red glands (nectaries, where insects that protect the tree from herbivores get fed), grows from under an inch to 1.33 inches long.

In early spring, clusters of two to six radially-symmetrical, five-petaled, showy white flowers, each one inch to 1.5 inch across, bloom on the tips of the twigs on flower stalks one to two inches long.

Small, smooth, spherical, red, yellow, or black, long-stalked cherries, 0.5 to one inch across and containing one hard seed 0.33 inches across, ripen close to the start of summer. The stalks of several cherries originate from the same point on the twig.

•Smooth, shiny bark, purplish-brown on young trees, becoming dark silvery gray and cracked with age
•Bark streaked with horizontal white lines
•Shiny, fine-toothed, oval, pointed, alternate leaves 2.75 to over 5.5 inches long and 1.5 to 2.75 inches wide
•Clusters of two to six radially-symmetrical, showy, long-stalked, 5-petaled white flowers, one inch to 1.5 inch across, growing on twig tips
•Small, smooth, spherical red, yellow, or black, long-stalked cherries 0.5 to one inch across
•Stalks of several cherries originating from the same point on the twig
•One hard seed 0.33 inches across inside each cherry

Sweet cherries are often hard to collect because too often, few branches grow within reach. And when a friend who repairs roofs for a living ascended one of these with me, using his mega-ladder, we still had to go out on a limb to reach the fruit. So look for young, relatively small trees at the edges of woodlands and in cultivated parks. You might get a really good crop from these every three to four years.

To collect efficiently, punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring, and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. When your container and stomach are full, transfer your harvest into one of your empty containers and resume picking.

Sweet cherries are smaller and more tart than commercial cherries, with a more intense cherry flavor. Use them raw or cooked like commercial cherries, in sweetened puddings, cakes, cereals, salads, smoothies, pies, ice cream, jams, and other desserts. To remove the seeds cook them with a sweetener and thickener and strain out the seeds using a food mill, or use a cherry pitter or paring knife.
In addition to carbohydrates, cherries provide vitamins C and K, folate; the carotinoids beta-carotene, choline, zeanxanthin, and lutein; and the minerals calcium, iron, magnesium, and phosphorus.

A decoction of the fruit stalks is considered astringent, diuretic and tonic, and has been used to treat cystitis, edema, bronchitis, diarrhea, and anemia. However it contains amygdalin and prunasin, potential sources of cyanide. Small amounts of these substances stimulate respiration, improve digestion, and create a feeling of well-being, but only if they don't release cyanide and kill you first (stick to safer medicinal plants)!

Except for the ripe fruit, all parts of the tree contain the toxic cyanogenic glycoside, amygdalin, which may break down into cyanide and cause gasping, weakness, excitement, pupil dilation, spasms, convulsions, coma, respiratory failure, and death, although if you cook the cherries before straining out the pits, the heat will destroy the toxins in the pits.

Black birch bark looks similar to cherry bark, but it's never reddish and has fewer cracks. All the trees' other features differ, and even in the winter, injured cherry twigs smell like bitter almond, whereas black birch trees smell like wintergreen.

Some apple and crab apple trees with white blossoms bloom at the time as sweet cherries, but apple bark is gray and scaly, not smooth, shiny, or streaked with horizontal white lines.

Sometimes sweet cherries get blackish, but they're not the same as our native black cherry, which has flowers and fruit ripening later in the season, and growing along long racemes. Nevertheless, like sweet cherries, black cherries are also sometimes confusingly called wild cherries.
Wild Cherry, Gean, Massard, Mazzard
These feral garden cherries are small and more flavorful than their larger, sweeter ancestors, but the wild versions are way better for cooking.
Wild Apple, Black Birch, Black Cherry
Black Forest Cake with Wild Cherries
black-forest-cake-with-wild-cherries

Here’s my healthful version of classic German chocolate cake topped with sweet cherries, that tastes even better than the original.

Dry Ingredients

1 cup (5 oz.) buckwheat flour + 3/4 cup (5 oz.) sweet brown rice flour, or 10 oz. any whole-grain flours
3/4 cup unsweetened Dutch cocoa powder
1/2 cup flax seeds ground into 3/4 cup meal
1 tsp. xanthan gum
1/2 tsp. guar gum
2 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1 tsp. nutmeg, ground
2 tsp. cream of tartar
1 tsp. baking soda
1/4 tsp. cloves, ground

Ingredients to Blend

2 cups soy mil, nut milk, or other non-dairy milk
6 tbs. almond oil
1/4 cup lecithin granules
6 dates
4 common spicebush berries, or 1 tsp. ground allspice
2 tsp. vanilla
1 tbs. liquid stevia

Cherry Topping

2-1/2 cups pitted wild sweet cherries or commercial cherries
1-1/4 cups cherry juice concentrate
1 tbs. agar
5 tsp. arrowroot
1 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tsp dried water or commercial mint, ground
1/2 tsp. powdered ginger
1/8 tsp. amaretto extract or almond extract (optional)

Icing

3 cups silken tofu, drained
3/4 cup dates
1/4 cup lecithin granules
2 tbs. almond oil
1 tbs. fresh lemon extract
2 tsp. vanilla
1 tsp. liquid stevia
1/4 tsp. butterscotch extract
1/4 tsp. salt

1. Mix together the dry ingredients.

2. Purée the ingredients to blend in a blender.

3. Mix the purée into the dry ingredients. Don’t overmix.

4. Transfer to 3 oiled 9-inch pie tins and bake in a preheated 350 degree oven for 30 minutes, or until an inserted toothpick emerges dry.

5. Cool on racks.

6. Meanwhile, mix the cherry topping ingredients in a saucepan, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low and simmer, uncovered, 5 minutes before chilling it.

7. Purée all the icing ingredients in a food processor.

8. Layer the cake with icing, cherry topping, and more cake, until all ingredients are used up.

Serves 8 to 10

Preparation time: 45 minutes

Cooking time: 30 minutes
1)Sweet Cherry Blossoms and Fruit
1sweet-cherry-blossoms-and-fruit

The sweet cherry tree's showy, long-stemmed, white, five-petaled, radially symmetrical blossoms grow in clusters of two to five, originating from a common point, sometimes before the oval, finely toothed, pointed, stalked, alternate leaves develop. The long-stalked red (sometimes yellow or black-purple) fruits resemble commercial cherries, only they're smaller.
3)Sweet Cherry in Flower
3sweet-cherry-in-flower
The sweet cherry's masses of showy white flowers make quite a display in early spring.
2)Sweet Cherry Flowers and Leaves
2sweet-cherry-flowers-and-leaves

The showy, white, radially-symmetrical, five-petaled flowers bloom in early spring, growing in clusters of two to five, and originating from a common point. Where the long leafstalk connects to the finely toothed, oval, alternate leaves, you'll find two or more distinctive, small, bright red glands—nectaries that feed the insects which defend their food source from destructive insects.
7)Sweet Cherry Red Fruit
7sweet-cherry-red-fruit

The long-stalked, smooth, thin-skinned, spherical, red (sometimes yellow or black) cherries grow in clusters of two to five, originating from a common point. Horizontal white streaks, lenticels that allow exchange of gasses with the atmosphere, adorn the stout, reddish twigs.

The leafstalks of the finely toothed, oval, pointed, alternate leaves bear distinctive red glands called nectaries, which provide food for beneficial insects, in exchange for defense from destructive insects. They're visible here as red dots on the leafstalks of the 2 leaves on the upper right.
5)Sweet Cherry Tree with Fruit
5sweet-cherry-tree-with-fruit
Some sweet cherry trees have red fruits, but this one is loaded with black-colored cherries—not the same as the smaller fruits growing on racemes of the native black cherry tree (P. serotina)
6)Sweet Cherry with Black Fruit
6sweet-cherry-with-black-fruit
This long-stalked, spherical fruit, growing among elliptical, alternate leaves, is black instead of red.
8)Sweet Cherry Bark
8sweet-cherry-bark
White, horizontal lines streak the shiny, smooth, silvery gray, which becomes fissured with age.
American Barberry
american-barberry
Berberidaceae, the barberry family
The young leaves are edible from mid-spring through early summer, and the berries ripen in early summer.
Full sun or partial shade, in mountains, on hills, along stream banks, in dry woods, among rocks, near rivers, and in rocky slopes and fields

This shrub grows mainly in the southern Appalachians, but you may also find it in New England, the Mid-Atlantic states, parts of the Midwest, and Canada. Distribution is spotty because it was eradicated in many areas in the past, in an unsuccessful attempt to stop the spread of wheat rust.

Look for a small to medium-sized shrub that has smooth, dark, reddish brown bark, three-parted thorns on the branches and trunks. Clustered at the ends of short spur branches are thick, smooth, oval, alternate leaves with two to 12 bristly teeth. Drooping racemes of tiny, yellow, six-petaled flowers grow in groups of three to five, and dry, red, oval to oblong berries hang in loose clusters.

This small to medium-sized shrub has smooth, dark, reddish brown bark, branches armed with three-parted spines, and yellow wood.

The thick, smooth, oval, alternate leaves, one to two inches long and about 0.66 inch wide, with two to 12 bristly teeth, cluster[ed] so tightly at the ends of short spur branches that they look whorled.

Tiny, yellow, six-petaled flowers bloom around the start of mid-spring in groups of three to five, growing on slender, long flower stalks attached to drooping racemes originating in the leaf axils. If you touch the flowers at the right stage, they snap back and release a puff of pollen.

The dry, red, oval to oblong berries, about 0.5 inch long, also hang in loose clusters. Each contains one or two hard seeds.

•Small to medium-sized shrub with smooth, dark, reddish brown bark
•Three-parted thorns
•Yellow wood
•Thick, smooth, oval, alternate leaves, one to two inches long and about 0.66 inch wide, with two to 12 bristly teeth
•Alternate leaves clustered at the ends of short spur branches, resembling whorled leaves
•Tiny, yellow, six-petaled flowers in groups of three to five, on long, slender flower stalks growing on drooping racemes originating from the leaf axils
•Dry, red, oval to oblong berries hanging in loose clusters
•One or two hard seeds in each berry

Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. Bring additional food containers to transfer your harvest when your collection container gets full. Wear heavy-duty work gloves with the fingertips cut off your picking hand, for protection against the thorns.
