Long sleeves and long pants are very helpful, as is planning foraging early on a relatively cool morning.

American barberries are very tart, so they're good used to perk up dishes with less acidic fruits, such as peaches or mangoes. You can use the fresh berries, or dehydrated and reconstituted ones, in pies, tarts, jams, jellies, and as a sour flavoring ingredient in desserts. For cooked recipes, remove the seeds with a food mill after cooking the berries with some fruit juice. You may also add a sweetener and thickener.

You may also pickle the berries, or purée the cooked berries in fruit juice and a sweetener to make a traditional drink, again, with the seeds removed.

The sour-flavored, tender, young leaves are edible as well. Add them to salads or sandwiches, use them as garnishes, or add them to cooked vegetable dishes. They cook in about 10 minutes.
Barberries are a good source of vitamin C.

A decoction of the cambium or the roots contains berberine, which has antibiotic and anti-cancer effects, but isn't absorbed through the digestive system, so it's used for bacterial infections of the digestive tract, especially dysentery. Berberine also has demonstrated anti-tumor activity, which should be followed up with additional research.

The decoction has also been used for fevers, indigestion, diarrhea, arthritis, jaundice and liver disorders, and various acute inflammations, as well as for vaginal yeast infections. Native Americans chewed the rhizomes for painful canker sores.

The common barberry (B. vulgaris) is so similar to the American species that botanists used to classify the American shrub as a subspecies of this European one. The common barberry has gray instead of reddish brown bark, and its leaves have 16 to 30 teeth instead of two to 12. Its uses, habitats, and range are similar to its American relative.

The Japanese barberry (B. thunbergii),with unpalatable berries and edible young leaves, grows across much of Northern North America and parts of the Southwest, but not in the Deep South. Its leaves lack teeth, and the thorns have one part, not three, like the American species.
Allegheny Barberry, Pipperidge Bush, Sourberry
This plant has edible leaves and berries, both of which are sour and tasty.
Japanese Barberry
American Barberry with Fruit
american-barberry-with-fruit

This shrub as alternate, oval leaves, toothed crowded together on short spur branches so they look whorled. The oblong, clustered, red berries hang from long leafstalks originating from the leaf axils (photo by April Wells).
Common Strawberry
common-strawberry
Rosaceae, the rose family
Common strawberries ripen at the end of spring or start of summer, and you can use the leaves for tea from spring to fall.
Open, sunny places, partial shade, moist ground, dry openings, open woods, woodland edges, rocky areas, in meadows and fields, near the seashore, and on hillsides and slopes
This widespread fruit, which is divided into 4 very similar subspecies, grows throughout all of North America.

Look for a trailing, colonial plant with a three-parted palmate-compound leaf atop a long leafstalk with coarsely-toothed, oval, leaflets. Common Strawberry has open terminal clusters of five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, white flowers blooming on a leafless stem and tiny, oval strawberries.

This trailing, weakly to strongly hairy, colonial plant grows from two to six inches tall, arising from slender, horizontal, reddish-tinged runners up to two feet long, and short, scaly rhizomes.

The palmate-compound leaf grow atop a long, finely hairy leafstalk about six inches long. Pale green underneath, the three oval to wedge-shaped leaflets, one to three inches long and about 1.5 inches wide, have coarse, sharp, even teeth and very short leafstalks.

In mid-spring, a softly hairy, leafless stem three to four inches long arises from the ground with open, terminal clusters of two to 15 five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, odorless white flowers, each 0.5 to one inch across.

The familiar red berries, white at first, ripen about five weeks later. 0.5 to 0.75 inch across, they look like tiny, oval versions of commercial strawberries, with tiny seeds partially sunken into the flesh, and ten tiny, green sepals at the fruit’s base.

•Trailing, hairy stemmed colonial plant two to six inches tall
•Reddish-tinged runners two feet long, with short, scaly rhizomes
•Three-parted palmate-compound leaves atop a finely hairy leafstalk six inches tall
•Three oval to wedge-shaped leaflets one to three inches long and 1.5 inches wide, with coarse, sharp, even teeth, and very short leafstalks
•Open terminal clusters of two to 15 radially-symmetrical, odorless, five-petaled, white flowers 0.5 to one inch across
•Flowers arising from a leafless stem three to four inches long
•Tiny oval strawberries, 0.5 to 0.75 inch across
•Tiny seeds partially sunken into the fruit's flesh
•Ten tiny, green sepals at the fruit’s base

These very tasty berries are so small, they take a long time to collect, especially if you can't resist eating each one you pick, or if you expect them to fill your stomach. Bring one small food container, an electronic listening device, and an audiobook version of War and Peace before you settle in!

Although wild strawberries have way more flavor than commercial strawberries, they're very small. They're great used in cold and hot cereals, pancakes, fruit salad, ice cream, sauces, jam, or other desserts, like commercial strawberries, although they're so tedious to collect they usually become a minor, albeit very tasty, component of dishes.
Strawberries provide magnesium, potassium, beta-carotene, iron, and malic and citric acids, and an infusion of the leaves provides vitamin C and K.

The woodland strawberry (F. vesca) is very similar to the common strawberry and very tasty, but with a larger, elongated, pointed fruit, rather than an oval one. It grows throughout North America except Nebraska, Oklahoma, Nevada, and the Southeast. For foragers, the two species are interchangeable.

The commercial strawberry is a hybrid of the common strawberry and the beach strawberry (F. chiloensis), a flavorless Chilean species that grows on the West Coast. The commercial strawberry rarely escapes into the wild.

Beware of the dreaded Indian strawberry (Duchesnea indica). Usually growing on the edges of trails, in moist woods, and in cultivated parks. This Asian species, which grows in Eastern North America and the West Coast, but not in New England, has a luscious-looking round strawberry with seeds that stand out from the surface, not indented like the common strawberries. It has backwards-pointing sepals, and yellow flowers instead of white ones. Disaster invariably strikes when any unwary forager samples this tempting-looking fruit: It has no flavor whatsoever—the berry is as tasteless as my jokes—and moments after ingestion, the hapless victim dies of disappointment!

Common cinquefoil (Potentilla simplex) is another very dangerous plant with leaves that resemble strawberry leaves enough to fool people, even though it has five leaflets rather than three, and the flowers are also yellow instead of white. People have waited, transfixed, for this non-poisonous plant to produce a strawberry that never appears, until they finally succumb to old age!
Virginia Strawberry, Wild Strawberry
One of the tastiest fruits in the world, it's unfortunate that the berries are so tiny.
Woodland Strawberry, Indian Strawberry
Strawberry-Banana Sorbet
strawberry-banana-sorbet

Using a fruit blend to replace some of my standard frozen dessert thickeners results in an irresistibly tasty sherbet.

3 cups soy-rice blend milk or nut milk
1 ripe banana
1/2 cup wild or commercial strawberries
1/4 cup silken tofu, drained
1/4 cup raw pignoli nuts or cashews
1/4 cup grape seed oil
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin
2 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tsp. orange extract
1 tsp. vanilla
1 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1/4 tsp. powdered ginger
1/4 tsp. salt

1. Purée all ingredients in a blender.

2. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

Makes 5-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Freezing time: 90 minutes
1)Common Strawberry Fruit and Flowers
1common-strawberry-fruit-and-flowers

Consisting of three coarsely, sharply, and evenly toothed leaflets, the common strawberry's three-parted, palmate-compound leaf grows singly atop a soft, slender stem. A loose terminal cluster of radially-symmetrical, five-petaled white flowers grows on a separate long, unbranched, leafless stem, as do the small, red, oval strawberries.
2)Common Strawberry in Flower
2common-strawberry-in-flower

The common strawberry's radially symmetrical, five-petaled, white flower grows in terminal clusters on an unbranched, leafless, finely hairy stem, above ten long sepals that persist when the fruit ripens. The three-parted, palmate-compound, sharply and coarsely toothed leaves also emerge from the ground on their own finely hairy stems.
Cranberries
cranberries
Ericaceae, the heath family
Cranberries ripen in early fall, but improve in late fall, after there's been a frost. And they sometimes persist into winter.

Cranberries generally grow in acidic bogs and wet areas with poor soil, including bogs behind sand dunes near the seashore, in pine barrens, and in glaciated regions. The small and large cranberries grow in bogs, peaty soil and swamps, while the mountain cranberry grows in cool, moist, acidic woodlands and rocky, mountainous habitats.

These circumpolar plants grow throughout most of Canada and south into Northeastern North America:

The small cranberry grows in the Northeast as far south as North Carolina's mountainous areas, in states near the Great Lakes, and in the Pacific Northwest.

The large cranberry grows in southeastern and western Canada, around the Great Lakes, in the Pacific Northwest and California, in New England, and further south only on mountains.

The mountain cranberry only grows as far south as the Great Lakes region and New England.

Look in bogs for a mat of slightly woody, creeping plants with slender, wiry, stems and small, oval, toothless, dark green, shiny, leathery, alternate, evergreen leaves. The small, dark pink, four-petaled flowers have distinctly reflexed petals and a forward-pointing style and stamens. The fruit is smooth, red, spherical, and similar to commercial cranberries.

These creeping, slender, wiry, somewhat wood perennials, with rhizomes that grow from one to three feet long, often form large mats.

The small, leathery, oval, toothless, dark green, shiny, alternate, evergreen leaves with pale undersides, turn bronze in autumn, and may curl under slightly.

Blooming in late spring and summer, the small, dark pink, four-petaled flowers have distinctly reflexed petals, exposing the forward-pointing stamens and style.

The smooth, red, spherical berry, which is larger than the leaves and white at first, looks very much like the commercial cranberry.

Three species grow in the US and northward:

The small cranberry (V. oxycoccos) is a small, slender, flexible, prostrate, golden-brown evergreen shrub with vine-like stems, densely covered with tiny leaves. One to Four inches tall, it rarely grows over one foot long. The pointed, oval leaves, 0.25 to 0.375 inch long, have distinctive edges that are rolled under, and its stems are thinner than other species'. The drooping, pink to red flowers, 0.375 across, and the fruit, 0.5 inch across, grow in small terminal clusters or singly, but not from the leaf axils. [-The]It's round, red cranberry grows 0.5 inch across, hanging from a stem one to 1.5 inches long

The large cranberry (V. macrocarpon), the species cultivated commercially, grows from four to eight inches tall and three feet long. Its leaves are larger than other species, 0.4 to 0.8 inches long. The pale pink to white flowers, which grow to about 0.5 inch long, and the fruit, grow from the leaf axils, not in terminal clusters.

The mountain cranberry (V. vitis-idaea) grows two to 16 inches tall, usually standing upright instead of creeping. The oval, oblong, or elliptical leaves turn purplish in autumn. The white to pink flowers, only 0.25 inch across, grow in terminal racemes of one to 15, and the berries, 0.2 to 0.4 inch across, ripen in late summer and early fall.

•Mats of slightly woody, creeping plants with slender, wiry, stems, and rhizomes
•Small, leathery, oval, toothless, dark green, alternate, shiny, evergreen leaves
•Small, pink, four-petaled flowers with distinctly reflexed petals, exposing the forward-pointing style and stamens
•Fruit like commercial cranberry—smooth, red, spherical, larger than the leaves, white at first
Wear warm, waterproof clothing and waterproof shoes if possible, sit on the ground on a mat or squat, pick the berries with your fingers, and transfer them to food containers.

Use the fruit like you'd use commercial cranberries—because they've only been brought into cultivation in recent centuries, the wild and commercial varieties don't differ greatly. Like apples, they contain pectin, a natural thickener. And because they’re cold-adapted, they store well in a freezer.

Cranberries are too bitter, acidic and mealy for anyone but the most dedicated raw food proponents to enjoy without cooking. Of course, cooking them with a sweetener and making cranberry sauce is the most common way to use them. But I also add them to pie filling, fruit crisps, cobblers, and other desserts. They're great cooked and added them to ice cream, where their tart flavor effectively offsets the other ingredients' creamy sweetness. I've found that apples and walnuts are especially good companion ingredients.

Cranberries provide vitamins A and C, beta-carotene, calcium, lutein, zeaxanthin, magnesium, manganese, potassium, and phosphorus, and they're also an excellent source of healthful antioxidants called anthocyanins which may benefit the cardiovascular and immune systems, and inhibit cancer.

Cranberries contain quinic, malic, citric and hippuric acids. A substantial body of research shows that drinking cranberry juice fights urinary tract infections by preventing pathogenic bacteria such as E. coli from sticking to the mucus membranes, and there's also evidence of direct anti-bacterial activity too. The juice is used to treat and prevent urinary tract infections, kidney disorders, incontinence, and cystitis, and the juice is a gentle, effective diuretic too.

Eating cranberries has been observed to aid the digestion of fat and protein, which is why cranberries often accompany rich meals. They're also used to reduce fever and soothe skin inflammations, although these claims remain to be tested.
Avoid cranberry juice and cranberries if you're taking Warfarin. The 2 together and cause problems with your blood's clotting system.
The highbush cranberry is an unrelated, very different-looking shrub with edible, red berries that only taste like cranberries.
The small cranberry is also called the common, northern or bog cranberry. The mountain cranberry is also called the cowberry and lingonberry.
Very similar to commercial cranberries, this fruit is very common in cold, boggy areas.
highbush cranberry
Large Cranberry
large-cranberry

This mat of slightly woody, creeping plants has slender, wiry, stems, small, oval, toothless, dark green, alternate, shiny, leathery, evergreen leaves, and a smooth, red, spherical fruit similar to a commercial cranberry.
3-Grain Cranberry Bread
3-grain-cranberry-bread

This recipe came about when I tried to create a pound cake, but it turns out I used too much leavening, not enough oil, and too little sweetener. The result was a complete surprise—a delicious, moist, bread, with tart cranberries providing the spark.

2 cups cranberries

Dry Ingredients

3-1/2 cups (1 lb.) sweet brown rice flour + 3-1/8 cups (1 lb.) oat flour + 1-3/4 cups (1/2 lb.) barley flour, or 2-1/2 lbs. of any whole-grain flour
1/2 cup arrowroot or kudzu
1/2 tbs. salt
2 tsp. xanthan gum
1 tsp. guar gum
1/2 tsp. turmeric

Ingredients to Blend

2 cups soy-rice milk or other non-dairy milk
1/4 cup corn oil
1/4 cup lecithin granules
2 tbs. lemon juice
2 tsp. liquid stevia
The scrapings of 1 inch of vanilla bean or 2 tsp. vanilla extract

1. Mix together the dry ingredients.

2. Purée the ingredients to blend in a blender.

3. Mix the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Don’t over-mix.

4. Stir in the remaining cranberries. Don’t over-mix.

5. Transfer to 2 oiled loaf pans and bake 50 minutes in a preheated 350 degree oven, or until an inserted cake tester or toothpick emerges clean.

6. Cool on racks.

Makes 2 loaves

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Cooking time: 50 minutes
Currants
currants
Grossulariaceae, the currant family
The fruits ripen in the middle of the growing season, wherever you live. Collect them from mid- to late summer.
Moist, partially or fully shaded woodlands, on prairies, along hillsides, and in thickets, canyons and ravines

Various species grow throughout North America, but distribution is spotty because currants were eradicated in the 20th century after it was discovered that they're necessary for the spread of blister rust fungus, a scourge of economically important pine trees.
Native and European currants grow wild thoughout most of North America.

Look for a small shrub with arching branches; simple, alternate, toothed, broadly triangular, maple-like leaves; many greenish or yellowish-white to purple, five-parted, bell-like or tubular flowers, growing on long, dropping racemes; and drooping racemes of small spherical, stalked, translucent berries.

[Look for a small shrub with arching branches and simple, alternate, toothed, broadly triangular, maple-like leaves. Many greenish or yellowish-white to purple, five-parted, bell-like or tubular flowers grow on long, dropping racemes. There are also drooping racemes of small spherical, stalked, translucent berries.]

The many species of currants are similar enough that after you've learned one species, you'll be able to recognize any others you find. And for the purposes of foragers, they're interchangeable.

These small shrubs usually grow 2 to 5 feet tall, with arching branches. The simple, alternate, toothed, broadly triangular, maple-like leaves, often shallowly heart-shaped at the base, have three to five lobes per leaf.

Five to 20 greenish or yellowish-white to purple flowers, five-parted, bell-like or tubular flowers grow on long, dropping racemes in the spring.

Five to 20 spherical, stalked fruits not more than 0.25 inches across ripen around mid-summer, on long, pendant racemes. Under a tight, smooth, translucent skin, the color ranges from red to pale yellow and even to black. Each berry contains three to 12 tiny, soft seeds.

•Small shrubs usually two to five feet tall, with arching branches
•Simple, alternate, toothed, broadly triangular, maple-like leaves, shallowly heart-shaped or straight at the base, three to five lobed
•Long, drooping racemes of flowers or fruits
•Five to 20 small, 5-parted, bell-like or tubular, greenish, yellowish-white, or purple flowers on each raceme
•Five to 20 spherical, stalked, translucent berries not more than 0.25 inches across, on each racemes

Strip off the ripe fruit with your fingers and transfer them to food containers. Attaching a collecting container to your belt by punching a hole through the top and using a key ring and key clip will free both your hands for more efficient collection.

Wild currants are very tasty but intensely sour, nothing like the unrelated commercial currants, which are really unrelated mini-raisins. Although wild currants are edible raw, like cranberries, they're much better sweetened and cooked. The seeds are so soft and tiny, you don't have to remove them. Furthermore, currants contain pectin, so they don't need much thickener.

In Europe people use currants for making juices, wines, jams, and tarts, and Native Americans cooked them with corn. I find them great in sweet, creamy desserts, such as puddings and pies, or in sauces, where their flavor can contrast those of the other ingredients. They go especially well with sweeter fruits, like apples, pears, bananas, and mangoes, and you can even bake them into breads. The same kinds of recipes that work with cranberries work with currants, although you can also use them in place of lemon or lime juice in any recipe that needs a sour touch.

Currants are a good source of vitamins A and C, and the minerals potassium, phosphorous, and calcium. They also contain malic and citric acid, as well as pectin.

The seeds of the black currant (R. nigrum) also provide gamma-linolenic acid, good for lowering the risk of cardiovascular disease.

Commercial currants (Vitis vinifera), also called Zante currants, aren't currants at all, but a dried species of grape, which is why they're so similar to commercial raisins, and so different from wild currants.

Gooseberries (Ribes spp.) are similar close relatives of currants, with thorny stems and bristly fruit. Except for bristly currants (R. lacustre), currants are thornless. And gooseberries have 3 flowers (followed by 3 berries) originating from the leaf axils, not the dangling racemes of currants. Gooseberries are widespread too, and you use them like currants after you remove the bristles, easier to do after cooking. I wish they grew in my area.

The maple-leaf viburnum (Viburnum acerifolium) is a shrub with leaves similar to currants, but they're opposite, not alternate, and the inedible fruit, which contains one seed, looks different and grows in an umbrella-like cluster.
Dog Bramble, Clove Bush
This is a very flavorful, sour-flavored berry that goes well with sweet, creamy fruits.
1)Black Currants with Berries and Flower
1black-currants-with-berries-and-flower

Currants are shrubs with long-stalked, toothed, three- to five-lobed, alternate leaves, flat at the base or slightly heart-shaped, and racemes of tiny, stalked flowers, followed by pendant racemes of small, spherical berries.
Currant Corn Bread
currant-corn-bread

Tart wild currants in every bite of this sweet bread produces a perfect contrast of flavor and texture, further proof of how tasty healthful whole-food and wild recipes can be.

Dry Ingredients

2-1/4 cups (14 oz.) cornmeal
1.5 cups (7 oz.) sweet brown rice flour
1/4 cup flax seeds or chia seeds, ground into 1/2 cup meal
1/2 tbs. cream of tartar
1-3/4 tsp. baking soda
1 tsp. salt
1/2 tsp. cloves, ground
1 tsp nutmeg, grated
1/4 tsp. ground cardamom

To Blend

3/4 cups cranberry juice
3/4 cup soy-rice milk, nut milk, or oat milk
6 tbs. corn oil
1/2 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tbs. freshly grated orange rind, or 1 tsp. orange extract
1/2 tsp. lemon extract (optional)

Other Ingredient

1-3/4 cups wild currants or cranberries

1. Mix together the dry ingredients.

2. Purée the wet ingredients in a blender.

3. Mix the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients. Don’t overmix.

4. Transfer into 2 oiled loaf pans and shape into loaves.

5. Place a pan of water in the oven to keep the bread from getting too crusty. Bake 45 minutes in a preheated 375 degree oven, or until an inserted cake tester or toothpick emerges clean.

6. Cool on racks.

Makes 2 loaves

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 45 minutes
2)Garden Red Currant with Berries
2garden-red-currant-with-berries

The spherical, veined berries of the red garden currant (R. sativum), hanging on long racemes, turn translucent-red when ripe. The alternate, lobed leaves look like maple leaves, although they're much smaller.
Common Elderberry
common-elderberry
Caprifoliaceae, the honeysuckle family
Elderberry flowers bloom in late spring and go out of season at the start of summer, while the berries reach their peak during the second half of the summer, and are usually gone in early fall.
Sunny and partially shaded, moist and dry places, in marshes, along riverbanks and roadsides, and in open woods and thickets
Eastern North America

Look for dense stands of large shrubs with gray, corky bark and dark green, large, opposite, feather-compound leaves with short-stalked, sharply pointed, saw-toothed, elliptical, medium-sized leaflets. Common Elderberry's showy, branched, lacy panicles have six to 12 of many tiny, white, five-petaled, star-shaped flowers. Those same panicles will produce tiny, shiny, spherical, juicy, purple-black to black, oblong berries.

This large shrub, which usually grows in dense stands, reaches from five to 15 feet tall and becomes equally wide. With many slender, arching branches and a broad, rounded crown, corky bumps (lenticels) spot the smooth, gray bark. A white, spongy pith grows inside the twigs and branches.

The opposite, feather-compound, dark green leaves, which turn yellow, orange, and red in autumn, may grow over three feet long. They smell unpleasant when cut or bruised. Divided into five to 11 opposite, saw-toothed, sharply pointed, short-stalked, elliptical leaflets, each two to seven inches long and half as wide. The leading leaflet's the longest.

Reaching six to 12 inches across, slightly rounded to flat-topped, showy, lacy panicles of many tiny, branched, white, five-petaled, star-shaped, sweet and musty smelling flowers bloom in late spring.

From mid-summer to early fall, the same panicles weigh down the branches when they're loaded with many tiny, shiny, spherical, juicy, purple-black to black berries, each 0.125 to 0.25 inch across, with three to five tiny, hard seeds inside.

•Large shrub in dense stands with gray, corky bark
•White pith inside the twigs and branches
•Dark green, opposite, feather-compound leaves over three feet long, divided into five to 11 opposite leaflets
•Short-stalked, sharply pointed, saw-toothed, opposite, elliptical leaflets two to seven inches long
•Slightly rounded to flat-topped, lacy, branched panicles, six to 12 inches across, of tiny, five-petaled, star-shaped, white flowers, blooming in late spring
•Panicles of tiny, shiny, spherical, juicy, purple-black to black berries, each with three to five tiny, hard seeds inside, ripening from mid-summer to fall

Break off the flower or berry clusters where they're relatively abundant—much easier than collecting most other berries. Avoid bushes with bad-tasting, rank-smelling, yellowing, overripe flowers, those with many unripe berries, or those where many of the berries have already fallen off. Bushes that get the most sunlight are usually the best.

Separate the flowers or berries from the stems, in the field or at home, using your fingers—labor-intensive but worth it. Freezing the berries on a tray or cookie sheet beforehand speeds the process. Discard any stems, which are mildly poisonous.

The flowers' delicate flavor is a little like vanilla. Not edible raw, they're great in fritters, provided you don't overpower them with stronger-tasting flavors. You can make a tasty infusion with elder flowers plus mint, or a fragrant, potent wine (you can also make wine with the berries).

You can also stuff a jar full of elder flowers, cover it with white vinegar, refrigerate it, shake it twice a day for two weeks, and strain out the flowers. The vinegar will take on the flowers' flavor.

The strongly flavored, crunchy, berries are excellent in any dish where you'd cook fruit—pancakes, ice cream, or puddings, for example. Unlike most other berries, they're not sweet or acidic, so add a sweetener (and thickener, if applicable). Depending on the recipe, something sour like lemon juice or sumac concentrate is helpful too. Elderberries also go well in desserts that include sweeter fruits. They're superb in baked dishes such as muffins, breads, and cakes. Use them, sweetened, like raisins.
The berries are an excellent source of potassium and beta-carotene, as well as sugar and fruit acids, plus calcium, phosphorous, and vitamin C.

The elderberry was used medicinally by Native Americans, and Hippocrates used a European species in 400 BC. Use only the flowers and berries for home remedies. Other parts of the plants, which have been used in traditional herbal medicine, are dangerous, with compounds that can easily turn into cyanide.

Distilled elderflower water is used to clean the skin, lighten freckles, and treat sunburn. An infusion or tincture of the flowers is supposed to be astringent, expectorant and diaphoretic. It's used with yarrow and peppermint for colds, flu, and asthma, and there's research indicating that it helps the immune system combat flu.

Herbalists also use elder flower infusion to soothe children's upset stomachs, and to relieve gas, and it's applied externally to swellings, rashes, and chilblains. It's used as an eyewash for conjunctivitis and eye inflammations. People also steeped the flowers in oil to make a massage lotion, which they also applied to burns and rashes, although dressing a burn with oil may make things worse.

An infusion of the berries is also considered astringent and diaphoretic. It's been used for colds, excessive mucus, and sore throats.

Only the cooked flowers and ripe berries of the elderberry are edible. Avoid eating other parts, which contain enough of a toxic alkaloid and cyanogenic (cyanide-releasing) glycosides to cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and coma. On the plus side, they don't contain enough poison to cause death!

Don't eat raw elderberries. They don't taste good to most people, and they're more likely to cause adverse reactions, but cooking or dehydration removes the rank flavor, and any slight residues of toxins. Eat only a small number of berries the first time, and increase your portions gradually. Elderberries make produce nausea and vomiting in 1 out of 50 people.

Other elderberry species (Sambucus spp.) grow throughout North America. The blue elder (S. cerulea) is a West Coast species similar to the common elderberry, but with dark blue to blackish berries. Reportedly even better-tasting than the common elderberry, as a New Yorker, I've never had the opportunity to try it.

Nor have I had the opportunity to try those species with red berries, which also grow in the Western US. All the better, since, while they're nonpoisonous, they're supposed to taste terrible.

Water hemlock is a deadly plant with umbrella-like clusters of white flowers and feather-compound leaves, but, unlike the common elderberry, it's herbaceous, not woody. Also, water hemlock's long-stemmed, umbrella-like flower clusters themselves are clustered like umbrellas (compound umbels), and its leaves are twice- or 3 times compound, not once-compound like the elder's.

Devil's walkingstick is a shrub or small tree with alternate feather-compound leaves that looks only a little like the common elderberry bush. It has edible shoots, but flat clusters of poisonous, black berries arranged small rings, and a short, unbranched, thorny trunk. Elderberry bushes have branches, large clusters of berries, no thorns, and opposite, not alternate, feather-compound leaves.
Elderblow, American Elderberry, American Elder, Common Elder, Elder, Elderberry
Both the young flowers and ripe berries of this common shrub are very tasty, although this shrub, which makes some people nauseous, isn't for everyone!
yarrow, peppermint
water hemlock, devil's walkingstick
Czeck Rice Pudding
czeck-rice-pudding1

Here’s a classic dessert that Czechs top with fresh fruit. I use wild berries when they’re in season.

As part of my whole foods and vegan cooking concepts, liquid stevia replaces sugar, and lecithin granules take over from egg yolks. Sweet brown rice, much more nutritious than refined white rice, has just the flavor and texture qualities that makes this pudding outstanding. Also, the flavoring choices here complement that of the traditional almonds. Czeck it out!

2 cups sweet brown rice
4 cups almond milk
1/4 cup elderberries or commercial currants
1/4 cup raisins
1/2 cup almonds or hazelnuts, chopped
1/4 cup lecithin granules
2 tbs. almond oil
1/2 tsp. almond extract
1/2 tsp. orange extract
1/2 tsp. amaretto extract (optional)
2 drops bitter almond extract (optional)
1/2 tsp. salt
2 cups of any fresh, wild berries; or other fresh fruit, sliced

1. Mix together all ingredients except for the fresh berries, and bake, uncovered, in a preheated 400 degree oven in an oiled casserole dish, for 2 hours, or until all the liquid is absorbed and the pudding is lightly browned.

2. Serve topped with the fresh berries.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 120 minutes
1)Common Elderberry in Flower
1common-elderberry-in-flower1

The common elderberry has dark green, alternate, feather-compound leaves with 5 to 11 opposite, sharply toothed, pointed, oval leaflets. A showy, lacy, branching terminal panicle holds many tiny, white, five-petaled, star-like flowers. And the cut branch below the smooth, gray, warty bark reveals a distinctive white pith inside.
4)Common Elderberry Fruit
4common-elderberry-fruit
These shiny, small, purple-black berries grow in great numbers at the end of branching panicles. Cooked with a sweetener, they're a wonderful addition to any dessert.
2)Elderberry Fruit Cluster
2elderberry-fruit-cluster
May small, shiny, oblong, black, berries replace the flowers on the very same panicles.
3)Common Elderberry Flowers
3common-elderberry-flowers

Tiny, five-petaled, star-shaped elder flowers create a showy display, growing in great numbers in flat-topped to slightly rounded, branching panicles, above the paired, elliptical, toothed leaflets of the feather-compound leaves.
Wild Grapes
wild-grapes
Vitaceae, the grape family

Most wild grape species are in season in autumn, although I once found ripe grapes in late summer. The leaves and tendrils are at their best from mid-to late spring, although you can still collect some in early summer.

Wild grapes grow in sunny and partially shaded habitats, in open woodlands and park lands, along lightly wooded trails, in edge habitats, thickets, and fields, on trees and fences, along streams and riverbanks, in thickets inland and near the seashore, and in wetlands.
Throughout North America
Various grape species are native to North America, but we also have Eurasia species, plus hybrids.

Look for high-climbing or creeping vines, usually forming dense thickets, with brown bark shredding in vertical strips. The persistent forked tendrils grow opposite to the three- or five-lobed, pointed, toothed, maple-like alternate leaves. Long clusters of about 20 dark purple, slightly greenish, or reddish, thick-skinned, spherical fruits, similar to commercial grapes, ripen mainly in autumn.

These high-climbing woody vines, which can also grow along the ground or create thickets, my reach from 60 to 100 feet in height. Brown bark shreds off in vertical strips, making wild grapes easily recognizable any time of year. Persistent forked tendrils attach the vine to trees and fences. They grow opposite to the leaves and become dark and brittle over time,

Usually three- or five-lobed, the broadly triangular to nearly heart-shaped or oval, pointed, toothed, alternate leaves, two to eight inches long and equally wide, resemble maple leaves. Veins spread like fingers from the leaf's base.

Long, inconspicuous clusters of tiny, fragrant, five-petaled, yellow-green flowers bloom in the leaf axils in mid-spring.

Green when immature, ripe wild grapes grow from 0.5 to 0.75 inch across. Spherical, smooth-skinned, and usually dark purple, they're occasionally slightly greenish or reddish. They grow in long clusters of about 20, like commercial grapes, but with thicker skins. Each grape contains two to six small, hard seeds.

Wild grapes most closely resemble commercial Concord grapes, and one wild species, the fox grape (V. labrusca), with the largest, sweetest, and tastiest fruit, is actually the Concord’s ancestor.

About 50 native species, plus introduced varieties and hybrids, grow throughout North America, and they're very hard to tell apart, but that's not a big concern for foragers, as they're all good to eat raw or cook.

•High-climbing or creeping vine with brown bark shredding in vertical strips
•Persistent forked tendrils opposite to the leaves, becoming dark and brittle over time
•Three- or five-lobed, broadly triangular, nearly heart-shaped or oval, pointed, toothed, alternate leaves, two to eight inches long and equally wide
•Long, inconspicuous clusters of tiny, fragrant, yellow-green, five-petaled flowers, blooming in the leaf axils in mid-spring
•Long clusters of about 20 dark thick-skinned, spherical, purple, slightly greenish, or reddish fruits 0.5 to 0.75 inch across, similar to commercial grapes
•Two to six small, hard seeds inside each grape

Collect medium-sized grape leaves. The smaller ones won't hold much stuffing and fall apart too easily, while the largest ones are too coarse and tough. You can also gather the green tendrils until they become too tough to chew, in mid-summer. Kids love hunting for these.

You usually have to search for fruit-bearing vines, since most grape vines don't bear fruit most years, and some years are better than others. Grapes do best in sunny locations and in dry years. Strip ripe grapes off the vines with your hands, and transfer them to food containers, or break off whole clusters and remove the grapes at home.

Grape leaves, a traditional food in the Middle East, where they're stuffed, are quite delicious. Cut off the stems and boil fresh grape leaves in lightly salted 1 minute (a dash of vinegar or olive oil is optional), turn off the heat, and let them steep in the hot water, covered, for 5 minutes or until tender, but not fragile. Then plunge them into cold water to stop the cooking. They should be tender enough to eat, but not so soft that they fall apart.

To stuff grape leaves, use any kind of stuffing that appeals to you, place a dollop in the center of the underside of a leaf, fold over the left and right edges so they meet in the center, and roll up the leaf from bottom to top. You may also cook chopped grape leaves in soups and stews, added at the end of the cooking time.

Grape tendrils are also good. They're too small to use as a major ingredient, but with their outstanding sour flavor, they make an excellent trail nibble and garnish.

Wild grapes have more flavor than commercial grapes, but they're less sweet, the skin is tougher, and they always have seeds. The ones that are too sour to enjoy raw are still great cooked, because of the intense flavor they add to any dessert. Cook them with a sweetener, plus a thickener if appropriate, and remove the seeds using a food mill. The pulp makes great jams, fruit sauces, toppings, puddings, ice cream, pancakes, and pie fillings. And, of course, you can also use wild grapes to make wine.

Grapes provide potassium, beta-carotene, fructose, tartaric acid, flavonols, caffeic acid, ellagic acid, quercetin, tannin, and malic acid, and the leaves are an excellent source of beta-carotene and vitamin B3.

People have confused three poisonous plants with wild grapes, but there are distinct differences you can use to tell them apart, so you won't poison yourself if you're careful.

Canada moonseed (Memispermum canadense) is a rare vine with leaves and fruit that resemble those of grapes. Fortunately, there are three distinct differences that make them easy to tell apart:
1. Each grape has many seeds, while Canada moonseed has one flattened seed shaped like a crescent moon.
2. Canada moonseed lacks the tendrils all grapes have, and climbs by twining.
3. Canada moonseed’s leafstalk attaches to the leaf by poking through the leaf near the base, while the grape’s leafstalk attaches at the leaf base. All parts of Canada moonseed contains a bitter toxic alkaloid called dauricine, that can lead to convulsions and death. There's only one good thing you can do with Canada moonseed: send it back to Canada!

Virginia creeper (Parthenocissus quinquefolia) is a common, low-growing or high-climbing poisonous vine with a palmate-compound leaf consisting of five toothed, elliptical leaflets, each up to about six inches long—completely different from the grape's simple, lobed leaves. Nevertheless, people have confused the tiny, spherical, blue-black berries, which contain oxalic acid, with grapes. Eating any part of this plant causes nausea, abdominal pain, bloody vomiting and diarrhea, dilated pupils, headache, sweating, weak pulse, drowsiness, twitching of face, and sometimes death.

Porcelainberry or amur peppervine (Ampelopsis brevipedunculata) is the best of the three look-alikes to use if you're going to accidentally poison yourself. All it will give you is a stomachache! This high-climbing vine has leaves similar to grape leaves, and tendrils too, but the vine isn't woody, it has a white pith rather than the brown pith of grape vines, and the gaudy, ripe fruit can be blue, purple, turquoise, or white—quite different from grapes.

Wild grapes are delicious, usually less sweet and more sour than commercial grapes, but they add way more flavor to fruit recipes. It's easy to find leaves to stuff in the spring, but you have to do some searching to find vines bearing fruit in the fall, and you must be aware of poisonous look-alikes and the features that let you tell them apart.
Virginia Creeper, Porcelain Berry
1)Pineapple-stuffed Grape Leaves
1pineapple-stuffed-grape-leaves

Pineapple-stuffed Grape Leaves

Here’s an unusual stuffed grape leaf appetizer that tastes authentic and wonderful.

20 wild or garden grape leaves, stems removed
5 cups rapidly boiling water
1 tbs. red wine vinegar or other vinegar
1 tsp. salt
1-1/2 cups cooked brown rice or other cooked grain
3/4 cups fresh pineapple, chopped
1/2 cup pignola or pine nuts
1/4 cup commercial currants
1 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1/8 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1/4 tsp. powdered ginger
1 tsp. dried water mint or other mint, ground

1. Boil the grape leaves in the water with the salt and vinegar 1 minute, turn off the heat, cover, and steep 5 to 7 minutes, or until tender but not mushy.

2. Meanwhile, mix together the remaining ingredients.

3. Drain and plunge the grape leaves into a bowl of cold water to stop any further cooking.

4. Place 1 tbs. of the stuffing in the center of the back of a leaf, fold over the left and right sides so they meet in the center, over the stuffing, and roll up the leaf from the base to the tip.

4. Repeat step 4 until all ingredients are used up.

Makes 20 stuffed grape leaves

Preparation time: 30 minutes
2)Wild Grape Jam
2wild-grape-jam

Wild grapes are often too sour for many people to enjoy raw, but they're outstanding cooked, sweetened, and thickened. This great grape jam, which you can use as a spread or in other dessert recipes, is proof.

7 cups wild grapes
1-1/2 cups grape juice
5 tbs. agar flakes
1 tbs. liquid stevia
2 tbs. vegetable glycerine
1/2 tsp. sassafras cambium or 1 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1 tbs. freshly grated or 1 tsp. dried orange rind

1. Simmer all ingredients together 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.

2. Remove the seeds using a food mill

3. Place a spoonful of the jam in a freezer for a few minutes. If too thin, add more agar and simmer for another 5 minutes. If too thick, stir in more grape juice or water and test again.

4. Refrigerate until jelled.

Makes 4 cups

Preparation/cooking time: 20 minutes
1)Wild Grapes with Leaves
1wild-grapes-with-leaves

Wild grapes have broadly triangular, oval, to heart-shaped, alternate, toothed leaves, and long clusters of dark purple fruit resembling commercial grapes. The tendrils, here at the base of the woody vine, are important for ruling out the poisonous Canada moonseed.
4)Wild Grape Cluster
4wild-grape-cluster
These dark purple, spherical, smooth wild grapes grow on long clusters, just like commercial grapes. Their relatively large size indicates that they're fox grapes, the tastiest species.
2)Wild Grape Leaves and Flowers
2wild-grape-leaves-and-flowers

Wild grape leaves are roughly triangular, oval, or heart-shaped. They're always toothed, and can have three or five lobes. The medium-sized ones are best for cooking and stuffing. The forked tendrils on the woody vines clinches the grape's ID.
3)Wild Grape Flowers
3wild-grape-flowers
The long raceme of inconspicuous, tiny, yellow-green flowers are configured like the grapes they'll become and will bloom in mid-spring.
Ground Cherry
ground-cherry
Solanaceae, the potato or nightshade family
The fruits ripen in mid- to late summer.
Dry, sunny, disturbed habitats, burned areas, hillsides, roadsides, and dry fields
Most of North America east of the Rocky Mountain states, but not Florida
We have native species, plus foreign wild and cultivated ones.

Look for an erect or prostrate, medium-sized plant one to three feet tall, with a weak, branching, hollow, ridged stem. The variable leaves are long-stalked, oval, triangular, or heart-shaped. The usually solitary, yellow to green-yellow (sometimes purple) bell- or wheel-shaped, five-lobed flowers with purple centers, hang from the leaf axils, giving way to inflated, ribbed, papery, lantern-like husks.

Growing up to one to three feet tall, this large group of similar plants with weak, branching, hollow, ridged, and often woody stems, which spread using rhizomes, may be erect or prostrate, and somewhat or very hairy.

The variable, coarsely toothed or toothless, medium-sized, long-stalked, triangular, oval, to heart-shaped leaves, which arise from where the stem branches, grow 1.5 to four inches long and one to 2.5 inches wide. When the leaves are opposite (they're also alternate), one leaf is much smaller than the other.

Usually yellow to greenish-yellow, with a purple to brown center (or sometimes all purple), the bell- or wheel-shaped, five-lobed flowers, 0.75 inch long, hang from the leaf axils, blooming in the summer. Usually solitary, they sometimes grow in clusters of up to five.

The brown, yellow, red, orange or purple, tomato-like fruits, 0.25 to 0.75 inch across and full of tiny seeds, hide inside an inflated, ribbed, papery, lantern-like husk 0.5 to 1.5 inches long.

•Erect or prostrate plant one to three feet tall with weak, branching, hollow, ridged stem
•Variable, long-stalked, oval, triangular, or heart-shaped leaves, sometimes hairy or coarsely toothed, arising from the stem's branches
•Yellow to green-yellow (sometimes purple) bell- or wheel-shaped, five-lobed flower with a purple center, usually solitary, hanging from the leaf axils
•Inflated, ribbed, papery, lantern-like husk 0.5 to 1.5 inches long, surrounding the fruit
•Small, tomato-like fruit, 0.25 to 0.5 inches across, yellow, brown, red, orange, or purple; spherical, and full of tiny seeds

Gather the fruits in the husks and let them ripen in the husks at room temperature for a few weeks if necessary. The husk becomes tan and papery as the fruit ripens, and the fruit becomes soft and sweet-tasting. To test for ripeness, feel whether the fruit is soft. In some species, the ripening berry will even burst through the husk.

Ground cherries taste like sweet tomatoes, so you can use them like fruits or like vegetables. In Mexico, people boil and mash them, and add raw, diced onions, chili, and cumin or coriander seeds. They use this sauce with burritos, tacos and enchiladas. You can use ground cherries in relish, jams, pies, puddings, or any recipe that calls for tomatoes.
Ground cherries are a good source of vitamin A , C, K, and, folate, plus alpha- and beta carotenes, choline, lutein, and zeaxanthin.
Avoid green-tinted berries, and all other parts of the plant, which are poisonous. Avoid bitter or strong-tasting fruits, which are unripe and poisonous.
The ground cherry is related the tomato (Solanum lycopersicum), but not cherries (Prunus spp.)

Avoid this nightshade's poisonous relatives, such as similar-looking plants with husk-less fruits such as the poisonous horse nettle, or those with fruit only partially enclosed. Avoid species with small fruits and husks smaller than 0.5 inch long, and don't eat plants with tight, rather than inflated, husks, or any that aren't ribbed. They're very dangerous, and I'm not ribbing you!
Tomatillo, Husk Tomato, Japanese Lantern
Similar to its cultivated relatives, the small, tomato-like fruit in this plant's lantern-like, papery husk, is wonderful raw or cooked.
Black Cherry, Sweet Cherry
Horse Nettle
1)Ground Cherry with Flowers and Fruit
1ground-cherry-with-flowers-and-fruit

This hairy plant has weak, ribbed stems, alternate, roughly oval, and slightly toothed leaves, plus five-lobed, bell-shaped flowers, and pointed, ribbed, ovate husks surrounding the sweet, edible fruit.
2)Ground Cherry Husks
2ground-cherry-husks
These ribbed, ovate, papery husks look like Chinese lanterns, but contain sweet, edible, tomato-like fruits inside.
Hawthorns
hawthorns
Rosaceae, the rose family

The developing leaves are edible toward the end of early spring.

Most hawthorns ripen in early- or mid fall, although some trees have fruit that persists well into the winter.
Thickets, fields, cultivated parks, edges of forests, along streets, in forests, and along streams
Throughout North America
Native and Eurasian hawthorn species grow throughout North America.

Look for small trees or shrubs with gray bark, sometimes vertically fissured, and branches armed with straight, sharp thorns. The variable, oval, alternate leaves are unevenly toothed or lobed. Flat-topped clusters of showy, white flowers are radially symmetrical, and rank-smelling. Hawthorns have loose clusters of round to heart-shaped, long-stemmed, red, dark purple, or yellowish, apple-like fruits.

This diverse group of shrubs and small trees grows 15 to 45 feet tall, with branches usually armed with straight, sharp thorns one to five inches long. Smooth and gray when young, vertical cracks develop in the bark of older trees.

The variable, raggedy-looking, strongly veined, oval, medium-sized alternate leaves may be lobed or unevenly toothed. They spiral around long shoots and grow in clusters on the short spur shoots that arise on the branches or twigs.

In early spring, showy, five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, rank-smelling, white flowers, 0.5 to 0.75 inch across, bloom in flat-topped clusters.

The round to heart shaped, long-stemmed, red (sometimes dark purple or yellowish) fruit, 0.25 to one inch across, grows in loose clusters. Each fruit contains one to five large, hard nutlets, but lacks the core of an apple.

•Small trees or shrubs with branches armed with straight, sharp thorns
•Bark smooth and gray when young, vertically fissured when older
•Variable, oval, alternate leaves, unevenly toothed or lobed
•Flat-topped clusters of showy, radially symmetrical, foul-smelling, medium-sized white flowers, blooming in spring
•Round to heart-shaped loose clusters of long-stemmed, red, dark purple, or yellowish, apple-like fruits, 0.25 to one inch across
•One to five hard nutlets inside each fruit
•No apple-like core

Some hawthorn trees have tiny fruits that consist of more seed than pulp. These are only good for making tea, or as a trail nibble.

Others have fruits close to an inch across. These are the best. Make sure they’re ripe—completely red, with no trace of green, and a little soft. Open a few to make sure they're not infested with maggots, which happens consistently on some individual trees, and rarely if ever on others. (This is especially important if you're a vegetarian.) Then pack the fruit that you don't eat into food containers.

Hawthorn fruits taste a little like sour apples, and they also contain pectin, the same thickener you get in apples. Eat them raw, or cook them in apple- or other fruit juice with a sweetener, along with sweet herbs such as cinnamon, nutmeg, and ginger or allspice. Then strain out the seeds with a food mill and blend in the blender or food processor if desired, to make a something akin to applesauce. Otherwise, cut out the seeds with a paring knife and use the fruit in any recipe that calls for apples.

The developing leaves, albeit somewhat bland-tasting, are good in soups, stews, and chili, cooked about 10 minutes.
Hawthorn berries provide vitamins C, B1, B2, B3, B5, B6, B9, and B12, plus PABA, choline, inositol, as well as flavonoids.
When harvesting hawthorns, don't poke yourself with the thorns, and don't forage from those trees where the berries are infested with maggots.
Crabapples, also edible, look like hawthorns, but hawthorns have no core: if you cut an apple across the "equator", the seeds form a five-parted star pattern, which you won't find inside hawthorns.
Thornapple, Hagedorn, Haw, Hazels, Gazels, Ladies Meat, Bread and Cheese Tree, Mayblossom, Hedgethorn, Maybush, Mayflower, Whitethorn
These berries, which grow on thorny trees or shrubs, taste somewhat like related apples, and they're good for the heart.
Wild Apples
1)Hawthorn Flowers and Berries
1hawthorn-flowers-and-berries

The Washington hawthorn, (C. phaenopyrum), shown here, has the largest and best-tasting fruit, and it's commonly planted in parks. The long-stalked, dark green, alternate leaves are slightly lobed and double-toothed. The radially symmetrical, five-petaled, white flowers, and the long-stalked, spherical, red berries, which have a crown of sepals at the tip, grow in loose clusters.
2)Hawthorn with Fruit, Flowers, Berries and Thorns
2hawthorn-with-fruit,-flowers,-berries-and-thorns

The hawthorn is a small tree or large shrub with branches armed with long, straight, sharp thorns. The oval, irregulary toothed, alternate leaves are sometimes lobed. The long-stemmed, spherical to heart-shaped fruits, usually red, grow in loose clusters.
Lemony Hawthorn Pudding
lemony-hawthorn-pudding

Here’s an improved version of a traditional lemon pudding, enhanced with vegan, whole ingredients, and an especially tasty wild fruit.

3-1/2 cups soy-rice milk or other non-dairy milk
1/2 cup walnut oil or almond oil
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/4 cup pignoli nuts or cashews
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin
1 tbs. arrowroot
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia
2 tsp. agar
2 tbs. lemon juice
1/2 tsp. vanilla extract
1/4 tsp. almond extract
1/4 tsp. salt
1/2 cup hawthorn berries, seeds removed
1/3 cup raisins

1. Purée all ingredients except the hawthorns and raisins in a blender.

2. Transfer to a heavy saucepan with the remaining ingredients and bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly.

3. Reduce the heat to low and simmer, uncovered, 10 minutes, or until the agar is dissolved and the pudding has thickened, stirring often.

4. Chill.

Preparation/cooking time: 30 minutes
3)Hawthorn Blossoms
3hawthorn-blossoms
Hawthorns have radially symmetrical five-petaled white flowers with many long stamens, and oval, alternate, toothed (here double-toothed) leaves.
4)Hawthorn Berries
4hawthorn-berries

The long-stemmed fruit of the Washington hawthorn are spherical and red, with a crown of many long, dark brown sepals at the tip. It looks like a crabapple, but lacks a core, and the branches are thorny.
5)Hawthorn Thorn
5hawthorn-thorn
Hawthorn means thorny hedge, and that's one of the reasons people planted them in the past. The thorns are long, strong, and sharp.
Juneberries
juneberries
Rosaceae, the rose family
The fruit of most juneberry species ripen in late spring, and you can sometimes still pick a few of their berries in summer. Some species ripen in the summer and fall, but they're relatively rare.

Various species prefer different habitats, although they generally grow in full sunlight or partial shade. You can find juneberries in moist and somewhat dry soil, in woods, along streams and lakes, on mountains, in thickets, clearings, and cultivated parks, in fields near the ocean, and on the grounds of landscaped parks, garden apartment complexes, and shopping malls, where they're planted for their showy flowers.
Juneberries grow throughout most of the US and Canada.
Most juneberries are native, but a couple of Eurasian species are sometimes planted too.

Look for multi-stemmed bushes or small trees with tight, smooth, ash gray to dark gray bark, marked with darker vertical lines and oval to elliptical, finely-toothed, stalked, medium-sized, alternate leaves that are light green underneath. The long, sparse racemes usually bear four to 20 showy, five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, medium-sized white flowers with five sepals. Later on, look for loose clusters of spherical blue berries, reddish or purple when unripe, each tipped with a 5-parted crown.

This group of mostly native multi-stemmed shrubs or small trees hybridize among themselves, making it hard to determine the number of species (botanists claim from six to 33 species), much less distinguish between them. But they all have smooth to slightly furrowed, tight, ash-gray to blackish bark, marked with wavy, vertical, dark gray to reddish stripes. Some species can grow up to 60 feet tall, but most are closer to 20 feet, with a spread of about ten feet.

The oval to elliptical, finely-toothed, stalked, alternate leaves, which turn red, yellow, or orange in the fall, usually grow to about two inches long and one inch wide, often with slightly downy, light green undersides. The leaf tip is pointed, the base rounded to slightly heart-shaped.

Long, sparse racemes two inches long, with four to 20 five-petaled, radially symmetrical, five-petaled white flowers, each 0.75 inch across and with five sepals, bloom early in the spring, before the leaves develop fully. With many conspicuously protruding stamens, they resemble the blossoms of their relative, the apple tree (Malus spp.)

The ripe blue-black (one species has berries that are red when ripe), spherical berries, reddish or purple at first, grow 0.25 to 0.33 inch across, the size of (unrelated) blueberries, which they resemble. Growing in loose racemes, they also have a frilled “crown” at the tip, like blueberries. Inside are several soft, irregularly elliptoid, almond-flavored seeds.

•Multi-stemmed bushes or small trees with tight, smooth, ash gray to dark gray bark, marked with vertical dark gray to reddish lines
•Oval to elliptical, finely-toothed, stalked, alternate leaves, usually about two inches long and 1 inch wide
•Leaves slightly downy, light green underneath
•Long, sparse racemes two inches long, usually bearing four to 20 flowers or berries
•Five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, showy, white flowers about 0.75 inch across, in early spring
•Five sepals under each flower
•Loose clusters of spherical blue berries (red in one species), reddish or purple when unripe, about 0.5 inch across, with a five-parted crown
•Several soft, irregularly elliptoid seeds inside the berries

And, as with most other wild foods, some years are better for juneberries than others, but you can usually harvest these berries in quantity without a huge amount of effort. Pull them off with your fingers, or use a saw-edged scoop.

Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. Bring additional food containers to transfer your harvest when your collection container and stomach are full.

This is simply one of the tastiest foods in the universe. Juneberries are usually exceptionally delicious—quite sweet, with the flavor of apples and blueberries, plus a hint of almonds from the soft seeds. Only a few varieties have bad-tasting fruits, but they're rare.

I use the berries raw in cereals, and bake them into muffins, pies, cakes, pancakes, and cobblers. They make a great jam, smoothies, and fruit sauces too, but there's virtually no dessert where they wouldn't be superb.

Juneberries contain pectin, so the puréed, cooked fruit will have some thickening properties, like apples.

Juneberries are loaded with anthocyanins, which reduce the risk of heart disease, cancer and diabetes. They're an excellent source of vitamin E, and provide vitamins C and B1, folate, potassium, iron, magnesium, and manganese as well.

Beware—these berries taste so good, they can make you die of happiness. Also, they can cause hair-loss—but only if you're a botanist trying to figure out which species is which—through excessive head-scratching!

There are no poisonous look-alikes, since no poisonous berry has a “crown,” but you can't go around eating any berries that are blue-colored, since there are bushes with poisonous berries that don't resemble juneberries at all but are colored blue.
The juneberries' fruit resembles that of blueberries (Vaccinium spp.), but those delicious wild berries have no detectable seeds, the shrubs don't have gray bark, and the flowers are bell-shaped.
Serviceberry, Sarvisberry, Shadbush, Shadblow, Shadwood, Saskatoon, Currant-tree Sugarplum, Chuckley Pear, and Wild-plum
If there's just one plant in this app you're going to want to find, this incredibly delicious berry is it!
Blueberries and Huckleberries
3)Juneberry Blossoms
3juneberry-blossoms

Landscapers plant juneberry bushes because of the showy display of white flowers, which bloom in early spring, before the leaves develop. The five radially symmetrical petals are nearly linear, and many stamens grow in the center.
5)Red Juneberry Bush, Berries, and Seeds
5red-juneberry-bush,-berries,-and-seeds

Most juneberry species are native to North America, but this one, A. alnifolia, var. ballerina, with red berries that ripen in autumn, not June, comes from England. Still, the bark is gray, the alternate, elliptical, toothed leaves aren't greatly different from other species, and the long-stalked, loosely clustered, apple-flavored berries, with their elliptoid, almond-flavored seeds, are quite good, although not as sweet as the blue varieties'.
1)Juneberry Blossoms and Berries
1juneberry-blossoms-and-berries

Juneberry bushes have alternate, elliptical, finely toothed leaves, usually light green underneath, with pointed tips and rounded bases. The showy, five-petaled, radially symmetrical white flowers grow on loose racemes in early spring. Long-stalked, spherical, blue berries grow in loose clusters, usually in late spring. Red when immature, the flowers' five sepals change into a five-parted crown at the berry's tip.
Juneberry Creme Pie
juneberry-creme-pie

An herb crust with ground almonds surrounding a juneberry filling, with just the right touch of seasonings, gives this fruit a luxuriant setting that makes it shine more than ever.

Crust Ingredients

1 cup (1/2 lb.) sweet brown rice flour
1 cup + 2 tbs. (1/2 lb.) barley flour
1 cup almonds, ground
1/2 cup arrowroot
1-1/2 tbs. almond oil
18 tbs. apple juice
1/2 tsp. nutmeg, ground
1 tsp. coriander, ground
1/4 tsp. salt

Filling Ingredients

6 cups juneberries or blueberries
4 cups silken tofu, drained
1-1/2 cup walnuts, chopped
1/4 cup arrowroot
1/4 tsp. salt
1 tbs. lemon juice
2 tsp. vanilla
2 tsp. clear liquid stevia
1/2 tsp. orange extract
1/4 cup lecithin granule

Other Ingredient

2 tsp. cinnamon, ground

1. Stir the flours, almonds, 1/2 arrowroot, nutmeg, coriander, and 1/4 tsp. salt together.

2. Mix in the almond oil, followed by the apple juice.

3. Knead briefly, then roll out two 3/8 inch thick circles on a floured pastry sheet, using a rolling pin covered with a floured sleeve, then transfer into 2 oiled, 9-inch pie tins. Reserve the remaining dough making lattices.

4. Purée all the filling ingredients except the berries and nuts in a food processor.

5. Stir in the berries and nuts.

6. Prick the crusts with a fork to keep them from rising, and fill with the filling.

7. Roll out the remaining dough into a rectangle, cut into strips, and arrange over the filling as a lattice.

8. Moisten the exposed pie dough well with water to keep it from burning.

9. Sprinkle with the cinnamon.

10. Bake 10 minutes in a preheated 425 degree oven.

11. Reduce the heat to 350 degrees and bake another 30 minutes, or until the crust is lightly browned and the filling is bubbly.

Makes 2 9-inch pies

Preparation time: 1 hour

Cooking time: 35 minutes

7juneberry-in-winter
The sparse, slender branches, plus the curving, vertical lines on the smooth bark, make the juneberry bush easy to recognize when there are no leaves.

Loose clusters of long-stalked, spherical berries, among the best-tasting foods on Earth, first pink, red, or purple, then blue, usually ripen in late spring. The five-parted flaring crown at the tip distinguishes them from any poisonous blue berries.

6juneberry-bark
The juneberry's smooth to slightly furrowed, tight, ash-gray bark, is adorned here with wavy, vertical, reddish stripes.
Kousa Dogwood
kousa-dogwood
Cornaceae, the dogwood family
The fruit ripens from early- to mid-fall
This tree grows in full sun and partial shade, in cultivated areas, parks and gardens
This tree is planted throughout much of North America, but doesn't spread into the wild.
China and Japan

Look for a small cultivated tree with flaky, mottled, brown and ocher bark; flower buds shaped like pointed onions; elliptical to oval, medium-sized, opposite leaves with undulating margins and parallel veins; a flower with 4 showy, large, white, oval, pointed, petal-like bracts; and a long-stalked, spherical, bumpy, fleshy, red-skinned fruit.

[Look for a small cultivated tree with flaky, mottled, brown and ocher bark, flower buds shaped like pointed onions and elliptical to oval, medium-sized, opposite leaves with undulating margins and parallel veins. The flower has four showy, large, white, oval, pointed, petal-like bracts then a long-stalked, spherical, bumpy, fleshy, red-skinned fruit.]

This small Asian tree, which grows from eight to 30 feet tall and at least equally wide, has flaky bark mottled with brown and ocher, and pointy tipped flower buds shaped like tiny onions.

The elliptical to oval, dark- to medium green, opposite leaves, which have undulating edges, grow from two to four inches long and 0.75 to 1 wide. The major veins are parallel, and the leaves turn red to red-purple in the fall.

Flowering begins in late spring with four showy, pointed, oval, white bracts one to two inches long about 0.5 to 0.75 inch wide, acting like petals, and a dull green, warty ball, smaller than a pea, in the center. In early summer, tiny, inconspicuous yellow-green to white flowers with four petals erupt from these warts, then disappear.

The bracts fall off, the bumpy sphere grows from one to 1.5 inches across. Upright at first, with a fruit stalk 1.5 to two inches long, it reddens, softens, and droops as it ripens. Under the red skin, the yellow-orange pulp contains several small, hard seeds.

•Small tree with flaky, mottled, brown and ocher bark
•Flower buds shaped like pointed onions
•Leaves opposite, elliptical to oval, two to four inches long and 0.75 to one wide
•Leaf margins undulating
•Major leaf veins parallel
•Four showy, large, white, oval, pointed, petal-like bracts surrounding a small, dull green sphere
•Tiny, inconspicuous, green-yellow, prong-like flowers, developing on the sphere in the center of the bracts
•Spherical, bumpy, fleshy, red-skinned, long-stalked fruit one to 1.5 inches across
•Fruit first upright, then pendant
•Yellow-orange pulp and small, hard seeds inside the fruit

Harvest from trees with large, ripe, soft, red, sweet-tasting fruit, when some of the fruit is falling. Quality varies greatly from tree to tree and and from year to year. Collect directly from the branches, and gather any ripe fruit from the ground. Don't collect unripe fruit, which won't ripen off the tree. Store the delicate fruit in plastic food containers, and store under refrigeration.

At its best, this fruit tastes like a sweet mango-apricot custard. If the skin is bitter, just eat the pulp and spit out the skin, along with the hard seeds.

I normally cook seedy fruits with a sweetener, sometimes with an added thickener, and strain out the seeds with a food mill. This doesn't work here. Cooking seems to bring out the worst of the skin, while creating an unappetizing gray color. Since the soft pulp makes peeling the skin impossible, I just enjoy the fruit raw.

The inedible flowering dogwood (K. florida) looks a little like the kousa dogwood when they're both flowering, but its bracts are rounded, not pointed, and the flowering dogwood's small, hard, inedible, capsule-shaped fruit is completely different from the kousa dogwood's spherical soft one, so it's easy to tell the two species apart.
Chinese Dogwood, Japanese Dogwood, Strawberry-tree
People plant this tree in their gardens as an ornamental, hardly suspecting that the unusual-looking fruit is edible and good.
1)Kousa Dogwood Flower and Fruit
1kousa-dogwood-flower-and-fruit

The kousa dogwood's pointed, oval to elliptical leaves have wavy margins, and their main veins are parallel. Tiny, inconspicuous, prong-like flowers grow on the center sphere, surrounded by four large, white, oval, pointed, petal-like bracts. The long-stalked, bumpy, spherical, red-skinned fruit grows upright at first, then droops. It's quite tasty and sweet when ripe.
