The true flowers here are the tiny prongs on the dark olive sphere in the center. They don't need to be showy because the four white, elliptical, pointed bracts surrounding them do the job of attracting pollinators.
4)Kousa Dogwood Fruits
4kousa-dogwood-fruits
People have planted this attractive tree throughout the country, unaware that the long-stalked, bumpy, spherical, red compound fruits, which hang in loose clusters, are edible and delicious.
Mayapple
mayapple
Berberidaceae, the barberry family
Mayapples ripen during the second half of the summer.
Dappled, light shade, in moist, rich, open woods, thickets, and pastures
Most of the eastern half of North America

Look for a single-stemmed colonial plant with one or two large, deeply lobed palmate-lobed leaves with a solitary, showy, fragrant, white, waxy, nodding, stalked flower arising from the leaf axil. A solitary, stalked, nodding, lemon-scented, ovoid fruit growing from the leaf axil drops to the ground and turns from green to yellow.

Growing from eight to 20 inches tall, this colonial plant spreads by dark brown, fibrous, jointed rhizomes.

Its one or two large, spreading, long-stalked, roughly circular, shiny, umbrella-like, deeply palmate-lobed, opposite leaves, four to 14 inches across, arise from a single, long, smooth, erect stem. The leaves are coarsely toothed toward the five to nine lobes’ tips, and the oblong to oval lobes are often partially divided at their tips as well.

In mid-spring, those plants with twin leaves bloom. A solitary, nodding, fragrant, showy, white, waxy, stalked flower, 0.75 to two inches across, arises from the axil at the base of the two leafstalks. Growing two inches wide, six sepals and six to nine petals surround the yellow-orange stamens and fused pistils.

From mid- to late summer, a solitary, nodding, lemon-scented, ovoid fruit, 1.25 to two inches long, falls to the ground from the axil, just as the leaves are dying back. As it ripens, it changes from green to yellow. White flesh and a few hard seeds lie under the thick skin.

•Single-stemmed colonial plant, eight to 20 inches tall, with one or two large, deeply palmate-lobed leaves, four to 14 inches across
•Leaves' five to nine oblong to oval lobes coarsely toothed toward their tips, which are sometimes divided
•Solitary, nodding, fragrant, showy, white, waxy, stalked flower 0.75 to two inches across, arising from the leaf axil
•Flower two inches wide, with six sepals and six to nine petals surrounding the yellow-orange stamens and fused pistils
•Solitary, stalked, lemon-scented, nodding, ovoid fruit 1.25 to two inches long, growing from the leaf axil
•Fruit dropping to the ground as the leaves are die back in mid-summer
•Fruit changing from green to yellow
•Fruit with white flesh and a few hard seeds under a thick skin
•Dark brown, fibrous, jointed rhizomes

Place the ripe and unripe fruits in separate containers. Eat, refrigerate, cook, or freeze the ripe fruits. Unripe fruit turns yellow, softens, and ripens at room temperature.

Although the plant usually grows in partially shaded areas in the woods, it only sets a good crop of fruit when it gets additional sunlight, and when it's cross-pollinated. So after 29 years of leading foraging tours, I only once got a really good harvest.

Peel and discard the tough skin, and enjoy the pulp, without the seeds, raw or cooked. It tastes like lemon custard. If you’re preparing it in quantity, simmer the coarsely-cut fruit for 5 to 10 minutes in fruit juice or non-dairy milk with a sweetener, along with a thickener if applicable, then use a food mill to remove the seeds, or remove them by hand when cooled.

The thick, tart pulp makes a great lemon substitute, and it's wonderful in pie fillings, custards, cake toppings, puddings, beverages, jams, jelly, marmalade, and sauces. You may also freeze the pulp in ice cube trays, store the cubes in food containers in the freezer, and add the cubes to recipes as needed.

Never eat the green, unripe fruit—it’s a powerful cathartic. All parts of this plant, except the soft, yellow, ripe fruit, are very poisonous. The rhizomes are especially bad. They cause salivation, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, excitement, inflammation of the stomach and intestines, fever, and coma. Death can ensue within a few hours of ingestion.

Even handling the rhizomes can create skin lesions, and getting any in your eyes will cause swelling, redness, and pain. And don't eat the thick skin of the ripe fruit, which may also be poisonous, or the hard seeds, which are poisonous.

Some sources claim the ripe fruit is poisonous if eaten in large quantity, but I only found enough to try this once. I didn't know that large quantities might be poisonous, and nothing happened to me except for a feeling of fullness (from eating all those delicious mayapples!)
The European mandrake (Mandragora officinarum) is a different, unrelated toxic plant that someone once decided had similarity to the may-apple, and confusingly transferred the same name.
American Mandrake, Wild Mandrake, Hogapple, Indian Apple, Mayflower, Umbrella Plant, Wild Lemon, Devil's Apple
This is a delicious fruit if you take proper precautions against poisoning yourself!
Sweet Mayapple Smoothie
sweet-mayapple-smoothie

Here’s an exotic beverage that’s as simple to make as it’s tasty.

3 cups soy-rice milk or other non-dairy milk
1-1/4 cup mayapple pulp; or the flesh of 1 mango, coarsely chopped, + 2 tbs. lemon juice
1/4 cup silken tofu
1/4 cup raw pignoli nuts or raw cashews
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia
1 tsp. grape seed oil, almond oil, sunflower oil, apricot kernel oil, or other light oil

Purée all ingredients in a blender.

Makes 5 cups

Preparation time:5 minutes
2)Mayapple Shoots
2mayapple-shoots

Colonies of what looks like shiny, raggedy, unopened plant umbrellas in early spring in the woods can only mean mayapples. One or two large, round, deeply lobed leaves will develop around a single, upright stem.
3)Mayapple Flower and Fruit
3mayapple-flower-and-fruit

The single flower, with six white petals and yellow-orange stamens and pistils, grows from the leaf axil above the single, smooth, erect stem, and between the two large, round, deeply lobed, long-stalked, umbrella-like leaves. The smooth, ovoid fruit matures from green to yellow.
4)Mayapple Fruit and Young Shoot
4mayapple-fruit-and-young-shoot

The mayapple begins as a thick, erect, unbranched, multi-colored column. The ovoid fruit, first green, then yellow, develops from the axil between the two long leafstalks, just as the plant is dying to the ground.
1)Mayapple with Immature Fruit
1mayapple-with-immature-fruit

The fruit of the mayapple develops from the flower, in the axil between the two long-stalked, deeply palmate-lobed, toothed leaves. Oval and green at first, it enlarges to the size of a hen's egg, drops to the ground, and turns yellow as it matures.
Mulberries
mulberries
Moraceae, the mulberry or fig family

The berries ripen in late spring, and a few late trees still bear fruit into early summer. Yet my wife and I once inexplicably found a very unusual red mulberry tree in a the Cross County Shopping Mall in Westchester, NY, with ripe fruit in early fall, but that only happened once, and I've never heard of it elsewhere, so I'm not going to add it to the tally!

The young, developing leaves are edible from mid- to late spring.
Residential streets, backyards, vacant lots, disturbed habitats, parks, fields, edges of woods, open woods, and near lakes, ponds, and rivers

The red mulberry grows throughout most of Eastern North America, the white mulberry grows throughout most of North America, but not Utah, the Texas mulberry grows in the Southwest, and the black mulberry grows in Texas, Louisiana, Ohio, West Virginia, and Kentucky.
The red and Texas mulberries are native, the black and white mulberries are from Europe and Asia respectively.

[Look down for a mess of squashed berries staining the sidewalk under a tree in late spring. Then look up for medium-sized trees with their vertical cracks or furrows on the bark, and an occasional orange-brown streak between the cracks. It has roughly oval, medium-sized, unlobed, mitten-shaped, or three-lobed, shiny, toothed, alternate, long-stalked leaves and small, soft, moist, spherical to cylindrical stalked multiple fruits, dark purple, pink, or white.

Mulberry bark has distinctive vertical cracks or furrows, with an occasional orange-brown streak between the cracks. The native red mulberry (M. rubra) and the Asian white mulberry (M. alba) are among the most common and widespread mulberry trees in North America. With rough, reddish-brown bark, the red mulberry reaches a height of about 65 feet, while the white mulberry, with rough, lighter, ochre-gray bark and spreading branches, only reaches 40 feet tall. Two additional similar species are the Texas mulberry (M. microphylla) and the black mulberry (M. nigra). All parts of mulberry trees exude a white, milky sap when injured.

Growing two to eight inches long the roughly oval, toothed, alternate, shiny, long-stalked leaves, which turn yellow in autumn, may be unlobed, mitten-shaped, or three-lobed. The red mulberry’s leaves feel rough underneath, while the white mulberry’s are smooth.

Tiny, yellow-white male and female flowers hang on separate, small, slender, inconspicuous spikes in mid-spring, while the leaves are still developing. The male's cluster is longer, 0.5 inch long, while the female's is shorter and rounder, 0.25 inch long.

The female flowers develop into spherical to cylindrical multiple fruits 0.5 to 1.5 inches long, each hanging individually from a slender, short fruit stalk. The fruit starts green. The white mulberries turn white and get soft and sticky. Also sticky when ripe, red mulberries become white, pink, reddish, purple, and finally nearly black. Hybrids of these species produce soft, sticky pink fruit.

•Medium-sized trees with distinctive vertical cracks or furrows on the bark, and occasional orange-brown streak between the cracks
•Roughly oval, unlobed, mitten-shaped, or three-lobed, shiny, toothed, alternate, long-stalked leaves two to eight inches long
•Leaves turning yellow in autumn
•Tiny, separate, spikes of yellow-white male and female flowers in mid-spring, 0.25 to 0.5 inch long
•Spherical to cylindrical multiple fruits 0.5 to 1.5 inches long, each hanging from a slender, short fruit stalk
•Ripe, soft, moist, sticky fruit, dark purple, pink, or white

Because these trees are so common, it isn't hard to find some growing away from heavy traffic with especially tasty fruit (quality varies from year to year, and trees with the largest berries in full sunlight are usually the best), and branches within reach. Although you can collect (or eat) the berries one at a time, it's more efficient to spread a medium-gauge, eight by 12 foot drop cloth, available in hardware stores, under the branches, and shake down the berries. If it's windy, put rocks or other weights on the corners of the drop cloth so it doesn't blow away. If you can climb the tree, you'll be able to shake more branches. Then carefully drag the drop cloth under other branches and repeat the process.

Bring lots of food containers. Your harvest may be immense. Pick over the contents of your drop cloth and remove any twigs leaves, and bugs [-(especially if you're a vegetarian!)] before gently transferring the fruit into your containers.

Harvest after a period of sunny, dry weather, for the best berries. Rain washes away much of the flavor.

Mulberries have a wonderfully sweet flavor, a little like figs, to which they're related, but juicy. They're very perishable, and get moldy after more than three days in the refrigerator—probably the reason they're not sold commercially. Plan to eat, cook, dehydrate, or freeze mulberries before they spoil.

Place mulberries in a colander, and set the colander in a low bowl. Run lukewarm water through the colander, and the berries won't overflow, but you'll get rid of much of the debris. Drain, then spread a layer of the berries on a tray or cookie sheet and pick out the remaining debris.

Add some lemon or lime juice to mulberry recipes if desired, since they lack the acidity of most other berries, and use them like other berries, in fruit salads, pies, muffins, cakes, pancakes, ice cream, jam, cobblers, compotes, fruit soups, or beverages. Or spread them on a cookie sheet and freeze, then pack into freezer containers. This way they won't stick together, and you can defrost them as needed.

Partially developed mulberry leaves are edible in early spring. Boiled them 20 minutes first and discard the water, which is somewhat toxic. The water and raw leaves, reputedly slightly hallucinogenic, produce such a bad headache and stomachache, that people who try to use them to get high once never seem to want to repeat the disaster!
Mulberries contain high levels of anthocyanins, vitamin C, and the minerals calcium, potassium, magnesium, iron, and zinc.

Large quantities of mulberries are supposed to be laxative, but my tour participants and I eat them in quantity every year, and I've never noticed my groups shrinking as the foragers start making for the bushes!

Don’t eat green, hard, dry, unripe mulberries (or any upripe fruit, for that matter). They can produce severe nausea, vomiting, and hallucinations.

And if you live in Iserlohn, Germany, don’t tell your mother that you eat mulberries—she might forbid it, claiming that the Devil uses them to blacken his boots!

The paper mulberry, (Broussonetia papyrifera or Morus papyrifera) has similar leaves, but they're very rough above and below. The frilly, red, spherical berry of this East Asian tree is edible, but I've never seen this tree, which has been planted in parks in NYC, bearing fruit.

Sassafras also has lobed and unlobed leaves, but, unlike mulberries, they’re fragrant and untoothed.

Raspberry and blackberry fruits superficially resemble mulberries, but these unrelated thorny canes aren't trees, and the fruits grow upright, on receptacles, instead of hanging from fruit stalks, like mulberries do.
This very tasty underappreciated fruit is common, widespread, and easy to collect in quantity, but it's only in season for a couple of weeks every year.
Mulberry Chocolate Pudding
mulberry-chocolate-pudding

Here’s a simple pudding combining sweet mulberries with creamy tapioca and the rich flavor of chocolate.

4 cups soy-rice milk, oat milk, or nut milk
1 cup tapioca pearls
1-1/4 cup red mulberries or other berries
3/4 cup vegan carob chips
1/4 cup unsweetened Dutch cocoa
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1 tbs. liquid stevia
1 to 2 tsp. coffee extract, or to taste
1/2 tbs. vanilla
1 tsp. orange extract

1. Bring 3 cups of the soy-rice milk, tapioca, and mulberries to a boil over medium heat in a heavy saucepan, stirring constantly.

2. Reduce the heat to low and simmer 15 minutes, stirring often.

3. Meanwhile, purée the remaining ingredients in a blender.

4. Remove the saucepan from the heat, stir in the purée, and chill before serving.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 20 minutes

Chilling time: 3 hours

2red-mulberries

These purple-black multiple berries hang from short, slender fruit stalks in great abundance, on branches that also support roughly oval, shiny, toothed, irregularly lobed, long-stalked, alternate leaves.
1)Ripe and Unripe Red Mulberries
1ripe-and-unripe-red-mulberries

These round to cylindrical multiple fruits hang individually from short, slender fruit stalks, grow among irregularly lobed, roughly oval, shiny, toothed, long-stalked alternate leaves. Beginning green, they turn pink and purple, then finally mature to a nearly black purple.

Tiny, yellow-green, and inconspicuous, the longer male flowers grow on separate spikes from the shorter, rounder female flowers, in mid-spring, while the oval, toothed leaves are still developing, on ocher-brown branches.

These ripe fruits, all cylindrical, soft, moist, and sticky, hang individually from short, slender fruit stalks. Confusingly, the red mulberry (left) is purple-black, while the pink mulberry (right) is reddish, but it can also be pink, depending on which genes of its two parent species predominate. At least the white mulberry (center) is what you'd expect.
5)Branches with Red Mulberries
5branches-with-red-mulberries

Hanging individually from short, slender fruit stalks, the dark purple-black ripe fruits are pink before they ripen. The shiny, toothed, oval leaves on the slender, drooping branches are sometimes lobed, sometimes unlobed.
Pawpaw
pawpaw
Annonaceae, the custard apple family
Pawpaws ripen from summer to early fall.
Deep, rich, moist soil, shade or partial sunlight, along streambanks, in forests, river valleys, and bottomlands
The pawpaw tree grows in the Southeast and Midwest. Sadly, for reasons scientists are still debating, it's in decline, and its range is shrinking.

Look for a small tree or multi-branched shrub with bumpy gray and light brown bark, sometimes cracked. Slender, spreading-ascending branches hold large, dark green, smooth-edged, membranous, oblong to lance-shaped, drooping, alternate leaves and small clusters of medium-sized, six-petaled, velvety, bell-shaped, hairy-stalked flowers. The fruits are bumpy, flattened, yellow-green, brown-spotted, mango-sized and -shaped.

This small tree or multi-branched shrub, with slender, spreading-ascending branches, grows ten to 40 feet tall and eight to 12 inches wide. The gray and light brown bark is bumpy, patchy.

Wider toward the tip and tapering toward the base, the large, thin, smooth-edged, membranous, oblong to lance-shaped, drooping, alternate leaves, dark green above and lighter below, grow from four inches to one foot long, and from two to six inches across. They smell like bell peppers when injured.

As new leaves begin to develop in the spring, one to four maroon, six-petaled, velvety, bell-shaped, fetid-smelling, hairy-stalked flowers one to 1.5 inches across grow clustered in the axils of the previous year's growth, with three green, red-spotted sepals.

The irregularly bumpy, oblong, aromatic, flattened, mango-sized and -shaped fruit grows from three to seven inches long and one to two inches thick, in clusters of two to nine. Often powdered with a whitish, waxy bloom, it turns from green to yellow, and becomes spotted with brown as it ripens.

Under the skin, rows of large, flat, brown, bean shaped, laterally compressed seeds, up to 1 inch long, grow in the sweet, aromatic pulp.

•Small tree or multi-branched shrub with slender, spreading or ascending branches
•Corky gray and light bark
•Large, thin, smooth-edged, membranous, oblong to lance-shaped, drooping, alternate leaves, 4 inches to 1 foot long, and 2 to 6 inches across
•Injured leaves bell pepper-scented
•From one to four flowers growing from previous year's leaf axils
•Six-petaled, velvety, bell-shaped, fetid-smelling, hairy-stalked, maroon flowers, one to 1.5 inches across
•Three green, red-spotted sepals
•Clusters of two to nine irregularly bumpy, oblong, aromatic, mango-shaped fruits, three to seven inches long and one to two inches thick.
•Sweet, aromatic pulp with rows of large, flat, brown, bean shaped, laterally compressed seeds, up to one inch long, under the skin

You can collect pawpaws by hand and transfer them to food containers, or gently shake the branches over a drop cloth. Try not to break the pawpaws, or the oozing pulp will cause problems.

If you live where critters can get the fruit, collect it unripe and store in a cool place until it ripens.

Peel pawpaws, discard the poisonous seeds, and use the pulp raw or cooked, like bananas. It has a banana’s texture, with overtones of pear, strawberry, pineapple, and mango. Try using the pulp in your favorite banana bread recipe, add it to smoothies, or use it in ice cream, muffins, cakes, pies, and puddings.

Pawpaws provide lots of vitamin C, magnesium, iron, copper, and manganese, as well as potassium, several essential amino acids, and significant amounts of vitamins B2 and B3, phosphorus, and zinc, plus more calories than most edible wild plants. They also contain the enzyme papain, which aids protein digestion.

Paw-paws may be slightly laxative and sedative, so don't drive a car after you've eaten them until you determine whether they'll make you fall asleep on the way to the bathroom!

The toxic fresh or tinctured seeds are emetic and produce a stupor, and should be avoided.

Also, eating pawpaws can cause nausea and vomiting susceptible people, so eat very small quantities the first time, and gradually increase your portion sizes. After I had no reaction the first time I ate a small serving, I made a pawpaw smoothie, drank a whole glassful, and promptly threw up—the only time I ever experienced a bad reaction from a wild food!

Don't go "picking up pawpaws and putting them in your pocket," as the traditional song goes, or the oozing pulp will ruin your pants!
Custard Apple, Indiana Banana, Hoosier Banana, Poor Man's Banana
This delicious wild fruit looks like a stubby banana, with a similar texture, and a flavor of many sweet fruits.
Baked Sweet Pawpaws
baked-sweet-pawpaws

If you have a big harvest of pawpaws and need to make a recipe in a hurry, here's one that's as tasty as it's quick and easy to make.

The pulp of 12 pawpaws or 8 sliced bananas

Mix together all ingredients, transfer into an oiled casserole dish and bake, uncovered, 1 hour, or until thickened and bubbly.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 60 minutes

This small tree, with slender, spreading-ascending branches, has large, thin, smooth-edged, membranous, oblong to lance-shaped, drooping, alternate leaves. Unfortunately, as here, it doesn't bear fruit every year.
2)Pawpaw Flower
2pawpaw-flower

The pawpaw's velvety, bell-shaped, six-parted flower grows from the axil of a leaf from the previous year.

The bumpy, gray bark is punctuated by large, crescent-shaped leaf scars, which, in turn, are dotted with bundle scars of the vessels that transported material to and from the previous year's leaves. And small buds anticipate leaves yet to come.

The large, lance-shaped to oblong, alternate leaves are thin and membranous.

The pawpaw's mango-shaped fruit, which will ripen in late summer and early fall, grows on the branches in small clusters. The thin, membranous, lance-shaped to oblong, alternate leaves are among the largest simple leaves you'll see on any edible fruit tree.
Wild Peach
wild-peach
Rosaceae, the rose family
Wild peaches usually ripen in mid-summer.
Sunny places, parks, fields, thickets, roadsides, and disturbed areas
Many of the eastern and Western states, and Manitoba, but not the Central States
China

Look for a small tree with slender, curving branches. It has narrow, curving, lance-shaped, sharp-pointed, finely-toothed, medium-sized, alternate leaves. The five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, solitary or paired, large, showy, pink flowers are short-stalked. They're downy, gently grooved, and yellow, with a red blush, and look like imperfect commercial peaches.

This small tree, growing 10 to 30 tall and 10 to 15 feet wide, has slender, curving branches.

Tapering to a sharp point, the long, narrow, curving, lance-shaped, finely-toothed, alternate leaves grow three to six inches long and one to two inches wide.

The large, showy, five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, solitary or paired, pink flowers, two to four inches across, bloom in early spring, before the leaves open.

Similar to its domestic forerunner, the short-stalked wild peaches are downy, gently grooved, and yellow, with a red blush. The flesh is yellow or white. There's one large, brown, oval, corrugated stone, with an almond-like inner kernel inside.

•Small tree with slender, curving branches
•Narrow, curving, lance-shaped, sharp-pointed, finely-toothed, alternate leaves, three to six inches long and one to two inches wide
•Large, showy, five-petaled, radially-symmetrical, solitary or paired pink flowers, two to four inches across
•Flowers blooming in early spring, before the leaves are developed
•Short-stalked fruit similar to commercial peaches—downy, gently grooved, and yellow, with a red blush
•Flesh yellow or white
•Large, brown, oval, corrugated stone containing an almond-like inner kernel

Pick peaches from the branches or the ground, separate the ripe from unripe fruit (which ripens at room temperature) and transfer to food containers. Wild peaches are much more delicate than commercial peaches, so proceed carefully. Use the good parts of trimmed damaged peaches.

Subject to natural selection rather than being selected by business for durability, wild peaches are far juicier and sweeter than commercial peaches, although you'll have more trouble shipping or storing them for the market. Just trim away any damaged parts, and be prepared for peaches that are way tastier than the ones you buy. Enjoy them raw, put them in fruit- or mixed salads, slice them onto cereals, and use them in pies, puddings, jam, ice cream, cobblers, shakes, and cakes.
Peaches provide vitamins B1, B2, B3, B6, and C, beta-carotene and folate, plus the minerals potassium, calcium, magnesium, phosphorous, selenium, and zinc.
Don’t eat the raw kernel inside the pit. It contains amygdalin and hydrocyanic acid, which can potentially turn into cyanide, although they're destroyed by heat.

Nectarines are smooth-skinned peaches, not a cross between peaches and plums as is commonly believed. I've only found 1 such wild tree, in Central Park, where it produced great crops year after year until sadly, its short lifespan came to an end.

The wild apricot tree (P. armeniaca) is a small tree, with medium-sized, simple, alternate, wedge-shaped, finely-toothed leaves, and spherical, orange fruits, smaller than peaches. Another escape from cultivation, it's supposed to grow in Pennsylvania, Illinois, Missouri, Kansas, Colorado, Utah, Idaho, Montana, California, and Oregon, but I found two trees in separate locations in Marine Park, Brooklyn, near the seashore, so they could be growing in sandy fields and thickets anywhere apricot-eating people tossed away the pits.
This fruit is way sweeter, more flavorful, and juicy than commercial peaches, but also way more perishable and subject to insect attack.
Wild Apricots

Preparation time: 20 minutes

Freezing time: 2 hours
1)Peach Blossoms and Fruit
1peach-blossoms-and-fruit

Wild peach blossoms grow along the slender branches singly or in twos, before the leaves have developed. Large and showy, they have five pink, radially symmetrical petals.

Peach leaves, long, slender, and curved, are so different from other trees' leaves, once you've seen them, they'll always be easy to recognize. Finely toothed, these elliptical alternate leaves taper to a point.

The fruit looks like that of commercial peach trees, but smaller and not as perfect-looking, but way juicier and tastier.

Purple-flowering Raspberry
purple-flowering-raspberry
Rosaceae, the rose family
Purple-flowering raspberries ripen toward the second half of the summer.
Moist shade, thickets, partially shaded woodland edges, and landscaped parks
Northeastern North America, parts of the Deep South, and Washington State

Look for erect canes with shredding old branches and red-bristly new branches covered in large, coarse, broad, ovate, light green, three- to five-parted palmate-lobed, alternate leaves. The showy, fragrant, saucer-shaped flowers have five large, purple-pink petals and a yellow central disk. Flattened, red, hollow, cup-shaped raspberries form in the summer.

This erect shrub, four to six feet tall, with a spread of six to 12 feet, doesn’t look like other raspberries. Instead of thorns, bristly red hairs cover its new branches, while the reddish-brown bark of older stems flakes off.

Its coarse, broad, ovate, alternate, light green, three- to five-parted palmate-lobed leaves, which grow up to ten inches long, resemble large maple leaves—quite different from the palmate-compound leaves of other raspberries.

The showy, saucer-shaped flowers grow up to almost four inches across, singly or in small clusters, with five fragrant, purple-pink petals and a yellow central disk of stamens and pistils.

The flattened, red, hollow, cup-shaped berries, 0.75 inch across, are drier, less abundant, and more crumbly than other species, but quite tasty.

•Erect cane with exfoliating old branches and red-bristly new branches
•Coarse, broad, ovate, light green, three- to five-parted, alternate, palmate-lobed leaves, up to 10 inches long
•Large, showy, fragrant, saucer-shaped flowers up to nearly four inches across, singly or in small clusters
•Flowers composed of five large, purple-pink petals, and a yellow central disk of stamens and pistils
•Flattened, red, hollow, cup-shaped berries, 0.75 inch across

Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. The berries are small, so bringing additional food containers to transfer your harvest usually won't be necessary, unless you'll be collecting different berries too.

Virtually every foraging book and botanical website tells you how bad these berries are, but they're all wrong. Looks like an initial mistake has been repeated repeatedly without anyone tasting the fruit in questions. These berries are quite delicious, as anyone one any of my tours who has tried them will attest. The only drawback is that they're too small and sparse to collect in quantity so I use as a trail nibble and a garnish.
Thimbleberry, Pink Thimbleberry, Flowering Raspberry,

This unusual thornless raspberry has leaves that look like maple leaves rather than palmate-compound leaves, and large, showy flowers which make it a favorite among landscapers—quite fortunate for foragers, since the red, cup-shaped raspberries are quite delicious.
1)Purple-flowering Raspberry in Flower
1purple-flowering-raspberry-in-flower

This atypical thornless raspberry has large, three- to five-lobed simple leaves that look like maple leaves, and loose racemes of large, showy, five-petaled flowers that will develop into cup-shaped red raspberries.
2)Purple-flowering Raspberry Flower
2purple-flowering-raspberry-flower

Orange-glazed Tempeh with Purple-flowering Raspberries
orange-glazed-tempeh-with-purple-flowering-raspber

I rarely use this fermented soybean conglomeration because of its bitterness, but here, the undesirable flavor is completely vanquished by reduced orange juice, purple-flowering raspberries, and herbs

6 tbs. olive oil
30 oz. tempeh, diced

Glaze

3 cups freshly squeezed orange juice (from 5 large juice oranges)
6 cloves garlic, crushed
1/4 cup fresh ginger, chopped
2 tbs. tamari soy sauce
1-1/2 tbs. white wine
1 tbs. slippery elm powder (available in health food stores)
1/2 tbs. liquid stevia
2 tsp. coriander, ground

Other Ingredients

1/2 cup sweet cicely leaves or cilantro, chopped
1 tbs. Sumac Concentrate or lime juice or
1-1/4 cup purple-flowering raspberries or other berries

1. Sauté the tempeh in the olive oil 5 to 10 minutes, or until browned

2. Meanwhile, mix the glaze ingredients together.

3. Purée the glaze ingredients in a blender and pour the glaze over the tempeh.

4. Cook over high heat to reduce the glaze, stirring often, until the glaze begins to thicken.

4. Lower the heat to prevent burning as the liquid thickens, and stir constantly.

4. When the liquid has evaporated, serve with the berries, sweet cicely leaves, and the sumac concentrate or juice.

Serves 6

Preparation/cooking time: 30 minutes
http://dev.winterroot.net/deepwinter/foraging/cms#pageId-2205
3)Purple-flowering Raspberry Fruit
3purple-flowering-raspberry-fruit
This raspberry has cup-shaped fruit with bristly, triangular sepals—not uncommon, but what's unusual is that it lacks prickles.
Prickly Pear
prickly-pear
Cactaceae, the cactus family
The pads are in season from mid- to late spring, the fruits from mid-fall into the winter.
Sunny, sandy or rocky soil, sandy shores, dunes
Prickly pears officially range throughout all of the US except northern New England, and most of southern Canada, but they're only greatly abundant in the Southwest.
The center of diversity for this genus is in Mexico.

Look for stands of cacti consisting of flattened pads connected by flattened joints, with a few spines emerging from small, dark bumps. Showy, yellow flowers with many petals grow at tips of the pads with elongated, egg-shaped fruits, narrowing at the base and wider at tip. They give way to elongated, egg-shaped fruits, narrowing at the base and wider at tip.

DON'T feel for the tiny, barely visible, painfully prickly spines that cover this plant!

These low-growing cacti consist of fleshy pads separated by flattened joints. Prickly, easily detachable bristles, almost too fine to see, called glochids, cover the whole plant, including the fruits, as do a few smooth, fixed spines.

Showy, radially-symmetrical, yellow flowers three to five inches across, with ten to 12 petals, grow on the pads’ upper segments in early summer.

Club-shaped, dull red-purple fruits ripen from late summer through autumn, persisting into the winter. Flat on top and tapering toward the bottom, they grow from one to two inches long and about 0.75 inch across. Many hard, flattened, nearly circular seeds grow inside the red pulp.

Even more prickly than picking up this plant without protection is trying to differentiate the 200 species, especially since they hybridize readily. Fortunately, they're all edible.

The eastern prickly pear or devil's tongue (O. humifusa), with brick red fruit, is prostrate, growing up to eight inches long. I've found it in dunes along the seashore in NYC, where it's rare, but it's much more common from the coastal NJ to the Gulf Coast.

Various Western species may be tall or short, and the fruit may be yellow, red, purple, or white. The most common of these, the tulip prickly pear (O. phaeacantha), grows up to three feet tall when it's not prostrate. With pads sometimes over one foot across, and larger, juicier, more abundant fruit, it's better than the Eastern species. Engelman’s prickly pear (O. engelmannii), another Southwest species, is even larger, reaching four to ten feet tall.

•Stands of cacti consisting of flattened pads connected by flattened joints
•A few spines emerging from small, dark bumps on the pads
•Showy, yellow flowers with many petals at the tips of pads, in early summer
•Elongated, egg-shaped fruits, narrow at base, wide at tip
•Many small, hard, flattened, nearly circular seeds inside fruit's red pulp
•Tiny, painful, barely visible prickly spines on the pads and fruits
Twist or cut off and collect the young pads and the ripe fruit wearing heavy-duty work gloves. Transfer them to containers, and avoid any contact with your skin until they've been processed.

Wearing heavy-duty work gloves, rub the fruit or pads vigorously with a damp towel to remove all the bristles, or place the fruit or pads on a stove burner and singe away the glochids over high heat, turning often with tongs.

The flavor of the fruit ranges from bland to sweet and delicious. The Eastern species, with which I'm the most familiar, tastes like a pulpy combination of watermelon and blackberry. You can peel it, remove the sweet pulp, and eat it as is, or remove the seeds by hand (the plant gummed up my food mill) and use the pulp in fruit recipes. It’s great in sauces, puddings, jelly, and beverages.

You can also dry the seeds and grind them, pre-roasted if desired, into a nutty-flavored flour, using a grain mill, blender, or coffee- or spice grinder.

In the spring, the tender, young, new pads make a mild, mucilaginous green vegetable, much like okra. You'll love it if you like okra, but not if you hate okra. Add it to stews and soups, which it thickens, cooking in 15 to 20 minutes.

You can also fry strips of the pads, as people in Mexico do. If you don’t like the gummy texture, pre-boil the sliced pads 10 minutes, then rinse them before proceeding.

The fruit is an excellent source of vitamin C, E, and carotinoids, the minerals calcium, potassium, and phosphorous, plus biothiols, taurine, and flavonols. The pads provide beta-carotene and potassium, and the seeds are high in protein and oils.

The whole plant, but especially the fruit, contain health-promoting antioxidants, including 3-methoxytyramine, candicine, hordenine, N-methyltyramine, tyramine, betanin, and indicaxanthin, although this varies from species to species. The take-home message: this plant is very good for you!

The glochids are harmless, but only so long as you don't touch them! Otherwise, always handle this plant with heavy-duty work gloves. If you do get the glochids in your skin, shine a bright light on the area and have someone with very good eyesight pull the prickles out, one by one, using tweezers.

Eating too many prickly pear fruits gives some people constipation.

Dry, woody, inedible relatives, called chollas (Cylindropuntia spp.), have cylindrical joints between the pads, not flattened joints like prickly pears. You can cook these, but then they come out like cooked wood!
Cactus Pear, Indian Fig, Nopales, Paddle Cactus, Tuna, Nopal

This delicious edible cactus has edible pads, which are often served, fried, in the better Mexican restaurants. It's fruits are very tasty, and the plant has medicinal uses as well. You have to handle and prepare it correctly, or you'll be stuck with very painful, nearly invisible prickles.
Chollas
1)Eastern Prickly Pear Pad in Flower
1eastern-prickly-pear-pad-in-flower
About two inches long and one inch wide, the showy, yellow flowers, with many petals, grow on top of the pads. It's the club-shaped base under the flowers that will turn into the fruits.
3)Eastern Prickly Pears in Flower
3eastern-prickly-pears-in-flower

These cacti grow in dense stands, with showy, yellow, many-petaled flowers on the tops of the flat pads. Spines sometimes emerge from the dark bumps, and nearly invisible prickly glochids grow everywhere.
4)Eastern Prickly Pear Fruit
4eastern-prickly-pear-fruit

The egg-shaped, reddish green fruits of the eastern prickly pear, broad on top and tapering toward the base, grow two to three inches long. As with the flattened pads, which can pile up to three levels, they're covered with nearly invisible, prickly glochids.
2)Vegan Tuna Jelly
2vegan-tuna-jelly

Is there something fishy about this recipe? Not at all. Prickly pear fruits are called tuna in Mexico! And this fruit is so glutinous, turning it into jelly is a simple as cooking it in a liquid with a sweetener, and removing the seeds. You can use the jelly just like commercial jelly, as a spread or a topping, although it has its own unique flavor.

2 cups prickly pears, glochids removed, and peeled
2 cups apple juice
1 tsp. liquid stevia

1. Simmer all ingredients together for 10 minutes.

2. Blend briefly at low speed in a blender to loosen the seeds.

3. Press the pulp through a sieve with a large rubber spatula to remove the seeds (or split the fruit in half with a knife and remove the seeds with a grapefruit spoon before cooking).

Makes 1-1/4 cups

Preparation/cooking time: 30 minutes
1)Cactus Cutlets
1cactus-cutlets

Prickly pear cactus pads, properly prepared, have a mild flavor and okra-like texture, ideal for breading and baking. They're very tasty, and nothing else is quite like them. Serve this vegetable side dish piping hot.

6 prickly pear cactus pads (available in season in Mexican grocery stores, as well as in the wild)
3/4 cup water
2 tbs. peanut oil
2 tbs. liquid lecithin
2 tbs. mellow miso
1 tbs. flax seeds ground into 2 tbs. meal
1/2 tbs. chili powder
2 cups bread crumbs

1. Pass the cactus pads over the stove burner on high heat, using tongs, to singe the thorns.

2. Scrape off the singed thorns with a paring knife.

3. Cut into strips 1/2 inch wide.

4. Boil in water to cover 15 minutes.

5. Meanwhile, purée the 3/4 cups of water, the peanut oil, liquid lecithin, miso, powdered flax seeds, and chili powder in a blender.

6. Pour over the cactus strips.

7. Stir in the bread crumbs.

8. Bake on a non-stick baking pad on a cookie sheet, or on an oiled cookie sheet, in a preheated 375 degree oven 30 minutes or until lightly browned.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Cooking time: 30 minutes
2)Eastern Prickly Pear Flower
2eastern-prickly-pear-flower

The eastern prickly pear's flat, oval pad is covered with small, round, black bumps which sometimes have a couple of thorns, but the really nasty glochids are nearly invisible. The showy, yellow flowers, with many petals, grow on top of the pads, over a club-shaped base which will eventually become the fruit.
American Mountain-Ash Tree
american-mountain-ash-tree
Rosaceae, the rose family
At its best after subjected to frost, the fruit ripens in late fall and persists into the winter.
Full sun or partial shade, rich, moist soil, the borders of swamps, and rocky slopes.
Eastern North America, the Great Lakes region, and southeastern Canada.

Look for a small tree or shrub with gray-brown bark that cracks with age. American mountain ash has hairless, alternate, feather-compound leaves consisting of 11 to 17 finely toothed leaflets that usually arch, and showy, flat-topped flower clusters of tiny, cream-white, five-petaled flowers. It's small, spherical, red-orange berries are in loose, branching clusters.

The small tree or shrub grows from ten to 30 (rarely 40) feet tall, with a short trunk four to ten inches wide, slender, spreading branches, a narrow, open, rounded crown, and a spread of up to 15 feet. Smooth and spotted with lenticels when young, the gray-brown bark cracks and develops fissures and scaly patches with maturity.

The hairless, feather-compound, alternate leaves grow six to 12 inches long, with 11 to 17 finely toothed, lance-shaped leaflets two to five inches long and 0.66 to one inch wide. The slender, dark green or red leafstalk is grooved. Often arching, the leaflets are dark green above and pale green below. They turn dull red, purple, orange, or yellow in autumn.

Showy, flat-topped clusters three to five inches across hold many small, creamy-white five-petaled flowers 0.125 inch across, from late spring to early summer, to be replaced by clusters of seedy, red-orange, spherical berries, 0.25 to 0.75 inches across, in the fall and winter.

•Small tree or shrub with gray-brown bark that cracks with age
•Hairless, alternate, feather-compound leaves six to 12 inches long
•11 to 17 finely toothed leaflets, two to five inches long, often arching
•Slender, grooved, dark red or green leafstalk
•Showy, flat-topped flower clusters three to five inches across
•Cream-white, five-petaled flowers 0.125 inches across
•Loose, branching clusters of spherical, red-orange berries, persisting into winter

Plan your harvest when it's above 40 degrees F if possible, so you can work without gloves. Break off bunches of berries and transfer them to food containers. You can remove the berries from the stalks at home.

After it's been subjected to frost, the fruit is tasty cooked, somewhat similar to crab apples (Malus spp.) Otherwise, the tannin content makes it too astringent to enjoy. Cooked, sweetened, and strained of its seeds, it's similar to applesauce, edible on its own, and a good addition to cookies or pies.
This fruit contains vitamin C and iron.

The raw seeds, which are too hard to eat, have the potential to release cyanide. Don't separate them from the fruit, grind them up, and force yourself swallow large quantities of them without cooking them (which destroys the poison) first!

Don't travel to the Himalayas, where there are very many similar-looking relatives—trying to figure out which is which may cause you to die of confusion!

The mountain ash isn't an ash. True ash trees ( Fraxinus spp.) have smooth, rather than toothed leaves, and they don't have berries.

The European mountain ash (S. aucuparia), also called the rowan tree, is very similar to its American relative, with edible orange berries, but it grows only under cultivation in North America. And it's winter buds are hairless, while the American mountain ash's are fuzzy.

The northern mountain ash (S. decora) is another close relative, but with hair on the leaves' undersides, which the American mountain ash lacks, and edible bright red rather than red-orange berries. It grows in mountainous areas in the Northeast and Canada. Five more similar but smaller native species (Sorbus spp.), again with edible, red berries, grow in Western North America.
Rowan Tree
This small tree has orange berries you can cook to make something similar to applesauce.
American and European Mountain Ash Trees
american-and-european-mountain-ash-trees

The American mountain ash tree (left, and inset) and the European mountain ash (right) are very similar in appearance and uses, but the American species has redder berries, while the European one, which doesn't grow wild but is cultivated extensively, has more orange-colored fruit.

[-Both species are small trees with slender branches, gray bark that cracks with age, and long, alternate, feather-compound leaves. The long, lance-shaped, finely-toothed leaflets are usually arched.

Ripening in late fall and persisting into the winter, the spherical berries grow in dense, drooping, branched clusters.]
Flowering Quince
flowering-quince
Rosaceae, the rose family
Quinces ripen in early fall, although a few may remain edible into mid-fall.
Sunny or partially shaded habitats, cultivated areas, parks, gardens, residential neighborhoods, and thickets
This shrub grows wild in some of the mid-Atlantic States, southern New England, Missouri, Kentucky, Tennessee, Wisconsin, and Louisiana.
Asia

Look for a prickly shrub with finely toothed, alternate, oval leaves and paired stipules. Showy, five-petaled flowers appear early in spring, usually pink, often in small clusters. Its fruits are small, hard, green-yellow pear- and apple-like with no fruit stalk.

This prickly shrub has smooth, brown bark with some raised lenticels. Growing from five to ten feet tall, it consists of many dense, arching branches and a tangled crown.

The simple, finely toothed, oval to lance-shaped, alternate leaves, shiny and dark green above and light green below, grow from 1.5 to 3.5 inches long. Small, stalkless, spatula-shaped, paired, leaf-like stipules also grow on the branches, along with the leaves.

Showy, pink (sometimes red or white) five-petaled, stalkless flowers, 1.5 inches across bloom alone or in clusters of two to four, on the branches, in very early spring, usually before the leaves develop.

The hard, rock-like, stalkless, green-yellow, red-spotted fruit, two to three inches across looks like a combination of apple and pear.

•Thorny, medium-sized shrub with smooth, brown bark and raised lenticels
•Densely tangled branches
•Simple, finely toothed, oval, alternate leaves, 1.5 to 3.5 inches long, shiny and dark green on top, and light green below
•Small, stalkless, spatula-shaped, paired, leaf-like stipules growing on branches
•Showy pink (sometimes red or white), stalkless, five-petaled flowers, 1.5 inch across, solitary or in clusters of two to four, in very early spring
•Stalkless, hard, rock-like, green-yellow, apple- and pear-like fruit, two to three inches across, in autumn

Twist the ripe fruits off the branches and transfer them to food containers or bags. If not completely ripe, leave them in a bowl at room temperature until ripe, or place them in a bag with apples, which speeds ripening.

The fruits are too hard, bitter, and astringent to enjoy raw, but cooked 15 to 10 minutes with other fruits and a sweetener, they impart a wonderful citrus-like flavor. Use them as a minor ingredient in pies, fruit soups, or compotes. They're especially good in desserts that include raisins. Because they contain pectin, like apples, they're also good for making jams and jellies.
Quinces are a good source of vitamins A, B3, C, and folate, as well as the minerals calcium, iron, magnesium, phosphorus, and potassium.

The fruit is considered analgesic, anti-inflammatory, antispasmodic, astringent, and digestive. A decoction has been used to treat nausea, joint pains, and cholera. Since it's used for food, it's known to be safe, but it still requires testing for effectiveness. Unfortunately, it's hard to get a volunteer willing to become infected with cholera!
Beware of the thorns!

The name flowering quince is misleading, since all quinces flower!

Other close relatives (Chaenomeles spp.) also have edible fruits, and the bushes you may find are often crosses between the flowering quince and the very similar Japanese quince (C. japonica).

The edible Chinese quince (Pseudocydonia sinensis) is also similar, but it's a taller shrub, reaching up to 15 feet in height, and the bark of its multiple branches flakes off, like a sycamore. These and the true quinces (Cydonia spp.), the ones sold commercially, are sometimes planted in gardens and parks but I've never seen any spreading into the wild.
Chinese Quince
Use this unusual, strong-flavored fruit almost like a seasoning. It's great for enhancing the flavor of dishes containing other fruits.
Japanese Quince, Chinese Quince, True Quinces
1)Branches with Flowering Quince Flowers and Fruit
1branches-with-flowering-quince-flowers-and-fruit

The flowering quince's stalkless, pink, showy five-petaled flowers bloom singly or in small clusters in early in the spring, usually before the leaves are fully developed. The finely toothed, oval, alternate, stalked leaves are accompanied by small, stalkless, paired stipules. The hard, yellow-green, pear- to apple-like fruit attaches to the slender, brown branches without a fruit stalk.
2)Flowering Quince Flowers
2flowering-quince-flowers

The flowering quince's finely-toothed, oval to lance-shaped leaves are a dark, shiny green above, and light green below. The stalkless, showy, pink, five-petaled flowers bloom singly or in small clusters, very early in the spring.
Quince and Blueberry Compote
quince-and-blueberry-compote

Quinces impart a sour flavor and thickness to the liquid the rest of the fruits produce when you cook them, and the fruit juice that provides part of the sweetness. This creates just the right texture and a very enjoyable blend of flavors.

3 cups apple juice
2 green apples, chopped
2 wild quinces or 1 commercial quince, chopped
1 cup blueberries
1 peach, chopped
1 banana, chopped
2 tsp. clear liquid stevia
2 tsp. cinnamon, ground
1 tsp. powdered ginger
1 tsp. dried mint, ground
1/2 tsp. cloves, ground
1/2 cup slivered almonds

1. Bring all ingredients except the almonds to a boil over medium heat in a heavy saucepan, stirring constantly.

2. Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 15 to 20 minutes, or until the fruit is soft.

3. Serve hot or cold, sprinkled with the almonds.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Cooking time: 20 minutes
3)Quince Branch and Fruit
3quince-branch-and-fruit
The flowering quince's hard fruit turns yellow and becomes spotted with brown when it ripens. It grows directly on the slender, brown branches without a fruit stalk.
Horseradish
horseradish
Family: Brassicaceae or Cruciferae, the mustard or cabbage family

The young leaves are best when they come up in mid-spring, before they become bitter. The root is best in the spring and fall, as well as during winter, although locating and digging them up then usually isn't possible.
Sunny or partially shaded disturbed habitats, wet roadsides, streambanks, and agricultural land
Throughout the US and southern Canada, but not in many of the Deep South or Southwest states
Eurasia

Look for a large, coarse, tall plant with large, upward-pointing, shiny, oblong to lance-shaped, toothed, alternate leaves. Horseradish has loose terminal and axillary clusters of white, four-petaled flowers and small, oval, upright seedpods.

Scratch and sniff for the odor of horseradish.

This a coarse-looking, spicy-scented garden escape usually grows two to four feet tall. Its huge, shiny, oblong, long-stalked, toothed, basal leaves (and the alternate leaves on the lower stem), with heart-shaped bases, get close to two feet long and four inches wide. The smaller, lance-shaped, alternate, toothed, upper leaves have short leafstalks or none. All the leaves point upward, not outward.

Larger than most mustard’s, the white, four-petaled flowers, 0.25 inch across, bloom in loose terminal and axillary clusters from mid- to late spring. The oval, upright seedpods that follow grow up to 0.25 inches long.

The large, whitish taproot can reach several feet in length.

•Large, coarse plant two to four feet tall with a large, white taproot
•Upward-pointing, shiny, oblong to lance-shaped, toothed, basal and alternate leaves, up to two feet long
•White, four-petaled flowers, 0.25 inch across, blooming in loose terminal and axillary clusters from mid- to late spring
•Oval, upright seedpods 0.25 inches long
•Whole plant smelling like horseradish (what else?)
Cut or break off the basal or young stem leaves, flowers, tender stem tips, and tender, young seedpods. Dig up the taproot.

The younger leaves, flowers, stem tips, and young seedpods are wonderful in salads. You can cook them, like other greens, 10 to 15 minutes, but they'll lose their spicy flavor, which is destroyed by heat.

To make prepared horseradish, a wonderful, pungent condiment, just grate the roots and cover them with vinegar immediately, before they darken, lose their pungency, and become bitter—caused by exposure to air. Prepared horseradish lasts indefinitely in the refrigerator. Add it to any dish that needs some pungency at the table, and don't cook it, or you’ll destroy its flavor too.
Horseradish leaves and roots provide vitamins B2, C, pantothenic acid, and folate, plus the minerals calcium, iron, magnesium, potassium, phosphorus, and selenium.

Use horseradish as a condiment only. In large amounts, the glucosinolates it contains can cause profuse sweating, irritation of the stomach and intestines, loss of strength, and disorientation, something you definitely want to avoid. I should know—I experienced these symptoms every time we had a math test in high school!

Prolonged contact of the root with the skin will cause it to blister.

Don't use this plant if you have stomach ulcers or thyroid problems.

Curly dock's large, edible leaves look somewhat like horseradish's, but with wavy edges and no teeth, unlike horseradish, the plants are easy to tell apart. And curly dock's leaves grow nearly nearly parallel to the ground, not upright, like horseradish.
Red Cole
You can buy the roots of this plant in the supermarket, but you can use the whole plant when you find it in the wild.
Curly Dock
2)Horseradish in Flower

This large, coarse plant has long, shiny, oblong to lance-shaped, toothed leaves, plus terminal and axillary flower clusters with white, four-petaled flowers.
1)Horseradish Leaves and Flowers
1horseradish-leaves-and-flowers

Horseradish's upper leaves (below) are much more deeply lobed and toothed than the lance-shaped basal leaves (above). The large, four-petaled flowers grow in loose clusters above the slender, upright seedpods.
Horseradish Potato Salad
horseradish-potato-salad

Potato salad was never this savory before it met up with spicy horseradish root.

8 red potatoes, diced
1/2 cup vegan mayonnaise
2 tbs. fruit-sweetened ketchup
1 to 2 tbs. prepared horseradish, or to taste
2 tsp. Vege-sal
3 scallions, sliced
3 celery stalks, peeled and sliced
1-1/2 cups pitted, low-sodium olives

1. Simmer the potatoes in water or stock for 20 minutes, or until tender, drain, and allow to cool.

2. Meanwhile, combine the mayo, ketchup, horseradish, and Vege-sal in a bowl with a whisk.

3. Stir in the potatoes and remaining ingredients.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking and cooling time: 30 minutes
Roses
roses
Rosaceae, the rose family
You can gather the flowers when they bloom en mass in late spring (some bloom in the summer too), and the fruits throughout autumn.
Sunny or partially shaded habitats, fields, edges of trails or woods, openings in the woods, thickets, wetlands, disturbed sites, lakesides, dunes near the seashore, and parks and cultivated places
We have native species, European and Asian species, and hybrids.

Look for densely thorny canes with familiar, fragrant, showy, five-petaled red, white, to yellow flowers that have many stamens and pistils in the center, and round to oval red to orange fruits with orange flesh. Sniff for the familiar fragrance of roses.

•Densely thorny canes
•Alternate, feather-compound leaves with three to 11 small, toothed, elliptical leaflets
•Familiar, fragrant, showy, five-petaled red, white, to yellow flowers, with many stamens and pistils in the center
•Round to oval red to orange fruits with orange flesh and many small, hard, white seeds

Wear long pants and sleeves, plus heavy-duty work gloves, for protection against the thorns, and bring tweezers just in case!

Pick the roses with your gloved fingers, and a knife or garden shears, and transfer them into plastic bags you can seal.

Choose species with the largest fruits. Pick only ripe hips. They're deeply colored and somewhat soft, without green. Twist off the fruit or cut it with a knife or garden shears.

The flowers of roses are edible, and while some people love them, I've never found them very tasty, and people who cook with them tend to drown them in sugar. You can add the petals to salads or dessert dishes.

The fruit of some of the larger species is usually quite good (some species taste terrible), with a flavor and texture similar to apricots, and it contains pectin, the same substance that thickens applesauce. Unfortunately, rose hips are labor-intensive to process. You have to cut them in half and scoop out the hard, bitter, non-poisonous white seeds. I use a paring knife and grapefruit spoon for this. You can also cook whole rose hips in fruit juice for 20 minutes or until tender, then strain out the seeds with a food mill.

Enjoy rose hips raw or add them to puddings, cakes, cookies, sauces, compotes, jam, fruit soups, ice cream, breads, or other dessert recipes. They also make an excellent herb tea, covered with boiling water and steeped for 20 minutes—the best way to use for those species with tiny rose hips.

Rose hips are an excellent source of vitamins A, B3, C, E, and K, plus the minerals calcium, manganese, and zinc, as well as pectin, malic and citric acids, fructose, and sucrose, bioflavonoids, carotenoids, anthocyanins, catechins and other polyphenolics.

Rose hips were used to treat scurvy, which their vitamin C cured. Eating the fruit is good for diarrhea, and it's been used to help people digest rich foods. It's also been used as an anti-inflammatory for arthritis , and it's currently being investigated for anti-cancer properties. Herbalists prescribed rose hips for infections, chest congestion, and bladder problems.

In Chinese traditional medicine, an infusion of the flowers is used for poor circulation, stomachaches, liver pains, mastitis, dysentery, vaginal yeast infections, and pregnancy.

Wild roses are very common, and some species have large, tasty fruit, called rose hips. Gather them when they're completely ripe—full-colored and somewhat soft—and use them raw, or cooked into a wide variety of desserts. The flowers are edible too, but not very tasty unless drowned in sugar.
2)Wrinkled Rose with Fruit
2wrinkled-rose-with-fruit
These large, spherical, red-orange fruits, with orange flesh, is exceptionally tasty. But you scrape out the hard, bitter, teardrop-shaped, white seeds before you can eat it.
These common, tiny fruits are ripe when they become deep red and very soft to the touch, in late fall, but they're too small for more than a trail nibble or a tea.
1)Wrinkled Rose in Flower
1wrinkled-rose-in-flower

The wrinkled rose, densely thorny, with a feather-compound leaf usually consisting of five elliptical, toothed leaflets, and a relatively large flower, usually rose colored, thas the best fruit of all the rose species I've tried.
Rose Hip and Pumpkin Smoothie
rose-hip-and-pumpkin-smoothie

Here’s one of the best drinks you’ll ever swallow, flavored with rose hips and pumpkins, and complemented with flavorings that work perfectly.

3-1/2 cups soy-rice milk, nut milk, or oat milk
1/2 cup wrinkled rose hips, seeds removed
1/2 cup cooked pumpkin
2 pitted Medjool dates
1 tsp. liquid stevia
1/4 tsp. ginger extract or powdered ginger
1/2 tsp. orange extract
1/2 tsp. vanilla
1/2 tsp. cranberry or lemon extract

Purée all ingredients in a blender.

Makes 4-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 5 minutes
Sumac
sumac
Anacardiaceae, the cashew family or sumac family

The berries of various sumac species come into season from late summer through fall. Smooth sumac and squawbush ripen in late summer, staghorn sumac ripens in early fall, and winged sumac ripens in mid-fall. And you can harvest the edible young shoots in the spring.

Staghorn, smooth, and winged sumac all grow in full or partial sunlight, in old fields, thickets, edges of woods, disturbed areas, canyons, stream banks, roadsides, dry sandy or rocky soil, and near the seashore. Skunkbush grows on slopes, plains, and canyons.

Various sumac species grow throughout North America.

Winged and staghorn sumac grow throughout Eastern and Central North America. Smooth sumac grows throughout North America. Skunkbush grows in the western half of the US, but it's also planted in parks on the East Coast—I've seen it in Central Park.

Look for dense stands of small trees or shrubs, with stout twigs that exude white sap. Sumac usually has long, feather-compound leaves, upright terminal spikes or panicles with many tiny, yellow to green-yellow, five-petaled flowers, and upright fruit clusters consisting of many tiny, spherical, hard, red berries.

•Small trees or large shrubs with stout twigs exuding white sap when cut
•Usually very large, feather-compound (sometimes palmate-compound) leaves, usually fragrant when cut
•Upright panicles or spikes of many tiny, yellow or green-yellow, five-petaled flowers
•Dense, upright clusters tiny, hard, spherical, red or red-orange berries

The best time to harvest the ripe berries is after a prolonged dry spell. The worst time is the day after it's rained, when most of the flavor has been washed away.

The best berries are brightly colored and dotted with whitish deposits of tasty acid. Pinch a berry and touch your finger to your tongue. You should detect a strong, sour flavor. This means it's harvest time.

Cut off the red seed heads with garden shears or a knife and transfer them to a bag, or twist and break them off with your hands.

Don't rinse off these berries before use or you'll wash all the flavor down the drain. The best-known way to use sumac is by making a wonderfully flavored pink lemonade with it. Submerge the berry cluster (minus any six- or eight-legged stragglers) in a bowl of room temperature or warm water, and squeeze and twist it with your hands for a minute or so (you may also steep the clusters in hot water, but lemonade is better cold). Strain out the berries through a fine sieve or cheesecloth-lined colander, sweeten to taste, and enjoy.

You can also make sumac concentrate, which you can use like lemon or lime juice (see recipe).

The young growth at the tips of the plants—the shoots, are also edible, raw or cooked, after you peel them. They make quite a tasty vegetable you can use in a variety of dishes.
Sumac is an excellent source of vitamin C. Most colorful fruits contain healthy proanthocyanins, but sumac hasn't been tested for these yet.
Sumac is related to cashews, mangoes, and poison ivy. If you're you're so sensitive to poison ivy that you can't eat cashews or mangoes, you should avoid sumac too.

In the Middle East, people use dried, ground sumac berries as a seasoning. That works with the species that grow there, but not with American ones, which have hard, stony seeds inside the berries. However, you can usually substitute Sumac Concentrate in recipe that calls for sumac, with good results. Just subtract a volume of liquid in the recipe equal to that of the Sumac Concentrate you're adding.

The black walnut tree has leaves similar to sumac's, but it's a much larger tree with different flowers, and edible nuts rather than berries in the fall. Also, the leaf doesn't exude a white sap, as sumac does.

The similar-looking leaf of the ailanthus tree (Ailanthus altissima) smells like rotten peanut butter and doesn't exude a white sap. Again, all other features are different.

The mountain ashes or rowan trees also have similar leaves, but again, no milky sap, and much larger, round, red or orange edible berries.

Make sure the flower clusters are upright, and the clusters of berries are upright and red or red-orange. Poison sumac (Rhus vernix) has drooping clusters of white berries, quite different from the edible species. Touch it, and you'll have a severe rash for a month that can recur over and over.

Poison oak has leaves similar to skunkbush, but the flowers are small and inconspicuous, and the berries are yellow-brown, not red.

Smooth sumac is also called red sumac.

Winged sumac is also called dwarf sumac or shining sumac.

Skunkbush is also called sourberry, three-leaf sumac, and squawbush.

People shudder with fear when they hear the word, "sumac," but they only think of the poisonous species. The edible ones, which are quite distinct, provide a wonderful pink lemonade, and a superb sour-flavored culinary ingredient.
Poison Sumac, Poison Oak, Black Walnut, Ailanthus, Mountain Ash
Poison Sumac, Poison Oak
3)Watermelon-Sumac Pops
3watermelon-sumac-pops

Here’s a delicious, healthful frozen fruit dessert, where the sourness of the sumac concentrate offsets the sweet flavor of the watermelon.

6 cups watermelon, diced
1 tbs. clear liquid stevia
1 tbs. sumac concentrate or lime juice, or to taste

1. Purée all ingredients in a blender. Adjust the amount of sweetener and sumac concentrate to taste.

2. Pour into 8 ice pop mold divisions and freeze.

Makes 8 pops

Preparation time: 5 minutes

Freezing time: 3 hours

2)Sumac-steamed Cauliflower
2sumac-steamed-cauliflower

Here's a quick, simple way to make the best cauliflower you've ever tasted, with sumac providing an exotic touch.

1 head of cauliflower, broken into florets
1 cup of water
2 tbs. + 2 tsp. olive oil, or to taste
1 tbs. + 1 tsp. sumac concentrate, or to taste
2-1/2 tsp. salt, or to taste

1. Place the water, 2 tbs. of olive oil, 1 tbs. sumac concentrate, and the 2 tsp. salt in a pressure cooker or large saucepan.

2. Place the cauliflower on a steamer rack above the water mixture, pressure cook 1 minute, and transfer the pressure cooker to a sink partially filled with water, to stop the cooking. If you're using a saucepan, steam, covered, 15 to 20 minutes, or until the cauliflower is just tender but not mushy.

3. Serve sprinkled with the remaining olive oil, sumac concentrate, and salt. Adjust the seasoning to taste.

Serves 4 to 6

Preparation time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 1 minute or 20 minutes

Most sumacs have long, feather-compound leaves consisting of many leaflets. Smooth sumac's flower cluster is loose and spreading, while staghorn sumac's berry cluster, which replaced its flowers, is much tighter.

Skunkbush is different from most sumac species, with a three-parted, palmate-compound instead of a feather-compound leaf. Each leaf consists of just three partially lobed leaflets. The cluster of tiny, yellow flowers is also smaller than other species'.

1)Sumac Concentrate
1sumac-concentrate

I've discovered that you can make a very useful and tasty sumac concentrate by processing about 5 batches of sumac through the same water. When you achieve the acidity of lemon juice, you can use this in any of the thousands of recipes that need a touch of acidity or call for lemon juice or lime juice, or vinegar.

Sumac will imparts its own special flavor to any appropriate dish, from salad dressings to desserts. It's especially good with mulberries, which lack the acidity of other berries, or other non-acidic fruits such as bananas, papayas, or pawpaws, not to mention mild-flavored vegetables such potatoes or cauliflower.

You can also freeze sumac concentrate in ice cube trays, pack the sumac cubes into freezer containers, and defrost as needed.

Sumac berry clusters, unwashed
Lukewarm or room temperature water as needed

1. Place the 1/5th of the sumac in a bowl, cover it with water, and squeeze and rub vigorously with your hands for a minute or so, or until most of the color has been transferred into the water.

2. Strain out the used sumac in a colander, and put the colored water back in the bowl.

3. Repeat step 1 with the remaining 4 portions of fresh sumac branches successively, until you've used up all the sumac.

4. Strain through a cheesecloth or fine sieve to remove all the debris.

Poison Sumac
poison-sumac
Anacardiaceae, the cashew family or sumac family
Poison sumac is very poisonous all year.
In full sunlight or partially shaded, sandy swamps, wooded wetlands, marshes, and bogs.
The eastern third of North America, plus parts of Louisiana and Texas
Surprisingly, poison sumac is native to Japan as well as North America.

Look for a shrub or small tree with light gray bark, branching close to the base; alternate, feather-compound leaves with wide-spaced, elliptical, toothless leaflets, plus reddish midribs and leafstalks; loose, pendant panicles of tiny, 5-petaled, greenish flowers, followed by small, nearly spherical, hard, whitish berries.

[Look for a shrub or small tree with light gray bark, branching close to the base that has alternate, feather-compound leaves with wide-spaced, elliptical, toothless leaflets, plus reddish midribs and leafstalks. Loose, pendant panicles of tiny, five-petaled, greenish flowers are followed by small, nearly spherical, hard, whitish berries.]

This shrub or small tree, which often branches near the base, grows 10 to 20 (sometimes 30) feet tall, with light gray bark and a trunk one to five inches across.

The alternate, feather-compound leaves consist of seven to 13 pointed, wavy-edged, toothless, widely spaced, elliptical leaflets, two to four inches long and one to 1.5 inches wide, with reddish midribs and leafstalks. The leaves produce brilliant shades of scarlet and orange in the fall.

Blooming from late spring to early summer, tiny, greenish, five-petaled flowers hang from the leaf axils on loose panicles three to eight inches long. Male and female flowers grow on separate trees.

Long, drooping panicles of smooth, whitish, nearly spherical, slightly compressed berries 0.2 inch across ripen in late summer and persist through the winter.

*Small tree or shrub usually 10 to 20 feet tall, with light gray bark, branching near the base
•Alternate, feather-compound leaves with seven to 13 pointed, wavy-edged, toothless, elliptical leaflets
•Leaflets two to four inches long, 1 to 1.5 inches across, widely spaced
•Loose panicles three to eight inches long, hanging from the leaf axils, with tiny, greenish, five-petaled flowers
•Long, drooping panicles of smooth, whitish, nearly spherical, slightly flattened berries, 0.2 inch across

Learn to recognize this plant from a distance and avoid it. Its only virtue, besides its rarity, is that it makes its relative, poison ivy, look like a minor annoyance in comparison.

Sensitive people may get rashes just from being near this plant. And once you touch it and the toxin, urushiol, enters your bloodstream, you get a painful rash that can continue for weeks, spread all over your body, and recur for months. And breathing the smoke from burning poison sumac can cause death. Give me poison ivy any day!
Edible sumacs (Rhus spp.) have upright flower- and fruit clusters, not drooping ones like poison sumac. Their berries are red, not white, and there aren't large spaces between the leaflets.
Poison Tree, Poison Wood, Poison Ash

Much worse than poison ivy, the rash lasts a month, spreads all over the body, and recurs later on. Fortunately, this is a rare plant that grows in sandy swamps and bogs, that you're unlikely to encounter very often.
Smooth Sumac, Staghorn Sumac, Winged Sumac, Skunkbush, Poison Ivy

This spreading shrub grows near water. Its feather-compound alternate leaf consists of leaflets more widely spaced than other sumacs.
