Highbush Cranberry
highbush-cranberry
Adoxaceae, the moschatel family
From mid-fall to late fall, sometimes into the winter
Moist thickets, woodlands, and edges of woodlands
All of the Northern US states plus New Mexico and southern Canada

Look for medium-sized shrubs with rough, waxy-gray bark and three-lobed toothed, opposite, maple-like leaves. The long leafstalks have tiny, dome-shaped glands and dense, round-topped flower clusters with circle of large, sterile flowers surrounding a central cluster of smaller, five-petaled, fertile flowers. In autumn and winter look for clusters of soft, juicy, translucent, ovate, red berries.

This shrub grows eight to 12 (sometimes 16) feet tall and broad, with rough , waxy-gray bark and smooth, erect branches.

The coarsely toothed, three-lobed, opposite leaves grow two to five inches long and almost equally wide. Resembling maple leaves, with pointed tips and rounded bases, they turn red-purple in autumn. Dome-shaped glands grow on the long leafstalks.

Growing in dense, round-topped clusters of three to four inches, two kinds of white flowers bloom in late spring—a showy outer circle of large, sterile flowers, each 0.75 inch across, and a central cluster of smaller, fertile, five-petaled flowers.

In autumn and often persisting into the winter, the inner clusters bear soft, juicy, translucent, red, ovate berries, 0.5 inch long, each containing one flat stone.

•Shrub eight to 12 feet tall and broad, with rough, waxy-gray bark
•Three-lobed toothed, opposite, maple-like leaves with pointed tips and rounded bases
•Long leafstalks with tiny, dome-shaped glands
•Dense, round-topped flower clusters, three to four inches across
•A circle of large, sterile flowers 0.75 inch across, surrounding a central cluster of smaller, five-petaled, fertile flowers
•Clusters of soft, juicy, translucent, ovate, red, berries, 0.5 inch long, from autumn into winter
•One flat stone in each berry

Pull the ripe berries off the stems and transfer to plastic food containers. This process is hastened if you punch a hole in your collecting container and attach it to your belt with key clips, or around your neck with a cord.

Highbush cranberries are very tart and flavorful, quite similar to cranberries, but with large seeds you need to remove, and without true cranberries' self-thickening pectin. Cook them with a sweetener, add a thickener if desired, and strain out the seeds using a food mill.

The thickened, sweetened purée makes a great alternative to cranberry sauce, especially seasoned with sweet spices such as mint, cinnamon, sassafras, orange rind, ginger, or cloves. You use it in pies, breads, ice cream, cakes, puddings. It's especially good in chocolate desserts, where the two very different flavorful ingredients complement each other perfectly.
Highbush cranberries are an excellent source of vitamin C. The probably contain health-promoting proanthocyanidins, like other brightly-colored berries, but they haven't been tested for these yet.

Unrelated true cranberries (Vaccinium spp.) also have red, sour-flavored berries, but that's where the resemblance ends. Real cranberries creep along the ground, with small, unlobed leaves, completely different flowers, and no large stone in the fruit.

The guilder rose or cramp bark (V. opulus) also looks very much like the highbush cranberry, from the leaves to the non-poisonous but unpalatable berries. A decoction of the cambium of this European cultivated ornamental, while inferior to its edible American relative, the black haw (V. prunifolium), is a traditional home remedy for menstrual cramps. And this one really works—ever since I've learned it, I go through month after month without ever experiencing a single cramp!

The best way to tell these close relatives (which some botanists consider subspecies of each other) apart is by examining the tiny glands on the leafstalks. Guider rose has bowl-shaped glands, while highbush cranberry's are dome-shaped.

The maple-leaf viburnum (V. acerifolium), on the other hand, is a related shrub with similar leaves but hard, blue-black, inedible berries.

The linden viburnum (V. dilatatum), has broadly oval to elliptical, coarsely toothed, finely fuzzy, pointed leaves three to five inches long that resemble those of the linden tree. Showy, flat-topped cymes three to five inches across with white, five-petaled flowers bloom from late spring to early summer, replaced by bright red, showy autumn berries 0.33 inch long. While they're edible and strongly lemon flavored, they're too small, and the seeds are too large, for more than a sour trail nibble or tea, although kids who like sour flavors can't get enough of them.
American Cranberrybush Viburnum, Kalyna
Unrelated to true cranberries, this berry has a similar flavor, and you can use it to make the same kind of cranberry dishes.
Guilder Rose, Linden Viburnum, Linden Tree, Cranberries, Black Haw, Maple-leaf Viburnum
Highbush Cranberry Ice Cream
highbush-cranberry-ice-cream

This ice cream brings out the best of this flavorful fruit, all the better since my innovative ice creams are as healthful as they're tasty. Anyone who tries it will be convinced that wild foods are the best, and that you can make especially delicious versions of desserts without the conventional refined sugar and saturated fats..

4 cups soy-rice milk or any non-dairy milk
1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
1 tbs. agar flakes
3 cup highbush cranberries or 1.5 cups cranberries
1/2 cup raw pignoli nuts
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/4 cup grape seed oil
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin
1 tbs. liquid stevia
1 tsp. cranberry extract (optional)
1/2 tsp. vanilla extract
1/4 tsp. dried pennyroyal or other dried mint leaves, ground
1/4 tsp. orange extract
1/4 tsp. salt

1. Mix the arrowroot and agar into 2 cups of the soy-rice milk with a whisk, add the highbush cranberries, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, uncovered, 10 minutes, stirring often.

2. Strain out the seeds using a food mill. (Skip this step if you're using cranberries, which don't have noticeable seeds, instead of highbush cranberries.)

3. Combine with the remaining ingredients in a blender and purée.

4. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

Makes 5-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 30 minutes

Freezing time: 2-1/2 to 3 hours
1)Highbush Cranberry Leaves and Fruit
1highbush-cranberry-leaves-and-fruit

The highbush cranberry has long-stalked, opposite, maple-like leaves, plus flat-topped clusters of oval berries. The leafstalks have convex glands, allowing you to tell them apart from the bad-tasting guilder rose, which has concave glands.
2)Highbush Cranberry with Fruit and Flowers
2highbush-cranberry-with-fruit-and-flowers

The highbush cranberry has clusters of long-stalked, roundish berries that turn red in autumn, and opposite, three-lobed, toothed, maple-like leaves, with long leafstalks. Dome-shaped glands on the leafstalks let you distinguish it from its bad-tasting cultivated relative, the guilder rose. In late spring, showy clusters of white flowers bloom, where the larger, outer, white, sterile flowers attract insects to pollinate the smaller, fertile, five-petaled flowers.
Japanese Yew
japanese-yew
Taxaceae, the yew family
The greatest number of berries are ripe in early- and mid-fall, although you can sometimes also harvest some a little earlier or later.
Sunny, partially shaded, or shaded cultivated areas, parks, pine forests, bogs, and thickets
The Japanese yew grows wild in Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and Ohio, and it grows under cultivation throughout North America.
Asia

Look for a commonly cultivated bush or tree with thin, reddish-brown, scaly bark, then short, flat, lance-shaped needles and tiny, inconspicuous, cream-colored flowers. The round, red, juicy, mucilaginous, cup-shaped berries each have a single, round, black seed visible.

This dense, medium-sized evergreen shrub (its most usual form) or tree's thin, reddish-brown, scaly bark covers a purple-red cambium. Growing 10 to 25 (sometimes 50) feet tall, its spread equals or surpasses its height. As a tree, its trunk can grow to nearly two feet across.

Its short, flat, singly attached, straight or curved, sharply pointed, lance-shaped needles grow 0.5 to one inch long and 0.1 inch wide, in V-shaped rows. Dark green and shiny above and pale green below, the spirally configured leaves generally twist to grow in 1 plane.

Tiny, inconspicuous, cream-colored male flowers, growing in groups, produce clouds of pollen during a period of about one week in early spring. The tiny, solitary female flower grow on separate bushes.

Spherical, juicy, mucilaginous red berries 0.25 inch across, form a round cup around a single, hard, round, black seed.

•Dense, medium-sized evergreen shrub or tree with thin, reddish-brown, scaly bark
•Short, flat, singly attached, straight or curved, sharply pointed, lance-shaped needles in V-shaped rows
•Needles dark green and shiny above and pale green below
•Needles generally growing in one plane
•Tiny, inconspicuous, cream-colored, clustered male flowers
•Solitary female flowers on bushes separate from the male flowers
•Round, red, juicy, mucilaginous, cup-shaped berries
•1 single, hard, round, black seed per berry, visible through opening in the cupped fruit

Simply remove the berries from the bush and transfer them to plastic containers, avoiding unripe fruit. Freeing both hands by stringing a container and tying it to your belt, or wearing it around your neck, makes collection faster.

The sweet berries taste like jelly, and make an outstanding trail nibble and snack food. Cooking with them is way too dangerous due to the possibility of deadly toxins escaping from the seeds, and the pulp is too gelatinous to let you remove the seeds by hand. You simply have to eat the pulp and spit out the seeds.

Taxol, a substance found in all yews in minute quantities, is used to treat breast and ovarian cancer, and it's extended the lives of many cancer patients. It's now semi-synthesized in pharmaceutical labs, but can't be separated from the deadly toxins without a state-of-the-art pharmaceutical laboratory.

Another substance extracted from yews is being researched to treat diabetes.

Native Americans used a decoction of various parts of the yew to treat a variety of diseases, and even though they took this in minute quantities, it's way to dangerous to use as a home remedy today.

If you chew and eat the seeds in these berries, you'll die. Remember: nothing is certain but death and Taxus!
Spit out the very deadly seeds when you eat the flesh, and don't eat them within sight of any young children, who could imitate you and swallow the seeds. It's possible that if you swallow a seed without chewing it, it will pass through your digestive system without killing you, but it's also possible that you could play Russian roulette and survive!

The seeds contain cardiac alkaloids that can stop your heart, and chewing them releases the poisons more quickly. Only one person on Earth can chew and swallow the seeds: my ex-girlfriend of nearly 10 years, who ran off with another guy on Valentine's Day in 1995—she has no heart!
This evergreen has delicious berries and deadly seeds, which you spit out when you eat the fruit.

The short, flat, singly attached, straight or curved, sharply pointed, lance-shaped needles grow in V-shaped rows. Marsh Mallow
marsh-mallow
Malvaceae, the mallow family
Collect the young leaves from mid- to late spring, the flowers and fruits from late summer to fall, and the roots in the spring and fall.
Sunny salt marshes, coastal areas

The marsh mallow grows in Northeastern North America, North Dakota, Nebraska, and Arkansas. It's generally rare, but not endangered because it's not native. It just never became well-established in North America.
Europe

Look for a hairy plant that is two to four feet tall, usually with a few side branches, holding large, soft, thick, velvety, gray-green, stalked, coarsely- and irregularly toothed, alternate leaves. Marsh mallow has short, dense axillary flower clusters, plus terminal panicles of showy, radially-symmetrical, stalked, five-petaled, pink flowers with a bushy central column. The radially divided fruit is dry, flattened, and disk-shaped.

Reaching two to four feet tall, this plant's upright, hairy stem often puts out a few branches. Tough and pliant, the long, thick, tapering taproot is pale yellow outside and white and fibrous inside.

The soft, thick, velvety, gray-green, stalked, coarsely- and irregularly toothed, alternate leaves grow from one to four inches long and about 1.25 inches broad. Heart-shaped or three- to five-lobed toward the bottom, they become roughly oval and pointed toward the top of the stem.

Growing in short, dense clusters from the upper leaves’ axils and in terminal panicles, and blooming in late summer, the showy, radially-symmetrical, stalked, pinkish, five-petaled flowers, grow from one to 1.5 inches across, with a bushy central column composed of fused stamens.

The dry, flattened, disk-shaped, one-seeded fruits, nearly two inches across, are radially divided into 15 to 20 segments.

•Hairy plant two to four feet tall with a few side branches, and a long, tough, pliant, yellow-white taproot
•Large, soft, thick, velvety, gray-green, stalked, coarsely- and irregularly toothed, alternate leaves
•Short, dense clusters of showy, radially-symmetrical, stalked, pink, five-petaled flowers, growing in terminal panicles, and from the upper leaves’ axils
•Flowers with a bushy central column composed of fused stamens
•Dry, flattened, disk-shaped, one-seeded fruit nearly two inches across, radially divided into 15 to 20 segments

Strip off the young leaves, and pick the flowers and fruits with your fingers.

The easiest way to dig up the roots is with a shovel.

The young leaves make a good cooked vegetable in soups, stews, sauces, or a variety of side dishes and entrées. They're somewhat bland, so include more flavorful ingredients or herbs and spices. They add the thickening properties of okra to any dish containing liquids, and cook in about 10 to 15 minutes.

While not harmful eaten raw, their fuzzy texture isn't especially enjoyable, so use the leaves sparingly in salads. The flowers are better in salads, while the fruits are best cooked, like the leaves.

The root is too fibrous to eat. People used to boil it, then boil down the liquid, sweeten it, and beat it into a meringue. That's how the familiar confection first came into being. Because the plant is rare in my area, I've never had the opportunity to dig up the root to try this.
Marshmallow leaves are a good source of vitamin C, the minerals iron and calcium, plus copper and other trace minerals.

The whole plant, which contains mucilage, has been used medicinally since ancient times. The roots contain pectin, asparagine, and tannins, while the leaves contain flavanoids such a kaempferol, plus quercitin, diosmetin, glucosides, and coumarin, as well as polyphenolic acids such as syringic, caffeic, salicyclic, vanillic, and p-coumaric acids.

The root is a demulcent, emmolient, diuretic, anti-inflammatory, and expectorant. A decoction of the roots is used for digestive and skin problems, and for inflammations of the mouth and throat, gastritis, peptic ulcers, enteritis, constipation, irritable bowel syndrome, and colitis. It's also supposedly increases the flow of breast milk, but this has never worked for me. Externally, it's used for treating varicose veins, ulcers, abscesses, bruises, sprains, aching muscles, insect bites, skin inflammations, splinters, and boils.

An infusion of the leaves is used for lung problems such as bronchitis, as well as for urinary tract problems such as cystitis, urethritis, gravel, and kidney stones.

While the plant seems to be a tried and true safe and effective home remedy for minor complaints, it should be used in conjunction with medical supervision for serious conditions, where, if the plant fails, the disease can do serious harm.

Please do not overharvest where this plant it's rare, or you might eradicate it. Even though it's not indigenous, it's also not invasive, and I hope that you agree that it deserves to exist in America.
Marshmallow, Marshmellow, Common Marshmallow
This plant is the original source of the confection with the same name. The best way to use it is to include the mild-flavored leaves in soups, stews, and casseroles.

1marsh-mallow-with-flowers-and-fruit

This soft, fuzzy plant, has large, thick, stalked, oval to heart-shaped, coarsely toothed, alternate leaves, plus showy flowers in short axillary clusters and on terminal panicles. The dry, flattened, disk-shaped fruits are radially segmented.

The marshmallow, which sometimes produces a few side branches, has soft, thick, velvety, coarsely- and irregularly toothed, stalked, alternate leaves that may be heart-shaped or oval. The large, showy, five-petaled flowers, usually more pink than white, grow in short, axillary clusters and terminal in panicles. The central column consists of fused stamens.
Marsh Macaroni
marsh-macaroni

Conventional macaroni and cheese tastes great, but it’s a cardiovascular and caloric national disaster. But you can make a dish at least as tasty with healthful ingredients with the same flavors and textures as the junky ones, smoothed out by chewy marsh mallow leaves, and here it is!

1/4 cup olive oil
5 yellow onions, sliced
2 cups marsh mallow leaves6 cloves of garlic, finely chopped
2 tbs. vegetarian Bac’uns (a bacon substitute available in health food stores)
1 tsp. all-purpose spice seasoning (available in health food stores)

For Sauce

3 cups soy-rice milk, nut milk, or oat milk
3 tbs. mellow (light-colored) miso (available in health food stores)
2 tbs. arrowroot
1/2 tbs. Vege-sal (available in health food stores)
1 10-oz. package of dairy-free soy mozzerella, diced
1 tsp. chili paste or a pinch of Cayenne hot pepper

Other Ingredients

1 lbs. whole-grain macaroni
1-3/4 cups dried bread crumbs
2 tbs. corn oil
1 10-oz. package of dairy-free soy cheddar, grated

1. Sauté the onions in the olive oil 15 to 20 minutes, or until lightly browned.

2. Add the marsh mallow leaves, garlic, Bac’us, and all-purpose seasoning and sauté another 5 minutes

3. Meanwhile, purée all sauce ingredients in a blender.

4. Stir the sauce into the sauté and transfer to a large, oiled baking dish.

5. Stir the corn oil into the bread crumbs and spread on top of the mixed ingredients.

6. Spread the soy cheddar on top.

7. Bake in a preheated 350 degree oven 40 minutes or until bubbly.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 30

Cooking time: 40 minutes
Wild Pear
wild-pear
Rosaceae, the rose family
Wild pears ripen from early- to mid fall. Callery pears ripen in late fall.
Sunny or partially shaded thickets, woods, and the edges of woods
The Northeastern US
Eurasia and northern Africa

Look for a tall, narrow tree with a rising crown and scaly, wrinkled, chunky bark. The leaves are finely toothed, sharp-pointed, medium sized, broadly oval to elliptical, and grow on yellowish leafstalks. The tree has flat-topped clusters of cream-white five-petaled, radially symmetrical flowers, and pears smaller than commercial ones.

This tall, narrow, upright tree, with rising crown of nearly vertical branches and with scaly, wrinkled, chunky bark, sometimes grows up to 65 feet. The thick, dark twigs are sometimes spiny, and the spines sometimes bear minute leaf structures at their bases.

The finely double-toothed, sharply pointed, broadly oval to elliptical leaves grow 1.5 to three inches. The leafstalks are yellowish.

The radially symmetrical, five-petaled, cream-white flowers, which bloom in flat-topped clusters before the leaves develop, in early spring, grow from one to two inches across.

Long and tear-shaped, wild pears usually grow smaller than cultivated varieties. With a five-parted crown of sepals on the end away from the twig, they have a five-parted, radial symmetry, like apples. A gritty area grows just below the crown.

A cultivated ornamental variety, the callery or Bartlett pear (Pyrus calleryana), planted on streets for its showy early spring blossoms, has small, hard fruits that ripen, soften, and become edible in very late fall, after several frosts.

•Tall, narrow, upright tree with upper branches tilted upward
•Scaly, wrinkled, chunky bark
•Thick, dark twigs sometimes spiny, with minute leaf-like structures on spine bases
•Flat-topped clusters of radially symmetrical, five-petaled cream-white flowers
•Finely double-toothed, sharply pointed, broadly oval to elliptical leaves
•Relatively small, long, tear-shaped fruit with a five-parted crown, five-parted radial symmetry, and grit under the stem
Collect from the ground or the tree, using two double shopping bags (pears are heavy), to keep ripe and unripe fruit separate.

Wild pears, which arise from seeds, not from cuttings like commercial clones, have genetic variety that makes them more like the hard, ancestral wild varieties than the pears you buy in the store—heartier, grittier, less juicy, and best cooked. Use them for pies, cakes, compotes, fruit soups, sauces, puddings, cobblers, and other desserts. They cook in 15 to 20 minutes.

Use or refrigerate the ripe pears immediately. Sort the unripe ones every day until the last pear ripens. Use or refrigerate the ripe ones, and throw out any that are becoming rotten before they contaminate the good ones. Storing pears with bananas, which give off ethylene gas, speeds ripening.

You can also eat ripe callery pears as is or cook them with a sweetener and seasonings, then remove the grit and seeds with a food mill, to make a delicious pear sauce.
The skin of pears provide vitamin C, and the minerals potassium, calcium, and phosphorous. Peel them and the nutrients are gone.

Pears have been used medicinally since ancient times, when the Greeks treated nausea with pears. Pears' insoluble fiber makes them good for constipation, and may even reduce the number of precancerous colon polyps. People have eaten pears to treat inflammation of the mucous membranes, and for colitis, chronic gallbladder problems, arthritis, and gout. They may lower high blood pressure, reduce HDL (bad) cholesterol, and even increase the urine's acidity, although more testing is needed.
Never try to swallow a thrown pear that you catch in your mouth. Drussus, the son of the Roman emperor Claudius, tried that, and he choked to death!

Apple trees look similar to pear trees, but pear trees have thicker, often darker twigs that are thinner and more gnarled than apples— sometimes even spiny. And apple flowers are pink, not white. Pears are gritty above the core, apples aren't. If you still can't tell the difference between an apple and a pear, put them in water. Pears sink, while apples float!
Wild pears are harder and more gritty than commercial pears, but they're exceptional in any kind of recipe that calls for cooking fruit.
Wild Apples

The top branches of the pear tree are nearly vertical.
Pear Sorbet
pear-sorbet

This is one that’s hard to stop eating, even more so with the wonderful flavor of ripe wild pears.

3 ripe wild pears or 2 ripe commercial pears
1-1/2 cups water
1 cup pear juice or apple juice
1/2 cup raw pignola nuts or cashews
1/4 cup lecithin granules
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin
1/4 cup grape seed oil
The juice of half a lime
2 tsp. liquid stevia
1 tsp. pear extract (optional)
1/4 tsp. amaretto extract or almond extract (optional)
1/2 tsp. salt

1. Purée all ingredients in a blender.

2. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

Makes 6 cups

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Freezing time: 2 hours

The pear flower has five radially symmetrical, cream-white petals, and many orange-tipped stamens surrounding one brownish pistil in the center. It blooms in flat-topped clusters before the leaves develop.

Wild pears and are very similar to commercial pears, hanging from thick twigs.
Wild Raisins
wild-raisins
Caprifoliaceae, the honeysuckle family
The fruit's in season mainly in mid-fall, while the best time to collect the cambium for medicinal uses is supposed to be in the spring.
Sunny or partially shaded habitats, parks, landscaped areas, thickets, moist and dry woods, bogs, edges of forests, overgrown fields, and rocky hillsides

The black haw grows throughout most of the Eastern US, but not New England except for Connecticut, and not Florida.

The nannyberry grows throughout Northeast and Northern Central North America, as well as parts of the Deep South.

The hobblebush grows throughout eastern North America, but not in the Deep South, except for Georgia and Alabama.

The siebold viburnum grows in the Mid-Atlantic states, Connecticut, and Massachusetts.
The black haw, nannyberry, and hobblebush are native. The siebold viburnum comes from Japan.

Look for a shrub or small tree with opposite, oval to elliptical, often finely toothed, pointed, stalked, medium-sized, simple leaves. The showy, umbrella-like cymes of small, fragrant, five-petaled, white flowers stand out in the spring. The round to ovate berries grow in clusters that sometimes flattened. First green, they becoming shiny blue-black when ripe.

•Shrubs or small trees six to 30 feet tall
•Opposite, oval to elliptical, often finely toothed, pointed, stalked, simple leaves two to five inches long.
•Showy, umbrella-like cymes of fragrant, five-petaled white flowers, each about 0.25 inch long, in mid-spring
• Round to ovate berries, sometimes flattened, green at first, then maturing to a shiny blue-black
•One flattened seed similar to a watermelon seed

Look for bushes that are full of large berries. The fruit of sparse bushes usually tastes terrible or has no flavor, and during many years, all the bushes do poorly. Wait for a good year and you'll really love these berries.

Pull the berries off the bushes with your fingers and transfer them into food containers. Attaching a container to your belt or around your neck with a cord frees both hands for more efficient collection.

The sweet, pulpy fruit tastes like prunes with the texture of banana. Enjoy it raw, spitting out the seeds, or cook in fruit juice with a sweetener plus an optional thickener for 15 to 20 minutes, strain out the seeds with a food mill, and use the pulp as a spread similar to prune butter, a pastry filling, or an ingredient in sauces. It also makes a superb pancake topping, and a filling for muffins. Lemon and orange rind, cinnamon, sassafras, and common spicebush berries or allspice make good accompanying seasonings.

A tincture of the cambium of viburnums has been used in traditional herbal medicines in the old and new worlds for centuries, due to its antispasmodic properties. The black haw, the best of the group, contains a bitter glucoside called viburnin, plus scopoletin, aesculetin, salicin, 1-methyl-2,3 clibutyl and hemimellitate.

The tincture supposedly relaxes the nervous system and tones the uterus. It's used for painful menstruation (its primary use today), cramps, amenorrhea, and bleeding. People have also it throughout pregnancy to prevent miscarriage, as well as for asthma, muscle cramps, epilepsy, and convulsions.

The black haw contains salicin, which the nannyberry probably contains too. It's chemically related to aspirin. Don't use it medicinally if you're allergic to aspirin.

Salicin my also damage DNA and cause mutations, so the tincture, which has been used to prevent miscarriage, should be avoided during the first two trimesters of pregnancy.

The black haw is also called false cramp bark, sloe, stag bush, and sloe-leaved viburnum.

The nannyberry is also called sweet viburnum and sheepberry.
This group of shrubs had sweet-tasting berries with the flavor of prunes and texture of bananas, and some species have substantial, sweet-tasting fruit.
Hobblebush, Siebold Viburnum, Highbush Cranberry
1)Black Haw Flowers and Berries

The black haw is a shrub with opposite, simple, toothed, elliptical, stalked leaves. The tiny white flowers, growing on cymes, create a showy display in the spring, and the red-stemmed, drooping clusters of blue-black, ovate berries provide a treat for humans and other species in the fall.
2)Black Haw Flowers
2black-haw-flowers

Crowded into a showy cyme, the five-petaled white flowers of the black haw, growing above the opposite, finely toothed, pointed, elliptical to ovate leaves, have five yellow-tipped stamens surrounding a single green pistil.
3)Black Haw Berry Cluster
3black-haw-berry-cluster

This cluster of ovate, dull blue berries, growing on branching, red stems, is easy to spot. Open up a berry and you'll see the pulpy flesh and flattened seed that confirms the identity of the black haw.
Wineberry
wineberry
Rosaceae, the rose family
Wineberries ripen in the second half of the summer and go out of season in late summer, although you can use the leaves for tea from spring to fall.
Wineberries grow in sunny and partially sunny habitats with moist soil, in thickets, fields, disturbed habitats, wetlands, and open woods, along trail- and forest edges and roadsides, and in praries.
Wineberries grow in the Mid-Atlantic states, southern New England, and parts of the Deep South, but not the Gulf Coast.
Asia

Look for unbranched, multi-stemmed, upright, arching canes covered with bristly, reddish, glandular hairs. The palmate-compound, alternate leaves have three large, broadly oval, sharply toothed, pointy tipped, papery leaflets, green above and whitish beneath. Red, bristly panicles with inconspicuous, white, five-petaled flowers and five longer, narrow, triangular, bristly sepals are followed by bright red to dark purple-red, juicy, spherical aggregate fruits, one inch or more in diameter, growing in small clusters.

Growing three to nine feet tall, bristly, reddish, glandular hairs cover this unbranched, multi-stemmed, upright and arching biennial cane, which can take root and spread further where its tip touches the ground. New growth from the perennial roots occurs the first year. Side branches with flowers and berries arise on the these during the second year, after which it dies back to the roots, to repeat the cycle.

The palmate-compound alternate leaves, which grow from four to seven inches long, consist of three large, broadly oval, sharply toothed, pointy tipped, papery leaflets, green above, and whitish beneath due to a mat of wooly hairs.

in mid-spring, flowers bloom on very bristly many-flowered panicles at the tips of the second year's side shoots. The sepals are long enough to enclose the immature flowers. Each inconspicuous, white flower grows 0.2 to 0.4 inch across, with five tiny, oval petals, within the five long, narrow, triangular, bristly sepals, which form a star nearly an inch across, on a densely prickly, red flower stalk.

The sepals close over the flower after fertilization too, and don't open until the aggregate fruit is nearly ripe. Orange before ripening, the bright red to dark purple-red, juicy, spherical berries, 1 inch or more in diameter, grow in small clusters. An orange receptacle is left behind after you pick the hollow berry.

•Unbranched, multi-stemmed, upright, arching cane
•Stems covered with bristly, reddish, glandular hairs
•Palmate-compound alternate leaves four to seven inches long, with three large, broadly oval, sharply toothed, pointed, papery leaflets
•Leaflets green above, and whitish with mat of whooly hair beneath
•Flowers and fruits growing on red, bristly panicles
•Inconspicuous, white flowers 0.2 to 0.4 inch across, with five tiny oval petals
•Five narrow, triangular, bristly sepals longer than the flowers, forming a star nearly 1 inch across
•Bright red to dark purple-red, juicy, spherical aggregate fruits, one inch or more in diameter, growing in small clusters
•Berries orange when unripe
•Receptacle orange

Plan your harvest in advance, choosing a relatively cool day, and forage early in the morning, so you can wear long pants and sleeves to protect yourself from thorns and mosquitoes without getting too hot.

Punch a hole in the top of a food container, insert a key ring and attach it to your belt with a key clip, to free both hands for picking. Wear heavy-duty work gloves with the fingertips of your picking hand's glove cut off (kitchen shears will do this) to protect your hands as much as possible.

Pick as many of the most dark red-purple berries as possible. They're the tastiest. When your container and stomach are full, transfer your harvest into one of your empty containers and resume picking.

These are especially tasty raspberries, much more flavorful and acidic than the ones you buy, although they contain hard seeds which you should strain out in any recipe where the fruit will be puréed, i.e., jams. Otherwise, use wineberries in any manner of dessert. The results are always astonishing.
These berries may cause bipolar disorder (manic-depressive syndrome): You become ecstatically happy while you're eating them, and dismally depressed when the season ends and they run out!
Other raspberries (Rubus spp.), also very tasty, lack the wineberry's red, glandular-hairy stems.
Japanese Wineberry, Wine Raspberry

This bramble has a distinctive, red, glandular-bristly stem. The alternate, palmate-compound leaves consist of three broadly oval, toothed, pointed leaflets, which are whitish underneath. The spherical aggregate fruits are orange at first, then red when ripe. Clustered on panicles, five long, narrow, triangular sepals grow below each of the faceted berries.
2)Wineberry in Flower, and in Fruit

This bramble, with its distinctive, glandular-bristly stem, has alternate, palmate-compound leaves consisting of three broadly oval, toothed, pointed leaflets. The flowers and fruits, each with five long, narrow, bristly, triangular sepals beneath, grow loosely clustered on panicles.

The five-petaled flowers are tiny and inconspicuous, but the juicy, spherical aggregate fruits, which emerge from the ovate calyx just before ripening, are easy to spot.

The wineberry's palmate-compound leaf consists of three broadly oval, toothed, pointed leaflets, and the stems are all covered with bristly red hairs.

The panicle of spherical, red, faceted, aggregate fruits, each above five long, bristly, triangular sepals, and growing on red, bristly stems, makes this delicious raspberry species distinct. Unlike blackberries, all raspberries are hollow, leaving behind a base, here an orange-colored receptacle, after the berry is removed.
Creamy Wineberry Ice Cream
creamy-wineberry-ice-cream

The wonderful flavor of wineberries shines through the perfect texture of this vegan ice cream

4 cups soy-rice milk, almond milk or other non-dairy milk
1 tbs. agar flakes
1 tbs. arrowroot or kudzu
1/2 cup raw pignola nuts or cashews
1/4 cup vegetable glycerin
1/4 cup grape seed oil
1 tbs. liquid stevia
1 tsp. vanilla extract
1/4 tsp. strawberry extract (optional)
1/4 tsp. orange ice extract
1/2 tsp. salt
1-1/2 cups Wild Raspberry or Wineberry Jam

1. Stir the agar and arrowroot into the soy-rice milk, bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, and simmer 5 minutes, or until the agar is dissolved, stirring often.

2. Combine with the remaining ingredients except the jam in a blender and purée.

3. Freeze in an ice cream machine according to the manufacturer’s directions.

4. Stir in the jam at the end.

Makes 5-1/2 cups

Preparation time: 25 minutes

Freezing time: 2 hours

Wintergreen
wintergreen
Ericaceae, the heath family
The leaves are in season all year, while the berries ripen in mid-fall, and some persist into early spring.
Partially shaded, moist habitats with poor, acidic soil, open woodlands, bogs, and clearings
Eastern North America, but not Florida

Look for mats of a very small, colonial, slightly woody, unbranched evergreen shrub with upright, reddish-brown stems. The thick, wavy edged or slightly toothed, shiny, elliptical to oval, leathery, evergreen, alternate leaves are dark green above, lighter underneath. Red-tinged in winter, they cluster toward tops of the stems. Small, white, five-lobed, bell-shaped flowers, with five sepals at the base, droop from the upper leaf axils, as do the small, pendant, bright red, solitary, spherical berries.

Scratch and sniff for the fragrance of wintergreen.

The slightly woody, unbranching, upright, reddish-brown stems of this colonial evergreen shrub, with creeping runners that form mats, grow three to six inches tall. All parts smell like wintergreen when crushed.

Clustered at the top of the stem, thick, wavy edged or slightly toothed, shiny, elliptical to oval, leathery, evergreen, alternate leaves grow one to two inches long and 0.33 to 0.75 inch wide. The youngest, softer leaves are yellowish-green, but the rest are dark green above and lighter underneath. Winter weather tinges them with red.

Small, paired, or in threes, the white, five-lobed, bell-shaped flowers, which grow from 0.25 to 0.5 inch long, bloom from summer to early fall, hanging from the upper leaf axils on drooping stalks. Five sepals grow at flower's base.

Bright red, solitary, spherical berries 0.25 to 0.5 inch across replace the flowers on the drooping stalks.

•Mats of small, fragrant, colonial, evergreen shrubs, with slightly woody, unbranching, upright, reddish-brown stems three to six inches tall
•Thick, wavy edged or slightly toothed, shiny, elliptical to oval, leathery, evergreen, alternate leaves one to two inches long and 0.33 to 0.75 inch wide
•Leaves clustered toward tops of stems
•Leaves dark green on top, lighter underneath, red-tinged in winter
•Five-lobed, bell-shaped white flowers 0.25 to 0.5 inch long
•Flowers hanging from the upper leaf axils on drooping stalks
•Five sepals at the flower's base.
•Bright red, solitary, spherical berries 0.25 to 0.5 inch across, on drooping stalks
Collect the berries and strip the leaves off with your fingers.

The berries' familiar, refreshing flavor makes them ideal for salads and fruit dishes, cereals, puddings, jello, pies, cakes, and sauces. They're small and labor-intensive to collect, so they're best used as a minor ingredient or garnish. They compliment sweet, juicy fruits especially well. Add them at the end of the cooking time, so you don't cook off the volatile wintergreen flavor.

Steep lots of fresh or dried wintergreen leaves or berries in water to cover to make a mild, pleasant-tasting, refreshing tea. Fermenting the leaves and berries in warm water for a few days increases their strength.
Wintergreen berries are high in vitamin C. Otherwise, nutritional information is lacking.

An infusion of any of the above-ground parts of this plant contains oil of wintergreen, a.k.a. methyl salicylate, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory and the chemical forerunner of aspirin. It was used by the Indians for pain and inflammation, although you'll need many cups of tea to equal over-the-counter pain killers. Low dose aspirin, on the other hand, is prescribed heart disease, to thin the blood and prevent clots from causing heart attacks and strokes, but aspirin increases the risk of internal bleeds that could lead to gastrointestinal ulcers and strokes. A couple of cups of strong wintergreen tea a day could have the same protective effect, there's no documented evidence of such side effects, and it tastes good.

The tea is also considered an analgesic, astringent, carminative, diuretic, stimulant, tonic, and emmenagogue. Women used the infusion internally for delayed, irregular, or painful menstruation and to ease the pain of childbirth. People have also used the tea as a mouth rinse and gargle, and chewing the leaves or eating the berries has been used for bad breath, to soothe irritated gums, and for canker sores.

Oil of wintergreen, a concentrate you'd have to buy, has been used externally as a balm, liniment, or ointment. It’s been an ingredient in massage oils for decades, and has been used externally for headaches, arthritis, neuralgia, hives, swelling, and sore nipples. It's supposed to be a counterirritant, alterative, painkiller, antiseptic, deobstruent, depurative, diaphoretic, diuretic, parasiticide, pectoral, stomachic, and vulnerary, so it has also used externally for burns, chafing, cholera, colds, cough, dandruff, diarrhea, dysentery, dysmenorrhea, gout, gravel, lumbago, rheumatism, scalds, sciatica, sores, and more, but without supporting evidence.

Wintergreen contains compounds chemically related to aspirin, so avoid this plant if you have a medical condition that prevents you from taking aspirin.

Don't take oil of wintergreen, a concentrate you'd have to buy, internally or use it in excess externally, or you'll poison yourself, and you might die.
Teaberry, Tea Leaf, American Wintergreen, Checkerberry, Boxberry, Deerberry
This plant, which smells just as you'd expect, makes a delicious, healthful tea just about all year, and it has tasty berries too.
2)Wintergreen in Flower and Fruit
2wintergreen-in-flower-and-fruit

Wintergreen is a small, colonial shrub with unbranching, reddish-brown stems. The oval, wavy edged, alternate leaves become tinged with red in autumn. Five-lobed, white, bell-shaped flowers hang from the leaf axils, developing into pendant, solitary, spherical, red berries.
Wintergreen Curry
wintergreen-curry

Wintergreen berries make this Thai curry even more exotic-tasting.

4 cups soy-rice blend milk, or other non-dairy milk
3-1/3 cups (2 16 oz. cans) of coconut milk
2 cups veggie beef (available in Chinese specialty stores and websites) or firm tofu, diced
1-1/4 cup bamboo shoots
1 cup long-grain brown rice
4 celery stalks, sliced
2 carrots, sliced
1 large red onion, chopped
1 mango, chopped
1/4 cup Thai curry paste, or to taste
1/2 tbs. salt, or to taste
1/4 tsp. clear liquid stevia
1 cup wintergreen berries

1. Bring all ingredients except the wintergreen berries to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer 1 hour, or until the rice is tender.

2. Serve garnished with the wintergreen berries.

Serves 8 to 10

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Cooking time: 60 minutes
1)Wintergreen with Immature Berries
1wintergreen-with-immature-berries
This small, unbranched, upright shrub has leathery, oval to elliptical, slightly toothed, alternate leaves, and small, hanging, spherical berries that are just beginning to develop here.
Poison Ivy
poison-ivy
Anacardiaceae, the cashew family or sumac family
Poison ivy and its toxic relatives are poisonous all year.
Sunny or partially shaded disturbed habitats, edges of trails, roadsides, near the seashore, on fences, in fields, parklands, marshes, thickets, and open woods
Throughout North America

Look for an herbaceous plant, a small shrub, or a long creeping and climbing, hairy-looking woody vine. It's stalked, alternate, three-parted, palmate-compound leaves are composed of three shiny, oval, toothless or sparely toothed leaflets with a long leafstalk on the leading leaflet. Loose, branching clusters of small, inconspicuous green-white, yellow-centered flowers hang with and pendant clusters of densely packed, small, dry, hard, spherical, cream-white berries.

Here's the plant I'm sure you're just itching to discover! People have trouble recognizing it because it takes several forms. It can grow as a small, harmless-looking herbaceous plant. It may be a small shrub with smooth, gray bark that can grow up to four feet tall (although increased carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is making it quite larger and much more toxic), and can carpet a forest floor.

It often takes the form of a coarsely hairy-looking vine with a trunk up to six inches across, that can trail four to ten feet, cover fences, or climb 150 feet high. The hairs are actually aerial roots which anchor the vine to whatever it's growing on, taking sunlight, but no nutrients, from its support structure. The other forms have these roots too, but they're small and inconspicuous, so you have to look for them—important for recognizing the gray shrub form, with small orange-brown buds, in the winter.

The stalked, alternate, three-parted palmate-compound leaves consist of two lateral, short-stalked leaflets pointing in opposite directions, and one long-stalked leading leaflet perpendicular to the other two. With pointed tips and rounded bases, the oval leaflets, which sometimes have a few coarse, irregular teeth, can grow from four to 14 inches long. The point of convergence of the three leafstalks is always red. The shiny leaflets themselves are red while they're still developing, in early spring, and when they change color in the fall.

Blooming in late spring and summer, loose, branching inconspicuous clusters of flowers with 5 green-white, oval petals surrounding a yellow center, grow on lateral stems arising from the leaf axils. They’re replaced by hanging clusters of small, dry, hard, spherical, ivory-white berries, 0.25 inch across, that ripen in late summer and fall, and sometimes persist into the winter.

•Herbaceous plant, small shrub, or long, creeping or climbing, woody vine
*Smooth, gray bark
•Hairy-looking, aerial roots on vine form
•Long-stalked, alternate, three-parted, palmate-compound leaves
•Three shiny, oval, toothless or sparsely toothed leaflets
•Leading leaflet long-stalked, lateral leaflets nearly stalkless
•Red spot where the leaflet's stalks converge
•Developing leaflets red
•Foliage red in autumn
•Loose, branching clusters of small, inconspicuous five-petaled, green-white, yellow-centered flowers
•Pendant clusters of densely packed, small, dry, hard, spherical, cream-white berries
The berries are delicious eaten right off the vine, but only if you're a bird!

The plant contains a yellow, lacquer-like phenolic compound called urushiol, which contains pentadecylcatechols that provoke severe allergic reactions in humans only, in the form of skin blistering contact dermatitis, usually within one to 12 hours. The oil also spreads through the blood, so you may also break out where you haven’t touched the plant.

Although some people aren't allergic to poison ivy, if they keep exposing themselves to it, they may become sensitive. Even contact with a dog that has run through poison ivy can cause a rash. So learn the plant, actively look for it, and avoid it.

Washing with regular soap, which contains oils, after exposure, spreads the oily poison. Washing with an oil-free detergent soap, sold in drugstores as poison ivy soap, helps prevent the rash.

Sometimes people on my tours don't heed my warnings, and contact poison ivy. I have them rub any exposed surfaces with the liquid from the stem of jewelweed right away, and their skin remains unaffected, even though their behavior was rash!

Jewelweed also helps half the people who try it after the rash has developed. Otherwise, the best home remedies are oatmeal and baking soda. For severe cases, medical intervention with immune system-suppressant steroids is necessary.

Some people eat small amounts of very young poison ivy leaves to desensitize themselves to the toxin. This sometimes works. Other times, you get a very bad rash where the poison ivy enters the body, and a much worse rash where it exits the body at the other end (the treatment backfires!) In extreme cases, your throat becomes so swollen that you can't breath! Likewise, burning poison ivy and breathing in the smoke can be fatal. There's only 1 person who'd be unaffected: Bill Clinton—he doesn't inhale!

Poison ivy is not related to the true ivies (Hedera spp.)

Blackberries and raspberries (Rubus spp.) have three-, five-, or seven-parted palmate compound leaves that look a little like poison ivy's, especially the three-parted ones, but, unlike poison ivy, these plants, which have edible berries, are prickly, and their leaves are strongly toothed.

The hog peanut, with a 3-parted palmate-compound leaf, grows in the same habitat as poison ivy, but it's a slender, sparsely branched, hairy, twining vine, and the leaflets are never even slightly toothed.

Poison oak (T. quercifolium on the East Coast and T. diversilobum on the West Coast), is a similar-looking shrub, except that the leaflets have rounded lobes, like oak leaves. Botanists aren't sure whether it's a species separate from poison ivy, or a subspecies. I have no opinion on this issue, since I avoid handling anything having to do with this group of plants!

Western poison ivy (T. rydbergii) is another equally toxic shrub, very similar to poison oak, that grows in Western North America.
Eastern Poison Ivy

"Leaves of three, let it be! Hairy rope, don't be a dope!"
Poison ivy is a herbaceous plant, a shrub, or a hairy vine with three-parted, palmate compound leaves that... well, you know the rest! So learn this plant to begin with, and be on the lookout for it any time you venture outdoors!
Blackberries, Raspberries, Hog Peanut
Poison Oak, Poison Sumac
1)Poison Ivy Leaf and Berries
1poison-ivy-leaf-and-berries

Poison ivy's palmate-compound leaf always has three parts. The oval, pointed, shiny leaflets have no teeth or a few coarse ones. The leading leaf has a long leafstalk, the two side leaflets have nearly none. The clusters of small, round, hard berries arise from the leaf axils.
2)Poison Ivy Leaf
2poison-ivy-leaf

Poison ivy's vine looks hairy due to the aerial roots that hold it onto its substrate. As they're developing in early spring, the shiny, oval, long-stalked, pointed leaflets of the three-parted, alternate, palmate-compound leaves are tinged with red. Only the leading leaflet has a long leafstalk.
3)Poison Ivy Mature Leaf
3poison-ivy-mature-leaf
Look for this 3-parted slightly toothed, palmate-compound leaf along the ground, on a short shrub, or on a vine, turn around, and walk the other way!
4)Poison Ivy Flowers
4poison-ivy-flowers
Hanging in loose clusters, these small, attractive, five-petaled, green-white flowers, with yellow centers, are as poisonous as the rest of the plant.
5)Poison Shrubs Ivy with Berries
5poison-shrubs-ivy-with-berries

Poison ivy can carpet the forest floor with many small, gray shrubs here, with seen with its small, angled, orange-brown buds. This not somewhere to take a walk, and these buds are not for you!

The three-parted palmate compound leaves, less shiny than usual here, lack the few teeth that some leaflets often have, but the leading leaflet's leafstalk is always much longer than the very short leafstalks of the lateral leaflets.

The small, hard, spherical, whitish berries grow tightly packed in clusters arising from the leaf axils.
6)Poison Ivy Vine in Winter
6poison-ivy-vine-in-winter

It's very easy to recognize these gray, densely hairy, woody vines in winter, as there's nothing similar. The hairs are aerial roots which anchor the vine tightly to the tree, but don't absorb nutrients.
7)Poison Ivy Shrubs
7poison-ivy-shrubs
If you see an extensive stand of short, gray, slightly branched shrubs in open woods in the winter, you've found one of poison ivy's 2 leafless forms.
8)Poison Ivy Shrub with Hairs
8poison-ivy-shrub-with-hairs
You can confirm the identity of a stand of short, gray poison ivy shrubs if you examine them closely and find some with hairy-looking aerial roots.
Poison Hemlock
poison-hemlock
Apiaceae or Umbelliferae, the umbellifers, or the parsley family
Poison hemlock is poisonous all year.
Sunny or partially shaded disturbed soil, pastures, open fields, low ground, roadsides, railroad right-of-ways, and edges of trails
All of the US, plus southeast and southwest Canada, but not in Mississippi and Florida
Europe

Look for a plant with a basal rosette of very large, oval to triangular, long-stalked, dark green, lacy, feather-compound leaves divided 2 or 3 times; hollow, branching, purple-blotched, upright, hairless, ribbed stems 3 to 10 feet tall; alternate stem leaves similar to the basal leaves; terminal, compound umbrella-like flower clusters with many, tiny, 5-petaled, white flowers over long-tipped, oval to lance-shaped bracts; and very many very small, flattened, oval, ribbed black seeds, in terminal, compound, umbrella-like clusters.

[Look for a plant with a basal rosette of very large, oval to triangular, long-stalked, dark green, lacy, feather-compound leaves divided two or three times. It's hollow, branching, purple-blotched, upright, hairless, ribbed stems are three to ten feet tall. Alternate stem leaves similar to the basal leaves and terminal, compound umbrella-like flower clusters with many, tiny, five-petaled, white flowers form over long-tipped, oval to lance-shaped bracts. Very many, very small, flattened, oval, ribbed black seeds are in terminal, compound, umbrella-like clusters.]

Crush any part of the plant and sniff for the musty odor of a dead mouse. Then go wash your hands!

This biennial appears very early in the spring, above a solid, thick, whitish, musty smelling taproot three to eight inches long, that smells like a dead mouse.

A basal rosette of oval to triangular, long-stalked, dark green, lacy, feather-compound leaves one to 2.5 or more feet long and almost equally wide, appears the first year. These divide two or three times, with long, hairless leaf stalks, ending in individual leaflets about 0.33 inch long.

A smooth, hollow, branching, hairless, purple-blotched, upright, ribbed flower stalk grows from three to ten feet tall in the spring. Similar alternate leaves, which often partially sheath the stem, grow about 18 inches long and 12 inches wide, becoming smaller toward the top. The lower leaves are long-stalked, the upper ones are nearly stalkless.

Blooming from mid-spring to late summer, terminal, compound, umbrella-like flower clusters two to five inches across subdivide eight to 16 times, ending in 12 to 25 five-petaled, white flowers 0.125 inch across. Long-tipped oval to lance-shaped bracts grow under each flower cluster, and smaller bracts grow under each individual flower.

One plant can produce 20,000 small, flattened, oval, ribbed black seeds, 0.125 inch long, in the same configuration.

•Thick, solid, whitish, musty smelling taproot three to eight inches long
•Basal rosette of oval to triangular, long-stalked, dark green, lacy, feather-compound leaves, one to 2.5 feet or more long, and almost equally wide
•Leaf divided two or three times into leaflets 0.33 inch long
•Hollow, branching, purple-blotched, upright, ribbed stem, three to ten feet tall
•Leaf stalks and stems smooth and hairless
•Alternate stem leaves 18 inches long and 12 inches wide, smaller toward the top, their bases partially sheathing the stem
•Lower leaves long-stalked, upper ones are nearly stalkless.
•Terminal, compound, umbrella-like flower clusters two to five inches across, subdivided eight to 16 times, ending in 12 to 25 5-petaled, white flowers 0.125 inch across
•Long-tipped, oval to lance-shaped bracts under each flower cluster, plus smaller bracts under each individual flower
•Very many very small, flattened, oval, ribbed black seeds, in terminal, compound, umbrella-like clusters

Poison hemlock contains the alkaloid toxins coniine, N-methyl coniine, conhydrine, lambda-coniceine, and pseudoconhydrine. Eating even small amounts of this plant depresses the central nervous system, and can cause salivation, vomiting, diarrhea, muscular weakness, paralysis, nervousness, trembling, dilation of the pupils, weak pulse, convulsions, and coma.

Death usually occurs due to respiratory failure, as the brain can no longer signal the lungs to breath, but 1 person wouldn't be harmed by this plant:

George W. Bush—he has no brain!

People have confused wild carrots (Daucus carota) or Queen Anne's Lace with poison-hemlock, but unlike wild carrots, poison hemlock has smooth hollow stalks with purple blotches, and no hairs on its stems. Also, poison hemlock can get up to eight feet tall or higher, while wild carrots don't grow more than three feet tall. Poison hemlock produces many flowers per flower head rather than one, and there's never a purple flower in the center of the flower head, as there is with many wild carrot flowers. Poison hemlock also begins flowering in the spring, not in the summer, like wild carrots.

No related plant's feather-compound leaves as large as poison hemlock's.

Fool’s parsley (Aethusa cynapium), also foul-smelling, also has finely-cut leaves and hairless stems, along with three-pronged, beard-like bracts that hang from its clusters of white, umbrella-like flowers. It's leaves aren't as large as poison hemlock. But don't worry if you confuse the two plants. Fool's parsley is nearly as deadly as poison hemlock, and will dispatch you just as effectively!

1. Whole Plant: Devil's Porridge, Beaver Poison, Herb Bennet (not Geum urbanum—an herb with the same name), Musquash Root, Poison Parsley, Spotted Corobane, Spotted Hemlock

2. Seed: Kecksies, Kex.

Poison hemlock depresses the central nervous system, stops the brain from communicating with the lungs, and causes respiratory failure and death. It killed Socrates, considered the wisest man in the world, who was condemned to death after he taught his students to think for themselves. On the other hand, it wouldn't kill George W. Bush, who instituted mindless rote learning for the sake of test scores, called No child left behind-—he has no brain!
1)Poison Hemlock Leaves and Taproot
1poison-hemlock-leaves-and-taproot

Poison hemlock's finely divided leaves and whitish taproot make it resemble the wild carrot enough that it's killed unwary foragers, but the leafstalks are smooth, not hairy, like wild carrots', and the root smells like a dead mouse, not like a carrot.
2)Poison Hemlock in Flower
2poison-hemlock-in-flower

Poison hemlock's twice-compound, white, umbrella-like flower heads look like Queen Anne's lace, but poison hemlock, which is a much taller plant, has a smooth, ridged stem that sets it apart from the wild carrot's shorter, hairy stem.
3)Poison Hemlock Skeleton and Seeds
3poison-hemlock-skeleton-and-seeds
These small, black, oval, ribbed seeds, in their umbrella-like configuration, remain behind in terminal clusters on the stem after poison hemlock dies. Eat them, and you'll be as dead as the stems!
Water Hemlock
water-hemlock
Apiaceae or Umbelliferae, the umbellifers, or the parsley family
This plant is deadly all year.
Sunny or partially shaded wet soil, marshes, swamps, wet meadows, lakesides, and streambanks
Throughout North America

Look for a branching plant with a smooth, stout stem, hollow toward the bottom, green and blotched with purple, or all purple. Its large, two- or three times feather-compound leaves, often reddish-tinged, consist of long, pointed, shiny, lance-shaped, strongly toothed, hairless leaflets. Tiny, white, five-petaled flowers grow in erect, compound, umbrella-like clusters. They give way to small, three-angled seeds.

Sniff for the fragrance of anise, but don't taste!

This branching plant, with a smooth, stout stem, hollow toward the bottom, grows three to six feet tall. It may be purple, or green and spotted with purple.

The fleshy, white, ovoid to oblong taproots, which resemble parsnips, have many swollen, finger-like side branches clustered together.

The two or three times feather-compound leaves, often reddish-tinged, grow up to 16 inches long and 12 inches wide, with sheathed leafstalks. The long, pointed, shiny, lance-shaped, strongly toothed, hairless leaflets grow from 0.75 to four inches long and up to 1.25 inches wide. Their veins end in the notches between the teeth, not inside the teeth, a very important distinction that sets water hemlock apart from similar-looking plants.

Blooming from summer to early fall, tiny, white, five-petaled flowers grow in erect, compound umbrella-like clusters two to six inches wide, with 10 to 20 subdivisions of 12 to 15 flowers. Bracts grow at the base of each small flower cluster, but not under the main flower clusters. Small three-angled seeds replace the flowers in late summer and fall.

The entire plant produces the enticing fragrance of anise when torn or crushed.

•Branching plant with a smooth, stout, stem, hollow toward the bottom, three to six feet tall, green with purple blotches, or purple
•Fleshy, white, ovoid to oblong taproots with many swollen, finger-like, clustered side branches
•Two or three times feather-compound leaves, often reddish-tinged, up to 16 inches long and 12 inches wide
•Sheathed leafstalks
•Long, pointed, shiny, lance-shaped, strongly toothed, hairless leaflets 0.75 to four inches long and up to 1.25 inches wide
•Leaflets' veins ending in the notches between the teeth
•Erect, compound, umbrella-like flower clusters two to six inches wide, with 10 to 20 subdivisions of 12 to 15 tiny, five-petaled, white, flowers
•Bracts only at the base of each small flower cluster
•Small, three-angled seeds
•Entire plant producing the fragrance of anise when torn or crushed

North America's most deadly plant, water hemlock contains cicutoxin, a clear, brown resin, and cicutol, toxins so powerful that eating one mouthful of any part of the plant can be fatal. Symptoms include severe stomach pain, vomiting, diarrhea, pupil dilation, difficulty breathing, frothing at the mouth, violent convulsions, and death within anywhere from 15 minutes or eight hours. After chewing their tongues to ribbons, victims may asphyxiate on their own vomit, unable to unclench their jaws. But on the plus side, the roots reportedly taste good!

There's no antidote to the poison, but with prompt medical treatment in the form of supportive therapy, recovery may occur within 24 hours, although neurological damage sometimes remains.

Other related plants resemble water hemlock. The wild parsnip, which you can eat without dying, has once-divided feather-compound leaves rather than two or three times divided leaves. The flowers are yellow rather than white, the stem isn't hollow, and there's a single taproot rather than bundles. The cow parsnip, another edible relative, has white flowers, but again, the leaves are once-compound.

Water parsnip (Sium sauve), has a strongly ridged stem and twice-compound, not three times compound, leaves. Its finely cut basal leaves, often submerged, grow from a single root, not a bundle, like water hemlock. But the flowers are similar, and it grows in the same habitat as water hemlock, sometimes side by side. Although it's edible, the risk of confusing the two plants is great enough that inexperienced foragers should avoid it.

People have poisoned themselves mistaking this plant with wild carrots, which have lacy, finely cut leaves and a single main taproot that smells like carrots—quite dissimilar from this plant, but apparently not dissimilar enough!
Spotted Water Hemlock, Spotted Cowbane, Spotted Parsley
This is the most poisonous plant in North America. People have been killed by a single mouthful, and it's a very painful death, although at least the plant is supposed to be tasty!
Wild Parsnip, Cow Parsnip, Wild Carrot

2water-hemlock-stem

Salsify
salsify
Family Asteraceae (Compositae), the astor or composite family

The roots of young plants with basal rosettes are in season in early spring and fall. Although they're theoretically edible in the winter, but without above-ground parts, you can't find them, nor would it be easy to dig them out of the frozen ground.

When they first appear in early- and mid-spring respectively, the tender young leaves and stems are edible.
Sunny or partially shaded, disturbed habitats, fields, meadows, and roadsides
Most of the US and southern Canada, but not in North Dakota and South Dakota, and not in the Deep South except for Georgia
Europe
Dig up the taproot with a shovel or trowel, and use a pocketknife to cut off the above-ground parts, or break or twist them off with your fingers.

Before they become too bitter, the very young leaves, immature stems, and the emerging buds are good in salads, or cooked in a variety of savory dishes. They're tasty, but carry an overtone of bitterness, like dandelions. Sautéeing shrinks them and concentrates their bitterness, but you can dispels this cook them further in a sauce, soup, or stew with plenty of herbs or spices.

The youngest roots are edible raw. Otherwise slice them, peel if necessary, and simmer for 20 to 30 minutes in soups and stews. Salsify reminds some people of the flavor of oysters, and it's great in mock seafood dishes, along with edible seaweeds, which increase the seafood flavor. It's also superb cream of potato soup and similar creamy dishes.

Some people also roast the roots until black, grind them, and use them as a coffee substitute.
Salsify root provides vitamins B6, B2, C, E, K, and folate, plus the minerals calcium, iron magnesium, manganese, phosphorus, and potassium, as well as the trace minerals copper, selenium, and zinc.

Purple goat’s beard, also called salsify and oyster plant (T. porrifolius), is a relative you use the same way you use T. pratensis, with which it hybridizes. They share the same range, but purple goat's beard has a tougher taproot and a violet flower, and it grows up to four feet tall, not three feet, like salsify.

Western Goat's Beard (T. dubius), an edible West Coast relative, has pale yellow flower heads with about 13 bracts instead of 8.

Spiderwort (Tradescantia spp.), also edible but unrelated, has leaves similar to salsify, but totally different flowers and no milky sap.
Meadow Salsify, Oyster Plant, Goat's Beard, John-Go-to-Bed-at-Noon
The leaves of this plant can be mistaken for grass until you take a good look, but after you dig up and cook the tasty root, you'll be glad you didn't miss this one.
1)Salsify in Flower
1salsify-in-flower
This unusual-looking plant has grass-like leaves, a long, slender, somewhat branched stem, huge, yellow, dandelion-like flowers with eight even longer bracts, and well as large, urn-shaped buds.
2)Salsify Flower Head
2salsify-flower-head
The large, yellow, dandelion-like flower head consists of only ray flowers. It grows above eight long, narrow, pointed, linear bracts that grow longer than the rest of the flower.
3)Salsify Seed Head
3salsify-seed-head

This spherical, white seed head looks like a dandelion's, but it's way larger. Long, spindle-shaped, brown seeds grow in the center. They're threaded with branching tufts of white hairs, ready to act as parachutes. The green, urn-shaped pods on the branching stems are preparing to open and release even more mature seeds.
Salsify Stew
salsify-stew

Here’s a stew that’s especially easy to make. Just simmer all the ingredients together. And with the rice acting as a thickener, along with wild salsify plus complementary ingredients and seasonings, the flavor is superb.

4 cups salsify root, burdock, or parnips, sliced
2 cups wild or commercial carrots, sliced
1-1/4 cups vegetable stock or water
2 tomatoes, chopped
1/2 cup cilantro, chopped
1 red onion, chopped
2 celery stalks, sliced
1/4 long-grain brown rice
2 tbs. olive oil
4 cloves of garlic, chopped
1 tsp. Vege-sal or 1/2 tsp. salt, or to taste
6 bayberry leaves or 3 bay leaves placed in a tea ball or tied into a piece of cheesecloth
2 tbs. white wine
1 tsp. thyme, ground
1 tsp. dried wild or commercial mint, ground
1 tsp. marjoram, ground
1/4 tsp. black pepper, or to taste

1. Bring all ingredients to a boil in a heavy saucepan over medium heat, stirring often.

2. Reduce the heat to low and simmer, covered, 1 hour or until the rice is tender.

3. Remove and discard the bayberry leaves.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 15 minutes

Cooking time: 60 minutes
Common Sow Thistle
common-sow-thistle
Family Asteraceae (Compositae), the astor or composite family

Collect the basal leaves in early spring and late fall, and the developing upper leaves with tender parts of the stem in mid-spring. You can sometimes collect the young stem leaves throughout the growing season if they're not too bitter, although they seem to gain and lose their bitterness sporadically.

Sunny and partially shaded areas, on disturbed soil, along roadsides, in meadows and fields, near the seashore, in cracks in the sidewalk, and often against walls, where it’s less likely to be cut down
Common sow thistle grows throughout most of North America.
Eurasia

Look for a basal rosette with roughly oval, hairless, bristly, stalked, deeply toothed, dull blue-green leaves. Later, look for a tall stem that branches very little below the flowers. It has broad-based, triangular-lobed, stalkess, alternate leaves similar to the basal leaves. They clasp the stem. The upper leaves are smaller, less lobed, less toothed, or entire. The leaf bases all taper at 2 points.

Terminal clusters of long-stemmed, yellow composite flowers with ray flowers only become white, spherical seed heads, smaller and more numerous than dandelions'.

Common sow thistle first appears in early spring as a basal rosette with roughly oval, hairless, bristly, stalked, deeply toothed, dull blue-green leaves.

The hollow stem, which appears in mid-spring, grows 1 to 6 feet tall, with very little branching below the flowers. The broad-based, triangular-lobed, stalkess, alternate leaves, up to 10 inches long and 2.5 inches across, are similar to the basal leaves, but they clasp the stem, and the two leaf base taper to a point. The upper leaves are less lobed and toothed, or entire. Older leaves turn grayish-green.

The long-stemmed composite flowers, blooming from early spring to late fall, cluster at the end of the stems. 0.25 to 0.75 inch wide, they consist of yellow strap-shaped ray flowers only. Present from mid-summer nearly to winter, the white, spherical seed heads resemble dandelions', only smaller and more numerous.

The whole plant, which arises from a taproot, exudes a white, milky sap when cut.

•Basal rosette with roughly oval, hairless, bristly, stalked, deeply toothed, dull blue-green leaves
•Hollow stem 1 to 6 feet tall, with very little branching below the flowers
•Broad-based, triangular-lobed, stalkess, alternate stem leaves similar to the basal leaves
•Stem leaves clasp the stem
•Upper stem leaves are less lobed than lower ones, less toothed, or entire
• Older leaves turn grayish-green
•Leaf bases tapers to two points
•Terminal clusters of long-stemmed, yellow composite flowers with ray flowers only
•Persistent white, spherical seed heads smaller and more numerous than dandelions'
•Long taproot
•Whole plant exudes white, milky sap when injured

Collect the smaller, youngest basal leaves when they first appear in early spring. They're the best-tasting. While you can certainly pluck off the leaves with your hands, cutting the root just under the center of the rosette with a pocketknife gets you the entire rosette in an instant, and while it's still intact, you can shake off most of the soil and debris before bagging the plant.

Later on in the spring, cut or tear off the youngest leaves and tender parts of the stem at the top. After cold weather in late fall, the stem leaves sometimes lose their bitterness, and you can strip these off too. Sometimes they leaves aren't bitter in the summer and early fall, but I haven't figured out how to predict when this will happen.

Raw common sow thistle tastes like lettuce. Cooked it's like Swiss chard. Add the leaves and tender young parts of the stems to salads, or sauté them with seasonings and cook them in a sauce, which dissipates the concentrated bitterness you'd expect when cooking shrinks the leaves.

You can also add the leaves to soups, stews, casseroles, or other dishes that call for vegetables. They cook in 10 to 15 minutes. If the outer layer of the stem is tough, peel it beforehand.
Common sow thistle provides vitamins A, B1, B2, B3, and C, as well as the minerals calcium, phosphorus, and iron.
Don’t collect where people have polluted the soil with excessive nitrates, which can make you sick.

Other sow thistle species, which grow across North America, are as good as common sow thistle. Spiny-leafed sow-thistle *(S. asper)* has very spiny, glossy, dark green leaves with smaller lobes, and curly leaf bases that clasp the stem. You have to cut off its spines to eat it.

Field sow thistle *(S. arvensis),* which grows 2 to 5 feet tall, has weak spines, a long, creeping, perennial taproot, and dandelion-like leaves. It has hairy flower stalks, and hairy bracts under the flowers.

Other less closely related edibles also resemble common sow thistle:

Dandelions have yellow composite flowers and white, milky sap too, but they hug the ground, each flower stalk has only one flower, and the leaves have larger teeth. Sow-thistles have more than one flower per flower stalk, there's a stem at some point during the life cycle, and the various species grow from 1 to 8 feet tall.

Wild lettuce has a row of hairs on the underside of the leaf’s midrib, and it lacks a taproot. Hairs sporadically spot chicory’s leaves, while common sow thistle’s bristly leaves lack hairs. Also, only common sow thistle’s older leaves turn grayish-green.

Sow thistle isn't a true thistle. True thistles, which include the edible bull thistle, have prickles that can really hurt, no white sap, and magenta flowers, not yellow ones.
Sow Thistle, Smooth Sow Thistle, Annual Sow Thistle, Hare's Colwort, Hare's Thistle, Milky Tassel, Swinie

This tasty relative of dandelions and lettuce is so nutritious, people in ancient Rome thought that a hare pursued by a fox would pause, chow down on some sow thistle, and gain enough energy to easily outrun its adversary. Even today, thousands of years later, one of common sow thistle's less common common names is hare's thistle!
Common Dandelion, Field Sow Thistle, Wild Lettuce, Bull Thistle, Chicory
1)Common Sow Thistle in Flower, and Basal Leaf

Common sow thistle's basal leaf (right) is deeply lobed, with lots of bristly teeth. The stem's alternate leaves' toothed lobes are triangular, and the leaf's stalkless base clasps the stem. Several small, long-stemmed, composite flowers that look like dandelion flowers cluster at the top of the stem.
2)Sow Thistle Basal Rosette
2sow-thistle-basal-rosette

You can recognize very young sow thistle basal leaves because they're lobed, with the largest lobe at the leaf tip. The leaves are hairless, and teeth plus bristly edges are just beginning to develop. If you break a leaf, it will exude a white, milky sap. These are the best leaves to eat, and they appear in early spring, before many other edibles.
3)Common Sow Thistle in Flower
