Growing from a crack in the pavement, this common plant produces branching clusters of long-stemmed, yellow, dandelion-like composite flowers near the tops of the stems. The bristly, hairless, toothed, alternate lower leaves have distinctly triangular lobes, while the upper leaves are more narrow, often without lobes, and with smaller teeth, if any.
Perilla
perilla
Lamiaceae, the mint family
You can use this plant from spring to fall.
Park lands, pastures, fields, stream banks, wet places, fence rows, and roadsides.
Most of the eastern half of the US and Ontario, but not northern New England.
East and Southeast Asia

Look for a medium-sized plant with deep purple, branching, square stems and medium-sized, long-stalked, wrinkly, toothed, hairy, oval to heart-shaped, reddish-green, opposite leaves. The upright, terminal spike-like racemes resemble bottle brushes. They bear small, hairy, tubular, pink to lavender bilaterally symmetrical flowers set inside a burgundy colored calyx.

Crush and sniff for the fragrance of mint and basil, and listen for a rattling sound when you shake the mature racemes when they contain seeds.

This aromatic annual mint's stout, branching, deep purple, hairy, square stems grow from one to three feet tall.

The long-stalked, wrinkly, toothed, hairy, oval to heart-shaped, reddish, opposite leaves grow from two to five inches across and 1.5 to four inches across.

Terminal spike-like racemes that look like bottle brushes arise from the leaf axils and grow up to ten inches tall. The many small, hairy, tubular, pink to lavender, bilaterally symmetrical flowers, 0.125 inch long, bloom from early summer through mid-fall. Each flower has a three-toothed upper lip and a two-toothed lower lip. The corolla barely protrudes from the hairy, burgundy colored calyx.

The seeds, tiny nutlets that ripen in autumn, are enclosed by the calyx, and rattle like a rattlesnake if shaken.

•Aromatic plant one to three feet tall with deep purple, branching, square stem.
• Long-stalked, wrinkly, toothed, hairy, oval to heart-shaped, opposite leaves two to five inches across and 1.5 to four inches across
•Upright, terminal spike-like racemes up to ten inches long, resembling bottle brushes
•Small, hairy, tubular, pink to lavender bilaterally symmetrical flowers
•Flower with three-toothed upper lip and a two-toothed lower lip
•Corolla barely protruding from the hairy, burgundy colored calyx
•Ripe nutlets inside calyx rattle when shaken
Strip off the leaves and flowers with your fingers. To use the stems for tea, cut them with a knife, clipper, or shears.

The leaves and flowers of this plant impart a strong, complex flavor that includes a combination of mint, apple, basil, and dark sesame oil. It's makes an exotic salad ingredient, and it's excellent for cooking or used as a seasoning. In East Asia, it's used in pickles, rice, and soups, where it cooks in 10 minutes, as well as in stir-fry dishes.
Perilla is a good source of beta-carotene and the omega-3 fatty acid alpha-linolenic acid.

Perilla contains apigenin, ascorbic-acid, caffeic-acid, citral, dillapiol, elemicin, limonene, luteolin, myristicin, perillaldehyde, protocatechuic-acid, quercetin, rosmarinic-acid, and other compounds.

An infusion of perilla leaves is used in Chinese traditional medicine for worms, bacterial infections and fever, food poisoning, coughs, indigestion and gas, and morning sickness, and as an antiseptic, antispasmodic, emollient, pectoral, restorative, stomachic, and tonic, as well as for the common cold.

Western science has found it to stimulate interferon activity, and preliminary evidence indicates that it can benefit seasonal allergies and asthma. It also shows antimutagenic, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory, consistent with its use for cancer in Asia.

Some people are allergic to this plant, so eat small quantities at first until you've ruled this out. Also, even though the Chinese use an infusion of the stems for morning sickness, there's some evidence that the herb may not be good for pregnant women, so they should avoid it altogether.

And don't eat this plant if you're a goat, sheep, cow, horse, rat, or mouse, or its perilla ketone, harmless to humans, may kill you!

Stinging nettles, edible when cooked, also have opposite leaves and square stems, but they're covered with stinging hairs. Nettle leaves, which are green rather than red, are more narrow, there are no branches, and tiny green flowers grow on slender, drooping racemes.
Beefsteak Plant, Shiso, Purple Mint, Japanese Basil, Wild Coleus, Summer Coleus, Wild Basil, Wild Red basil, Chinese Basil, Purple Mint, Rattlesnake Weed, Wild Sesame

Familiar to anyone who eats Japanese food, it's surprising to find this flavorful exotic vegetable (I'd call it a "green," only it's red!) growing wild in parks and meadows. And it's very easy to recognize. If you fail to notice the burgundy red leaves, shake the plant when its seeds are ripe and they'll rattle.
Stinging Nettles
1)Perilla, side view
1perilla,-side-view
This mint, with its square stem, opposite, oval to heart-shaped, toothed, stalked leaves, and especially its reddish color, is hard to miss.
2)Perilla, from above
2perilla,-from-above
The burgundy colored, oval to heart-shaped, toothed, opposite leaves make this plant easy to recognize right away.
Catnip
catnip
Lamiaceae, Mint Family
In season from spring to fall, the newer leaves of spring and early fall are the best.
Wet areas along roads, in ditches and thickets, on disturbed soil, in open woods, and in wet meadows
All of the US, southern Canada, and Alaska, but not Florida
Europe

Look for a branching, medium-sized, upright mint with square stems and opposite leaves, and a grayish cast. The pairs of large, downy, stalked, heart-shaped leaves grow at right angles to those directly above or below them. Terminal racemes bear whorls of small, pale pink, purple-spotted flowers with red anthers, and the 5-lobed calyx is soft and hairy.

Sniff for a minty fragrance.

This branching mint's upright, square stems grow up to three feet tall. The entire plant looks grayish because it's coated everywhere with heavy, whitish down, and all parts are fragrant when injured.

Its large, toothed, downy, heart-shaped, stalked, opposite leaves grow to 1 to 4 inches long and 0.75 to 1.75 inches wide. Each pair grows at right angles to those directly above and below it.

Whorls of bilaterally symmetrical lipped flowers grow on terminal racemes 0.5 to 3.5 inches long and 0.5 to 1.5 inches wide. Pale pink and spotted with purple, each small flower, set inside a soft, hairy, 5-lobed calyx, contains red anthers. The seeds that ripen inside the calyx are small, hard nutlets.

•Branching, fragrant, downy, grayish mint up to three feet tall
•Large, soft, heart-shaped, stalked, opposite leaves
•Each pair of leaves at right angles to those just above and below it
•Terminal racemes with whorls of bilaterally symmetrical pale pink flowers
•Flowers spotted with purple
•Red anthers
•Flower set inside a soft, hairy, 5-lobed calyx
•Tiny nutlets inside mature calyx
Strip off the leaves to use as food, pluck of the flowers to use as a garnish, or cut off the entire plant for tea.
The young leaves make an excellent ingredient in salads, and they're also good as a flavoring for sweet dishes, the same as many other mints. They also make an outstanding tea.
Catnip provides calcium, chromium, iron, magnesium, manganese, phosphorus, potassium, selenium, silicon, and zinc.

An infusion of the whole plant is used to help people sleep, and catnip contains the terpenoid nepetalactone, a mild sedative that gets about half the cats exposed to it high. Other constituents include alpha-humulene, beta-elemene, camphor, carvacrol, caryophyllene, citral, citronellal, geraniol, myrcene, piperitone, pulegone, rosmarinic acid, and thymol.

Catnip's also a diaphoretic, and has been used to help fight colds and flu, as well as measles and other childhood diseases. It also helps calm an unsettled stomach, and has been used to alleviate colic, and for gas and diarrhea. It's been applied externally, as a compress, to black eyes, and used internally and externally for headaches. It's also been used to prevent miscarriage, although this hasn't been tested for safety or effectiveness.

An excellent mosquito repellent in the lab, the musty-smelling essential oil proved completely useless when I tested it in the field. The mosquitoes loved me as much as ever, and cats started following me around too!
Because it affects the uterus and hasn't been tested for safety in pregnancy, pregnant women are better off avoiding this herb.

A cultivated relative with much smaller leaves that's also used for tea but doesn't grow wild in the US, *N. mussinii,* is also called catmint. Other fragrant mints *(Mentha spp.)* with opposite leaves and square stems don't have catnip's gray cast, leaves at right angles to those above and blow them, and the terminal the racemes with whorls of spotted, pale pink flowers.

Stinging nettles have opposite leaves that look a little like catnip's, but they're more narrow, and the plant doesn't branch. The racemes are axillary rather than terminal, they droop, and the nettle's hairs sting!
Catmint, Catswort, Kitty Crack

This European mint gets some cats high and leaves others unaffected, and it also makes a good seasoning and tea for humans. It's a major medicinal plant as well, used for fevers, indigestion, insomnia, headaches, and more.
Stinging Nettles, Catmint
1)Catnip in Flower
1catnip-in-flower

This softly hairy, grayish plant has pairs of heart-shaped, stalked leaves at right angles to those above and below it. Terminal racemes bear whorls of pale pink, spotted flowers emerging from soft, hairy, 5-lobed calyxes.
2)Catnip Flowers
2catnip-flowers
These small, pale pink, spotted flowers, which grow in whorls, emerge from soft, hairy, 5-lobed calyxes.
Lesser Celandine
lesser-celandine
*Ranunculaceae,* the buttercup family

Lesser celandine's leaves and tubers are good to eat when the leaves first appear at the end of winter and very beginning of spring, before it flowers, and the flower buds are good to eat soon after, also in early spring.
Bare, damp ground in low open woods, swamps, floodplains, and near rivers, as well as in wet meadows
Northeastern North America and the Pacific Northwest, but not northern New England
Eurasia, Northern Africa, Western Asia, Caucasus, and Siberia

Look for long-stalked, smooth-edged basal leaves carpeting wet, bare ground in early spring. A broken black stripe often runs from the leaf's base to tip. The solitary, long-stalked, yellow, buttercup-like flower, with 8 to 12 waxy petals, grows up to 1 inch across.

This very invasive spring ephemeral grows from 2 to 6 inches tall, carpeting forest and swamp floors with huge, dense stands. Its succulent, dark green, glossy, smooth-edged, kidney- to heart-shaped, long-stalked leaves grow 0.75 to 1.75 inches across—first basal, then alternate toward the bottom of the stem. A broken black stripe often runs from the leaf base to its tip.

Blooming in early spring, the large, showy, yellow flowers, which grow up to 1 inch wide, look like buttercups with eight to 12 waxy petals. Each solitary flower grows on a tall, slender, delicate stem, towering above the alternate leaves, which are similar to the basal ones. After the petals fall off, a cluster of small, ovoid seeds replaces the flower.

Small, whitish, finger-like tubers grow on the fibrous roots.

•Herbaceous plant 2 to 6 inches tall carpeting bare, wet ground in forests and swamps
•Dark green, smooth-edged, long-stalked, succulent, kidney- to heart-shaped basal leaves
•Alternate leaves on the lower stem similar to the basal leaves
•Broken black strip often present from leaf base to tip
•Showy, long-stalked, solitary, yellow flower with 7 to 12 waxy petals
•Cluster of small, ovoid, whitish seeds replaces flower
Hold bunches of leaves down in one hand and cut off the stems with a pocketknife, or twist them off with your other hand.

The cooked young leaves, stems, tubers, and flower buds are edible, with a somewhat chewy texture. Unfortunately, they're not very flavorful. Chop the leaves and stemsand parboil them 2 minutes before adding them to soups, stews, rice dishes, or curries and cooking them another ten to 15 minutes. You can include the tubers, which are too small to chop, or pickle them or the flower buds, which you also parboil before cooking.

Although non-poisonous raw, for some reason the leaves have an very unpleasant bitter aftertaste in this country, although not in their native range (in addition to first-hand experience here, I've queried other foragers in America and abroad to confirm this strange finding).
The leaves are a good source of vitamin C.

Lesser celandine contains lactones, triterpenoids, tannin, and possibly an acrid substance similar to anemonin. One of the constituents, protoanemonin, may have antibiotic properties, and its saponins may be fungicidal, but they need more testing.

Nevertheless, dried, powdered lesser celandine leaves are mixed with cold cream and applied to hemorrhoids, and to the perineum if torn during childbirth, as an astringent and possible antiseptic. Herbalists claim that it works.

An infusion of the leaves is poured into bathwater for dermatitis and other skin irritations, i.e., rosacea, which usually involves a reddening of the skin of the face.

The plant becomes mildly toxic when it flowers and goes to seed, so use it when it's young.

Herbalists advise pregnant and nursing women to avoid using this herb medicinally. Medicinal use may cause skin irritation or skin sensitivity to sunlight, and it may interfere with prescription medications, but there are no adverse reactions reported when it's used for food.

Marsh marigold, also edible boiled, looks similar, and this robust plant has glossy, rounded to kidney-shaped, long-stalked leaves, plus yellow, stalked flowers. However, it usually grows in water, and the leaves never have black stripes. It has five to nine deep yellow petal-like sepals, and it never creates dense stands that carpet the floors of forests.

Greater celandine *(Chelidonium magus)* also has yellow flowers, but this toxic member of the poppy family never creates mats, the flowers aren't waxy, they don't look like buttercups, and the plant simply doesn't look like lesser celandine—the greatest similarity is in their misleadingly similar names!
Fig Buttercup, Pilewort, Small Celandine

This very common invasive plant carpets wet, bare, forested areas with its yellow flowers in springtime. It's young leaves, stems, tubers, and flower buds are edible cooked, but so bland that you can use them with whatever herbs and spices your imagination can come up with, without worrying about covering up a flavor that's not there!
Marsh Marigold, Greater Celandine
1)Lesser Celandine in Flower
1lesser-celandine-in-flower
Lesser celandine's showy flower, with 8 to 12 waxy petals, grows on top of a slender, long stem. Long-stalked, kidney- to heart-shaped alternate leaves grow toward the bottom of the stem.
2)Lesser Celandine Basal Leaf
2lesser-celandine-basal-leaf
This long-stalked, smooth-edged, kidney-shaped leaf has a broken black stripe running from its base to tip, typical of this plant.
3)Greater Celandine in Flower
3greater-celandine-in-flower
This large, showy flower has 9 waxy, yellow petals surrounding a center that's darker yellow. It grows high above the smooth-edged, heart- to kidney-shaped, long-stalked stem- and basal leaves
Curried Celandine
curried-celandine

Lesser celandine is usually pretty bland, but not anymore. Curry paste, lentils, amaranth, and some delicious vegetables adds everything it’s missing, and the wild plant’s creamy texture complements the other ingredients. Serve with glass noodles or with Indian bread.

14 cups boiling water
1 tbs. red wine vinegar
3 tsp. salt
8 cups lesser young lesser celandine leaves and stems, collected before the plant flowers, or other wild greens, or beet greens, chopped
1-1/4 cup plum tomatoes, sliced
3 small carrots, sliced
1 medium red onion, sliced
1 yellow summer squash, sliced
1/2 cup red dal (small lentils)
1/2 cup raw cashews
2 tbs. amaranth
3-1/2 cups coconut milk
2 tbs. Penang curry paste or curry powder, or to taste
1 tbs. coconut oil

1. Boil the lesser celandine in the water with the vinegar and 2 tsp. of the salt 2 minutes and drain.

2. Combine with the remaining ingredients in an oiled casserole dish

3. Bake covered 1 hour, or until the dal soft.

Serves 6

Preparation time: 30

Cooking time: 60 minutes

Young lesser celandine has glossy, long-stalked kidney- to heart-shaped leaves, often with a broken black stripe running from the leaf base to tip, and small, finger-shaped tubers and fibrous roots.

4)What's in a Name?

5)Foraging Through the Seasons
5foraging-through-the-seasons

While I've provided you with the most accurate info possible about when plants are in season, seasons are relative. Early spring, for example, comes earlier or later in different years, and in different parts of the county, depending on how far north or south you are. That's why I've hedged my bets and avoided giving exact months: such info would often be wrong.

I live in NY, and while I've tried to describe the seasons of plants so they're accurate throughout the East (and much of the rest of the country), seasons will be different in different regions, so adjust your expectations accordingly if you live far north or south from me. And if you live where winters are puny, for example, expect to find cold-weather herbs, greens, and roots that are in season in early spring and late fall in colder regions to be available during the winter too.

Long-range climate change will alter the plants' seasons too. When I began foraging in 1982, plants began coming into season close to a month later at the start of the foraging season as they do as of this writing, in 2011. Fruits that depend on spring flowering time to ripen in autumn are also a month earlier, while cold-weather greens and roots remain in season a month longer, and, politically motivated climate change deniers not withstanding, the best available science projects that such trends will continue or even accelerate.
6)Home on the Range
6home-on-the-range

Here you'll find what's known about what parts of the continent the plant grows. This is compiled by having botanists walk around and note what they see. Since botanists haven't strolled through every part of every state during all the seasons necessary to spot all the plants, and because climate change is shuffling the plants around, this info is approximate. When we add a a social networking component to a future version of this app, you can add to the science of plant distribution with your own observations, comments, and photos!
90)Foraging and Environmental Conservation
90foraging-and-environmental-conservation

It seems as though removing plants from natural habitats would be environmentally destructive, but this ain't necessarily so. Most, but not all wild foods are renewable resources. The faster you pick dandelions, Japanese knotweed, and garlic mustard, the faster they grow back. And mulberry trees aren't going to roll over and die no matter how many berries you eat.

Of course, a few edible wild plants are rare in some locations. Those you should leave alone, or look for them where they're common, when harvesting would be more efficient anyway. If you collect small proportions of common plants where they're common, take only a small fraction, and, with the exception of common root vegetables, leave the roots in the soil to regenerate, so you'll be able to forage for these plants year after year. Using such common sense methods, I've had large groups of people foraging with me in the same places year after year for nearly 3 decades with no environmental impact whatsoever.

The real danger to wild plants is habitat destruction, so take whatever actions you can to support those who are protecting our planet. Indirectly, teaching kids to forage will promote a love of nature and the environment, and lead to more environmental protection in the future. I work with kids all the time, and it's amazing to see what they're capable of. Some of them have even grown up to become school teachers who bring their classes on my tours, and other teach their students about the environment in many other ways as well.
91)Harvesting Wild Plants
91harvesting-wild-plants

This app will give you info on the most practical way to harvest plants most effectively. As a self-taught forager, I've learned from my mistakes, and I've made plenty. I've even poisoned myself, but that was before I became a forager: I grew up on junk food!

Foraging is also easier if you're prepared. Bring appropriate clothing—extra layers and a warm hat, warm socks and gloves if it's cold. Bring plenty of water (or ice water in an insulated container), special clothes that wick away sweat, and a broad-brimmed hat in hot weather. Don't forget a snack or lunch, and a navigation device (compass or GPS) in unfamiliar terrain. Bring plastic bags for veggies and herbs, containers for berries, and work gloves for thorny berries, nettles, and digging

A small, sturdy shovel or trowel is much better than using a stick for roots, but beware of flimsy trowels, those with crimped blades instead of cylindrical shafts, commonly sold for soft garden soil, that break as soon as you try dig in wild soil.
92)Food Preparation
92food-preparation

I've included the best ways of preparing the wild foods, some similar to what you'd do with commercial foods of the same type, some specific for the wild plants. You'll also get my recipes for all the plants I've had been able to collect in quantity. I suffer from a severe case of CCD (compulsive cooking disorder), and find myself continually drawn to the kitchen to experiment with whatever I've brought home. People think of foragers as survivalists, but I got into this field through my interests in food, cooking and science.

I'm also a whole-foods vegan, and by some strange coincidence, so are all my recipes. Vegan and non-vegan tour participants who try them during my tours' lunch breaks always love them, and so will you, if you give them a chance. And just as you'd have to shop in a Japanese store or Mexican store to get unusual ingredients for cooking such cuisines, you may need to go to a health food store for some of the ingredients for vegan recipes. But they work, and the science I've studied has convinced me that they're good for you too.

I certainly don't want to push my ideas about health and nutrition down anyone's throats, but if you're interested in these concepts, check out my Wild Vegan Cookbook, available, signed on my site (please make any purchases there, so the book business doesn't get all your money), at http://www.wildmanstevebrill.com
93)Medicinal Uses
93medicinal-uses
95)Death from Confusion
95death-from-confusion

Yes, you really can die from confusion. People mistaking poke sallet (sallet is an old word for cooked vegetable) for poke salad and ate pokeweed without proper preparation have died from extreme dehydration following severe vomiting and diarrhea.

So check out any factors that might be confusing, in the Similar Plants and Confusing Factors section, where you'll also find descriptions of plants that are similar or related to the main entry, some of which are quite good, and others that are non-poisonous but not good to eat.
94)Pick Your Poison (Just don't eat it!)
94pick-your-poison-just-dont-eat-it!
97)About "Wildman" Steve Brill
97about-wildman-steve-brill
7)Wild (and Not-so-Wild) Habitats
7wild-and-not-so-wild-habitats
8)A Parting of the Parts
8a-parting-of-the-parts

On some plants, only one part is edible, and others are inedible or even toxic. On other plants, different parts, available in different seasons, are good to eat. Sometimes some of these parts are much better than others, other times the different plant parts are equally good. Check out all this info on the plants you're looking for, to make a better choice about what you'd like to do with them.
9)Actively Avoid Poison Ivy
9actively-avoid-poison-ivy

One of the most important things to do if you're going to engage in any outdoor activities is to learn poison ivy as soon as you can. Read the info, look at the pictures, and see if you can spot it. Or if you have friends who can recognize it, have them point it out to you. This will save you and anyone with you lots of itching and scratching!
96)The Future of Your App
96the-future-of-your-app

This app will continue to grow, and you'll get free updates. There will soon be a field where you can add your own notes about where you found the plant, when, how you liked it, or anything that's important to you. We'll also be adding a social networking component, so you can share your foraging experiences with others.

Please feel free to send me suggestions concerning how to improve the app (the personal notes field was from a suggestion of one of my tour participants). I'll take them all into consideration and have my development team implement the ones that we think are the best and most practical.

I hope this app helps put you in touch with our planet, leads you to enjoy its renewable resources, share what you're experiencing with others, and strengthens your resolve to help protect our world's non-renewable riches.

Happy Foraging!

"Wildman" Steve Brill
About WinterRoot
about-winterroot
Minor Plants
minor-plants
Chinese Chestnut
chinese-chestnut

Cultivated and abandoned Chinese chestnut trees grow in residential areas and woodlands throughout the United States. They're hard to tell apart from the native species, although they become full-grown trees, not sickly looking branches arising from stumps. Otherwise, the clearest difference is that American chestnut tree's twigs are hairless, and the other species' are hairy.
1)Chinese Chestnut Tree Leaves and Fruit
1chinese-chestnut-tree-leaves-and-fruit

The very bristly, spherical green fruits of the Chinese chestnut tree are impossible to hold without thick work gloves. The shiny, long, alternate, lance-shaped leaves' edges are sparsely ornamented with sharp, recurved teeth.
2)Chinese Chestnut Open Fruit
2chinese-chestnut-open-fruit
The Chinese chestnut tree's green, spherical, very bristly fruit splits open to reveal several nutshells.
Horse Chestnut
horse-chestnut

Unrelated to the American chestnut, this species contains aesculin, a bitter, poisonous glycoside that breaks down blood proteins. Symptoms include vomiting, loss of coordination, stupor, and occasionally, paralysis, but death is rare.
2)Horse Chestnut Nuts
2horse-chestnut-nuts

These spiky-husked red-brown nuts, each with a large, elliptical, white "eye," look enough like commercial chestnuts that people have no qualms foregoing any effort to verify their identity before poisoning themselves. Fortunately, they reportedly taste so bad that few people manage to eat enough to kill themselves.
1)Horse Chestnut Flowers
1horse-chestnut-flowers
Unlike edible chestnuts, which have simple leaves and inconspicuous flowers borne on catkins, the horse chestnut has palmate-compound leaves, as well as long spikes of large, showy, pink flowers.
Spiderwort
spiderwort

This larger ornamental relative of Asiatic dayflower's flowers and leaves are edible when they're young and tender. When they get old and tough, the only good thing to do with spiderwort is feed it to Spider-man!
2)Spiderwort Flower and Leaves
2spiderwort-flower-and-leaves

Spiderwort has long, smooth, linear leaves, evoking the image of a spider's legs, and a flower with three large, blue petals. Asiatic dayflower, an edible relative, is smaller in all respects. The leaves are much shorter and there are only two large, blue petals on the flower, plus one tiny, translucent petal.
1)Spiderwort in Flower
1spiderwort-in-flower

Spiderwort looks like Asiatic dayflower but larger. Unlike its edible relative, spiderwort's flowers have three large petals rather than two large and one small one, and the tips of its leaves flop over.
Choke Cherry
choke-cherry
These fruits growing on racemes look like black cherries but they're red when ripe, not black, and too astringent to eat without cooking and sweetening.
Choke Cherry Fruits
choke-cherry-fruits
These ripe fruits growing on racemes look like black cherries, but they're red, and the elliptical leaves lack the black cherry's tiny, reddish hairs growing under the midrib.
Pagoda Tree
pagoda-tree

This Asian ornamental tree, also known as the Japanese scholar tree and Japanese pagoda tree, has edible pods and seeds which I haven't gotten to try yet. It grows in landscaped areas such as parks and suburban streets.
Pagoda Tree in Flower
pagoda-tree-in-flower

Its racemes of inedible white flowers and feather-compound leaves resemble those of the black locust, but the leaflets are pointed, not rounded, and it blooms from mid- to late summer, not in the spring.
European Buckthorn
1)European Buckthorn with Berries
1european-buckthorn-with-berries

This poisonous fruit resembles blueberries only superficially, since the smooth berries of this tall shrub lack a crown, while the blueberries and huckleberries have five-parted crown at each berry's tip.
2)European Buckthorn Berries
2european-buckthorn-berries
These spherical blue-black berries lack any openings, setting them apart from blueberries and huckleberries.
Spotted Spurge

The dark marks on the leaves, lack of a row of hair on the stem, and white, milky sap, readily differentiate this superficially similar poisonous plant from chickweed and purslane, as long as you pay attention, since it grows among both edible plants.
5)Spotted Spurge
5spotted-spurge

The dark marks on the leaves, lack of a row of hair on the stem, and white, milky sap, readily differentiate this superficially similar poisonous plant from chickweed and purslane, as long as you pay attention, since it grows among both edible plants.
Scarlet Pimpernel

This small, widespread plant looks like chickweed, but it lacks chickweed's row of tiny hairs on the stem, and it's flower is orange, not white. It's suspected of being poisonous, and may cause rashes if handled. So don't try eating this plant especially if you're French:

They seek him here, they seek him there, Those Frenchies seek him everywhere.

Is he in heaven or is he in hell? That demned elusive Pimpernel.

He meddles with the Frenchie Revolution, Popping in and out each week, Spoiling every lovely execution, La, what cheek!

They seek him here, they seek him there, Those Frenchies seek him everywhere.

If you should see him, please do give a yell! That demned elusive Pimpernel.

They seek him here, they seek him there, Those Frenchies seek him everywhere.

Oh, Pimpy, how the Frenchies do implore you, Simply to stay home in bed.

With all your interference, It's a chore to chop a head!

They seek him here, they seek him there, The ladies seek him everywhere!

He give the Frenchies nothing but frustration. Sink me! He's a spoilsport.

Each and every demned decapitation, He cuts short.

They seek him here, they seek him there, Those Frenchies seek him everywhere.

Is he in heaven or is he in hell? That demned elusive Pimpernel.
(I haven't read the book, but the movie, which I saw decades ago, was especially funny.)
Scarlet Pimpernel
scarlet-pimpernel

This creeping plant, which forms mats, has four-sided stems, and shiny, stalked, bright green, opposite or whorled leaves 0.25 to 1.25 inches long. The small, flat, bright pinkish-orange blossoms grow 0.25 inch wide.
Round Leaf Yellow Violet
round-leaf-yellow-violet1
Avoid all violet species with yellow flowers, such as this round-leaf yellow violet, since they may cause nausea and vomiting.
Round-leaf Yellow Violet
round-leaf-yellow-violet
This native woodland perennial has heart-shaped toothed leaves, all basal, and a bilaterally symmetrical flower, like the common blue violet, but the flower is yellow, not blue.
Common Reed
common-reed

The common reed has long, narrow leaves and grows in dense stands in wetlands, like the cattail, but the leaves aren't all basal: alternate leaves grow on the stem. And the flower head looks like a flag, not a cat's tail.

Contrary to the claims of non-foraging botanist-authors, the tiny amount of food inside the shoot isn't tasty or worth excavating. And getting any small amount of food from the fibrous rhizomes, if you could ever wrench them from the mud an clean them, is nearly impossible.

On the other hand, they're right about the seeds being delicious. The only hitch is that the seeds don't exist! The plant spreads by its roots, and in 3 decades of foraging, I've never once seen the common reed set a single seed. There might have been a rare native species of Phragmites from which one tribe of Native Americans could have [-supposedly] harvested seeds centuries ago, and this might have been noted by a 19th century writer and passed along in the unreliable foraging literature ever since.

So here's my final word of advice on the subject: If you're going to harvest the non-existent seeds, be sure to bring them home riding on your non-existent unicorn!
1)Common Reed Shoot
1common-reed-shoot
The cattail has only basal leaves, while the common reed has alternate leaves growing on the stem.
2)Common Reed Flower Head
2common-reed-flower-head
The cattail has a cylindrical flower head, while the common reed has a raceme that looks like a flag, with tiny flowers.
Dogbane
dogbane
Also known as Indian hemp, Native Americans used the fibers of this plant for making crafts, especially rope, so if you eat it and suffer cardiac arrest, you'll reach the end of your rope!
Dogbane Shoot and Mature Plant
dogbane-shoot-and-mature-plant

The shoots of dogbane (Apocynum cannabinum) closely resemble those of common milkweed. Both have a stout, unbranched stem, opposite leaves, and white, milky sap, but dogbane's stem lack milkweed's tiny hairs, quite apparent under magnification.

When dogbane matures, it branches. Milkweed doesn't, and dogbane's tiny white flowers are completely different from milkweed's large, spherical cluster of pink flowers. The seeds are quite different too. If you're still having trouble telling the two plants apart, there's one distinguishing factor: eating dogbane can lead to cardiac arrest!
Common Winterberry
This poisonous plant, which causes vomiting and diarrhea, has red berries that look a little like the spicebush's berries, but all other features differ.
Common Winterberry
common-winterberry

This toxic shrub has red berries and alternate leaves like the spicebush, but the leaves are toothed, not toothless, and all parts are odorless, the opposite of the spicebush. Also, the winterbush's berries ripen after those of the spicebush are gone.
Woodland Strawberry
woodland-strawberry
This close relative of the common strawberry is very similar and just as good, so foragers can treat both plants identically by eating them as quickly as possible!
Woodland Strawberry
woodland-strawberry1

Woodland strawberries look like common strawberries, only elongated and pointed, and with the seeds protruding from the flesh. Like common strawberries, they come in loose terminal clusters on a long, slender, finely hairy, leafless stem. Each fruit also has its own fruit stalk, plus ten small pointed sepals.
Bitter Dock
bitter-dock
This awful-tasting plant looks a little like its relative, curly dock, but the leaves are broader, the edges aren't very wavy, and the leaves' midribs are reddish.
1)Bitter Dock Basal Leaves
1bitter-dock-basal-leaves

Also called broad-leaf dock, this awful-tasting plant looks a little like its relative, curly dock, but its leaves are broader, the edges aren't very wavy, and the leaves' midribs are reddish. Bitter dock's broad leaves also resemble those of burdock, but burdock's leaves are whitish underneath, it doesn't have a yellow root, and the flowers and seeds are completely different.
2)Bitter Dock Flowers
2bitter-dock-flowers

Bitter dock's ridged, branched stem with many tiny pink flowers looks like curly dock's, but bitter dock's leaves' margins aren't wavy, like curly dock. Also, burdock has completely different flowers from either of these plants.
Iris
iris
1)Iris Shoot
1iris-shoot
Unlike similar edible plants, the iris' shoot is flattened, and its leaves form the letter "V."
2)Iris Flower
2iris-flower
This showy blue flower makes it easy to tell that this is an iris and not a cattail, even though the sword-shaped leaves of the two plants are superficially similar.
False Hellebore
false-hellebore

This native plant of Eastern and Western North America, which grows in swamps and wetlands, has killed people who mistook it for skunk cabbage, a less toxic plant they shouldn't have been trying to use for food in the first place. False hellebore shoots resemble true- and false Solomon's seal only slightly, but it's a species foragers should be aware of.

Symptoms include a burning sensation in the mouth and throat, excessive salivation, cold sweats, headache, nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain and gastrointestinal distress, diarrhea, gas, slow respiration and difficulty breathing, slow and irregular heartbeat, low blood pressure, spasms or convulsions, paralysis, and death. Doctors treat false hellebore poisoning with atropine.
2)False Hellebore Shoots
2false-hellebore-shoots

False hellebore's young, pleated shoots are shaped like the thick crayons toddlers use, whereas Solomon's- and false Solomon's seal smooth shoots are much longer and more slender, like thin pencils. This makes them easy to tell apart so long as you're paying attention.
3)False Hellebore in Flower
3false-hellebore-in-flower
Mature false hellebore has a single, straight erect stem, stalkless, elliptical, alternate leaves, and a terminal panicle of small, yellow-green flowers.
1)Immature and Mature False Hellebore
1immature-and-mature-false-hellebore

False hellebore's stalkless, elliptical, alternate leaves are distinctly pleated, like an accordion. Both the unbranched, erect, immature plant, and the mature version with the addition of a long, loose, branched, terminal panicle of small flowers, are strikingly distinct.
Horse Nettle
horse-nettle1

This nightshade is a thorny plant with coarsely toothed, pointed, oval to lance-shaped leaves, attractive, and five-petaled, white flowers with yellow centers. The smooth, spherical, seedy fruits that are just like little, yellow tomatoes, except for the fact that they cause headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and death!

Unlike ground cherries, the fruit isn't surrounded by a papery husk.
Horse Nettle
horse-nettle

This nightshade is a thorny plant with coarsely toothed, pointed, oval to lance-shaped leaves, attractive, and 5-petaled, white flowers with yellow centers. The smooth, spherical, seedy fruits that are just like little, yellow tomatoes, except for the fact that they cause headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and death!

Unlike ground cherries, the fruit isn't surrounded by a papery husk.
Witch Hazel

Witch hazel is a medicinal plant unrelated to hazelnuts. You can make a decoction from the cambium, to use externally as an astringent, but it injures the shrub, and you can buy a very inexpensive pure extract in any drugstore, so this is one example of foraging I'd advise you to forgo.
2)Witch Hazel
2witch-hazel
Witch hazel's rounded to heart-shaped alternate leaves look like the hazelnuts' but all other features are different.[-, and] The nutlets are small, hard, and without a shell.
1)Witch Hazel in Flower
1witch-hazel-in-flower
This small shrub's modest, yellow flowers stand out again the bare background of late winter, as they bloom before the leaves appear or any other plants become active.
Guilder Rose
This European ornamental shrub resembles the highbush cranberry closely, and although non-poisonous, the berries are unpleasantly bitter to most people.
1)Guilder Rose in Flower
1guilder-rose-in-flower

This European ornamental shrub has opposite, toothed, three-lobed leaves like the highbush cranberry, as well as a similar ring of larger sterile flowers surrounding small, five-petaled fertile flowers. However, this shrub has bowl-shaped glands on the leafstalk, whereas its relative's glands are dome-shaped. And because these features are small, they help me sell magnifying loupes on my foraging tours!
Guilder Rose with Fruit
guilder-rose-with-fruit

Except for the dome-shaped glands on the leafstalk, the ovate red fruit and opposite, three-lobed, toothed, maple-like leaves of this shrub look just like the highbush cranberry, which has bowl-shaped glands.
Linden Viburnum
This edible viburnum has opposite leaves and umbrella-like clusters of red berries, each with one seed, like its relative, the highbush cranberry, but the leaves and fruit are quite different.
Linden Viburnum with Fruit
linden-viburnum-with-fruit

This viburnum, with leaves resembling the unrelated linden tree, has broadly oval to elliptical, coarsely toothed, finely fuzzy, pointed leaves, and small, bright red, showy berries in flat-topped cymes, ripening in the fall. As sour as lemons, there's too little fruit and too large a seed for practical food use here, but kids who love sour flavors enjoy it as a trail nibble.
Giant Knotweed Shoot
Giant knotweed is less common than Japanese knotweed, but very similar, only larger. You can use both plants the same way.
Giant Knotweed
giant-knotweed

Giant knotweed has a green stem with joints and sheaths, and it's flecked with red, just like Japanese knotweed. The main difference is that it's large and much less common. But the flavor and food uses of both plants are identical.
Pennsylvania Smartweed
This related plant looks like lady's thumb, but it's bigger. Too acrid to eat, there's only one good thing to do with Pennsylvania smartweed—send it back to Pennsylvania!
Pennsylvania Smartweed
pennsylvania-smartweed

Also known as pinkweed, pink knotweed, and smartweed, this erect or sprawling annual, which grows from one to five feet tall, has lance-shaped leaves, each attached to a node on the stem by a membranous sheath, but without the fringe of hairs of the smaller lady's thumb.
Orache

This salt-loving plant looks a little lamb's-quarters, and some foraging authors praise the its salty flavor, but I always find it to have a very unpleasantly bitter aftertaste, and rate it very low as an "edible" species. Perhaps other species in the genus are better, or I'll taste orache from other regions in the country and change my mind in the future.
Orache
orache

This salt-loving plant grows near the seashore, and in salty, alkaline soil throughout the country. It looks a little like lamb's-quarters, but it leaves are arrow-shaped instead of diamond-shaped, and the flowers are whitish instead of green.
Chamomile

Closely related to pineapple weed but larger, chamomile has white ray flowers, which pineapple weed lacks. Chamomile also has larger central disk and it's yellow, not yellow-green like its smaller relative. Nevertheless, you can use the two plants the same way.
1)Chamomile Stand in Flower
1chamomile-stand-in-flower
Chamomile is much taller than pineapple weed, and it has white rays that chamomile lacks, plus a larger yellow disk rather than a yellow-green one.
2)Chamomile Flowers
2chamomile-flowers

Chamomile's daisy-like flowers are quite different from pineapple weed's. It has white ray flowers that pineapple weed lacks, and a large, yellow disk, rather than the small, button-shaped yellow-green disk of pineapple weed.
Greater Ragweed
greater-ragweed
This inedible, wind-pollinated foreign plant is notorious for its allergy-provoking pollen.
Greater Ragweed
greater-ragweed1

Greater ragweed has panicles with green seeds that resemble poor man's pepper's, but the seeds and green flowers are unevenly spherical, not flat. And that's where the resemblance ends. The large, palm-like leaves, which feel like sandpaper, are nothing like poor man's pepper's lance-shaped, toothed leaves. And greater ragweed is a much larger plant.
Spotted Spurge
This plant, which sometimes grows along with edible chickweed, contains an acrid, white sap. Don't carelessly bag this toxic species along with your dinner!
Spotted Spurge
spotted-spurge

This creeping plant, with its wiry stem, elliptical, spotted leaves, white flowers, and sickly-looking white sap, often grows right along with purslane and chickweed, which it doesn't really resemble.
Wall Rocket
wall-rocket

Wall rocket is an erect, branching mustard that grows up to 1.5 feet tall. Its fleshy, alternate, lobed or unlobed leaves look a little like sea rocket, and the spicy young leaves, tender young stems, and flowers are exceptionally delicious. However, its four-petaled flowers are yellow, its seed capsules are long, straight, and narrow seeds capsules, quite different from sea rocket.
Wall Rocket in Flower
wall-rocket-in-flower

This plant's usually branching stem have lance-shaped leaves that are usually lobed, and a terminal raceme of yellow, four-petaled flowers. I found itplant growing in a sandy field near the seashore only once, before it was eradicated forever by mowers, but I'd love to come across it again. It's really tasty!
Field Bindweed
This non-poisonous relative of morning glory (Ipomoea spp.) is not edible.
Field Bindweed
field-bindweed

Field bindweed's arrow-shaped leaves might make people confuse it with sheep sorrel, but field bindweed is a vine, not an upright plant, and it has a large, white, funnel-shaped flower, completely different from sheep sorrel's.
Starry False Solomon's Seal
starry-false-solomons-seal

This edible relative of False Solomon's seal, which grows in the sandy habitat of the seashore, as well as in moist meadows, has more narrow leaves than false Solomon's seal, and the rhizome doesn't have prominent seal-like scars.
Starry False Solomon's Seal
starry-false-solomons-seal1

This subspecies of False Solomon's seal, which grows in the sandy habitat of the seashore, as well as in moist meadows, has more narrow leaves than false Solomon's seal, and the rhizome doesn't have prominent seal-like scars. Nonetheless, the two plants are considered the same species because they're genetically similar enough to interbreed in nature. And they're both equally edible.
Clearweed

Also know as Canadian clearweed, coolwort, and richweed, this erect, colonial annual of Eastern North America has oval to elliptical toothed leaves with distinctly depressed veins. People confuse it with stinging nettles, which doesn't have such veins and lack's clearweed's translucent stems. Also, clearweed doesn't sting. And while it's not a food, it's also nonpoisonous.
Clearweed
clearweed
With long-stalked, oval, toothed leaves, this non-poisonous plant resembles stinging nettles with 2 major differences—no stingers, and no flavor!
Clearweed
clearweed1

Clearweed's toothed, elliptical, opposite leaves make it look like stinging nettles, but the translucent stem and lack of stinging hairs set this inedible plant apart.
Nevertheless, when I tried to enlighten a troop of boy scouts who had been forcing themselves to eat these awful-tasting non-stinging nettles for years, they found it necessary to deny my expertise and continue eating it so they wouldn't have to admit their mistake, and I think they're still out in the woods, chowing down on it, to this very day!
Virginia Creeper
virginia-creeper

People confuse this toxic species with wild grapes, even though the leaves are completely different, and Virginia creeper has much smaller berries. Eating them can cause nausea, abdominal pain, bloody vomiting and diarrhea, dilated pupils, headache, drowsiness, profuse sweating, weak pulse, drowsiness, twitching of face, and sometimes death. Even touching the autumn foliage can give some people a rash.

The best thing to do with Virginia creeper is send it back to Virginia!
Virginia Creeper
virginia-creeper1
Virginia creeper will develop poisonous berries that look a little like tiny grapes, but instead of a leaf that looks like a maple- or grape leaf it has a five-parted, palmate-compound leaf.
Wild Apricots
This relative of the peach is better-tasting than the commercial apricot, and unlike wild peaches, it's not especially susceptible to insect infestation.
Wild Apricots
wild-apricots
This relative of the peach has broad, pointed, toothed, alternate, wedge-shaped leaves, and a smooth fruit that's smaller than a peach, but also with a shallow groove.
Hobblebush
This shrub resembles other edible viburnums, such as the black haw, and although its berries are edible too, they're quite small.
1)Hobblebush in Flower
1hobblebush-in-flower

The hobblebush has broad, oval to heart-shaped, stalked, toothed, opposite, simple leaves, and terminal flower cymes. A circle of large, sterile five-petaled white flowers surrounds the smaller, central, five-petaled, fertile flowers.
2)Hobblebush Flowers and Leaves
2hobblebush-flowers-and-leaves

The hobblebush has long-pointed, broadly elliptical, finely toothed, opposite leaves. The showy terminal cymes of five-petaled white flowers, growing above the leaves, are unusual: a large ring of sterile flowers attracts pollinators to the smaller, fertile flowers in the center.
Siebold Viburnum
siebold-viburnum

This shrub looks a little like its edible relative, the black haw. The sweet black berries, which ripen in autumn, each contains one seed. But the berries are so much smaller than black haws that the bush provides no more than a tasty trail nibble.
Siebold Viburnum in Flower
siebold-viburnum-in-flower

Like all viburnums, the seibold viburnum has opposite, simple leaves, but here the teeth are relatively large and well-defined, and the veins are especially prominent. The small, white, 5-petaled flowers grow on a relatively large, showy cyme, with more branches than most viburnums.
White Snakeroot

This deadly plant killed many American pioneers after their cows, which weren't kept in pastures, wandered in the woods, nibbled on its leaves, and poisoned the milk. The condition was called milk sickness. It blocks the brain from signaling the lungs to breath and the heart to beat, leading to death by respiratory failure and cardiac arrest. It killed Abraham Lincoln's mother. Nevertheless there's one person immune to its effects: George W. Bush—he has no brain!
White Snakeroot
white-snakeroot

This deadly plant has long-stalked, coarsely toothed, oval, opposite leaves growing on an erect, unbranched stem like wood nettles. But it has a terminal umbrella-like cluster of white flowers, not a pendant raceme of tiny green-white flowers, and it lacks stinging hairs, so the two plants could only be confused through carelessness.
Daffodil
daffodil

This toxic ornamental has long, narrow leaves similar to those any number of edible plants, such, cattails, daylilies, or some of the wild onions. However, it's odorless rather than onion-scented, it lacks the daylily's tubers, and doesn't grow in the water like cattails, and the flowers are different from the others'.
1)Daffodil Shoot and Flower
1daffodil-shoot-and-flower

This poisonous wild and cultivated plant has a large, showy, yellow flower with a distinct, tube-shaped "trumpet," different from any of its edible look-alikes, although the long, narrow leaves could fool someone who doesn't check for other features that differ from those of similar edibles.
2)Daffodil in Flower
2daffodil-in-flower
Once the daffodil's showy flowers appear, there's no possibility of confusing it with narrow-leaves edibles. Its tube-shaped "trumpet" is distinct form in the plant world.
Star of Bethlehem
star-of-bethlehem
1)Star of Bethlehem Leaf and Flowers
1star-of-bethlehem-leaf-and-flowers

Star of Bethlehem's long, flat, linear leaf resembles various wild onions', only it has no odor, and there's a stripe running down each leaf's length. And the showy, six-tepaled white flowers resemble no edible plant's flowers.
2)Star of Bethlehem Leaves and Bulb
2star-of-bethlehem-leaves-and-bulb
The bulb of this odorless plant resembles those of edible wild onions, but a white stripe runs down the length of the flat, linear leaves, quite different from the odoriferous onions.
3)Star of Bethlehem Young Leaves
3star-of-bethlehem-young-leaves

This bunch of basal leaves superficially resembles field garlic's, and there are even bulbs underground. However, Star of Bethlehem's leaves are flat, not cylindrical, and a whitish stripe runs down each leaf's length.
4)Star of Bethlehem in Flower
4star-of-bethlehem-in-flower

By the time the 6-tepaled white flowers of star of Bethlehem blooms from the green and white onion-shaped flower buds, the white stripe that runs along the length of each leaf is plainly evident, making it impossible to confuse this plant with anything else.
5)Star of Bethlehem Shoots
5star-of-bethlehem-shoots

Star of Bethlehem's bulbs often become exposed after heavy rains, and while they and the linear leaves resemble various wild onion species, there's no odor, and each leaf has a white stripe running its length.
Hairy Lettuce
hairy-lettuce
Vastly inferior to wild lettuce, hairy lettuce is as bitter-tasting as it's hairy!
Hairy Lettuce Basal Rosette
hairy-lettuce-basal-rosette1
This plant's basal rosettes resemble those of wild lettuce, only the lance-shaped, toothed leaves are noticeably hairy.
Doorweed
doorweed

Doorweed looks a little like chickweed because it often grows along the ground, sometimes along with chickweed, but its leaves are alternate, not opposite, and it can form a basal rosette, which chickweed doesn't. There's no row of hair on the stems, which are are punctuated by joints.

While not poisonous, it's about as good to eat as string. You can cook it, but then it will taste like cooked string.
Doorweed
doorweed1
This plant can grow upright or creep along the ground. Unlike chickweed, it has alternate leaves. The stems lack chickweed's row of hairs, and it doesn't have chickweed's star-like white flowers.
Tiger Lily
tiger-lily
People often confuse the tiger lily with the daylily, and they are related. Fortunately, both plants are edible.
Tiger Lily
tiger-lily1

The tiger lily, which grows in the wild as well as people's gardens, resembles the daylily, but the petals are more yellow than orange, and instead of lines, the tiger lily's petals have spots. Also, the stem has leaves, unlike the daylily's bare stem.
Field Peppergrass
field-peppergrass

Also known as field pepperweed, this spicy edible begins with a basal rosette of toothed leaves, like poor man's pepper, but without teeth that point to the leaf's base, and the stalkless stem leaves are arrow-shaped, setting these two plants apart even further.
Field Peppergrass
field-peppergrass1

This European mustard has a raceme of flowers which forks off from the stem. Its small, white, four-petaled flowers become small, flat, green, oval seedpods without the notch of field pennycress or the triangular shape of shepherd's purse.
Porcelain Berry
porcelain-berry1
Although the fruit of this invasive Asian vine, also called amur peppervine, doesn't look like grapes, the leaves do. Fortunately, people who poison themselves with this plant only get a stomachache.
Porcelain Berry
porcelain-berry2

Also called amur peppervine, this high-climbing vine has leaves similar to grape leaves, and tendrils too, but it isn't woody like grape vines, it has a white pith rather than the brown pith of grape vines, and the gaudy, ripe fruit can be blue, purple, turquoise, or white—quite different from grapes.
Indian Strawberry
indian-strawberry
This Asian strawberry species, which grows in Eastern North America and the West Coast, but not in New England, has a luscious-looking round strawberry that tastes like air!
Indian Strawberry
indian-strawberry1

This round, red, flavorless fruit's seeds that stand out from the surface. The seeds of the common strawberry are inset. Also, the Indian strawberry is different because it has backwards-pointing sepals, plus yellow flowers instead of white ones.
Ailanthus Tree
ailanthus-tree

This fast-growing deciduous tree has spreading branches and large large, feather-compound leaves leaves with 15 to 41 long pointed, toothless leaflets. There's always a terminal leaflet and pairs of leaflets often lobed at their bases. They all smell like rotten peanut butter when crushed.

Large panicles of small, wind-pollinated flowers go from yellow-green to reddish, then brown. The fruit is a samara, like that of maple trees.

Other trees with feather-compound leaves, such as the black locust, black walnut, and butternut, have different leaflets, [-as well as other features that set them apart,] and none of them smells as bad as the ailanthus!
1)Ailanthus Leaves
1ailanthus-leaves

The ailanthus has spreading branches and large large, feather-compound leaves leaves with 15 to 41 long pointed, toothless leaflets. There's always a terminal leaflet, plus pairs of leaflets often lobed at their bases, and they all smell like rotten peanut butter when crushed. Similar trees have different leaflets and unoffensive odors.
2)Ailanthus Tree with Seeds
2ailanthus-tree-with-seeds
Unlike many trees that also have feather-compound leaves, the ailanthus has warty, gray bark, and the fruit's a brown, papery samara that blows away in the wind.
Prickly Lettuce
prickly-lettuce2
Young Prickly Lettuce
young-prickly-lettuce
With large prickles on the undersides of its lobed, alternate leaves' midribs, prickly lettuce is excellent...to avoid! While it's non-poisonous, it's really bitter, even when young.
Yarrow
yarrow

Because of its narrow, feathery leaves and composite flower head, this medicinal plant and beverage is easy to recognize, and to distinguish from the wild carrot and its relatives.

A tea of the above-ground parts of this plant is a diaphoretic, taken for fever, and a compress, which is astringent. It's been used to stop bleeding since the days of the legendary warrior Achilles, accounting for the generic name.
1)Yarrow in Flower
1yarrow-in-flower1

This plant has a single stem with narrow, fern-like, alternate leaves, quite different from the wild carrot's feather-compound leaves. And the flowers grow clustered at the top of the stem. What look like individual flowers are composites of many tiny central disk flowers surrounded by five ray flowers.
2)Yarrow Basal Leaves
2yarrow-basal-leaves1
Yarrow's feathery basal leaves look a little like wild carrots', since they're finely divided, but the fragrant leaves of this medicinal plant are much more narrow and not branched.
3)Yarrow Flower Head
3yarrow-flower-head
Yarrow's composite flower head consists of tightly clustered tiny individual florets, each with a yellowish disk and white rays, unlike Queen Anne's Laces' much simpler five-petaled flowers.
Chokeberries
chokeberries
1)Chokeberries
1chokeberries
2)Red Chokeberry in Flower
2red-chokeberry-in-flower
This shrub's five-petaled, radially symmetrical, white flower is a far cry from the bell-shaped flowers of blueberries and huckleberries.
3)Black Chokeberry with Fruit
3black-chokeberry-with-fruit

The black chokeberry's cluster of spherical, long-stalked fruit has an impressed five-parted crown, rather than the flaring crown of blueberries and huckleberries. This fruit is so astringent, it will make you want to choke yourself, although the extracted juice is drinkable.
Northern Mountain Ash
northern-mountain-ash
This native bush, also called the showy mountain-ash, grows in Northeastern North America and the Midwest. It has edible berries you use the same as the American mountain ash.
Northern Mountain Ash Berries and Leaf
northern-mountain-ash-berries-and-leaf

Very similar to American mountain ash and used the same way, the feather-compound leaf (which is alternate) has around 15 arched, finely-toothed, pointed, lance-shaped leaflets. It has small, spherical berries grow in branching clusters, and unlike the American mountain ash, its berries are bright red instead of orange, a little hard to see in a black-and-white drawing!
Cocklebur
cocklebur

Cockleburs have burrs like burdock, but the burrs grow spirally. Also, cocklebur leaves aren't whitish underneath. Since you don't eat burdock when it has burrs, I doubt anyone has ever been poisoned by confusing the two, but you should be aware that burdock isn't the only plant in the world with large burrs.
Common Cocklebur
common-cocklebur
This common species, (X. strumarium), also called rough cocklebur, clotbur, large cocklebur, and woolgarie bur, has burrs like, but doesn't have burdock's whitish taproot or magenta composite flower.
Swamp Blue Violet
swamp-blue-violet
Growing in wetlands, this is one of very many edible violet species that populate the US.
Swamp Blue Violet in Flower
swamp-blue-violet-in-flower
The blue flower of this relative of the common blue violet is much taller than the heart-shaped leaves—a major difference between these two edible species.
Callery Pear
callery-pear

This showy, ornamental cultivated tree's white, five-petaled, radially symmetrical flowers bloom early in spring, before the leaves appear, making it a favorite among horticulturalists, who plant it on streets. The small pears are quite tasty when they ripen and get soft in late fall. Cooked, sweetened, and strained, they make a delicious pear sauce.
1)Callery Pear in Flower
1callery-pear-in-flower
2)Callery Pear Flowers
2callery-pear-flowers

The callery pear has thick twigs and medium-sized, heart-shaped, toothed, alternate leaves. The showy, flat-topped clusters of large, cream-white flowers have many long stamens surrounding the pistils, which form a central button.
3)Callery Pear Fruit
3callery-pear-fruit

These pears are much smaller than commercial pears but quite good at this stage, in late fall, when they become soft and sweet like pear sauce. You can tell they're soft because a few have already been squashed.
Henbit Deadnettle
henbit-deadnettle

This low-growing, softly hairy European annual mint has opposite, rounded leaves with lobed margins, square stems, and attractive-looking pink to purple, two-sided flowers. Its musty smell reminds me of an accumulation of dust under the bed, and although people have eaten this plant without ill effects, I don't consider it food.

It superficially resembles garlic mustard and stinging nettles, but unlike garlic mustard, henbit deadnettle has opposite, not alternate leaves, and red, square leafstalks and stems, quite different from garlic mustard, which smells like garlic when crushed

Stinging nettles are covered with stinging hairs, and when you try to crush it, instead of detecting a musty odor, you get stung!
Henbit Deadnettle Rosette
henbit-deadnettle-rosette

At this stage, this awful smelling and tasting plant, with its basal rosette of heart-shaped leaves, superficially looks like garlic mustard but the stem is square and red, unlike garlic mustard's rounder stem. Also, garlic mustard smells like garlic when you crush it.
Henbit Deadnettle in Flower
henbit-deadnettle-in-flower

Henbit deadnettle, with its hairy, lobed, roundish to oval leaves, doesn't resemble stinging nettles or garlic mustard when its showy, pink, bilaterally symmetrical flowers bloom. Those plants have completely different flowers.
Arrowhead
arrowhead

Also called wapatoo, duck potato, swan potato, and tule potato, this plant grows in the Mid-Atlantic states, the Midwest, and the Deep South. It's the same plant sold powdered as arrowroot and used as a culinary thickener.

You can cook the tubers of the wild plant, but it definitely ranks among the most difficult wild foods to harvest. You have to remove the tubers from the mud under lakes during root season, in late fall or early spring, when the water is ice-cold. It can be done, but I wasn't successful in loosening any tubers before the extremely cold water drove me back to dry land!

Other similar Sagittaria species are equally edible and just as difficult to harvest.
1)Arrowhead Leaf
1arrowhead-leaf
Arrowhead's arrow-shaped leaf looks like an arrow and, unlike pickerelweed which looks similar, it has a clear midrib and pointed lobes.
2)Arrowhead Fruit
2arrowhead-fruit
This aquatic plant has spherical, green fruits growing on its stem.
